FOREWORD

前言

Great sages of history have been ill-served in the preservation of their wisdom. The best of these saints and savants—ancient Hindu and Jewish holy men, the Buddha, Confucius, Socrates, Jesus Christ, the Prophet Mohammed—left few significant writings. Their truths were unfolded in profound discourses and sagacious dialogues—oral expositions transmitted to us in incomplete renderings. Thus, only some of the verities are known; many have been lost. Those who seek the complete scheme, as originally presented, have to depend on unreliable intermediaries such as faith, interpretation, interpolation, and reconstruction.

历史上伟大的圣贤们在保存其智慧方面一直做得不够好。这些圣贤中最杰出的人物——古代印度教和犹太教的圣人、佛陀、孔子、苏格拉底、耶稣基督、先知穆罕默德——留下的重要著作寥寥无几。他们的真理是通过深刻的论述和睿智的对话来阐述的——这些口头传述往往以不完整的形式流传至今。因此，我们所知的真理只有一部分，许多已经失传。那些想要探寻其最初完整面貌的人，不得不依赖信仰、诠释、推断和重构等不可靠的媒介。

As we move closer to our time, this problem is inverted. Knowledge overtakes wisdom and culture surrenders to technology. Recordings are comprehensive, but what is recorded is often of lesser value. There is, it seems, a shortage of authentic sages. By the numbers there are plenty who purvey wisdom and pseudo-wisdom, teachers claiming to possess and provide transcendent insights. However, very few of them survive the tests that surely define a real spiritual pathfinder—the ability to convey a message that is universal and liberating, nondiscriminating and free of hatred; a message that is capable of disinterested enrichment of minds and lives, and is also within the understanding of everyone. By any or all of these yardsticks, J. Krishnamurti was truly a modern master.

随着我们步入现代，这个问题似乎发生了逆转。知识凌驾于智慧之上，文化向科技屈服。记录浩如烟海，但记录的内容往往价值不高。真正的圣贤似乎难觅踪迹。从数量上看，兜售智慧和伪智慧的人比比皆是，许多老师声称拥有并能传授超凡的洞见。然而，真正能经受住考验、成为精神导师的人寥寥无几——他们必须能够传递一种普世的、解放性的、不带偏见的、无仇恨的信息；一种能够无私地丰富人们心灵和生活，并且人人都能理解的信息。无论从哪个角度衡量，克里希那穆提都是一位真正的现代大师。

Krishnamurti’s entire life was focused on realizing and explaining the human quest. For six decades, until his death in 1986 at the age of ninety, he traveled the world bringing his thoughts to those who would listen. Millions did. His popularity sometimes fluctuated, but Krishnamurti persisted in his efforts to “set man absolutely, unconditionally free.” Toward the end of his life, new generations—children of our technetronic age—rediscovered Krishnamurti. In an era of hot shots and holy rollers, razzle-dazzle religion and pulpit rap, he retained the aura of an old-fashioned prophet. Philosophic fads came and went; Krishnamurti endured.

克里希那穆提毕生致力于理解和阐释人类的终极追求。在长达六十年的时间里，直到1986年去世，享年九十岁，他周游世界，将自己的思想传播给所有愿意倾听的人。数以百万计的人聆听了他的教诲。他的声望有时起伏不定，但他始终坚持不懈地努力“使人类获得绝对的、无条件的自由”。在他生命的最后阶段，新一代——我们这个科技时代的孩子们——重新发现了克里希那穆提。在这个充斥着哗众取宠之徒和狂热信徒、浮夸的宗教仪式和说唱布道的时代，他依然保持着一位老派先知的风范。哲学潮流来来去去，而克里希那穆提却经久不衰。

There are two reasons for this apparent timelessness. The most obvious is, of course, the personality of Krishnamurti. His public persona radiated a kind of undemonstrative charisma, the attraction of luminous restraint. Add to this a speaking manner and tone that could evoke a personal intimacy in the midst of even the largest audiences. It is not surprising that the writer Aldous Huxley, no slouch when it came to critical observation, declaimed: “It was like listening to a discourse of the Buddha—such power, such intrinsic authority.”

这种永恒魅力有两个原因。最显而易见的当然是克里希那穆提的个人魅力。他散发着一种内敛的魅力，一种内敛而又不失光彩的吸引力。此外，他说话的方式和语调即使在最大的听众面前也能营造出一种亲切感。难怪以敏锐的观察力著称的作家奥尔德斯·赫胥黎会赞叹道：“这就像在聆听佛陀的教诲——如此强大的力量，如此内在的权威。”

Yet, in the end, personality alone is an unsatisfactory explanation. Many who did not see or hear Krishnamurti were and still are drawn to his thoughts. So, to appreciate the appeal we must go to the philosophic source—the ideas he articulated and their main themes. A careful examination of this body of work will reveal both consistency and changes. While certain central concepts remain fundamental, Krishnamurti did not hesitate to adapt and evolve to new historical circumstances and spiritual quests.

然而，归根结底，仅凭个人魅力不足以解释一切。许多未曾亲眼见过或亲耳听过克里希那穆提的人，过去和现在都深受他的思想吸引。因此，要理解其魅力所在，我们必须追溯到哲学根源——他阐述的思想及其核心主题。仔细研读他的著作，便会发现其中既有连贯性，也有变化。尽管某些核心概念始终不变，克里希那穆提也毫不犹豫地根据新的历史环境和精神追求进行调整和发展。

Again and again, Krishnamurti declared that people do not need guidance, they need awakening. This high confidence in human potential was rooted in the belief that each individual has no limit on development, if he can eschew the cultural barnacles that load his being: “A theory based on another man’s experience in matters of the psyche or of an inward life has no meaning at all. ... We have to let it go completely because we have to stand alone.” With this denial of the transferability of experience and the rejection of all spiritual guidance, including his own, Krishnamurti breaks with most world religions—all of which have spiritual paradigms and instructors whose examples we can emulate. It was not his purpose to attack other faiths, but he frequently warns against the misleading power of religions, institutions, and rituals—and above all, the divisiveness of sectarianism.

克里希那穆提反复宣称，人们需要的不是指导，而是觉醒。他对人类潜能的高度自信源于这样的信念：只要能够摆脱束缚自身存在的文化桎梏，每个人的发展就没有极限。“基于他人心理或内在生活经验的理论毫无意义……我们必须彻底放下它，因为我们必须独立自主。” 克里希那穆提否定经验的可复制性，并拒绝一切精神指导（包括他自己的指导），这使他与大多数世界宗教决裂——而这些宗教都拥有可供我们效仿的精神范式和导师。他的目的并非攻击其他信仰，但他经常警告人们警惕宗教、机构和仪式的误导性力量，尤其要警惕宗派主义的分裂性。

As the years passed, Krishnamurti’s philosophic and intellectual membranes expanded beyond his core themes. Increasingly, we see him addressing the evils of civil and religious power, the futility of existing social structures, the inertia of conformity, and the failure of temporizing reform. By the mid-1950s, Krishnamurti had developed notions about education, human relations, and communications that are not found in his earlier discourses. The teacher was also learning—not only answering the questions of others but also extending his own questions. Yet, the range of his expositions grows to embrace a number of new concerns—nationalism, war, ecological despoliation, unemployment, and hunger. With an almost contemporary sensitivity, social issues that were once on the periphery of his perceptions come closer to center stage. References to the significance of meditation become more frequent. A note of impatience, an urgency, begins to surface. Krishnamurti senses the peril of the times and the compelling demand for action. As if to respond in style as well as substance, his talks become more focused and his dialogues less elliptical. And yet, the essential message is unchanged: “When one sees life as it is, when one sees oneself as one is, [only] from there can one move [ahead].”

随着岁月的流逝，克里希那穆提的哲学和思想疆界超越了他最初的核心主题。我们越来越看到他探讨世俗和宗教权力的弊端、现有社会结构的徒劳无功、墨守成规的惰性以及治标不治本的改革的失败。到了20世纪50年代中期，克里希那穆提发展出了关于教育、人际关系和沟通的理念，这些理念在他早期的论述中并未出现。这位教师同时也在学习——他不仅回答他人的问题，也不断拓展自己的思考。然而，他的论述范围不断扩大，涵盖了一系列新的关注点——民族主义、战争、生态破坏、失业和饥饿。他以一种近乎当代人的敏锐度，将那些曾经处于他视野边缘的社会问题推到了中心位置。他对冥想重要性的提及也更加频繁。一种不耐烦和紧迫感开始浮现。克里希那穆提感受到了时代的危机和采取行动的迫切需求。仿佛为了在风格和实质上都做出回应，他的讲话变得更加集中，对话也不再那么晦涩难懂。然而，其核心信息却始终未变：“只有当一个人看清生活的本来面目，看清自己的本来面目，才能从那里继续前进。”

Of all the sages and significant spiritual figures of modern times, Krishnamurti has had the longest exposure—about sixty-five years on the stage of eminence. Yet, it is difficult to assess his historical stature. He is too close to us and it is too early to know the full effect of his teachings. After all, for several decades subsequent to his crucifixion, there was little sign that Jesus Christ would make a major mark on history. At the moment of their death and for quite some time after, who could have predicted the long-term influence of the Buddha, Confucius, or even Karl Marx? If Krishnamurti’s ideas become more widely accepted in the future, it will be because they resonate with the yearnings of people—because they speak intently to individuals disillusioned with all-knowing and socially transforming macroideologies. Should this outcome take place, it will be because Krishnamurti’s discourses resonate across boundaries of time and place. His voice is silent but its message never ceases to speak.

在近代所有圣贤和重要的精神领袖中，克里希那穆提的影响力最为深远——他已在世人面前活跃了约六十五年。然而，要评估他的历史地位却并非易事。他与我们如此亲近，而要全面了解他的教义的影响还为时尚早。毕竟，在他被钉十字架后的几十年里，几乎没有任何迹象表明耶稣基督会在历史上留下如此重要的印记。在佛陀、孔子，甚至是卡尔·马克思去世的那一刻以及之后的相当长一段时间里，又有谁能够预料到他们会产生如此深远的影响呢？如果克里希那穆提的思想在未来能够被更广泛地接受，那是因为它们与人们的渴望产生了共鸣——因为它们能够精准地触动那些对无所不知、能够改变社会的宏观意识形态感到失望的人们。如果这种情况真的发生，那是因为克里希那穆提的言论超越了时间和空间的界限，引起了人们的共鸣。他的声音虽然沉默，但他的信息却从未停止传递。

Ralph Buultjens, Ph.D.

拉尔夫·布尔特延斯博士

Professor of Social Sciences, New York University,

纽约大学社会科学教授

former Nehru Professor at Cambridge University, U.K.

英国剑桥大学前尼赫鲁教授

#↩

PREFACE

前言

From obscure beginnings in a small town in India, Krishnamurti emerged as an uncompromising and unclassifiable teacher, whose talks and writings were not linked to any specific religion and were neither of the East nor the West but for the whole world.

克里希那穆提出身于印度一个小镇，默默无闻，但他却成为了一位不妥协、难以归类的导师，他的演讲和著作不与任何特定宗教联系在一起，既不属于东方也不属于西方，而是面向全世界。

For some sixty years he spoke to vast audiences in words that were of vital, catalytic relevance to every individual and every society. He had frequent discussions with distinguished writers, philosophers, scientists, educators, and national leaders. With extraordinary immediacy and directness, and without any frameworks or dependencies, he was able to reach the core of problems with which humanity has grappled for centuries.

在长达六十年的时间里，他面向广大听众发表演讲，其言辞对每个人和社会都具有至关重要的启发意义。他经常与杰出的作家、哲学家、科学家、教育家和国家领导人进行交流。他以非凡的敏锐和直率，不拘泥于任何框架或依赖，直击人类几个世纪以来一直苦苦思索的问题的核心。

Krishnamurti’s books have been published all over the world and translated into more than twenty languages. His works are also available on audio and video recordings and electronic disks. Much of this material is now used in over 150 colleges and universities.

克里希那穆提的著作已在全球出版发行，并被翻译成二十多种语言。他的作品还有音频、视频和电子光盘等多种形式。目前，超过150所高校都在使用这些资料。

Faced with this volume of material, we have chosen a broad range of previously published works as well as unpublished ones to give a sense of the depth and breadth of Krishnamurti’s teaching. Readers are, of course, encouraged to look beyond this selection to the whole body of his talks and writings.

面对如此浩瀚的资料，我们精选了一系列已出版和未出版的作品，以展现克里希那穆提教义的深度和广度。当然，我们也鼓励读者在阅读本书之外，进一步探索他的全部演讲和著作。

The full text of “Truth Is a Pathless Land,” the talk which set in motion his break with Theosophy, is included as it embodies the theme that informed his life’s work. The rest of the book has four, more or less chronologically arranged, parts.

本书收录了《真理是一片无路之地》的全文，这篇演讲开启了他与神智学的决裂，因为它体现了他毕生事业的核心主题。本书其余部分大致按时间顺序分为四个部分。

Part 1 contains material from talks given in the years following his dissociation from Theosophy. Part 2 is drawn from accounts of his conversations with various individuals, an early work on education, and the more private Journal and Krishnamurti to Himself .

第一部分收录了他脱离神智学之后几年间所作演讲的资料。第二部分则取材于他与不同人士的对话记录、早期教育著作以及更为私密的《克里希那穆提自述》日记。

Part 3 presents, from records of public meetings, discussions with students and talks with Foundation Trustees, an indication of the great variety of questions that Krishnamurti dealt with during his years of traveling and meeting people.

第三部分通过公开会议记录、与学生的讨论以及与基金会理事的谈话，展现了克里希那穆提在多年旅行和与人会面期间所处理的各种问题。

The final part opens with Krishnamurti’s own statement of The Core of his teaching, followed by talks from the later years, which explore the themes of The Core and recall his earlier declaration of truth as a pathless land that is total freedom, love, and intelligence.

最后一部分以克里希那穆提本人对其教义核心的阐述开篇，随后是他晚年的演讲，探讨了教义核心的主题，并回顾了他早先关于真理是一片没有道路的土地，是完全的自由、爱和智慧的宣言。

Mary Cadogan, Alan Kishbaugh, Mark Lee, Ray McCoy

玛丽·卡多根、艾伦·基什鲍、马克·李、雷·麦考伊

#↩

INTRODUCTION

介绍

When first privileged to meet Krishnamurti, I was deeply struck by the intensity of his quietude. The intensity bespoke great energy and his quietude expressed a settled tranquility. Such a combination is rare; indeed, so rare that on encountering it nothing can be taken for granted.

初次有幸见到克里希那穆提时，我被他那份深沉的静谧深深打动。那份静谧蕴含着巨大的能量，而那份沉静则展现出一种安详的平和。这种特质实属罕见；事实上，如此罕见，以至于一旦遇到，便不敢掉以轻心。

Our meeting was, as we say loosely, accidental. It was in a sound studio. I had neither met him before nor read any of his books. Yet, amazingly, he invited me on the spot to undertake a videotaped dialogue with him. He seemed not in the least concerned that, in the ordinary sense, he did not know me from Adam. I inferred that he was either a great gambler or so attuned to the present instant that his action was exact, a paragon of timeliness. There was something profoundly impersonal in that invitation without his being aloof or indifferent.

我们的相遇，用通俗的话来说，纯属偶然。那是在一个录音棚里。我之前既没见过他，也没读过他的任何作品。然而，令人惊讶的是，他当场邀请我与他进行一段录像对话。他似乎丝毫不在意，从通常意义上讲，他根本不认识我。我推测，他要么是个赌徒，要么就是对当下极其敏感，以至于他的行动精准无比，堪称时机把握的典范。他的邀请中蕴含着某种深刻的客观性，但他并非冷漠或疏离。

The next shock came with his asking me, “What would you like to talk about?” I replied, “How about hearing and seeing?” He accepted the topic joyously. And so immediately began, impromptu, a conversation on inward hearing and inward seeing. Two years later, again utterly unexpectedly, he invited me to undertake a series of dialogues that would encompass the kernel of his teaching. Though years before I had been in radio broadcasting—announcing and newscasting—and so had some professional acquaintance with studio programming, none of that experience was decisive for the movement of the dialogues. They developed without any rehearsal, prearrangement, contrivance, or hands-on fashioning. Both his ease and intensity of focus were amazing.

接下来让我震惊的是，他问我：“你想聊些什么？”我回答说：“听觉和视觉怎么样？”他欣然接受了这个话题。于是，一场关于内听和内视的即兴对话就此展开。两年后，同样出乎意料的是，他邀请我参与一系列对话，这些对话将涵盖他教义的核心。虽然多年前我曾在广播电台工作——担任播音员和新闻播报员——对演播室节目制作有一定的专业了解，但这些经验对对话的进行并无决定性作用。对话的展开没有任何排练、预先安排、刻意安排或人为策划。他轻松自如又专注投入，这都令人叹为观止。

Krishnamurti was an exact embodiment of his doctrine of “choiceless awareness.” Here, the word choiceless might suggest only a mode of subjectivity. On the contrary, choiceless awareness, while reflected in the persona, is in no way reducible to it and so eludes a psychological reduction. Choicelessness is the mind’s equivalent of the silence out of which intelligible utterance arises, of “that emptiness in which the things of the mind can exist but the things are not the mind ... that emptiness has no center and so is capable of infinite movement. Creation is born out of this emptiness but it is not the creation of man putting things together. That creation of emptiness is love and death.” This last sentence points directly and immediately to the character of the instant for both self-awakening and self-misunderstanding. Unless there is a psychological death to our self-identification with memory and upon the same instant a total understanding of need, we remain collapsed into the content of thought and a timely response to the instant eludes us:

克里希那穆提完美地体现了他的“无选择觉知”教义。此处，“无选择”一词或许仅仅暗示了一种主观性模式。然而，无选择觉知虽然体现在人格面具之中，却绝非人格面具所能概括，因此也无法被心理学所还原。无选择是心灵层面的寂静，可理解的言语正是从中产生的，它是“心灵之物得以存在，但事物本身并非心灵的空性……这种空性没有中心，因此能够无限运动。创造源于这种空性，但并非人类将事物组合而成的创造。这种空性的创造即是爱与死。”最后这句话直接而直接地指出了瞬间的本质，即自我觉醒和自我误解。除非我们能够从心理上彻底摆脱对记忆的认同，并在同一瞬间完全理解自身的需求，否则我们将继续沉溺于思维的内容之中，无法对瞬间做出及时的回应。

“When there is a total understanding of need, the outward and the inner, then desire is not a torture. Then it has a quite different meaning, a significance far beyond the content of thought and it goes beyond feeling, with its emotions, myths and illusions. With the total understanding of need, not the mere quantity or the quality of it, desire then is a flame and not a torture. Without this flame life itself is lost. It is this flame that burns away the pettiness of its object, the frontiers, the fences that have been imposed upon it. Then call it by whatever name you will, love, death, beauty. Then it is there without an end.”

“当对需求——包括外在和内在的需求——有完全的理解时，欲望便不再是一种折磨。那时，它便有了截然不同的意义，一种远超思想内容、超越情感、超越迷思和幻觉的意义。当对需求——而非仅仅关注其数量或性质——有完全的理解时，欲望便成为一团火焰，而非折磨。没有这团火焰，生命本身便会消逝。正是这团火焰，烧尽了欲望对象的渺小、界限和强加于其上的藩篱。那时，你可以随意称呼它，爱、死亡、美。那时，它将永无止境。”

Some might think it untoward to begin a short introduction to sagely works with a personal anecdote. One thinks of Krishnamurti’s repeated caution to his audiences: “The speaker is unimportant.” Then there is Chuang Tzu’s: “The Perfect man has no self; the Holy man has no merit; the Sage has no fame.” (All three being the same.) True enough and almost never pondered, let alone embodied. Yet to find in such words an invitation to ignore the personal presence of a great teacher (whether in the flesh or remembered) betrays a shallow readiness to try to go beyond where one has not begun. Krishnamurti admonishes us that “Meditation is not something different from daily life ... it is the seeing of what is and going beyond it.” If one has not seen what is , how can one go beyond it?

有些人或许会觉得，以个人轶事作为对圣贤著作的简短介绍并不妥当。人们会想起克里希那穆提反复告诫听众：“演讲者并不重要。”还有庄子的话：“至善无我，圣者无功德，圣人无名。”（三者实为一体。）这固然没错，但几乎无人深思，更遑论付诸实践。然而，若从这些话语中解读出一种忽略伟大导师（无论其身在何处，亦或仅存在于记忆之中）的邀请，则暴露出一种肤浅的渴望，即试图超越自己尚未涉足的领域。克里希那穆提告诫我们：“冥想并非与日常生活截然不同……它是看清事物的本来面目，并超越它。”如果一个人连事物的本来面目都未曾看清，又怎能超越它呢？

Unfortunately, academic practice shows little or no understanding of “seeing what is ” in the context of genuine self-inquiry. Rather, academic life is a journey through the forest of abstractions. Experimental science has the advantage of requiring laboratory demonstration of its theoretical conclusions. Even so, this procedure is pursued within the dual structure of perceiver and perceived. Perception without the perceiver, as in meditation, is unheard of:

遗憾的是，学术实践对在真正的自我探究语境下“看清事物本质”几乎一无所知。相反，学术生活更像是一场穿越抽象森林的旅程。实验科学的优势在于它要求通过实验室验证其理论结论。即便如此，这一过程仍然是在感知者与被感知者二元结构中进行的。脱离感知者的感知，例如冥想，是闻所未闻的。

“This perception is entirely different from seeing an object without an observer, because in the perception of meditation there is no object and therefore no experience. What meaning has such meditation? There is no meaning; there is no utility. But in that meditation there is a movement of great ecstasy. It is the ecstasy which gives to the eye, to the brain, and to the heart the quality of innocency. Without seeing life as something totally new, it is a routine, a boredom, a meaningless affair. So meditation is of the greatest importance. It opens the door to the incalculable, to the measureless.”

这种感知与在没有观察者的情况下感知物体截然不同，因为在冥想的感知中没有物体，因此也没有体验。这样的冥想有何意义？没有意义，也没有效用。但在这种冥想中，有一种极大的狂喜。正是这种狂喜赋予眼睛、大脑和心灵一种纯真无邪的特质。如果不能将生活视为全新的事物，它就只是例行公事、枯燥乏味、毫无意义的事情。因此，冥想至关重要。它开启了通往不可估量、无边无际之境的大门。

This ecstatic pointer of Krishnamurti’s so escapes our contemporary mind-set as to be practically unintelligible. Yet it is supremely intelligent. How so? Because it implies a radical distinction between consciousness and awareness. In our time, philosophy and depth psychology have virtually absolutized consciousness. They fail to discern that consciousness is not self-correcting. How can it be so since consciousness is ever tied to change? It is only as awareness has an object that consciousness comes into play. In itself awareness is both independent of objects and changeless. On that account it is the door to the incalculable and measureless.

克里希那穆提这番令人欣喜的指引，如此超脱于我们当代的思维模式，以至于几乎难以理解。然而，它却蕴含着至高无上的智慧。为何如此？因为它暗示了意识与觉知之间根本的区别。在当今时代，哲学和深度心理学几乎将意识绝对化。它们未能辨别出意识并非自我修正的。既然意识始终与变化相连，又怎能自我修正呢？只有当觉知有了对象时，意识才得以发挥作用。觉知本身既独立于对象，又永恒不变。正因如此，它才是通往不可估量、无边无际之境的大门。

Krishnamurti invites us to begin the most radical self-inquiry since it opens out upon the infinite space of awareness. Self-inquiry begins by asking not what am I but what am I not? Such a no-nonsense question has no need of theoretical structures, the conceptual paraphernalia of our depth psychologies, philosophies, and theologies and belief systems. The question is astonishingly yet frighteningly simple; frightening because it entails the deepest sense of aloneness, since none but oneself can ask the question nor answer it. Yet, with the patience, courage, and radical trust to hang in there without bolting from it one discovers the unlonely aloneness of that “meditation which is absolutely no effort, no achievement, no thinking, the brain is quiet, not made quiet by will, by intention, by conclusion and all that nonsense; it is quiet. And, being quiet, it has infinite space.”

克里希那穆提邀请我们开启最彻底的自我探寻，因为它开启了通往无限意识空间的大门。自我探寻始于追问：我不是“我是什么”，而是“我不是什么？”这样一个直截了当的问题无需任何理论框架，也无需我们深度心理学、哲学、神学和信仰体系中那些概念性的附属品。这个问题简单得令人惊讶，却又令人畏惧；令人畏惧是因为它蕴含着最深层的孤独感，因为除了自己，无人能够提出这个问题，也无人能够回答这个问题。然而，只要拥有耐心、勇气和全然的信任，坚持下去而不逃避，我们就能发现那种“完全无功无业、无思考的冥想”中不孤独的独处，大脑一片寂静，并非由意志、意图、结论以及所有那些无稽之谈所使之寂静；它就是寂静。而正因为寂静，它才拥有无限的空间。

In this short introduction, I have deliberately avoided taking an academic approach to Krishnamurti’s teaching. To have done so would have falsified his spirit and quite missed the mark of his message. He was not concerned with the career of ideas and the ongoing palaver that is believed to express the finest examples of the life of the mind. In his last talk (January 1986) he put the matter cogently and succinctly:

在这篇简短的介绍中，我刻意避免以学术的方式来探讨克里希那穆提的教义。那样做会歪曲他的精神，完全偏离他信息的真谛。他并不关心思想的传播和那些被认为是精神生活最佳体现的无休止的争论。在他最后一次演讲（1986年1月）中，他简洁明了地阐述了这一点：

“It would be useless for you and the speaker to listen to a lot of words, but if we could together take a very long journey, not in terms of time, not in terms of belief or conclusions or theories, but in examining very carefully the way of our lives, fear, uncertainty, insecurity and all the inventions that man has made, including the extraordinary computers. If we take a long journey into this, where are we at the end of two million years? Where are we going, not as some theory, not what some wretched book says, however holy it is, but where are we all going? And where have we begun? They’re both related to each other: where we are going, where we begin. The beginning may be the ending. Don’t agree. Find out.”

“你和演讲者若只是听一大堆废话，毫无意义。但如果我们能一起踏上一段漫长的旅程，这段旅程并非指时间上的流逝，也并非指信仰、结论或理论的堆砌，而是仔细审视我们的生活方式、恐惧、不确定性、不安全感，以及人类的所有发明创造，包括非凡的计算机。如果我们深入探究这一切，两百万年后，我们究竟身处何方？我们究竟要去往何方？并非依据某种理论，也并非依据某本可悲的书籍（无论它多么神圣），而是我们所有人最终的归宿。而我们又从何而来？这两者息息相关：我们要去往何方，我们从何而来。起点或许就是终点。不要轻易认同。去探寻吧。”

Right away, one hears the cry: “How? How find out?!” The very word, how, betrays a belief in the power of process and procedure to produce an effect; and indeed, they do in the material order. But here, the directive to find out addresses a different sphere, the sphere of one’s misrelation to oneself. The attempt to impose upon this disorder any discipline according to a pattern only hardens the misrelation, binding it further to time, belief, conclusions, and theories. There is no how to making a pure act of attention to what is at hand. There is nothing mysterious about this. In fact, in the normal course of daily living we make, perhaps, a few such acts but quickly fall out of them. Why? The answer to that question comes only through self-examination—not through theories of the unconscious or from learned disquisitions on the nature of man. The pure act of attention is spontaneous and free; the hearer and the heard, the perceiver and perceived drop away leaving only listening and seeing. “Only when the mind is blissful, quiet, without any movement of its own, without projection of thought, conscious or unconscious—only then does the eternal come into being.”

立刻，人们便会发出这样的呼喊：“怎么做？怎么才能弄明白？！” “怎么做”这个词本身就暴露出一种对过程和程序能够产生效果的信念；的确，在物质世界里，它们确实能起到作用。但在这里，寻求答案的指令指向的是另一个领域，即人与自身关系错乱的领域。试图按照某种模式将任何规矩强加于这种错乱之上，只会加剧这种错乱，使其进一步受制于时间、信念、结论和理论。我们无法做到纯粹地专注于眼前的事物。这其中并无神秘之处。事实上，在日常生活中，我们或许会做出一些这样的举动，但很快就会放弃。为什么？这个问题的答案只能通过自我反省获得——而不是通过无意识理论或对人性的学术探讨。纯粹的专注是自发的、自由的；听者和被听者、感知者和被感知者都消失了，只剩下聆听和观看。 “只有当心灵处于极乐、平静的状态，没有任何自主的活动，没有任何有意识或无意识的念头投射时，永恒才会存在。”

During this century we have taken in with our mother’s milk the enervating dogma that the hallmarks of human nature are anxiety (angst) and estrangement, a secularized version of the dogma of original sin. But through meditation, as Krishnamurti revealed it, and self-inquiry, one discovers one’s original nature, original innocence and the natural state. Is this, then, the heart of the matter? Yes, since the heart of the matter is a matter of the heart.

在本世纪，我们从小就被灌输了一种令人疲惫的教条：焦虑和疏离是人性的标志，这不过是原罪教条的世俗化版本。但正如克里希那穆提所揭示的，通过冥想和自我探寻，人们可以发现自己的本性、最初的纯真和自然状态。那么，这是否就是问题的核心？是的，因为问题的核心在于内心。

Allan W. Anderson

艾伦·W·安德森

Professor Emeritus of Religious Studies

宗教学荣誉退休教授

San Diego University

圣地亚哥大学

#↩

TRUTH IS A PATHLESS LAND

真理是一片没有路的土地

The Dissolution of the Order of the Star

星辰教团的解散

The Order of the Star in the East was founded in 1911 to proclaim the coming of the World Teacher. Krishnamurti was made Head of the Order. On August 2, 1929, the opening day of the annual Star Camp at Ommen, Holland, Krishnamurti dissolved the Order before three thousand members. This is the full text of the talk he gave on that occasion.

东方之星教团成立于1911年，旨在宣告世界导师的到来。克里希那穆提被任命为教团领袖。1929年8月2日，在荷兰奥门举行的年度星光营开幕当天，克里希那穆提在三千名成员面前宣布解散该教团。以下是他当时演讲的全文。

We are going to discuss this morning the dissolution of the Order of the Star. Many people will be delighted, and others will be rather sad. It is a question neither for rejoicing nor for sadness, because it is inevitable, as I am going to explain.

今天上午我们要讨论星辰会的解散问题。许多人会为此感到高兴，也有人会感到悲伤。但这既非值得庆贺之事，也非值得悲伤之事，因为这是不可避免的，我将在下文中解释。

You may remember the story of how the devil and a friend of his were walking down the street when they saw ahead of them a man stoop down and pick up something from the ground, look at it, and put it away in his pocket. The friend said to the devil, “What did that man pick up?” “He picked up a piece of Truth,” said the devil. “That is a very bad business for you, then,” said his friend. “Oh, not at all,” the devil replied, “I am going to let him organize it.”

你或许还记得这个故事：魔鬼和他的一个朋友走在街上，看到前面一个人弯腰从地上捡起什么东西，看了看，然后放进口袋里。朋友问魔鬼：“那人捡了什么？”魔鬼说：“他捡到了一块真理。”朋友说：“那对你来说可就糟了。”魔鬼回答说：“哦，一点也不糟，我要让他好好整理一下。”

I maintain that Truth is a pathless land, and you cannot approach it by any path whatsoever, by any religion, by any sect. That is my point of view, and I adhere to that absolutely and unconditionally. Truth, being limitless, unconditioned, unapproachable by any path whatsoever, cannot be organized; nor should any organization be formed to lead or to coerce people along any particular path. If you first understand that, then you will see how impossible it is to organize a belief. A belief is purely an individual matter, and you cannot and must not organize it. If you do, it becomes dead, crystalized; it becomes a creed, a sect, a religion, to be imposed on others. This is what everyone throughout the world is attempting to do. Truth is narrowed down and made a plaything for those who are weak, for those who are only momentarily discontented. Truth cannot be brought down; rather, the individual must make the effort to ascend to it. You cannot bring the mountaintop to the valley. If you would attain to the mountaintop you must pass through the valley, climb the steeps, unafraid of the dangerous precipices. You must climb toward the Truth, it cannot be “stepped down” or organized for you. Interest in ideas is mainly sustained by organizations, but organizations only awaken interest from without. Interest, which is not born out of love of Truth for its own sake, but aroused by an organization, is of no value. The organization becomes a framework into which its members can conveniently fit. They no longer strive after Truth or the mountaintop, but rather carve for themselves a convenient niche in which they put themselves, or let the organization place them, and consider that the organization will thereby lead them to Truth.

我认为真理是一片无路之地，任何道路、任何宗教、任何教派都无法通往它。这是我的观点，我绝对且无条件地坚持这一点。真理无限、无条件、任何道路都无法接近，因此无法被组织；也不应该建立任何组织来引导或强迫人们走上任何特定的道路。如果你首先理解了这一点，你就会明白组织一种信仰是多么不可能。信仰纯粹是个人之事，你不能也不应该组织它。如果你这样做，它就会变得僵化、僵化；它会变成一种信条、一个教派、一种宗教，强加于他人。这正是全世界每个人都在试图做的事情。真理被狭隘化，沦为软弱者、那些只是一时不满者的玩物。真理无法被拉下来；相反，每个人都必须努力攀登到它的高度。你无法把山顶搬到山谷里。如果你想登上山巅，就必须穿越山谷，攀登陡峭的山峰，无惧危险的悬崖峭壁。你必须攀登真理，真理无法“下山”或被安排好。人们对思想的兴趣主要由组织维系，但组织只是从外部激发兴趣。并非出于对真理本身的热爱，而是由组织激发的兴趣毫无价值。组织变成了一个框架，成员们可以方便地融入其中。他们不再追求真理或登上山巅，而是为自己开辟一个舒适的角落，把自己安置其中，或者让组织把他们安置其中，并认为组织会因此引领他们走向真理。

So that is the first reason, from my point of view, why the Order of the Star should be dissolved. In spite of this, you will probably form other Orders, you will continue to belong to other organizations searching for Truth. I do not want to belong to any organization of a spiritual kind, please understand this. I would make use of an organization which would take me to London, for example; this is quite a different kind of organization, merely mechanical, like the post or the telegraph. I would use a motorcar or a steamship to travel; these are only physical mechanisms which have nothing whatever to do with spirituality. Again, I maintain that no organization can lead man to spirituality.

所以，在我看来，这是星辰教团应该解散的第一个原因。尽管如此，你们或许还会组建其他教团，继续加入其他寻求真理的组织。我不想加入任何灵性组织，请理解这一点。比如，我会选择能带我去伦敦的组织；这完全是另一种组织，它只是机械性的，就像邮政或电报一样。我会选择汽车或轮船出行；这些都只是物理机制，与灵性毫无关系。再次强调，我坚持认为，没有任何组织能够引导人走向灵性。

If an organization be created for this purpose, it becomes a crutch, a weakness, a bondage, and must cripple the individual, and prevent him from growing, from establishing his uniqueness, which lies in the discovery for himself of that absolute, unconditioned Truth. So that is another reason why I have decided, as I happen to be the Head of the Order, to dissolve it. No one has persuaded me to this decision.

如果为了这个目的而建立一个组织，它就会变成拐杖、弱点和束缚，必然会阻碍个人的成长，阻止他确立自身的独特性——而这种独特性就蕴藏在他自己发现那绝对的、无条件的真理之中。因此，作为该组织的首领，这也是我决定解散它的另一个原因。没有人说服我做出这个决定。

This is no magnificent deed, because I do not want followers, and I mean this. The moment you follow someone you cease to follow Truth. I am not concerned whether you pay attention to what I say or not. I want to do a certain thing in the world and I am going to do it with unwavering concentration. I am concerning myself with only one essential thing: to set man free. I desire to free him from all cages, from all fears, and not to found religions, new sects, nor to establish new theories and new philosophies. Then you will naturally ask me why I go the world over, continually speaking. I will tell you for what reason I do this: not because I desire a following, not because I desire a special group of special disciples. (How men love to be different from their fellowmen, however ridiculous, absurd, and trivial their distinctions may be! I do not want to encourage that absurdity.) I have no disciples, no apostles, either on earth or in the realm of spirituality.

这并非什么了不起的壮举，因为我不需要追随者，我说的就是这个意思。一旦你追随他人，你就不再追随真理。我并不在意你是否关注我的言论。我只想在这个世界上做一件事，而且我会全心全意地去做。我只关注一件至关重要的事：解放人类。我渴望将他们从一切牢笼、一切恐惧中解救出来，而不是创立宗教、新的教派，或是建立新的理论和哲学。那么，你自然会问我，为何我周游世界，不断布道。我会告诉你我这样做的原因：并非因为我渴望追随者，也并非因为我渴望一群特殊的门徒。（人们多么喜欢与众不同，无论这种区别多么荒谬、可笑、微不足道！我不想助长这种荒谬。）无论在尘世还是在灵性领域，我都没有门徒，也没有使徒。

Nor is it the lure of money, nor the desire to live a comfortable life, which attracts me. If I wanted to lead a comfortable life I would not come to a camp or live in a damp country! I am speaking frankly because I want this settled once and for all. I do not want these childish discussions year after year.

吸引我的既不是金钱的诱惑，也不是对舒适生活的渴望。如果我想要过舒适的生活，我就不会来营地，也不会住在潮湿的国家！我坦诚相待，是因为我希望这件事能彻底解决。我不想年复一年地进行这种幼稚的争论。

One newspaper reporter, who interviewed me, considered it a magnificent act to dissolve an organization in which there were thousands and thousands of members. To him it was a great act because, he said: “What will you do afterwards, how will you live? You will have no following, people will no longer listen to you.” If there are only five people who will listen, who will live, who have their faces turned toward eternity, it will be sufficient. Of what use is it to have thousands who do not understand, who are fully embalmed in prejudice, who do not want the new, but would rather translate the new to suit their own sterile, stagnant selves? If I speak strongly, please do not misunderstand me; it is not through lack of compassion. If you go to a surgeon for an operation, is it not kindness on his part to operate even if he causes you pain? So, in like manner, if I speak straightly, it is not through lack of real affection, on the contrary.

一位采访过我的报社记者认为，解散一个拥有成千上万成员的组织是一项了不起的举动。在他看来，这之所以伟大，是因为他说：“解散之后你该怎么办？你该如何生活？你将无人追随，人们将不再听你的。” 即使只有五个人愿意倾听，愿意继续生活，愿意面向永恒，那也足够了。成千上万的人不理解，他们被偏见彻底麻木，他们不想要新事物，反而会把新事物曲解成符合他们自身贫瘠、停滞不前的样子，这又有什么用呢？如果我言辞激烈，请不要误解；这并非出于缺乏同情心。如果你去找外科医生做手术，即使手术会让你感到疼痛，难道这不是他出于仁慈吗？同样，如果我直言不讳，也并非出于缺乏真情实感，恰恰相反。

As I have said, I have only one purpose: to make man free, to urge him toward freedom, to help him to break away from all limitations, for that alone will give him eternal happiness, will give him the unconditioned realization of the self.

正如我所说，我只有一个目的：使人获得自由，敦促人走向自由，帮助人摆脱一切限制，因为只有这样才能给他带来永恒的幸福，才能给他带来无条件的自我实现。

Because I am free, unconditioned, whole—not the part, not the relative, but the whole Truth that is eternal—I desire those, who seek to understand me, to be free; not to follow me, not to make out of me a cage which will become a religion, a sect. Rather should they be free from all fears—from the fear of religion, from the fear of salvation, from the fear of spirituality, from the fear of love, from the fear of death, from the fear of life itself. As an artist paints a picture because he takes delight in that painting, because it is his self-expression, his glory, his well-being, so I do this and not because I want anything from anyone.

因为我是自由的、无条件的、完整的——不是局部，不是相对的，而是永恒的整体真理——我渴望那些寻求理解我的人也能获得自由；不要追随我，不要把我囚禁起来，最终形成宗教或教派。他们应该摆脱一切恐惧——摆脱对宗教的恐惧，摆脱对救赎的恐惧，摆脱对灵性的恐惧，摆脱对爱的恐惧，摆脱对死亡的恐惧，摆脱对生命本身的恐惧。正如艺术家作画是因为他从中获得乐趣，因为那是他的自我表达，他的荣耀，他的幸福，我作画也不是为了从任何人那里得到什么。

You are accustomed to authority, or to the atmosphere of authority, which you think will lead you to spirituality. You think and hope that another can, by his extraordinary powers—a miracle—transport you to this realm of eternal freedom, which is Happiness. Your whole outlook on life is based on that authority. You have listened to me for three years now, without any change taking place except in the few. Now analyze what I am saying, be critical, so that you may understand thoroughly, fundamentally. When you look for an authority to lead you to spirituality, you are bound automatically to build an organization around that authority. By the very creation of that organization, which, you think, will help this authority to lead you to spirituality, you are held in a cage.

你习惯了权威，或者说是权威的氛围，你认为这能引领你走向灵性。你相信并希望有人能凭借其非凡的力量——一个奇迹——将你带入永恒自由的境界，也就是幸福。你对人生的整个看法都建立在这种权威之上。三年来，你一直听我讲道，除了少数人之外，没有任何改变。现在，请分析我所说的话，批判性地思考，以便你能够彻底、根本地理解。当你寻求权威来引领你走向灵性时，你自然而然地会围绕着这个权威建立一个组织。而正是通过建立这个组织——你认为它能帮助这个权威引领你走向灵性——你反而把自己囚禁在了牢笼之中。

If I talk frankly, please remember that I do so, not out of harshness, not out of cruelty, not out of the enthusiasm of my purpose, but because I want you to understand what I am saying. That is the reason why you are here, and it would be a waste of time if I did not explain clearly, decisively, my point of view.

如果我说话直白，请记住，我这样做并非出于苛刻，并非出于残忍，也并非出于某种目的的狂热，而是因为我希望你们能理解我的意思。你们来到这里就是为了这个目的，如果我不清晰、果断地阐明我的观点，那将是浪费时间。

For eighteen years you have been preparing for this event, for the Coming of the World Teacher. For eighteen years you have organized, you have looked for someone who would give a new delight to your hearts and minds, who would transform your whole life, who would give you a new understanding; for someone who would raise you to a new plane of life, who would give you a new encouragement, who would set you free—and now look what is happening! Consider, reason with yourselves, and discover in what way that belief has made you different—not with the superficial difference of the wearing of a badge, which is trivial, absurd. In what manner has such a belief swept away all the unessential things of life? That is the only way to judge: In what way are you freer, greater, more dangerous to every Society which is based on the false and the unessential? In what way have the members of this organization of the Star become different?

十八年来，你们一直在为这一盛事——世界导师的到来——做准备。十八年来，你们一直在组织、一直在寻找一位能给你们的心灵带来全新喜悦、彻底改变你们人生、赋予你们全新领悟的人；一位能将你们提升到全新境界、给予你们全新鼓励、解放你们的人——而现在，看看这一切正在发生！请你们思考，请你们自己去思考，去发现这种信念究竟在哪些方面使你们变得不同——并非仅仅因为佩戴一枚徽章这种肤浅的、微不足道的、荒谬可笑的差异。这种信念究竟在哪些方面扫除了生活中所有无关紧要的东西？这才是评判的唯一标准：你们究竟在哪些方面变得更加自由、更加伟大、更加威胁到所有建立在虚假和无关紧要之上的社会？星辰组织的成员究竟在哪些方面变得与众不同？

As I said, you have been preparing for eighteen years for me. I do not care if you believe that I am the World Teacher or not. That is of very little importance. Since you belong to the organization of the Order of the Star, you have given your sympathy, your energy, acknowledging that Krishnamurti is the World Teacher partially or wholly: wholly for those who are really seeking, only partially for those who are satisfied with their own half-truths.

正如我所说，你们已经为我准备了十八年。我不在乎你们是否相信我是世界导师，这无关紧要。既然你们属于星辰教团，你们就投入了你们的同情和精力，承认克里希那穆提是世界导师，无论这种承认是部分还是全部：对于真正寻求真理的人来说是全部，而对于那些满足于自身片面真理的人来说只是部分。

You have been preparing for eighteen years, and look how many difficulties there are in the way of your understanding, how many complications, how many trivial things. Your prejudices, your fears, your authorities, your churches new and old—all these, I maintain, are a barrier to understanding. I cannot make myself clearer than this. I do not want you to agree with me. I do not want you to follow me. I want you to understand what I am saying.

你们准备了十八年，看看你们的理解之路有多少障碍，有多少复杂之处，有多少琐碎之事。你们的偏见、恐惧、权威、新旧教会——我认为，所有这些都是理解的绊脚石。我已经说得很清楚了。我并不想让你们同意我的观点，也不想让你们追随我。我只是想让你们明白我的意思。

This understanding is necessary because your belief has not transformed you but only complicated you, and because you are not willing to face things as they are. You want to have your own gods—new gods instead of the old, new religions instead of the old, new forms instead of the old—all equally valueless, all barriers, all limitations, all crutches. Instead of old spiritual distinctions you have new spiritual distinctions, instead of old worships you have new worships. You are all depending for your spirituality on someone else, for your happiness on someone else, for your enlightenment on someone else; and although you have been preparing for me for eighteen years, when I say all these things are unnecessary, when I say that you must put them all away and look within yourselves for the enlightenment, for the glory, for the purification, and for the incorruptibility of the self, not one of you is willing to do it. There may be a few, but very, very few.

这种理解是必要的，因为你们的信仰非但没有改变你们，反而使你们更加复杂，也因为你们不愿面对事物的本来面目。你们想要拥有自己的神——用新的神取代旧的，用新的宗教取代旧的，用新的形式取代旧的——所有这些都毫无价值，都是障碍，都是限制，都是拐杖。你们用新的精神区分取代旧的灵性区分，用新的崇拜取代旧的崇拜。你们的灵性、幸福、觉悟都依赖于他人；尽管你们已经为我准备了十八年，但当我说这一切都没有必要，当我说你们必须抛弃这一切，向内寻求觉悟、荣耀、净化和自我的不朽时，你们中没有一个人愿意这样做。或许有几个愿意，但真的非常少。

So why have an organization?

那么，为什么要成立组织呢？

Why have false, hypocritical people following me, the embodiment of Truth? Please remember that I am not saying something harsh or unkind, but we have reached a situation when you must face things as they are. I said last year that I would not compromise. Very few listened to me then. This year I have made it absolutely clear. I do not know how many thousands throughout the world—members of the Order—have been preparing for me for eighteen years, and yet now they are not willing to listen unconditionally, wholly, to what I say.

为什么会有虚伪做作的人追随我，我可是真理的化身啊！请记住，我并非在说些刻薄或刻薄的话，但我们已经到了必须面对现实的地步。去年我说过我不会妥协，当时几乎没人听我的。今年我更是把话说得清清楚楚。我不知道全世界有多少信徒——也就是教团成员——为了迎接我的到来准备了十八年，可如今他们却不愿意无条件地、全然地听从我的指示。

So why have an organization?

那么，为什么要成立组织呢？

As I said before, my purpose is to make men unconditionally free, for I maintain that the only spirituality is the incorruptibility of the self, which is eternal, is the harmony between reason and love. This is the absolute, unconditioned Truth, which is Life itself. I want, therefore, to set man free, rejoicing as the bird in the clear sky, unburdened, independent, ecstatic in that freedom. And I, for whom you have been preparing for eighteen years, now say that you must be free of all these things, free from your complications, your entanglements. For this you need not have an organization based on spiritual belief. Why have an organization for five or ten people in the world who understand, who are struggling, who have put aside all trivial things? And for the weak people, there can be no organization to help them to find the Truth, because Truth is in everyone; it is not far, it is not near; it is eternally there.

正如我之前所说，我的目的是使人获得无条件的自由，因为我坚信，唯一的灵性在于自我的不朽，它是永恒的，是理性与爱的和谐统一。这便是绝对的、无条件的真理，它本身就是生命。因此，我渴望使人获得自由，如同晴空中的鸟儿般欢欣雀跃，无拘无束，独立自主，沉浸在自由的喜悦之中。而我，你们为之准备了十八年，现在我要告诉你们，你们必须摆脱这一切，摆脱你们的种种纠葛和束缚。为此，你们无需建立一个基于灵性信仰的组织。世界上只有五到十个人理解真理，正在努力奋斗，并且已经摒弃了一切琐碎之事，为何还要建立一个组织呢？至于那些意志薄弱的人，也不需要任何组织来帮助他们找到真理，因为真理存在于每个人心中；它既不遥远，也不近在咫尺；它永恒存在。

Organizations cannot make you free. No man from outside can make you free; nor can organized worship, nor the immolation of yourselves for a cause, make you free; nor can forming yourselves into an organization, nor throwing yourselves into works, make you free. You use a typewriter to write letters, but you do not put it on an altar and worship it. But that is what you are doing when organizations become your chief concern. “How many members are there in it?” That is the first question I am asked by all newspaper reporters. “How many followers have you? By their number we shall judge whether what you say is true or false.” I do not know how many there are. I am not concerned with that. As I said, if there were even one man who had been set free, that is enough.

组织无法使你获得自由。任何外人都无法使你获得自由；有组织的宗教活动，或为某种事业献身，都无法使你获得自由；组建组织，或投身于各种事业，都无法使你获得自由。你用打字机写信，但你不会把它放在祭坛上膜拜。然而，当组织成为你最关心的事情时，你就是在做这样的事。“你们有多少成员？”这是所有报社记者问我的第一个问题。“你有多少追随者？我们将根据他们的数量来判断你所说的话是真是假。”我不知道有多少人。我并不关心这个。正如我所说，即使只有一个人获得了自由，那就足够了。

Again, you have the idea that only certain people hold the key to the Kingdom of Happiness. No one holds it. No one has the authority to hold that key. That key is your own self, and in the development and the purification and in the incorruptibility of that self alone is the Kingdom of Eternity.

你又一次认为只有某些人掌握着通往幸福王国的钥匙。其实没有人掌握它。没有人有权掌握那把钥匙。那把钥匙就是你自己，唯有通过自身的成长、净化和不朽，才能进入永恒王国。

So you will see how absurd is the whole structure that you have built, looking for external help, depending on others for your comfort, for your happiness, for your strength. These can only be found within yourselves.

所以你会明白，你所构建的整个体系是多么荒谬——寻求外在的帮助，依赖他人来获得舒适、幸福和力量。这些只能在你们自身找到。

So why have an organization?

那么，为什么要成立组织呢？

You are accustomed to being told how far you have advanced, what is your spiritual status. How childish! Who but yourself can tell you if you are beautiful or ugly within? Who but yourself can tell you if you are incorruptible? You are not serious in these things.

你习惯于别人告诉你你进步了多少，你的灵性境界如何。多么幼稚！除了你自己，谁能告诉你你的内心是美是丑？除了你自己，谁能告诉你你是否清白无瑕？你对这些事情并不认真。

So why have an organization?

那么，为什么要成立组织呢？

But those who really desire to understand, who are looking to find that which is eternal, without beginning and without an end, will walk together with a greater intensity, will be a danger to everything that is unessential, to unrealities, to shadows. And they will concentrate, they will become the flame, because they understand. Such a body we must create, and that is my purpose. Because of that real understanding there will be true friendship. Because of that true friendship—which you do not seem to know—there will be real cooperation on the part of each one. And this not because of authority, not because of salvation, not because of immolation for a cause, but because you really understand, and hence are capable of living in the eternal. This is a greater thing than all pleasure, than all sacrifice.

但那些真正渴望理解、寻求永恒、无始无终之物的人，将会更加坚定地携手前行，对一切非本质之物、虚幻之物、虚影之物构成威胁。他们会专注，他们会化作火焰，因为他们理解。我们必须创造这样一个群体，而这正是我的目标。因为有了真正的理解，就会有真正的友谊。因为有了这真正的友谊——你们似乎并不了解——就会有彼此间真正的合作。这并非出于权威，并非出于救赎，并非出于为某种事业献身，而是因为你们真正理解了，因此能够活在永恒之中。这比一切享乐，比一切牺牲都更伟大。

So these are some of the reasons why, after careful consideration for two years, I have made this decision. It is not from a momentary impulse. I have not been persuaded to it by anyone. I am not persuaded in such things. For two years I have been thinking about this, slowly, carefully, patiently, and I have now decided to disband the Order, as I happen to be its Head. You can form other organizations and expect someone else. With that I am not concerned, nor with creating new cages, new decorations for those cages. My only concern is to set men absolutely, unconditionally free.

所以，经过两年的深思熟虑，我做出这个决定，原因有以下几点。这并非一时冲动，也并非受任何人说服。在这种事情上，我不会轻易被说服。两年来，我一直在缓慢、谨慎、耐心地思考这个问题，现在我决定解散这个组织，因为我恰好是它的首领。你们可以组建其他组织，也可以期待其他人来领导。对此我并不关心，也不关心建造新的牢笼，或者为这些牢笼增添新的装饰。我唯一关心的是让人们获得绝对的、无条件的自由。

#↩

PART 1

第一部分

Early Works

早期作品

Jiddu Krishnamurti was born in 1895 into a modest Brahmin home in Madanapalle, India. His mother died when he was ten, and during his childhood he was delicate and frequently ill. When his father retired from government employment, he arranged with Annie Besant, the President of the International Theosophical Society, to work for this organization of which he had been a member for some years. Krishnamurti, then in his fourteenth year, moved with three of his brothers and his father to the Theosophical headquarters in Madras.

吉杜·克里希那穆提于1895年出生于印度马达纳帕莱一个普通的婆罗门家庭。他十岁时母亲去世，童年时期体弱多病。父亲从政府部门退休后，与国际神智学会主席安妮·贝赞特商议，让他为这个他已加入多年的组织工作。当时十四岁的克里希那穆提与他的三个兄弟和父亲一起搬到了位于马德拉斯的神智学会总部。

A deeply affectionate bond formed between Mrs. Besant and Krishnamurti, and she became his legal guardian. The theosophists had been awaiting the advent of a “World Teacher,” to prepare for whose coming they had formed a group known as the Order of the Star in the East, with Krishnamurti at its Head. In 1912 Krishnamurti was formally proclaimed the World Teacher, but in 1929 he disbanded the Order with his spiritually radical speech “Truth Is a Pathless Land.” By doing so he rejected estates, money, power, and all claims to authority or guru status.

贝赞特夫人与克里希那穆提之间建立了深厚的感情，她成为了克里希那穆提的法定监护人。神智学者们一直在等待一位“世界导师”的到来，为了迎接他的到来，他们成立了一个名为“东方之星教团”的组织，克里希那穆提担任教团首领。1912年，克里希那穆提被正式宣布为世界导师，但在1929年，他发表了极具精神变革意义的演讲《真理是一片无路之地》，并解散了该教团。通过这一举动，他放弃了财产、金钱、权力以及一切权威或导师身份。

For the rest of his life he traveled extensively, giving talks to all who cared to listen in Europe, India, the United States, South America, Australia, and New Zealand. Thousands from all walks of life came to hear him.

在他余生的大部分时间里，他周游世界，在欧洲、印度、美国、南美洲、澳大利亚和新西兰等地，向所有愿意倾听的人发表演讲。成千上万来自各行各业的人前来聆听他的演讲。

This part comprises a selection from his talks given in the mid-1930s. It includes one given in Mexico City and a series given in 1934 in Ojai, California, where Krishnamurti later spent the years of World War II (1939 to 1945).

这部分内容选自他在 20 世纪 30 年代中期发表的演讲。其中包括在墨西哥城发表的一次演讲，以及 1934 年在加利福尼亚州奥海发表的一系列演讲。克里希那穆提后来在二战期间（1939 年至 1945 年）在那里度过了岁月。

#↩

WHAT I WANT TO DO

我想做什么

You may ask, “What is it that you want to do? If you don’t want us to join any society or accept certain theories, what is it then that you want to do?”

你可能会问：“你们到底想做什么？如果你们不想让我们加入任何社团或接受某些理论，那你们到底想做什么？”

What I want to do is to help you, the individual, to cross the stream of suffering, confusion and conflict, through deep and complete fulfillment. This fulfillment does not come through egotistic self-expression, nor through compulsion and imitation. Not through some fantastic sentiment and conclusions, but through clear thinking, through intelligent action, we shall cross this stream of pain and sorrow. There is a reality which can be understood only through deep and true fulfillment.

我希望帮助你，作为个体，跨越痛苦、困惑和冲突的洪流，获得深刻而圆满的满足。这种圆满并非源于自我陶醉的表达，也非出于强迫和模仿。它并非来自虚幻的情感和结论，而是通过清晰的思考和明智的行动，我们才能跨越这痛苦和悲伤的洪流。唯有通过深刻而真实的圆满，才能真正理解那份真理。

Before we can understand the richness and the beauty of fulfillment, mind must free itself from the background of tradition, habit, and prejudice. For example, if you belong to a particular political party, you naturally regard all your political considerations from the narrow, limited point of view of that party. If you have been brought up, nursed, conditioned in a certain religion, you look at life through its veil of prejudice and darkness. That background of tradition prevents the complete understanding of life, and so causes confusion and suffering.

在我们能够理解圆满的丰富与美好之前，心灵必须摆脱传统、习惯和偏见的束缚。例如，如果你属于某个政党，你自然会从该政党狭隘的视角看待所有政治问题。如果你从小在某种宗教中长大，接受某种宗教的熏陶，你就会透过它所笼罩的偏见和黑暗面纱来看待生活。这种传统的束缚阻碍了我们对生活的全面理解，从而导致困惑和痛苦。

I would beg of you to listen to what I have to say, freeing yourself for this hour at least from the background in which you have been brought up, with its traditions and prejudices, and think simply and directly about the many human problems.

我恳请各位听我说，至少在这一个小时里，请暂时放下你们从小到大所处的环境及其传统和偏见，简单直接地思考人类面临的诸多问题。

To be truly critical is not to be in opposition. Most of us have been trained to oppose and not to criticize. When a man merely opposes, it generally indicates that he has some vested interest which he desires to protect, and that is not deep penetration through critical examination. True criticism lies in trying to understand the full significance of values without the hindrance of defensive reactions.

真正的批判并非反对。我们大多数人从小就被训练成反对而非批评。当一个人仅仅反对时，通常表明他有某种既得利益需要维护，而这并非通过批判性审视实现的深刻理解。真正的批判在于，在不受防御性反应干扰的情况下，努力理解各种价值观的全部意义。

We see throughout the world extremes of poverty and riches, abundance and at the same time starvation; we have class distinction and racial hatred, the stupidity of nationalism and the appalling cruelty of war. There is exploitation of man by man; religions with their vested interests have become the means of exploitation, also dividing man from man. There is anxiety, confusion, hopelessness, frustration.

世界各地贫富差距悬殊，既有富足之人，也有饥荒之徒；阶级分化和种族仇恨并存，民族主义的愚蠢和战争的残酷令人发指。人与人之间存在着剥削；宗教及其既得利益也沦为了剥削的工具，加剧了人与人之间的隔阂。焦虑、困惑、绝望和挫败感充斥着我们的生活。

We see all this. It is part of our daily life. Caught up in the wheel of suffering, if you are at all thoughtful you must have asked yourself how these human problems can be solved. Either you are conscious of the chaotic state of the world, or you are completely asleep, living in a fantastic world, in an illusion. If you are aware, you must be grappling with these problems. In trying to solve them, some turn to experts for their solution, and follow their ideas and theories. Gradually they form themselves into an exclusive body, and thus they come into conflict with other experts and their parties; and the individual merely becomes a tool in the hands of the group or of the expert. Or you try to solve these problems by following a particular system, which, if you carefully examine it, becomes merely another means of exploiting the individual. Or you think that to change all this cruelty and horror there must be a mass movement, a collective action.

这一切都是我们目睹的。它已成为我们日常生活的一部分。身陷苦难的漩涡，如果你稍有思考，就一定会问自己：这些人类问题该如何解决？你要么意识到世界的混乱现状，要么完全沉睡，活在一个虚幻的世界里。如果你有所觉察，就必然在努力应对这些问题。为了解决这些问题，有些人会求助于专家，遵循他们的理念和理论。渐渐地，他们形成了一个排他性的团体，从而与其他专家及其政党产生冲突；个人沦为群体或专家手中的工具。或者，你试图通过遵循某种特定的体系来解决这些问题，但如果你仔细审视，就会发现它只不过是另一种剥削个人的手段。又或者，你认为要改变这一切残酷和恐怖，就必须发起一场群众运动，一次集体行动。

Now the idea of a mass movement becomes merely a catchword if you, the individual, who are part of the mass, do not understand your true function. True collective action can take place only when you, the individual, who are also the mass, are awake and take the full responsibility for your action without compulsion.

如果作为群体一员的你，不理解自身真正的作用，那么群众运动的概念就仅仅沦为一句空话。真正的集体行动只有在你——作为群体一员的你——觉醒并自愿承担起自身行为的全部责任时，才能发生。

Please bear in mind that I am not giving you a system of philosophy which you can follow blindly, but I am trying to awaken the desire for true and intelligent fulfillment, which alone can bring about happy order and peace in the world.

请记住，我不是在给你一套你可以盲目遵循的哲学体系，而是在试图唤醒人们对真正而明智的满足的渴望，只有这样才能给世界带来幸福的秩序与和平。

There can be fundamental and lasting change in the world, there can be love and intelligent fulfillment, only when you wake up and begin to free yourself from the net of illusions, the many illusions which you have created about yourself through fear. When the mind frees itself from these hindrances, when there is that deep, inward, voluntary change, then only can there be true, lasting, collective action, in which there can be no compulsion.

只有当你觉醒并开始挣脱幻象之网——那些你因恐惧而为自己编织的种种幻象——世界才能发生根本而持久的改变，才能拥有爱与智慧的圆满。当心灵摆脱这些障碍，当内心深处发生自觉的改变，才能实现真正持久的集体行动，其中不应有任何强迫。

Please understand that I am talking to you as an individual, not to a collective group or to a particular party. If you do not awaken to your full responsibility, to your fulfillment, then your function as a human being in society must be frustrated, limited, and in that lies sorrow.

请理解，我是在和你个人对话，而不是和某个群体或特定政党对话。如果你不能充分认识到自己的责任和价值，实现自我价值，那么你作为社会成员的功能就必然会受到阻碍和限制，而这其中必将充满痛苦。

So the question is: How can there be this profound individual revolution? If there is this true, voluntary revolution on the part of the individual, then you will create the right environment for all, without the distinction of class or race. Then the world will be a single human unit.

所以问题是：如何才能发生这种深刻的个人革命？如果个人能够真正自愿地进行这种革命，那么就能为所有人创造一个适宜的环境，不再受阶级或种族的限制。那时，世界将成为一个人类大家庭。

How are you going to awaken as individuals to this profound revolution? Now what I am going to say is not complicated, it is simple; and because of its very simplicity, I am afraid you will reject it as not being positive. What you call positive is to be given a definite plan, to be told exactly what to do. But if you can understand for yourself what are the hindrances that are preventing your deep and true fulfillment, then you will not become a mere follower and be exploited. All following is detrimental to completeness.

作为个体，你们将如何觉醒，迎接这场意义深远的变革？我接下来要说的并不复杂，而是很简单；正因为它的简单，我担心你们会觉得它不够积极。你们所谓的积极，是指被赋予一个明确的计划，被告知该做什么。但如果你们能够自己理解那些阻碍你们获得真正圆满的障碍是什么，那么你们就不会沦为盲从者，也不会被人利用。盲从只会阻碍你们的圆满。

To have this profound revolution, you must become fully conscious of the structure which you have created about yourself and in which you are now caught. That is, we have now certain values, ideals, beliefs, which act as a net to hold the mind, and by questioning and understanding all their significance, we shall realize how they have come into existence. Before you can act fully and truly, you must know the prison in which you are living, how it has been created; and in examining it without any self-defense you will find out for yourself its true significance, which no other can convey to you. Through your own awakening of intelligence, through your own suffering you will discover the manner of true fulfillment.

要实现这场深刻的变革，你必须充分意识到你为自己构建并困于其中的结构。也就是说，我们如今拥有某些价值观、理想和信念，它们如同网一般束缚着我们的思想。通过质疑和理解它们的全部意义，我们将领悟它们是如何产生的。在你能够真正地行动之前，你必须了解你身处的牢笼，了解它是如何形成的；当你毫无顾忌地审视它时，你将发现它真正的意义，这是任何人都无法传达给你的。通过你自身智慧的觉醒，通过你自身的苦难，你将发现真正圆满的途径。

Each one of us is seeking security, certainty, through egotistic thought and action, objectively and subjectively. If you are conscious of your own thought, you will see that you are pursuing your own egotistic certainty and security, both outwardly and inwardly. In reality, there is no such absolute division of life as the objective and the subjective world. I make this division only for convenience.

我们每个人都在通过以自我为中心的思想和行为来寻求安全感和确定性，无论客观还是主观。如果你能觉察自己的想法，就会发现你无论在外在还是内在，都在追求你那以自我为中心的确定性和安全感。事实上，生活中并不存在客观世界和主观世界这种绝对的划分。我之所以这样划分，只是为了方便起见。

Objectively, this search for egotistic security and certainty expresses itself through family, which becomes a center of exploitation, based on acquisitiveness. If you examine it, you will see that what you call the love of family is nothing but possessiveness.

客观来说，这种对利己主义式的安全感和确定性的追求，是通过家庭体现出来的，家庭变成了一个基于占有欲的剥削中心。仔细审视一下，你会发现你所谓的家庭之爱，其实不过是占有欲罢不能。

That search for security again expresses itself through class divisions, which develop into the stupidity of nationalism and imperialism, breeding hatred, racial antagonism, and the ultimate cruelty of war. So through our own egotistic desires we have created a world of nationalities and conflicting sovereign governments, whose function is to prepare for war and force man against man.

对安全的追求再次通过阶级分化表现出来，进而演变为愚蠢的民族主义和帝国主义，滋生仇恨、种族对抗，最终酿成战争的残酷暴行。因此，出于我们自身的利己欲望，我们创造了一个由众多民族和相互冲突的主权政府构成的世界，其功能在于为战争做准备，并迫使人类互相残杀。

Then there is the search for egotistic security, certainty, through what we call religion. You like fondly to believe that divine beings have created these organized forms of belief which we call religions. You yourself have created them for your own convenience; through ages they have become sanctified, and you have now become enslaved to them. There can never be ideal religions, so let us not waste our time discussing them. They can exist only in theory, not in reality. Let us examine how we have created religions and in what manner we are enslaved to them. If you deeply examine them as they are, you will see that they are nothing but the vested interest of organized belief—holding, separating, and exploiting man. As you are objectively seeking security, so also you are seeking subjectively a different kind of security, certainty, which you call immortality. You crave egotistic continuance in the hereafter, calling it immortality. Later in my talks I will explain what to me is true immortality.

然后，还有一种追求以自我为中心的安全感和确定感的方式，我们称之为宗教。你们喜欢天真地相信，这些我们称之为宗教的信仰体系是由神灵创造的。其实，是你们自己为了自身便利而创造了它们；历经岁月，它们被奉为神圣，而你们如今却沦为它们的奴隶。理想的宗教永远不存在，所以我们不必浪费时间去讨论它们。它们只存在于理论中，而非现实中。让我们来审视一下我们是如何创造宗教的，以及我们又是如何被它们奴役的。如果你们深入审视它们的本质，就会发现它们不过是有组织的信仰的既得利益体现——控制、分裂和剥削人类。正如你们在客观上寻求安全感一样，你们也在主观上寻求另一种安全感和确定感，你们称之为永生。你们渴望在来世获得以自我为中心的延续，并称之为永生。稍后，我将在演讲中解释对我而言真正的永生是什么。

In your search for that security, fear is born, and so you submit yourself to another who promises you that immortality. Through fear you create a spiritual authority, and to administer that authority there are priests who exploit you through belief, dogma, and creed, through show, pomp, and pageantry, which throughout the world is called religion. It is essentially based on fear, though you may call it the love of God or truth; it is, if you examine it intelligently, nothing but the result of fear and, therefore, it must become one of the means of exploiting man. Through your own desire for immortality, for selfish continuance, you have built this illusion which you call religion, and you are unconsciously or consciously caught in it. Or you may not belong to any particular religion, but you may belong to some sect which subtly promises a reward, a subtle inflation of the ego in the hereafter. Or you may not belong to any society or sect, but there may be an inward desire, hidden and concealed, to seek your own immortality. So long as there is a desire for self-continuance in any form, there must be fear, which creates authority, and from this there come the subtle cruelty and stupidity of submitting oneself to exploitation. This exploitation is so subtle, so refined, that one becomes enamored of it, calling it spiritual progress and advancement toward perfection.

在寻求安全感的过程中，恐惧滋生，于是你臣服于另一个承诺你永生的人。恐惧催生了精神权威，而为了行使这种权威，一些神职人员利用信仰、教条和信条，利用各种形式、排场和仪式来剥削你，而这一切在世界各地都被称作宗教。它本质上是建立在恐惧之上的，尽管你可以称之为对上帝的爱或对真理的爱；但如果你理性地审视它，就会发现它不过是恐惧的产物，因此，它必然成为剥削人类的手段之一。出于你对永生、对自私延续的渴望，你构建了你称之为宗教的幻象，而你却在不知不觉或有意识地深陷其中。或许你不属于任何特定的宗教，但你可能属于某个教派，该教派巧妙地承诺来世的奖赏，一种微妙的自我膨胀。或许你不属于任何社团或教派，但你内心深处可能隐藏着一种追求永生的渴望。只要存在任何形式的自我延续的欲望，就必然存在恐惧，恐惧滋生权威，而权威又由此衍生出一种微妙的残酷和愚蠢——甘愿受人剥削。这种剥削如此隐蔽，如此精妙，以至于人们会对其产生迷恋，并将其称为精神进步和迈向完美的途径。

Now you, the individual, must become conscious of all this intricate structure, conscious of the source of fear, and be willing to eradicate it, whatever be the consequence. This means coming into conflict individually with the existing ideals and values; and when the mind frees itself from the false, there can be the creation of right environment for the whole.

现在，作为个体的你，必须意识到所有这些错综复杂的结构，意识到恐惧的根源，并愿意无论后果如何都要将其根除。这意味着你要与现有的理想和价值观发生个人层面的冲突；而当心灵摆脱了虚假的束缚，才能为整体创造一个合适的环境。

Your first concern is to become conscious of the prison; then you will see that your own thought is continually trying to avoid coming into conflict with the values of the prison. This escape creates ideals which, however beautiful, are but illusions. It is one of the tricks of the mind to escape into an ideal, because if it does not escape, it must come directly into conflict with the prison, with the environment. That is, the mind wants to escape into an illusion rather than face the suffering which will inevitably arise when it begins to question the values, the morality, the religion of the prison.

你首先要做的就是意识到自己身处监狱之中；然后你就会明白，你的思想一直在试图避免与监狱的价值观发生冲突。这种逃避会创造出一些理想，无论这些理想多么美好，都不过是幻象。逃避到理想之中是心灵的惯用伎俩之一，因为如果不逃避，它就必然会与监狱、与环境直接冲突。也就是说，心灵宁愿逃避到幻象之中，也不愿面对一旦开始质疑监狱的价值观、道德和宗教信仰时必然产生的痛苦。

So what matters is to come into conflict with the traditions and values of the society and religion in which you are caught, and not intellectually escape through an ideal. When you begin to question these values, you begin to awaken that true intelligence which alone can solve the many human problems.

所以，关键在于要敢于直面你所处的社会和宗教的传统与价值观，而不是试图通过理想逃避现实。当你开始质疑这些价值观时，你便开始觉醒真正的智慧，而唯有这种智慧才能解决诸多人类难题。

As long as the mind is caught up in false values, there cannot be fulfillment. Completeness alone will reveal truth, the movement of eternal life.

只要心灵被错误的价值观所束缚，就无法获得圆满。唯有圆满才能揭示真理，展现永恒生命的运行规律。

Mexico City, October 20, 1935

墨西哥城，1935年10月20日

#↩

WHAT ARE YOU SEEKING?

你在寻找什么？

It is my purpose during these talks not so much to give a system of thought as to awaken thought, and to do that I am going to make certain statements, naturally not dogmatic, which I hope you will consider. As you consider them, there will arise many questions; if you will kindly put these to me, I will try to answer them, and thus we can discuss further what I have to say.

我此次谈话的目的与其说是阐述一套思想体系，不如说是唤醒大家的思考。为此，我将提出一些观点，当然，这些观点并非教条，希望各位能够认真思考。在思考的过程中，你们可能会产生许多疑问；如果你们能提出这些问题，我将尽力解答，这样我们就可以进一步探讨我的观点。

I wonder why most of you come here? Presumably you are seeking something. And what are you seeking? You cannot answer that question, naturally, because your search varies, the object of your search varies; the object of your search is constantly changing, so you do not definitely know what you seek, what you want. But you have established, unfortunately, a habit of going from one supposed spiritual teacher to another supposed spiritual teacher, of joining various organizations, societies, and of following systems; in other words, trying to find out what gives you greater and greater satisfaction, excitement.

我很好奇你们大多数人来这里是为了什么？想必你们都在寻求某种东西。那么，你们究竟在寻求什么呢？当然，你们无法回答这个问题，因为你们的寻求各不相同，你们寻求的对象也在不断变化；你们寻求的对象一直在改变，所以你们并不确切地知道自己在寻求什么，想要什么。但不幸的是，你们已经养成了一种习惯：从一个所谓的灵性导师到另一个所谓的灵性导师，加入各种各样的组织、社团，追随各种体系；换句话说，你们试图找到能给你们带来越来越大满足感和兴奋感的东西。

This process of going from one school of thought to another, from one system of thought to another, from one teacher to another, you call the search for truth. In other words, you are going from one idea to another idea, from one system of thought to another, accumulating, hoping to understand life, trying to fathom its significance, its struggles, each time declaring that you have found something.

你把这种从一个思想流派到另一个思想流派、从一个思想体系到另一个思想体系、从一位老师到另一位老师的游历过程称为寻求真理。换句话说，你是在不断地从一个想法到另一个想法、从一个思想体系到另一个思想体系，不断积累，希望能理解人生，试图领悟人生的意义和挣扎，每一次都宣称自己有所发现。

Now, I hope you won’t say at the end of my talks that you have found something, because the moment you have found something you are already lost; it is an anchor to which mind clings and, therefore, that eternal movement, this true search of which I am going to speak, ceases. And most minds are looking for a definite aim, with this definite desire to find, and when once there is established this desire, you will find something. But it won’t be something living; it will be a dead thing that you will find and, therefore, you will put that away to turn to another; and this process of continually choosing, continually discarding, you call acquiring wisdom, experience, or truth.

现在，我希望你们听完我的演讲后，不要说你们找到了什么，因为一旦你们找到了什么，你们就已经迷失了；它就像一个锚，你们的心灵紧紧抓住它，因此，我接下来要讲的那种永恒的运动，那种真正的探索，就此停止。大多数人的心灵都在寻找一个明确的目标，带着一种明确的寻找欲望，一旦这种欲望确立，你们就会找到一些东西。但那不会是鲜活的事物；你们找到的会是一个死物，因此，你们会把它抛弃，转而寻找另一个；而你们把这种不断选择、不断舍弃的过程称为获得智慧、经验或真理。

Probably most of you have come here with this attitude, consciously or unconsciously, so your thought is expended merely on the search for schemes and confirmations, on the desire to join a movement or form groups, without the clarity of the fundamental or trying to understand what these fundamental things of life mean. So as I said, I am not putting forward an ideal to be imitated, a goal to be found; but my purpose is, rather, to awaken that thought by which the mind can liberate itself from these things which we have established, which we have taken for granted as being true.

或许你们大多数人都是带着这种态度而来，无论是有意识的还是无意识的，所以你们的注意力仅仅集中在寻找各种方案和佐证上，一心想加入某个运动或组建团体，却缺乏对根本问题的清晰认识，也未能尝试理解这些根本问题的意义。因此，正如我所说，我并非提出一个需要效仿的理想，一个需要追求的目标；我的目的，恰恰是唤醒一种思想，使人们的心灵能够从我们既定的、被视为理所当然的真理中解脱出来。

Now, each one tries to immortalize the product of environment; that thing which is the result of the environment we try to make eternal. That is, the various fears, hopes, longings, prejudices, likes, and personal views which we glorify as our temperament are, after all, the result, the product, of environment; and this bundle of memories, which is the result of environment, the product of the reactions to environment, becomes that consciousness which we call the “I.” Is that not so? The whole struggle is between the result of environment, with which mind identifies itself and becomes the “I,” between that and environment. After all, the “I,” the consciousness with which the mind identifies itself, is the result of environment. The struggle takes place between that “I” and the constantly changing environment.

如今，每个人都试图将环境的产物永恒化；我们试图将环境的产物——也就是我们试图使其永恒的东西——永久化。也就是说，我们奉为自身性情的各种恐惧、希望、渴望、偏见、喜好和个人观点，归根结底都是环境的结果和产物；而这堆记忆，作为环境的结果，作为对环境反应的产物，最终变成了我们称之为“我”的意识。难道不是吗？所有的斗争都发生在环境的结果（心灵认同于此并成为“我”）与环境之间。毕竟，“我”，即心灵认同于此的意识，是环境的结果。斗争发生在“我”与不断变化的环境之间。

You are continually seeking immortality for this “I.” In other words, falsehood tries to become the real, the eternal. When you understand the significance of the environment, there is no reaction and, therefore, no conflict between the reaction, that is, between what we call the “I” and the creator of the reaction, which is the environment. So this seeking for immortality, this craving to be certain, to be lasting, is called the process of evolution, the process of acquiring truth or God or the understanding of life. And anyone who helps you toward this, who helps you to immortalize reaction, which we call the “I,” you make of him your redeemer, your savior, your master, your teacher, and you follow his system. You follow him with thought, or without thought; with thought when you think that you are following him with intelligence because he is going to lead you to immortality, to the realization of that ecstasy. That is, you want another to immortalize for you that reaction which is the outcome of environment, which is in itself inherently false. Out of the desire to immortalize that which is false you create religions, sociological systems and divisions, political methods, economic panaceas, and moral standards. So gradually in this process of developing systems to make the individual immortal, lasting, secure, the individual is completely lost, and he comes into conflict with the creations of his own search, with the creations which are born out of his longing to be secure and which he calls immortality.

你不断地为这个“我”寻求永生。换句话说，虚假试图成为真实，成为永恒。当你理解了环境的重要性，就不会有反应，因此，反应（也就是我们所说的“我”）与反应的创造者（即环境）之间也就不存在冲突。所以，这种对永生的追求，这种对确定性、对永恒的渴望，被称为进化的过程，是获得真理、上帝或生命理解的过程。任何帮助你达到这个目标的人，任何帮助你使反应（我们称之为“我”）永生的人，你都会把他当作你的救赎者、你的救世主、你的导师、你的老师，并追随他的体系。你带着思考追随他，或者不带思考地追随他；当你认为自己是在用智慧追随他时，你才会带着思考，因为他会引领你走向永生，走向那种极乐的实现。也就是说，你想让别人为你使那个反应永生，而那个反应本身就是环境的结果，它本质上是虚假的。出于将虚假之物永恒化的渴望，人们创造了宗教、社会体系和分化、政治手段、经济灵丹妙药以及道德标准。因此，在这个旨在使个体永生、持久、安全的体系发展过程中，个体逐渐迷失，并与自身探索的产物——那些源于对安全的渴望并被他称为永生的创造物——产生冲突。

After all, why should religions exist? Religions as divisions of thought have grown, have been glorified and nourished by sets of beliefs because there is this desire that you shall realize, that you shall attain, that there shall be immortality.

毕竟，宗教存在的意义是什么？宗教作为一种思想分支，之所以发展壮大，并因各种信仰体系而得到颂扬和滋养，是因为人们渴望实现某种目标，渴望获得某种成就，渴望获得永生。

And again, moral standards are merely the creations of society, so that the individual may be held within its bondage. To me, morality cannot be standardized. There cannot be at the same time morality and standards. There can only be intelligence, which is not, which cannot be, standardized. But we shall go into that in my later talks.

再说一遍，道德标准不过是社会的产物，其目的是为了束缚个人。在我看来，道德无法标准化。道德和标准不可能同时存在。存在的只有智慧，而智慧本身是无法标准化的。不过，我们将在以后的演讲中详细探讨这个问题。

So this continual search in which each one of us is caught up, the search for happiness, for truth, for reality, for health—this continual desire is cultivated by each one of us in order that we may be secure, permanent. And out of that search for permanency, there must be conflict, conflict between the result of environment, that is, the “I,” and the environment itself.

因此，我们每个人都身处其中，不断地追寻幸福、真理、现实和健康——这种持续的渴望是我们每个人都为了获得安全感和永恒感而培养的。而正是在这种对永恒感的追求中，必然会产生冲突，即环境的结果（也就是“我”）与环境本身之间的冲突。

Now if you come to think of it, what is the “I”? When you talk about “I,” “mine,” my house, my enjoyment, my wife, my child, my love, my temperament, what is that? It is nothing but the result of environment, and there is a conflict between that result, the “I,” and the environment itself. Conflict can only, and must inevitably, exist between the false and the false, not between truth and the false. Isn’t that so? There cannot be conflict between what is true and what is false. But there can be conflict and there must be conflict between two false things, between the degrees of falseness, between the opposites.

仔细想想，“我”究竟是什么？当你谈论“我”、“我的”、我的房子、我的享受、我的妻子、我的孩子、我的爱、我的性情时，那又是什么呢？它不过是环境的产物，而这种产物，也就是“我”，与环境本身之间存在着冲突。冲突只能存在于虚假与虚假之间，也必然存在于真与假之间。难道不是吗？真与假之间不可能存在冲突。但两个虚假的事物之间，虚假的程度之间，对立的事物之间，却存在冲突，而且必然存在冲突。

So do not think this struggle between the self and the environment, which you call the true struggle, is true. Isn’t there a struggle taking place in each one of you between yourself and your environment, your surroundings, your husband, your wife, your child, your neighbor, your society, your political organizations? Is there not a constant battle going on? You consider that battle necessary in order to help you to realize happiness, truth, immortality, or ecstasy. To put it differently: What you consider to be the truth is but self-consciousness, the “I,” which is all the time trying to become immortal, and the environment, which I say is the continual movement of the false. This movement of the false becomes your ever-changing environment, which is called progress, evolution. So to me, happiness, or truth, or God, cannot be found as the outcome of the result of environment, the “I,” the continually changing conditions.

所以，不要以为你们所谓的“真正的斗争”——自我与环境之间的斗争——是真实的。难道你们每个人内心深处，不都存在着一场自我与环境、与周围环境、与丈夫、妻子、孩子、邻居、社会、政治组织之间的斗争吗？难道不是一场永无休止的斗争吗？你们认为这场斗争是必要的，它能帮助你们获得幸福、真理、永生或极乐。换句话说：你们所认为的真理，不过是自我意识，是那个始终试图获得永生的“我”，而环境，在我看来，则是虚假的持续运动。这种虚假的运动构成了你们不断变化的环境，也就是你们所谓的进步、进化。因此，在我看来，幸福、真理或上帝，都不是环境、“我”以及不断变化的环境的结果。

I will try to put it again, differently. There is conflict, of which each one of you is conscious, between yourself and the environment, the conditions. Now, you say to yourself, “If I can conquer environment, overcome it, dominate it, I shall find out, I shall understand”; so there is this continual battle going on between yourself and environment.

我换个方式再说一遍。你们每个人都意识到，你们自身与环境、与各种条件之间存在着冲突。你们会对自己说：“如果我能征服环境，战胜环境，掌控环境，我就能找到答案，就能理解一切。”于是，你们自身与环境之间就一直存在着这种持续不断的斗争。

Now, what is the “yourself”? It is but the result, the product, of environment. So what are you doing? You are fighting one false thing with another false thing, and environment will be false so long as you do not understand it. Therefore, the environment is producing that consciousness which you call the “I,” which is continually trying to become immortal. And to make it immortal there must be many ways, there must be means, and therefore you have religions, systems, philosophies, all the nuisances and barriers that you have created. Hence, there must be conflict between the result of environment and environment itself; and, as I said, there can be conflict only between the false and the false; never between truth and the false, whereas in your minds there is this firmly established idea that in this struggle between the result of environment, which is the “I,” and the environment itself, lies power, wisdom, the path to eternity, to reality, truth, happiness.

那么，“自我”究竟是什么？它不过是环境的结果，是环境的产物。所以你在做什么？你用一个虚假的事物去对抗另一个虚假的事物，而只要你不理解环境，它就永远是虚假的。因此，环境造就了你称之为“我”的意识，而这个意识不断地试图获得永生。为了使其永生，必须有很多方法，必须有很多手段，因此你才有了宗教、体系、哲学，以及你所创造的所有麻烦和障碍。因此，环境的结果与环境本身之间必然存在冲突；而且，正如我所说，冲突只能存在于虚假与虚假之间；真理与虚假之间绝不可能存在冲突。然而，在你们的头脑中，却根深蒂固地存在着这样一种观念：在环境的结果（即“我”）与环境本身之间的斗争中，蕴藏着力量、智慧、通往永恒、通往现实、通往真理、通往幸福的道路。

Our vital concern should be with this environment, not with the conflict, not how to overcome it, not how to run away from it. By questioning the environment and trying to understand its significance, we shall find out its true worth. Isn’t that so? Most of us are enmeshed, caught up in the process of trying to overcome, to run away from circumstances, environment; we are not trying to find out what it means, what is its cause, its significance, its value. When you see the significance of environment, it means drastic action, a tremendous upheaval in your life, a complete, revolutionary change of ideas, in which there is no authority, no imitation. But very few are willing to see the significance of environment, because it means change, a radical change, a revolutionary change, and very few people want that. So most people, vast numbers of people, are concerned with the evasion of environment; they cover it up, or try to find new substitutions by getting rid of Jesus Christ and setting up a new savior; by seeking new teachers in place of the old, but they do not ever inquire whether they need a guide at all. This alone would help, this alone would give the true significance of that particular demand.

我们真正应该关注的是环境本身，而不是冲突，不是如何克服冲突，也不是如何逃避冲突。通过质疑环境并试图理解其意义，我们才能发现它的真正价值。难道不是吗？我们大多数人都深陷其中，忙于试图克服和逃避环境，却不去探究它的意义、根源、重要性和价值。当你真正理解环境的意义时，就意味着要采取果断行动，你的生活将发生翻天覆地的变化，观念将彻底颠覆，不再有任何权威，不再有任何模仿。然而，很少有人愿意正视环境的意义，因为它意味着改变，彻底的改变，革命性的改变，而很少有人渴望改变。因此，大多数人，绝大多数人，都在逃避环境；他们掩盖环境，或者试图通过抛弃耶稣基督、树立新的救世主来寻找新的替代品。他们用新老师取代旧老师，却从未想过自己是否真的需要指导。仅此一点就足以说明问题，仅此一点就能揭示这一需求的真正意义。

So where there is a search for substitution, there must be authority, the following of leadership, and hence the individual becomes but a cog in the social and religious machinery of life. If you look closely you will see that your search is nothing but a search for comfort and security and escape; not a search for understanding, not a search for truth, but rather a search for an evasion and, therefore, a search for the conquering of all obstacles; after all, all conquering is but substitution, and in substitution there is no understanding.

因此，凡是寻求替代的地方，就必然存在权威，必然存在对领导的追随，于是个人便沦为社会和宗教机器中的一颗螺丝钉。仔细观察，你会发现你的寻求不过是对舒适、安全和逃避的追求；并非对理解的追求，也非对真理的追求，而是一种逃避，因此，也是一种征服一切障碍的追求；毕竟，一切征服都只是替代，而替代之中没有理解。

There are escapes through religions, with their edicts, moral standards, fears, authorities; and escapes through self-expression; what you call self-expression, what the vast majority of people call self-expression, is but the reaction against environment, is but the effort to express oneself through reaction against that environment—self-expression through art, through science, through various forms of action. Here I am not including the true, spontaneous expressions of beauty, of art, of science; they in themselves are complete. I am talking of the man who is seeking these things as a means of self-expression. A real artist does not talk about his self-expression, he is expressing that which he intensely feels; but there are so many spurious artists, like the spurious spiritual people, who are all the time seeking self-expression as a means of getting something, some satisfaction which they cannot find in the environment in which they live.

人们可以通过宗教及其教义、道德标准、恐惧和权威来逃避现实；也可以通过自我表达来逃避现实；你所谓的自我表达，或者绝大多数人所谓的自我表达，不过是对环境的一种反抗，不过是通过反抗环境来表达自我的努力——通过艺术、科学以及各种行动形式进行自我表达。这里我并不包括真正自发的、对美、艺术和科学的表达；它们本身就是完整的。我指的是那些将这些东西作为自我表达手段的人。真正的艺术家不会谈论他的自我表达，他表达的是他内心深处的感受；但是，有很多伪艺术家，就像那些伪灵修者一样，他们总是寻求自我表达，以此来获得某种东西，某种他们在所处环境中无法找到的满足感。

Through this search for security and permanency, we have established religions—with all their inanities, divisions, exploitations—as means of escape; and these means of escape become so vital, so important, because, to tackle environment, that is, the conditions about us, demands tremendous action, voluntary, dynamic action, and very few are willing to take that action. On the contrary, you are willing to be forced to an action by environment, by circumstances; that is, if a man becomes highly moral and virtuous through depression, you say what a nice man he is, how he has changed. For that change you depend upon environment; and so long as there is the dependence on environment for righteous action, there must be means of escape, substitutions, call it religion or what you will, whereas for the true artist, who is also truly spiritual, there is spontaneous expression, which in itself is sufficient, complete, whole.

为了寻求安全感和永恒感，我们建立了各种宗教——尽管它们充斥着荒谬、分裂和剥削——作为逃避现实的手段；而这些逃避手段之所以如此重要，如此关键，是因为要应对环境，也就是我们周围的境况，需要采取巨大的行动，自愿的、积极的行动，而愿意采取这种行动的人寥寥无几。相反，人们往往愿意被环境、被境遇所迫而采取行动；也就是说，如果一个人因为抑郁而变得道德高尚、品德高尚，你就会称赞他多么好，他改变了多少。这种改变依赖于环境；只要正义的行动依赖于环境，就必然存在逃避的手段、替代品，你可以称之为宗教，或者任何你想用的词。然而，对于真正的艺术家，那些真正具有精神追求的人而言，他们拥有自发的表达，这种表达本身就已足够、完整、圆满。

So what are you doing? What is happening to each one of you? What are you trying to do in your lives? You are seeking; and what are you seeking? There is a conflict between yourself and the constant movement of environment. You are seeking a means to overcome that environment, so as to perpetuate your own self, which is but the result of that environment; or, because you have been thwarted so often by environment, which prevents you from self-expressing, as you call it, you seek a new means of self-expression through service to humanity, through economic adjustments, and all the rest of it.

那么，你们在做什么？你们每个人身上发生了什么？你们在生活中试图做什么？你们在寻求什么？你们寻求的是什么？你们自身与不断变化的环境之间存在着冲突。你们寻求一种克服环境的方法，从而延续你们自身——而你们的自身不过是环境的产物；或者，因为你们屡次受阻于环境，无法如你们所说的“自我表达”，所以你们寻求一种新的自我表达方式，例如通过服务人类、通过经济调整等等。

Each one has to find out for what he is searching; if he is not searching, then there is satisfaction and decay. If there is conflict, there is the desire to overcome that conflict, to escape from that conflict, to dominate it. And as I have said, conflict can exist only between two false things, between that supposed reality which you call the “I,” which to me is nothing else but the result of environment, and the environment itself. If your mind is merely concerned with the overcoming of that struggle, then you are perpetuating falseness and hence, there is more conflict, more sorrow. But if you understand the significance of environment, that is, wealth, poverty, exploitation, oppression, nationalities, religions, and all the inanities of social life in modern existence, not trying to overcome them but seeing their significance, then there must be individual action, and complete revolution of ideas and thought. Then there is no longer a struggle, but rather light dispelling darkness. There is no conflict between light and darkness. There is no conflict between truth and that which is false. There is only conflict where there are opposites.

每个人都必须找到自己所追寻的；如果不去追寻，就会陷入满足与衰败。如果存在冲突，就会产生克服冲突、逃离冲突、主宰冲突的欲望。正如我所说，冲突只能存在于两个虚假的事物之间，存在于你所谓的“我”——在我看来，它不过是环境的产物——与环境本身之间。如果你的思想仅仅关注于克服这种斗争，那么你就是在延续虚假，因此，冲突和痛苦也会更多。但是，如果你理解了环境的意义——也就是财富、贫困、剥削、压迫、民族、宗教以及现代社会生活中所有荒谬的事物——不是试图克服它们，而是理解它们的意义，那么就必然会产生个人行动，以及思想和观念的彻底革命。那时，不再有斗争，而是光明驱散黑暗。光明与黑暗之间没有冲突，真理与谬误之间也没有冲突。冲突只存在于对立面之中。

Ojai, California, June 16, 1934

加利福尼亚州奥海，1934年6月16日

#↩

THE SIGNIFICANCE OF ENVIRONMENT

环境的重要性

You may remember that yesterday I was talking about the birth of conflict, and how the mind seeks a solution for it. I want to deal this morning with the whole idea of conflict and disharmony, and show the utter futility of mind trying to seek a solution for conflict, because the mere search for the solution will not do away with the conflict itself.
