When you seek a solution, a means of dissolving the conflict, you merely try to superimpose, or substitute in its place, a new set of ideas, a new set of theories, or you try to run away from conflict altogether. When people desire a solution for their conflict, that is what they seek.

你或许还记得，昨天我谈到了冲突的起源，以及人们如何寻求解决之道。今天早上我想深入探讨冲突与不和谐的本质，并指出人们试图寻找冲突解决方案的徒劳无功，因为仅仅寻找解决方案并不能消除冲突本身。当你寻求解决方案，寻求化解冲突的方法时，你只不过是试图用一套新的想法、一套新的理论来取代原有的冲突，或者干脆逃避冲突。当人们渴望找到冲突的解决方案时，他们真正寻求的正是这些。

If you observe, you will see that when there is conflict, you are at once seeking a solution for it. You want to find a way out of that conflict, and you generally do find a way out; but you have not solved the conflict, you have merely shifted it by substituting a new environment, a new condition, which will in turn produce further conflict. So let us look into this whole idea of conflict, from where it arises, and what we can do with it.

如果你仔细观察，就会发现，当冲突发生时，你会立刻寻求解决之道。你想找到摆脱冲突的方法，而且通常也确实能找到；但你并没有解决冲突，只是通过引入新的环境、新的条件，将冲突转移到了另一个层面，而这反过来又会引发新的冲突。所以，让我们来深入探讨一下冲突的本质，探究它的根源，以及我们该如何应对它。

Now, conflict is the result of environment, isn’t it? To put it differently, what is environment? When are you conscious of environment? Only when there is conflict and a resistance to that environment. So, if you observe, if you look into your lives, you will see that conflict is continually twisting, perverting, shaping your lives; and intelligence, which is the perfect harmony of mind and heart, has no part in your lives at all. That is, environment is continually shaping, molding your lives to action, and naturally out of that continual twisting, molding, shaping, perversion, conflict is born. So where there is this constant process of conflict there cannot be intelligence. And yet we think that by continually going through conflict we shall arrive at that intelligence, that fullness, and that plenitude of ecstasy. But by the accumulation of conflict we cannot find out how to live intelligently; you can find out how to live intelligently only when you understand the environment which is creating conflict, and mere substitution, that is, the introduction of new conditions, is not going to solve the conflict. And yet if you observe, you will see that when there is conflict, mind is seeking a substitution. We either say, “It is heredity, economic conditions, past environment,” or we assert our belief in karma, reincarnation, evolution; so we are trying to give excuses for the present conflict in which the mind is caught, and are not trying to find out what is the cause of conflict itself, which is to inquire into the significance of environment.

冲突是环境造成的，不是吗？换句话说，什么是环境？你何时会意识到环境的存在？只有当冲突发生，你对环境产生抵触情绪时，你才会意识到环境的存在。所以，如果你观察，如果你审视自己的生活，你会发现冲突不断地扭曲、改变、塑造着你的生活；而智慧，即心灵与情感的完美和谐，在你的生活中却毫无立足之地。也就是说，环境不断地塑造、影响着你的生活，而冲突自然就源于这种持续不断的扭曲、塑造、改变。因此，在持续不断的冲突中，智慧是不存在的。然而我们却认为，通过不断经历冲突，我们就能获得智慧，获得圆满，获得极致的喜悦。但是，通过冲突的积累，我们无法找到智慧的生活方式；只有当你理解了制造冲突的环境，才能找到智慧的生活方式。而仅仅用新的条件来替代，并不能解决冲突。然而，如果你仔细观察，就会发现当冲突发生时，我们的心会寻求替代。我们要么说：“这是遗传、经济状况或过去环境造成的”，要么强调因果报应、轮回转世、进化论；我们试图为当下困扰我们的冲突寻找借口，而不是去探究冲突的根源，也就是探究环境的意义。

Conflict then can exist only between environment—environment being economic and social conditions, political domination, neighbors—between that environment, and the result of environment, which is the “I.” Conflict can exist only so long as there is reaction to that environment which produces the “I,” the self. The majority of people are unconscious of this conflict—the conflict between one’s self, which is but the result of the environment, and the environment itself; very few are conscious of this continuous battle. One becomes conscious of that conflict, that disharmony, that struggle between the false creation of the environment, which is the “I,” and the environment itself, only through suffering. Isn’t that so? It is only through acuteness of suffering, acuteness of pain, acuteness of disharmony, that you become conscious of the conflict.

因此，冲突只能存在于环境（环境包括经济和社会条件、政治统治、邻里关系等）与环境的产物——即“我”之间。冲突只有在对产生“我”——即自我——的环境做出反应时才会存在。大多数人并未意识到这种冲突——自我（不过是环境的产物）与环境本身之间的冲突；极少有人意识到这场持续不断的斗争。只有经历苦难，人们才会意识到这种冲突、这种不和谐、这种环境造物（即“我”）与环境本身之间的斗争。难道不是吗？只有经历剧烈的痛苦、剧烈的折磨、剧烈的不和谐，你才会意识到这种冲突。

What happens when you become conscious of the conflict? What happens when in that intensity of suffering you become fully conscious of the battle, the struggle which is going on? Most people want an immediate relief, an immediate answer. They want to shelter themselves from that suffering and, therefore, they find various means of escape such as religions, excitements, inanities, and the many mysterious avenues of escape which we have created through our desire to protect ourselves from this struggle. Suffering makes one conscious of this conflict, and yet suffering will not lead man to that fullness, to that richness, that plenitude, that ecstasy of life, because after all, suffering can only awaken the mind to great intensity. And when the mind is acute, then it begins to question—the environment, the conditions, and in that questioning, intelligence is functioning; and it is only intelligence that will lead man to the fullness of life and to the discovery of the significance of sorrow. Intelligence begins to function in the moment of acuteness of suffering, when mind and heart are no longer escaping, escaping through the various avenues which you have so cleverly made, which are so apparently reasonable, factual, real. If you observe carefully, without prejudice, you will see that so long as there is an escape you are not solving, you are not coming face-to-face with conflict and, therefore, your suffering is merely the accumulating of ignorance. That is, when one ceases to escape, through the well-known channels, then in that acuteness of suffering, intelligence begins to function.

当你意识到冲突的存在时会发生什么？当你在极度痛苦中完全意识到这场战斗、这场斗争时，又会发生什么？大多数人想要立即得到解脱，立即得到答案。他们想要逃避痛苦，因此，他们寻找各种各样的逃避途径，例如宗教、刺激、虚妄之事，以及我们为了保护自己免受这场斗争的渴望而创造的诸多神秘的逃避之道。痛苦使人意识到这场冲突，然而痛苦本身并不能引领人走向圆满、富饶、充实、极致的生命体验，因为归根结底，痛苦只能唤醒心灵的敏锐。而当心灵敏锐时，它便开始质疑——质疑环境、质疑境况，而正是在这种质疑中，智慧得以发挥作用；也只有智慧才能引领人走向圆满的生命体验，并发现悲伤的意义。智慧在痛苦最剧烈的时刻开始发挥作用，那时心灵和思想不再能够逃避，不再能够通过你精心构建的各种途径逃避——这些途径看似合理、真实、无误。如果你仔细观察，不带偏见，你就会发现，只要你没有解决任何逃避的途径，你就无法直面冲突，因此，你的痛苦仅仅是无知的积累。也就是说，当一个人不再通过那些众所周知的途径逃避时，智慧便会在痛苦最剧烈的时刻开始发挥作用。

Please, I do not want to give you examples and similes, because I want you to think it out, and if I give examples I do all the thinking and you merely listen, whereas if you begin to think about what I am saying, you will see, you will observe for yourself how mind, being accustomed to so many substitutions, authorities, escapes, never comes to that point of acuteness of suffering which demands that intelligence must function. And it is only when intelligence is fully functioning that there can be the utter dissolution of the cause of conflict.

请不要让我举例子和比喻，因为我想让你们自己思考。如果我举例子，所有的思考都由我来做，你们只是听着而已。但如果你们开始思考我所说的，你们就会明白，你们会亲眼观察到，由于心智习惯了如此多的替代、权威和逃避，它永远不会达到那种需要理智发挥作用的痛苦的临界点。只有当理智完全发挥作用时，冲突的根源才能彻底消解。

Whenever there is the lack of understanding of environment there must be conflict. Environment gives birth to conflict, and so long as we do not understand environment, conditions, surroundings, and are merely seeking substitutions for these conditions, we are evading one conflict and meeting another. But if in that acuteness of suffering which brings forth in its fullness a conflict, if in that state we begin to question environment, then we shall understand the true worth of environment, and intelligence then functions naturally. Hitherto mind has identified itself with conflict, with environment, with evasions and, therefore, with suffering; that is, you say, “I suffer,” whereas in that state of acuteness of suffering, in that intensity of suffering in which there is no longer escape, mind itself becomes intelligence.

凡是对环境缺乏了解，冲突便必然存在。环境孕育冲突，只要我们不了解环境、条件和周围环境，而只是寻求替代这些条件，我们就是在逃避一种冲突，却又遭遇另一种冲突。但如果在痛苦的极致体验中，在这种体验中我们开始质疑环境，那么我们就会理解环境的真正价值，而智慧也会自然而然地发挥作用。迄今为止，心智一直等同于冲突、环境、逃避，因而等同于痛苦；也就是说，你会说“我受苦”，然而，在痛苦的极致体验中，在那种无法逃避的痛苦强度中，心智本身就变成了智慧。

To put it again differently, so long as we are seeking solutions, so long as we are seeking substitutions, authorities for the cause and the alleviation of conflict, there must be identification of the mind with the particular; whereas if the mind is in that state of intense suffering in which all the avenues of escape are blocked, then intelligence will be awakened, will function naturally and spontaneously.

换句话说，只要我们寻求解决方案，只要我们寻求替代品，寻求解决冲突的权威和缓解冲突的方法，就必然存在心灵与特定事物的认同；然而，如果心灵处于那种所有逃避途径都被堵塞的强烈痛苦状态，那么智慧就会被唤醒，并自然而然地发挥作用。

Please, if you experiment with this, you will see that I am not giving you theories, but something with which you can work, something which is practical. You have so many environments, which have been imposed on you by society, by religion, by economic conditions, by social distinctions, by exploitation, and political oppressions. The “I” has been created by that imposition, by that compulsion; there is the “I” in you which is fighting the environment and hence, there is conflict. It is no use creating a new environment, because the same thing will still exist. But if in that conflict there is conscious sorrow and suffering—and there is always suffering in all conflict, only man wants to run away from that struggle and he therefore seeks substitutes—if in that acuteness of suffering you stop searching for substitutes and really face the facts, you will see that mind, which is the summation of intelligence, begins to discover the true worth of environment, and then you will realize that mind is free of conflict. In the very acuteness of suffering lies its own dissolution. So therein is the understanding of the cause of conflict.

请你尝试一下，你会发现我给你的不是理论，而是你可以实践的东西，是切实可行的方法。你身处诸多环境之中，这些环境是由社会、宗教、经济状况、社会等级、剥削和政治压迫强加于你的。“我”正是由这些强加和胁迫所造就；你内心深处的“我”与环境抗争，因此产生了冲突。创造新的环境毫无意义，因为同样的问题依然存在。但是，如果在这种冲突中，你感受到了有意识的悲伤和痛苦——所有冲突中都必然伴随着痛苦，只是人们总是想要逃避这种斗争，因此寻求替代品——如果在痛苦的煎熬中，你停止寻找替代品，真正面对现实，你就会发现，作为智慧总和的心灵，开始发现环境的真正价值，那时你就会意识到，心灵已摆脱了冲突。痛苦的煎熬本身就蕴含着自身的消解。这就是冲突根源的理解。

Also, one should bear in mind that what we call accumulation of sorrows does not lead to intensity, nor does the multiplication of suffering lead to its own dissolution; for acuteness of mind in suffering comes only when the mind has ceased to escape. And no conflict will awaken that suffering, that acuteness of suffering, when the mind is trying to escape, for in escape there is no intelligence.

此外，我们应当谨记，所谓悲伤的累积并不会导致痛苦的加剧，苦难的增多也不会使其消散；因为只有当心灵不再逃避时，才能在苦难中体悟到痛苦的深刻。而当心灵试图逃避时，任何冲突都无法唤醒那种痛苦，那种痛苦的深刻，因为逃避之中没有智慧。

To put it briefly again, before I answer the questions that have been given to me: First of all, everyone is caught up in suffering and conflict, but most people are unconscious of that conflict; they are merely seeking substitutions, solutions, and escapes, whereas if they cease seeking escapes and begin to question the environment which causes that conflict, then mind becomes acute, alive, intelligent. In that intensity mind becomes intelligence and, therefore, sees the full worth and significance of the environment, which creates conflict.

简而言之，在我回答大家提出的问题之前，我想先说明一点：首先，每个人都身处苦难和冲突之中，但大多数人对此浑然不觉；他们只是寻求替代品、解决方案和逃避现实的途径。然而，如果他们不再寻求逃避，而是开始质疑造成冲突的环境，那么他们的心智就会变得敏锐、鲜活、睿智。在这种高度集中的状态下，心智会转化为智慧，从而能够看到造成冲突的环境的全部价值和意义。

Please, I am sure half of you don’t understand this, but it doesn’t matter. What you can do, if you will, is to think this over, really think over it, and see if what I am saying is not true. But to think over it is not to intellectualize it, that is, to sit down and make it vanish away through the intellect. To find out if what I am saying is true, you have to put it into action, and to put it into action you must question the environment. That is, if you are in conflict, naturally you must question the environment, but most minds have become so perverted that they are not aware that they are seeking solutions, escapes through their marvelous theories. They reason perfectly, but their reasoning is based on the search for escape, of which they are wholly unconscious.

我知道你们当中有一半人可能不理解，但这无关紧要。你们可以做的，是认真思考一下，仔细想想，看看我说的是不是真的。但思考并非只是理性分析，也不是坐下来用理性让它消失。要验证我说的是否属实，你们必须付诸行动，而要付诸行动，你们就必须质疑周围的环境。也就是说，如果你身处冲突之中，自然要质疑周围的环境，但大多数人的思想已经扭曲到他们意识不到自己正试图通过那些精妙的理论来寻求解决之道，逃避现实。他们的推理看似完美，但他们的推理却建立在逃避现实的寻求之上，而他们对此却浑然不觉。

So if there is conflict, and if you want to find out the cause of that conflict, naturally the mind must discover it through acuteness of thought and, therefore, the questioning of all that which environment places about you—your family, your neighbors, your religions, your political authorities; and by questioning there will be action against the environment. There is the family, the neighbor and the state, and by questioning their significance you will see that intelligence is spontaneous, not to be acquired, not to be cultivated. You have sown the seed of awareness and that produces the flower of intelligence.

所以，如果存在冲突，而你想找出冲突的根源，那么心智自然必须通过敏锐的思考来发现它，因此，你需要质疑你周围的一切——你的家庭、邻居、宗教、政治权威；通过质疑，你会采取行动对抗这种环境。家庭、邻居和国家都存在，通过质疑它们的意义，你会发现智慧是自发的，它无法习得，也无法培养。你已经播下了觉知的种子，它终将绽放智慧之花。

Questioner : You say that the “I” is the product of environment. Do you mean that a perfect environment could be created which would not develop the “I” consciousness? If so, the perfect freedom of which you speak is a matter of creating the right environment. Is this correct?

提问者：您说“我”是环境的产物。您的意思是，可以创造一个完美的环境，使“我”的意识不会发展吗？如果是这样，您所说的完美自由就取决于创造合适的环境。我的理解正确吗？

Krishnamurti : Wait a minute. Can there ever be right environment, perfect environment? There cannot. So let us reason together, go into it fully.

克里希那穆提：等等。真的存在合适的、完美的环境吗？不存在的。所以，让我们一起来思考，深入探讨一下。

What is environment? Environment is created, this whole human structure has been created, by human fears, longings, hopes, desires, attainments. Now, you cannot make a perfect environment because each man is creating, according to his fancies and desires, new sets of conditions; but having an intelligent mind, you can pierce through all these false environments and, therefore, be free of that “I” consciousness. Please, the “I” consciousness, the sense of “mine,” is the result of environment, isn’t it? I don’t think we need discuss it because it is pretty obvious.

什么是环境？环境，或者说整个人类社会结构，都是由人类的恐惧、渴望、希望、欲望和成就所创造的。当然，你不可能创造一个完美的环境，因为每个人都会根据自己的幻想和欲望创造新的条件；但是，只要拥有智慧的头脑，你就能看穿所有这些虚假的环境，从而摆脱“我”的意识。请注意，“我”的意识，或者说“我的”意识，不正是环境的产物吗？我想我们无需赘述，因为这显而易见。

If the state gave you your house and everything you required, there would be no need of “my house”; there might be some other sense of “mine,” but we are discussing the particular. As that has not been the case with you, there is the sense of “mine,” possessiveness. That is the result of environment; that “I” is but the false reaction to environment, whereas if the mind begins to question the environment itself, there is no longer a reaction to environment. Therefore, we are not concerned with the possibility of there ever being a perfect environment.

如果国家给你房子和一切所需，那就不需要“我的房子”这种说法了；“我的”或许还有其他含义，但我们讨论的是具体情况。正因为你没有得到这样的待遇，所以才有了“我的”这种占有欲。这是环境造成的；这种“我”不过是对环境的一种虚假反应，而如果心灵开始质疑环境本身，就不会再对环境做出反应。因此，我们并不关心是否存在完美的环境。

After all, what is perfect environment? Each man will tell you what to him is a perfect environment. The artist will say one thing, the financier another, the cinema actress another; each man asks for a perfect environment which satisfies him, in other words, which does not create conflict in him. Therefore, there cannot be a perfect environment. But if there is intelligence, then environment has no value, no significance, because intelligence is then freed from circumstance; it is functioning fully.

毕竟，什么是完美的环境？每个人都会告诉你，对他而言，什么是完美的环境。艺术家会说一种，金融家会说另一种，电影演员又会说另一种；每个人都在寻求一个令自己满意的完美环境，换句话说，一个不会让他感到冲突的环境。因此，完美的环境是不存在的。但是，如果存在智慧，那么环境就失去了价值和意义，因为智慧此时摆脱了环境的束缚，得以充分发挥其作用。

The question is not whether we can create a perfect environment, but rather how to awaken that intelligence which shall be free of environment, imperfect or perfect. I say you can awaken that intelligence by questioning the full value of any environment in which your mind is caught up. Then you will see that you are free of any particular environment, because then you are functioning intelligently, not being twisted, perverted, shaped by environment.

问题不在于我们能否创造一个完美的环境，而在于如何唤醒那种不受环境（无论完美与否）束缚的智慧。我认为，你可以通过质疑任何束缚你心灵的环境的全部价值来唤醒这种智慧。那时你就会发现，你已经摆脱了任何特定环境的束缚，因为那时你是在以智慧的方式运作，而不是被环境扭曲、左右或塑造。

Q : Surely you cannot mean what your words seem to convey. When I see vice rampant in the world, I feel an intense desire to fight against that vice and against all the suffering it creates in the lives of my fellow human beings. This means great conflict, for when I try to help I am often viciously opposed. How then can you say that there is no conflict between the false and the true?

问：你这话听起来好像是真心话，你肯定不是这个意思。当我看到世间罪恶横行时，我强烈地想要与之抗争，对抗罪恶以及它给同胞带来的种种苦难。这意味着巨大的冲突，因为当我试图伸出援手时，往往会遭到猛烈的反对。那么，你又怎能说真假之间没有冲突呢？

K : I said yesterday that there can be struggle only between two false things, conflict between the environment and the result of environment, which is the “I.” Now between these two lie innumerable avenues of escape, which the “I” has created, which we call vice, goodness, morality, moral standards, fears, and all the many opposites; and the struggle can exist only between the two, between the false creation of the environment, which is the “I,” and the environment itself. But there cannot be struggle between truth and that which is false. Surely that is obvious, isn’t it? You may be viciously opposed because the other man is ignorant. It doesn’t mean you mustn’t fight—but don’t assume the righteousness of fighting. Please, you know there is a natural way of doing things, a spontaneous, sweet way of doing things, without this aggressive, vicious righteousness.

K：我昨天说过，斗争只能发生在两个虚假的事物之间，即环境与环境的结果——也就是“我”——之间的冲突。在这两者之间，存在着无数条逃避的途径，这些途径是“我”创造的，我们称之为恶习、善行、道德、道德标准、恐惧以及所有对立面；斗争只能存在于这两者之间，存在于环境的虚假创造——也就是“我”——与环境本身之间。但真理与虚假之间不可能存在斗争。这难道不是显而易见的吗？你可能会因为对方的无知而遭到激烈的反对。但这并不意味着你不能反抗——但不要自以为反抗是正义的。请记住，有一种自然的方式，一种自发的、美好的方式，无需这种咄咄逼人、恶毒的正义感。

First of all, in order to fight, you must know what you are fighting, so there must be understanding of the fundamental, not of the divisions between the false things. Now we are so conscious, we are so fully conscious of the divisions between the false things, between the result and the environment, that we fight them and, therefore, we want to reform, we want to change, we want to alter, without fundamentally changing the whole structure of human life. That is, we still want to preserve the “I” consciousness which is the false reaction to environment; we want to preserve that and yet want to alter the world. In other words, you want to have your own bank account, your own possessions; you want to preserve the sense of “mine,” and yet you want to alter the world so that there shall not be this idea of “mine” and “yours.”

首先，要进行斗争，你必须知道你在斗争什么，也就是说，必须理解问题的本质，而不是纠结于虚假事物之间的界限。如今，我们如此清楚地意识到虚假事物之间的界限，如此充分地意识到结果与环境之间的界限，以至于我们与之斗争，因此，我们想要改革，想要改变，想要调整，却不愿从根本上改变人类生活的整个结构。也就是说，我们仍然想要保留“我”的意识，即对环境的错误反应；我们想要保留它，却又想要改变世界。换句话说，你想要拥有自己的银行账户，自己的财产；你想要保留“我的”的概念，却又想要改变世界，让“我的”和“你的”这种观念不复存在。

So what one has to do is to find out if one is dealing with the fundamental, or merely with the superficial. And to me the superficial will exist so long as you are merely concerned with the alteration of environment so as to alleviate conflict. That is, you still want to cling to the “I” consciousness as “mine,” but yet desire to alter the circumstances so that they will not create conflict in that “I.” I call that superficial thought, and from that there naturally is superficial action, whereas if you think fundamentally, that is, question the very result of the environment, which is the “I” and, therefore, question the environment itself, then you are acting fundamentally and, therefore, lastingly. And in that there is an ecstasy, in that there is a joy of which now you do not know because you are afraid to act fundamentally.

所以，我们必须弄清楚自己是在处理根本问题，还是仅仅在处理表面问题。在我看来，只要你仅仅关注如何改变环境以缓解冲突，表面问题就会一直存在。也就是说，你仍然执着于将“我”意识视为“我的”，却又渴望改变环境，使其不会在“我”的内心引发冲突。我称之为表面思维，由此自然会产生表面行动。然而，如果你进行根本思考，也就是质疑环境本身——即“我”——的最终结果，进而质疑环境本身，那么你的行动就是根本性的，也是持久的。在这种根本思考中，蕴藏着一种狂喜，一种你现在还无法体会的喜悦，因为你害怕进行根本性的行动。

Q : In your talk yesterday you spoke of environment as the movement of the false. Do you include in environment all the creations of nature, including human forms?

问：您昨天在演讲中将环境描述为虚假的运动。您是否将自然界的所有造物，包括人类形态，都包含在环境的范畴内？

K : Doesn’t environment continually change? Doesn’t it? For most people it doesn’t change because change implies continual adjustment and, therefore, continual awareness of mind, and most people are concerned with the static condition of the environment. Yet environment is moving because it is beyond your control, and it is false so long as you do not understand its significance.

K：环境难道不是一直在变化吗？难道不是吗？对大多数人来说，环境似乎没有变化，因为变化意味着持续的调整，因此也意味着持续的意识觉察，而大多数人关注的是环境的静态状态。然而，环境其实一直在变化，因为它超出了你的控制范围，只要你不理解它的意义，它就是虚假的。

Does environment include human forms? Why set them apart from nature? We are not concerned so much with nature, because we have almost brought nature under control, but we have not understood the environment created by human beings. Look at the relationship between peoples, between two human beings, and all the conditions which human beings have created that we have not understood, even though we have largely understood and conquered nature through science.

环境是否包含人类形态？为什么要将人类与自然割裂开来？我们并不太关注自然，因为我们几乎已经控制了自然，但我们却对人类创造的环境知之甚少。看看人与人之间的关系，看看两个人之间的关系，看看人类创造的种种我们尚未理解的境况——尽管我们已经通过科学在很大程度上了解并征服了自然。

So we are not concerned with the stability, with the continuance, of an environment which we understand, because the moment we understand it there is no conflict. That is, we are seeking security, emotional and mental, and we are happy so long as that security is assured and, therefore, we never question environment, and hence the constant movement of environment is a false thing which is creating disturbance in each one. As long as there is conflict, it indicates that we have not understood the conditions placed about us; and that movement of environment remains false so long as we do not inquire into its significance, and we can only discover it in that state of acute consciousness of suffering.

因此，我们并不关心我们所理解的环境的稳定性或延续性，因为一旦我们理解了它，冲突便不复存在。也就是说，我们追求的是情感和精神上的安全感，只要这种安全感得到保障，我们就会感到快乐。因此，我们从不质疑环境，所以环境的不断变化对我们来说是一种虚假的现象，它会扰乱我们每个人的生活。只要存在冲突，就表明我们尚未理解周遭环境；只要我们不去探究环境变化的意义，它就始终是虚假的，而我们只有在深刻意识到痛苦的状态下才能发现它。

Q : It is perfectly clear to me that the “I” consciousness is the result of environment, but do you not see that the “I” did not originate for the first time in this life? From what you say it is obvious that the “I” consciousness, being the result of environment, must have begun in the distant past and will continue in the future.

问：我完全明白“我”意识是环境的产物，但您难道不认为“我”意识并非今生才出现的吗？从您的描述来看，作为环境产物的“我”意识显然始于遥远的过去，并将延续到未来。

K : I know this is a question to catch me about reincarnation. But that doesn’t matter. Now let’s look into it. First of all, you will admit, if you think about it, that the “I” is the result of environment. Now to me it doesn’t matter whether it is the past environment or present environment. After all, environment is of the past also. You have done something which you haven’t understood, you did something yesterday which you haven’t understood, and that pursues you until you understand it. You cannot solve that past environment till you are fully conscious in the present. So it doesn’t matter whether the mind is crippled by past or present conditions. What matters is that you shall understand the environment and this will liberate the mind from conflict.

K：我知道这个问题是想套我关于轮回的理论。不过这并不重要。现在我们来探讨一下。首先，如果你仔细想想，就会承认“我”是环境的产物。对我来说，是过去的环境还是现在的环境并不重要。毕竟，环境也属于过去。你做过一些自己不明白的事情，你昨天也做过一些自己不明白的事情，这些都会一直困扰着你，直到你明白为止。只有当你完全觉察到当下，你才能解决过去的环境问题。所以，心智是被过去还是现在的境况所束缚并不重要。重要的是你要理解环境，这样才能使心智从冲突中解脱出来。

Some people believe that the “I” has had a birth in the distant past and will continue in the future. It is irrelevant to me, it has no significance at all. I will show you why. If the “I” is the result of the environment, if the “I” is but the essence of conflict, then the mind must be concerned not with that continuance of conflict, but with freedom from that conflict. So it does not matter whether it is the past environment which is crippling the mind, or the present which is perverting it, or whether the “I” has had a birth in the distant past. What matters is that in that state of suffering, in that consciousness, that conscious acuteness of suffering, there is the dissolution of the “I.”

有些人认为“我”诞生于遥远的过去，并将延续到未来。这对我来说无关紧要，毫无意义。我会解释原因。如果“我”是环境的产物，如果“我”仅仅是冲突的本质，那么心灵关注的就不是冲突的延续，而是摆脱冲突。因此，究竟是过去的环境束缚了心灵，还是当下扭曲了心灵，又或者“我”诞生于遥远的过去，都无关紧要。重要的是，在那种痛苦的状态中，在那种意识中，在那种对痛苦的深刻觉察中，“我”会消解。

This brings in the idea of karma. You know what it means, that you have a burden in the present, the burden of the past in the present. That is, you bring with you the environment of the past into the present, and because of that burden, you control the future, you shape the future. If you come to think of it, it must be so, that if your mind is perverted by the past, naturally the future must also be twisted, because if you have not understood the environment of yesterday it must be continued today and, therefore, as you don’t understand today, naturally you will not understand tomorrow either. That is, if you have not seen the full significance of an environment or of an action, this perverts your judgment of today’s environment, of today’s action born of environment, which will again pervert you tomorrow. So one is caught up in this vicious circle, and hence the idea of continual rebirth, rebirth of memory, or rebirth of the mind continued by environment.

这就引出了业力的概念。你知道它的含义，即你现在背负着过去的重担。也就是说，你把过去的环境带入了现在，而正是因为这份重担，你掌控着未来，塑造着未来。仔细想想，必然如此：如果你的心智被过去扭曲，未来自然也会被扭曲，因为如果你没有理解昨天的环境，它就会延续到今天；因此，既然你不理解今天，自然也不会理解明天。也就是说，如果你没有看到某个环境或行为的全部意义，这就会扭曲你对今天环境以及今天由环境引发的行为的判断，而这又会反过来扭曲你明天的判断。于是，人就陷入了这个恶性循环，因此才有了不断轮回、记忆轮回或心智轮回的概念，而这些轮回又是由环境延续的。

But I say mind can be free of the past, of past environment, past hindrances and, therefore, you can be free of the future, because then you are living dynamically in the present, intensely, supremely. In the present is eternity, and to understand that, mind must be free of the burden of the past; and to free the mind of the past there must be an intense questioning of the present, not the considering of how the “I” will continue in the future.

但我认为，心灵可以摆脱过去，摆脱过去的环境和障碍，因此，你也能摆脱未来，因为那时你便能充满活力、全然投入地活在当下。当下即是永恒，要理解这一点，心灵必须摆脱过去的重负；而要摆脱过去的束缚，就必须对当下进行深入的探究，而不是思考“我”将如何继续存在于未来。

Ojai, California, June 17, 1934

加利福尼亚州奥海，1934年6月17日

#↩

A DYNAMIC SOCIETY

一个充满活力的社会

Today, we are going to answer questions.

今天，我们将回答一些问题。

Questioner : What is the difference between self-discipline and suppression?

提问者：自律和压抑有什么区别？

Krishnamurti : I don’t think there is much difference between the two because both deny intelligence. Suppression is the gross form of the subtler self-discipline, which is also repression; that is, both suppression as well as self-discipline are mere adjustments to environment. One is the gross form of adjustment, which is suppression, and the other, self-discipline, is the subtle form. Both are based on fear: suppression, on an obvious fear; the other, self-discipline, on fear born of loss, or on fear which expresses itself through gain.

克里希那穆提：我认为两者之间并没有太大区别，因为它们都否定了智慧。压抑是更为微妙的自律的粗略形式，而自律本身也是一种压制；也就是说，压抑和自律都只是对环境的适应。一种是粗略的适应形式，即压抑；另一种，即自律，则是更为微妙的形式。两者都基于恐惧：压抑基于显而易见的恐惧；而自律则基于因失去而生的恐惧，或通过获得而表现出来的恐惧。

Self-discipline—what you call self-discipline—is merely an adjustment to an environment which we have not completely understood; therefore, in that adjustment there must be the denial of intelligence. Why has one ever to discipline one’s self? Why does one discipline, force one’s self to mold after a particular pattern? Why do so many people belong to the various schools of disciplines, supposed to lead to spirituality, to greater understanding, greater unfoldment of thought? You will see that the more you discipline the mind, train the mind, the greater its limitations. Please, one has to think this over carefully and with delicate perception and not get confused by introducing other issues. Here I am using the word self-discipline as in the question, that is, disciplining one’s self after a certain pattern, preconceived or preestablished and, therefore, with the desire to attain, to gain, whereas to me the very process of discipline, this continual twisting of mind to a particular preestablished pattern, must eventually cripple the mind. The mind, which is really intelligent, is free of self-discipline, for intelligence is born out of the questioning of environment and the discovery of the true significance of environment. In that discovery is true adjustment, not the adjustment to a particular pattern or condition, but the adjustment through understanding, which is, therefore, free of the particular condition.

你所谓的自律，不过是对我们尚未完全理解的环境的一种适应；因此，这种适应必然包含对智慧的否定。人为什么要自律？为什么要约束自己，强迫自己按照某种特定的模式塑造自己？为什么那么多人会加入各种各样的修行体系，这些体系本应通往灵性、更深刻的理解和更广阔的思维？你会发现，你越是约束、训练你的心智，它的局限性就越大。请仔细思考这个问题，保持敏锐的洞察力，不要被其他问题所迷惑。我在这里使用“自律”一词，正如问题中所述，即按照某种预先设定或既定的模式约束自己，并因此渴望获得某种东西。然而在我看来，这种约束的过程本身，这种不断地将心智扭曲成某种特定模式的做法，最终必然会削弱心智。真正智慧的心灵不受自我约束，因为智慧源于对环境的质疑和对环境真正意义的发现。真正的适应就在于此，并非适应某种特定的模式或条件，而是通过理解而进行的适应，因此，这种适应不受特定条件的限制。

Take a primitive man; what does he do? In him there is no discipline, no control, no suppression. He does what he desires to do, this primitive. The intelligent man also does what he desires, but with intelligence. Intelligence is not born out of self-discipline or suppression. In the one instance it is wholly the pursuit of desire, the primitive man pursuing the object he desires. In the other instance, the intelligent man sees the significance of desire and sees the conflict; the primitive man does not, he pursues anything he desires and creates suffering and pain. So to me self-discipline and suppression are both alike—they both deny intelligence.

以原始人为例，他会做什么？他没有自律，没有自制，没有克制。他随心所欲，这就是原始人。聪明人也随心所欲，但他运用智慧。智慧并非源于自律或克制。原始人完全是追逐欲望，追求他想要的东西。而聪明人则能理解欲望的意义和冲突；原始人却不理解，他追求任何他想要的东西，最终只会制造痛苦和折磨。因此，在我看来，自律和克制本质上是一样的——它们都扼杀了智慧。

Please experiment with what I have said about discipline, self-discipline. Don’t reject it, don’t say you must have self-discipline, because there will be chaos in the world—as if there were not already chaos; and again, don’t merely accept what I say, agreeing that it is true. I am telling you something with which I have experimented and which I have found to be true. Psychologically I think it is true, because self-discipline implies a mind that is tethered to a particular thought or belief or ideal, a mind that is held by a condition; and as an animal that is tethered to a post can only wander within the distance of its rope, so does the mind which is tethered to a belief, which is perverted through self-discipline, wander only within the limitation of that condition. Therefore, such a mind is not mind at all, it is incapable of thought. It may be capable of adjustment between the limitations of the post and the farthest point of its reach; but such a mind, such a heart cannot really think and feel. The mind and the heart are disciplined, crippled, perverted, through denying thought, denying affection. So you must observe, become aware how your own thought, how your own feelings are functioning, without wanting to guide them in any particular direction. First of all, before you guide them, find out how they are functioning. Before you try to change and alter thought and feeling, find out the manner of their working, and you will see that they are continually adjusting themselves within the limitations established by that point fixed by desire and the fulfillment of that desire. In awareness there is no discipline.

请尝试理解我刚才所说的关于纪律和自律的内容。不要否定它，不要说你必须要有自律，否则世界就会陷入混乱——仿佛世界现在还不够混乱似的；也不要仅仅接受我的话，认为它是正确的。我告诉你的是我亲身实践过并验证过的东西。从心理学角度来说，我认为它是正确的，因为自律意味着心灵被某种特定的想法、信念或理想所束缚，被某种条件所限制；就像被拴在柱子上的动物只能在绳子范围内活动一样，被某种信念束缚、又被自律扭曲的心灵，也只能在这种条件的限制范围内游荡。因此，这样的心灵根本算不上心灵，它不具备思考的能力。它或许能够在柱子的限制和它所能触及的最远点之间做出调整；但这样的心智，这样的心灵，无法真正地思考和感受。心智和心灵因否定思考、否定情感而被束缚、残缺、扭曲。因此，你必须观察，觉察你的思想和情感是如何运作的，而不要试图引导它们朝任何特定的方向发展。首先，在你引导它们之前，先了解它们是如何运作的。在你试图改变和调整思想和情感之前，先了解它们的运作方式，你会发现它们不断地在欲望及其满足所设定的限制范围内调整自身。在觉察之中，没有束缚。

Let me take an example. Suppose that you are class-minded, class-conscious, snobbish. You don’t know that you are snobbish, but you want to find out if you are; how will you find out? By becoming conscious of your thought and your emotions. Then what happens? Suppose that you discover that you are snobbish, then that very discovery creates a disturbance, a conflict, and that very conflict dissolves snobbishness, whereas if you merely discipline the mind not to be snobbish, you are developing a different characteristic which is the opposite of being a snob, and being deliberate, therefore false, is equally pernicious.

让我举个例子。假设你很有阶级观念，很讲阶级，有点势利眼。你不知道自己势利，但你想弄清楚自己是不是势利眼；你会怎么做呢？通过觉察自己的想法和情绪。然后会发生什么呢？假设你发现自己势利眼，那么这种发现本身就会造成一种不安，一种冲突，而正是这种冲突会消除势利眼。然而，如果你只是刻意约束自己不要势利眼，你就会培养出一种与势利眼截然相反的特质，而刻意为之，因而也是虚假的，同样有害。

So, because we have established various patterns, various goals, aids, which we are continually—consciously or unconsciously—pursuing, we discipline our minds and hearts toward them and, therefore, there must be control, perversion, whereas if you begin to inquire into the conditions that create conflict, and thereby awaken intelligence, then that intelligence itself is so supreme that it is continually in movement and, therefore, there is never a static point which can create conflict.

因此，因为我们已经建立了各种模式、各种目标和辅助手段，并且我们不断地——有意识的或无意识地——追求它们，所以我们训练我们的思想和心灵去适应它们，因此必然存在控制和扭曲；然而，如果你开始探究造成冲突的条件，从而唤醒智慧，那么智慧本身是如此至高无上，以至于它不断地运动，因此，永远不会存在一个静止的点来造成冲突。

Q : Granted that the “I” is made up of reactions from environment, by what method can one escape its limitations; or how does one go about the process of reorientation, in order to avoid conflict between the two false things?

问：假设“我”是由环境反应构成的，那么一个人如何才能摆脱它的局限性；或者，一个人如何才能进行重新定位的过程，以避免两个虚假事物之间的冲突？

K : First of all, you want to know the method of escape from the limitations. Why? Why do you ask? Please, why do you always ask for a method, for a system? What does it indicate, this desire for a method? Every demand for a method indicates the desire to escape. You want me to lay down a system so that you may imitate that system. In other words, you want a system invented for you to superimpose on those conditions which are creating conflict, so that you can escape from all conflict. In other words you merely seek to adjust yourselves to a pattern, in order to escape from conflict or from your environment. That is the desire behind the demand for a method, for a system. You know life is not Pelmanism. The desire for a method indicates essentially the desire to escape.

K：首先，你想知道摆脱限制的方法。为什么？你为什么问这个问题？请问，你为什么总是寻求方法、寻求体系？这种对方法的渴望表明了什么？每一种对方法的需求都表明了逃避的渴望。你想让我为你制定一个体系，以便你模仿它。换句话说，你想得到一个为你量身定制的体系，用来叠加在那些造成冲突的条件之上，这样你就能逃避所有冲突。换句话说，你只是想让自己适应某种模式，以便逃避冲突或逃避你的环境。这就是对方法、对体系的需求背后的渴望。你知道生活不是佩尔曼主义。对方法的渴望本质上表明了逃避的渴望。

How does one go about the process of reorientation in order to avoid constant conflict between the two false things? First of all, are you aware that you are in conflict, before you want to know how to get away from it? Or, being aware of conflict, are you merely seeking a refuge, a shelter which will not create further conflict? So let us decide whether you want a shelter, a safety zone, which will no longer yield conflict, whether you want to escape from the present conflict to enter a condition in which there shall be no conflict; or whether you are unaware, unconscious of this conflict in which you exist. If you are unconscious of the conflict, that is, the battle that is taking place between that self and the environment, if you are unconscious of that battle, then why do you seek further remedies? Remain unconscious. Let the conditions themselves produce the necessary conflict, without your rushing after, invoking artificially, falsely, a conflict which does not exist in your mind and heart. And you create artificially a conflict because you are afraid you are missing something. Life will not miss you. If you think it does, something is wrong with you. Perhaps you are neurotic, not normal.

如何才能重新调整方向，避免在两个虚假的事物之间陷入持续的冲突？首先，在你寻求摆脱冲突的方法之前，你是否意识到自己正处于冲突之中？或者，即便意识到冲突的存在，你仅仅是在寻找一个避难所，一个不会引发更多冲突的庇护所？那么，让我们来思考一下，你想要的是一个不再产生冲突的庇护所，一个安全区，还是想要逃离当前的冲突，进入一个没有冲突的状态？又或者，你是否对自身所处的冲突浑然不觉？如果你对冲突——也就是自我与环境之间正在发生的斗争——浑然不觉，那么你又何必寻求其他的解决办法呢？保持这种浑然不觉的状态吧。让环境本身产生必要的冲突，而不是你急于求成，人为地、虚假地制造出一个并不存在于你心中的冲突。你之所以人为地制造冲突，是因为你害怕自己错过了什么。但生活并不会错过你。如果你这么认为，那说明你有问题。或许你患有神经质，而不是正常人。

If you are in conflict, you will not ask me for a method. Were I to give you a method you would merely be disciplining yourself according to that method, trying to imitate an ideal, a pattern which I have laid down and, therefore, destroying your own intelligence, whereas if you are really conscious of that conflict, in that consciousness suffering will become acute and in that acuteness, in that intensity, you will dissolve the cause of suffering, which is the lack of understanding of the environment.

如果你身处冲突之中，你不会向我寻求方法。如果我给你方法，你只会按照那方法约束自己，试图模仿我设定的理想模式，从而扼杀你自身的智慧。然而，如果你真正意识到这种冲突，在这种意识中，痛苦会变得尖锐，而在这种尖锐和强烈中，你将化解痛苦的根源——对环境缺乏理解。

You know we have lost all sense of living normally, simply, directly. To get back to that normality, that simplicity, that directness, you cannot follow methods, you cannot merely become automatic machines; and I am afraid most of us are seeking methods because we think that through them we shall realize fullness, stability, and permanency. To me methods lead to slow stagnation and decay and they have nothing to do with real spirituality, which is, after all, the summation of intelligence.

你知道，我们已经完全失去了正常、简单、直接的生活方式。要回归那种正常、简单、直接的状态，你不能墨守成规，也不能仅仅变成机器；恐怕我们大多数人都在追求方法，因为我们认为通过方法就能获得圆满、稳定和永恒。在我看来，方法只会导致缓慢的停滞和衰败，它们与真正的灵性毫无关系，而真正的灵性，归根结底，是智慧的总和。

Q : You speak of the necessity of a drastic revolution in the life of the individual. If he does not want to revolutionize his outward personal environment because of the suffering it would cause to his family and friends, will inward revolution lead him to the freedom from all conflict?

问：您谈到个人生活中需要一场彻底的变革。如果他因为担心给家人和朋友带来痛苦而不愿改变外在的个人环境，那么内在的变革能否让他摆脱一切冲突？

K : First of all, sirs, don’t you also feel that a drastic revolution in the life of the individual is necessary? Or are you merely satisfied with things as they are, with your ideas of progress, evolution, and your desire for attainment, with your longings and fluctuating pleasures? You know, the moment you begin to think, really begin to feel, you must have this burning desire for a drastic change, drastic revolution, complete reorientation of thinking. Now, if you feel that that is necessary, then neither family nor friends will stand in the way. Then there is neither an outward revolution nor an inward revolution; there is only revolution, change. But the moment you begin to limit it by saying, “I must not hurt my family, my friends, my priest, my capitalistic exploiter or state exploiter,” then you really don’t see the necessity for radical change, you merely seek a change of environment. In that there is merely lethargy, which creates further false environment and continues the conflict.

K：首先，先生们，难道你们不觉得个人生活需要一场彻底的变革吗？还是你们仅仅满足于现状，满足于你们对进步、进化以及成就的渴望，满足于你们的欲望和瞬息万变的快乐？要知道，一旦你开始思考，真正开始感受，你就会渴望一场彻底的改变，一场彻底的革命，一种思维方式的彻底重塑。如果你觉得这是必要的，那么家人和朋友都不会阻碍你。那时，既没有外在的革命，也没有内在的革命；只有革命，只有改变。但是，一旦你开始限制这种改变，说“我不能伤害我的家人、我的朋友、我的牧师、我的资本剥削者或国家剥削者”，那么你实际上就看不到彻底改变的必要性，你仅仅寻求改变环境。那样只会滋生惰性，从而制造出更多虚假的环境，并使冲突持续下去。

I think we give the rather false excuse that we must not hurt our families and our friends. You know when you want to do something vital, you do it, irrespective of your family and friends, don’t you? Then you don’t consider that you are going to hurt them. It is beyond your control; you feel so intensely, you think so completely that it carries you beyond the limitation of family circles, classified bondages. But you begin to consider family, friends, ideals, beliefs, traditions, the established order of things, only when you are still clinging to a particular safety, when there is not that inward richness, but merely the dependence on external stimulation for that inward richness. So if there is that full consciousness of suffering, brought about by conflict, then you are not held in the bondage of any particular orthodoxy, friends, or family. You want to find out the cause of that suffering, you want to find out the significance of the environment which creates that conflict; then in that there is no personality, no limited thought of the “I.” But it is only when you cling to that limited thought of the “I” that you have to consider how far you shall wander and how far you shall not wander.

我认为我们常常用“不能伤害家人和朋友”这种不太恰当的借口来搪塞。你知道，当你想要做一件至关重要的事情时，你会不顾家人和朋友的感受去做，对吗？那时你不会考虑会伤害他们。这超出了你的控制；你的感受如此强烈，你的思考如此彻底，以至于超越了家庭圈子和既定束缚的限制。但是，只有当你仍然执着于某种特定的安全感，当内心缺乏那种丰富的感悟，而仅仅依赖外部刺激来获得这种丰富感时，你才会开始考虑家庭、朋友、理想、信仰、传统以及既定的秩序。因此，如果你充分意识到冲突带来的痛苦，那么你就不会被任何特定的正统观念、朋友或家庭所束缚。你会想要找出痛苦的根源，想要找出造成冲突的环境的意义；那时，人格便不复存在，不再有“我”的局限。只有当你执着于“我”这种狭隘的观念时，你才需要考虑你将走多远，又将止步于何处。

Surely truth, or that Godhead of understanding, is not to be found by clinging either to family or tradition or habit. It is to be found only when you are completely naked, stripped of your longings, hopes, securities; and in that direct simplicity is the richness of life.

真理，或者说理解的神性，绝非依附于家庭、传统或习惯就能找到。它唯有在你彻底赤裸、剥离所有欲望、希望和安全感时才能寻得；而那份直接的纯粹，正是生命的丰富所在。

Q : Can you explain why environment started being false instead of true? What is the origin of all this mess and trouble?

问：你能解释一下为什么环境从真实变为虚假吗？这一切混乱和麻烦的根源是什么？

K : Who do you think created environment? Some mysterious God? Please, just a minute; who created environment, the social structure, the economic, the religious structure? We. Each one has contributed individually, until it has become collective, and the individual who has helped to create the collective now is lost in the collective, for it has become his mold, his environment. Through the desire for security—financial, moral, and spiritual—you have created a capitalistic environment in which there is nationality, class distinction, and exploitation. We have created it, you and I. This thing hasn’t miraculously come into being. You will again create another capitalistic, acquisitive system of a different kind, with a different nuance, with a different color, so long as you are seeking security. You may abolish this present pattern, but so long as there is possessiveness, you will create another capitalistic state, with a new phraseology, a new jargon.

K：你认为是谁创造了环境？某个神秘的神吗？请稍等片刻；是谁创造了环境、社会结构、经济结构、宗教结构？是我们。每个人都做出了个人贡献，最终汇聚成集体，而那些曾经帮助创造集体的人如今却迷失在集体之中，因为集体已经变成了他们的模样，他们的环境。出于对安全感——经济上的、道德上的和精神上的——的渴望，你们创造了一个资本主义环境，在这个环境中存在着民族性、阶级分化和剥削。是我们创造了它，你和我。它并非凭空而来。只要你们还在追求安全感，你们就会再次创造出另一种资本主义的、占有欲极强的体系，它或许有所不同，或许会有不同的细微差别，不同的色彩。你们或许可以废除现有的模式，但只要占有欲存在，你们就会创造出另一个资本主义国家，只不过会使用新的措辞，新的术语。

And the same thing applies to religions, with all their absurd ceremonies, exploitations, fears. Who has created them? You and I. Throughout the centuries we have created these things and yielded to them through fear. It is the individual who has created false environment everywhere. And he has become a slave, and that false condition has resulted in a false search for the security of that self-consciousness which you call the “I,” and hence, the constant battle between the “I” and the false environment.

同样的道理也适用于宗教，以及它们荒谬的仪式、剥削和恐惧。是谁创造了它们？是你和我。几个世纪以来，我们创造了这些东西，又因为恐惧而屈服于它们。正是个人在各处营造了虚假的环境。他沦为奴隶，而这种虚假的状态导致他错误地寻求所谓的“自我意识”的安全感，因此，才有了“自我”与虚假环境之间永无休止的斗争。

You want to know who has created this environment and all this appalling mess and trouble, because you want a redeemer to lift you out of that trouble and set you in a new heaven. Clinging to all your particular prejudices, hopes, fears, and preferences, you have individually created this environment, so individually you must break it down and not wait for a system to come and sweep it away. A system will probably come and sweep it away and then you will merely become slaves to that system. The communistic system may come in, and then probably you will be using new words, but having the same reactions, only in a different manner, with a different tempo.

你想知道是谁制造了这般环境，以及这一切可怕的混乱和麻烦，因为你渴望一位救赎者将你从困境中解救出来，带你进入新的天堂。你执着于自身的偏见、希望、恐惧和喜好，一手缔造了这般环境，因此，你必须独自打破它，而不是坐等某个体制来将其扫除。或许某个体制终会到来，将其扫除，而你最终只会沦为该体制的奴隶。共产主义体制或许会建立，届时你或许会换个说法，但反应却如出一辙，只是方式和节奏有所不同。

That is why I said the other day that if environment is driving you to a certain action, it is no longer righteous. It is only when there is action born out of the understanding of that environment that there is righteousness.

这就是为什么我前几天说，如果环境驱使你采取某种行动，那么这种行动就不再是正义的。只有当行动源于对环境的理解时，才是正义的。

So individually we must become conscious. I assure you, you will then individually create something immense, not a society which is merely holding to an ideal and, therefore, decaying, but a society that is constantly in movement, not coming to a culmination and dying. Individuals establish a goal, strive after its attainment, and after attaining, collapse. They try all the time to reach some goal and stay at that stage which they have attained. As the individual so the state—the state is trying all the time to reach an ideal, a goal, whereas to me the individual must be in constant movement, must ever be becoming, not seeking a culmination, not pursuing a goal. Then self-expression, which is society, will be ever in constant movement.

所以，我们每个人都必须觉醒。我向你们保证，你们每个人都将创造出伟大的事物，那不是一个仅仅固守理想而走向衰败的社会，而是一个不断进步、永不停息的社会，而不是一个最终走向终结、走向消亡的社会。个人设定目标，努力追求，最终却在达成目标后走向崩溃。他们总是试图达到某个目标，然后停滞在已达到的阶段。正如个人如此，国家亦然——国家总是试图达到某种理想、某个目标，而我认为，个人必须不断进步，必须不断成长，而不是追求终点，而不是追逐某个目标。如此，自我表达，也就是社会，才能永远处于不断进步的状态。

Q : Do you consider that karma is the interaction between the false environment and the false “I”?

问：您是否认为业力是虚假环境与虚假“自我”之间的相互作用？

K : You know karma is a Sanskrit word which means to act, to do, to work, and also it implies cause and effect. Now karma is the bondage, the reaction born out of the environment, which the mind has not understood. As I tried to explain yesterday, if we do not understand a particular condition, naturally the mind is burdened with that condition, with that lack of understanding; and with that lack of understanding we function and act and, therefore, create further burdens, greater limitations.

K：你知道，业力（karma）是一个梵语词，意思是行动、做事、工作，它也蕴含着因果关系。业力是一种束缚，是源于环境的、心智尚未理解的反作用。正如我昨天试图解释的那样，如果我们不理解某种特定的境况，心智自然会被这种境况、这种理解的缺失所束缚；而正是这种理解的缺失，让我们在行动中产生更多的负担，更大的局限。

So one has to find out what creates this lack of understanding, what prevents the individual from gathering the full significance of the environment, whether it be the past environment or the present. And to discover that significance, mind must really be free of prejudice. It is one of the most difficult things to be really free of a bias, of a temperament, of a twist; and to approach environment with a fresh openness, a directness, demands a great deal of perception. Most minds are biased through vanity, through the desire to impress others by being somebody, or through the desire to attain truth, or to escape from their environment, or expand their own consciousness—only they call this by a special spiritual name—or through their national prejudices. All these desires prevent the mind from perceiving directly the full worth of the environment; and as most minds are prejudiced, the first thing that one has to become conscious of is one’s own limitations. And when you begin to be conscious, there is conflict in that consciousness. When you know that you are really brutally proud or conceited, in the very consciousness of conceit it begins to dissipate, because you perceive the absurdity of it; but if you begin merely to cover it up, it creates further diseases, further false reactions.

因此，我们必须找出造成这种理解缺失的原因，找出阻碍个人充分领悟环境意义的根源，无论是过去的环境还是当下的环境。而要发现这种意义，心灵必须真正摆脱偏见。真正摆脱偏见、性情和固有观念是最难的事情之一；以一种全新的开放和直接的态度去面对环境，需要极强的感知力。大多数人的心灵都受到虚荣心、渴望通过出人头地来给人留下深刻印象、渴望获得真理、渴望逃离环境、渴望扩展自身意识（他们用一个特殊的精神名称来称呼这种意识）或渴望民族偏见的影响。所有这些欲望都阻碍了心灵直接感知环境的全部价值；由于大多数人的心灵都带有偏见，因此首先要意识到的就是自身的局限性。而当你开始意识到这一点时，你的意识中就会产生冲突。当你意识到自己真的骄傲自大时，这种自负感就会在自负的意识中开始消散，因为你意识到了它的荒谬之处；但如果你只是开始掩盖它，它就会造成更多的问题，更多的错误反应。

So to live each moment now without the burden of the past or of the present, without that crippling memory created by the lack of understanding, mind must ever meet things anew. It is fatal to meet life with the burden of certainty, with the conceit of knowledge, because, after all, knowledge is merely a thing of the past. So when you come to that life with a freshness, then you will know what it is to live without conflict, without this continual straining effort. Then you wander far on the floods of life.

因此，为了摆脱过去和现在的重负，摆脱因缺乏理解而产生的沉重记忆，活在当下，心灵必须不断以全新的视角看待事物。带着确定性的重负和知识的自负去面对生活是致命的，因为归根结底，知识不过是过去的东西。当你以清新的心态拥抱生活时，你就会明白什么是无冲突的生活，什么是无需持续的挣扎。那时，你就能在人生的洪流中自由徜徉。

Ojai, California, June 18, 1934

加利福尼亚州奥海，1934年6月18日

#↩

LIVING IN ECSTASY

生活在狂喜之中

To me there is a reality, an immense living truth; and to comprehend that, there must be utter simplicity of thought. What is simple is infinitely subtle, what is simple is greatly delicate. There is a great subtlety, an infinite subtlety and delicacy, and if you use words merely as a means of getting to that delicacy, to that simplicity of thought, then I am afraid you will not comprehend what I want to convey. But if you would use the significance of words as a bridge to cross, then words will not become an illusion in which the mind is lost.

对我而言，存在着一种现实，一种浩瀚无垠的鲜活真理；而要理解它，必须拥有纯粹的思维。简单之物蕴含着无限的精妙，简单之物极其微妙。其中蕴含着巨大的微妙，无限的微妙与微妙，如果你仅仅将语言作为抵达这种微妙、抵达这种思维简单的手段，那么恐怕你将无法理解我想要表达的。但如果你将语言的意义作为一座桥梁来跨越，那么语言就不会成为迷失心灵的幻象。

I say there is this living reality, call it God, truth, or what you like, and it cannot be found or realized through search. Where there is the implication of search, there must be contrast and duality; whenever mind is seeking, it must inevitably imply a division, a distinction, a contrast, which does not mean that mind must be contented, mind must be stagnant. There is that delicate poise, which is neither contentment, nor this ceaseless effort born of search, of this desire to attain, to achieve; and in that delicacy of poise lies simplicity, not the simplicity of having but few clothes or few possessions. I am not talking of such simplicity, which is merely a crude form, but of simplicity born of this delicacy of thought, in which there is neither search nor contentment.

我说，存在着这样一种鲜活的现实，你可以称之为上帝、真理，或者任何你喜欢的称呼，它无法通过寻觅来发现或领悟。凡是蕴含着寻觅之意的地方，就必然存在着对比和二元性；每当心灵寻求时，就必然包含着分离、区分和对比，但这并不意味着心灵就应该满足，就应该停滞不前。有一种微妙的平衡，它既非满足，也非源于寻觅、源于渴望获得、成就的无休止的努力；而这种微妙的平衡中蕴含着一种纯粹的纯粹，并非指衣着简朴或拥有少量财物。我所说的并非那种粗浅的纯粹，而是指源于这种微妙思维的纯粹，在这种纯粹中，既无寻觅，亦无满足。

As I said, search implies duality, contrast. Now where there is contrast, duality, there must be identification with one of the opposites, and from this there arises compulsion. When we say we search, our mind is rejecting something and seeking a substitute that will satisfy it, and thereby it creates duality, and from this there arises compulsion. That is, the choice of the one is the overcoming of the other, isn’t it?

正如我所说，寻找意味着二元性、对比。而凡是有对比、有二元性的地方，就必然会认同其中一方，由此便产生了强迫。当我们说我们在寻找时，我们的心其实是在拒绝某些东西，并寻找一个能满足它的替代品，从而创造了二元性，而由此便产生了强迫。也就是说，选择其中一方就意味着克服另一方，不是吗？

When we say we seek out or cultivate a new value, it is but the overcoming of that in which the mind is already caught up, which is its opposite. This choice is based on attraction to one or fear of the other, and this clinging through attraction, or rejection through fear, creates influence over the mind. Influence then is the negation of understanding and can exist only where there is division, the psychological division from which there arise distinctions such as class, national, religious, sex. That is, when the mind is trying to overcome, it must create duality, and that very duality negates understanding and creates the distinctions. That duality influences the mind, and hence a mind influenced by duality cannot understand the significance of environment or the significance of the cause of conflict. These psychological influences are merely reactions to environment from that center of “I” consciousness, of like and dislike, of antitheses, and naturally where there are antitheses, opposites, there can be no comprehension. From this distinction there arises the classification of influences as beneficial and evil. So as long as mind is influenced—and influence is born of attraction, opposites, antitheses—there must be the domination or compulsion of love, of intellect, of society; and this influence must be a hindrance to that understanding which is beauty, truth, and love itself.

当我们说我们寻求或培养一种新的价值观时，这不过是克服心智早已执着于其对立面的事物。这种选择基于对某一方的吸引或对另一方的恐惧，而这种因吸引而产生的执着，或因恐惧而产生的排斥，都会对心智产生影响。影响是对理解的否定，它只能存在于分裂之处，这种分裂源于心理层面，并由此产生了阶级、民族、宗教、性别等差异。也就是说，当心智试图克服某种事物时，它必然会创造二元性，而正是这种二元性否定了理解，并创造了各种差异。这种二元性影响着心智，因此，受二元性影响的心智无法理解环境的意义，也无法理解冲突根源的意义。这些心理影响仅仅是“我”意识中心对环境的反应，是好与坏、对立的体现。自然而然地，在存在对立面的地方，就不可能有理解。正是基于这种区分，才产生了对影响的分类，即有益的影响和有害的影响。所以，只要思想受到影响——而影响源于吸引力、对立面、对立面——就必然存在爱、理智、社会的支配或强迫；而这种影响必然会阻碍对美、真理和爱本身的理解。

Now, if you can become aware of this influence, then you can discern its cause. Most people seem to be aware superficially, not at the greatest depth. It is only when there is awareness at the greatest depth of consciousness, of thought and emotion, that you can discern the division that is created through influence, which negates understanding.

如果你能意识到这种影响，就能辨别其根源。大多数人似乎只是肤浅地意识到这一点，而没有深入探究。只有当意识、思想和情感达到最深层次时，你才能辨别出这种影响所造成的隔阂，这种隔阂会阻碍理解。

Questioner : After listening to your talk about memory, I have completely lost mine, and I find I cannot remember my huge debts. I feel blissful. Is this liberation?

提问者：听了您关于记忆的演讲后，我的记忆力完全丧失了，我发现自己竟然记不起自己欠下的巨额债务。我感到无比幸福。这是解脱吗？

Krishnamurti : Ask the person to whom you owe the money. I am afraid that there is some confusion with regard to what I have been trying to say concerning memory. If you rely on memory as a guide to conduct, as a means of activity in life, then that memory must impede your action, your conduct, because then that action or conduct is merely the result of calculation and, therefore, it has no spontaneity, no richness, no fullness of life. It does not mean that you must forget your debts. You cannot forget the past. You cannot blot it out of your mind. That is an impossibility. Subconsciously it will exist, but if that subconscious, dormant memory is influencing you unconsciously, is molding your action, your conduct, your whole outlook on life, then that influence must ever be creating further limitations, imposing further burdens on the functioning of intelligence.

克里希那穆提：去问问你欠钱的人。恐怕大家对我之前关于记忆的论述有些误解。如果你依赖记忆作为行为准则，作为生活活动的手段，那么记忆必然会阻碍你的行动和行为，因为那样一来，你的行动或行为就仅仅是计算的结果，因此缺乏自发性、丰富性和生命力。这并不意味着你必须忘记你的债务。你无法忘记过去，也无法将它从记忆中抹去。那是不可能的。它会在潜意识中存在，但如果这种潜意识中沉睡的记忆在无意识中影响着你，塑造着你的行动、你的行为，以及你对人生的整个看法，那么这种影响必然会不断造成限制，加重智力的负担。

For example, I have recently come from India; I have been to Australia and New Zealand, where I met various people, had many ideas and saw many sights. I can’t forget these, though the memory of them may fade. But the reaction to the past may impede my full comprehension in the present; it may hinder the intelligent functioning of my mind. That is, if my experiences and remembrances of the past are becoming hindrances in the present through their reaction, then I cannot comprehend or live fully, intensely, in the present.

例如，我最近刚从印度回来；我去过澳大利亚和新西兰，在那里我结识了形形色色的人，获得了许多想法，也欣赏了许多美景。我无法忘记这些，尽管记忆可能会逐渐消退。但是，对过去的种种反应可能会妨碍我对当下的充分理解；它可能会阻碍我思维的正常运转。也就是说，如果我对过去的经历和记忆因为其反应而成为当下的阻碍，那么我就无法充分、深刻地理解或体验当下。

You react to the past because the present has lost its significance, or because you want to avoid the present; so you go back to the past and live in that emotional thrill, in that reaction of surging memory, because the present has little value. So when you say, “I have completely lost my memory,” I am afraid you are fit for only one place. You cannot lose memory, but by living completely in the present, in the fullness of the moment, you become conscious of all the subconscious entanglements of memory, the dormant hopes and longings which surge forward and prevent you from functioning intelligently in the present. If you are aware of that, if you are aware of that hindrance, aware of it at its depth, not superficially, then the dormant subconscious memory, which is but the lack of understanding and incompleteness of living, disappears and, therefore, you meet each movement of environment, each swiftness of thought, anew.

你之所以对过去做出反应，是因为当下失去了意义，或者是因为你想逃避当下；所以你回到过去，沉浸在那种情绪的刺激中，沉浸在记忆涌动的反应中，因为当下对你来说毫无价值。所以，当你说“我完全失去了记忆”时，恐怕你只能待在一个地方。你不可能失去记忆，但如果你完全活在当下，活在当下的充实之中，你就会意识到所有潜意识中记忆的纠缠，那些沉睡的希望和渴望涌现出来，阻碍你理性地活在当下。如果你意识到这一点，如果你意识到这种阻碍，并且是深入地意识到它，而不是肤浅地意识到它，那么沉睡的潜意识记忆——它不过是对生活的理解不足和不完整——就会消失，因此，你就能以全新的视角去面对环境的每一个变化，每一个思绪的飞速运转。

Q : You say that the complete understanding of the outer and inner environment of the individual releases him from bondage and sorrow. Now, even in that state, how can one free himself from the indescribable sorrow which in the nature of things is caused by the death of someone he really loves?

问：您说，对个人的外部和内部环境的全面了解能使他从束缚和悲伤中解脱出来。那么，即使到了那种境界，一个人又该如何摆脱因挚爱之人离世而带来的难以言喻的悲痛呢？

K : What is the cause of suffering in this case? And what is it that we call suffering? Isn’t suffering merely a shock to the mind to awaken it to its own insufficiency? The recognition of that insufficiency creates what we call sorrow. Suppose that you have been relying on your son or your husband or your wife to satisfy that insufficiency, that incompleteness; by the loss of that person whom you love, there is created the full consciousness of that emptiness, of that void, and out of that consciousness comes sorrow, and you say, “I have lost somebody.”

K：在这种情况下，痛苦的根源是什么？我们所说的痛苦又是什么？痛苦难道不只是对心灵的一种冲击，使它意识到自身的不足吗？对这种不足的认知会产生我们所说的悲伤。假设你一直依靠你的儿子、丈夫或妻子来填补这种不足，这种不完整；失去你所爱的人，让你充分意识到那种空虚，那种缺失，而悲伤就源于这种意识，你会说：“我失去了某人。”

So through death there is, first of all, the full consciousness of emptiness, which you have been carefully evading. Hence, where there is dependence there must be emptiness, shallowness, insufficiency and, therefore, sorrow and pain. We don’t want to recognize that; we don’t see that that is the fundamental cause. So we begin to say, “I miss my friend, my husband, my wife, my child. How am I to overcome this loss? How am I to overcome this sorrow?”

所以，死亡首先带来的是对空性的彻底觉知，而你一直都在刻意回避它。因此，凡是有依赖的地方，就必然有空性、肤浅、不足，因而也必然有悲伤和痛苦。我们不愿承认这一点；我们看不到这才是根本原因。所以我们开始说：“我想念我的朋友、我的丈夫、我的妻子、我的孩子。我该如何克服这种失去？我该如何克服这种悲伤？”

Now, all overcoming is but substitution. In that there is no understanding and, therefore, there can only be further sorrow, though momentarily you may find a substitution that will completely put the mind to sleep. If you don’t seek an overcoming, then you turn to seances, mediums, or take shelter in the scientific proof that life continues after death. So you begin to discover various means of escape and substitution, which momentarily relieve you from suffering, whereas if there were the cessation of this desire to overcome and if there were really the desire to understand—to find out, fundamentally—what causes pain and sorrow, then you would discover that so long as there is loneliness, shallowness, emptiness, insufficiency, which in its outer expression is dependence, there must be pain. And you cannot fill that insufficiency by overcoming obstacles, by substitutions, by escaping or by accumulating, which is merely the cunning of the mind lost in the pursuit of gain.

如今，一切所谓的克服都不过是替代。其中并无真正的理解，因此只会带来更多的痛苦，尽管你或许能暂时找到某种替代，使你的心神彻底沉睡。如果你不寻求克服，你就会转向降神会、灵媒，或者沉溺于“死后生命延续”的科学论证。于是，你开始探索各种逃避和替代的途径，这些途径能暂时缓解你的痛苦。然而，如果你不再执着于克服，而是真正渴望理解——从根本上探寻——痛苦和悲伤的根源，你就会发现，只要存在孤独、浅薄、空虚和匮乏（其外在表现为依赖），痛苦就必然存在。而你无法通过克服障碍、寻求替代、逃避或积累来填补这种匮乏，后者不过是迷失在追求利益中的心智的狡诈罢了。

Suffering is merely that high, intense clarity of thought and emotion which forces you to recognize things as they are. But this does not mean acceptance, resignation. When you see things as they are in the mirror of truth, which is intelligence, then there is a joy, an ecstasy; in that there is no duality, no sense of loss, no division. I assure you this is not theoretical. If you consider what I am now saying, with my answer to the first question about memory, you will see how memory creates greater and greater dependence, the continual looking back to an event emotionally, to get a reaction from it, which prevents the full expression of intelligence in the present.

苦难不过是那种高度而强烈的清晰的思维和情感，它迫使你认清事物的本来面目。但这并不意味着接受或屈服。当你透过真理之镜——也就是智慧——看到事物的本来面目时，便会感受到喜悦和狂喜；在那种境界中，没有二元对立，没有失落感，没有分裂。我向你保证，这并非空谈。如果你结合我刚才对第一个关于记忆的问题的回答来思考我刚才所说的，你就会明白记忆是如何造成越来越大的依赖性的，它让我们不断地在情感上回溯过去，试图从中获得某种反应，而这恰恰阻碍了我们在当下充分运用智慧。

Q : What suggestion or advice would you give to one who is hindered by strong sexual desire?

问：对于受强烈性欲困扰的人，您有什么建议或意见？

K : After all, where there is no creative expression of life, we give undue importance to sex, which becomes an acute problem. So the question is not what advice or suggestion I would give, or how one can overcome passion, sexual desire, but how to release that creative living, and not merely tackle one part of it, which is sex; that is, how to understand the wholeness, the completeness of life.

K：毕竟，如果生活中缺乏创造性的表达，我们就会过分重视性，这会成为一个棘手的问题。所以问题不在于我会给出什么建议，或者如何克服激情和性欲，而在于如何释放那种创造性的生活，而不仅仅是处理其中的一部分——性；也就是说，如何理解生活的完整性和圆满性。

Now, through modern education, through circumstances and environment, you are driven to do something which you hate. You are repelled, but you are forced to do it because of your lack of proper equipment, proper training. In your work you are being prevented by circumstances, by conditions, from expressing yourself fundamentally, creatively, and so there must be an outlet; and this outlet becomes the sex problem or the drink problem or some idiotic, inane problem. All these outlets become problems.

如今，在现代教育、环境和境遇的影响下，你被迫去做你厌恶的事情。你感到厌恶，却又因为缺乏必要的工具和训练而不得不去做。在工作中，种种境遇和条件限制了你进行根本性的、创造性的自我表达，因此你必须找到一个出口；而这个出口就变成了性问题、酗酒问题，或者其他一些愚蠢无稽的问题。所有这些出口最终都会变成问题。

Or you are artistically inclined. There are very few artists, but you may be inclined, and that inclination is continually being perverted, twisted, thwarted, so that you have no means of real self-expression and thus, undue importance comes to be given either to sex or to some religious mania. Or your ambitions are thwarted, curtailed, hindered, and so again undue importance is given to those things that should be normal. So, until you understand comprehensively your religious, political, economic, and social desires, and their hindrances, the natural functions of life will be of immense importance, and the first place in your life. Hence, all the innumerable problems of greed, of possessiveness, of sex, of social and racial distinctions have their false measure and false value. But if you were to deal with life, not in parts but as a whole, comprehensively, creatively, with intelligence, then you would see that these problems, which are enervating the mind and destroying creative living, disappear, and then intelligence functions normally, and in that there is an ecstasy.

或许你天生具有艺术天赋。艺术家寥寥无几，但你可能确实有此天赋，而这种天赋却不断遭到扭曲、阻碍和阻挠，以致你无法真正表达自我，于是，你便过度重视性或某种宗教狂热。又或许你的抱负遭到挫折、限制和阻碍，于是，你又过度重视那些本应正常的事情。因此，在你全面理解你的宗教、政治、经济和社会欲望及其阻碍之前，生命的自然功能将至关重要，并占据你生活的首要位置。由此可见，所有关于贪婪、占有欲、性、社会和种族差异的无数问题，都具有其虚假的衡量标准和价值。但是，如果你以整体、全面、创造性和智慧的方式处理生活，而不是将生活分割开来，那么你就会发现，这些削弱心智、破坏创造性生活的问题都会消失，然后智力就能正常运作，而其中就蕴含着一种狂喜。

Q : I have been under the impression that I have been putting your ideas into action; but I have no joy in life, no enthusiasm for any pursuit. My attempts at awareness have not cleared my confusion, nor have they brought any change or vitality into my life. My living has no more meaning for me now than it had when I started to listen to you seven years ago. What is wrong with me?

问：我一直以为自己已经将您的理念付诸实践；但我却感觉不到生活的乐趣，对任何事都提不起兴趣。我努力提升自我认知，却既没有解开我的困惑，也没有给我的生活带来任何改变或活力。如今，我的生活对我来说和七年前刚开始听您讲道时一样，毫无意义。我到底怎么了？

K : I wonder if the questioner has, first of all, understood what I have been saying before trying to put my ideas into action. And why should he put my ideas into action? And what are my ideas? And why are they my ideas? I am not giving you a mold or a code by which you can live, or a system which you can follow. All that I am saying is, that to live creatively, enthusiastically, intelligently, vitally, intelligence must function. That intelligence is perverted, hindered, by what one calls memory, and I have explained what I mean by that, so I won’t go into it again. So long as there is this constant battle to achieve, so long as mind is influenced, there must be duality, and hence, pain, struggle; and our search for truth or for reality is but an escape from that pain.

K：我首先想知道提问者是否理解了我刚才所说的内容，然后再试图将我的想法付诸实践。他为什么要实践我的想法？我的想法是什么？为什么它们是我的想法？我不是在给你一个可以照搬的模式或准则，也不是在给你一套可以遵循的体系。我只是想说，要想创造性地、热情地、智慧地、充满活力地生活，智力必须发挥作用。而这种智力却被所谓的记忆所扭曲和阻碍，我已经解释过我的意思，所以不再赘述。只要存在这种不断追求成功的斗争，只要思维受到影响，就必然存在二元性，因此也必然存在痛苦和挣扎；而我们对真理或现实的追寻，只不过是为了逃避这种痛苦。

And so I say, become aware that your effort, your struggle, your impinging memories are destroying your intelligence. To become aware is not to be superficially conscious, but to go into the full depth of consciousness so as not to leave undiscovered one unconscious reaction. All this demands thought; all this demands an alertness of mind and heart, not a mind that is cluttered up with beliefs, creeds, and ideals. Most minds are burdened with these and with the desire to follow. As you become conscious of your burden, don’t say you mustn’t have ideals, you mustn’t have creeds, and repeat all the rest of the jargon. The very “must” creates another doctrine, another creed; merely become conscious and in the intensity of that consciousness, in the intensity of awareness, in that flame you will create such crisis, such conflict, that that very conflict itself will dissolve the hindrance.

所以我说，要意识到你的努力、你的挣扎、你挥之不去的记忆正在摧毁你的智慧。意识到这一点并非肤浅的意识，而是深入意识的深处，不放过任何一个无意识的反应。这一切都需要思考；这一切都需要心灵的警觉，而不是被信仰、信条和理想所充斥的头脑。大多数人的头脑都背负着这些重担，并渴望追随它们。当你意识到自己的重担时，不要说你不能有理想，你不能有信条，然后重复其他那些陈词滥调。“必须”这个词本身就会创造出另一种教条，另一种信条；只需觉察，在觉察的强度中，在觉知的强度中，在那火焰中，你将创造出如此巨大的危机，如此巨大的冲突，而正是这冲突本身将消除阻碍。

I know some people come here year after year, and I try to explain these ideas in different ways each year, but I am afraid there is very little thought among the people who say, “We have been listening to you for seven years.” I mean by thought, not mere intellectual reasoning, which is but ashes, but that poise between emotion and reason, between affection and thought; and that poise is not influenced, is not affected, by the conflict of the opposites. But if there is neither the capacity to think clearly, nor the intensity of feeling, how can you awaken, how can there be poise, how can there be this alertness, this awareness? So life becomes futile, inane, worthless.

我知道有些人年复一年地来这里，我也每年都尝试用不同的方式解释这些理念，但我担心那些说“我们已经听了你七年了”的人，其实并没有真正思考过。我所说的思考，并非仅仅是空洞的理性推理，那不过是灰烬，而是情感与理性、爱与思辨之间的平衡；这种平衡不受对立面冲突的影响。但如果既没有清晰思考的能力，也没有强烈的情感，又怎能觉醒？又怎能拥有平衡？又怎能拥有这种警觉和觉察？如此一来，生命便会变得徒劳、空洞、毫无价值。

Hence, the very first thing to do, if I may suggest it, is to find out why you are thinking in a certain way, and why you are feeling in a certain manner. Don’t try to alter it, don’t try to analyze your thoughts and your emotions; but become conscious of why you are thinking in a particular groove and from what motive you act. Although you can discover the motive through analysis, although you may find out something through analysis, it will not be real; it will be real only when you are intensely aware at the moment of the functioning of your thought and emotion; then you will see their extraordinary subtlety, their fine delicacy. So long as you have a “must” and a “must not,” in this compulsion you will never discover that swift wandering of thought and emotion. And I am sure you have been brought up in the school of “must” and “must not” and hence, you have destroyed thought and feeling. You have been bound and crippled by systems, methods, by your teachers. So leave all those “musts” and “must nots.” This does not mean that there shall be licentiousness, but become aware of a mind that is ever saying, “I must,” and “I must not.” Then as a flower blossoms forth of a morning, so intelligence happens, is there, functioning, creating comprehension.

因此，如果我可以提建议的话，首先要做的是弄清楚你为什么会以某种方式思考，为什么会有某种感受。不要试图改变它，不要试图分析你的想法和情绪；而是要意识到你为什么会陷入某种特定的思维模式，以及你的行为动机是什么。虽然你可以通过分析发现动机，虽然你可以通过分析发现一些东西，但这并非真实；只有当你全然觉察到你的思想和情绪运作的当下，它才是真实的；那时你才能看到它们非凡的微妙之处，它们精妙的本质。只要你心中有“必须”和“禁止”，在这种束缚下，你永远无法发现思想和情绪的灵动游移。我相信你是在“必须”和“禁止”的教条下长大的，因此，你扼杀了思想和情感。你被各种体系、方法和你的老师束缚和限制。所以，放下所有这些“必须”和“禁止”。这并非意味着要放纵情欲，而是要意识到内心总在说着“我必须”和“我不能”。如此，如同清晨花朵绽放，智慧亦然，它存在、运作，创造理解。

Q : The artist is sometimes mentioned as one who has this understanding of which you speak, at least while working creatively. But if someone disturbs or crosses him, he may react violently, excusing his reaction as a manifestation of temperament. Obviously he is not living completely at the moment. Does he really understand if he so easily slips back into self-consciousness?

问：人们有时会说，艺术家具备你所说的这种理解，至少在创作时是如此。但如果有人打扰或冒犯他，他可能会做出过激反应，并将这种反应归咎于自己的性情。显然，他并没有完全活在当下。如果他如此轻易地又陷入自我意识的束缚，他真的理解这种理解吗？

K : Who is that person whom you call an artist? A man who is momentarily creative? To me he is not an artist. The man who merely at rare moments has this creative impulse and expresses that creativeness through perfection of technique, surely you would not call him an artist. To me, the true artist is one who lives completely, harmoniously, who does not divide his art from living, whose very life is that expression, whether it be a picture, music, or his behavior; who has not divorced his expression on a canvas or in music or in stone from his daily conduct, daily living. That demands the highest intelligence, highest harmony. To me the true artist is the man who has that harmony. He may express it on canvas, or he may talk, or he may paint; or he may not express it at all, he may feel it. But all this demands that exquisite poise, that intensity of awareness and, therefore, his expression is not divorced from the daily continuity of living.

K：你所谓的艺术家究竟是什么样的人？是那种偶尔迸发出创作灵感的人吗？在我看来，他算不上艺术家。那种只是偶尔拥有创作冲动，并通过精湛的技艺来表达这种灵感的人，你肯定不会称他为艺术家。在我看来，真正的艺术家是生活完整和谐的人，他不会将艺术与生活割裂开来，他的生活本身就是艺术的表达，无论是绘画、音乐还是言行举止；他不会将画布上、音乐中或石刻上的表达与日常生活脱节。这需要极高的智慧和极致的和谐。在我看来，真正的艺术家是拥有这种和谐的人。他或许会用画笔表达，或许会用言语，或许会用绘画；或许他根本不会表达，只是用心感受。但所有这些都需要那种精妙的平衡感和高度的觉察力，因此，他的表达与日常生活的连续性密不可分。

Ojai, California, June 29, 1934

加利福尼亚州奥海，1934年6月29日

#↩

TO BE A TRUE HUMAN BEING

做一个真正的人

What we call happiness or ecstasy is, to me, creative thinking. And creative thinking is the infinite movement of thought, emotion, and action. That is, when thought, which is emotion, which is action itself, is unimpeded in its movement, is not compelled or influenced or bound by an idea, and does not proceed from the background of tradition or habit, then that movement is creative. So long as thought—and I won’t repeat each time emotion and action—so long as thought is circumscribed, held by a fixed idea, or merely adjusts itself to a background or condition and, therefore, becomes limited, such thought is not creative.

在我看来，我们所谓的幸福或狂喜，其实就是创造性思维。而创造性思维，是思想、情感和行动的无限流动。也就是说，当思想——即情感，即行动本身——不受阻碍地自由流动，不受任何观念的束缚、影响或限制，也不受传统或习惯的制约时，这种流动便是创造性的。只要思想——我不再赘述情感和行动——受到限制，被固定的观念束缚，或者仅仅为了适应某种背景或条件而变得局限，这样的思想就不是创造性的。

So the question which every thoughtful person puts to himself is how can he awaken this creative thinking; because when there is this creative thinking, which is infinite movement, then there can be no idea of a limitation, a conflict.

因此，每个有思想的人都会问自己，如何才能唤醒这种创造性思维；因为当有了这种创造性思维，也就是无限的运动时，就不会有限制、冲突的概念。

Now this movement of creative thinking does not seek in its expression a result, an achievement; its results and expressions are not its culmination. It has no culmination or goal, for it is eternally in movement. Most minds are seeking a culmination, a goal, an achievement, and are molding themselves upon the idea of success, and such thought, such thinking is continually limiting itself, whereas if there is no idea of achievement but only the continual movement of thought as understanding, as intelligence, then that movement of thought is creative. That is, creative thinking ceases when mind is crippled by adjustment through influence, or when it functions with the background of a tradition which it has not understood, or from a fixed point, like an animal tied to a post. So long as this limitation, this adjustment, exists, there cannot be creative thinking, intelligence, which alone is freedom.

这种创造性思维的运动并不追求结果或成就；它的结果和表达并非其最终目标。它没有终点或目标，因为它永恒地处于运动之中。大多数人的思维都在追求终点、目标和成就，并试图将自己塑造成成功的模样，而这种想法、这种思维方式不断地限制着自身。然而，如果思维中没有成就的观念，只有作为理解和智慧的持续运动，那么这种思维运动就是创造性的。也就是说，当思维因外在影响而受到束缚，或在其不理解的传统背景下运作，或像被拴在柱子上的动物一样固定在一个固定点上时，创造性思维就会停止。只要这种限制、这种束缚存在，就不可能存在创造性思维和智慧，而唯有创造性思维和智慧才是自由。

This creative movement of thought never seeks a result or comes to a culmination, because result or culmination is always the outcome of alternate cessation and movement, whereas if there is no search for a result, but only continual movement of thought, then that is creative thinking.

这种创造性的思维运动从不追求结果或达到顶峰，因为结果或顶峰总是交替停止和运动的结果，而如果不追求结果，只有持续的思维运动，那就是创造性思维。

Again, creative thinking is free of division, which creates conflict between thought, emotion, and action. And division exists only when there is the search for a goal, when there is adjustment and the complacency of certainty.

再次强调，创造性思维不受割裂的影响，而割裂会在思想、情感和行动之间造成冲突。只有当人们追求目标、做出调整并安于现状时，割裂才会出现。

Action is this movement which is itself thought and emotion, as I explained. This action is the relationship between the individual and society. It is conduct, work, cooperation, which we call fulfillment. That is, when mind is functioning without seeking a culmination, a goal, and, therefore, thinking creatively, that thinking is action, which is the relationship between the individual and society. Now if this movement of thought is clear, simple, direct, spontaneous, profound, then there is no conflict in the individual against society, for action then is the very expression of this living, creative movement.

正如我所解释的，行动本身就是思想和情感的运动。这种行动是个人与社会之间的关系。它是行为、工作、合作，我们称之为成就。也就是说，当思维运作而不追求终点或目标，因而具有创造性思维时，这种思维就是行动，即个人与社会之间的关系。如果这种思维运动清晰、简洁、直接、自发、深刻，那么个人与社会之间就不会存在冲突，因为行动正是这种鲜活的、创造性运动的体现。

So to me there is no art of thinking, there is only creative thinking. There is no technique of thinking, but only spontaneous creative functioning of intelligence, which is the harmony of reason, emotion, and action, not divided or divorced from each other.

所以在我看来，没有所谓的思考艺术，只有创造性的思考。没有所谓的思考技巧，只有自发的、创造性的智力运作，它是理性、情感和行动的和谐统一，三者并非彼此割裂或分离。

Now this thinking and feeling, without a search for a reward, a result, is true experiment, isn’t it? In real experiencing, real experimenting, there cannot be the search for result, because this experimenting is the movement of creative thought. To experiment, mind must be continually freeing itself from the environment with which it conflicts in its movement, the environment which we call the past. There can be no creative thinking if mind is hindered by the search for a reward, by the pursuit of a goal.

这种不追求回报、不追求结果的思考和感受，才是真正的实验，不是吗？在真正的体验和实验中，不可能存在对结果的追求，因为这种实验本身就是创造性思维的运动。为了进行实验，心灵必须不断地从与之冲突的环境——我们称之为“过去”的环境——中解放出来。如果心灵被对回报的追求、对目标的执着所束缚，就不可能产生创造性思维。

When the mind and heart are seeking a result or a gain, thereby complacency and stagnation, there must be practice, an overcoming, a discipline, out of which comes conflict. Most people think that by practicing a certain idea they will release creative thinking. Now, practice, if you come to observe it, ponder over it, is nothing but the result of duality. And an action born of this duality must perpetuate that distinction between mind and heart, and such action becomes merely the expression of a calculated, logical, self-protective conclusion. If there is this practice of self-discipline, or this continual domination or influence by circumstances, then practice is merely an alteration, a change toward an end; it is merely action within the confines of the limited thought which you call self-consciousness. So practice does not bring about creative thinking.

当心灵追求结果或利益，从而陷入自满和停滞时，就必须进行练习、克服困难、培养自律，而冲突正是由此产生的。大多数人认为，通过实践某种理念，就能激发创造性思维。然而，如果你仔细观察、思考，就会发现练习不过是二元对立的结果。而源于这种二元对立的行动必然会强化心灵与头脑之间的隔阂，这样的行动最终只会沦为一种经过深思熟虑、逻辑严密、自我保护式的结论。如果存在这种自我约束的练习，或者持续受到环境的支配或影响，那么练习就仅仅是一种改变，一种朝着某个目标迈进的转变；它仅仅是在你称之为“自我意识”的有限思维框架内进行的行动。因此，练习并不能带来创造性思维。

To think creatively is to bring about harmony between mind, emotion, and action. That is, if you are convinced of an action, without the search of a reward at the end, then that action, being the result of intelligence, releases all hindrances that have been placed on the mind through the lack of understanding.

创造性思维的本质在于协调思想、情感和行动。也就是说，如果你确信某个行动是正确的，而不追求最终的回报，那么这个行动作为智慧的产物，就能消除所有因缺乏理解而加诸于心灵的障碍。

Where the mind and heart are held by fear, by lack of understanding, by compulsion, such a mind, though it can think within the confines, within the limitations of that fear, is not really thinking, and its action must ever throw up new barriers. Therefore, its capacity to think is ever being limited. But if the mind frees itself through the understanding of circumstances and, therefore, acts, then that very action is creative thinking.

当心灵被恐惧、无知和强迫所束缚时，即使它能在恐惧的局限内思考，也并非真正意义上的思考，其行动必然会不断突破新的障碍。因此，它的思考能力始终受到限制。然而，如果心灵能够通过理解环境而获得解脱，并因此采取行动，那么这种行动本身就是创造性的思考。

Questioner : Will you please give an example of the practical exercise of constant awareness and choice in everyday life?

提问者：请您举例说明在日常生活中如何进行持续的觉察和选择的实际练习？

Krishnamurti : Would you ask that question if there were a poisonous snake in your room? Then you wouldn’t ask, “How am I to keep awake? How am I to be intensely aware?” You ask that question only when you are not sure that there is a poisonous snake in your room. Either you are wholly unconscious of it, or you want to play with that snake, you want to enjoy its pain and its delights.

克里希那穆提：如果你的房间里有一条毒蛇，你还会问这个问题吗？那样的话，你就不会问“我该如何保持清醒？我该如何保持高度警觉？”只有当你不确定房间里是否有毒蛇时，你才会问这个问题。要么你对此完全无知，要么你想和那条蛇玩耍，你想享受它的痛苦和快感。

Please follow this. There cannot be awareness, that alertness of mind and emotion, so long as mind is still caught up in both pain and pleasure. That is, when an experience gives you pain and at the same time gives you pleasure, you do nothing about it. You act only when the pain is greater than the pleasure, but if the pleasure is greater, you do nothing at all about it, because there is no acute conflict. It is only when pain overbalances pleasure, is more acute than pleasure, that you demand an action.

请谨记这一点。只要心念仍被痛苦和快乐所束缚，就无法觉察到心智和情绪的清醒。也就是说，当某种经历既带给你痛苦又带给你快乐时，你不会采取任何行动。只有当痛苦大于快乐时，你才会采取行动；但如果快乐大于痛苦，你也不会采取任何行动，因为不存在剧烈的冲突。只有当痛苦压倒快乐，比快乐更加强烈时，你才会要求采取行动。

Most people wait for the increase of pain before they act, and during this waiting period they want to know how to be aware. No one can tell them. They are waiting for the increase of pain before they act; that is, they wait for pain through its compulsion to force them to act, and in that compulsion there is no intelligence. It is merely environment which forces them to act in a particular way, not intelligence. Therefore when a mind is caught up in this stagnation, in this lack of tenseness, there will naturally be more pain, more conflict.

大多数人会在痛苦加剧后才采取行动，而在这段等待期间，他们渴望知道如何保持觉察。然而，没有人能够告诉他们。他们等待痛苦加剧后才行动；也就是说，他们等待痛苦的强制力迫使他们行动，而这种强制力中并无智慧。仅仅是环境迫使他们以某种特定的方式行动，而非智慧。因此，当心灵陷入这种停滞状态，陷入这种缺乏紧张感的状态时，自然会产生更多的痛苦和冲突。

By the look of things political, war may break out again. It may break out in two years, in five years, in ten years. An intelligent man can see this and intelligently act. But the man who is stagnating, who is waiting for pain to force him to action, looks to greater chaos, greater suffering to give him impetus to act and hence, his intelligence is not functioning. There is awareness only when the mind and heart are taut, are in great tenseness.

从目前的政治形势来看，战争可能再次爆发。或许两年后，或许五年后，或许十年后。明智的人能够预见到这一点，并采取明智的行动。但那些停滞不前、等待痛苦迫使他们行动的人，却寄希望于更大的混乱和更大的苦难来激发他们的行动动力，因此，他们的智慧无法发挥作用。只有当心灵紧绷、高度紧张时，才能真正觉察到危险。
