For example, when you see that possessiveness must lead to incompleteness, when you see that insufficiency, lack of richness, shallowness, must ever produce dependence, when you recognize that, what happens to your mind and heart? The immediate craving is to fill that shallowness; but apart from that, when you see the futility of continual accumulation, you begin to be aware of how your mind is functioning. You see that in mere accumulation there cannot be creative thinking; and yet mind is pursuing accumulation. Therefore, in becoming aware of that, you create a conflict, and that very conflict will dissolve the cause of accumulation.

例如，当你意识到占有欲必然导致不完整，当你意识到匮乏、贫乏、肤浅必然导致依赖，当你认识到这一点，你的心智会发生什么变化？最直接的渴望是填补这种肤浅；但除此之外，当你意识到持续积累的徒劳无功时，你便开始觉察到你的思维是如何运作的。你明白，仅仅积累无法产生创造性思维；然而，你的思维却在追求积累。因此，当你意识到这一点时，你便会产生冲突，而正是这种冲突会化解积累的根源。

Q : In what way could a statesman who understood what you are saying give it expression in public affairs? Or is it not more likely that he would retire from politics when he understood their false bases and objectives?

问：一位理解了您所说的政治家，会如何将其运用到公共事务中呢？或者，当他意识到政治的虚假基础和目标时，他更有可能选择退出政坛吗？

K : If he understood what I am saying, he would not separate politics from life in its completeness; and I don’t see why he should retire. After all, politics now are merely instruments of exploitation; but if he considered life as a whole, not politics only—and by politics he means only his country, his people, and the exploitation of others—and regarded human problems not as national but as world problems, not as American, Hindu, or German problems, then, if he understood what I am talking about, he would be a true human being, not a politician. And to me, that is the most important thing, to be a human being, not an exploiter, or merely an expert in one particular line. I think that is where the mischief lies. The politician deals with politics only; the moralist with morals, the so-called spiritual teacher with the spirit, each thinking that he is the expert, and excluding all others. Our whole structure of society is based on that, and so these leaders of the various departments create greater havoc and greater misery, whereas if we as human beings saw the intimate connection between all these, between politics, religion, economics, and social life, if we saw the connection, then we would not think and act separatively, individualistically.

K：如果他理解我的意思，他就不会将政治与完整的人生割裂开来；我也不明白他为什么要退休。毕竟，如今的政治不过是剥削的工具；但如果他能将人生视为一个整体，而不仅仅是政治——他所谓的政治仅仅是指他的国家、他的人民以及对其他人的剥削——并将人类问题视为世界性问题而非国家问题，而不是美国、印度或德国的问题，那么，如果他理解我的意思，他就会成为一个真正的人，而不是一个政客。对我而言，这才是最重要的，做一个真正的人，而不是一个剥削者，或者仅仅是某个领域的专家。我认为问题就出在这里。政客只关注政治；道德家只关注道德；所谓的精神导师只关注精神，每个人都自认为才是专家，排斥其他一切。我们整个社会结构都建立在这个基础上，因此，各个部门的领导人造成了更大的混乱和更大的痛苦，而如果我们作为人类能够看到所有这些之间，政治、宗教、经济和社会生活之间的密切联系，如果我们能够看到这种联系，那么我们就不会各自为政、各自为政地思考和行动。

In India, for example, there are millions starving. The Hindu who is a nationalist says, “Let us first become intensely national; then we shall be able to solve this problem of starvation,” whereas to me, the way to solve the problem of starvation is not to become nationalistic, but the contrary; starvation is a world problem, and this process of isolation but further increases starvation. So if the politician deals with the problems of human life merely as a politician, then such a man creates greater havoc, greater mischief; but if he considers the whole of life without differentiation between races, nationalities, and classes, then he is truly a human being, though he may be a politician.

例如，在印度，有数百万人正在挨饿。一些信奉印度教的民族主义者会说：“让我们先成为强烈的民族主义者；这样我们就能解决饥荒问题。”然而在我看来，解决饥荒问题的途径并非走向民族主义，而是恰恰相反；饥荒是世界性问题，而这种孤立主义只会加剧饥荒。因此，如果政治家仅仅以政治家的身份来处理人类生活的问题，那么这样的人只会造成更大的破坏和危害；但如果他能够不分种族、民族和阶级地看待整个人类生活，那么即使他是一位政治家，他仍然是一个真正的人。

Q : You have said that with two or three others who understand, you could change the world. Many believe that they themselves understand, and that there are others likewise, such as artists and men of science, and yet the world is not changed. Please speak of the way in which you would change the world. Are you not now changing the world, perhaps slowly and subtly, but nevertheless definitely, through your speaking, your living, and the influence you will undoubtedly have on human thought in the years to come? Is this the change you had in mind, or was it something immediately affecting the political, economic, and racial structure?

问：您曾说过，只要有两三个志同道合的人，您就能改变世界。许多人自认为理解您的理念，也认为还有其他人，比如艺术家和科学家，也同样理解，然而世界并没有改变。请您谈谈您会如何改变世界。您现在难道不是正在改变世界吗？或许是缓慢而微妙的，但无疑是通过您的言行举止，以及您在未来几年对人类思想的深远影响？这是否就是您所设想的改变？还是说，您设想的改变是能够立即影响政治、经济和种族结构的改变？

K : I am afraid I have never thought of the immediacy of action and its effect. To have a lasting, true result, there must be behind action great observation, thought, and intelligence, and very few people are willing to think creatively, or be free from influence and bias. If you begin to think individually, you will then be able to cooperate intelligently; and as long as there is no intelligence there cannot be cooperation, but only compulsion and hence, chaos.

K：恐怕我从未考虑过行动的即时性和其影响。要想取得持久而真实的成果，行动背后必须有敏锐的观察力、深刻的思考和卓越的智慧，而愿意进行创造性思考或摆脱外界影响和偏见的人寥寥无几。如果你开始独立思考，你就能进行明智的合作；而只要没有智慧，就不可能有合作，只有强迫，最终只会导致混乱。

Q : To what extent can a person control his own actions? If we are, at any one time, the sum of our previous experience, and there is no spiritual self, is it possible for a person to act in any other way than that which is determined by his original inheritance, the sum of his past training, and the stimuli which play upon him at the time? If so, what causes the changes in the physical processes, and how?

问：一个人能在多大程度上控制自己的行为？如果我们任何时候都是过往经验的总和，而不存在精神自我，那么一个人是否有可能做出不同于其先天遗传、过往训练以及当下所受刺激的行为？如果可能，是什么导致了生理过程的变化，又是如何发生的？

K : “To what extent can a person control his own actions?” A person does not control his own actions if he has not understood environment. Then he is only acting under the compulsion, the influence, of environment; such an action is not action at all, but is merely reaction or self-protectiveness. But when a person begins to understand environment, sees its full significance and worth, then he is master of his own actions, then he is intelligent; and therefore, no matter what the condition he will function intelligently.

K：“一个人能在多大程度上控制自己的行为？” 如果一个人不了解环境，他就无法控制自己的行为。那时，他只是在环境的胁迫和影响下行事；这样的行为根本算不上行动，而仅仅是反应或自我保护。但是，当一个人开始了解环境，认识到环境的全部意义和价值时，他就能掌控自己的行为，他就能变得明智；因此，无论身处何种境地，他都能明智地行事。

“If we are, at any one time, the sum of our previous experience, and there is no spiritual self, is it possible for a person to act in any other way than that which is determined by his original inheritance, the sum of his past training, and the stimuli which play upon him at the time?”

“如果我们在任何时候都是我们过去经验的总和，而没有精神自我，那么一个人是否有可能以不同于其原始遗传、过去训练的总和以及当时作用于他的刺激的方式行事呢？”

Again, what I have said applies to this. That is, if he is merely acting from the burden of the past, whether it be his individual or racial inheritance, such action is merely the reaction of fear; but if he understands the subconscious, that is, his past accumulations, then he is free of the past and, therefore, he is free of the compulsion of the environment.

我之前所说的同样适用于这种情况。也就是说，如果他仅仅是受制于过去的包袱，无论是个人的还是种族的传承，这种行为仅仅是恐惧的反应；但如果他理解了潜意识，也就是他过去的积累，那么他就摆脱了过去的束缚，因此，他也摆脱了环境的胁迫。

After all, environment is of the present as well as of the past. One does not understand the present because of the clouding of the mind by the past; and to free the mind from the subconscious, the unconscious hindrances of the past, is not to roll memory back into the past, but to be fully conscious in the present. In that consciousness, in that full consciousness of the present, all the past hindrances come into activity, surge forward, and in that surging forward, if you are aware, you will see the full significance of the past and, therefore, understand the present.

毕竟，环境既包含现在，也包含过去。人们之所以无法理解现在，是因为过去的阴影蒙蔽了心灵；而要将心灵从潜意识中，从无意识的过去束缚中解脱出来，并非是将记忆拉回到过去，而是要全然地觉察当下。在这种觉察中，在这种对当下的全然觉察中，所有过去的束缚都会被激活，涌现出来；而在这种涌现之中，如果你能够觉察到，你就会看到过去的全部意义，从而理解现在。

“If so, what causes the changes in the physical processes, and how?” As far as I understand the questioner, he wants to know what produces this action, this action which is forced upon him by environment. He acts in a particular manner, compelled by environment, but if he understood environment intelligently, there would be no compulsion whatever; there would be understanding, which is action itself.

“如果真是如此，是什么导致了物理过程的变化，又是如何发生的呢？”据我理解，提问者想知道是什么产生了这种行为，这种行为是环境迫使他采取的。他以某种特定的方式行事，是受环境的驱使；但如果他能理性地理解环境，就不会有任何强迫；就会有理解，而理解本身就是行为。

Q : I live in a world of chaos, politically, economically, and socially, bound by laws and conventions which restrict my freedom. When my desires conflict with these impositions, I must break the law and take the consequences, or repress my desires. Where then, in such a world, is there any escape from self-discipline?

问：我生活在一个政治、经济和社会混乱的世界，受到各种法律和习俗的束缚，这些法律和习俗限制了我的自由。当我的欲望与这些限制发生冲突时，我必须违法并承担后果，或者压抑自己的欲望。那么，在这样的世界里，我该如何摆脱自我约束呢？

K : Self-discipline is merely an adjustment to environment, brought about through conflict. That is what I call self-discipline. You have established a pattern, an ideal, which acts as a compulsion, and you are forcing the mind to adjust itself to that environment, forcing it, modifying it, controlling it. What happens when you do that? You are really destroying creativeness; you are perverting, suppressing, creative affection. But if you begin to understand environment, then there is no longer repression or mere adjustment to environment, which you call self-discipline.

K：自律不过是对环境的一种适应，是通过冲突实现的。这就是我所谓的自律。你建立了一种模式，一种理想，它像一种强制力，你强迫自己的思想去适应环境，强迫它、改变它、控制它。这样做会发生什么？你实际上是在扼杀创造力；你在扭曲、压制创造性的情感。但如果你开始理解环境，那么就不存在压抑或仅仅是对环境的适应，而你所谓的自律也就不存在了。

How then can you understand environment? How can you understand its full worth, significance? What prevents you from seeing its significance? First of all, fear. Fear is the cause of the search for protection or security, security which is either physical, spiritual, religious, or emotional. So long as there is that search there must be fear, which then creates a barrier between your mind and your environment, and thereby creates conflict; and that conflict you cannot dissolve as long as you are only concerned with adjustment, modification, and never with the discovery of the fundamental cause of fear.

那么，你如何理解环境？你如何理解它的全部价值和意义？是什么阻碍了你看到它的意义？首先是恐惧。恐惧是寻求保护或安全感的根源，这种安全感可以是物质的、精神的、宗教的或情感的。只要存在这种寻求，恐惧就必然存在，它会在你的心灵和环境之间筑起一道屏障，从而产生冲突；而如果你只关注于调整和改变，却从未探究恐惧的根本原因，那么你就无法化解这种冲突。

So where there is this search for security, for a certainty, for a goal, preventing creative thinking, there must be adjustment, called self-discipline, which is but compulsion, the imitation of a pattern, whereas when the mind sees that there is no such thing as security in the piling up of things or of knowledge, then mind is released from fear and, therefore, mind is intelligence, and that which is intelligence does not discipline itself. There is self-discipline only where there is no intelligence. Where there is intelligence, there is understanding, free from influence, from control and domination.

因此，当人们寻求安全感、确定性和目标，从而阻碍创造性思维时，就必须进行调整，即所谓的自律。然而，自律不过是一种强迫，是对某种模式的模仿。相反，当心灵意识到积累物质或知识并不能带来安全感时，心灵便摆脱了恐惧。因此，心灵即是智慧，而智慧本身并不会自我约束。只有当智慧不存在时，才会出现自律。而当智慧存在时，便会产生理解，这种理解不受任何影响、控制和支配。

Q : How is it possible to awaken thought in an organism wherein the mechanism requisite for the apprehension of abstract ideas is absent?

问：如何才能唤醒一个缺乏理解抽象概念所需机制的生物体的思维？

K : By the simple process of suffering; by the process of continual experience. But you see, we have taken such shelter behind false values that we have ceased to think at all, and then we ask, “What are we to do? How are we to awaken thought?” We have cultivated fears which have become glorified as virtues and ideals, behind which mind takes shelter, and all action proceeds from that shelter, from that mold. Therefore, there is no thinking. You have conventions, and the adjusting of oneself to these conventions is called thought and action, which is not at all thought or action, because it is born of fear and, therefore, cripples the mind.

K：通过苦难的简单过程；通过持续的体验过程。但是你看，我们已经躲在虚假价值观的庇护之下，以至于完全停止了思考，然后我们问：“我们该怎么办？我们如何才能唤醒思考？”我们培养了恐惧，并将之美化为美德和理想，心灵躲藏在这些恐惧之后，所有行动都源于这庇护所，源于这模样。因此，没有思考。你们有的是习俗，而适应这些习俗的行为被称为思考和行动，但这根本不是思考或行动，因为它源于恐惧，因此会削弱心灵。

How can you awaken thought? Circumstances, or the death of someone you love, or a catastrophe, or depression, force you into conflict. Outer circumstances force you to act, and in that compulsion there cannot be the awakening of thought, because you are acting through fear. And if you begin to see that you cannot wait for circumstances to force you to act, then you begin to observe the very circumstances themselves; then you begin to penetrate and understand the circumstances, the environment. You don’t wait for depression to make you into a virtuous person, but you free your mind from possessiveness, from compulsion.

如何唤醒思想？境遇，比如挚爱之人的离世、灾难或抑郁，会迫使你陷入冲突。外在环境迫使你行动，而在这种强迫中，思想无法觉醒，因为你是出于恐惧而行动。如果你开始意识到不能坐等境遇迫使你行动，那么你便开始观察境遇本身；你便开始深入理解境遇和环境。你无需等待抑郁将你塑造成一个有德之人，而是将你的思想从执着和强迫中解放出来。

The acquisitive system is based on the idea that you can possess, and that it is legal to possess. Possession glorifies you. The more you have, the better, the nobler, you are considered. You have created that system, and you have become a slave to that system. You can create another society, not based on acquisitiveness, and that society can compel you as individuals to conform to its conventions, just as this society compels you to conform to its acquisitiveness. What is the difference? None whatever. You as individuals are merely being forced by circumstances or law to act in a particular direction and, therefore, there is no creative thinking at all; whereas if intelligence is beginning to function, then you are not a slave to either society, the acquisitive or the nonacquisitive. But to free the mind, there must be great intensity; there must be this continual alertness, observation, which itself creates conflict. This alertness itself produces a disturbance, and when there is that crisis, that intensity of conflict, then mind, if it is not escaping, begins to think anew, to think creatively, and that very thinking is eternity.

这种占有主义体系基于这样的理念：你可以拥有，而且拥有是合法的。占有能使你荣耀。你拥有的越多，就越好，就越高尚。你创造了这个体系，也成为了这个体系的奴隶。你可以创造另一个不以占有为基础的社会，这个社会可以像这个社会强迫你服从其占有欲一样，强迫你作为个体遵守其习俗。区别是什么？根本没有区别。作为个体，你只是被环境或法律强迫着朝着某个特定方向行动，因此，根本没有创造性思维；而如果智力开始发挥作用，那么你就不再是任何社会——无论是占有主义社会还是非占有主义社会——的奴隶。但是，要解放思想，必须有极高的专注力；必须有持续的警觉和观察力，而这本身就会产生冲突。这种警觉本身会产生一种扰动，当危机、冲突的强度出现时，如果心灵没有逃避，它就会开始重新思考，进行创造性思考，而这种思考本身就是永恒。

Ojai, California, June 30, 1934

加利福尼亚州奥海，1934年6月30日

#↩

BEING VULNERABLE TO TRUTH

面对真相的脆弱

I think most people have lost the art of listening. They come with their particular problems, and think that by listening to my talk their problems will be solved. I am afraid this will not happen; but if you know how to listen, then you will begin to understand the whole, and your mind will not be entangled by the particular.

我认为大多数人已经丧失了倾听的艺术。他们带着各自的问题而来，以为听了我的演讲就能解决所有问题。恐怕这不会发生；但如果你懂得倾听，你就会开始理解整体，你的思维也不会被个别细节所束缚。

So, if I may suggest it, don’t try to seek from this talk a solution for your particular problem, or an alleviation of your suffering. I can help you or rather, you will help yourself only if you think anew, creatively. Regard life not as several isolated problems, but comprehensively, as a whole, with a mind that is not suffocated by the search for solutions. If you will listen without the burden of problems, and take a comprehensive outlook, then you will see that your particular problem has a different significance; and although it may not be solved at once, you will begin to see the true cause of it. In thinking anew, in relearning how to think, there will come the dissolution of the problems and conflicts with which one’s mind and heart are burdened, and from which arise all disharmony, pain, and suffering.

所以，恕我直言，请不要试图从这次谈话中寻求解决你具体问题的方案，或者减轻你的痛苦。只有当你以全新的、创造性的思维方式思考时，我才能帮助你，或者更确切地说，你才能真正帮助到自己。不要把生活看作是几个孤立的问题，而要把它看作一个整体，一个全面的整体，不要让寻找答案的念头束缚你的心灵。如果你能放下问题的包袱，以更全面的视角来聆听，你就会发现你遇到的具体问题有着不同的意义；虽然它可能不会立刻得到解决，但你会开始看到问题的真正根源。通过全新的思考方式，通过重新学习如何思考，那些压在你心头的难题和冲突将会消解，而这些难题和冲突正是所有不和谐、痛苦和磨难的根源。

Now, each one, more or less, is consumed by desires whose objects vary according to environment, temperament, and inheritance. According to your particular condition, to your particular education and upbringing, religious, social, and economic, you have established certain objectives whose attainment you are ceaselessly pursuing, and this pursuit has become paramount in your lives.

如今，每个人或多或少都被欲望所驱使，而欲望的对象则因环境、性情和出身而异。根据你的具体情况、教育背景、宗教信仰、社会地位和经济状况，你设定了一些目标，并孜孜不倦地追求这些目标的实现，而这种追求已成为你生命中最重要的事情。

Once you have established these objectives, there naturally arise the specialists who act as your guides toward the attainment of your desires. Hence, the perfection of technique, specialization, becomes merely the means to gain your end; and in order to gain this end, which you have established through your religious, economic, and social conditioning, you must have specialists. So your action loses its significance, its value, because you are concerned with the attainment of an objective, not with the fulfillment of intelligence which is action; you are concerned with the arrival, not with that which is fulfillment itself. Living becomes merely the means to an end, and life a school in which you learn to attain an end. Action, therefore, becomes but a medium through which you can come to that objective which you have established through your various environments and conditions. So life becomes a school of great conflict and struggle, never a thing of fulfillment, of richness, of completeness.

一旦你确立了这些目标，自然就会出现一些专家，他们引导你实现愿望。因此，技术的完善和专业化仅仅成为达成目的的手段；而为了达成这个你通过宗教、经济和社会环境所确立的目标，你必须拥有专家。于是，你的行动失去了意义和价值，因为你关注的是目标的达成，而不是作为行动的智慧的实现；你关注的是结果，而不是结果本身。生活仅仅成为达成目的的手段，人生成为你学习如何达成目标的学校。因此，行动仅仅成为一种媒介，通过这种媒介，你可以到达你通过各种环境和条件所确立的目标。于是，人生变成了一个充满冲突和斗争的学校，而不是一个充满圆满、丰富和完整的场所。

Then you begin to ask, what is the end, the purpose of living? This is what most people ask; this is what is in the minds of most people here. Why are we living? What is the end? What is the goal? What is the purpose? You are concerned with the purpose, with the end, rather than with living in the present; whereas a man who fulfills never inquires into the end because fulfillment itself is sufficient. But as you do not know how to fulfill, how to live completely, richly, sufficiently, you begin to inquire into the purpose, the goal, the end, because you think you can then meet life, knowing the end—at least you think you can know the end—then, knowing the end, you hope to use experience as a means toward that end; hence, life becomes a medium, a measure, a value to come to that attainment.

于是你开始追问，人生的终点是什么？人生的意义是什么？这是大多数人都会问的问题；这也是大多数人心中的疑问。我们为何而活？终点是什么？目标是什么？意义是什么？你关注的是意义，是终点，而不是活在当下；而一个真正满足的人从不探究终点，因为满足本身就已足够。但既然你不知道如何满足，如何活得完整、充实、圆满，你便开始探究意义、目标、终点，因为你认为，一旦知道了终点——至少你认为你能知道终点——你就能更好地面对人生，然后，你希望将人生经历作为达成终点的手段；因此，人生变成了一种媒介、一种衡量标准、一种价值，最终达到那个目标。

Consciously or unconsciously, surreptitiously or openly, one begins to inquire into the purpose of life, and each one receives an answer from the so-called specialists. The artist, if you ask him what is the purpose of life, will tell you that it is self-expression through painting, sculpture, music, or poetry; the economist, if you ask him, will tell you that it is work, production, cooperation, living together, functioning as a group, as society; and if you ask the religionist he will tell you the purpose of life is to seek and to realize God, to live according to the laws laid down by teachers, prophets, saviors, and that by living according to their laws and edicts you may realize that truth which is God. Each specialist gives you his answer about the purpose of life, and according to your temperament, fancies, and imagination you begin to establish these purposes, these ends, as your ideals.

无论自觉还是不自觉，无论隐秘还是公开，人们都会开始探寻人生的意义，而每个人都会从所谓的专家那里得到不同的答案。如果你问艺术家人生的意义是什么，他会告诉你，是通过绘画、雕塑、音乐或诗歌进行自我表达；如果你问经济学家，他会告诉你，人生的意义在于工作、生产、合作、共同生活、作为一个群体、作为一个社会发挥作用；如果你问宗教人士，他会告诉你，人生的意义在于寻求并认识上帝，在于遵循导师、先知、救世主制定的法则生活，并通过遵循他们的法则和教诲来领悟真理——上帝。每个专家都会给出他们关于人生意义的答案，而你也会根据自己的性情、喜好和想象力，开始将这些意义、这些目标确立为自己的理想。

Such ideals and ends have become merely a haven of refuge because you use them to guide and protect yourself in this turmoil. So you begin to use these ideals to measure your experiences, to inquire into the conditions of your environment. You begin, without the desire to understand or to fulfill, merely to inquire into the purpose of environment; and in discovering that purpose, according to your conditioning, your preconceptions, you merely avoid the conflict of living without understanding.

这些理想和目标如今已沦为避难所，因为你用它们来指引和保护自己，以应对这动荡不安的局面。于是，你开始用这些理想来衡量你的经历，探究你所处环境的状况。你开始探寻环境存在的意义，并非出于理解或实现的渴望；而当你根据自身的固有观念和成见去发现这个意义时，你只不过是在逃避那种在无知中生存的冲突。

So mind has divided life into ideals, purposes, culminations, attainments, ends; and turmoil, conflict, disturbance, disharmony; and you, yourself, the self-consciousness. That is, mind has separated life into these three divisions. You are caught up in turmoil and so through this turmoil, this conflict, this disturbance which is but sorrow, you work toward an end, a purpose. You wade through, plough through this turmoil to the goal, to the end, to the haven of refuge, to the attainment of the ideal; and these ideals, ends, refuges have been designed by economic, religious, and spiritual experts.

因此，心智将人生划分为理想、目标、巅峰、成就、终点；以及动荡、冲突、扰乱、不和谐；还有你，你自己，自我意识。也就是说，心智将人生分为这三个部分。你身处动荡之中，于是，你通过这动荡、这冲突、这扰乱（其实就是悲伤），朝着某个终点、某个目标努力。你跋涉、耕耘这动荡，直至抵达目标、抵达终点、抵达避难所、抵达理想的彼岸；而这些理想、终点、避难所，都是由经济、宗教和精神领域的专家们精心设计的。

Thus, you are, at one end, wading through conditions and environment, and creating conflict while trying to realize ideals, purposes, and attainments which have become refuges and shelters at the other. The very inquiry into the purpose of life indicates the lack of intelligence in the present; and the man who is fully active—not lost in activities, as most Americans are, but fully active, intelligently, emotionally, fully alive—has fulfilled himself. Therefore, the inquiry into an end is futile, because there is no such thing as an end and a beginning; there is but the continual movement of creative thinking, and what you call problems are the results of your ploughing through this turmoil toward a culmination. That is, you are concerned with how to overcome this turmoil, how to adjust yourselves to environment in order to arrive at an end. With that your whole life is concerned, not with yourself and the goal. You are not concerned with that, you are concerned with the turmoil, how to go through it, how to dominate it, how to overcome it and, therefore, how to evade it. You want to arrive at that perfect evasion which you call ideals, at that perfect refuge which you call the purpose of life, which is but an escape from the present turmoil.

因此，一方面，你们在各种境遇和环境中挣扎求生，制造冲突，试图实现那些在另一端却沦为避难所和庇护所的理想、目标和成就。对人生意义的探究本身就表明了当下智慧的匮乏；而那些积极主动的人——不像大多数美国人那样沉溺于各种活动，而是积极主动、智慧充沛、情感丰富、充满活力——才真正实现了自我价值。因此，探究人生的终点是徒劳的，因为根本不存在终点和起点；存在的只是创造性思维的持续运动，而你们所谓的“问题”，不过是你们在这场动荡中奋力前行，最终抵达终点的结果。也就是说，你们关注的是如何克服这场动荡，如何适应环境以抵达终点。你们的整个人生都围绕着这个展开，而不是关注自身和目标。你并不关心这些，你关心的是动荡本身，如何度过它，如何驾驭它，如何克服它，从而如何逃避它。你想要达到你所谓的理想，达到你所谓的人生目标，达到你所谓的人生目标，而这不过是逃离当下动荡的一种方式。

Naturally, when you seek to overcome, to dominate, to evade, and to arrive at that ultimate goal, there arises the search for systems and their leaders, guides, teachers, and experts; to me all these are exploiters. The systems, the methods, and their teachers, and all the complications of their rivalries, enticements, promises, and deceits, create divisions in life known as sects and cults.

当然，当你试图克服困难、掌控局面、逃避现实，最终达成目标时，你自然会开始寻找各种体系及其领导者、导师、老师和专家；在我看来，他们都是剥削者。这些体系、方法、导师，以及它们之间错综复杂的竞争、诱惑、承诺和欺骗，在生活中制造了各种分裂，形成了所谓的教派和邪教。

That is what is happening. When you are seeking an attainment, a result, an overcoming of the turmoil, and not considering the “you,” the “I” consciousness, and the end which you are ceaselessly and consciously, or unconsciously, pursuing, naturally you must create exploiters, either of the past or the present; and you are caught up in their pettinesses, their jealousies, their disciplines, their disharmonies, and their divisions. So the mere desire to go through this turmoil ever creates further problems, for there is no consideration of the actor or the manner of his action, but merely the consideration of the scene of turmoil as a means to get to an end.

这就是正在发生的事情。当你追求某种成就、某种结果、某种对困境的克服，却忽略了“你”、“我”的意识，以及你不断地、有意识或无意识地追求的最终目标时，你自然会招致剥削，无论是过去的还是现在的；你会被他们的琐碎、嫉妒、纪律、不和谐和分裂所困扰。因此，仅仅是想要经历这种困境的欲望，就会不断制造更多的问题，因为你没有考虑行动者或行动的方式，而只是把困境本身当作达到目的的手段。

Now to me, the turmoil, the end, and the “you” are the same; there is no division. This division is artificial, and it is created by the desire to gain, by the pursuit of acquisitive accumulation, which is born of insufficiency.

对我而言，动荡、终结和“你”是一体的；它们之间没有界限。这种界限是人为的，它源于对物质的渴求和对财富的贪婪积累，而这种贪婪和贪婪又源于匮乏。

In becoming conscious of emptiness, of shallowness, one begins to realize the utter insufficiency of one’s own thinking and feeling, and so in one’s thought there arises the idea of accumulation, and from that is born this division between “you,” the self-consciousness, and the end. To me, as I said, there can be no such distinction, because the moment you fulfill there can no longer be the actor and the act, but only that creative movement of thought which does not seek a result, and so there is a continual living, which is immortality.

当意识到空虚和浅薄时，人便开始领悟自身思想和情感的彻底匮乏，于是思想中便产生了积累的观念，由此产生了“你”、自我意识与终点之间的割裂。对我而言，正如我所说，这种区分并不存在，因为当你圆满的那一刻，便不再有行动者和行动本身，而只有不求结果的创造性思维运动，因此便存在着持续的生命，这便是永生。

But you have divided life. Let us consider what this “I,” this actor, this observer, this center of conflict, is. It is but a long, continuous scroll of memory. This “I” is a scroll of memory in which there are accentuations. These accentuations or depressions we call complexes, and from these we act. That is, mind, being conscious of insufficiency, pursues a gain and, therefore, creates a distinction, a division. Such a mind cannot understand environment, and as it cannot understand it, it must rely on the accumulation of memory for guidance; for memory is but a series of accumulations which act as a guide toward an end. That is the purpose of memory. Memory is the lack of comprehension; that lack of comprehension is your background, and from that proceeds your action.

但你却将生活割裂开来。让我们思考一下这个“我”，这个行动者，这个观察者，这个冲突的中心，究竟是什么。它不过是一卷绵延不断的记忆。这个“我”是一卷记忆，其中充满了强调。我们称这些强调或压抑为情结，并由此而行动。也就是说，心智意识到自身的不足，便追求某种满足，因此制造了区分和割裂。这样的心智无法理解环境，正因为无法理解，它才必须依赖记忆的积累来指引方向；因为记忆不过是一系列积累，它们指引我们走向某个目标。这就是记忆的目的。记忆是理解的缺失；这种理解的缺失构成了你的背景，而你的行动也由此而来。

This memory is acting as a guide toward an end, and that end, being preestablished, is merely a self-protective refuge which you call ideals, attainment, truth, God, or perfection. The beginning and the end, the “you” and the goal, are the results of this self-protective mind.

这段记忆如同指引你走向终点的指南针，而这个终点，由于早已预设，不过是你用来保护自己的避难所，你称之为理想、成就、真理、上帝或完美。开始与结束，你与目标，都是这种自我保护心态的产物。

I have explained how a self-protective mind comes into being; it comes into being as the result of the consciousness or awareness of emptiness, of void. Therefore, it begins to think in terms of achievement, acquisition, and from that it begins to function, dividing life and restricting its actions. So the end and the “you” are the result of this self-protective mind; and turmoil, conflict, and disharmony are but the process of self-protection, and are born out of this self-protection, spiritual and economic.

我已经解释过自我保护的心态是如何产生的；它源于对空性、对虚无的觉知。因此，它开始以成就、获取为导向进行思考，并由此运作，分割生活，限制自身行为。所以，终点和“你”都是这种自我保护心态的结果；而动荡、冲突和不和谐不过是自我保护的过程，它们都源于这种精神和经济上的自我保护。

Spiritually and economically you are seeking security, because you rely on accumulation for your richness, for your comprehension, for your fullness, for your fulfillment. And so the cunning, in the spiritual as well as in the economic world, exploit you, for both seek power by glorifying self-protection. So each mind is making a tremendous effort to protect itself, and the end, the means, and the “you” are nothing else but the process of self-protection. What happens when there is this process of self-protection? There must be conflict with circumstances, which we call society; there is the “you” trying to protect itself against the collective, the group, the society.

在精神和经济层面，你都在寻求安全感，因为你依赖积累来获得财富、理解力、充实感和满足感。因此，无论是在精神领域还是经济领域，狡诈之徒都在利用你，因为两者都通过颂扬自我保护来寻求权力。所以，每个人的心灵都在竭尽全力地保护自己，而最终目的、手段以及“你”本身，都不过是自我保护的过程。当这种自我保护的过程发生时，会发生什么呢？必然会与我们称之为社会的环境产生冲突；“你”试图保护自己免受集体、群体和社会的侵害。

Now, the reverse of that isn’t true. That is, don’t think that if you cease to protect yourself you will be lost. On the contrary, you will be lost if you are protecting yourself due to the insufficiency, due to the shallowness of thought and affection. But if you merely cease to protect yourself because you think through that you are going to find truth, again it will be but another form of protection.

然而，反过来却不成立。也就是说，不要以为停止自我保护就会迷失方向。恰恰相反，如果你因为思想和情感的匮乏或肤浅而自我保护，你才会迷失。但如果你仅仅因为认为自己会找到真理而停止自我保护，那也只不过是另一种形式的自我保护而已。

So, as we have built up through centuries, generation after generation, this wheel of self-protection, spiritual and economic, let us find out if spiritual or economic self-protection is real. Perhaps economically you may assert self-protection for a while. The man who has money and many possessions, and who has secured comforts and pleasures for his body, is generally, if you will observe, most insufficient and unintelligent, and is groping after so-called spiritual protection.

因此，经过几个世纪、一代又一代人的积累，我们构建了这套精神和经济上的自我保护体系。现在，让我们来探究一下，精神上的自我保护和经济上的自我保护究竟是否真实存在。或许在经济层面，你可以暂时声称自己拥有自我保护的能力。但如果你仔细观察，就会发现，那些拥有金钱和众多财产，并且已经为身体提供了舒适和享乐的人，通常都是最缺乏智慧和能力的人，他们只是在摸索所谓的精神保护。

Let us inquire however if there really is spiritual self-protection, because economically we see there is no security. The illusion of economic security is shown throughout the world by these depressions, crises, wars, calamities, and chaos. We recognize this, and so turn to spiritual security. But to me there is no security, there is no self-protection, and there never can be any. I say there is only wisdom, which is understanding, not protection. That is, security, self-protection, is the outcome of insufficiency, in which there is no intelligence, in which there is no creative thinking, in which there is constant battle between the “you” and society, and in which the cunning exploit you ruthlessly. As long as there is the pursuit of self-protection there must be conflict, and so there can be no understanding, no wisdom. And as long as this attitude exists, your search for spirituality, for truth, or for God is vain, useless, because it is merely the search for greater power, greater security.

然而，让我们探究一下是否存在真正的精神自我保护，因为在经济层面，我们看到并不存在安全感。经济安全的幻象在世界各地都通过经济萧条、危机、战争、灾难和混乱得以展现。我们认识到这一点，于是转向精神安全。但对我而言，并不存在安全感，也不存在自我保护，而且永远不可能存在。我认为，唯有智慧，即理解，而非保护。也就是说，安全感和自我保护是匮乏的结果，在匮乏中，缺乏智慧，缺乏创造性思维，只有“你”与社会之间持续不断的斗争，以及狡诈之人对你的无情剥削。只要人们追求自我保护，冲突就必然存在，因此也就不可能产生理解和智慧。只要这种态度存在，你对灵性、真理或上帝的追求就是徒劳无功的，因为它仅仅是对更大权力、更大安全的追求。

It is only when the mind, which has taken shelter behind the walls of self-protection, frees itself from its own creations that there can be that exquisite reality. After all, these walls of self-protection are the creations of the mind which, conscious of its insufficiency, builds these walls of protection, and behind them takes shelter. One has built up these barriers unconsciously or consciously, and one’s mind is so crippled, bound, held, that action brings greater conflict, further disturbances.

只有当躲藏在自我保护壁垒之后的心灵，从自身创造的种种束缚中挣脱出来时，才能体验到那精妙绝伦的现实。毕竟，这些自我保护的壁垒正是心灵的造物，它意识到自身的不足，于是筑起这些保护的壁垒，并躲藏其中。人们或有意识或无意识地筑起了这些屏障，心灵因此变得如此残缺、束缚、禁锢，以至于任何行动都只会带来更大的冲突和更多的扰乱。

So the mere search for the solution of your problems is not going to free the mind from creating further problems. As long as this center of self-protectiveness, born of insufficiency, exists, there must be disturbances, tremendous sorrow, and pain; and you cannot free the mind of sorrow by disciplining it not to be insufficient. That is, you cannot discipline yourself, or be influenced by conditions and environment, in order not to be shallow. You say to yourself, “I am shallow; I recognize the fact, and how am I going to get rid of it?” I say, do not seek to get rid of it, which is merely a process of substitution, but become conscious, become aware of what is causing this insufficiency. You cannot compel it; you cannot force it; it cannot be influenced by an ideal, by a fear, by the pursuit of enjoyment and powers. You can find out the cause of insufficiency only through awareness. That is, by looking into environment and piercing into its significance there will be revealed the cunning subtleties of self-protection.

所以，仅仅寻求问题的答案并不能让你的心灵摆脱制造新问题的命运。只要这种源于不足感的自我保护机制存在，就必然会有扰乱、巨大的悲伤和痛苦；而你无法通过约束自己，使其不再感到不足，来摆脱悲伤。也就是说，你无法约束自己，也无法受制于环境和条件，从而避免肤浅。你会对自己说：“我很肤浅；我承认这一点，但我该如何摆脱它呢？”我的回答是，不要试图摆脱它，那只不过是一种替代的过程，而是要觉察，觉察到造成这种不足感的原因。你无法强迫它；你无法强迫它；它无法被任何理想、恐惧、对享乐和权力的追求所影响。你只能通过觉察来找到这种不足感的根源。也就是说，通过观察环境并探究其意义，就能揭示出自我保护的巧妙之处。

After all, self-protection is the result of insufficiency, and as the mind has been trained, caught up in its bondage for centuries, you cannot discipline it, you cannot overcome it. If you do, you lose the significance of the deceits and subtleties of thought and emotion behind which mind has taken shelter; and to discover these subtleties you must become conscious, aware.

毕竟，自我保护源于不足，而人的心智已被训练得如此，被束缚了数个世纪，你无法驾驭它，也无法战胜它。如果你试图这样做，你就会失去对思想和情感中那些欺骗和微妙之处的理解，而心智正是躲藏在这些欺骗和微妙之处背后的；要发现这些微妙之处，你必须变得有意识，觉察。

Now to be aware is not to alter. Our mind is accustomed to alteration which is merely modification, adjustment, becoming disciplined to a condition; whereas if you are aware, you will discover the full significance of the environment. Therefore there is no modification, but entire freedom from that environment.

觉知并非改变。我们的心智习惯于改变，而改变仅仅是调整、适应，是对某种状态的规训；然而，如果你觉知，你就会发现环境的全部意义。因此，不存在改变，而是完全摆脱环境的束缚。

Only when all these walls of protection are destroyed in the flame of awareness, in which there is no modification or alteration or adjustment, but complete understanding of the significance of environment with all its delicacies and subtleties—only through that understanding is there the eternal; because in that there is no “you” functioning as a self-protective focus. But as long as that self-protecting focus which you call the “I” exists, there must be confusion, there must be disturbance, disharmony, and conflict. You cannot destroy these hindrances by disciplining yourself or by following a system or by imitating a pattern; you can understand them with all their complications only through the full awareness of mind and heart. Then there is an ecstasy, there is that living movement of truth, which is not an end, not a culmination, but an ever-creative living, an ecstasy which cannot be described, because all description must destroy it. So long as you are not vulnerable to truth, there is no ecstasy, there is no immortality.

只有当所有这些保护的壁垒在觉知的火焰中被摧毁，不再有任何修改、改变或调整，而是对环境及其所有微妙之处的意义有完全的理解——只有通过这种理解，才能获得永恒；因为在这种理解中，不再有作为自我保护焦点的“你”。但是，只要你称之为“我”的那个自我保护焦点存在，就必然会有混乱、扰乱、不和谐和冲突。你无法通过约束自己、遵循某种体系或模仿某种模式来消除这些障碍；你只能通过身心的完全觉知来理解它们及其所有复杂性。那时，便会有一种狂喜，一种真理的鲜活流动，它不是终点，不是顶峰，而是一种永恒的创造，一种无法描述的狂喜，因为任何描述都会破坏它。只要你对真理不敞开心扉，就没有狂喜，就没有永生。

Ojai, California, July 1, 1934

加利福尼亚州奥海，1934年7月1日

#↩

PART 2

第二部分

Insights into Everyday Life

对日常生活的洞察

People have often wondered how Krishnamurti, whom they believe lived in protected and luxurious circumstances, could have had the remarkable insights into the often trouble-fraught lives of ordinary people that he demonstrated in his writings and talks. Without knowing of the illnesses of his childhood, his suffering at the time of his brother’s death, or his lifelong physical pain and sensitivity, they have marveled at his ability to see through the eyes of a mother living in poverty in an Indian village, of a laborer toiling on a dusty road, of a rich man or a troubled young student.

人们常常好奇，克里希那穆提生活在优渥的环境中，为何能像他在著作和演讲中展现的那样，对普通人充满苦难的生活拥有如此深刻的洞察力。人们并不知道他童年时的疾病、哥哥去世时的悲痛，以及他终生饱受的身体疼痛和敏感，却依然惊叹于他能够设身处地地去感受印度乡村贫困母亲、尘土飞扬的道路上辛勤劳作的工人、富人或迷茫的年轻学生的处境。

During the 1930s and ’40s, Krishnamurti gave private interviews to people from almost every social background who asked to speak with him about their personal problems. Perceiving the unity of human existence, he was able to convey revealing insights into issues affecting all men and women. He described the essence of these probing discussions in books which also expressed his deep appreciation of the natural landscape and his intense, long-standing concern for the environment.

在20世纪30年代和40年代，克里希那穆提为几乎所有社会阶层的人士提供私人面谈，倾听他们个人的问题。他洞察到人类存在的统一性，并能就影响所有男女的问题提出深刻的见解。他将这些深入探讨的精髓记录在书中，这些书籍也表达了他对自然景观的深深敬意以及他对环境的长期关注。

This part presents some of these writings, which have been published in three volumes as the Commentaries on Living . Here, too, are extracts from his writings on education and to the young ( Education and the Significance of Life and Life Ahead ) and on freedom, in a book with an introduction by Aldous Huxley, The First and Last Freedom . Possibly some of the most intimate and revealing passages are those selected from his Journal and from Krishnamurti to Himself in which (as in Krishnamurti’s Notebook ) he often touches on the deepest mystical sources of his lifetime of teaching.

本部分收录了他的一些著作，这些著作已结集出版，名为《生活评注》（Commentaries on Living），共三卷。此外，还摘录了他关于教育和青年的著作（《教育与生命的意义》和《未来的生活》），以及关于自由的著作（收录于奥尔德斯·赫胥黎作序的《最初与最终的自由》一书中）。或许最私密、最发人深省的段落，选自他的日记和自述，其中（如同克里希那穆提的笔记一样）他常常触及他毕生教学中最深奥的神秘源泉。

#↩

THE FIRST AND LAST FREEDOM

首要且最终的自由

To communicate with one another, even if we know each other very well, is extremely difficult. I may use words that may have to you a significance different from mine. Understanding comes when we, you and I, meet on the same level at the same time. That happens only when there is real affection between people, between husband and wife, between intimate friends. That is real communion. Instantaneous understanding comes when we meet on the same level at the same time.

即使彼此非常了解，沟通也极其困难。我使用的词语，对你而言可能意义不同。只有当我们——你和我——在同一时刻处于同一水平线上时，才能产生理解。而这只有在人与人之间，夫妻之间，挚友之间，存在真挚情感时才会发生。那才是真正的交流。当我们在同一时刻处于同一水平线上时，便能瞬间达成共识。

It is very difficult to commune with one another easily, effectively, and with definitive action. I am using words which are simple, which are not technical, because I do not think that any technical type of expression is going to help us solve our difficult problems; so I am not going to use any technical terms, either of psychology or of science. I have not read any books on psychology or any religious books, fortunately. I would like to convey, by the very simple words which we use in our daily life, a deeper significance; but that is very difficult if you do not know how to listen.

彼此之间要进行轻松、有效且果断的沟通非常困难。我使用简单易懂的语言，避免使用专业术语，因为我认为任何晦涩难懂的表达方式都无助于我们解决难题；所以我不会使用任何心理学或科学方面的专业术语。幸运的是，我没有读过任何心理学书籍或宗教书籍。我希望用我们日常生活中使用的简单语言来传达更深层次的含义；但如果你不懂得倾听，这很难做到。

There is an art of listening. To be able really to listen, one should abandon or put aside all prejudices, preformulations, and daily activities. When you are in a receptive state of mind, things can be easily understood; you are listening when your real attention is given to something. But unfortunately most of us listen through a screen of resistance. We are screened with prejudices, whether religious or spiritual, psychological, or scientific; or with our daily worries, desires, and fears. And with these for a screen, we listen. Therefore, we listen really to our own noise, to our own sound, not to what is being said. It is extremely difficult to put aside our training, our prejudices, our inclination, our resistance, and, reaching beyond the verbal expression, to listen so that we understand instantaneously. That is going to be one of our difficulties.

聆听是一门艺术。要真正做到聆听，就应该摒弃或放下所有的偏见、先入为主的观念和日常活动。当你处于一种易于接受的状态时，事物就更容易被理解；当你真正专注于某件事时，你就是在聆听。但不幸的是，我们大多数人都是隔着一层阻力在聆听。我们被各种偏见所蒙蔽，无论是宗教的、精神的、心理的还是科学的；或是被我们日常的忧虑、欲望和恐惧所蒙蔽。我们就这样被这些蒙蔽的屏障所阻挡，聆听着。因此，我们真正听到的其实是我们自己的噪音，是我们自己的声音，而不是别人在说什么。放下我们的固有观念、偏见、倾向和阻力，超越语言的表达，从而瞬间理解，这极其困难。这将是我们面临的挑战之一。

If, during this discourse, anything is said which is opposed to your way of thinking and belief, just listen; do not resist. You may be right and I may be wrong; but by listening and considering together we are going to find out what is the truth. Truth cannot be given to you by somebody. You have to discover it; and to discover, there must be a state of mind in which there is direct perception. There is no direct perception when there is a resistance, a safeguard, a protection. Understanding comes through being aware of what is . To know exactly what is , the real, the actual, without interpreting it, without condemning or justifying it, is, surely, the beginning of wisdom. It is only when we begin to interpret, to translate according to our conditioning, according to our prejudice, that we miss the truth. After all, it is like research. To know what something is, what it is exactly, requires research—you cannot translate it according to your moods. Similarly, if we can look, observe, listen, be aware of, what is , exactly, then the problem is solved. And that is what we are going to do in all these discourses. I am going to point out to you what is , and not translate it according to my fancy; nor should you translate it or interpret it according to your background or training.

如果在讨论过程中，有人说了任何与你的想法和信仰相悖的话，请倾听，不要抗拒。你或许是对的，我或许是错的；但通过共同倾听和思考，我们终将找到真相。真理无法由他人赋予，必须由你自己去发现；而要发现真理，必须具备一种能够直接感知的心态。当存在抗拒、防备或保护时，就无法获得直接的感知。理解源于对事物本质的觉察。准确地了解事物的本质，了解真实、现实，而不加以诠释、谴责或辩解，这无疑是智慧的开端。只有当我们开始诠释，根据自身的局限和偏见去解读时，我们才会错失真理。毕竟，这就像研究一样。要了解事物的本质，了解它的确切面貌，需要进行研究——你不能根据自己的情绪去解读它。同样地，如果我们能够观察、聆听、觉察事物的本质，那么问题就迎刃而解了。而这正是我们在所有这些论述中要做的事情。我将向你们指出事物的本来面目，而不是根据我的个人喜好去翻译；你们也不应该根据你们的背景或训练去翻译或解释它。

Is it not possible, then, to be aware of everything as it is? Starting from there, surely, there can be an understanding. To acknowledge, to be aware of, to get at that which is, puts an end to struggle. If I know that I am a liar, and it is a fact which I recognize, then the struggle is over. To acknowledge, to be aware of what one is, is already the beginning of wisdom, the beginning of understanding, which releases you from time. To bring in the quality of time—time, not in the chronological sense, but as the medium, as the psychological process, the process of the mind—is destructive, and creates confusion.

那么，难道就不能如实地觉察一切吗？从那里出发，必然可以有所领悟。承认、觉察、把握事物的本来面目，便能终结一切挣扎。如果我知道自己是个骗子，并且我承认这是一个事实，那么挣扎便结束了。承认、觉察自身的本质，本身就是智慧的开端，是理解的开端，它能使你从时间中解脱出来。引入时间的属性——这里的时间并非指时间顺序上的时间，而是作为一种媒介、一种心理过程、一种思维过程——是具有破坏性的，只会造成混乱。

So, we can have understanding of what is when we recognize it without condemnation, without justification, without identification. To know that one is in a certain condition, in a certain state, is already a process of liberation; but a man who is not aware of his condition, of his struggle, tries to be something other than he is, which brings about habit. So, then, let us keep in mind that we want to examine what is , to observe and be aware of exactly what is the actual, without giving it any slant, without giving it an interpretation. It takes an extraordinarily astute mind, an extraordinarily pliable heart, to be aware of and to follow what is ; because what is is constantly moving, constantly undergoing a transformation, and if the mind is tethered to belief, to knowledge, it ceases to pursue, it ceases to follow the swift movement of what is . What is is not static, surely it is constantly moving, as you will see if you observe it very closely. To follow it, you need a very swift mind and a pliable heart—which are denied when the mind is static, fixed in a belief, in a prejudice, in an identification; and a mind and heart that are dry cannot follow easily, swiftly, that which is.

因此，当我们不带谴责、不辩解、不认同地认识事物本身时，我们就能理解事物的本质。意识到自己处于某种状态，本身就是一种解脱；但一个人如果意识不到自己的状态和挣扎，就会试图成为与自己不同的人，从而养成习惯。所以，我们要记住，我们要探究事物的本质，观察并觉察事物的真实面貌，不带任何偏见，不加任何诠释。觉察并追随事物的本质，需要极其敏锐的头脑和极其柔韧的心灵；因为事物本身在不断变化，不断演进，如果头脑被信念和知识所束缚，它就会停止追寻，停止追随事物的迅疾变化。事物并非静止不变，它必然在不断运动，如果你仔细观察，就会发现这一点。要理解它，你需要非常敏捷的思维和一颗灵活的心——当思维停滞不前，固守于某种信念、偏见或认同时，这些能力就会丧失；而头脑和心灵如果枯燥乏味，就无法轻易、迅速地理解事物的本来面目。

One is aware, I think, without too much discussion, too much verbal expression, that there is individual as well as collective chaos, confusion, and misery. It is not only in India, but right throughout the world; in China, America, England, Germany, all over the world, there is confusion, mounting sorrow. It is not only national, it is not particularly here, it is all over the world. There is extraordinarily acute suffering, and it is not individual only but collective. So it is a world catastrophe, and to limit it merely to a geographical area, a colored section of the map, is absurd; because then we shall not understand the full significance of this worldwide as well as individual suffering. Being aware of this confusion, what is our response today? How do we react?

我想，无需过多讨论，无需过多言辞，人们都能意识到，无论是个人层面还是集体层面，都存在着混乱、困惑和苦难。这不仅发生在印度，而是遍及全球；在中国、美国、英国、德国，世界各地都弥漫着混乱和日益加剧的悲痛。这并非仅限于某个国家，也并非局限于此，而是遍及世界各地。人们遭受着极其严重的苦难，这不仅是个人层面的，也是集体层面的。因此，这是一场世界性的灾难，仅仅将其局限于某个地理区域，地图上的某个色块是荒谬的；因为那样我们就无法理解这场全球性以及个人层面的苦难的全部意义。既然意识到了这种混乱，我们今天应该如何回应？我们应该如何应对？

There is suffering—political, social, religious; our whole psychological being is confused, and all the leaders, political and religious, have failed us; all the books have lost their significance. You may go to the Bhagavad Gita or the Bible or the latest treatise on politics or psychology, and you will find that they have lost that ring, that quality of truth; they have become mere words. You yourself, who are the repeater of those words, are confused and uncertain, and mere repetition of words conveys nothing. Therefore, the words and the books have lost their value; that is, if you quote the Bible, or Marx, or the Bhagavad Gita, as you who quote it are yourself uncertain, confused, your repetition becomes a lie; because what is written there becomes mere propaganda, and propaganda is not truth. So when you repeat, you have ceased to understand your own state of being. You are merely covering with words of authority your own confusion. But what we are trying to do is to understand this confusion and not cover it up with quotations; so what is your response to it? How do you respond to this extraordinary chaos, this confusion, this uncertainty of existence? Be aware of it, as I discuss it. Follow not my words, but the thought which is active in you. Most of us are accustomed to being spectators and not to partake in the game. We read books but we never write books. It has become our tradition, our national and universal habit, to be the spectators, to look on at a football game, to watch the public politicians and orators. We are merely the outsiders, looking on, and we have lost the creative capacity. Therefore, we want to absorb and partake.

苦难无处不在——政治的、社会的、宗教的；我们整个心理状态都处于混乱之中，所有政治和宗教领袖都让我们失望了；所有的书籍都失去了意义。你去翻阅《薄伽梵歌》或《圣经》，或是最新的政治或心理学论著，你会发现它们失去了那种铿锵有力、真理的特质；它们沦为了空洞的文字。而你，作为这些文字的复述者，自身也感到困惑和迷茫，仅仅重复文字毫无意义。因此，文字和书籍都失去了价值；也就是说，如果你引用《圣经》、马克思或《薄伽梵歌》，而你自身却感到迷茫和困惑，那么你的重复就变成了谎言；因为那里所写的内容变成了纯粹的宣传，而宣传并非真理。所以，当你重复时，你已经不再理解你自身的状态。你只是用权威的文字掩盖你自身的迷茫。但我们努力的目标是理解这种迷茫，而不是用引文来掩盖它。那么，你对此有何回应？你如何应对这非同寻常的混乱、迷茫和生存的不确定性？在我讨论这些问题时，请留意它们。不要盲目听从我的话语，而是跟随你内心活跃的思绪。我们大多数人习惯于做旁观者，而不是参与者。我们读书，却从不写书。旁观已成为我们的传统，我们民族乃至全世界的习惯，观看足球比赛，旁观政客和演说家的演讲。我们仅仅是局外人，旁观着一切，我们失去了创造力。因此，我们渴望吸收，渴望参与其中。

But if you are merely observing, if you are merely spectators, you will lose entirely the significance of this discourse, because I am not going to give you information which you can pick up in an encyclopedia. What we are trying to do is to follow each other’s thoughts, to pursue as far as we can, as profoundly as we can, the intimations, the responses, of our own feelings. So please find out what your response is to this cause, to this suffering; not what somebody else’s words are, but how you yourself respond. Your response is one of indifference if you benefit by the suffering, by the chaos, if you derive profit from it, either economic, social, political, or psychological. Therefore, you do not mind if this chaos continues. Surely, the more trouble there is in the world, the more chaos, the more one seeks security. Haven’t you noticed it? When there is confusion in the world, psychologically and in every way, you enclose yourself in some kind of security, either that of a bank account or that of an ideology; or else you turn to prayer, you go to the temple, which is really escaping from what is happening in the world. More and more sects are being formed, more and more “isms” are springing up all over the world. Because the more confusion there is, the more you want a leader, somebody who will guide you out of this mess, so you turn to the religious books, or to one of the latest teachers; or else you act and respond according to a system which appears to solve the problem, a system either of the left or of the right. That is exactly what is happening.

但如果你只是旁观者，仅仅是旁观者，你就会完全失去这次谈话的意义，因为我不会给你百科全书里就能找到的信息。我们努力做的是彼此交流思想，尽可能深入地探究我们自身感受的暗示和回应。所以，请你思考你对这项事业、对这场苦难的回应是什么；不是别人说了什么，而是你自己如何回应。如果你从苦难、混乱中获益，如果你从中得到经济、社会、政治或心理上的好处，那么你的回应就是漠不关心。因此，你并不在意这场混乱的持续。当然，世事越纷乱，越混乱，人们就越渴望安全感。你难道没有注意到吗？当世界陷入混乱，无论在心理上还是其他方面，你都会把自己包裹在某种安全感之中，无论是银行账户的安全感还是某种意识形态的安全感；否则，你就会转向祈祷，去寺庙，这实际上是在逃避世间正在发生的一切。越来越多的教派涌现，越来越多的“主义”在世界各地层出不穷。因为越是混乱，你就越渴望一位领袖，一位能带领你走出困境的人，于是你转向宗教经典，或者求助于某个最新的导师；或者，你按照某种看似能解决问题的体系行事，这种体系要么是左翼的，要么是右翼的。这正是正在发生的事情。

The moment you are aware of confusion, of exactly what is , you try to escape from it. Those sects which offer you a system for the solution of suffering—economic, social, or religious—are the worst; because then system becomes important and not man—whether it be a religious system, or a system of the left or of the right. System becomes important—the philosophy, the idea, becomes important—and not man; and for the sake of the idea, of the ideology, you are willing to sacrifice all mankind, which is exactly what is happening in the world. This is not merely my interpretation; if you observe, you will find that is exactly what is happening. The system has become important. Therefore, as the system has become important, men, you and I, lose significance; and the controllers of the system, whether religious or social, whether of the left or of the right, assume authority, assume power and, therefore, sacrifice you, the individual. That is exactly what is happening.

当你意识到混乱，意识到现实的真相时，你就会试图逃离它。那些声称能为你提供解决苦难的体系——无论是经济的、社会的还是宗教的——都是最糟糕的；因为那时，体系本身变得重要，而人则不再重要——无论是宗教体系，还是左翼或右翼的体系。体系——哲学、理念——变得重要，而人则不再重要；为了理念、为了意识形态，你甘愿牺牲全人类，而这正是当今世界正在发生的事情。这并非我的个人解读；如果你仔细观察，就会发现事实的确如此。体系变得重要了。因此，随着体系变得重要，人，你我，变得无关紧要；而体系的掌控者，无论是宗教的还是社会的，无论是左翼还是右翼，都攫取了权威，攫取了权力，从而牺牲了你，个体。这正是正在发生的事情。

Now what is the cause of this confusion, this misery? How did this misery come about, this suffering, not only inwardly but outwardly, this fear and expectation of war, the third World War that is breaking out? What is the cause of it? Surely it indicates the collapse of all moral, spiritual, values, and the glorification of all sensual values, of the value of things made by the hand or by the mind. What happens when we have no other values except the value of the things of the senses, the value of the products of the mind, of the hand, or of the machine? The more significance we give to the sensual value of things, the greater the confusion, is it not? Again, this is not my theory. You do not have to quote books to find out that your values, your riches, your economic and social existence are based on things made by the hand or by the mind. So we live and function and have our being steeped in sensual values, which means that things, the things of the mind, the things of the hand and of the machine, have become important; and when things become important, belief becomes predominantly significant—which is exactly what is happening in the world, is it not?

那么，造成这种混乱和痛苦的原因是什么？这种痛苦，这种折磨，不仅是内在的，也是外在的，这种对战争的恐惧和预期，这种即将爆发的第三次世界大战，是如何产生的？它的根源是什么？这无疑表明所有道德和精神价值的崩溃，以及所有感官价值，即手工或智力创造之物的价值，都被奉为圭臬。当我们除了感官之物的价值，除了智力、手工或机器创造之物的价值之外，别无其他价值时，会发生什么？我们越重视事物的感官价值，混乱就越严重，不是吗？当然，这并非我的理论。你无需引用书籍就能发现，你的价值观、你的财富、你的经济和社会生活都建立在手工或智力创造之物之上。因此，我们生活、运作、存在都浸润在感官价值之中，这意味着事物，智力创造之物，手工和机器创造之物，变得至关重要；当某些事情变得重要时，信仰就变得至关重要——这不正是当今世界正在发生的事情吗？

Thus, giving more and more significance to the values of the senses brings about confusion; and, being in confusion, we try to escape from it through various forms, whether religious, economic or social, or through ambition, through power, through the search for reality. But the real is near, you do not have to seek it; and a man who seeks truth will never find it. Truth is in what is —and that is the beauty of it. But the moment you conceive it, the moment you seek it, you begin to struggle; and a man who struggles cannot understand. That is why we have to be still, observant, passively aware. We see that our living, our action, is always within the field of destruction, within the field of sorrow; like a wave, confusion and chaos always overtake us. There is no interval in the confusion of existence.

因此，过分强调感官的价值会导致混乱；身处混乱之中，我们试图通过各种方式逃离，无论是宗教的、经济的、社会的，还是通过野心、权力、对真理的追寻。但真理近在咫尺，无需刻意寻找；而一个苦苦追寻真理的人永远也找不到它。真理存在于万物之中——这正是它的美妙之处。然而，一旦你开始执着于真理，一旦你开始追寻它，你便开始挣扎；而一个挣扎的人无法理解。正因如此，我们必须保持静默、观察、被动地觉察。我们看到，我们的生活，我们的行动，始终处于毁灭的领域，处于悲伤的领域；如同波浪一般，混乱和混沌总是将我们吞噬。存在的混乱之中没有一丝喘息之机。

Whatever we do at present seems to lead to chaos, seems to lead to sorrow and unhappiness. Look at your own life and you will see that our living is always on the border of sorrow. Our work, our social activity, our politics, the various gatherings of nations to stop war, all produce further war. Destruction follows in the wake of living; whatever we do leads to death. That is what is actually taking place.

我们现在所做的一切似乎都导向混乱，导向悲伤和不幸。审视一下你自己的生活，你会发现我们的生活总是徘徊在悲伤的边缘。我们的工作、我们的社会活动、我们的政治活动、各国为制止战争而举行的各种会议，都只会引发更多的战争。毁灭紧随生活而来；我们所做的一切最终都指向死亡。这才是正在发生的事情。

Can we stop this misery at once, and not go on always being caught by the wave of confusion and sorrow? That is, great teachers, whether the Buddha or the Christ, have come; they have accepted faith, making themselves, perhaps, free from confusion and sorrow. But they have never prevented sorrow, they have never stopped confusion. Confusion goes on, sorrow goes on. If you, seeing this social and economic confusion, this chaos, this misery, withdraw into what is called the religious life and abandon the world, you may feel that you are joining these great teachers; but the world goes on with its chaos, its misery and destruction, the everlasting suffering of its rich and poor. So, our problem, yours and mine, is whether we can step out of this misery instantaneously. If, living in the world, you refuse to be a part of it, you will help others out of this chaos—not in the future, not tomorrow, but now. Surely that is our problem. War is probably coming, more destructive, more appalling in its form. Surely we cannot prevent it, because the issues are much too strong and too close. But you and I can perceive the confusion and misery immediately, can we not? We must perceive them, and then we shall be in a position to awaken the same understanding of truth in another. In other words, can you be instantaneously free? Because that is the only way out of this misery. Perception can take place only in the present; but if you say, “I will do it tomorrow,” the wave of confusion overtakes you, and you are then always involved in confusion.

我们能否立刻止息这苦难，不再被迷茫和悲伤的浪潮所吞噬？也就是说，伟大的导师，无论是佛陀还是基督，都曾出现；他们接受了信仰，或许因此摆脱了迷茫和悲伤。但他们从未阻止过悲伤，也从未停止过迷茫。迷茫依旧，悲伤依旧。如果你目睹了这社会和经济的混乱、这无序、这苦难，选择遁入所谓的宗教生活，遁世隐居，你或许会觉得自己加入了这些伟大导师的行列；但世界依然在继续它的混乱、苦难和毁灭，富人和穷人依然在承受着永恒的痛苦。所以，我们面临的问题，你我共同的问题，是我们能否瞬间摆脱这苦难。如果你身处世间，却拒绝成为其中的一部分，你就能帮助他人摆脱这混乱——不是在未来，不是明天，而是现在。这无疑是我们面临的问题。战争或许即将到来，而且会更加具有破坏性，更加骇人听闻。我们当然无法阻止这一切，因为问题太过棘手，也太过切身。但你我都能立刻感受到这种困惑和痛苦，不是吗？我们必须感知到它们，然后才能在他人心中唤醒同样的真理认知。换句话说，你能否瞬间获得解脱？因为那是摆脱这种痛苦的唯一途径。感知只能发生在当下；但如果你说“我明天再做”，那么困惑的浪潮就会将你吞噬，你将永远深陷其中。

Now is it possible to come to that state when you yourself perceive the truth instantaneously and, therefore, put an end to confusion? I say that it is, and that it is the only possible way. I say it can be done and must be done, not based on supposition or belief. To bring about this extraordinary revolution—which is not the revolution to get rid of the capitalists and install another group—to bring about this wonderful transformation, which is the only true revolution, is the problem. What is generally called revolution is merely the modification or the continuance of the right according to the ideas of the left. The left, after all, is the continuation of the right in a modified form. If the right is based on sensual values, the left is but a continuance of the same sensual values, different only in degree or expression. Therefore, true revolution can take place only when you, the individual, become aware in your relationship to another. Surely what you are in your relationship to another, to your wife, your child, your boss, your neighbor, is society. Society by itself is nonexistent. Society is what you and I, in our relationship, have created; it is the outward projection of all our own inward psychological states. So if you and I do not understand ourselves, merely transforming the outer, which is the projection of the inner, has no significance whatsoever; that is, there can be no significant alteration or modification in society so long as I do not understand myself in relationship to you. Being confused in my relationship, I create a society which is the replica, the outward expression, of what I am. This is an obvious fact, which we can discuss. We can discuss whether society, the outward expression, has produced me, or whether I have produced society.

那么，是否有可能达到那种境界，即你瞬间领悟真理，从而终结一切迷茫？我的答案是肯定的，而且这是唯一可行的途径。我的答案是，这可以做到，也必须做到，并非基于臆测或信念。真正的问题在于，如何实现这场非凡的革命——它并非推翻资本家、建立另一批人的革命——如何实现这场伟大的变革，这才是唯一真正的革命。通常所谓的革命，不过是根据左派的理念对右派进行修正或延续。毕竟，左派是右派的某种修正后的延续。如果说右派建立在感官价值之上，那么左派也不过是同样的感官价值的延续，只是程度或表现形式有所不同。因此，真正的革命只有在你——个体——意识到你与他人的关系时才会发生。你与他人的关系，你与妻子、孩子、老板、邻居的关系，正是你与社会的关系。社会本身并不存在。社会是你我关系中共同创造的；它是我们所有内在心理状态的外在投射。因此，如果我们彼此不了解自己，仅仅改变外在形式（即内在的投射）毫无意义；也就是说，只要我不了解自己与你的关系，社会就不可能发生任何实质性的改变或演变。由于我在这段关系中感到困惑，我创造了一个社会，而这个社会正是我自身的复制品，是我自身的外在表现。这是一个显而易见的事实，我们可以探讨。我们可以探讨究竟是我创造了社会（即外在表现），还是我创造了社会。

Is it not, therefore, an obvious fact that what I am in my relationship to another creates society, and that without radically transforming myself, there can be no transformation of the essential function of society? When we look to a system for the transformation of society, we are merely evading the question, because a system cannot transform man; man always transforms the system, which history shows. Until I, in my relationship to you, understand myself, I am the cause of chaos, misery, destruction, fear, brutality. Understanding myself is not a matter of time; I can understand myself at this very moment. If I say, “I shall understand myself tomorrow,” I am bringing in chaos and misery, my action is destructive. The moment I say that I “shall” understand, I bring in the time element and so am already caught up in the wave of confusion and destruction. Understanding is now, not tomorrow. Tomorrow is for the lazy mind, the sluggish mind, the mind that is not interested. When you are interested in something, you do it instantaneously, there is immediate understanding, immediate transformation. If you do not change now, you will never change, because the change that takes place tomorrow is merely a modification, it is not transformation. Transformation can only take place immediately; the revolution is now, not tomorrow.

因此，我与他人的关系创造了社会，这难道不是一个显而易见的事实吗？如果不彻底改变自己，社会的本质功能就无法改变。当我们指望通过某种体系来改造社会时，我们只是在回避问题，因为体系无法改变人；历史已经证明，总是人改造体系。在我与你的关系中，除非我理解自己，否则我就是混乱、痛苦、毁灭、恐惧和暴行的根源。理解自己并非时间问题；我此刻就能理解自己。如果我说“我明天再理解自己”，我便带来了混乱和痛苦，我的行为是破坏性的。当我说我“将要”理解的那一刻，我就引入了时间因素，从而被卷入了混乱和毁灭的浪潮之中。理解就在当下，而非明天。明天是懒惰、迟钝、漠不关心的人才会考虑的。当你对某件事感兴趣时，你会立即行动，立刻理解，立刻改变。如果你现在不改变，就永远不会改变，因为明天发生的改变仅仅是修正，而非变革。变革只能立即发生；革命就在当下，而非明日。

When that happens, you are completely without a problem, for then the self is not worried about itself; then you are beyond the wave of destruction.

当这种情况发生时，你就完全没有问题了，因为那时自我不再为自身担忧；那时你就超越了毁灭的浪潮。

#↩

AMBITION

志向

The baby had been crying all night, and the poor mother had been doing her best to quiet him. She sang to him, she scolded him, she petted and rocked him; but it was no good. The baby must have been teething, and it was a weary night for the whole family. But now the dawn was coming over the dark trees, and at last the baby became quiet. There was a peculiar stillness as the sky grew lighter and lighter. The deep branches were clear against the sky, slender and naked; a child called, a dog barked, a lorry rattled by, and another day had begun. Presently the mother came out carrying the baby, carefully wrapped, and walked along the road past the village, where she waited for a bus. Presumably she was taking him to the doctor. She looked so tired and haggard after that sleepless night, but the baby was fast asleep.

婴儿哭了一整夜，可怜的母亲竭尽全力哄他安静下来。她唱歌哄他，责骂他，抚摸他，摇晃他；但都无济于事。婴儿一定是长牙了，对全家来说，这都是一个疲惫的夜晚。但现在，黎明正从黑暗的树林中透出，婴儿终于安静了下来。随着天空越来越亮，周围一片静谧。纤细而光秃的树枝在天空的映衬下显得格外清晰；一个孩子的哭声，一声狗吠，一辆卡车隆隆驶过，新的一天开始了。过了一会儿，母亲抱着裹得严严实实的婴儿走了出来，沿着路走过村庄，在那里等着公共汽车。想必她是要带他去看医生。经过一夜未眠，她看起来疲惫不堪，憔悴不堪，但婴儿却睡得很香。

Soon the sun was over the treetops, and the dew sparkled on the green grass. Far away a train whistled, and the distant mountains looked cool and shadowy. A large bird flew noisily away, for we had disturbed her brooding. Our approach must have been very sudden, for she hadn’t had time to cover her eggs with dry leaves. There were over a dozen of them. Even though uncovered they were hardly visible, she had so cleverly concealed them, and now she was watching from a distant tree. We saw the mother with her brood a few days later, and the nest was empty.

太阳很快升到了树梢之上，露珠在绿草上闪闪发光。远处传来火车的汽笛声，远山显得凉爽而阴沉。一只大鸟聒噪地飞走了，因为我们打扰了它孵蛋。我们的靠近一定非常突然，因为它来不及用干树叶盖住鸟蛋。鸟蛋足足有十几枚。即使没有树叶的遮盖，它们也几乎看不见，但它藏得如此巧妙，现在正从远处的一棵树上观察着。几天后，我们看到了这只母鸟和它的幼鸟，但鸟巢已经空了。

It was shady and cool along the path, which led through the damp woods to the distant hilltop, and the wattle was in bloom. It had rained heavily a few days before, and the earth was soft and yielding. There were fields of young potatoes, and far down in the valley was the town. It was a beautiful, golden morning. Beyond the hill the path led back to the house.

沿着小路走，阴凉舒适，这条路穿过潮湿的树林，通往远处的山顶，金合欢花正值盛开。几天前下了一场大雨，泥土松软肥沃。远处是成片的土豆苗，山谷深处便是小镇。这是一个美丽的金色清晨。翻过山丘，小路又通向房子。

She was very clever. She had read all the latest books, had seen the latest plays, and was well-informed about some philosophy which had become the latest craze. She had been analyzed and had apparently read a great deal of psychology, for she knew the jargon. She made a point of seeing all the important people, and had casually met someone who brought her along. She talked easily and expressed herself with poise and effect. She had been married, but had had no children; and one felt that all that was behind her, and that now she was on a different journey. She must have been rich, for she had about her that peculiar atmosphere of the wealthy. She began right away by asking, “In what way are you helping the world in this present crisis?” It must have been one of her stock questions. She went on to ask, more eagerly, about the prevention of war, the effects of communism, and the future of man.

她非常聪明。她读过所有最新的书籍，看过最新的戏剧，并且对某种时下流行的哲学颇有研究。她接受过心理分析，而且显然读过大量的心理学书籍，因为她熟悉那些专业术语。她刻意结识所有重要人物，并且偶然间认识了一位带她一同前往的人。她谈吐得体，举止优雅，富有感染力。她结过婚，但没有孩子；人们感觉她已经告别了过去，现在正踏上另一段人生旅程。她一定很富有，因为她身上散发着富人特有的气质。她一上来就问道：“在当前的危机中，您是如何帮助世界的？”这一定是她的惯用问题之一。随后，她更加急切地询问了关于预防战争、共产主义的影响以及人类未来等问题。

Are not wars, the increasing disasters and miseries, the outcome of our daily life? Are we not, each one of us, responsible for this crisis? The future is in the present; the future will not be very different if there is no comprehension of the present. But do you not think that each one of us is responsible for this conflict and confusion?

战争、日益增多的灾难和苦难，难道不是我们日常生活的必然结果吗？我们每个人，难道不都应该为这场危机负责吗？未来就在当下；如果我们不理解当下，未来也不会有太大的不同。难道你不认为，我们每个人都应该为这场冲突和混乱负责吗？

“It may be so; but where does this recognition of responsibility lead? What value has my little action in the vast destructive action? In what way is my thought going to affect the general stupidity of man? What is happening in the world is sheer stupidity, and my intelligence is in no way going to affect it. Besides, think of the time it would take for individual action to make any impression on the world.”

“或许如此；但这种对责任的认知又将把我引向何方？在浩瀚的破坏性浪潮中，我微不足道的行动又有何价值？我的想法又能如何影响人类普遍的愚昧？世间正在发生的一切纯粹是愚昧，我的智慧根本无济于事。再说，想想看，个人的行动需要多久才能对世界产生任何影响。”

Is the world different from you? Has not the structure of society been built up by people like you and me? To bring about a radical change in the structure, must not you and I fundamentally transform ourselves? How can there be a deep revolution of values if it does not begin with us? To help in the present crisis, must one look for a new ideology, a new economic plan? Or must one begin to understand the conflict and confusion within oneself, which, in its projection, is the world? Can new ideologies bring unity between man and man? Do not beliefs set man against man? Must we not put away our ideological barriers—for all barriers are ideological—and consider our problems, not through the bias of conclusions and formulas, but directly and without prejudice? We are never directly in relationship with our problems, but always through some belief or formulation. We can solve our problems only when we are directly in relationship with them. It is not our problems which set man against man, but our ideas about them. Problems bring us together, but ideas separate us. If one may ask, why are you so apparently concerned about the crisis?

世界与你不同吗？社会结构难道不是由像你我这样的人构建起来的吗？要彻底改变这种结构，你我难道不应该从根本上改变自己吗？如果一场深刻的价值观革命不从我们自身开始，又怎能发生？为了应对当前的危机，我们必须寻找新的意识形态、新的经济方案吗？还是应该开始理解自身内部的冲突和困惑——而这冲突和困惑，正是世界的投射？新的意识形态能够带来人与人之间的团结吗？信仰难道不会使人与人对立吗？我们难道不应该摒弃意识形态的壁垒——因为所有的壁垒都是意识形态的——而是应该抛开成见和公式的偏见，直接、客观地审视我们的问题吗？我们从未直接面对问题，而是总是通过某种信念或表述来理解问题。只有当我们直接面对问题时，才能解决问题。使人与人对立的不是问题本身，而是我们对问题的看法。问题使我们团结，而观念使我们分裂。恕我直言，您为何如此关注这场危机？

“Oh, I don’t know. I see so much suffering, so much misery, and I feel something must be done about it.”

“哦，我不知道。我看到这么多苦难，这么多悲惨的事情，我觉得必须做点什么来改变这种状况。”

Are you really concerned, or are you merely ambitious to do something?

你真的关心这件事，还是仅仅因为野心勃勃想做点什么？

“When you put it that way, I suppose I am ambitious to do something in which I shall succeed.”

“这么说来，我想我的确很有抱负，想做一件我能成功的事情。”

So few of us are honest in our thinking. We want to be successful, either directly for ourselves, or for the ideal, the belief with which we have identified ourselves. The ideal is our own projection, it is the product of our mind, and our mind experiences according to our conditioning. For these self-projections we work, we slave away and die. Nationalism, like the worship of God, is only the glorification of oneself. It is oneself that is important, actually or ideologically, and not the disaster and the misery. We really do not want to do anything about the crisis; it is merely a new topic for the clever, a field for the socially active and for the idealist.

我们当中很少有人能坦诚思考。我们渴望成功，要么是为了自己，要么是为了某种理想——我们认同的信念。理想是我们自身的投射，是我们思维的产物，而我们的思维又受制于我们的固有思维模式。为了这些自我投射，我们辛勤劳作，甚至献出生命。民族主义，如同对上帝的崇拜，不过是自我的荣耀。真正重要的，是自身，无论从实际层面还是意识形态层面，而非灾难和苦难。我们其实并不想为这场危机做任何事；它只不过是聪明人的新话题，是社会活动家和理想主义者的舞台。

Why are we ambitious?

我们为何雄心勃勃？

“If we were not, nothing would get done in the world. If we were not ambitious we would still be driving about in horse carriages. Ambition is another name for progress. Without progress, we would decay, wither away.”

“如果我们不追求卓越，世界上将一事无成。如果我们没有雄心壮志，我们可能还在乘坐马车。雄心壮志是进步的另一种说法。没有进步，我们就会衰败，消亡。”

In getting things done in the world, we are also breeding wars and untold miseries. Is ambition progress? For the moment we are not considering progress, but ambition. Why are we ambitious? Why do we want to succeed, to be somebody? Why do we struggle to be superior? Why all this effort to assert oneself, whether directly, or through an ideology or the State? Is not this self-assertion the main cause of our conflict and confusion? Without ambition, would we perish? Can we not physically survive without being ambitious?

在追求成功的过程中，我们也滋生了战争和难以言喻的苦难。雄心壮志是进步吗？此刻，我们关注的并非进步，而是雄心壮志。我们为何如此雄心勃勃？为何渴望成功，渴望成为重要人物？为何我们苦苦追求卓越？为何我们要如此费尽心思地展现自我，无论是直接的，还是通过意识形态或国家？这种自我展现难道不是我们冲突和混乱的根源吗？没有雄心壮志，我们会灭亡吗？没有雄心壮志，我们难道就无法生存吗？

“Who wants to survive without success, without recognition?”

“谁愿意在没有成功、没有认可的情况下苟活呢？”

Does not this desire for success, for applause, bring conflict both within and without? Would being free of ambition mean decay? Is it stagnation to have no conflict? We can drug ourselves, put ourselves to sleep with beliefs, with doctrines, and so have no deep conflicts. For most of us, some kind of activity is the drug. Obviously, such a state is one of decay, disintegration. But when we are aware of the false as the false, does it bring death? To be aware that ambition in any form, whether for happiness, for God, or for success, is the beginning of conflict both within and without, surely does not mean the end of all action, the end of life.

对成功和赞誉的渴望，难道不会带来内外冲突吗？摆脱野心是否意味着衰败？没有冲突是否意味着停滞不前？我们可以用信仰和教条麻痹自己，让自己沉睡，从而避免深刻的冲突。对我们大多数人来说，某种活动就是麻醉剂。显然，这种状态是一种衰败和瓦解。但是，当我们意识到虚假的本质时，是否就意味着死亡？意识到任何形式的野心，无论是对幸福的追求、对上帝的信仰，还是对成功的渴望，都是内外冲突的开端，这绝不意味着一切行动的终结，生命的终结。

Why are we ambitious?

我们为何雄心勃勃？

“I would be bored if I were not occupied in striving to achieve some kind of result. I used to be ambitious for my husband, and I suppose you would say it was for myself through my husband; and now I am ambitious for myself through an idea. I have never thought about ambition, I have just been ambitious.”

“如果我不忙于努力追求某种成果，我会感到无聊。我过去对丈夫充满抱负，我想你会说，那是通过丈夫来实现我自己的抱负；而现在，我通过一个想法来实现我自己的抱负。我从未刻意思考过抱负，我只是自然而然地拥有了抱负。”

Why are we clever and ambitious? Is not ambition an urge to avoid what is ? Is not this cleverness really stupid, which is what we are? Why are we so frightened of what is ? What is the good of running away if whatever we are is always there? We may succeed in escaping, but what we are is still there, breeding conflict and misery. Why are we so frightened of our loneliness, of our emptiness? Any activity away from what is is bound to bring sorrow and antagonism. Conflict is the denial of what is or the running away from what is ; there is no conflict other than that. Our conflict becomes more and more complex and insoluble because we do not face what is . There is no complexity in what is , but only in the many escapes that we seek.

我们为何如此聪明且雄心勃勃？雄心难道不是一种逃避现实的冲动吗？这种聪明难道不正是愚蠢的本质吗？我们为何如此惧怕现实？如果我们的本质始终存在，逃避又有何益？我们或许能够成功逃脱，但我们的本质依然存在，滋生冲突和痛苦。我们为何如此惧怕孤独，惧怕空虚？任何逃避现实的行为都注定会带来悲伤和对抗。冲突是对现实的否定或逃避；除此之外，别无其他冲突。我们的冲突变得越来越复杂，越来越难以解决，因为我们不愿面对现实。现实本身并不复杂，复杂只存在于我们所寻求的种种逃避之中。

#↩

THE INDIVIDUAL AND THE IDEAL

个人与理想

“Our life here in India is more or less shattered; we want to make something of it again, but we don’t know where to begin. I can see the importance of mass action, and also its dangers. I have pursued the ideal of nonviolence, but there has been bloodshed and misery. Since the Partition, this country has had blood on its hands, and now we are building up the armed forces. We talk of nonviolence and yet prepare for war. I am as confused as the political leaders. In prison I used to read a great deal, but it has not helped me to clarify my own position.

“我们在印度的生活几乎支离破碎；我们想重建家园，却不知从何下手。我明白群众运动的重要性，也明白它的危险。我一直奉行非暴力理想，但随之而来的是流血和苦难。自印巴分治以来，这个国家双手沾满鲜血，而现在我们却在扩充军备。我们口口声声说着非暴力，却又在备战。我和那些政治领袖一样困惑。在狱中，我读了很多书，但这并没有帮助我理清自己的立场。”

“Can we take one thing at a time and somewhat go into it? First, you lay a great deal of emphasis on the individual, but is not collective action necessary?”

“我们能不能一步一步来，慢慢深入探讨一下？首先，你非常强调个人，但集体行动难道不是必要的吗？”

The individual is essentially the collective, and society is the creation of the individual. The individual and society are interrelated, are they not? They are not separate. The individual builds the structure of society, and society or environment shapes the individual. Though environment conditions the individual, he can always free himself, break away from his background. The individual is the maker of the very environment to which he becomes a slave; but he has also the power to break away from it and create an environment that will not dull his mind or spirit. The individual is important only in the sense that he has the capacity to free himself from his conditioning and understand reality. Individuality that is merely ruthless in its own conditioning builds a society whose foundations are based on violence and antagonism. The individual exists only in relationship, otherwise he is not; and it is the lack of understanding of this relationship that is breeding conflict and confusion. If the individual does not understand his relationship to people, to property, and to ideas or beliefs, merely to impose upon him a collective or any other pattern only defeats its own end. To bring about the imposition of a new pattern will require so-called mass action; but the new pattern is the invention of a few individuals, and the mass is mesmerized by the latest slogans, the promises of a new utopia. The mass is the same as before, only now it has new rulers, new phrases, new priests, new doctrines. This mass is made up of you and me, it is composed of individuals; the mass is fictitious, it is a convenient term for the exploiter and the politician to play with. The many are pushed into action, into war, and so on, by the few; and the few represent the desires and urges of the many. It is the transformation of the individual that is of the highest importance, but not in terms of any pattern. Patterns always condition, and a conditioned entity is always in conflict within himself and so with society. It is comparatively easy to substitute a new pattern of conditioning for the old; but for the individual to free himself from all conditioning is quite another matter.

个体本质上是集体，社会是个体的创造。个体与社会相互关联，不是吗？它们并非分离的。个体构建社会结构，社会或环境塑造个体。尽管环境制约着个体，个体总能挣脱束缚，摆脱既有环境的束缚。个体既是自身所处环境的创造者，也是最终沦为奴隶的个体；但他同样有能力挣脱束缚，创造一个不会使其思想或精神麻木的环境。个体之所以重要，仅仅在于他有能力摆脱制约，理解现实。如果个体仅仅被自身的制约所束缚，那么他所构建的社会基础便是暴力和对抗。个体的存在离不开关系，否则他便不复存在；正是对这种关系的无知滋生了冲突和混乱。如果个体不理解自身与他人、财产、思想或信仰的关系，那么强加于他的任何集体或其他模式都只会适得其反。要推行一种新的模式，需要所谓的群众行动；然而，这种新模式不过是少数人的发明，而群众却被最新的口号和对新乌托邦的承诺所迷惑。群众和以前一样，只不过现在有了新的统治者、新的口号、新的牧师和新的教条。这个群众由你我组成，由一个个个体构成；群众是虚构的，是剥削者和政客用来玩弄权术的方便词汇。少数人驱使多数人采取行动，发动战争等等；而少数人则代表多数人的欲望和冲动。最重要的在于个体的转变，但这并非以任何模式为依据。模式总是具有制约性，而受制约的个体总是处于内部冲突，也总是与社会冲突。用新的制约模式取代旧的制约模式相对容易；但要让个体摆脱所有制约，则完全是另一回事。

“This requires careful and detailed thought, but I think I am beginning to understand it. You lay emphasis on the individual, but not as a separate and antagonistic force within society. Now the second point. I have always worked for an ideal, and I don’t understand your denial of it. Would you mind going into this problem?”

“这需要仔细思考，但我认为我开始理解了。您强调的是个人，但并非将其视为社会中独立且对立的力量。现在是第二点。我一直为理想而奋斗，我不明白您为何否定它。您能否就此问题进行一番探讨？”

Our present morality is based on the past or the future, on the traditional, or the what ought to be. The what ought to be is the ideal in opposition to what has been, the future in conflict with the past. Nonviolence is the ideal, the what should be; and the what has been is violence. The what has been projects the what should be; the ideal is homemade, it is projected by its own opposite, the actual. The antithesis is an extension of the thesis; the opposite contains the element of its own opposite. Being violent, the mind projects its opposite, the ideal of nonviolence. It is said that the ideal helps to overcome its own opposite; but does it? Is not the ideal an avoidance, an escape from the what has been, or from what is ? The conflict between the actual and the ideal is obviously a means of postponing the understanding of the actual, and this conflict only introduces another problem which helps to cover up the immediate problem. The ideal is a marvelous and respectable escape from the actual. The ideal of nonviolence, like the collective utopia, is fictitious; the ideal, the what should be, helps us to cover up and avoid what is .

我们当下的道德观建立在过去或未来，建立在传统或“应然”之上。“应然”是与“已然”相对立的理想，是与“过去”相冲突的未来。非暴力是理想，是“应然”；而“已然”则是暴力。“已然”投射出“应然”；理想是人为构建的，它由自身的对立面——现实——投射而来。对立面是正题的延伸；对立面包含着自身对立面的元素。由于暴力，心灵投射出其对立面——非暴力的理想。有人说理想有助于克服自身的对立面；但事实果真如此吗？理想难道不是一种逃避，一种对“已然”或“现在”的逃避吗？现实与理想之间的冲突显然是一种延缓理解现实的手段，而这种冲突只会引入另一个问题，从而掩盖眼前的难题。理想是一种奇妙而体面的逃避现实的方式。非暴力理想，就像集体乌托邦一样，是虚构的；理想，应该是什么样子，帮助我们掩盖和逃避现实。

The pursuit of the ideal is the search for reward. You may shun the worldly rewards as being stupid and barbarous, which they are; but your pursuit of the ideal is the search for reward at a different level, which is also stupid. The ideal is a compensation, a fictitious state which the mind has conjured up. Being violent, separate, and out for itself, the mind projects the gratifying compensation, the fiction which it calls the ideal, the utopia, the future, and vainly pursues it. That very pursuit is conflict, but it is also a pleasurable postponement of the actual. The ideal, the what should be, does not help in understanding what is ; on the contrary, it prevents understanding.

追求理想即是寻求回报。你或许会鄙视世俗的回报，认为它们愚蠢而野蛮——它们的确如此；但你对理想的追求，却是在另一个层面上寻求回报，而这同样是愚蠢的。理想是一种补偿，是心灵臆造出来的虚构状态。心灵充满暴力、孤立和自我中心，它投射出令人愉悦的补偿，这种虚构的状态被它称为理想、乌托邦、未来，并徒劳地追求它。这种追求本身就是一种冲突，但它也是对现实的一种愉悦的延缓。理想，即“应该是什么”，无助于理解“是什么”；相反，它阻碍了理解。

“Do you mean to say that our leaders and teachers have been wrong in advocating and maintaining the ideal?”

“你的意思是说，我们的领导人和教师在倡导和维护这一理想方面是错误的吗？”

What do you think?

你怎么认为？

“If I understand correctly what you say—”

“如果我理解没错的话——”

Please, it is not a matter of understanding what another may say, but of finding out what is true. Truth is not opinion; truth is not dependent on any leader or teacher. The weighing of opinions only prevents the perception of truth. Either the ideal is a homemade fiction which contains its own opposite, or it is not. There are no two ways about it. This does not depend on any teacher, you must perceive the truth of it for yourself.

请记住，关键不在于理解他人所说的话，而在于探寻真相。真理并非观点，也不依赖于任何领袖或导师。权衡各种观点只会阻碍我们对真理的认知。理想要么是自创的、包含其自身对立面的虚构，要么就不是。没有其他选择。这与任何导师无关，你必须自己去领悟真理。

“If the ideal is fictitious, it revolutionizes all my thinking. Do you mean to say that our pursuit of the ideal is utterly futile?”

“如果理想是虚构的，那将彻底颠覆我的想法。你的意思是说，我们对理想的追求完全是徒劳的吗？”

It is a vain struggle, a gratifying self-deception, is it not?

这是一种徒劳的斗争，一种令人满足的自我欺骗，不是吗？

“This is very disturbing, but I am forced to admit that it is. We have taken so many things for granted that we have never allowed ourselves to observe closely what is in our hand. We have deceived ourselves, and what you point out upsets completely the structure of my thought and action. It will revolutionize education, our whole way of living and working. I think I see the implications of a mind that is free from the ideal, from the what should be. To such a mind, action has a significance quite different from that which we give it now. Compensatory action is not action at all, but only a reaction—and we boast of action! But without the ideal, how is one to deal with the actual, or with the what has been?”

“这令人非常不安，但我不得不承认事实的确如此。我们一直以来都把太多事情视为理所当然，以至于从未认真审视过我们手中所拥有的。我们一直在自欺欺人，而你指出的这一点彻底颠覆了我的思维和行动模式。它将彻底改变教育，改变我们整个生活和工作方式。我想我明白了摆脱理想、摆脱‘应该是什么’的思维模式意味着什么。在这种思维模式下，行动的意义与我们现在赋予它的意义截然不同。补偿性行动根本算不上行动，而仅仅是一种反应——而我们却还自诩行动！但如果没有理想，我们又该如何面对现实，如何面对过去呢？”

The understanding of the actual is possible only when the ideal, the what should be, is erased from the mind; that is, only when the false is seen as the false. The what should be is also the what should not be. As long as the mind approaches the actual with either positive or negative compensation, there can be no understanding of the actual.
