To understand the actual you must be in direct communion with it; your relationship with it cannot be through the screen of the ideal, or through the screen of the past, of tradition, of experience. To be free from the wrong approach is the only problem. This means, really, the understanding of conditioning, which is the mind. The problem is the mind itself, and not the problems it breeds; the resolution of the problems bred by the mind is merely the reconciliation of effects, and that only leads to further confusion and illusion.

只有当理想，即“应然”从心中抹去，才能真正理解现实；也就是说，只有当虚假被看作虚假时，才能真正理解现实。“应然”同时也是“不应然”。只要心智以正向或负向的补偿来接近现实，就无法理解现实。要理解现实，你必须与它直接交流；你与它的关系不能透过理想的屏障，也不能透过过去、传统或经验的屏障。摆脱错误的方法是唯一的问题。这实际上意味着理解制约，也就是心智本身。问题在于心智本身，而不是它所滋生的问题；解决心智所滋生的问题仅仅是调和结果，而这只会导致更多的困惑和幻觉。

“How is one to understand the mind?”

“如何才能理解人的心灵？”

The way of the mind is the way of life—not the ideal life, but the actual life of sorrow and pleasure, of deception and clarity, of conceit and the pose of humility. To understand the mind is to be aware of desire and fear.

心之道即人生之道——并非理想人生，而是充满悲欢离合、迷惑明晰、自负谦逊的真实人生。了解心，便是觉察欲望与恐惧。

“Please, this is getting a bit too much for me. How am I to understand my mind?”

“拜托，这对我来说有点太难了。我该如何理解自己的内心呢？”

To know the mind, must you not be aware of its activities? The mind is only experience, not just the immediate, but also the accumulated. The mind is the past in response to the present, which makes for the future. The total process of the mind has to be understood.

要了解心智，难道不应该觉察它的活动吗？心智就是经验，不仅是当下的体验，也包括累积的经验。心智是过去对现在的回应，而现在又塑造了未来。我们必须理解心智的整个运作过程。

“Where am I to begin?”

我该从何说起呢？

From the only beginning: relationship. Relationship is life; to be is to be related. Only in the mirror of relationship is the mind to be understood, and you have to begin to see yourself in that mirror.

一切皆源于关系。关系即生命；存在即关联。唯有在关系的镜中，心灵方能被理解，而你必须开始在那面镜子中审视自己。

“Do you mean in my relationship with my wife, with my neighbor, and so on? Is that not a very limited process?”

“你是说我和妻子、邻居等等之间的关系吗？那岂不是一个非常局限的过程吗？”

What may appear to be small, limited, if approached rightly, reveals the fathomless. It is like a funnel, the narrow opens into the wide. When observed with passive watchfulness, the limited reveals the limitless. After all, at its source the river is small, hardly worth noticing.

看似渺小、有限的事物，若以正确的方式看待，便能揭示其深不可测的本质。它如同漏斗，狭窄之处通向宽广之处。以被动的觉察力观察，有限的事物便会展现出无限的可能。毕竟，河流的源头也十分渺小，几乎不值一提。

“So I must begin with myself and my immediate relationships.”

“所以我必须从我自己以及我身边的人开始。”

Surely. Relationship is never narrow or small. With the one or with the many, relationship is a complex process, and you can approach it pettily, or freely and openly. Again, the approach is dependent on the state of the mind. If you do not begin with yourself, where else will you begin? Even if you begin with some peripheral activity, you are in relationship with it, the mind is the center of it. Whether you begin near or far, you are there. Without understanding yourself, whatever you do will inevitably bring about confusion and sorrow. The beginning is the ending.

当然。关系从来都不是狭隘或渺小的。无论是与一个人还是与一群人，关系都是一个复杂的过程，你可以斤斤计较，也可以自由开放地对待。再次强调，这种对待方式取决于你的心境。如果你不从自身开始，又能从哪里开始呢？即使你从一些无关紧要的事情开始，你也与它建立了联系，因为你的心是它的中心。无论你从近处还是远处开始，你都身处其中。如果不了解自己，你所做的一切都必然会带来困惑和痛苦。开始即是结束。

“I have wandered far afield. I have seen and done many things, I have suffered and laughed like so many others, and yet I have had to come back to myself. I am like that sannyasi who set out in search of truth. He spent many years going from teacher to teacher, and each pointed out a different way. At last he wearily returned to his home, and in his own house was the jewel! I see how foolish we are, searching the universe for that bliss which is to be found only in our own hearts when the mind is purged of its activities. You are perfectly right. I begin from where I started. I begin with what I am.”

我曾远行四方，见识过许多事物，也像其他人一样经历过苦难和欢笑，然而最终我还是回归了自我。我就像那位苦行僧，踏上寻道之旅。他多年求学，拜访过无数老师，每位老师都指引他不同的道路。最终，他疲惫地回到家中，却发现珍宝就在家中！我明白我们是多么愚蠢，在宇宙中苦苦寻觅那份唯有在我们内心深处才能找到的极乐，而那时，我们的心念才能彻底摆脱一切纷扰。你说得完全正确。我从起点出发，从我本来的样子出发。

#↩

FEAR AND ESCAPE

恐惧与逃避

We were steadily climbing, without any perceptible movement. Below us was a vast sea of clouds, white and dazzling, wave upon wave as far as the eye could see. They looked so astonishingly solid and inviting. Occasionally, as we climbed higher in a wide circle there were breaks in this brilliant foam, and far below was the green earth. Above us was the clear blue sky of winter, soft and immeasurable. A massive range of snow-covered mountains stretched from north to south, sparkling in the brilliant sun. These mountains reached an elevation of over fourteen thousand feet, but we had risen above them and were still climbing. They were a familiar range of peaks, and they looked so near and serene. The higher peaks lay to the north, and we shot off to the south, having reached the required altitude of twenty thousand feet.

我们稳步攀升，几乎感觉不到任何移动。下方是一片浩瀚的云海，洁白耀眼，层层叠叠，绵延至目之所及。它们看起来如此坚实，如此诱人。偶尔，当我们绕着一个大圈向上攀登时，这片闪耀的云层会出现一些缝隙，远处便是绿色的土地。上方是冬日湛蓝的天空，柔和而无垠。一条绵延的雪山从北向南延伸，在灿烂的阳光下闪闪发光。这些山峰海拔超过一万四千英尺，但我们已经超过了它们，并且仍在继续攀登。这些山峰似曾相识，看起来如此近在咫尺，又如此宁静祥和。更高的山峰位于北方，而我们则向南疾驰，到达了所需的两万英尺高度。

The passenger in the next seat was very talkative. He was unfamiliar with those mountains, and had dozed as we climbed; but now he was awake and eager for a talk. It appeared that he was going out on some business for the first time; he seemed to have many interests, and spoke with considerable information about them. The sea was now below us, dark and distant, and a few ships were dotted here and there. There was not a tremor of the wings, and we passed one lighted town after another along the coast. He was saying how difficult it was not to have fear, not particularly of a crash, but of all the accidents of life. He was married and had children, and there was always fear—not of the future alone, but of everything in general. It was a fear that had no particular object, and though he was successful, this fear made his life weary and painful. He had always been rather apprehensive, but now it had become extremely persistent and his dreams were of a frightening nature. His wife knew of his fear, but she was not aware of its seriousness.

坐在旁边的乘客很健谈。他对这片山脉并不熟悉，我们爬山的时候他打了个盹儿；但现在他醒了，很想聊聊天。看来他是第一次出差；他似乎兴趣广泛，而且对这些事情都了如指掌。此时，大海就在我们下方，深邃而遥远，零星散布着几艘船只。飞机机翼平稳，我们沿着海岸线，一个接一个地经过灯火通明的城镇。他正说着，不害怕是多么困难，倒不是害怕坠机，而是害怕生活中所有的意外。他已婚，有孩子，总是心怀恐惧——不仅是对未来的恐惧，而是对一切事物的恐惧。这种恐惧没有具体的原因，虽然他事业有成，但这种恐惧却让他的生活疲惫不堪，痛苦不堪。他一直都有些忧虑，但现在这种忧虑变得格外挥之不去，他的梦境也变得令人毛骨悚然。他的妻子知道他害怕，但她并不知道这种恐惧有多么严重。

Fear can exist only in relation to something. As an abstraction, fear is a mere word, and the word is not the actual fear. Do you know specifically of what you are afraid?

恐惧只能与事物相关联。作为一种抽象概念，恐惧仅仅是一个词，而这个词本身并非恐惧。你具体知道你害怕的是什么吗？

“I have never been able to lay my finger on it, and my dreams too are very vague; but threading through them all there is fear. I have talked to friends and doctors about it, but they have either laughed it off or otherwise not been of much help. It has always eluded me, and I want to be free of the beastly thing.”

“我一直无法确切地描述它，我的梦境也很模糊；但贯穿始终的是一种恐惧。我曾和朋友、医生谈过这件事，但他们要么一笑置之，要么也帮不上什么忙。它一直困扰着我，我只想摆脱这种可怕的感觉。”

Do you really want to be free, or is that just a phrase?

你真的想要自由吗？还是这只是一句空话？

“I may sound casual, but I would give a great deal to be rid of this fear. I am not a particularly religious person, but strangely enough I have prayed to have it taken away from me. When I am interested in my work, or in a game, it is often absent; but like some monster it is ever waiting, and soon we are companions again.”

“我可能听起来漫不经心，但我多么渴望摆脱这种恐惧。我并非一个特别虔诚的信徒，但奇怪的是，我曾祈祷过摆脱它。当我专注于工作或游戏时，它往往不会出现；但它就像某种怪物，时刻潜伏着，很快我们又会如影随形。”

Have you that fear now? Are you aware now that it is somewhere about? Is the fear conscious or hidden?

你现在有这种恐惧吗？你现在意识到它就在你身边吗？这种恐惧是有意识的还是隐藏的？

“I can sense it, but I do not know whether it is conscious or unconscious.”

“我能感觉到，但我不知道这是有意识的还是无意识的。”

Do you sense it as something far away or near—not in space or distance, but as a feeling?

你觉得它是遥远的还是近在咫尺的？——不是指空间或距离，而是一种感觉？

“When I am aware of it, it seems to be quite close. But what has that got to do with it?”

“当我意识到这一点时，它似乎非常接近。但这又有什么关系呢？”

Fear can come into being only in relation to something. That something may be your family, your work, your preoccupation with the future, with death. Are you afraid of death?

恐惧只能与某种事物相关联而产生。这种事物可能是你的家人、你的工作、你对未来的担忧，或者你对死亡的恐惧。你害怕死亡吗？

“Not particularly, though I would like to have a quick death and not a long drawn-out one. I don’t think it is my family that I have this anxiety about, nor is it my job.”

“倒也不是特别想死，虽然我希望死得痛快些，而不是痛苦地死去。我觉得让我焦虑的既不是我的家人，也不是我的工作。”

Then it must be something deeper than the superficial relationships that is causing this fear. One may be able to point out what it is, but if you can discover it for yourself it will have far greater significance. Why are you not afraid of the superficial relationships?

那么，这种恐惧一定源于比肤浅的人际关系更深层次的原因。或许有人能指出它是什么，但如果你能自己发现它，意义将更加重大。你为什么不害怕肤浅的人际关系呢？

“My wife and I love each other; she wouldn’t think of looking at another man, and I am not attracted to other women. We find completeness in each other. The children are an anxiety, and what one can do, one does; but with all this economic mess in the world, one cannot give them financial security, and they will have to do the best they can. My job is fairly secure, but there is the natural fear of anything happening to my wife.”

“我和妻子彼此相爱；她根本不会考虑其他男人，我对其他女人也没有兴趣。我们彼此都是对方的依靠。孩子们让我很焦虑，能做的我们都会尽力去做；但如今世界经济如此混乱，我们无法给他们提供经济保障，他们只能尽力而为。我的工作还算稳定，但我自然会担心妻子会遭遇不测。”

So you are sure of your deeper relationship. Why are you so certain?

所以你对你们之间更深层次的关系非常确定。你为什么如此肯定？

“I don’t know, but I am. One has to take some things for granted, hasn’t one?”

“我不知道，但我的确是。有些事情我们必须视为理所当然，不是吗？”

That’s not the point. Shall we go into it? What makes you so sure of your intimate relationship? When you say that you and your wife find completeness in each other, what do you mean?

这不是重点。我们来深入探讨一下吧？是什么让你对你们的亲密关系如此确信？你说你和妻子在彼此身上找到了完整的自我，这是什么意思？

“We find happiness in each other: companionship, understanding, and so on. In the deeper sense, we depend on each other. It would be a tremendous blow if anything happened to either of us. We are in that sense dependent.”

“我们从彼此身上找到快乐：陪伴、理解等等。更深层次上，我们彼此依赖。如果我们中的任何一个出了什么事，都会是巨大的打击。从这个意义上说，我们是相互依存的。”

What do you mean by dependent? You mean that without her you would be lost, you would feel utterly alone, is that it? She would feel the same; so you are mutually dependent.

你说的“依赖”是什么意思？你的意思是，没有她你会迷失方向，你会感到彻底孤独，是这样吗？她也会有同样的感觉；所以你们是相互依赖的。

“But what is wrong with that?”

“但这有什么问题呢？”

We are not condemning or judging, but only inquiring. Are you sure you want to go into all this? You are quite sure? All right, then let’s go on.

我们并非谴责或评判，只是询问。你确定要深入探讨这些吗？你非常确定？好的，那我们继续。

Without your wife, you would be alone, you would be lost in the deepest sense; so she is essential to you, is she not? You depend on her for your happiness, and this dependence is called love. You are afraid to be alone. She is always there to cover up the fact of your loneliness, as you cover up hers; but the fact is still there, is it not? We use each other to cover up this loneliness; we run away from it in so many ways, in so many different forms of relationship, and each such relationship becomes a dependence. I listen to the radio because music makes me happy, it takes me away from myself; books and knowledge are also a very convenient escape from myself. And on all these things we depend.

如果没有妻子，你会感到孤独，你会迷失在最深层的意义上；所以她对你来说至关重要，不是吗？你的幸福依赖于她，这种依赖就叫做爱。你害怕孤独。她总是在你身边，掩盖你的孤独，就像你掩盖她的孤独一样；但孤独依然存在，不是吗？我们利用彼此来掩盖这种孤独；我们用各种各样的方式，在各种各样的关系中逃避它，而每一种关系都变成了一种依赖。我听广播是因为音乐让我快乐，它让我暂时忘却自我；书籍和知识也是逃避自我的便捷途径。而我们依赖的正是所有这些。

“Why should I not escape from myself? I have nothing to be proud of, and by being identified with my wife, who is much better than I am, I get away from myself.”

“我为什么不能逃离我自己呢？我没有什么值得骄傲的，通过与比我优秀得多的妻子认同，我就能摆脱我自己。”

Of course, the vast majority escape from themselves. But by escaping from yourself, you have become dependent. Dependence grows stronger, escapes more essential, in proportion to the fear of what is . The wife, the book, the radio, become extraordinarily important; escapes come to be all-significant, of the greatest value. I use my wife as a means of running away from myself, so I am attached to her. I must possess her, I must not lose her; and she likes to be possessed, for she is also using me. There is a common need to escape, and mutually we use each other. This usage is called love. You do not like what you are, and so you run away from yourself, from what is .

当然，绝大多数人都在逃避自我。但逃避自我，反而使你变得依赖。依赖越深，逃避就越重要，这与你对现实的恐惧成正比。妻子、书籍、收音机都变得异常重要；逃避变得至关重要，价值连城。我利用妻子逃避自我，所以我依恋她。我必须拥有她，不能失去她；而她也喜欢被拥有，因为她也在利用我。我们都有逃避的共同需求，我们彼此利用。这种利用被称为爱。你不喜欢真实的自己，所以你逃避自我，逃避现实。

“That is fairly clear. I see something in that, it makes sense. But why does one run away? What is one escaping from?”

“这很清楚。我明白其中的道理，这很有道理。但是，一个人为什么要逃跑？他究竟在逃避什么？”

From your own loneliness, your own emptiness, from what you are. If you run away without seeing what is , you obviously cannot understand it; so first you have to stop running, escaping, and only then can you watch yourself as you are. But you cannot observe what is if you are always criticizing it, if you like or dislike it. You call it loneliness and run away from it; and the very running away from what is is fear. You are afraid of this loneliness, of this emptiness, and dependence is the covering of it. So fear is constant; it is constant as long as you are running away from what is . To be completely identified with something, with a person or an idea, is not a guarantee of final escape, for this fear is always in the background. It comes through dreams, when there is a break in identification; and there is always a break in identification, unless one is unbalanced.

从你自身的孤独、你的空虚、你的本质中逃离。如果你逃避而不去正视现实，显然你无法理解它；所以，你首先必须停止逃避，停止奔跑，只有这样你才能正视真实的自己。但如果你总是批判它，总是喜欢或厌恶它，你就无法观察它。你称之为孤独，然后逃离它；而逃离现实本身就是一种恐惧。你害怕这种孤独，这种空虚，而依赖则掩盖了它。所以恐惧是永恒的；只要你还在逃离现实，它就一直存在。完全认同于某物、某个人或某种观念，并不能保证最终的解脱，因为这种恐惧始终潜伏在暗处。它会在梦境中出现，当认同出现断裂时；而除非一个人失去平衡，否则认同总是会断裂的。

“Then my fear arises from my own hollowness, my insufficiency. I see that all right, and it is true; but what am I to do about it?”

“那么，我的恐惧源于我自身的空虚和不足。我明白这一点，而且这是事实；但我又能怎么办呢？”

You cannot do anything about it. Whatever you do is an activity of escape. That is the most essential thing to realize. Then you will see that you are not different or separate from that hollowness. You are that insufficiency. The observer is the observed emptiness. Then if you proceed further, there is no longer calling it loneliness; the terming of it has ceased. If you proceed still further, which is rather arduous, the thing known as loneliness is not; there is a complete cessation of loneliness, emptiness, of the thinker as the thought. This alone puts an end to fear.

你对此无能为力。你所做的一切都是一种逃避。这是最关键的领悟。那时你就会明白，你与那空虚并无二致，也并非分离。你就是那不足本身。观察者即是被观察的空虚。若你继续深入，便不再称之为孤独；对它的称呼已然消逝。若你再进一步，这实属不易，那所谓的孤独便不复存在；孤独、空虚、作为思想的思考者都将彻底消亡。唯有如此，恐惧才能终结。

“Then what is love?”

那么，爱究竟是什么呢？

Love is not identification; it is not thought about the loved. You do not think about love when it is there; you think about it only when it is absent, when there is distance between you and the object of your love. When there is direct communion, there is no thought, no image, no revival of memory; it is when the communion breaks, at any level, that the process of thought, of imagination, begins. Love is not of the mind. The mind makes the smoke of envy, of holding, of missing, of recalling the past, of longing for tomorrow, of sorrow and worry; and this effectively smothers the flame. When the smoke is not, the flame is. The two cannot exist together; the thought that they exist together is merely a wish. A wish is a projection of thought, and thought is not love.

爱并非认同，也并非对所爱之人的思念。爱在身处时，你不会思念它；只有当爱缺席，当你与所爱之人之间产生距离时，你才会思念它。当彼此直接交流时，不会产生任何思念、意象或记忆的复苏；唯有当这种交流在任何层面断裂时，思念和想象才会开始。爱并非源于头脑。头脑制造出嫉妒、执着、思念、回忆、对未来的渴望、悲伤和忧虑的烟雾；而这些烟雾有效地扼杀了爱的火焰。当烟雾散去，火焰才会燃烧。二者无法共存；认为它们可以共存的想法仅仅是一种愿望。愿望是思维的投射，而思维并非爱。

#↩

TIME AND TRANSFORMATION

时间与转变

I would like to talk a little about time, because I think the enrichment, the beauty and significance of that which is timeless, of that which is true, can be experienced only when we understand the whole process of time. After all, we are seeking, each in his own way, a sense of happiness, of enrichment. Surely a life that has significance, the riches of true happiness, is not of time. Like love, such a life is timeless; and to understand that which is timeless, we must not approach it through time but rather understand time. We must not utilize time as a means of attaining, realizing, apprehending, the timeless. That is what we are doing most of our lives: spending time trying to grasp that which is timeless, so it is important to understand what we mean by time, because I think it is possible to be free of time. It is very important to understand time as a whole and not partially.

我想谈谈时间，因为我认为，只有当我们理解时间的整个过程时，才能体验到永恒之物、真理之物的丰富性、美感和意义。毕竟，我们每个人都在以自己的方式寻求幸福和充实。当然，真正有意义的人生，拥有真正幸福的财富，并非受时间束缚。如同爱情，这样的人生是永恒的；而要理解永恒之物，我们不能通过时间去接近它，而是要理解时间本身。我们不应将时间作为获取、领悟、理解永恒之物的手段。我们一生中大部分时间都在做这件事：花费时间试图抓住永恒之物，因此，理解我们所说的“时间”究竟是什么至关重要，因为我认为我们有可能摆脱时间的束缚。理解时间的整体而非局部至关重要。

It is interesting to realize that our lives are mostly spent in time—time, not in the sense of chronological sequence, of minutes, hours, days, and years, but in the sense of psychological memory. We live by time, we are the result of time. Our minds are the product of many yesterdays and the present is merely the passage of the past to the future. Our minds, our activities, our being, are founded on time; without time we cannot think, because thought is the result of time, thought is the product of many yesterdays and there is no thought without memory. Memory is time, for there are two kinds of time, the chronological and the psychological. There is time as yesterday by the watch and as yesterday by memory. You cannot reject chronological time; it would be absurd—you would miss your train. But is there really any time at all apart from chronological time? Obviously there is time as yesterday but is there time as the mind thinks of it? Is there time apart from the mind? Surely time, psychological time, is the product of the mind. Without the foundation of thought there is no time—time merely being memory as yesterday in conjunction with today, which molds tomorrow. That is, memory of yesterday’s experience in response to the present is creating the future, which is still the process of thought, a path of the mind. The thought process brings about psychological progress in time but is it real, as real as chronological time? And can we use that time which is of the mind as a means of understanding the eternal, the timeless? As I said, happiness is not of yesterday, happiness is not the product of time, happiness is always in the present, a timeless state. I do not know if you have noticed that when you have ecstasy, a creative joy, a series of bright clouds surrounded by dark clouds, in that moment there is no time: there is only the immediate present. The mind, coming in after the experiencing in the present, remembers and wishes to continue it, gathering more and more of itself, thereby creating time. So time is created by the “more”; time is acquisition and time is also detachment, which is still an acquisition of the mind. Therefore, merely disciplining the mind in time, conditioning thought within the framework of time, which is memory, surely does not reveal that which is timeless.

有趣的是，我们意识到，我们的大部分生命都耗费在时间之中——这里的时间并非指按时间顺序排列的分钟、小时、天和年，而是指心理记忆。我们因时间而生，我们本身就是时间的产物。我们的思想是无数个昨天的产物，而现在仅仅是过去流向未来的过程。我们的思想、我们的活动、我们的存在都建立在时间之上；没有时间，我们就无法思考，因为思考是时间的产物，思考是无数个昨天的产物，而没有记忆就没有思考。记忆即时间，因为时间有两种：按时间顺序排列的时间和心理时间。时间既有手表所记录的“昨天”，也有记忆所记录的“昨天”。你不能否定按时间顺序排列的时间；那样做是荒谬的——你会错过火车。但是，除了按时间顺序排列的时间之外，真的存在其他形式的时间吗？显然，存在“昨天”这样的时间，但是是否存在我们思维所感知到的时间呢？是否存在脱离思维的时间？当然，时间，心理时间，正是思维的产物。如果没有思想的基础，时间便无从谈起——时间仅仅是记忆，如同昨日与今日交织，塑造着明日。也就是说，对昨日经验的记忆回应着当下，创造着未来，而这未来本身仍然是思想的过程，是心灵的路径。思想过程在时间中带来心理上的进步，但它是真实的吗？它是否像时间本身那样真实？我们能否将这种心灵的时间作为理解永恒、超越时间的途径？正如我所说，幸福并非来自昨日，幸福并非时间的产物，幸福永远存在于当下，是一种超越时间的状态。我不知道你是否注意到，当你体验到狂喜、创造性的喜悦，如同乌云密布间点点繁星，在那一刻，时间并不存在：只有当下。心灵在体验当下之后介入，它记住并渴望延续这种体验，不断积累自身，从而创造了时间。因此，时间是由“更多”所创造的；时间既是获取，也是解脱，而解脱本身也是心灵的获取。因此，仅仅在时间框架内训练思维，将思想限制在记忆的时间框架内，肯定无法揭示永恒的事物。

Is transformation a matter of time? Most of us are accustomed to thinking that time is necessary for transformation: I am something, and to change what I am into what I should be requires time. I am greedy, with greed’s results of confusion, antagonism, conflict, and misery; to bring about the transformation, which is nongreed, we think time is necessary. That is to say, time is considered as a means of evolving something greater, of becoming something. The problem is this: One is violent, greedy, envious, angry, vicious, or passionate. To transform what is , is time necessary? First of all, why do we want to change what is , or bring about a transformation? Why? Because what we are dissatisfies us; it creates conflict, disturbance, and disliking that state we want something better, something nobler, more idealistic. Therefore, we desire transformation because there is pain, discomfort, conflict. Is conflict overcome by time? If you say it will be overcome by time, you are still in conflict. You may say it will take twenty days or twenty years to get rid of conflict, to change what you are, but during that time you are still in conflict and, therefore, time does not bring about transformation. When we use time as a means of acquiring a quality, a virtue, or a state of being, we are merely postponing or avoiding what is : and I think it is important to understand this point. Greed or violence cause pain, disturbance in the world of our relationship with another, which is society; and being conscious of this state of disturbance, which we term greed or violence, we say to ourselves, “I will get out of it in time. I will practice nonviolence, I will practice non-envy, I will practice peace.” Now, you want to practice nonviolence because violence is a state of disturbance, conflict, and you think that in time you will gain nonviolence and overcome the conflict. What is actually happening? Being in a state of conflict you want to achieve a state in which there is no conflict. Now is that state of no conflict the result of time, of a duration? Obviously not, because while you are achieving a state of nonviolence, you are still being violent and are, therefore, still in conflict.

转变是否只是时间问题？我们大多数人习惯于认为转变需要时间：我目前的状态需要时间，而要将我现在的状态转变为我应该成为的状态，就需要时间。我贪婪，而贪婪会带来混乱、对抗、冲突和痛苦；为了实现转变——即摆脱贪婪——我们认为时间是必要的。也就是说，时间被视为进化成更伟大事物、成为某种事物的手段。问题在于：一个人可能充满暴力、贪婪、嫉妒、愤怒、恶毒或激情。要改变现状，时间真的必要吗？首先，我们为什么想要改变现状，或者说，为什么想要转变？为什么？因为我们现在的状态让我们不满；它造成了冲突、不安，我们厌恶这种状态，想要更好的、更高尚的、更理想的状态。因此，我们渴望转变，因为痛苦、不适和冲突并存。冲突能被时间克服吗？如果你认为时间可以克服冲突，那么你仍然身处冲突之中。你或许会说，摆脱冲突、改变自身需要二十天，也可能需要二十年，但在这段时间里，你依然身处冲突之中，因此，时间并不能带来真正的转变。当我们把时间当作获得某种品质、美德或存在状态的手段时，我们只不过是在拖延或逃避现实：我认为理解这一点至关重要。贪婪或暴力会造成痛苦，扰乱我们与他人（即社会）的关系；意识到这种扰乱状态（我们称之为贪婪或暴力）后，我们会对自己说：“我会随着时间的推移摆脱它。我会践行非暴力，我会践行不嫉妒，我会践行和平。” 你想践行非暴力，是因为暴力本身就是一种扰乱、冲突的状态，你认为随着时间的推移，你会获得非暴力，并克服冲突。但实际情况究竟如何呢？你身处冲突之中，却想要达到一种没有冲突的状态。那么，这种没有冲突的状态是时间或持续一段时间的结果吗？显然不是，因为即使你达到了非暴力状态，你仍然在进行暴力行为，因此仍然处于冲突之中。

Our problem is, can a conflict, a disturbance, be overcome in a period of time, whether it be days, years, or lives? What happens when you say, “I am going to practice nonviolence” during a certain period of time? The very practice indicates that you are in conflict, does it not? You would not practice if you were not resisting conflict; you say the resistance to conflict is necessary in order to overcome conflict and for that resistance you must have time. But the very resistance to conflict is itself a form of conflict. You are spending your energy in resisting conflict in the form of what you call greed, envy, or violence but your mind is still in conflict, so it is important to see the falseness of the process of depending on time as a means of overcoming violence and thereby being free of that process. Then you are able to be what you are: a psychological disturbance which is violence itself.

我们的问题在于，冲突或困扰能否在一段时间内被克服，无论是几天、几年还是一生？当你声称“我要在一段时间内践行非暴力”时，会发生什么？这种践行本身就表明你身处冲突之中，不是吗？如果你不抗拒冲突，你就不会践行非暴力；你说，为了克服冲突，必须抗拒冲突，而抗拒冲突需要时间。但抗拒冲突本身也是一种冲突。你耗费精力去抗拒你所谓的贪婪、嫉妒或暴力形式的冲突，但你的内心仍然处于冲突之中，因此，重要的是要看清依赖时间来克服暴力并摆脱暴力的这种做法是错误的。如此，你才能真正成为你本来的样子：一种心理困扰，而这种困扰本身就是暴力。

To understand anything, any human or scientific problem, what is important, what is essential? A quiet mind, is it not? A mind that is intent on understanding. It is not a mind that is exclusive, that is trying to concentrate, which again is an effort of resistance. If I really want to understand something, there is immediately a quiet state of mind. When you want to listen to music or look at a picture which you love, which you have a feeling for, what is the state of your mind? Immediately there is a quietness, is there not? When you are listening to music, your mind does not wander all over the place; you are listening. Similarly, when you want to understand conflict, you are no longer depending on time at all; you are simply confronted with what is , which is conflict. Then immediately there comes a quietness, a stillness of mind. When you no longer depend on time as a means of transforming what is because you see the falseness of that process, then you are confronted with what is , and as you are interested to understand what is , naturally you have a quiet mind. In that alert yet passive state of mind there is understanding. So long as the mind is in conflict, blaming, resisting, condemning, there can be no understanding. If I want to understand you, I must not condemn you, obviously. It is that quiet mind, that still mind, which brings about transformation. When the mind is no longer resisting, no longer avoiding, no longer discarding or blaming what is but is simply passively aware, then in that passivity of the mind you will find, if you really go into the problem, that there comes a transformation.

要理解任何事物，无论是人类问题还是科学问题，什么才是重要的，什么是本质的？是平静的心灵，不是吗？是专注于理解的心灵。它不是那种排斥一切、试图集中注意力的心灵，因为那本身就是一种阻力。如果我真的想理解某件事，我的内心会立刻平静下来。当你想要聆听音乐或欣赏一幅你喜爱、让你心生感动的画作时，你的内心状态如何？立刻就会感到平静，不是吗？当你聆听音乐时，你的思绪不会四处游荡；你会全神贯注地聆听。同样地，当你想要理解冲突时，你不再依赖时间；你只是直面冲突本身。然后，平静，内心的宁静就会立刻到来。当你不再依赖时间来转化事物，因为你看清了这种转化过程的虚妄，那么你就会直面事物本身，而当你渴望理解事物本身时，你的内心自然就会平静下来。在那种既警觉又平静的心态中，蕴藏着理解。只要内心充满冲突、责备、抗拒和谴责，就不可能有理解。显然，如果我想理解你，就不能谴责你。正是那颗平静的心，那颗安宁的心，带来了转变。当内心不再抗拒、不再逃避、不再抛弃或责备所发生的一切，而只是被动地觉察时，如果你真正深入问题，就会发现，在这种平静的心态中，转变悄然发生。

Revolution is only possible now, not in the future; regeneration is today, not tomorrow. If you will experiment with what I have been saying, you will find that there is immediate regeneration, a newness, a quality of freshness; because the mind is always still when it is interested, when it desires or has the intention to understand. The difficulty with most of us is that we have not the intention to understand, because we are afraid that, if we understood, it might bring about a revolutionary action in our life and, therefore, we resist. It is the defense mechanism that is at work when we use time or an ideal as a means of gradual transformation.

革命只可能发生在当下，而非未来；复兴就在今天，而非明日。如果你实践我所说的，你会发现复兴就在眼前，一种崭新感，一种清新感油然而生；因为当心灵感兴趣，渴望或有意理解时，它总是平静的。我们大多数人的问题在于，我们缺乏理解的意愿，因为我们害怕，一旦理解，它可能会在我们的生活中引发一场革命性的变革，因此我们抗拒。当我们把时间或理想当作渐进转变的手段时，正是这种防御机制在作祟。

Thus, regeneration is only possible in the present, not in the future, not tomorrow. A man who relies on time as a means through which he can gain happiness or realize truth or God is merely deceiving himself; he is living in ignorance and, therefore, in conflict. A man who sees that time is not the way out of our difficulty and who is, therefore, free from the false, such a man naturally has the intention to understand; therefore, his mind is quiet spontaneously, without compulsion, without practice. When the mind is still, tranquil, not seeking any answer or any solution, neither resisting nor avoiding—it is only then that there can be a regeneration, because then the mind is capable of perceiving what is true; and it is truth that liberates, not your effort to be free.

因此，重生只能在当下发生，而非未来，也非明日。若有人依赖时间来获得幸福、领悟真理或认识神，那他不过是在自欺欺人；他生活在无知之中，因而饱受冲突之苦。若有人明白时间并非摆脱困境的途径，因而得以从虚妄中解脱，这样的人自然而然地拥有求知的意愿；因此，他的心境自然而然地平静下来，无需强迫，无需刻意练习。当心灵平静安宁，不寻求任何答案或解决方案，既不抗拒也不逃避——唯有如此，重生才有可能发生，因为那时心灵才能感知真理；而真正带来解脱的是真理，而非你为获得解脱所做的努力。

#↩

SORROW FROM SELF-PITY

自怜带来的悲伤

At this time of the year, in this warm climate, it was spring. The sun was exceptionally mild, for a light wind was coming from the north where the mountains were fresh in the snow. A tree beside the road, bare a week ago, was now covered with new green leaves which sparkled in the sun. The new leaves were so tender, so delicate, so small in the vast space of the mind, of the earth and the blue sky; yet within a short time they seemed to fill the space of all thought. Further along the road there was a flowering tree which had no leaves, but only blossoms. The breeze had scattered the petals on the ground, and several children were sitting among them. They were the children of the chauffeurs and other servants. They would never go to school; they would always be the poor people of the earth, but among the fallen petals beside the tarred road, those children were part of the earth. They were startled to see a stranger sitting there with them, and they became suddenly silent; they stopped playing with the petals, and for a few seconds they were as still as statues. But their eyes were alive with curiosity, friendliness, and apprehension.

一年中的这个时候，在这温暖的气候里，正是春天。阳光格外和煦，因为一阵轻柔的风从北方吹来，那里山峦还覆盖着皑皑白雪。路边一棵树，一周前还光秃秃的，如今已长满了嫩绿的新叶，在阳光下闪闪发光。这些新叶如此娇嫩，如此纤细，在广袤的心灵、大地和蓝天中显得如此渺小；然而，在短短的时间里，它们似乎填满了所有的思绪。路的尽头，有一棵开花的树，没有叶子，只有花朵。微风吹落了花瓣，几个孩子坐在花瓣堆里。他们是司机和其他仆人的孩子。他们永远无法上学；他们永远是这世上的穷人，但在柏油路旁的花瓣堆里，这些孩子也成为了这片土地的一部分。他们看到一个陌生人坐在他们中间，吓了一跳，突然安静下来；他们停止了玩弄花瓣，像雕像一样一动不动地站了几秒钟。但他们的眼中充满了好奇、友善和担忧。

In a small, sunken garden by the roadside there were quantities of bright flowers. Among the leaves of a tree in that garden a crow was shading itself from the midday sun. Its whole body was resting on the branch, the feathers covering its claws. It was calling or answering other crows, and within a period of ten minutes there were five or six different notes in its cawing. It probably had many more notes, but now it was satisfied with a few. It was very black, with a gray neck; it had extraordinary eyes which were never still, and its beak was hard and sharp. It was completely at rest and yet completely alive. It was strange how the mind was totally with that bird. It was not observing the bird, though it had taken in every detail; it was not the bird itself, for there was no identification with it. It was with the bird, with its eyes and its sharp beak, as the sea is with the fish; it was with the bird, and yet it went through and beyond it. The sharp, aggressive, and frightened mind of the crow was part of the mind that spanned the seas and time. This mind was vast, limitless, beyond all measure, and yet it was aware of the slightest movement of the eyes of that black crow among the new, sparkling leaves. It was aware of the falling petals, but it had no focus of attention, no point from which to attend. Unlike space, which has always something in it—a particle of dust, the earth, or the heavens—it was wholly empty, and being empty it could attend without a cause. Its attention had neither root nor branch. All energy was in that empty stillness. It was not the energy that is built up with intent, and which is soon dissipated when pressure is taken away. It was the energy of all beginning; it was life that had no time as ending.

路边一个略微下沉的小花园里，开满了鲜艳的花朵。花园里一棵树的枝叶间，一只乌鸦正躲避着正午的烈日。它整个身子都倚靠在树枝上，羽毛遮住了它的爪子。它鸣叫着，仿佛在回应其他乌鸦，短短十分钟内，它的叫声就出现了五六种不同的音调。它或许会发出更多不同的音调，但现在它对这几种已经很满足了。它的羽毛漆黑，脖子是灰色的；它有一双非同寻常的眼睛，总是睁得大大的；它的喙又硬又尖。它完全静止，却又充满活力。奇妙的是，我的思绪完全沉浸在这只鸟身上。我并非在观察这只鸟，尽管我已将每一个细节都尽收眼底；我并非鸟本身，因为我与它之间没有任何认同。我与这只鸟同在，与它的眼睛和尖喙同在，就像大海与鱼儿同在；我与这只鸟同在，却又超越了它，进入了鸟的世界。乌鸦敏锐、好斗又恐惧的心灵，是那跨越海洋与时间的心灵的一部分。这心灵浩瀚无垠，无边无际，超越一切衡量，却能感知到那只黑乌鸦在新生闪亮的树叶间最细微的眼神移动。它能感知到飘落的花瓣，却没有关注的焦点，没有可以依附的源头。与总是包含着万物的空间——一粒尘埃、大地或苍穹——不同，它是完全空无的，正因为空无，它才能无缘无故地关注一切。它的注意力既无根基，也无枝桠。所有的能量都蕴藏在那空寂之中。这并非那种刻意积聚、压力消散后便迅速消散的能量。它是万物之始的能量；它是没有终结的生命。

Several people had come together, and as each one tried to state some problem, the others began to explain it and to compare it with their own trials. But sorrow is not to be compared. Comparison breeds self-pity, and then misfortune ensues. Adversity is to be met directly, not with the idea that yours is greater than another’s.

几个人聚在一起，每个人都试图陈述自己的问题，其他人则开始解释，并拿自己的遭遇作比较。但悲伤是不能比较的。比较只会滋生自怜，然后不幸就会随之而来。面对逆境，应该直面它，而不是抱着“我的遭遇比别人的更严重”的想法。

They were all silent now, and presently one of them began.

他们此刻都沉默不语，过了一会儿，其中一人开口说话了。

“My mother has been dead for some years. Quite recently I have lost my father also, and I am full of remorse. He was a good father, and I ought to have been many things which I was not. Our ideas clashed; our respective ways of life kept us apart. He was a religious man, but my religious feeling is not so obvious. The relationship between us was often strained, but at least it was a relationship, and now that he is gone I am stricken with sorrow. My sorrow is not only remorse, but also the feeling of suddenly being left alone. I have never had this kind of sorrow before, and it is quite acute. What am I to do? How am I to get over it?”

“我母亲去世已有数年。不久前，我的父亲也去世了，我感到无比懊悔。他是一位好父亲，而我本应成为很多我没能成为的人。我们思想不合，各自的生活方式让我们渐行渐远。他是个虔诚的信徒，但我对宗教的信仰却并不那么明显。我们之间的关系常常很紧张，但至少我们之间还有亲情。如今他走了，我悲痛欲绝。我的悲痛不仅是懊悔，还有突然被抛弃的孤独感。我从未经历过这种悲伤，它如此强烈。我该怎么办？我该如何走出这种痛苦？”

If one may ask, do you suffer for your father, or does sorrow arise from having no longer the relationship to which you had grown accustomed?

如果有人问，你是为父亲的离世而痛苦，还是因为失去了曾经习惯的父子关系而感到悲伤？

“I don’t quite understand what you mean.”

我不太明白你的意思。

Do you suffer because your father is gone or because you feel lonely?

你是因为父亲的离世而感到痛苦，还是因为感到孤独而感到痛苦？

“All I know is that I suffer, and I want to get away from it. I really don’t understand what you mean. Will you please explain?”

我只知道自己很痛苦，我想摆脱这种痛苦。我真的不明白你的意思。你能解释一下吗？

It is fairly simple, is it not? Either you are suffering on behalf of your father, that is, because he enjoyed living and wanted to live, and now he is gone; or you are suffering because there has been a break in a relationship that had significance for so long, and you are suddenly aware of loneliness. Now, which is it? You are suffering surely, not for your father, but because you are lonely, and your sorrow is that which comes from self-pity.

这不是很简单吗？要么你是在为父亲的离世而痛苦，因为他热爱生活，渴望活下去，而如今他已不在人世；要么你是在为一段长久以来意义非凡的关系的破裂而痛苦，你突然感受到孤独。那么，究竟是哪一种呢？你痛苦的肯定不是为父亲，而是因为你感到孤独，而你的悲伤源于自怜。

“What exactly is loneliness?”

孤独究竟是什么？

Have you never felt lonely?

你从未感到过孤独吗？

“Yes, I have often taken solitary walks. I go for long walks alone, especially on my holidays.”

“是的，我经常独自散步。我经常独自进行长途散步，尤其是在假期里。”

Isn’t there a difference between the feeling of loneliness and being alone as on a solitary walk?

孤独感和独自散步时的独处感之间难道没有区别吗？

“If there is, then I don’t think I know what loneliness means.”

“如果真有孤独这种东西，那我可能就不知道孤独是什么感觉了。”

“I don’t think we know what anything means, except verbally,” someone added.

“我觉得除了口头交流之外，我们对任何事情的含义都一无所知，”有人补充道。

Have you never experienced for yourself the feeling of loneliness, as you might a toothache? When we talk of loneliness, are we experiencing the psychological pain of it, or merely employing a word to indicate something which we have never directly experienced? Do we really suffer, or only think we suffer?

你是否从未亲身体验过孤独，就像牙痛一样？当我们谈论孤独时，我们是在感受那种心理上的痛苦，还是仅仅用一个词来指代我们从未直接体验过的东西？我们真的在承受痛苦，还是只是自以为在承受痛苦？

“I want to know what loneliness is,” he replied.

“我想知道什么是孤独，”他回答说。

You mean you want a description of it. It’s an experience of being completely isolated; a feeling of not being able to depend on anything, of being cut off from all relationship. The “me,” the ego, the self, by its very nature, is constantly building a wall around itself; all its activity leads to isolation. Becoming aware of its isolation, it begins to identify itself with virtue, with God, with property, with a person, country, or ideology; but this identification is part of the process of isolation. In other words, we escape by every possible means from the pain of loneliness, from this feeling of isolation, and so we never directly experience it. It’s like being afraid of something round the corner and never facing it, never finding out what it is, but always running away and taking refuge in somebody or something, which only breeds more fear. Have you never felt lonely in this sense of being cut off from everything, completely isolated?

你是想了解它的具体描述。这是一种完全孤立的体验；一种无法依赖任何事物、与所有关系隔绝的感觉。“我”，即自我，本质上就是不断地在自身周围筑起一道墙；它的一切活动最终都指向孤立。当它意识到自身的孤立时，便开始将自己与美德、上帝、财产、某个人、国家或意识形态等同起来；但这种认同本身就是孤立过程的一部分。换句话说，我们想方设法逃避孤独的痛苦，逃避这种孤立感，因此我们从未直接体验过它。这就像害怕拐角处有什么东西，却从不面对它，从不去弄清楚它到底是什么，而是总是逃避，寻求某人或某物的庇护，而这只会滋生更多的恐惧。你是否从未体验过这种与一切隔绝、完全孤立的孤独感？

“I have no idea at all what you are talking about.”

“我完全不知道你在说什么。”

Then, if one may ask, do you really know what sorrow is? Are you experiencing sorrow as strongly and urgently as you would a toothache? When you have a toothache, you act; you go to the dentist. But when there is sorrow you run away from it through explanation, belief, drink, and so on. You act, but your action is not the action that frees the mind from sorrow, is it?

那么，不妨问问，你真的了解悲伤是什么吗？你感受到的悲伤是否像牙痛一样强烈而迫切？牙痛时，你会采取行动；你会去看牙医。但悲伤来临时，你会通过解释、信仰、酗酒等等方式逃避它。你会采取行动，但你的行动并不能使心灵摆脱悲伤，不是吗？

“I don’t know what to do, and that’s why I’m here.”

“我不知道该怎么办，所以我才来这里。”

Before you can know what to do, must you not find out what sorrow actually is? Haven’t you merely formed an idea, a judgment, of what sorrow is? Surely, the running away, the evaluation, the fear, prevents you from experiencing it directly. When you are suffering from a toothache you don’t form ideas and opinions about it; you just have it and you act. But here there is no action, immediate or remote, because you are really not suffering. To suffer and to understand suffering, you must look at it, you must not run away.

在你明白该怎么做之前，难道你不应该先弄清楚悲伤究竟是什么吗？你难道不是仅仅对悲伤形成了一种观念、一种判断吗？逃避、评判、恐惧，无疑阻碍了你直接体验悲伤。当你牙疼的时候，你不会去形成任何观念或看法；你只是感受到疼痛，然后采取行动。但在这里，你没有任何行动，无论是直接的还是间接的，因为你并没有真正地感受到痛苦。要体验痛苦，要理解痛苦，你必须正视它，而不是逃避。

“My father is gone beyond recall, and so I suffer. What must I do to go beyond the reaches of suffering?”

“我的父亲已经离世，我因此饱受痛苦。我该如何做才能摆脱这种痛苦呢？”

We suffer because we do not see the truth of suffering. The fact and our ideation about the fact are entirely distinct, leading in two different directions. If one may ask, are you concerned with the fact, the actuality, or merely with the idea of suffering?

我们之所以痛苦，是因为我们看不到痛苦的真相。事实和我们对事实的理解截然不同，二者指向两个不同的方向。不妨问问自己，你关心的是痛苦的事实、现实，还是仅仅是痛苦的概念？

“You are not answering my question, sir. What am I to do?”

“先生，您没有回答我的问题。我该怎么办？”

Do you want to escape from suffering, or to be free from it? If you merely want to escape, then a pill, a belief, an explanation, an amusement, may “help,” with the inevitable consequences of dependence, fear, and so on. But if you wish to be free from sorrow, you must stop running away and be aware of it without judgment, without choice; you must observe it, learn about it, know all the intimate intricacies of it. Then you will not be frightened of it, and there will no longer be the poison of self-pity. With the understanding of sorrow there is freedom from it. To understand sorrow there must be the actual experiencing of it, and not the verbal fiction of sorrow.

你是想逃避痛苦，还是想摆脱痛苦？如果你只是想逃避，那么药物、信仰、解释、娱乐或许能“帮上忙”，但随之而来的必然是依赖、恐惧等等。如果你渴望摆脱悲伤，就必须停止逃避，正视它，不加评判，不加选择；你必须观察它，了解它，洞悉它所有错综复杂的细节。如此，你便不再惧怕它，也不再受自怜之毒的折磨。理解悲伤，方能摆脱它。而理解悲伤，必须亲身经历，而非沉溺于言语的虚构。

“May I ask just one question?” put in one of the others. “In what manner should one live one’s daily life?”

“我可以问一个问题吗？”另一位同学插话道，“一个人应该如何度过他的日常生活？”

As though one were living for that single day, for that single hour.

仿佛人只为那一天、那一个小时而活。

“How?”

“如何？”

If you had only one hour to live, what would you do?

如果你只剩下一个小时的生命，你会做什么？

“I really don’t know,” he replied anxiously.

“我真的不知道，”他焦急地回答道。

Would you not arrange what is necessary outwardly, your affairs, your will, and so on? Would you not call your family and friends together and ask their forgiveness for the harm that you might have done to them, and forgive them for whatever harm they might have done to you? Would you not die completely to the things of the mind, to desires, and to the world? And if it can be done for an hour then it can also be done for the days and years that may remain.

你难道不想安排好外在的必要之事，比如你的事务、遗嘱等等吗？你难道不想召集家人朋友，请求他们原谅你可能对他们造成的伤害，也原谅他们可能对你造成的伤害吗？你难道不想彻底放下心念、欲望和世俗的牵绊吗？如果这能在短短一小时内做到，那么在余下的岁月里也同样可以做到。

“Is such a thing really possible, sir?”

“先生，这种事真的可能发生吗？”

Try it and you will find out.

试试就知道了。

#↩

EDUCATION AND THE SIGNIFICANCE OF LIFE

教育与人生的意义

When one travels around the world, one notices to what an extraordinary degree human nature is the same, whether in India or America, in Europe or Australia. This is especially true in colleges and universities. We are turning out, as if through a mold, a type of human being whose chief interest is to find security, to become somebody important, or to have a good time with as little thought as possible.

环游世界，你会发现人性竟如此惊人地相似，无论是在印度还是美国，欧洲还是澳大利亚。这一点在高校中尤为突出。我们仿佛被模子里刻出来的一样，都是些一心只想寻求安全感、出人头地，或者不假思索地寻欢作乐的人。

Conventional education makes independent thinking extremely difficult. Conformity leads to mediocrity. To be different from the group or to resist environment is not easy and is often risky as long as we worship success. The urge to be successful, which is the pursuit of reward whether in the material or in the so-called spiritual sphere, the search for inward or outward security, the desire for comfort—this whole process smothers discontent, puts an end to spontaneity and breeds fear; and fear blocks the intelligent understanding of life. With increasing age, dullness of mind and heart sets in.

传统教育使独立思考变得极其困难。墨守成规只会导致平庸。只要我们崇尚成功，与众不同或反抗环境就并非易事，而且往往充满风险。对成功的渴望，无论是物质上的还是所谓精神上的，对回报的追求，对内在或外在安全感的寻求，对舒适的渴望——所有这些过程都会扼杀不满，扼杀自发性，滋生恐惧；而恐惧会阻碍我们对生活的深刻理解。随着年龄的增长，心智和情感都会变得迟钝。

In seeking comfort, we generally find a quiet corner in life where there is a minimum of conflict, and then we are afraid to step out of that seclusion. This fear of life, this fear of struggle and of new experience, kills in us the spirit of adventure; our whole upbringing and education have made us afraid to be different from our neighbor, afraid to think contrary to the established pattern of society, falsely respectful of authority and tradition.

为了寻求安逸，我们通常会在生活中找到一个安静的角落，那里冲突最少，然后我们便害怕走出这片宁静。这种对生活的恐惧，这种对奋斗和新体验的恐惧，扼杀了我们冒险的精神；我们从小到大受到的教育让我们害怕与邻居不同，害怕违背社会既定的模式，害怕虚假地尊重权威和传统。

Fortunately, there are a few who are in earnest, who are willing to examine our human problems without the prejudice of the right or of the left; but in the vast majority of us, there is no real spirit of discontent, of revolt. When we yield uncomprehendingly to environment, any spirit of revolt that we may have had dies down, and our responsibilities soon put an end to it.

幸运的是，确实有一些人是真心实意的，他们愿意抛开左右之争，客观地审视我们人类面临的问题；但我们大多数人心中并没有真正的不满和反抗精神。当我们对环境不加思索地屈服时，我们可能存在的任何反抗精神都会消磨殆尽，而我们的责任很快就会扼杀它。

Revolt is of two kinds: there is violent revolt, which is mere reaction, without understanding, against the existing order; and there is the deep psychological revolt of intelligence. There are many who revolt against the established orthodoxies only to fall into new orthodoxies, further illusions and concealed self-indulgences. What generally happens is that we break away from one group or set of ideals and join another group, take up other ideals, thus creating a new pattern of thought against which we will again have to revolt. Reaction only breeds opposition, and reform needs further reform.

反抗有两种：一种是暴力反抗，这仅仅是出于对现有秩序的无意识反应；另一种是源于理性的深刻心理反抗。许多人反抗既定的正统观念，最终却又陷入新的正统观念、更深层的幻想和隐秘的自我放纵之中。通常的情况是，我们脱离一个群体或一套理想，加入另一个群体，接受其他的理想，从而形成一种新的思维模式，而我们又不得不再次反抗这种模式。反抗只会滋生反对，改革需要进一步的改革。

But there is an intelligent revolt which is not reaction, and which comes with self-knowledge through the awareness of one’s own thought and feeling. It is only when we face experience as it comes and do not avoid disturbance that we keep intelligence highly awakened; and intelligence highly awakened is intuition, which is the only true guide in life.

但有一种智慧的反抗并非逆来顺受，而是源于对自身思想和感受的觉察，从而获得自我认知。只有当我们坦然面对人生百态，不回避干扰时，才能保持高度觉醒的智慧；而高度觉醒的智慧便是直觉，它是人生唯一真正的指引。

Now, what is the significance of life? What are we living and struggling for? If we are being educated merely to achieve distinction, to get a better job, to be more efficient, to have wider domination over others, then our lives will be shallow and empty. If we are being educated only to be scientists, to be scholars wedded to books, or specialists addicted to knowledge, then we shall be contributing to the destruction and misery of the world.

那么，生命的意义究竟是什么？我们为何而活，为何而奋斗？如果我们接受教育仅仅是为了追求名利、获得更好的工作、提高效率、凌驾于他人之上，那么我们的人生将肤浅而空虚。如果我们接受教育仅仅是为了成为科学家、成为埋头书本的学者、成为沉迷于知识的专家，那么我们将成为世界的毁灭和苦难的帮凶。

Though there is a higher and wider significance to life, of what value is our education if we never discover it? We may be highly educated, but if we are without deep integration of thought and feeling, our lives are incomplete, contradictory, and torn with many fears; and as long as education does not cultivate an integrated outlook on life, it has very little significance.

尽管生命蕴含着更高更广的意义，但如果我们从未发现它，我们的教育又有何价值？我们或许受过高等教育，但如果我们缺乏思想与情感的深度融合，我们的人生便是不完整的、矛盾的，并且饱受恐惧的折磨；只要教育不能培养一种完整的人生观，它就几乎毫无意义。

In our present civilization we have divided life into so many departments that education has very little meaning, except in learning a particular technique or profession. Instead of awakening the integrated intelligence of the individual, education is encouraging him to conform to a pattern and so is hindering his comprehension of himself as a total process. To attempt to solve the many problems of existence at their respective levels, separated as they are into various categories, indicates an utter lack of comprehension.

在当今文明中，我们将生活划分成如此之多的领域，以至于教育的意义几乎荡然无存，除了学习某种特定的技能或职业之外。教育非但没有唤醒个体的综合智能，反而鼓励其墨守成规，从而阻碍了其对自身作为一个整体的理解。试图在各自独立的层面上解决众多被划分为不同类别的生存问题，恰恰表明我们对这些问题缺乏深刻的理解。

The individual is made up of different entities, but to emphasize the differences and to encourage the development of a definite type leads to many complexities and contradictions. Education should bring about the integration of these separate entities, for without integration, life becomes a series of conflicts and sorrows. Of what value is it to be trained as lawyers if we perpetuate litigation? Of what value is knowledge if we continue in our confusion? What significance has technical and industrial capacity if we use it to destroy one another? What is the point of our existence if it leads to violence and utter misery? Though we may have money or are capable of earning it, though we have our pleasures and our organized religions, we are in endless conflict.

人由不同的个体构成，但强调这些差异并鼓励发展某种特定类型会导致诸多复杂和矛盾。教育应当促进这些独立个体的整合，因为缺乏整合，生活将沦为一系列冲突和苦难。如果我们继续沉溺于诉讼，接受律师培训又有何意义？如果我们继续迷失方向，知识又有何价值？如果我们用技术和工业能力互相残杀，它们又有何意义？如果我们的存在只会导致暴力和彻底的苦难，那么我们存在的意义又是什么？即便我们拥有金钱或有能力赚钱，即便我们拥有享乐和宗教信仰，我们依然深陷无休止的冲突之中。

We must distinguish between the personal and the individual. The personal is the accidental; and by the accidental I mean the circumstances of birth, the environment in which we happen to have been brought up, with its nationalism, superstitions, class distinctions and prejudices. The personal or accidental is but momentary, though that moment may last a lifetime; and as the present system of education is based on the personal, the accidental, the momentary, it leads to perversion of thought and the inculcation of self-defensive fears.

我们必须区分个人和个体。个人指的是偶然因素；我所说的偶然因素指的是出生环境、我们恰巧成长的环境，以及其中存在的民族主义、迷信、阶级差异和偏见。个人或偶然因素只是暂时的，尽管这一刻可能持续一生；而由于现行的教育体系建立在个人、偶然和暂时的因素之上，它会导致思想的扭曲和自我防御性恐惧的灌输。

All of us have been trained by education and environment to seek personal gain and security, and to fight for ourselves. Though we cover it over with pleasant phrases, we have been educated for various professions within a system based on exploitation and acquisitive fear. Such a training must inevitably bring confusion and misery to ourselves and to the world, for it creates in each individual those psychological barriers which separate and hold him apart from others.

我们所有人都在教育和环境的熏陶下，被训练去追求个人利益和安全感，并为自己而战。尽管我们用悦耳的言辞掩盖这一点，但我们接受的教育却是在一个建立在剥削和贪婪恐惧之上的体系中，为各种职业做好准备。这样的训练必然会给我们自身和世界带来困惑和痛苦，因为它会在每个人心中筑起心理壁垒，将人与他人隔离开来。

Education is not merely a matter of training the mind. Training makes for efficiency, but it does not bring about completeness. A mind that has merely been trained is the continuation of the past, and such a mind can never discover the new. That is why, to find out what is right education, we will have to inquire into the whole significance of living.

教育不仅仅是训练思维。训练能提高效率，但并不能带来圆满。仅仅接受过训练的思维只是过去的延续，这样的思维永远无法发现新事物。因此，要找到正确的教育方式，我们必须探究生命的全部意义。

To most of us, the meaning of life as a whole is not of primary importance, and our education emphasizes secondary values, merely making us proficient in some branch of knowledge. Though knowledge and efficiency are necessary, to lay chief emphasis on them only leads to conflict and confusion.

对我们大多数人来说，人生的整体意义并非首要之事，我们的教育也侧重于次要价值，仅仅让我们精通某些知识领域。虽然知识和效率固然必要，但过分强调它们只会导致冲突和混乱。

There is an efficiency inspired by love which goes far beyond and is much greater than the efficiency of ambition; and without love, which brings an integrated understanding of life, efficiency breeds ruthlessness. Is this not what is actually taking place all over the world? Our present education is geared to industrialization and war, its principal aim being to develop efficiency; and we are caught in this machine of ruthless competition and mutual destruction. If education leads to war, if it teaches us to destroy or be destroyed, has it not utterly failed?

有一种源于爱的效率，它远远超越、甚至远胜于野心所带来的效率；而没有爱——爱能带来对人生的整体理解——效率只会滋生冷酷无情。这难道不是正在世界各地发生的现实吗？我们当前的教育以工业化和战争为导向，其主要目标是培养效率；而我们却深陷于这台残酷竞争和相互毁灭的机器之中。如果教育导致战争，如果它教唆我们去毁灭或被毁灭，那么它岂不是彻底失败了吗？

To bring about right education, we must obviously understand the meaning of life as a whole, and for that we have to be able to think, not consistently, but directly and truly. A consistent thinker is a thoughtless person, because he conforms to a pattern; he repeats phrases and thinks in a groove. We cannot understand existence abstractly or theoretically. To understand life is to understand ourselves, and that is both the beginning and the end of education.

要实现正确的教育，我们显然必须理解生命的整体意义，而要做到这一点，我们必须能够思考，不是墨守成规，而是直接而真诚地思考。墨守成规的思考者是缺乏思考的，因为他墨守成规，重复陈词滥调，思维僵化。我们无法抽象地或理论地理解存在。理解生命就是理解我们自己，这既是教育的起点，也是教育的终点。

Education is not merely acquiring knowledge, gathering and correlating facts; it is to see the significance of life as a whole. But the whole cannot be approached through the part, which is what governments, organized religions, and authoritarian parties are attempting to do.

教育不仅仅是获取知识、收集和关联事实；它更在于理解人生的整体意义。然而，我们不能通过局部来理解整体，而这正是政府、宗教组织和专制政党试图做的。

The function of education is to create human beings who are integrated and, therefore, intelligent. We may take degrees and be mechanically efficient without being intelligent. Intelligence is not mere information; it is not derived from books, nor does it consist of clever self-defensive responses and aggressive assertions. One who has not studied may be more intelligent than the learned. We have made examinations and degrees the criterion of intelligence and have developed cunning minds that avoid vital human issues. Intelligence is the capacity to perceive the essential, the what is ; and to awaken this capacity, in oneself and in others, is education.

教育的功能在于培养身心健全、因而也具有智慧的人。我们可以获得学位，也能机械地高效工作，却未必拥有智慧。智慧并非仅仅是信息；它并非来源于书本，也并非由巧妙的自我防御和咄咄逼人的言论构成。一个未曾学习的人可能比一个博学之士更聪明。我们把考试和学位作为衡量智慧的标准，培养出一些狡猾的头脑，让他们回避重要的人类问题。智慧是感知本质、洞察事物本质的能力；而唤醒自身和他人的这种能力，正是教育的意义所在。

Education should help us to discover lasting values so that we do not merely cling to formulas or repeat slogans; it should help us to break down our national and social barriers, instead of emphasizing them, for they breed antagonism between man and man. Unfortunately, the present system of education is making us subservient, mechanical, and deeply thoughtless; though it awakens us intellectually, inwardly it leaves us incomplete, stultified, and uncreative.

教育应当帮助我们发现永恒的价值，使我们不至于仅仅拘泥于形式或重复口号；它应当帮助我们打破民族和社会壁垒，而不是强化它们，因为壁垒只会滋生人与人之间的对抗。不幸的是，现行的教育体系正使我们变得唯唯诺诺、机械麻木、缺乏思考；尽管它在智力上唤醒了我们，但在内心深处，它却使我们变得不完整、僵化、缺乏创造力。

Without an integrated understanding of life, our individual and collective problems will only deepen and extend. The purpose of education is not to produce mere scholars, technicians, and job hunters, but integrated men and women who are free of fear; for only between such human beings can there be enduring peace.

若缺乏对人生的整体理解，我们个人和集体的问题只会日益加深和蔓延。教育的目的并非培养单纯的学者、技术人员和求职者，而是培养身心健全、无所畏惧的男女；因为只有在这样的人之间，才能拥有持久的和平。

It is in the understanding of ourselves that fear comes to an end. If the individual is to grapple with life from moment to moment, if he is to face its intricacies, its miseries and sudden demands, he must be infinitely pliable and, therefore, free of theories and particular patterns of thought.

只有真正了解自己，恐惧才会终结。如果一个人想要应对生活中的每一刻，想要面对生活的复杂性、苦难和突如其来的需求，他就必须拥有无限的灵活性，因此，他必须摆脱理论和特定思维模式的束缚。

Education should not encourage the individual to conform to society or to be negatively harmonious with it, but help him to discover the true values which come with unbiased investigation and self-awareness. When there is no self-knowledge, self-expression becomes self-assertion, with all its aggressive and ambitious conflicts. Education should awaken the capacity to be self-aware and not merely indulge in gratifying self-expression.

教育不应鼓励个人顺应社会或与之消极共存，而应帮助其通过客观的探究和自我认知，发现真正的价值。缺乏自我认知，自我表达就会沦为自我主张，伴随着各种攻击性和野心勃勃的冲突。教育应当唤醒自我认知的能力，而不仅仅是沉溺于令人愉悦的自我表达。

What is the good of learning if in the process of living we are destroying ourselves? As we are having a series of devastating wars, one right after another, there is obviously something radically wrong with the way we bring up our children. I think most of us are aware of this, but we do not know how to deal with it.

如果学习的过程本身就是自我毁灭，那么学习又有何意义？我们接连遭受毁灭性的战争，显然，我们教育孩子的方式存在根本性的问题。我想我们大多数人都意识到了这一点，但我们却不知道该如何应对。

Systems, whether educational or political, are not changed mysteriously; they are transformed when there is a fundamental change in ourselves. The individual is of first importance, not the system; and as long as the individual does not understand the total process of himself, no system, whether of the left or of the right, can bring order and peace to the world.

无论是教育体系还是政治体系，都不会凭空改变；只有当我们自身发生根本性的改变时，体系才会随之转变。个人才是最重要的，而非体系；只要个人不了解自身的全部发展历程，任何体系，无论是左翼还是右翼，都无法为世界带来秩序与和平。

#↩

LIFE AHEAD

未来生活

It seems to me that a totally different kind of morality and conduct, and an action that springs from the understanding of the whole process of living, have become an urgent necessity, in our world of mounting crises and problems. We try to deal with these issues through political and organizational methods, through economic readjustment and various reforms; but none of these things will ever resolve the complex difficulties of human existence, though they may offer temporary relief. All reforms, however extensive and seemingly lasting, are in themselves merely productive of further confusion and further need of reformation. Without understanding the whole complex being of man, mere reformation will bring about only the confusing demand for further reforms. There is no end to reform; and there is no fundamental solution along these lines.

在我看来，在我们这个危机和问题日益增多的世界里，一种截然不同的道德和行为准则，以及一种源于对整个生活过程理解的行动，已成为迫切需要。我们试图通过政治和组织手段、经济调整和各种改革来应对这些问题；但这些都无法解决人类生存的复杂难题，尽管它们或许能带来暂时的缓解。所有改革，无论多么广泛和看似持久，其本身都只会加剧混乱，并导致对进一步改革的需求。如果不理解人类复杂存在的全貌，单纯的改革只会导致对更多改革的困惑需求。改革永无止境；而且，从根本上来说，也找不到解决之道。

Political, economic, or social revolutions are not the answer either, for they have produced appalling tyrannies, or the mere transfer of power and authority into the hands of a different group. Such revolutions are not at any time the way out of our confusion and conflict.

政治、经济或社会革命也并非解决之道，因为它们要么催生了骇人的暴政，要么仅仅是将权力转移到了另一个群体手中。此类革命在任何时候都无法帮助我们摆脱困境和冲突。

But there is a revolution which is entirely different and which must take place if we are to emerge from the endless series of anxieties, conflicts, and frustrations in which we are caught. This revolution has to begin not with theory and ideation, which eventually prove worthless, but with a radical transformation in the mind itself. Such a transformation can be brought about only through right education and the total development of the human being. It is a revolution that must take place in the whole of the mind and not merely in thought. Thought, after all, is only a result and not the source. There must be radical transformation of the source and not mere modification of the result. At present we are tinkering with results, with symptoms. We are not bringing about a vital change, uprooting the old ways of thought, freeing the mind from traditions and habits. It is with this vital change we are concerned and only right education can bring it into being.

但是，若要摆脱我们深陷其中的无休止的焦虑、冲突和挫折，一场截然不同的革命势在必行。这场革命并非始于最终被证明毫无价值的理论和构想，而是始于思想本身的根本性转变。这种转变唯有通过正确的教育和人的全面发展才能实现。这是一场必须在整个心灵层面发生的革命，而不仅仅是在思想层面。毕竟，思想只是结果，而非根源。我们必须从根本上改变根源，而不仅仅是修正结果。目前，我们只是在修补结果，修补症状。我们并没有带来根本性的改变，没有根除旧有的思维模式，没有将思想从传统和习惯中解放出来。我们所关注的正是这种根本性的改变，而唯有正确的教育才能促成它的实现。

To inquire and to learn is the function of the mind. By learning I do not mean the mere cultivation of memory or the accumulation of knowledge, but the capacity to think clearly and sanely without illusion, to start from facts and not from beliefs and ideals. There is no learning if thought originates from conclusions. To merely acquire information or knowledge is not to learn. Learning implies the love of understanding and the love of doing a thing for itself. Learning is possible only when there is no coercion of any kind. And coercion takes many forms, does it not? There is coercion through influence, through attachment or threat, through persuasive encouragement or subtle forms of reward.

探究和学习是心智的功能。我所说的学习并非仅仅指记忆的积累或知识的堆砌，而是指能够清晰、理智地思考，不带任何幻想，从事实出发，而非从信念和理想出发。如果思想源于结论，那就谈不上学习。仅仅获取信息或知识并非学习。学习意味着对理解的热爱，以及对自主思考的热爱。只有在没有任何形式的强迫的情况下，学习才有可能发生。而强迫的形式多种多样，不是吗？它可以是影响，可以是依恋或威胁，也可以是劝说性的鼓励或微妙的奖励。

Most people think that learning is encouraged through comparison, whereas the contrary is the fact. Comparison brings about frustration and merely encourages envy, which is called competition. Like other forms of persuasion, comparison prevents learning and breeds fear. Ambition also breeds fear. Ambition, whether personal or identified with the collective, is always antisocial. So-called noble ambition in relationship is fundamentally destructive.

大多数人认为比较能促进学习，但事实恰恰相反。比较只会带来挫败感，并滋生嫉妒，也就是竞争。与其他说服方式一样，比较会阻碍学习，滋生恐惧。野心也会滋生恐惧。无论是个人野心还是集体野心，都具有反社会性。所谓高尚的人际关系中的野心，从根本上来说是具有破坏性的。

It is necessary to encourage the development of a good mind—a mind which is capable of dealing with the many issues of life as a whole, and which does not try to escape from them and so become self-contradictory, frustrated, bitter, or cynical. And it is essential for the mind to be aware of its own conditioning, its own motives and pursuits.

培养健全的心智至关重要——这种心智能够全面应对人生中的诸多问题，而不是试图逃避，从而变得自相矛盾、沮丧、痛苦或愤世嫉俗。同时，心智也必须觉察自身的局限、动机和追求。

Since the development of a good mind is one of our chief concerns, how one teaches becomes very important. There must be a cultivation of the totality of the mind, and not merely the giving of information. In the process of imparting knowledge, the educator has to invite discussion and encourage the students to inquire and to think independently.

培养健全的人格是我们的首要任务之一，因此，教学方式至关重要。教育必须注重培养学生的全面发展，而不仅仅是传授知识。在知识传授的过程中，教育者必须引导学生参与讨论，鼓励他们探究问题，独立思考。

Authority, as “the one who knows,” has no place in learning. The educator and the student are both learning through their special relationship with each other, but this does not mean that the educator disregards the orderliness of thought. Orderliness of thought is not brought about by discipline in the form of assertive statements of knowledge; but it comes into being naturally when the educator understands that in cultivating intelligence there must be a sense of freedom. This does not mean freedom to do whatever one likes, or to think in the spirit of mere contradiction. It is the freedom in which the student is being helped to be aware of his own urges and motives, which are revealed to him through his daily thought and action.

权威，即“知晓者”，在学习中毫无立足之地。教育者和学生都通过彼此间的特殊关系进行学习，但这并不意味着教育者可以忽视思维的条理性。思维的条理性并非源于以断言知识形式呈现的纪律，而是在教育者理解培养智力必须包含自由意识时自然而然形成的。这种自由并非指随心所欲的自由，或仅仅是出于反驳精神的自由。它指的是在这种自由中，学生能够觉察自身的欲望和动机，而这些欲望和动机正是通过日常的思考和行动逐渐显露出来的。

A disciplined mind is never a free mind, nor can a mind that has suppressed desire ever be free. It is only through understanding the whole process of desire that the mind can be free. Discipline always limits the mind to a movement within the framework of a particular system of thought or belief, does it not? And such a mind is never free to be intelligent. Discipline brings about submission to authority. It gives the capacity to function within the pattern of a society which demands functional ability, but it does not awaken the intelligence which has its own capacity. The mind that has cultivated nothing but capacity through memory is like the modern electronic computer which, though it functions with astonishing ability and accuracy, is still only a machine. Authority can persuade the mind to think in a particular direction. But being guided to think along certain lines, or in terms of a foregone conclusion, is not to think at all; it is merely to function like a human machine, which breeds thoughtless discontent, bringing with it frustration and other miseries.

受过约束的心灵永远无法获得自由，压抑欲望的心灵也永远无法获得自由。唯有理解欲望的整个过程，心灵才能获得自由。纪律总是将心灵限制在特定思想体系或信仰框架内，不是吗？这样的心灵永远无法自由地发挥智慧。纪律使人屈服于权威。它使人具备在社会模式中运作的能力，满足社会对功能性能力的要求，但它无法唤醒自身蕴藏的智慧。如果心灵仅仅通过记忆来培养能力，就如同现代电子计算机，尽管它运行起来能力惊人、精度极高，但终究只是一台机器。权威可以引导心灵朝着某个特定的方向思考。但是，被引导着沿着某些既定的思路或基于预设的结论去思考，根本算不上思考；它仅仅是像一台机器一样运转，滋生着盲目的不满，带来挫败感和其他痛苦。

We are concerned with the total development of each human being, helping him to realize his own highest and fullest capacity—not some fictitious capacity which the educator has in view as a concept or an ideal. Any spirit of comparison prevents this full flowering of the individual, whether he is to be a scientist or a gardener. The fullest capacity of the gardener is the same as the fullest capacity of the scientist when there is no comparison; but when comparison comes in, then there is the disparagement and the envious reactions which create conflict between man and man. Like sorrow, love is not comparative; it cannot be compared with the greater or the lesser. Sorrow is sorrow, as love is love, whether it be in the rich or in the poor.

我们关注的是每个人的全面发展，帮助他充分发挥自身最高潜能——而非教育者所设想的某种虚构的、概念化的理想潜能。任何比较的心态都会阻碍个人潜能的充分绽放，无论他将来是成为科学家还是园丁。当不存在比较时，园丁的最高潜能与科学家的最高潜能并无二致；但一旦引入比较，便会产生贬低和嫉妒的反应，从而造成人与人之间的冲突。如同悲伤一样，爱也并非可以比较的；它无法与更大或更小的事物相提并论。悲伤就是悲伤，爱就是爱，无论它存在于富人还是穷人身上。

The fullest development of every individual creates a society of equals. The present social struggle to bring about equality on the economic or some spiritual level has no meaning at all. Social reforms aimed at establishing equality breed other forms of antisocial activity, but with right education, there is no need to seek equality through social and other reforms, because envy, with its comparison of capacities, ceases.

每个人的充分发展才能创造一个平等的社会。当前在经济或精神层面追求平等的社会斗争毫无意义。旨在建立平等的社会改革反而会滋生其他形式的反社会行为，但只要接受正确的教育，就无需通过社会改革或其他改革来寻求平等，因为嫉妒及其对能力的比较将不复存在。

We must differentiate here between function and status. Status, with all its emotional and hierarchical prestige, arises only through the comparison of functions as the high and the low. When each individual is flowering to his fullest capacity, there is then no comparison of functions; there is only the expression of capacity as a teacher, or a prime minister, or a gardener, and so status loses its sting of envy.

我们必须在此区分职能和地位。地位及其所蕴含的情感和等级威望，仅仅是通过将职能高低进行比较而产生的。当每个人都充分发挥自身潜能时，职能之间便不再存在比较；存在的只是能力的展现，例如教师、首相或园丁，因此地位也就失去了其令人艳羡的意味。

Functional or technical capacity is now recognized through having a degree after one’s name; but if we are truly concerned with the total development of the human being, our approach is entirely different. An individual who has the capacity may take a degree and add letters after his name, or he may not, as he pleases. But he will know for himself his own deep capabilities, which will not be framed by a degree, and their expression will not bring about that self-centered confidence which mere technical capacity usually breeds. Such confidence is comparative and, therefore, antisocial. Comparison may exist for utilitarian purpose; but it is not for the educator to compare the capacities of his students and give greater or lesser evaluation.

如今，人们往往通过学位来认可一个人的功能或技术能力；但如果我们真正关注人的全面发展，我们的方法则截然不同。一个人如果具备相应的能力，可以选择攻读学位，也可以选择不攻读，这完全取决于他自己的意愿。但他会清楚地认识到自身深层的潜能，而这种潜能不会被学位所束缚，也不会滋生那种仅仅依靠技术能力而产生的自负自信。这种自信是比较性的，因此也是反社会的。比较或许出于实用目的，但教育者的职责并非比较学生的能力并给予高低评价。

Since we are concerned with the total development of the individual, the student may not be allowed in the beginning to choose his own subjects, because his choice is likely to be based on passing moods and prejudices, or on finding the easiest thing to do; or he may choose according to the immediate demands of a particular need. But if he is helped to discover by himself and to cultivate his innate capacities, then he will naturally choose not the easiest subjects, but those through which he can express his capacities to the fullest and highest extent. If the student is helped from the very beginning to look at life as a whole, with all its psychological, intellectual, and emotional problems, he will not be frightened by it.

鉴于我们关注的是个体的全面发展，学生在初期可能无法自主选择科目，因为他的选择很可能受一时情绪和偏见的影响，或是出于图省事；也可能仅仅是为了满足眼前的特定需求。但如果引导他发现并培养自身的天赋，他自然会选择那些能够让他充分发挥潜能的科目，而不是最简单的科目。如果从一开始就帮助学生以整体的视角看待人生，包括其中所有的心理、智力和情感问题，他就不会感到畏惧。

Intelligence is the capacity to deal with life as a whole; and giving grades or marks to the student does not assure intelligence. On the contrary, it degrades human dignity. This comparative evaluation cripples the mind, which does not mean that the teacher must not observe the progress of every student and keep a record of it. Parents, naturally anxious to know the progress of their children, will want a report; but if, unfortunately, they do not understand what the educator is trying to do, the report will become an instrument of coercion to produce the results they desire, and so undo the work of the educator.

智力是应对人生整体的能力；给学生打分或评分并不能保证智力水平。相反，它会贬低人的尊严。这种比较式的评价会扼杀心智，但这并不意味着教师不应该观察每个学生的进步并做好记录。家长自然渴望了解孩子的学习进度，会要求一份报告；但如果他们不理解教育者的意图，这份报告就会变成一种强制手段，迫使他们达到自己想要的结果，从而抵消教育者的努力。

Parents should understand the kind of education the school intends to give. Generally they are satisfied to see their children preparing to get a degree of some kind which will assure them of a livelihood. Very few are concerned with more than this. Of course, they wish to see their children happy, but beyond this vague desire very few give any thought to their total development. As most parents desire above all else that their children should have a successful career, they frighten or affectionately bully them into acquiring knowledge, and so the book becomes very important; and with it there is the mere cultivation of memory, the mere repetition without the quality of real thought behind it.

家长应该了解学校打算提供的教育类型。通常，他们乐于见到孩子准备获得某种学位，从而保障生计。很少有人关心更多。当然，他们希望孩子快乐，但除了这种模糊的愿望之外，很少有人会考虑孩子的全面发展。由于大多数家长最希望孩子拥有成功的事业，他们会用恐吓或慈爱的“督促”来督促孩子学习知识，因此书本变得至关重要；而随之而来的仅仅是记忆的培养，仅仅是重复，缺乏真正思考的成分。

Perhaps the greatest difficulty the educator has to face is the indifference of parents to a wider and deeper education. Most parents are concerned only with the cultivation of some superficial knowledge that will secure their children respectable positions in a corrupt society. So the educator not only has to educate the children in the right way, but also to see to it that the parents do not undo whatever good may have been done at the school. Really the school and the home should be joint centers of right education, and should in no way be opposed to each other, with the parents desiring one thing and the educator doing something entirely different. It is very important that the parents be fully acquainted with what the educator is doing and be vitally interested in the total development of their children. It is as much the responsibility of the parents to see that this kind of education is carried out as it is of the teachers, whose burden is already sufficiently heavy. A total development of the child can be brought about only when there is the right relationship between the teacher, the student, and the parents. As the educator cannot yield to the passing fancies or obstinate demands of the parents, it is necessary for them to understand the educator and cooperate with him, and not bring about conflict and confusion in their children.

或许教育者面临的最大挑战是家长对更广泛、更深入教育的漠视。大多数家长只关心培养孩子一些肤浅的知识，以确保他们在腐败的社会中获得体面的地位。因此，教育者不仅要以正确的方式教育孩子，还要确保家长不会破坏学校所做的一切努力。事实上，学校和家庭应该是共同的教育中心，两者绝不应该相互对立，家长的期望与教育者的做法完全不同。家长充分了解教育者的工作，并真正关心孩子的全面发展，这一点至关重要。确保这种教育得以实施，不仅是教师的责任，也是家长的责任，而教师的负担已经非常沉重。只有当教师、学生和家长之间建立起良好的关系时，孩子的全面发展才能实现。教育者不能屈从于家长一时兴起或固执己见的要求，因此家长必须理解教育者并与教育者合作，不要给孩子带来冲突和混乱。

The child’s natural curiosity, the urge to learn, exists from the very beginning, and surely this should be intelligently encouraged continually, so that it remains vital and without distortion, and will gradually lead him to the study of a variety of subjects. If this eagerness to learn is encouraged in the child at all times, then his study of mathematics, geography, history, science, or any other subject, will not be a problem to the child or to the educator. Learning is facilitated when there is an atmosphere of happy affection and thoughtful care.

孩子天生的好奇心和求知欲从一开始就存在，理应得到持续而明智的鼓励，使其保持活力，不致扭曲，并逐步引导他学习各种学科。如果始终鼓励孩子保持这种求知欲，那么无论学习数学、地理、历史、科学还是其他任何学科，对孩子和教育者来说都不会成为问题。在充满爱与关怀的氛围中，学习会更加顺利。

Emotional openness and sensitivity can be cultivated only when the student feels secure in his relationship with his teachers. The feeling of being secure in relationship is a primary need of children. There is a vast difference between the feeling of being secure and the feeling of dependency. Consciously or unconsciously, most educators cultivate the feeling of dependency, and thereby subtly encourage fear, which the parents also do in their own affectionate or aggressive manner. Dependency in the child is brought about by authoritarian or dogmatic assertions on the part of parents and teachers as to what the child must be and do. With dependency there is always the shadow of fear, and this fear compels the child to obey, to conform, to accept without thought the edicts and sanctions of his elders. In this atmosphere of dependency, sensitivity is crushed, but when the child knows and feels that he is secure, his emotional flowering is not thwarted by fear.

只有当学生在与老师的关系中感到安全时，才能培养情感的开放性和敏感性。安全感是儿童的基本需求。安全感和依赖感之间有着巨大的差异。大多数教育者有意或无意地培养孩子的依赖感，从而潜移默化地助长了恐惧，而父母也会以他们慈爱或强势的方式达到同样的目的。父母和老师对孩子应该成为什么样的人、应该做什么的权威或教条式的断言，会造成孩子的依赖。依赖总是伴随着恐惧的阴影，这种恐惧迫使孩子服从、顺从，不假思索地接受长辈的命令和惩罚。在这种依赖的氛围下，敏感性被扼杀；但当孩子知道并感受到安全感时，他的情感发展就不会被恐惧所阻碍。

This sense of security in the child is not the opposite of insecurity. It is the feeling of being at ease, whether in his own home or at school, the feeling that he can be what he is, without being compelled in any way; that he can climb a tree and not be scolded if he falls. He can have this sense of security only when the parents and the educators are deeply concerned with the total welfare of the child.

孩子的这种安全感并非不安全感的反义词。它是一种自在的感觉，无论是在家中还是在学校，都能让他感到放松自在，可以自由地做自己，不受任何强迫；他可以爬树，即使摔下来也不会被责骂。只有当父母和教育者真正关心孩子的全面福祉时，孩子才能拥有这种安全感。

It is important in a school that the child should feel at ease, completely secure from the very first day. This first impression is of the highest importance. But if the educator artificially tries by various means to gain the child’s confidence and allows him to do what he likes, then the educator is cultivating dependency; he is not giving the child the feeling of being secure, the feeling that he is in a place where there are people who are deeply concerned with his total welfare.

在学校里，让孩子从第一天起就感到自在和安全至关重要。第一印象至关重要。但如果教育者人为地用各种手段来获取孩子的信任，并放任孩子为所欲为，那么教育者就是在培养孩子的依赖性；他没有给孩子带来安全感，没有让孩子感受到自己身处一个真正关心他身心健康的环境。

The very first impact of this new relationship based on confidence, which the child may never have had before, will help toward a natural communication, without the young regarding the elders as a threat to be feared. A child who feels secure has his own natural ways of expressing the respect which is essential for learning. This respect is denuded of all authority and fear. When he has a feeling of security, the child’s conduct or behavior is not something imposed by an elder, but becomes part of the process of learning. Because he feels secure in his relationship with the teacher, the child will naturally be considerate; and it is only in this atmosphere of security that emotional openness and sensitivity can flower. Being at ease, feeling secure, the child will do what he likes; but in doing what he likes, he will find out what is the right thing to do, and his conduct then will not be due to resistance, or obstinacy, or suppressed feelings, or the mere expression of a momentary urge.

这种基于信任的全新关系，对孩子而言或许是前所未有的，它带来的首要影响是促进自然沟通，使孩子不再将长辈视为需要恐惧的威胁。一个感到安全的孩子会自然而然地表达尊重，而这种尊重对于学习至关重要。这种尊重不包含任何权威和恐惧。当孩子感到安全时，他的言行举止不再受长辈的强加，而是成为学习过程的一部分。因为与老师的关系让他感到安全，孩子自然会体贴他人；只有在这种安全的氛围中，情感的开放和敏感才能得以绽放。感到自在和安全的孩子会做自己喜欢的事；但在做自己喜欢的事的过程中，他会逐渐明白什么是正确的，此时他的行为不再是出于抗拒、固执、压抑的情感或仅仅是一时冲动。

Sensitivity means being sensitive to everything around one—to the plants, the animals, the trees, the skies, the waters of the river, the bird on the wing; and also to the moods of the people around one, and to the stranger who passes by. This sensitivity brings about the quality of uncalculated, unselfish response, which is true morality and conduct. Being sensitive, the child in his conduct will be open and not secretive; therefore, a mere suggestion on the part of the teacher will be accepted easily, without resistance or friction.

敏感意味着对周围的一切事物保持敏锐——对植物、动物、树木、天空、河水、飞鸟的感知；也包括对周围人的情绪以及擦肩而过的陌生人的体察。这种敏感带来一种不加计谋、无私的回应，这才是真正的道德和行为准则。敏感的孩子在行为举止上会坦诚开放，不藏私；因此，老师的任何建议都能被他们欣然接受，不会产生抵触或摩擦。

As we are concerned with the total development of the human being, we must understand his emotional urges, which are very much stronger than intellectual reasoning; we must cultivate emotional capacity and not help to suppress it. When we understand and are, therefore, capable of dealing with emotional as well as intellectual issues, there will be no sense of fear in approaching them. For the total development of the human being, solitude as a means of cultivating sensitivity becomes a necessity. One has to know what it is to be alone, what it is to meditate, what it is to die; and the implications of solitude, of meditation, of death, can be known only by seeking them out. These implications cannot be taught, they must be learned. One can indicate, but learning by what is indicated is not the experiencing of solitude or meditation. To experience what is solitude and what is meditation, one must be in a state of inquiry; only a mind that is in a state of inquiry is capable of learning. But when inquiry is suppressed by previous knowledge, or by the authority and experience of another, then learning becomes mere imitation, and imitation causes a human being to repeat what is learned without experiencing it.

既然我们关注的是人的全面发展，就必须理解人的情感冲动，因为情感冲动远比理性推理强烈得多；我们必须培养情感能力，而不是压制它。当我们理解并因此能够处理情感和理性问题时，面对它们就不会感到恐惧。为了人的全面发展，独处作为培养敏感性的手段，变得必不可少。人必须知道什么是独处，什么是冥想，什么是死亡；而独处、冥想和死亡的意义，只能通过探寻才能了解。这些意义无法被教授，必须被学习。我们可以指出，但通过指出来学习并非体验独处或冥想。要体验独处和冥想的真谛，人必须处于一种探究的状态；只有处于探究状态的心灵才能学习。但是，当探究受到先前的知识，或者受到他人的权威和经验的压制时，学习就变成了单纯的模仿，而模仿会导致人重复所学的内容，却没有真正体验过。

Teaching is not the mere imparting of information but the cultivation of an inquiring mind. Such a mind will penetrate into the question of what is religion, and not merely accept the established religions with their temples and rituals. The search for God, or truth, or whatever one may like to name it—and not the mere acceptance of belief and dogma—is true religion.

教学并非仅仅是传授知识，而是培养求知精神。这样的精神会深入探究宗教的本质，而不仅仅是接受既定的宗教及其寺庙和仪式。探寻上帝、真理，或者任何你喜欢称之为的东西——而非仅仅接受信仰和教条——才是真正的宗教。

Just as the student cleans his teeth every day, bathes every day, learns new things every day, so also there must be the action of sitting quietly with others or by himself. This solitude cannot be brought about by instruction, or urged by the external authority of tradition, or induced by the influence of those who want to sit quietly but are incapable of being alone. Solitude helps the mind to see itself clearly, as in a mirror, and to free itself from the vain endeavor of ambition with all its complexities, fears, and frustrations, which are the outcome of self-centered activity. Solitude gives to the mind a stability, a constancy which is not to be measured in terms of time. Such clarity of mind is character. The lack of character is the state of self-contradiction.

如同学生每日刷牙、每日沐浴、每日学习新知识一样，也必须有与他人或独自静坐的习惯。这种独处并非通过教导就能获得，也非受传统权威的外在约束，更非受那些渴望独处却无法做到的人的影响。独处有助于心灵如镜般清晰地审视自身，并使其摆脱以自我为中心的活动所带来的种种复杂、恐惧和挫败感，以及虚妄的野心。独处赋予心灵一种稳定和恒久性，这种稳定和恒久性无法用时间来衡量。这种清晰的心灵便是品格。缺乏品格则是一种自相矛盾的状态。

To be sensitive is to love. The word love is not love. And love is not to be divided as the love of God and the love of man, nor is it to be measured as the love of the one and of the many. Love gives itself abundantly as a flower gives its perfume; but we are always measuring love in our relationship and thereby destroying it.

敏感即是爱。爱这个词本身并非爱。爱不应被割裂为对上帝的爱和对人的爱，也不应被衡量为对一个人的爱和对许多人的爱。爱如同花朵般慷慨地付出芬芳；然而，我们却总是试图在人际关系中衡量爱，从而扼杀它。

Love is not a commodity of the reformer or the social worker; it is not a political instrument with which to create action. When the politician and the reformer speak of love, they are using the word and do not touch the reality of it; for love cannot be employed as a means to an end, whether in the immediate or in the far-off future. Love is of the whole earth and not of a particular field or forest. The love of reality is not encompassed by any religion; and when organized religions use it, it ceases to be. Societies, organized religions, and authoritarian governments, sedulous in their various activities, unknowingly destroy the love that becomes passion in action.

爱并非改革者或社会工作者的商品；它并非用来促成行动的政治工具。当政治家和改革者谈论爱时，他们只是在利用这个词，而没有触及爱的本质；因为爱不能被用作达成目的的手段，无论这个目的是为了眼前还是遥远的未来。爱属于整个世界，而非某个特定的田野或森林。对现实的爱不属于任何宗教；当有组织的宗教利用它时，它便不复存在。社会、有组织的宗教和专制政府，在各自的活动中孜孜不倦地运作，却在不知不觉中摧毁了那化作行动激情的爱。

In the total development of the human being through right education, the quality of love must be nourished and sustained from the very beginning. Love is not sentimentality, nor is it devotion. It is as strong as death. Love cannot be bought through knowledge; and a mind that is pursuing knowledge without love is a mind that deals in ruthlessness and aims merely at efficiency.

在通过正确的教育实现人格全面发展的过程中，爱的品质必须从一开始就得到滋养和维护。爱不是感伤，也不是奉献，它如同死亡般强大。爱无法用知识换取；而一个只追求知识却缺乏爱的头脑，只会变得冷酷无情，只追求效率。

So the educator must be concerned from the very beginning with this quality of love, which is humility, gentleness, consideration, patience, and courtesy. Modesty and courtesy are innate in the man of right education; he is considerate to all, including the animals and plants, and this is reflected in his behavior and manner of talking.

因此，教育者必须从一开始就关注这种爱的品质，即谦逊、温柔、体贴、耐心和礼貌。谦逊和礼貌是受过良好教育的人与生俱来的品质；他体贴一切，包括动物和植物，这体现在他的行为和言谈举止中。

The emphasis on this quality of love frees the mind from its absorption in its ambition, greed, and acquisitiveness.
