Does not love have about it a refinement which expresses itself as respect and good taste? Does it not also bring about the purification of the mind, which otherwise has a tendency to strengthen itself in pride? Refinement in behavior is not a self-imposed adjustment or the result of an outward demand; it comes spontaneously with this quality of love. When there is the understanding of love, then sex and all the complications and subtleties of human relationship can be approached with sanity and not with excitement and apprehension.

对爱的这种特质的强调，能使人的心灵摆脱野心、贪婪和占有欲的束缚。爱难道不自带一种高雅的气质，体现在尊重和良好的品味上吗？它难道不也能净化心灵，使之免于骄傲的滋生吗？行为上的高雅并非自我强加的调整，也不是外在要求的结果；它随着爱的这种特质自然而然地流露出来。当人们真正理解了爱的真谛，就能以理智而非激动和焦虑的态度来面对性以及人际关系中所有复杂微妙之处。

The educator to whom the total development of the human being is of primary importance must understand the implications of the sexual urge which plays such an important part in our life, and be able from the very beginning to meet the children’s natural curiosity without arousing a morbid interest. Merely to impart biological information at the adolescent age may lead to experimental lust if the quality of love is not felt. Love cleanses the mind of evil. Without love and understanding on the part of the educator, merely to separate the boys from the girls, whether by barbed wire or by edicts, only strengthens their curiosity and stimulates that passion which is bound to degenerate into mere satisfaction. So it is important that boys and girls be educated together rightly.

以人全面发展为首要目标的教育者，必须理解性冲动在我们生活中扮演的重要角色，并从一开始就能够满足孩子们与生俱来的好奇心，而不激起病态的兴趣。如果缺乏爱的滋养，仅仅在青春期传授生物学知识可能会导致他们沉溺于尝试性的性欲。爱能净化心灵，驱散邪恶。如果教育者缺乏爱与理解，仅仅用铁丝网或法令将男孩和女孩隔离开来，只会加剧他们的好奇心，刺激那种注定会堕落为单纯满足欲望的激情。因此，男孩和女孩接受正确的共同教育至关重要。

This quality of love must express itself also in doing things with one’s hands, such as gardening, carpentry, painting, handicrafts; and through the senses, as seeing the trees, the mountains, the richness of the earth, the poverty that men have created amongst themselves; and in hearing music, the song of the birds, the murmur of running waters.

这种爱的品质也必须体现在亲身实践中，例如园艺、木工、绘画、手工艺；并通过感官来表达，例如观赏树木、山峦、土地的富饶、人类自身造成的贫困；以及聆听音乐、鸟儿的歌唱、流水的潺潺声。

We are concerned not only with the cultivation of the mind and the awakening of emotional sensitivity, but also with a well-rounded development of the physique, and to this we must give considerable thought. For if the body is not healthy, vital, it will inevitably distort thought and make for insensitivity. This is so obvious that we need not go into it in detail. It is necessary that the body be in excellent health, that it be given the right kind of food and have sufficient sleep. If the senses are not alert, the body will impede the total development of the human being. To have grace of movement and well-balanced control of the muscles, there must be various forms of exercise, dancing, and games. A body that is not kept clean, that is sloppy and does not hold itself in good posture, is not conducive to sensitivity of mind and emotions. The body is not the instrument of the mind, but body, emotions, and mind make up the total human being, and unless they live together harmoniously, conflict is inevitable.

我们不仅关注心智的修炼和情感的觉醒，也关注体魄的全面发展，对此我们必须认真思考。因为如果身体不健康、缺乏活力，必然会影响思维，导致情感迟钝。这一点显而易见，无需赘述。身体必须保持健康，摄入合适的食物，并拥有充足的睡眠。如果感官不敏锐，身体就会阻碍人的全面发展。为了拥有优雅的体态和均衡的肌肉控制力，必须进行各种形式的锻炼、舞蹈和游戏。不保持清洁、邋遢、姿势不良的身体不利于心智和情感的敏锐。身体并非心灵的工具，而是身、心、灵三者共同构成完整的人，如果它们不能和谐共处，冲突就不可避免。

Conflict makes for insensitivity. The mind may dominate the body and suppress the senses, but it thereby makes the body insensitive; and an insensitive body becomes a hindrance to the full flight of the mind. The mortification of the body is definitely not conducive to the seeking out of the deeper layers of consciousness; for this is possible only when the mind, the emotions, and the body are not in contradiction with each other, but are integrated and in unison, effortlessly, without being driven by any concept, belief, or ideal.

冲突会导致麻木。心智或许可以支配身体，压制感官，但这会使身体变得麻木；而麻木的身体会阻碍心智的充分发挥。苦行绝非探寻意识深层之道；因为只有当心智、情感和身体彼此和谐统一，浑然天成，不受任何概念、信仰或理想的驱使时，才能真正达到这种境界。

In the cultivation of the mind, our emphasis should not be on concentration, but on attention. Concentration is a process of forcing the mind to narrow down to a point, whereas attention is without frontiers. In that process the mind is always limited by a frontier or boundary, but when our concern is to understand the totality of the mind, mere concentration becomes a hindrance. Attention is limitless, without the frontiers of knowledge. Knowledge comes through concentration, and any extension of knowledge is still within its own frontiers. In the state of attention the mind can and does use knowledge, which of necessity is the result of concentration; but the part is never the whole, and adding together the many parts does not make for the perception of the whole. Knowledge, which is the additive process of concentration, does not bring about the understanding of the immeasurable. The total is never within the brackets of a concentrated mind.

在修心之道中，我们不应着重于专注，而应着重于觉察。专注是强迫心念聚焦于一点的过程，而觉察则无边无际。在这个过程中，心念总是受到某种界限的限制，但当我们追求理解心念的整体时，单纯的专注反而会成为一种阻碍。觉察是无限的，不受知识的界限束缚。知识源于专注，而任何知识的延伸仍然在其自身的界限之内。在觉察的状态下，心念能够也确实会运用知识，而知识必然是专注的结果；但部分永远不是整体，将众多部分相加也无法感知整体。知识，作为专注的累加过程，并不能带来对不可测度之物的理解。整体永远无法被专注的心念所涵盖。

So attention is of primary importance, but it does not come through the effort of concentration. Attention is a state in which the mind is ever learning without a center around which knowledge gathers as accumulated experience. A mind that is concentrated upon itself uses knowledge as a means of its own expansion; and such activity becomes self-contradictory and antisocial.

因此，注意力至关重要，但它并非源于刻意集中注意力。注意力是一种心智持续学习的状态，它没有一个中心，知识无需围绕其积累经验即可聚集。一个专注于自身的心智会将知识作为自我扩张的手段；而这种行为最终会变得自相矛盾且反社会。

Learning in the true sense of the word is possible only in that state of attention in which there is no outer or inner compulsion. Right thinking can come about only when the mind is not enslaved by tradition and memory. It is attention that allows silence to come upon the mind, which is the opening of the door to creation. That is why attention is of the highest importance.

真正的学习只有在一种不受任何外在或内在强迫的专注状态下才有可能发生。只有当心灵不再受传统和记忆的束缚时，正确的思考才能产生。正是专注使心灵得以宁静，而宁静正是通往创造之门的开启。因此，专注至关重要。

Knowledge is necessary at the functional level as a means of cultivating the mind, and not as an end in itself. We are concerned not with the development of just one capacity, such as that of a mathematician, or a scientist, or a musician, but with the total development of the student as a human being.

知识在功能层面是必要的，它是培养心智的手段，而非目的本身。我们关注的并非仅仅是培养某一项能力，例如数学家、科学家或音乐家的能力，而是学生作为人的全面发展。

How is the state of attention to be brought about? It cannot be cultivated through persuasion, comparison, reward, or punishment, all of which are forms of coercion. The elimination of fear is the beginning of attention. Fear must exist as long as there is an urge to be or to become, which is the pursuit of success, with all its frustrations and tortuous contradictions. You can teach concentration, but attention cannot be taught, just as you cannot possibly teach freedom from fear; but we can begin to discover the causes that produce fear, and in understanding these causes there is the elimination of fear. So attention arises spontaneously when around the student there is an atmosphere of well-being, when he has the feeling of being secure, of being at ease, and is aware of the disinterested action that comes with love. Love does not compare, and so the envy and torture of becoming cease.

如何才能培养专注的状态？它无法通过说服、比较、奖励或惩罚来培养，因为这些都是强制的形式。消除恐惧是专注的开始。只要存在成为或成长的渴望，恐惧就必然存在，而这种渴望就是对成功的追求，伴随着所有的挫折和曲折的矛盾。你可以教人集中注意力，但专注力无法教授，正如你不可能教人摆脱恐惧一样；但我们可以开始发现产生恐惧的原因，而理解这些原因就能消除恐惧。因此，当学生周围充满幸福的氛围，感到安全、自在，并意识到爱所带来的无私行动时，专注力就会自然而然地产生。爱不比较，因此，追求成功的嫉妒和痛苦也就消失了。

The general discontent which all of us experience, whether young or old, soon finds a way to satisfaction, and thus our minds are put to sleep. Discontent is awakened from time to time through suffering, but the mind again seeks a gratifying solution. In this wheel of dissatisfaction and gratification the mind is caught, and the constant awakening through pain is part of our discontent. Discontent is the way of inquiry, but there can be no inquiry if the mind is tethered to tradition, to ideals. Inquiry is the flame of attention.

无论老幼，我们每个人都会经历普遍的不满，而这种不满很快就会找到满足的途径，于是我们的心智便沉睡了。痛苦不时会唤醒这种不满，但心智又会再次寻求令人满意的解决办法。心智被困在这不满与满足的循环之中，而痛苦带来的不断觉醒正是我们不满的一部分。不满是探索的途径，但如果心智被传统和理想所束缚，探索便无从谈起。探索是专注的火焰。

By discontent I mean that state in which the mind understands what is , the actual, and constantly inquires to discover further. Discontent is a movement to go beyond the limitations of what is ; and if you find ways and means of smoothing or overcoming discontent, then you will accept the limitations of self-centered activity and of the society in which you find yourself.

我所说的不满，是指心灵理解了现实，却仍然不断探寻更深层次意义的状态。不满是一种超越现实局限的运动；如果你找到了平息或克服不满的方法，那么你也就接受了以自我为中心的活动以及你所处社会的局限性。

Discontent is the flame which burns away the dross of satisfaction, but most of us seek to dissipate it in various ways. Our discontent then becomes the pursuit of the more, the desire for a bigger house, a better car, and so on, all of which are within the field of envy; and it is envy that sustains such discontent. But I am talking of a discontent in which there is no envy, no greed for “the more,” a discontent that is not sustained by any desire for satisfaction. This discontent is an unpolluted state which exists in each one of us, if it is not deadened through wrong education, through gratifying solutions, through ambition, or through the pursuit of an ideal. When we understand the nature of real discontent, we shall see that attention is part of this burning flame, which consumes the pettiness and leaves the mind free of the limitations of self-enclosing pursuits and gratifications.

不满如同火焰，烧尽满足的杂质，但我们大多数人却试图用各种方式来消除它。于是，我们的不满变成了对更多东西的追求，渴望更大的房子、更好的车等等，而所有这些都属于嫉妒的范畴；正是嫉妒维系着这种不满。但我所说的不满，并非出于嫉妒，也并非出于对“更多”的贪婪，它并非由任何对满足的渴望所维系。这种不满是一种纯净的状态，存在于我们每个人心中，除非它被错误的教育、令人满足的解决方案、野心或对理想的追求所麻痹。当我们理解真正不满的本质时，就会明白，注意力也是这团燃烧的火焰的一部分，它能吞噬琐碎，使心灵摆脱自我封闭的追求和满足的束缚。

So attention comes into being only when there is inquiry not based on self-advancement or gratification. This attention must be cultivated in the child, right from the beginning. You will find that when there is love—which expresses itself through humility, courtesy, patience, gentleness—you are already free of the barriers which insensitivity builds; and so you are helping to bring about in the child this state of attention from a very tender age.

因此，只有当探究并非出于自我提升或满足的目的时，专注力才会产生。这种专注力必须从孩子幼年时期就开始培养。你会发现，当爱——通过谦逊、礼貌、耐心和温柔来表达——存在时，你就已经摆脱了冷漠所筑起的壁垒；因此，你正在帮助孩子从很小的时候就培养出这种专注力。

Attention is not something to be learned, but you can help to awaken it in the student by not creating around him that sense of compulsion which produces a self-contradictory existence. Then his attention can be focused at any moment on any given subject, and it will not be the narrow concentration brought about through the compulsive urge of acquisition or achievement.

注意力并非后天习得，但你可以通过避免营造那种导致自我矛盾的强迫氛围，来帮助学生唤醒这种能力。如此一来，他的注意力便能随时集中于任何事物，而不会沦为因强迫性的获取或成就欲望而导致的狭隘专注。

A generation educated in this manner will be free of acquisitiveness and fear, the psychological inheritance of their parents and of the society in which they are born; and because they are so educated, they will not depend on the inheritance of property. This matter of inheritance destroys real independence and limits intelligence; for it breeds a false sense of security, giving a self-assurance which has no basis and creating a darkness of the mind in which nothing new can flourish. But a generation educated in this totally different manner we have been considering will create a new society; for they will have the capacity born of that intelligence which is not hedged about by fear.

以这种方式教育的一代人将摆脱贪婪和恐惧——这些心理缺陷源于他们的父母和他们所出生的社会；正因为他们接受了这样的教育，他们才不会依赖财产继承。财产继承会摧毁真正的独立性，限制智力发展；因为它滋生了一种虚假的安全感，赋予人一种毫无根据的自信，并在心灵深处筑起一道黑暗的屏障，使任何新事物都无法萌芽。但是，以我们一直在探讨的这种截然不同的方式接受教育的一代人，将创造一个全新的社会；因为他们将拥有源于不受恐惧束缚的智慧的能力。

Since education is the responsibility of the parents as well as of the teachers, we must learn the art of working together, and this is possible only when each one of us perceives what is true. It is perception of the truth that brings us together, and not opinion, belief, or theory. There is a vast difference between the conceptual and the factual. The conceptual may bring us together temporarily, but there will again be separation if our working together is only a matter of conviction. If the truth is seen by each one of us, there may be disagreement in detail but there will be no urge to separate. It is the foolish who break away over some detail. When the truth is seen by all, the detail can never become an issue over which there is dissension.

教育是父母和教师的共同责任，因此我们必须学会合作，而这只有在我们每个人都能认识到真理时才有可能实现。将我们凝聚在一起的是对真理的认知，而非观点、信仰或理论。概念与事实之间存在着巨大的差异。概念或许能暂时让我们走到一起，但如果我们的合作仅仅基于信念，那么最终还是会走向分裂。如果我们每个人都能看到真理，即使细节上存在分歧，也不会产生分裂的念头。只有愚人才会因为一些细节而分崩离析。当所有人都能看到真理时，细节就永远不会成为引发争论的焦点。

Most of us are used to working together along the lines of established authority. We come together to work for a concept, or to advance an ideal, and this requires conviction, persuasion, propaganda, and so on. Such working together for a concept, for an ideal, is totally different from the cooperation which comes from seeing the truth and the necessity of putting that truth into action. Working under the stimulus of authority—whether it be the authority of an ideal, or the authority of a person who represents that ideal—is not real cooperation. A central authority who knows a great deal, or who has a strong personality and is obsessed with certain ideas, may force or subtly persuade others to work with him for what he calls the ideal; but surely this is not the working together of alert and vital individuals, whereas when each one of us understands for himself the truth of any issue, then our common understanding of that truth leads to action, and such action is cooperation. He who cooperates because he sees the truth as the truth, the false as the false, and the truth in the false, will also know when not to cooperate, which is equally important.

我们大多数人习惯于在既定权威的框架下合作。我们聚集在一起，为了某个理念或理想而努力，这需要信念、说服、宣传等等。这种为了理念或理想而进行的合作，与基于对真理的理解以及将真理付诸行动的必要性而产生的合作截然不同。在权威的驱使下工作——无论是理念的权威，还是代表该理念的人的权威——都不是真正的合作。一个博学多识、个性鲜明且执着于某些理念的中心权威，或许会强迫或巧妙地劝说他人与他一起为他所谓的理想而努力；但这绝非一群敏锐而充满活力的个体之间的合作。相反，当我们每个人都独立地理解了某个问题的真相时，我们对真相的共同理解便会促成行动，而这种行动才是真正的合作。能够明辨是非、视真视假、视假中亦真而选择合作的人，也同样懂得何时不该合作，这一点同样重要。

If each one of us realizes the necessity of a fundamental revolution in education and perceives the truth of what we have been considering, then we shall work together without any form of persuasion. Persuasion exists only when someone takes a stand from which he is unwilling to move. When he is merely convinced of an idea or entrenched in an opinion, he brings about opposition, and then he or the other has to be persuaded, influenced, or induced to think differently. Such a situation will never arise when each one of us sees the truth of the matter for himself. But if we do not see the truth and act on the basis of merely verbal conviction or intellectual reasoning, then there is bound to be contention, agreement or disagreement, with all the associated distortion and useless effort.

如果我们每个人都能意识到教育领域亟需一场根本性的变革，并领悟到我们一直在思考的真理，那么我们就能携手合作，无需任何说服。说服只有在某人立场坚定、不愿改变时才会存在。当他仅仅坚信某种观点或固执己见时，就会引发反对，这时就需要说服、影响或引导他改变想法。如果我们每个人都能看清真相，这种情况就不会发生。但如果我们看不到真相，仅仅基于口头上的信念或理性的推理行事，那么必然会出现争论、赞同或反对，以及随之而来的各种扭曲和徒劳的努力。

It is essential that we work together, and it is as if we were building a house. If some of us are building and others are tearing down, the house will obviously never be built. So we must individually be very clear that we really see and understand the necessity of bringing about the kind of education that will produce a new generation capable of dealing with the issues of life as a whole, and not as isolated parts unrelated to the whole.

我们必须齐心协力，这就像盖房子一样。如果一部分人在盖，一部分人在拆，房子显然永远也盖不起来。所以，我们每个人都必须清楚地认识到，我们真正理解并认识到，我们需要建立一种教育体系，培养出能够从整体上应对人生各种问题的新一代，而不是将他们视为与整体无关的孤立部分。

To be able to work together in this really cooperative way, we must meet often and be alert not to get submerged in detail. Those of us who are seriously dedicated to the bringing about of the right kind of education have the responsibility not only of carrying out in action all that we have understood, but also of helping others to come to this understanding. Teaching is the noblest profession—if it can be called a profession at all. It is an art that requires, not just intellectual attainments, but infinite patience and love. To be truly educated is to understand our relationship to all things—to money, to property, to people, to nature—in the vast field of our existence.

为了能够以这种真正合作的方式共同努力，我们必须经常会面，并警惕不要陷入细节之中。我们这些认真致力于实现正确教育的人，不仅有责任将我们所理解的一切付诸实践，还有责任帮助他人获得这种理解。教师是最崇高的职业——如果它能被称为职业的话。它是一门艺术，需要的不仅是知识成就，更是无限的耐心和爱。真正受过教育意味着理解我们在广阔的生存领域中与万物——金钱、财产、人、自然——的关系。

Beauty is part of this understanding, but beauty is not merely a matter of proportion, form, taste, and behavior. Beauty is that state in which the mind has abandoned the center of self in the passion of simplicity. Simplicity has no end; and there can be simplicity only when there is an austerity which is not the outcome of calculated discipline and self-denial. This austerity is self-abandonment, which love alone can bring about. When we have no love we create a civilization in which beauty of form is sought without the inner vitality and austerity of simple self-abandonment. There is no self-abandonment if there is an immolation of oneself in good works, in ideals, in beliefs. These activities appear to be free of the self, but in reality the self is still working under the cover of different labels. Only the innocent mind can inquire into the unknown. But the calculated innocence which may wear a loincloth or the robe of a monk is not that passion of self-abandonment from which come courtesy, gentleness, humility, patience—the expressions of love.

美是这种理解的一部分，但美并非仅仅关乎比例、形式、品味和行为。美是一种心境，在这种状态下，心灵在纯粹的激情中舍弃了自我中心。纯粹永无止境；而纯粹唯有在一种并非出于刻意约束和自我克制的苦行中才能存在。这种苦行即是自我舍弃，唯有爱才能带来这种舍弃。当我们缺乏爱时，我们便创造了一种文明，在这种文明中，人们追求形式之美，却缺乏内在的活力和纯粹自我舍弃的苦行。如果一个人在善行、理想和信仰中自我牺牲，那就谈不上自我舍弃。这些活动看似摆脱了自我，但实际上，自我仍然在以不同的标签掩盖下运作。唯有纯洁的心灵才能探寻未知。但是，那种穿着缠腰布或僧袍的刻意装出来的天真无邪，并不是那种自我牺牲的激情，而这种激情才能带来礼貌、温柔、谦逊、耐心——爱的表达。

Most of us know beauty only through that which has been created or put together—the beauty of a human form, or of a temple. We say a tree, or a house, or the widely curving river, is beautiful. And through comparison we know what ugliness is—at least we think we do. But is beauty comparable? Is beauty that which has been made evident, manifest? We consider beautiful a particular picture, poem, or face, because we already know what beauty is from what we have been taught, or from what we are familiar with and about which we have formed an opinion. But does not beauty cease with comparison? Is beauty merely a familiarity with the known, or is it a state of being in which there may or may not be the created form?

我们大多数人对美的认知仅限于那些被创造或组合在一起的事物——比如人体之美，或是寺庙之美。我们会说一棵树、一栋房子，或是蜿蜒的河流是美的。通过比较，我们也能感知丑陋——至少我们自认为如此。但美真的可以比较吗？美仅仅是那些显而易见、显而易见的事物吗？我们之所以认为某幅画、某首诗或某张脸是美的，是因为我们已经从所受的教育或熟悉的事物中了解了美，并形成了自己的看法。但美难道止步于比较吗？美仅仅是对已知事物的熟悉，还是一种存在状态，在这种状态下，被创造的形体可能存在，也可能不存在？

We are always pursuing beauty and avoiding the ugly, and this seeking of enrichment through the one and avoidance of the other must inevitably breed insensitivity. Surely, to understand or to feel what beauty is, there must be sensitivity to both the so-called beautiful and the so-called ugly. A feeling is not beautiful or ugly, it is just a feeling. But we look at it through our religious and social conditioning and give it a label; we say it is a good feeling or a bad feeling, and so we distort or destroy it. When feeling is not given a label it remains intense, and it is this passionate intensity that is essential to the understanding of that which is neither ugliness nor manifested beauty. What has the greatest importance is sustained feeling, that passion which is not the mere lust of self-gratification; for it is this passion that creates beauty and, not being comparable, it has no opposite.

我们总是追求美，逃避丑，这种通过美来丰富自我、通过逃避丑来逃避自我的做法，必然会滋生麻木。诚然，要理解或感受美的本质，就必须对所谓的美和所谓的丑都保持敏感。感觉本身无所谓美丑，它只是一种感觉。但我们却透过宗教和社会教条去看待它，并给它贴上标签；我们说它是好的感觉，说它是坏的感觉，就这样，我们扭曲甚至摧毁了它。当感觉不被贴上标签时，它便保持着强烈的状态，而正是这种炽热的强度，对于理解既非丑也非显性美的事物至关重要。最重要的，是持续的感受，是那种并非单纯满足自我欲望的激情；因为正是这种激情创造了美，而且它无法与任何事物相提并论，所以它没有对立面。

In seeking to bring about a total development of the human being, we must obviously take into full consideration the unconscious mind as well as the conscious. Merely to educate the conscious mind without understanding the unconscious brings self-contradiction into human lives, with all its frustrations and miseries. The hidden mind is far more vital than the superficial. Most educators are concerned only with giving information or knowledge to the superficial mind, preparing it to acquire a job and adjust itself to society. So the hidden mind is never touched. All that so-called education does is to superimpose a layer of knowledge and technique, and a certain capacity to adjust to environment.

为了实现人的全面发展，我们显然必须充分考虑潜意识和意识。仅仅教育意识而不了解潜意识，会给人类生活带来自相矛盾的后果，以及种种挫折和痛苦。潜意识远比表层意识重要得多。大多数教育者只关注于向表层意识传授信息或知识，使其具备获得工作和适应社会的能力。因此，潜意识从未被触及。所谓的教育所做的，不过是给个体叠加一层知识和技能，以及某种适应环境的能力。

The hidden mind is far more potent than the superficial mind, however well-educated and capable of adjustment; and it is not something very mysterious. The hidden or unconscious mind is the repository of racial memories. Religion, superstition, symbol, peculiar traditions of a particular race, the influence of literature both sacred and profane, aspirations, frustrations, mannerisms, and varieties of food—all these are rooted in the unconscious. The open and secret desires, with their motivations, hopes, and fears, their sorrows and pleasures, and the beliefs which are sustained through the urge for security, translating itself in various ways—these things also are contained in the hidden mind, which not only has this extraordinary capacity to hold the residual past, but also the capacity to influence the future. Intimations of all this are given to the superficial mind through dreams and in various other ways when it is not wholly occupied with everyday events.

隐秘的心灵远比表层心灵强大，无论后者受过多么良好的教育，适应能力多么强；而且它并非什么神秘莫测的东西。隐秘的或无意识的心灵是种族记忆的宝库。宗教、迷信、符号、特定种族的独特传统、神圣与世俗文学的影响、抱负、挫折、举止以及各种食物——所有这些都根植于无意识之中。公开和隐秘的欲望，以及它们的动机、希望和恐惧，它们的悲伤和快乐，以及因对安全感的渴望而维系的信念，以各种方式呈现出来——这些也都包含在隐秘的心灵之中。隐秘的心灵不仅拥有容纳残留过去的非凡能力，也拥有影响未来的能力。当表层心灵并非完全被日常琐事占据时，梦境和其他各种方式都会向它传递所有这些暗示。

The hidden mind is nothing sacred and nothing to be frightened of, nor does it demand a specialist to expose it to the superficial mind. But because of the hidden mind’s enormous potency, the superficial mind cannot deal with it as it would wish. The superficial mind is to a great extent impotent in relation to its own hidden part. However much it may try to dominate, shape, or control the hidden, because of its immediate social demands and pursuits, the superficial can only scratch the surface of the hidden; and so there is a cleavage or contradiction between the two. We try to bridge this chasm through discipline, through various practices, sanctions, and so on; but it cannot so be bridged.

隐秘的心灵并非神圣不可侵犯，也无需恐惧，更不需要专家将其揭示给表层心灵。然而，由于隐秘心灵蕴藏着巨大的力量，表层心灵却无法随心所欲地驾驭它。表层心灵在很大程度上无力应对自身的隐秘部分。无论它如何努力支配、塑造或控制隐秘的部分，由于其迫在眉睫的社会需求和追求，表层心灵最终也只能触及隐秘的皮毛；因此，两者之间存在着裂痕或矛盾。我们试图通过纪律、各种修行、惩罚等等来弥合这道鸿沟，但这终究无法做到。

The conscious mind is occupied with the immediate, the limited present, whereas the unconscious is under the weight of centuries, and cannot be stemmed or turned aside by an immediate necessity. The unconscious has the quality of deep time, and the conscious mind, with its recent culture, cannot deal with it according to its passing urgencies. To eradicate self-contradiction, the superficial mind must understand this fact and be quiescent, which does not mean giving scope to the innumerable urges of the hidden. When there is no resistance between the open and the hidden, then the hidden, because it has the patience of time, will not violate the immediate.

意识专注于当下，专注于有限的此时此地，而无意识则承载着数个世纪的厚重，无法被眼前的需要所压制或忽视。无意识具有深邃时间的特质，而意识凭借其近代的文化熏陶，无法根据自身转瞬即逝的紧迫感来应对它。为了消除自相矛盾，意识必须理解这一事实并保持静默，但这并不意味着要放任潜意识中无数的冲动。当显性与隐性之间没有阻力时，隐性便会因其拥有时间的耐心，而不会违背当下。

The hidden, unexplored, and un-understood mind, with its superficial part which has been “educated,” comes into contact with the challenges and demands of the immediate present. The superficial may respond to the challenge adequately; but because there is a contradiction between the superficial and the hidden, any experience of the superficial only increases the conflict between itself and the hidden. This brings about still further experience, again widening the chasm between the present and the past. The superficial mind, experiencing the outer without understanding the inner, the hidden, only produces deeper and wider conflict.

隐秘的、未被探索的、未被理解的心灵，连同其已被“教育”过的表层部分，共同面对着当下的挑战和需求。表层或许能够对挑战做出恰当的回应；但由于表层与隐秘之间存在矛盾，任何对表层的体验只会加剧表层与隐秘之间的冲突。这又会带来更多的体验，进一步扩大当下与过去之间的鸿沟。表层心灵只体验外在世界而不理解内在的、隐秘的层面，只会造成更深更广的冲突。

Experience does not liberate or enrich the mind, as we generally think it does. As long as experience strengthens the experiencer, there must be conflict. In having experiences, a conditioned mind only strengthens its conditioning, and so perpetuates contradiction and misery. Only for the mind that is capable of understanding the total ways of itself can experiencing be a liberating factor.

经验并不能像我们通常认为的那样解放或丰富心灵。只要经验强化了体验者自身，冲突就必然存在。受制约的心灵在经历各种体验时，只会强化自身的制约，从而使矛盾和痛苦永无止境。只有当心灵能够完全理解自身的运行规律时，经验才能成为一种解放的因素。

Once there is perception and understanding of the power and capacities of the many layers of the hidden, then the details can be looked into wisely and intelligently. What is important is the understanding of the hidden, and not the mere education of the superficial mind to acquire knowledge, however necessary. This understanding of the hidden frees the total mind from conflict, and only then is there intelligence.

一旦感知并理解了隐藏的诸多层面所蕴含的力量和潜能，便能以智慧和理性去探究细节。重要的是理解隐藏的本质，而非仅仅为了获取知识而对肤浅的思维进行教育，即便这些知识再必要也无济于事。这种对隐藏本质的理解能使整个心灵摆脱冲突，唯有如此，智慧方能存在。

We must awaken the full capacity of the superficial mind that lives in everyday activity, and also understand the hidden. In understanding the hidden there is a total living in which self-contradiction, with its alternating sorrow and happiness, ceases. It is essential to be acquainted with the hidden mind and aware of its workings; but it is equally important not to be occupied with it or give it undue significance. It is only when the mind understands the superficial and the hidden that it can go beyond its own limitations and discover that bliss which is not of time.

我们必须唤醒日常生活中表层思维的全部潜能，同时也要理解隐秘的层面。理解隐秘的层面，便能达到一种完整的生活状态，在这种状态下，自我矛盾及其交替出现的悲喜都将消弭。了解隐秘的层面并觉察其运作固然重要，但同样重要的是不要被它所困扰或赋予它过分的重要性。只有当思维理解了表层和隐秘的层面，它才能超越自身的局限，发现那超越时间的极乐。

#↩

FREEDOM FROM THE KNOWN

摆脱已知

1

If you think it is important to know about yourself only because I or someone else has told you it is important, then I am afraid all communication between us comes to an end. But if we agree that it is vital that we understand ourselves completely, then you and I have quite a different relationship, then we can explore together with a happy, careful, and intelligent inquiry.

如果你认为了解自己很重要仅仅是因为我或其他人告诉你这很重要，那么恐怕我们之间的所有交流都将就此结束。但如果我们都认同彻底了解自己至关重要，那么你我之间的关系就截然不同了，我们可以一起愉快、认真、明智地探索自我。

I do not demand your faith; I am not setting myself up as an authority. I have nothing to teach you—no new philosophy, no new system, no new path to reality; there is no path to reality any more than to truth. All authority of any kind, especially in the field of thought and understanding, is the most destructive, evil thing. Leaders destroy the followers and followers destroy the leaders. You have to be your own teacher and your own disciple. You have to question everything that man has accepted as valuable, as necessary.

我并不强求你们的信仰；我并非自封权威。我没有什么可以教给你们的——没有新的哲学，没有新的体系，也没有通往现实的新路径；通往现实的道路并无二致，正如通往真理的道路并无二致。任何形式的权威，尤其是在思想和认知领域，都是最具破坏性、最邪恶的东西。领导者会摧毁追随者，追随者也会摧毁领导者。你们必须成为自己的老师和门徒。你们必须质疑人类所接受的一切，质疑一切被认为是有价值、必要的事物。

If you do not follow somebody you feel very lonely. Be lonely then. Why are you frightened of being alone? Because you are faced with yourself as you are and you find that you are empty, dull, stupid, ugly, guilty, and anxious—a petty, shoddy, secondhand entity. Face the fact; look at it, do not run away from it. The moment you run away fear begins.

如果你不跟随任何人，你会感到非常孤独。那就孤独吧。你为什么害怕独处？因为你会直面真实的自己，发现自己空虚、迟钝、愚蠢、丑陋、充满罪恶感、焦虑不安——一个卑微、粗制滥造、二手货。面对现实吧；正视它，不要逃避。当你逃避的那一刻，恐惧就开始了。

In inquiring into ourselves we are not isolating ourselves from the rest of the world. It is not an unhealthy process. Man throughout the world is caught up in the same daily problems as ourselves, so in inquiring into ourselves we are not being in the least neurotic because there is no difference between the individual and the collective. That is an actual fact. I have created the world as I am. So don’t let us get lost in this battle between the part and the whole.

反思自身并非将我们与世隔绝，也并非有害的过程。全世界的人都和我们一样，每天都面临着同样的问题，因此，反思自身绝非焦虑不安，因为个体与集体之间并无本质区别。这是不争的事实。我创造了我所创造的世界。所以，不要让我们迷失在局部与整体的斗争中。

I must become aware of the total field of my own self, which is the consciousness of the individual and of society. It is only then, when the mind goes beyond this individual and social consciousness, that I can become a light to myself that never goes out.

我必须觉察到自身完整的领域，即个体意识和社会意识。只有当心灵超越这种个体意识和社会意识时，我才能成为自己永不熄灭的明灯。

Now where do we begin to understand ourselves? Here am I, and how am I to study myself, observe myself, see what is actually taking place inside myself? I can observe myself only in relationship because all life is relationship. It is no use sitting in a corner meditating about myself. I cannot exist by myself. I exist only in relationship to people, things, and ideas, and in studying my relationship to outward things and people, as well as to inward things, I begin to understand myself. Every other form of understanding is merely an abstraction and I cannot study myself in abstraction. I am not an abstract entity; therefore, I have to study myself in actuality—as I am, not as I wish to be.

那么，我们该从何处开始了解自己呢？我身处此地，该如何研究自己、观察自己，看清自己内心深处究竟发生了什么？我只能在关系中观察自己，因为生命本身就是关系。独自坐在角落里冥想毫无意义。我无法孤立存在。我唯有与人、物、观念建立关系才能存在，通过研究我与外在事物和人，以及与内在事物的关系，我才能开始了解自己。其他任何形式的理解都只是抽象，而我无法在抽象层面研究自己。我并非抽象实体；因此，我必须在现实中研究自己——如我本来的样子，而非我希望的样子。

Understanding is not an intellectual process. Acquiring knowledge about yourself and learning about yourself are two different things, for the knowledge you accumulate about yourself is always of the past and a mind that is burdened with the past is a sorrowful mind. Learning about yourself is not like learning a language or a technology or a science—then you obviously have to accumulate and remember; it would be absurd to begin all over again—but in the psychological field, learning about yourself is always in the present and knowledge is always in the past, and as most of us live in the past and are satisfied with the past, knowledge becomes extraordinarily important to us. That is why we worship the erudite, the clever, the cunning. But if you are learning all the time, learning every minute, learning by watching and listening, learning by seeing and doing, then you will find that learning is a constant movement without the past.

理解并非一个智力过程。获取关于自身的知识和了解自身是两回事，因为你积累的关于自身的知识总是来自过去，而背负着过去的心灵是痛苦的。了解自身不同于学习语言、技术或科学——在学习语言、技术或科学时，你显然需要积累和记忆；从头再来显然是荒谬的——但在心理学领域，了解自身始终处于当下，而知识始终存在于过去。由于我们大多数人活在过去，并且满足于过去，知识对我们来说变得异常重要。这就是为什么我们崇拜博学之士、聪明之人、足智多谋之人。但是，如果你时刻都在学习，每时每刻都在学习，通过观察、聆听、观察和实践来学习，那么你会发现，学习是一个持续不断的运动，它不再受制于过去。

If you say you will learn gradually about yourself, adding more and more, little by little, you are not studying yourself now as you are but through acquired knowledge. Learning implies a great sensitivity. There is no sensitivity if there is an idea, which is of the past, dominating the present. Then the mind is no longer quick, pliable, alert. Most of us are not sensitive, even physically. We overeat, we do not bother about the right diet, we oversmoke and drink so that our bodies become gross and insensitive; the quality of attention in the organism itself is made dull. How can there be a very alert, sensitive, clear mind if the organism itself is dull and heavy? We may be sensitive about certain things that touch us personally but to be completely sensitive to all the implications of life demands that there be no separation between the organism and the psyche. It is a total movement.

如果你说你会循序渐进地了解自己，一点一点地积累，那么你并非在了解当下的自己，而是在通过后天习得的知识来了解自己。学习意味着高度的敏感。如果一种源于过去的观念主导着当下，那么敏感就会消失。那时，思维便不再敏捷、灵活、警觉。我们大多数人缺乏敏感，甚至在生理层面也是如此。我们暴饮暴食，不注重健康饮食，过度吸烟酗酒，以至于身体变得迟钝麻木；机体本身的注意力也变得迟钝。如果机体本身迟钝沉重，又怎能拥有敏锐、敏感、清晰的头脑呢？我们或许会对某些触动我们内心的事物保持敏感，但要对生活的全部意义都保持完全的敏感，就要求机体与心灵之间没有分离。这是一个整体的运动。

To understand anything you must live with it, you must observe it, you must know all its content, its nature, its structure, its movement. Have you ever tried living with yourself? If so, you will begin to see that your self is not a static state, it is a fresh living thing. And to live with a living thing your mind must also be alive. And it cannot be alive if it is caught in opinions, judgments, and values.

要想理解任何事物，你必须与之共处，观察它，了解它的全部内涵、本质、结构和运行规律。你试过与自己相处吗？如果试过，你就会开始明白，你的自我并非静止不变，而是一个鲜活的生命体。而要与一个鲜活的生命体共处，你的心智也必须充满活力。如果被成见、评判和价值观所束缚，它就无法真正鲜活起来。

In order to observe the movement of your own mind and heart, of your whole being, you must have a free mind, not a mind that agrees and disagrees, taking sides in an argument, disputing over mere words but rather, following with an intention to understand—a very difficult thing to do because most of us don’t know how to look at, or listen to, our own being any more than we know how to look at the beauty of a river or listen to the breeze among the trees.

为了观察你自己的思想和心灵，你整个存在的运动，你必须拥有自由的思想，而不是一个赞同或反对、在争论中站队、为区区字句争论不休的思想，而是带着理解的意图去跟随——这是一件非常困难的事情，因为我们大多数人不知道如何观察或倾听自己的存在，就像我们不知道如何欣赏河流的美丽或倾听树间的微风一样。

When we condemn or justify we cannot see clearly, nor can we when our minds are endlessly chattering; then we do not observe what is , we look only at the projections we have made of ourselves. Each of us has an image of what we think we are or what we should be, and that image, that picture, entirely prevents us from seeing ourselves as we actually are.

当我们谴责或辩解时，我们无法看清真相；当我们的思绪喋喋不休时，我们也无法看清真相；那时，我们观察不到事物的本来面目，而只看到我们自己投射出的形象。我们每个人都对自己是谁或应该成为什么样的人有一个认知，而这个认知，这幅画面，完全阻碍了我们看清真实的自己。

It is one of the most difficult things in the world to look at anything simply. Because our minds are very complex we have lost the quality of simplicity. I don’t mean simplicity in clothes or food, wearing only a loincloth or breaking a record fasting or any of that immature nonsense the saints cultivate, but the simplicity that can look directly at things without fear—that can look at ourselves as we actually are without any distortion, to say when we lie we lie, not cover it up or run away from it.

世上最难的事情之一就是以简单的眼光看待事物。因为我们的思维过于复杂，我们失去了这种简单的品质。我指的并非衣着或饮食上的简单，比如只穿一条缠腰布，或者打破禁食纪录，又或是圣徒们所推崇的那些幼稚的无稽之谈，而是指能够无所畏惧地直视事物——能够毫无扭曲地审视真实的自我，坦诚地说出谎言，而不是掩盖或逃避。

Also in order to understand ourselves we need a great deal of humility. If you start by saying, “I know myself,” you have already stopped learning about yourself; or if you say, “There is nothing much to learn about myself because I am just a bundle of memories, ideas, experiences, and traditions,” then you have also stopped learning about yourself. The moment you have achieved anything you cease to have that quality of innocence and humility; the moment you have a conclusion or start examining from knowledge, you are finished, for then you are translating every living thing in terms of the old, whereas if you have no foothold, if there is no certainty, no achievement, there is freedom—to look, to achieve. And when you look with freedom it is always new. A confident man is a dead human being.

此外，为了更好地了解自己，我们需要极大的谦逊。如果你一开始就说“我了解我自己”，那么你已经停止了对自身的探索；或者如果你说“我没什么可了解的，因为我不过是记忆、观念、经历和传统的集合体”，那么你也停止了对自身的探索。一旦你取得了任何成就，你就失去了那份纯真和谦逊；一旦你得出结论或开始用知识去审视事物，你就已经完成了，因为那时你是在用旧有的视角去解读一切事物。然而，如果你没有立足点，没有确定性，没有成就，你便拥有了自由——去观察，去探索。当你以自由的视角去观察时，一切都是崭新的。一个自信的人，如同行尸走肉。

But how can we be free to look and learn when our minds, from the moment we are born to the moment we die, are shaped by a particular culture in the narrow pattern of the “me”? For centuries we have been conditioned by nationality, caste, class, tradition, religion, language, education, literature, art, custom, convention, propaganda of all kinds, economic pressure, the food we eat, the climate we live in, our family, our friends, our experiences—every influence you can think of—and, therefore, our responses to every problem are conditioned.

但是，当我们从出生到死亡，思想都被特定文化以狭隘的“我”的模式塑造时，我们又如何能自由地观察和学习呢？几个世纪以来，我们一直受到国籍、种姓、阶级、传统、宗教、语言、教育、文学、艺术、习俗、惯例、各种宣传、经济压力、食物、气候、家庭、朋友、经历——你能想到的所有影响因素——的制约，因此，我们对每一个问题的反应都受到制约。

Are you aware that you are conditioned? That is the first thing to ask yourself, not how to be free of your conditioning. You may never be free of it, and if you say, “I must be free of it,” you may fall into another trap of another form of conditioning. So are you aware that you are conditioned? Do you know that even when you look at a tree and say, “That is an oak tree,” or “That is a banyan tree,” the naming of the tree, which is botanical knowledge, has so conditioned your mind that the word comes between you and actually seeing the tree? To come in contact with the tree you have to put your hand on it and the word will not help you to touch it.

你意识到自己受到制约了吗？这才是你应该首先问自己的问题，而不是如何摆脱制约。你可能永远无法摆脱制约，如果你说“我必须摆脱它”，你可能会落入另一种制约的陷阱。所以，你意识到自己受到制约了吗？你知道吗，即使你看着一棵树，说“那是一棵橡树”或“那是一棵榕树”，这种对树的命名——也就是植物学知识——已经深深地制约了你的思维，以至于这个词阻碍了你真正地看到树本身？要真正接触到树，你必须把手放在它上面，而这个词并不能帮助你触摸到它。

How do you know you are conditioned? What tells you? What tells you you are hungry?—not as a theory but the actual fact of hunger? In the same way, how do you discover the actual fact that you are conditioned? Isn’t it by your reaction to a problem, a challenge? You respond to every challenge according to your conditioning and your conditioning, being inadequate, will always react inadequately.

你怎么知道自己受到了某种条件反射的影响？是什么告诉你的？是什么告诉你你饿了？——不是理论层面的饥饿，而是饥饿的真实感受？同样地，你如何发现自己确实受到了某种条件反射的影响？难道不是通过你对问题或挑战的反应吗？你对每一个挑战的反应都取决于你的条件反射，而你的条件反射本身就存在缺陷，所以你的反应也总是会不尽如人意。

When you become aware of it, does this conditioning of race, religion, and culture bring a sense of imprisonment? Take only one form of conditioning, nationality, become seriously, completely aware of it and see whether you enjoy it or rebel against it, and if you rebel against it, whether you want to break through all conditioning. If you are satisfied with your conditioning you will obviously do nothing about it, but if you are not satisfied, when you become aware of it you will realize that you never do anything without it. Never! And, therefore, you are always living in the past with the dead.

当你意识到种族、宗教和文化的制约时，它们是否会让你感到束缚？就拿国籍这种制约形式来说，认真、彻底地去觉察它，看看你是享受它还是反抗它，如果你反抗它，你是否想要突破所有制约。如果你对你的制约感到满意，你显然不会采取任何行动；但如果你不满意，当你意识到这一点时，你会明白你做什么都离不开它。永远离不开！因此，你永远活在过去，与逝者为伍。

You will be able to see for yourself how you are conditioned only when there is a conflict in the continuity of pleasure or the avoidance of pain. If everything is perfectly happy around you, your wife loves you, you love her, you have a nice house, nice children and plenty of money, then you are not aware of your conditioning at all. But when there is a disturbance—when your wife looks at someone else or you lose your money or are threatened with war or any other pain or anxiety—then you know you are conditioned. When you struggle against any kind of disturbance or defend yourself against any outer or inner threat, then you know you are conditioned. And as most of us are disturbed most of the time, either superficially or deeply, that very disturbance indicates that we are conditioned. So long as the animal is petted he reacts nicely, but the moment he is antagonized the whole violence of his nature comes out.

只有当快乐的延续与避免痛苦之间出现冲突时，你才能真正意识到自己是如何被条件反射所束缚的。如果周围的一切都完美无缺：妻子爱你，你也爱她，你们拥有漂亮的房子、可爱的孩子和充足的财富，那么你根本不会意识到自己受到了条件反射的影响。但是，一旦出现干扰——比如妻子看向别人，或者你失去了金钱，或者面临战争的威胁，或者其他任何痛苦或焦虑——你就会明白自己受到了条件反射的束缚。当你与任何干扰作斗争，或者抵御任何外部或内部的威胁时，你就会明白自己受到了条件反射的束缚。而我们大多数人时时刻刻都处于某种程度的干扰之中，无论是表面的还是深层的，这种干扰本身就表明我们受到了条件反射的束缚。就像动物被抚摸时会表现得很温顺，但一旦受到挑衅，它天性中的暴力就会完全暴露出来一样。

We are disturbed about life, politics, the economic situation, the horror, the brutality, the sorrow in the world as well as in ourselves, and from that we realize how terribly narrowly conditioned we are. And what shall we do? Accept that disturbance and live with it as most of us do? Get used to it as one gets used to living with a backache? Put up with it?

我们为生活、政治、经济形势、恐怖、残酷、世间以及自身的悲伤而忧心忡忡，也正因如此，我们才意识到自己是多么狭隘。那么，我们该怎么办？接受这种忧虑，像大多数人一样与之共存？像习惯背痛一样习以为常？忍耐下去？

There is a tendency in all of us to put up with things, to get used to them, to blame them on circumstances. “Ah, if things were right I would be different,” we say, or, “Give me the opportunity and I will fulfill myself,” or, “I am crushed by the injustice of it all,” always blaming our disturbances on others or on our environment or on the economic situation.

我们每个人都有一种倾向，那就是忍受现状，习以为常，并将一切归咎于环境。“唉，如果一切都顺遂，我就会不一样了，”我们会这样说；或者，“给我机会，我就能实现自我，”又或者，“这一切的不公让我感到无比沮丧”，总是把自己的不满归咎于他人、环境或经济状况。

If one gets used to disturbance it means that one’s mind has become dull, just as one can get so used to beauty around one that one no longer notices it. One gets indifferent, hard and callous, and one’s mind becomes duller and duller. If we do not get used to it we try to escape from it by taking some kind of drug, joining a political group, shouting, writing, going to a football match or to a temple or church, or finding some other form of amusement.

如果一个人习惯了扰乱生活，就意味着他的心智变得迟钝，就像一个人会对周围的美景习以为常，以至于不再注意到它们一样。人会变得冷漠、麻木、麻木不仁，心智也变得越来越迟钝。如果我们不习惯扰乱生活，就会试图通过吸毒、加入政治团体、呐喊、写作、去看足球比赛、去寺庙或教堂，或者寻找其他娱乐方式来逃避它。

Why is it that we escape from actual facts? We are afraid of death—I am just taking that as an example—and we invent all kinds of theories, hopes, beliefs, to disguise the fact of death, but the fact is still there. To understand a fact we must look at it, not run away from it. Most of us are afraid of living as well as of dying. We are afraid for our family, afraid of public opinion, of losing our job, our security, and hundreds of other things. The simple fact is that we are afraid, not that we are afraid of this or that. Now why cannot we face that fact?

为什么我们要逃避现实？我们害怕死亡——我只是举个例子——我们编造各种各样的理论、希望和信仰来掩盖死亡的事实，但事实依然存在。要理解一个事实，我们必须正视它，而不是逃避它。我们大多数人既害怕活着，也害怕死亡。我们害怕家人，害怕舆论，害怕失去工作、失去安全感，以及其他数百种东西。事实很简单：我们害怕，而不是害怕这个或那个。那么，为什么我们不能面对这个事实呢？

You can face a fact only in the present and if you never allow it to be present because you are always escaping from it, you can never face it, and because we have cultivated a whole network of escapes we are caught in the habit of escape.

你只能在当下面对事实，如果你因为总是逃避而从不让它摆在眼前，你就永远无法面对它，而且因为我们已经养成了一整套逃避的习惯，所以我们陷入了逃避的习惯中。

Now, if you are at all sensitive, at all serious, you will not only be aware of your conditioning but you will also be aware of the dangers it results in, what brutality and hatred it leads to. Why, then, if you see the danger of your conditioning, don’t you act? Is it because you are lazy, laziness being lack of energy? Yet you will not lack energy if you see an immediate physical danger like a snake in your path, or a precipice, or a fire. Why, then, don’t you act when you see the danger of your conditioning? If you saw the danger of nationalism to your own security, wouldn’t you act?

如果你稍有敏感，稍有严肃，你不仅会意识到自己受到的制约，还会意识到它带来的危险，它会导致怎样的残暴和仇恨。那么，既然你看到了制约的危险，为什么不采取行动呢？是因为你懒惰吗？懒惰意味着缺乏精力。然而，如果你看到迫在眉睫的危险，比如路上的蛇、悬崖或大火，你绝不会缺乏精力。那么，当你看到制约的危险时，为什么不采取行动呢？如果你看到了民族主义对自身安全的威胁，难道你不会采取行动吗？

The answer is you don’t see. Through an intellectual process of analysis you may see that nationalism leads to self-destruction but there is no emotional content in that. Only when there is an emotional content do you become vital.

答案是你看不见。通过理性的分析，你或许会发现民族主义会导致自我毁灭，但这其中缺乏情感成分。只有当情感成分融入其中时，你才能真正感受到生命的意义。

If you see the danger of your conditioning merely as an intellectual concept, you will never do anything about it. In seeing a danger as a mere idea there is conflict between the idea and action and that conflict takes away your energy. It is only when you see the conditioning and the danger of it immediately, and as you would see a precipice, that you act. So seeing is acting.

如果你仅仅把自身习得的危险视为一种理性的概念，你永远不会采取任何行动。把危险仅仅看作一个想法，就会产生想法与行动之间的冲突，而这种冲突会消耗你的精力。只有当你像看到悬崖一样，立刻看清习得的习得及其危险时，你才会采取行动。所以，看清即行动。

Most of us walk through life inattentively, reacting unthinkingly according to the environment in which we have been brought up, and such reactions create only further bondage, further conditioning, but the moment you give your total attention to your conditioning you will see that you are free from the past completely, that it falls away from you naturally.

我们大多数人漫不经心地度过一生，不假思索地根据我们成长的环境做出反应，而这样的反应只会造成更深的束缚，更深的制约。但是，当你全神贯注于你的制约时，你会发现你已经完全摆脱了过去，它会自然而然地从你身边消失。

2

We said in a previous chapter that joy was something entirely different from pleasure, so let us find out what is involved in pleasure and whether it is at all possible to live in a world that does not contain pleasure but a tremendous sense of joy, of bliss.

我们在前一章中说过，快乐与愉悦完全不同，所以让我们来探究一下愉悦包含什么，以及是否有可能生活在一个没有愉悦，却充满巨大快乐、幸福感的世界里。

We are all engaged in the pursuit of pleasure in some form or other—intellectual, sensuous or cultural pleasure, the pleasure of reforming, telling others what to do, of modifying the evils of society, of doing good—the pleasure of greater knowledge, greater physical satisfaction, greater experience, greater understanding of life, all the clever, cunning things of the mind; and the ultimate pleasure is, of course, to have God.

我们都在以某种形式追求快乐——智力上的快乐、感官上的快乐或文化上的快乐，改革的快乐、告诉别人该做什么的快乐、改变社会弊端的快乐、行善的快乐——获得更多知识、更多身体上的满足、更多经验、更深刻地理解生活的快乐，所有聪明狡猾的头脑带来的快乐；当然，最终的快乐是拥有上帝。

Pleasure is the structure of society. From childhood until death we are secretly, cunningly, or obviously pursuing pleasure. So whatever our form of pleasure is, I think we should be very clear about it because it is going to guide and shape our lives. It is, therefore, important for each one of us to investigate closely, hesitantly, and delicately this question of pleasure, for to find pleasure, and then nourish and sustain it, is a basic demand of life and without it existence becomes dull, stupid, lonely, and meaningless.

快乐是社会结构的基石。从孩提时代到死亡，我们都在或隐秘、或狡猾、或公开地追求快乐。因此，无论我们追求的是何种形式的快乐，我认为我们都应该对此有清晰的认识，因为它将指引和塑造我们的人生。所以，对我们每个人来说，认真、谨慎、细致地探究快乐的本质至关重要。因为找到快乐，并滋养和维系它，是生命的基本需求；没有快乐，生命就会变得枯燥乏味、愚昧无知、孤独寂寞、毫无意义。

You may ask why then should life not be guided by pleasure? For the very simple reason that pleasure must bring pain, frustration, sorrow and fear, and, out of fear, violence. If you want to live that way, live that way. Most of the world does anyway, but if you want to be free from sorrow you must understand the whole structure of pleasure.

你或许会问，既然如此，为何人生就不能以享乐为导向呢？原因很简单：享乐必然伴随着痛苦、挫折、悲伤和恐惧，而恐惧又会导致暴力。如果你想那样生活，那就那样生活吧。世界上大多数人的确如此，但如果你想摆脱悲伤，就必须理解享乐的整个结构。

To understand pleasure is not to deny it. We are not condemning it or saying it is right or wrong, but if we pursue it, let us do so with our eyes open, knowing that a mind that is all the time seeking pleasure must inevitably find its shadow, pain. They cannot be separated, although we run after pleasure and try to avoid pain.

理解快乐并非否定它。我们并非谴责它，也并非评判它的对错，但如果我们追求快乐，就应该睁开双眼，因为一味追求快乐的心灵必然会遭遇其阴影——痛苦。快乐与痛苦密不可分，尽管我们追逐快乐，试图逃避痛苦。

Now, why is the mind always demanding pleasure? Why is it that we do noble and ignoble things with the undercurrent of pleasure? Why is it we sacrifice and suffer on the thin thread of pleasure? What is pleasure and how does it come into being? I wonder if any of you have asked yourself these questions and followed the answers to the very end?

那么，为什么人的心总是渴望快乐？为什么我们会在追求快乐的暗流涌动下做出高尚或卑劣的事情？为什么我们会为了那微不足道的快乐而牺牲和承受痛苦？快乐究竟是什么？它又是如何产生的？我想知道，你们当中是否有人曾问过自己这些问题，并追问到底？

Pleasure comes into being through four stages—perception, sensation, contact, and desire. I see a beautiful motorcar, say; then I get a sensation, a reaction, from looking at it; then I touch it or imagine touching it, and then there is the desire to own and show myself off in it. Or I see a lovely cloud, or a mountain clear against the sky, or a leaf that has just come in springtime, or a deep valley full of loveliness and splendor, or a glorious sunset, or a beautiful face, intelligent, alive, not self-conscious and, therefore, no longer beautiful. I look at these things with intense delight and as I observe them there is no observer but only sheer beauty like love. For a moment I am absent with all my problems, anxieties, and miseries—there is only that marvelous thing. I can look at it with joy and the next moment forget it, or else the mind steps in, and then the problem begins; my mind thinks over what it has seen and thinks how beautiful it was; I tell myself I should like to see it again many times. Thought begins to compare, judge, and say “I must have it again tomorrow.” The continuity of an experience that has given delight for a second is sustained by thought.

愉悦的产生要经历四个阶段——感知、感觉、接触和欲望。比如说，我看到一辆漂亮的汽车；然后，看着它，我产生一种感觉，一种反应；接着，我触摸它，或者想象着触摸它；然后，我便产生了拥有它、在它面前炫耀的欲望。又比如，我看到一朵美丽的云，一座映衬着天空的巍峨山峰，一片春天刚刚萌发的嫩叶，一个充满美丽与壮丽的深谷，一场绚丽的日落，或者一张美丽的脸庞，充满智慧，生机勃勃，不拘泥于自我，因此，它不再是单纯的美丽。我带着强烈的喜悦凝视着这些事物，在观察它们的过程中，没有旁观者的存在，只有纯粹的美，如同爱一般。那一刻，我忘却了所有的烦恼、焦虑和痛苦——只有那美好的事物。我可以带着喜悦凝视它，下一刻便将其忘却，或者，我的思绪开始介入，问题也随之而来；我的思绪回味着所见，思考着它是多么美丽；我告诉自己，我应该多次重温那一幕。思绪开始比较、评判，并说：“明天我一定要再看一遍。” 短暂的愉悦体验，竟被思绪维系着，得以延续。

It is the same with sexual desire or any other form of desire. There is nothing wrong with desire. To react is perfectly normal. If you stick a pin in me I shall react unless I am paralyzed. But then thought steps in and chews over the delight and turns it into pleasure. Thought wants to repeat the experience, and the more you repeat, the more mechanical it becomes; the more you think about it, the more strength thought gives to pleasure. So thought creates and sustains pleasure through desire, and gives it continuity; and, therefore, the natural reaction of desire to any beautiful thing is perverted by thought. Thought turns it into a memory and memory is then nourished by thinking about it over and over again.

性欲或其他任何形式的欲望都是如此。欲望本身并没有错。产生反应完全正常。如果你用针扎我，除非我麻痹了，否则我肯定会有反应。但随后，思想介入，反复咀嚼这种愉悦，将其转化为享乐。思想想要重复这种体验，而重复的次数越多，它就越机械化；思考得越多，思想赋予享乐的力量就越强。因此，思想通过欲望创造并维持享乐，并赋予其延续性；所以，欲望对任何美好事物的自然反应都被思想扭曲了。思想将其转化为记忆，而记忆又通过反复思考得到滋养。

Of course, memory has a place at a certain level. In everyday life we could not function at all without it. In its own field it must be efficient, but there is a state of mind where it has very little place. A mind which is not crippled by memory has real freedom.

当然，记忆在某种程度上是重要的。在日常生活中，没有记忆我们根本无法正常运转。在它所处的领域，记忆必须高效，但在某些精神状态下，记忆的作用微乎其微。不受记忆束缚的心灵才拥有真正的自由。

Have you ever noticed that when you respond to something totally, with all your heart, there is very little memory? It is only when you do not respond to a challenge with your whole being that there is a conflict, a struggle, and this brings confusion and pleasure or pain. And the struggle breeds memory. That memory is added to all the time by other memories and it is those memories which respond. Anything that is the result of memory is old and, therefore, never free. There is no such thing as freedom of thought. It is sheer nonsense.

你有没有注意到，当你全心全意地回应某件事时，记忆就很少？只有当你没有全身心地投入到挑战中时，才会产生冲突和挣扎，这会带来困惑、快乐或痛苦。而挣扎本身就会滋生记忆。这些记忆不断地被其他记忆所补充，而正是这些补充的记忆会做出回应。任何由记忆产生的事物都是陈旧的，因此永远无法获得真正的自由。根本不存在所谓的思想自由，那纯粹是无稽之谈。

Thought is never new, for thought is the response of memory, experience, knowledge. Thought, because it is old, makes this thing which you have looked at with delight and felt tremendously for the moment, old. From the old you derive pleasure, never from the new. There is no time in the new.

思想并非全新，因为思想是对记忆、经验和知识的回应。思想，正因为它古老，才使你此刻曾欣喜若狂、感受无比的事物也变得陈旧。快乐源于旧事物，而非新事物。新事物中没有时间的概念。

So if you can look at all things without allowing pleasure to creep in—at a face, a bird, the color of a sari, the beauty of a sheet of water shimmering in the sun, or anything that gives delight—if you can look at it without wanting the experience to be repeated, then there will be no pain, no fear and, therefore, tremendous joy.

所以，如果你能观察万物而不让快乐滋生——观察一张脸、一只鸟、一件纱丽的颜色、阳光下波光粼粼的水面，或者任何能带来愉悦的事物——如果你能观察它们而不想要重复这种体验，那么就不会有痛苦，不会有恐惧，因此，就会有巨大的快乐。

It is the struggle to repeat and perpetuate pleasure which turns it into pain. Watch it in yourself. The very demand for the repetition of pleasure brings about pain, because it is not the same as it was yesterday. You struggle to achieve the same delight, not only to your aesthetic sense but the same inward quality of the mind, and you are hurt and disappointed because it is denied to you.

正是对快乐的执着追求，最终将快乐转化为痛苦。审视一下你自己。对快乐的重复渴望本身就带来了痛苦，因为快乐不再如昨日。你努力追求同样的愉悦，不仅是审美上的满足，更是内心深处的平静，却因为无法如愿而感到痛苦和失望。

Have you observed what happens to you when you are denied a little pleasure? When you don’t get what you want you become anxious, envious, hateful. Have you noticed when you have been denied the pleasure of drinking or smoking or sex or whatever it is, have you noticed what battles you go through? And all that is a form of fear, isn’t it? You are afraid of not getting what you want or of losing what you have. When some particular faith or ideology which you have held for years is shaken or torn away from you by logic or life, aren’t you afraid of standing alone? That belief has for years given you satisfaction and pleasure, and when it is taken away you are left stranded, empty, and the fear remains until you find another form of pleasure, another belief.

你有没有观察过，当你被剥夺了一点快乐时会发生什么？当你得不到想要的东西时，你会变得焦虑、嫉妒、憎恨。你有没有注意到，当你被剥夺了饮酒、吸烟、性爱或其他任何乐趣时，你会经历怎样的挣扎？所有这些都是一种恐惧，不是吗？你害怕得不到想要的，害怕失去已经拥有的。当你多年来坚持的某种信仰或理念被逻辑或生活动摇或摧毁时，你难道不害怕孤独吗？这种信仰多年来带给你满足和快乐，当它被夺走时，你会感到孤立无援、空虚寂寞，而这种恐惧会一直伴随着你，直到你找到另一种快乐，另一种信仰。

It seems to me so simple and because it is so simple we refuse to see its simplicity. We like to complicate everything. When your wife turns away from you, aren’t you jealous? Aren’t you angry? Don’t you hate the man who has attracted her? And what is all that but fear of losing something which has given you a great deal of pleasure, a companionship, a certain quality of assurance and the satisfaction of possession?

在我看来，这似乎很简单，正因为它简单，我们才拒绝承认它的简单。我们总是喜欢把一切都复杂化。当你的妻子离你而去时，你难道不嫉妒吗？你难道不生气吗？你难道不恨那个吸引她的男人吗？这一切难道不都是害怕失去那些曾带给你巨大快乐、陪伴、某种安全感和占有欲的东西吗？

So if you understand that where there is a search for pleasure there must be pain, live that way if you want to, but don’t just slip into it. If you want to end pleasure, though, which is to end pain, you must be totally attentive to the whole structure of pleasure, not cut it out as monks and sannyasis do, never looking at a woman because they think it is a sin and thereby destroying the vitality of their understanding—but seeing the whole meaning and significance of pleasure. Then you will have tremendous joy in life. You cannot think about joy. Joy is an immediate thing and by thinking about it, you turn it into pleasure. Living in the present is the instant perception of beauty and the great delight in it without seeking pleasure from it.

所以，如果你明白追求快乐必然伴随着痛苦，那么如果你愿意，就那样生活，但不要轻易沉溺其中。然而，如果你想终结快乐，也就是终结痛苦，你必须全然关注快乐的整个结构，而不是像僧侣和苦行僧那样将其剔除，他们从不看女人，因为他们认为这是罪过，从而扼杀了他们理解力的活力——而是要看到快乐的完整意义和重要性。那样，你将在生活中获得巨大的喜悦。快乐无法被思考。快乐是即时的，而思考它，就把它变成了快乐。活在当下，就是对美的瞬间感知，以及从中获得的巨大喜悦，而无需从中寻求快乐。

3

Fear, pleasure, sorrow, thought, and violence are all interrelated. Most of us take pleasure in violence, in disliking somebody, hating a particular race or group of people, having antagonistic feelings toward others. But in a state of mind in which all violence has come to an end there is a joy that is very different from the pleasure of violence, with its conflicts, hatreds, and fears.

恐惧、快乐、悲伤、思想和暴力彼此关联。我们大多数人从暴力中获得快感，比如厌恶某人、憎恨某个种族或群体、对他人抱有敌意。但是，在一种所有暴力都已终结的精神状态下，会有一种与暴力带来的快感截然不同的喜悦，这种快感伴随着冲突、仇恨和恐惧。

Can we go to the very root of violence and be free from it? Otherwise we shall live everlastingly in battle with each other. If that is the way you want to live—and apparently most people do—then carry on; if you say, “Well, I’m sorry, violence can never end,” then you and I have no means of communication, you have blocked yourself; but if you say there might be a different way of living, then we shall be able to communicate with each other.

我们能否直击暴力的根源，彻底摆脱它？否则，我们将永远生活在彼此争斗之中。如果你选择这样的生活——显然大多数人都是如此——那就继续吧；如果你说：“唉，很遗憾，暴力永远无法停止”，那么你我之间就失去了沟通的渠道，你把自己封闭了起来；但如果你说或许存在另一种生活方式，那么我们就能彼此交流了。

So let us consider together, those of us who can communicate, whether it is at all possible totally to end every form of violence in ourselves and still live in this monstrously brutal world. I think it is possible. I don’t want to have a breath of hate, jealousy, anxiety, or fear in me. I want to live completely at peace. Which doesn’t mean that I want to die. I want to live on this marvelous earth, so full, so rich, so beautiful. I want to look at the trees, flowers, rivers, meadows, women, boys and girls, and at the same time live completely at peace with myself and with the world. What can I do?

所以，让我们这些能够沟通的人一起思考：是否有可能彻底消除自身一切形式的暴力，同时又能生活在这个残酷无情的世界里？我认为这是可能的。我不想心中残留一丝仇恨、嫉妒、焦虑或恐惧。我渴望完全的平静。但这并不意味着我想死。我渴望生活在这片奇妙的土地上，它如此丰饶、如此美丽。我渴望欣赏树木、花朵、河流、草地、妇女、男孩和女孩，同时与自己和这个世界都保持完全的和平。我能做些什么呢？

If we know how to look at violence, not only outwardly in society—the wars, the riots, the national antagonisms and class conflicts—but also in ourselves, then perhaps we shall be able to go beyond it.

如果我们知道如何看待暴力，不仅要看待社会上的暴力——战争、骚乱、民族对抗和阶级冲突——还要看待我们自身的暴力，那么或许我们就能超越暴力。

Here is a very complex problem. For centuries upon centuries man has been violent; religions have tried to tame him throughout the world and none of them have succeeded. So if we are going into the question we must, it seems to me, be at least very serious about it because it will lead us into quite a different domain, but if we want merely to play with the problem for intellectual entertainment we shall not get very far.

这是一个非常复杂的问题。几个世纪以来，人类一直充满暴力；世界各地的宗教都试图驯服人类，但没有一种成功。因此，如果我们要探讨这个问题，在我看来，至少必须非常认真地对待它，因为它会将我们引向一个截然不同的领域；但如果我们只是想把它当作智力娱乐来玩弄，我们将一事无成。

You may feel that you yourself are very serious about the problem but that as long as so many other people in the world are not serious and are not prepared to do anything about it, what is the good of your doing anything? I don’t care whether they take it seriously or not. I take it seriously, that is enough. I am not my brother’s keeper. I myself, as a human being, feel very strongly about this question of violence and I will see to it that in myself I am not violent, but I cannot tell you or anybody else, “Don’t be violent.” It has no meaning—unless you yourself want it. So if you yourself really want to understand this problem of violence let us continue on our journey of exploration together.

你或许觉得自己对这个问题非常重视，但既然世界上还有那么多人不重视，也不愿为此采取任何行动，那么你做什么又有什么意义呢？我不在乎他们是否认真对待。我认真对待就足够了。我不是我兄弟的守护者。作为一个人，我对暴力问题感触很深，我会努力克制自己，不诉诸暴力，但我不能对你或任何人说“不要暴力”。除非你自己想要暴力，否则这句话毫无意义。所以，如果你真的想了解暴力问题，那就让我们继续携手探索吧。

Is this problem of violence out there or here? Do you want to solve the problem in the outside world or are you questioning violence itself as it is in you? If you are free of violence in yourself the question is, “How am I to live in a world full of violence, acquisitiveness, greed, envy, brutality? Will I not be destroyed?” That is the inevitable question which is invariably asked. When you ask such a question it seems to me you are not actually living peacefully.

暴力问题究竟存在于外部世界还是自身？你是想解决外部世界的暴力问题，还是在质疑自身内在的暴力？如果你内心没有暴力，那么问题就变成了：“我该如何生活在一个充满暴力、贪婪、嫉妒和残暴的世界里？我不会被毁灭吗？”这是一个不可避免的问题，也是人们总是会问到的问题。在我看来，当你问出这样的问题时，你实际上并没有真正地生活在和平之中。

If you live peacefully you will have no problem at all. You may be imprisoned because you refuse to join the army or shot because you refuse to fight—but that is not a problem; you will be shot. It is extraordinarily important to understand this.

只要你安分守己，就不会有任何问题。你可能会因为拒绝参军而被监禁，或者因为拒绝战斗而被枪毙——但这都不是问题；你注定会被枪毙。理解这一点至关重要。

We are trying to understand violence as a fact, not as an idea, as a fact which exists in the human being, and the human being is myself. And to go into the problem I must be completely vulnerable, open, to it. I must expose myself to myself—not necessarily expose myself to you because you may not be interested—but I must be in a state of mind that demands to see this thing right to the end and at no point stops and says I will go no further.

我们试图将暴力理解为一种事实，而非一种观念；理解为存在于人性之中的事实，而这个人就是我自己。要深入探讨这个问题，我必须完全敞开自己，坦诚面对它。我必须直面自己——不一定非要向你敞开自己，因为你可能不感兴趣——但我必须保持一种执着于探究真相的心态，绝不半途而废，绝不放弃。

Now it must be obvious to me that I am a violent human being. I have experienced violence in anger, violence in my sexual demands, violence in hatred, creating enmity, violence in jealousy, and so on. I have experienced it, I have known it, and I say to myself, “I want to understand this whole problem, not just one fragment of it expressed in war, but this aggression in man which also exists in the animals and of which I am a part.”

现在我必须清楚地认识到，我是一个有暴力倾向的人。我体验过愤怒中的暴力、性欲中的暴力、仇恨中的暴力、制造敌意中的暴力、嫉妒中的暴力等等。我经历过，我了解，所以我对自己说：“我想理解整个问题，不仅仅是战争中体现的其中一部分，而是人类身上这种也存在于动物身上、而我自身也是其中一部分的侵略性。”

Violence is not merely killing another. It is violence when we use a sharp word, when we make a gesture to brush away a person, when we obey because there is fear. So violence isn’t merely organized butchery in the name of God, in the name of society or country. Violence is much more subtle, much deeper, and we are inquiring into the very depths of violence.

暴力不仅仅是杀人。当我们恶语相向、做出推搡他人的动作、因恐惧而服从时，暴力也是暴力。因此，暴力不仅仅是以神、以社会或国家之名进行的有组织的屠杀。暴力更加隐蔽、更加深刻，我们正在探究暴力的本质。

When you call yourself an Indian or a Muslim or a Christian or a European, or anything else, you are being violent. Do you see why it is violent? Because you are separating yourself from the rest of mankind. When you separate yourself by belief, by nationality, by tradition, it breeds violence. So a man who is seeking to understand violence does not belong to any country, to any religion, to any political party or partial system; he is concerned with the total understanding of mankind.

当你自称印度人、穆斯林、基督徒、欧洲人或其他任何身份时，你就是在诉诸暴力。你明白为什么这是暴力吗？因为你将自己与全人类隔离开来。当你因信仰、国籍或传统而将自己与他人割裂开来时，暴力便会滋生。因此，一个试图理解暴力的人，不属于任何国家、任何宗教、任何政党或任何局部体制；他关注的是对全人类的全面理解。

Now, there are two primary schools of thought with regard to violence: one which says, “Violence is innate in man” and the other which says, “Violence is the result of the social and cultural heritage in which man lives.” We are not concerned with which school we belong to—it is of no importance. What is important is the fact that we are violent, not the reason for it.

关于暴力，目前主要有两种观点：一种认为“暴力是人类的本性”，另一种认为“暴力是人类所处社会文化环境的产物”。我们并不关心自己属于哪一种观点——这无关紧要。重要的是我们具有暴力倾向，而不是我们暴力的原因。

One of the most common expressions of violence is anger. When my wife or sister is attacked I say I am righteously angry; when my country is attacked, my ideas, my principles, my way of life, I am righteously angry. I am also angry when my habits are attacked or my petty little opinions. When you tread on my toes or insult me I get angry, or if you run away with my wife and I get jealous, that jealousy is called righteous because she is my property. And all this anger is morally justified. But to kill for my country is also justified. So when we are talking about anger, which is a part of violence, do we look at anger in terms of righteous and unrighteous anger according to our own inclinations and environmental drive, or do we see only anger? Is there righteous anger ever? Or is there only anger? There is no good influence or bad influence, only influence, but when you are influenced by something which doesn’t suit me I call it an evil influence. The moment you protect your family, your country, a bit of colored rag called a flag, a belief, an idea, a dogma, the thing that you demand or that you hold, that very protection indicates anger. So can you look at anger without any explanation or justification, without saying, “I must protect my goods,” or “I was right to be angry,” or “How stupid of me to be angry”?

愤怒是暴力最常见的表现形式之一。当我的妻子或姐妹受到攻击时，我会说我义愤填膺；当我的国家、我的理念、我的原则、我的生活方式受到攻击时，我义愤填膺。当我的习惯或一些微不足道的观点受到攻击时，我也会愤怒。当你冒犯我或侮辱我时，我会生气；如果你拐走了我的妻子，我会嫉妒，这种嫉妒也被称为正义的嫉妒，因为她是我的财产。所有这些愤怒在道德上都是正当的。为国杀戮也是正当的。所以，当我们谈论愤怒——它是暴力的一部分——时，我们是否应该根据自身的倾向和环境因素，将愤怒分为正义的愤怒和非正义的愤怒，还是仅仅将其视为愤怒本身？是否存在正义的愤怒？或者说，愤怒仅仅是愤怒？没有好的影响或坏的影响，只有影响，但当你受到某种不适合你的东西的影响时，我会称之为邪恶的影响。当你保护你的家人、你的国家、一块被称为国旗的彩色破布、一种信仰、一种理念、一种教条，或者你所要求或所坚持的东西时，这种保护本身就表明了愤怒。那么，你能不加解释或辩解地看待愤怒吗？你能不说“我必须保护我的东西”、“我生气是对的”或者“我生气真是太愚蠢了”吗？

Can you look at anger as if it were something by itself? Can you look at it completely objectively, which means neither defending it nor condemning it? Can you? Can I look at you if I am antagonistic to you or if I am thinking what a marvelous person you are? I can see you only when I look at you with a certain care in which neither of these things is involved. Now, can I look at anger in the same way, which means that I am vulnerable to the problem, I do not resist it, I am watching this extraordinary phenomenon without any reaction to it?

你能把愤怒当作一件独立存在的东西来看待吗？你能完全客观地看待它吗？既不为它辩护，也不谴责它。你能吗？如果我对你抱有敌意，或者我心里想着你多么了不起，我能看清你吗？只有当我带着某种谨慎的目光注视你时，我才能真正看清你，这种谨慎不掺杂任何负面情绪。那么，我能用同样的方式看待愤怒吗？也就是说，我承认自己容易受到愤怒的影响，但我并不抗拒它，我只是静静地观察着这种非同寻常的现象，不做出任何反应。

It is very difficult to look at anger dispassionately because it is a part of me, but that is what I am trying to do. Here I am, a violent human being, whether I am black, brown, white, or purple. I am not concerned with whether I have inherited this violence or whether society has produced it in me; all I am concerned with is whether it is at all possible to be free from it. To be free from violence means everything to me. It is more important to me than sex, food, position, for this thing is corrupting me. It is destroying me and destroying the world, and I want to understand it, I want to be beyond it. I feel responsible for all this anger and violence in the world. I feel responsible—it isn’t just a lot of words—and I say to myself, “I can do something only if I am beyond anger myself, beyond violence, beyond nationality.” And this feeling I have that I must understand the violence in myself brings tremendous vitality and passion to find out.

冷静地看待愤怒非常困难，因为它是我的一部分，但这正是我努力尝试的。我是一个充满暴力的人，无论我是黑人、棕色人种、白人还是其他肤色。我并不关心这种暴力是遗传的，还是社会造成的；我只关心是否有可能摆脱它。摆脱暴力对我来说意义非凡。它比性、食物、地位都重要，因为暴力正在腐蚀我。它正在摧毁我，也在摧毁这个世界，我想了解它，我想超越它。我感到自己对世间所有的愤怒和暴力负有责任。我感到自己有责任——这并非空谈——我告诉自己：“只有当我超越愤怒、超越暴力、超越国籍时，我才能有所作为。”这种必须理解自身暴力的感觉，为我带来了巨大的活力和热情去探寻。

But to be beyond violence I cannot suppress it, I cannot deny it, I cannot say, “Well, it is a part of me and that’s that,” or “I don’t want it.” I have to look at it, I have to study it, I must become very intimate with it and I cannot become intimate with it if I condemn it or justify it. We do condemn it, though; we do justify it. Therefore, I am saying, stop for the time being condemning it or justifying it.

但要超越暴力，我不能压制它，不能否认它，不能说“好吧，它是我的一部分，就这样吧”，或者“我不想要它”。我必须正视它，我必须研究它，我必须与它建立非常亲密的关系，而如果我谴责它或为它辩解，我就无法与它建立亲密的关系。然而，我们确实在谴责它，也确实在为它辩解。因此，我想说，暂时停止谴责它或为它辩解。

Now, if you want to stop violence, if you want to stop wars, how much vitality, how much of yourself, do you give to it? Isn’t it important to you that your children are killed, that your sons go into the army where they are bullied and butchered? Don’t you care? My God, if that doesn’t interest you, what does? Guarding your money? Having a good time? Taking drugs? Don’t you see that this violence in yourself is destroying your children? Or do you see it only as some abstraction?

现在，如果你想制止暴力，如果你想制止战争，你为此投入了多少精力，多少自我？难道你的孩子被杀害，你的儿子参军在战场上遭受欺凌和屠杀，对你来说就不重要吗？你难道不在乎吗？我的天哪，如果这些都不能让你关心，那还有什么能让你关心？守护你的金钱？寻欢作乐？吸毒？难道你看不出你内心的暴力正在摧毁你的孩子吗？还是你只把它看作某种抽象的概念？

All right then, if you are interested, attend with all your heart and mind to find out. Don’t just sit back and say, “Well, tell us all about it.” I point out to you that you cannot look at anger nor at violence with eyes that condemn or justify, and that if this violence is not a burning problem to you, you cannot put those two things away. So first you have to learn; you have to learn how to look at anger, how to look at your husband, your wife, your children; you have to listen to the politician, you have to learn why you are not objective, why you condemn or justify. You have to learn that you condemn and justify because it is part of the social structure you live in, your conditioning as a German or an Indian or a Negro or an American or whatever you happen to have been born, with all the dulling of the mind that this conditioning results in. To learn, to discover, something fundamental you must have the capacity to go deeply. If you have a blunt instrument, a dull instrument, you cannot go deeply. So what we are doing is sharpening the instrument, which is the mind—the mind which has been made dull by all this justifying and condemning. You can penetrate deeply only if your mind is as sharp as a needle and as strong as a diamond. It is no good just sitting back and asking, “How am I to get such a mind?” You have to want it as you want your next meal, and to have it you must see that what makes your mind dull and stupid is this sense of invulnerability which has built walls round itself and which is part of this condemnation and justification. If the mind can be rid of that, then you can look, study, penetrate, and perhaps come to a state that is totally aware of the whole problem.

好了，如果你感兴趣，就全心全意地来了解。不要只是坐着听，然后说：“好吧，给我们讲讲吧。”我要指出的是，你不能用谴责或辩解的眼光看待愤怒或暴力，如果暴力对你来说不是一个迫切的问题，你就无法摆脱这两种情绪。所以，首先你必须学习；你必须学习如何看待愤怒，如何看待你的丈夫、妻子、孩子；你必须倾听政客的言论，你必须明白为什么你无法客观，为什么你会谴责或辩解。你必须明白，你之所以会谴责和辩解，是因为这是你所处的社会结构的一部分，是你作为德国人、印度人、黑人、美国人或其他任何你出生时的身份所受到的制约，以及这种制约造成的思维迟钝。要学习，要发现一些根本性的东西，你必须具备深入思考的能力。如果你的工具是钝的、迟钝的，你就无法深入思考。所以，我们现在所做的，是磨砺这件工具，也就是我们的心智——这颗因辩解和谴责而变得迟钝的心智。只有当你的心智像针一样锋利、像钻石一样坚韧时，你才能深入洞察。仅仅坐着问“我该如何拥有这样的心智？”是毫无用处的。你必须像渴望下一顿饭一样渴望它，而要拥有它，你必须明白，使你的心智迟钝愚钝的，正是那种自我保护的优越感，它为自己筑起了高墙，而这种优越感本身也是谴责和辩解的一部分。如果心智能够摆脱这种优越感，你就能观察、研究、深入，或许还能达到一种完全觉察整个问题的境界。

So let us come back to the central issue—is it possible to eradicate violence in ourselves? It is a form of violence to say, “You haven’t changed, why haven’t you?” I am not doing that. It doesn’t mean a thing to me to convince you of anything. It is your life, not my life. The way you live is your affair. I am asking whether it is possible for a human being living psychologically in any society to clear violence from himself inwardly? If it is, the very process will produce a different way of living in this world.

所以，让我们回到核心问题——我们是否有可能根除自身内在的暴力？质问“你没变，为什么没变？”本身就是一种暴力。我不会那样做。说服你对我来说毫无意义。这是你的人生，不是我的。你的生活方式是你的事。我问的是，生活在任何社会中的个体，是否有可能在心理上清除自身内在的暴力？如果可以，这个过程本身就会带来一种截然不同的生活方式。

Most of us have accepted violence as a way of life. Two dreadful wars have taught us nothing except to build more and more barriers between human beings, that is, between you and me. But for those of us who want to be rid of violence, how is it to be done? I do not think anything is going to be achieved through analysis, either by ourselves or by a professional. We might be able to modify ourselves slightly, live a little more quietly, with a little more affection, but in itself it will not give total perception. But I must know how to analyze, which means that in the process of analysis my mind becomes extraordinarily sharp, and it is that quality of sharpness, of attention, of seriousness, which will give total perception. One hasn’t the eyes to see the whole thing at a glance; this clarity of the eye is possible only if one can see the details, then jump. Some of us, in order to rid ourselves of violence, have used a concept, an ideal called nonviolence, and we think by having an ideal of the opposite to violence, nonviolence, we can get rid of the fact, the actual—but we cannot. We have had ideals without number, all the sacred books are full of them, yet we are still violent—so why not deal with violence itself and forget the word altogether?

我们大多数人已经接受了暴力作为一种生活方式。两场可怕的战争教会我们的，除了在人与人之间，也就是在你我之间，筑起越来越多的壁垒之外，什么也没有。但对于我们这些想要摆脱暴力的人来说，该如何做到呢？我认为，无论是我们自己还是专业人士，单靠分析都无法取得任何进展。我们或许可以稍微改变自己，生活得更平静一些，更有爱心一些，但这本身并不能带来全面的觉悟。但我必须学会分析，这意味着在分析的过程中，我的思维会变得异常敏锐，而正是这种敏锐、专注和严肃的品质，才能带来全面的觉悟。人不可能一眼看清全局；只有能够看到细节，然后迅速抓住重点，才能拥有这种清晰的洞察力。我们当中有些人为了摆脱暴力，运用了一种名为“非暴力”的概念或理念，我们认为，只要拥有与暴力相反的理想——非暴力——就能摆脱暴力的事实和现实——但这是不可能的。我们拥有无数的理想，所有的圣书都充满了这些理想，然而我们仍然诉诸暴力——那么，为什么不从根本上解决暴力问题，彻底摒弃“暴力”这个词呢？

If you want to understand the actual you must give your whole attention, all your energy, to it. That attention and energy are distracted when you create a fictitious, ideal world. So can you completely banish the ideal? The man who is really serious, with the urge to find out what truth is, what love is, has no concept at all. He lives only in what is .

如果你想理解现实，就必须将全部的注意力、全部的精力都投入其中。当你创造一个虚构的理想世界时，你的注意力和精力就会被分散。那么，你能彻底摒弃理想吗？真正严肃认真、渴望探寻真理和爱的人，其实并没有任何概念。他只活在现实之中。

To investigate the fact of your own anger you must pass no judgment on it, for the moment you conceive of its opposite you condemn it and, therefore, you cannot see it as it is. When you say you dislike or hate someone that is a fact, although it sounds terrible. If you look at it, go into it completely, it ceases, but if you say, “I must not hate; I must have love in my heart,” then you are living in a hypocritical world with double standards. To live completely, fully, in the moment is to live with what is , the actual, without any sense of condemnation or justification—then you understand it so totally that you are finished with it. When you see clearly the problem is solved.

要探究自身愤怒的根源，你必须对它不加评判，因为一旦你设想它的反面，你便会谴责它，因而无法看清它的本来面目。当你表达厌恶或憎恨某人时，这的确是一个事实，尽管听起来很糟糕。如果你正视它，深入其中，它便会消散；但如果你说：“我不能恨；我的心中必须充满爱”，那么你便生活在一个虚伪的世界，充斥着双重标准。全然地、充分地活在当下，意味着与现实同在，不带任何谴责或辩解的意味——如此，你便能彻底理解它，从而彻底摆脱它。当你看清一切，问题便迎刃而解。

But can you see the face of violence clearly—the face of violence not only outside you but inside you, which means that you are totally free from violence because you have not admitted ideology through which to get rid of it? This requires very deep meditation, not just a verbal agreement or disagreement. You have now read a series of statements but have you really understood? Your conditioned mind, your way of life, the whole structure of the society in which you live, prevent you from looking at a fact and being entirely free from it immediately. You say, “I will think about it; I will consider whether it is possible to be free from violence or not. I will try to be free.” That is one of the most dreadful statements you can make, “I will try.” There is no trying, no doing your best. Either you do it or you don’t do it. You are admitting time while the house is burning. The house is burning as a result of the violence throughout the world and in yourself and you say, “Let me think about it. Which ideology is best to put out the fire?” When the house is on fire, do you argue about the color of the hair of the man who brings the water?

但你能否清晰地看到暴力的真面目——不仅在你之外，也在你之内，这意味着你之所以能完全摆脱暴力，是因为你没有接受任何可以摆脱暴力的意识形态？这需要非常深刻的冥想，而不仅仅是口头上的同意或反对。你现在已经读了一系列陈述，但你真的理解了吗？你受制约的思维、你的生活方式、你所生活的整个社会结构，都阻碍你直面事实并立即从中解脱出来。你说：“我会思考；我会考虑是否有可能摆脱暴力。我会努力获得自由。”“我会努力”是你所能说出的最可怕的话之一。没有尝试，没有尽力。要么你做，要么你不做。你一边等待时间，一边眼睁睁地看着房子着火。房子着火是因为世界各地以及你内心的暴力，而你却说：“让我想想。哪种意识形态最适合扑灭这场大火？”房子着火了，你会去争论送水人的头发颜色吗？

4

None of the agonies of suppression, nor the brutal discipline of conforming to a pattern, has led to truth. To come upon truth the mind must be completely free, without a spot of distortion.

压抑的痛苦，以及墨守成规的残酷训练，都无法通往真理。要领悟真理，心灵必须完全自由，不受任何扭曲。

But first let us ask ourselves if we really want to be free.

但首先让我们扪心自问，我们是否真的想要自由。

When we talk of freedom are we talking of complete freedom or of freedom from some inconvenient or unpleasant or undesirable thing? We would like to be free from painful and ugly memories and unhappy experiences but keep our pleasurable, satisfying ideologies, formulas, and relationships. But to keep the one without the other is impossible, for, as we have seen, pleasure is inseparable from pain.

当我们谈论自由时，我们指的是完全的自由，还是摆脱某些不便、不愉快或令人不快的事物的自由？我们渴望摆脱痛苦丑陋的回忆和不愉快的经历，却又想保留那些令人愉悦、满足的理念、模式和人际关系。然而，两者不可分割，因为正如我们所见，快乐与痛苦密不可分。

So it is for each one of us to decide whether or not we want to be completely free. If we say we do, then we must understand the nature and structure of freedom.

所以，是否想要完全的自由，由我们每个人自己决定。如果我们说想要，那么我们就必须理解自由的本质和结构。

Is it freedom when you are free from something—free from pain, free from some kind of anxiety? Or is freedom itself something entirely different? You can be free from jealousy, say, but isn’t that freedom a reaction and, therefore, not freedom at all? You can be free from dogma very easily, by analyzing it, by kicking it out, but the motive for that freedom from dogma has its own reaction because the desire to be free from a dogma may be that it is no longer fashionable or convenient. Or you can be free from nationalism because you believe in internationalism or because you feel it is no longer economically necessary to cling to this silly nationalistic dogma with its flag and all that rubbish. You can easily put that away. Or you may react against some spiritual or political leader who has promised you freedom as a result of discipline or revolt. But has such rationalism, such logical conclusion, anything to do with freedom?

摆脱某种束缚——摆脱痛苦，摆脱焦虑——就是自由吗？或者，自由本身另有玄机？比如说，你可以摆脱嫉妒，但这难道不是一种反抗，因而根本算不上自由吗？你可以轻易地摆脱教条，通过分析它，摒弃它，但这种摆脱教条的动机本身也会带来反抗，因为想要摆脱教条的原因可能是它不再时髦或方便。或者，你可以摆脱民族主义，因为你信仰国际主义，或者因为你觉得在经济上不再有必要坚持这种愚蠢的民族主义教条，以及它的旗帜和所有那些乱七八糟的东西。你可以轻易地抛弃它。或者，你可能会反抗某个精神或政治领袖，他承诺通过纪律或反抗就能给你带来自由。但是，这种理性主义，这种逻辑结论，与自由有任何关系吗？

If you say you are free from something, it is a reaction which will then become another reaction which will bring about another conformity, another form of domination. In this way you can have a chain of reactions and accept each reaction as freedom. But it is not freedom; it is merely a continuity of a modified past, which the mind clings to.

如果你说你摆脱了某种束缚，这本身就是一种反应，而这种反应又会引发另一种反应，最终导致另一种顺从，另一种形式的支配。如此一来，你便会陷入一连串的反应，并将每一次反应都视为自由。但这并非真正的自由；它只不过是对过去某种修正的延续，而你的头脑却执着于此。

The youth of today, like all youth, are in revolt against society, and that is a good thing in itself, but revolt is not freedom because when you revolt it is a reaction and that reaction sets up its own pattern and you get caught in that pattern. You think it is something new. It is not; it is the old in a different mold. Any social or political revolt will inevitably revert to the good old bourgeois mentality.

当今的青年，和所有青年一样，都在反抗社会，这本身是件好事，但反抗并非自由，因为反抗是一种反动，而这种反动会形成自己的模式，最终你会被困其中。你以为这是新的事物，其实不然；它只是旧事物的另一种形式。任何社会或政治反抗最终都必然会回归到旧有的资产阶级思维模式。

Freedom comes only when you see and act, never through revolt. The seeing is the acting and such action is as instantaneous as when you see danger. Then there is no cerebration, no discussion or hesitation; the danger itself compels the act and, therefore, to see is to act and to be free.

自由唯有在觉察并行动时方能获得，绝非通过反抗。觉察即行动，而这种行动如同目睹危险时一般迅捷。那时，无需思考，无需讨论，也无需犹豫；危险本身便会驱使行动，因此，觉察即行动，即获得自由。

Freedom is a state of mind—not freedom from something but a sense of freedom, a freedom to doubt and question everything and, therefore, so intense, active, and vigorous that it throws away every form of dependence, slavery, conformity, and acceptance. Such freedom implies being completely alone. But can the mind brought up in a culture so dependent on environment and its own tendencies ever find that freedom which is complete solitude and in which there is no leadership, no tradition, and no authority?

自由是一种心态——并非摆脱某种束缚，而是一种自由感，一种质疑一切的自由，因此，这种自由如此强烈、活跃、充满活力，以至于它抛弃了一切形式的依赖、奴役、顺从和接受。这样的自由意味着完全的独处。但是，在如此依赖环境和自身倾向的文化中成长起来的心灵，真的能够找到那种完全的孤独，那种没有领导、没有传统、没有权威的自由吗？
