This solitude is an inward state of mind, which is not dependent on any stimulus or any knowledge and is not the result of any experience or conclusion. Most of us, inwardly, are never alone. There is a difference between isolation, cutting oneself off, and aloneness, solitude. We all know what it is to be isolated, building a wall around oneself in order never to be hurt, never to be vulnerable, or cultivating detachment, which is another form of agony, or living in some dreamy ivory tower of ideology. Aloneness is something quite different.

这种独处是一种内在的心境，它不依赖于任何刺激或知识，也不是任何经验或结论的结果。我们大多数人的内心深处其实并不孤单。隔离、自我封闭与独处、独处之间存在着区别。我们都体会过隔离的滋味，在自己周围筑起一道墙，以免受到伤害，以免变得脆弱，或者刻意培养一种超脱感——这本身就是一种痛苦——又或者生活在某种虚幻的象牙塔般的意识形态中。而独处则截然不同。

You are never alone because you are full of all the memories, all the conditioning, all the mutterings of yesterday; your mind is never clear of all the rubbish it has accumulated. To be alone you must die to the past. When you are alone, totally alone, not belonging to any family, any nation, any culture, any particular continent, there is that sense of being an outsider. The man who is completely alone in this way is innocent and it is this innocence that frees the mind from sorrow.

你永远不会感到孤独，因为你的脑海里充满了所有的记忆、所有的习性、所有的昨日低语；你的头脑永远无法摆脱积攒的垃圾。要真正孤独，你必须舍弃过去。当你孤独，彻底孤独，不属于任何家庭、任何国家、任何文化、任何特定的大陆时，你会感受到一种局外人的感觉。以这种方式彻底孤独的人是纯真的，正是这种纯真使心灵摆脱了悲伤。

We carry about with us the burden of what thousands of people have said and the memories of all our misfortunes. To abandon all that totally is to be alone, and the mind that is alone is not only innocent but young—not in time or age, but young, innocent, alive at whatever age—and only such a mind can see that which is truth and that which is not measurable by words.

我们背负着成千上万人的话语和所有不幸的记忆。彻底抛弃这一切，便是孤独；而孤独的心灵不仅纯真，而且年轻——并非指时间或年龄上的衰老，而是指无论身处何种年龄，都保持着年轻、纯真和鲜活的生命力——唯有这样的心灵才能洞悉真理，才能领悟那些无法用言语衡量的事物。

In this solitude you will begin to understand the necessity of living with yourself as you are, not as you think you should be or as you have been. See if you can look at yourself without any tremor, any false modesty, any fear, any justification, or condemnation—just live with yourself as you actually are. It is only when you live with something intimately that you begin to understand it. But the moment you get used to it—get used to your own anxiety or envy or whatever it is—you are no longer living with it. If you live by a river, after a few days you do not hear the sound of the water anymore, or if you have a picture in the room which you see every day you lose it after a week. It is the same with the mountains, the valleys, the trees—the same with your family, your husband, your wife. But to live with something like jealousy, envy, or anxiety you must never get used to it, never accept it. You must care for it as you would care for a newly planted tree, protect it against the sun, against the storm. You must care for it, not condemn it or justify it. Therefore, you begin to love it. When you care for it, you are beginning to love it. It is not that you love being envious or anxious, as so many people do, but rather that you care for watching.

在这份独处中，你会开始明白，与真实的自我相处，而不是以你认为应该成为的样子或过去的自己相处，是多么重要。试着看看你是否能毫无颤抖、毫无虚伪的谦逊、毫无恐惧、毫无辩解或谴责地审视自己——只是坦然地与真实的自我相处。只有当你与某件事物亲密相处时，你才能开始真正理解它。但一旦你习惯了它——习惯了你的焦虑、嫉妒或其他任何负面情绪——你就无法再与它共存。如果你住在河边，几天后你就听不到水声了；如果你房间里有一幅每天都能看到的画，一周后你就会忘记它。山川、山谷、树木也是如此——你的家人、你的丈夫、你的妻子也是如此。但是，要与嫉妒、羡慕或焦虑之类的负面情绪共存，你绝不能习惯它，绝不能接受它。你必须像呵护一棵新栽的树苗一样呵护它，保护它免受烈日暴晒和风雨侵袭。你必须关爱它，而不是谴责它或为它辩解。因此，你便开始爱它。当你关爱它时，你便开始爱它。这并非像许多人那样，让你沉溺于嫉妒或焦虑之中，而是让你乐于观察它。

So can you—can you and I—live with what we actually are, knowing ourselves to be dull, envious, fearful, believing we have tremendous affection when we have not, getting easily hurt, easily flattered, and bored—can we live with all that, neither accepting it nor denying it, but just observing it without becoming morbid, depressed, or elated?

那么，你——你和我——能否接受我们真实的自我，明知自己迟钝、嫉妒、恐惧，自以为拥有巨大的爱而实际上并没有，容易受伤，容易被奉承，容易感到厌倦——我们能否接受这一切，既不接受也不否认，只是观察它而不变得病态、沮丧或欣喜若狂？

Now let us ask ourselves a further question. Is this freedom, this solitude, this coming into contact with the whole structure of what we are in ourselves—is it to be come upon through time? That is, is freedom to be achieved through a gradual process? Obviously not, because as soon as you introduce time you are enslaving yourself more and more. You cannot become free gradually. It is not a matter of time.

现在让我们再问自己一个问题。这种自由，这种独处，这种与我们自身全部结构的接触——是否需要时间才能获得？也就是说，自由是否可以通过渐进的过程实现？显然不是，因为一旦你引入时间的概念，你就是在不断地奴役自己。你不可能逐渐获得自由。这与时间无关。

The next question is, can you become conscious of that freedom?

下一个问题是，你能意识到这种自由吗？

If you say, “I am free,” then you are not free. It is like a man saying, “I am happy.” The moment he says, “I am happy,” he is living in a memory of something that has gone. Freedom can only come about naturally, not through wishing, wanting, longing. Nor will you find it by creating an image of what you think it is. To come upon it the mind has to learn to look at life, which is a vast movement, without the bondage of time, for freedom lies beyond the field of consciousness.

如果你说“我是自由的”，那么你其实并不自由。这就像一个人说“我很快乐”一样。当他说“我很快乐”的那一刻，他其实还活在对逝去事物的回忆中。自由只能自然而然地到来，而不是通过愿望、渴望或期盼。你也无法通过构建自己想象中的自由形象来获得它。要真正领悟自由，心灵必须学会以超越时间束缚的视角去看待生命——生命本身就是一场浩瀚的运动，因为自由存在于意识之外。

5

The demand to be safe in relationship inevitably breeds sorrow and fear. This seeking for security is inviting insecurity. Have you ever found security in any of your relationships? Have you? Most of us want the security of loving and being loved, but is there love when each one of us is seeking his own security, his own particular path? We are not loved because we don’t know how to love.

在关系中寻求安全感，必然会滋生悲伤和恐惧。这种对安全感的追求，反而会招致不安全感。你曾在任何一段关系中找到过安全感吗？真的找到过吗？我们大多数人都渴望爱与被爱带来的安全感，但当我们每个人都在追求自己的安全感，走自己的路时，爱还能存在吗？我们不被爱，是因为我们不知道如何去爱。

What is love? The word is so loaded and corrupted that I hardly like to use it. Everybody talks of love—every magazine and newspaper and every missionary talks everlastingly of love. I love my country, I love my king, I love some book, I love that mountain, I love pleasure, I love my wife, I love God. Is love an idea? If it is, it can be cultivated, nourished, cherished, pushed around, twisted in any way you like. When you say you love God what does it mean? It means that you love a projection of your own imagination, a projection of yourself clothed in certain forms of respectability according to what you think is noble and holy; so to say, “I love God,” is absolute nonsense. When you worship God you are worshiping yourself—and that is not love.

什么是爱？这个词被赋予了太多含义，被扭曲得不堪入目，以至于我几乎不愿使用它。每个人都在谈论爱——每本杂志、每份报纸、每个传教士都在喋喋不休地谈论爱。我爱我的国家，我爱我的国王，我爱某本书，我爱那座山，我爱享乐，我爱我的妻子，我爱上帝。爱是一种观念吗？如果是，它就可以被培养、滋养、珍视、摆布、扭曲，随心所欲。当你声称爱上帝时，这意味着什么？这意味着你爱的是你自己想象的投射，是你自己披上某种体面外衣的投射，而这种体面是按照你认为高尚和神圣的标准来包装的；所以说“我爱上帝”完全是无稽之谈。当你敬拜上帝时，你其实是在敬拜你自己——而那不是爱。

Because we cannot solve this human thing called love we run away into abstractions. Love may be the ultimate solution to all man’s difficulties, problems, and travails, so how are we going to find out what love is? By merely defining it? The church has defined it one way, society another and there are all sorts of deviations and perversions. Adoring someone, sleeping with someone, the emotional exchange, the companionship—is that what we mean by love? That has been the norm, the pattern, and it has become so tremendously personal, sensuous, and limited that religions have declared that love is something much more than this. In what they call human love they see there is pleasure, competition, jealousy, the desire to possess, to hold, to control and to interfere with another’s thinking, and knowing the complexity of all this they say there must be another kind of love: divine, beautiful, untouched, uncorrupted.

因为我们无法解决人类情感中名为“爱”的难题，所以我们转而追求抽象的概念。爱或许是解决人类所有困难、问题和苦难的最终方案，那么我们该如何探寻爱的本质呢？仅仅通过定义它吗？教会对爱有这样的定义，社会又有另一种定义，其中充斥着各种各样的偏差和扭曲。崇拜某人、与某人发生性关系、情感交流、陪伴——这就是我们所说的爱吗？这曾经是常态，是模式，但它变得如此个人化、感官化和局限，以至于宗教宣称爱远不止于此。在他们所谓的“人类之爱”中，他们看到了快乐、竞争、嫉妒、占有欲、控制欲以及干涉他人思想的欲望，他们深知这一切的复杂性，因此认为一定存在另一种爱：神圣的、美好的、纯洁无瑕的、未被玷污的爱。

Throughout the world, so-called holy men have maintained that to look at a woman is something totally wrong: they say you cannot come near to God if you indulge in sex; therefore, they push it aside although they are eaten up with it. But by denying sexuality they put out their eyes and cut out their tongues for they deny the whole beauty of the earth. They have starved their hearts and minds; they are dehydrated human beings; they have banished beauty because beauty is associated with woman.

世界各地，所谓的圣人都认为，看女人是绝对错误的：他们说，沉溺于性欲就无法接近上帝；因此，尽管内心充满欲望，他们却将其拒之门外。然而，否认性欲如同挖眼割舌，因为他们否定了世间一切美好。他们的心灵和思想都已枯竭；他们是脱水的灵魂；他们摒弃了美，因为美与女人息息相关。

Can love be divided into the sacred and the profane, the human and the divine, or is there only love? Is love of the one and not of the many? If I say, “I love you,” does that exclude the love of the other? Is love personal or impersonal? Moral or immoral? Family or nonfamily? If you love mankind can you love the particular? Is love sentiment? Is love emotion? Is love pleasure and desire? All these questions indicate, don’t they, that we have ideas about love, ideas about what it should or should not be, a pattern or a code developed by the culture in which we live.

爱能否被划分为神圣与世俗、人性与神性？或者，爱只有一种？爱是属于一个人的，还是属于所有人的？如果我说“我爱你”，这是否就排除了我对其他人的爱？爱是个人化的还是非个人化的？是道德的还是不道德的？是家庭的还是非家庭的？如果你爱的是全人类，你还能爱具体的个体吗？爱是情感吗？爱是情绪吗？爱是快乐还是欲望？所有这些问题都表明，我们对爱有着各种观念，关于爱应该是什么或不应该是什么，这些观念或模式是由我们所处的文化发展而来的。

So to go into the question of what love is we must first free it from the encrustation of centuries, put away all ideals and ideologies of what it should or should not be. To divide anything into what should be and what is is the most deceptive way of dealing with life.

所以，要探究爱的本质，我们首先必须将其从几个世纪的束缚中解放出来，摒弃所有关于爱应该是什么或不应该是什么的理想和意识形态。将任何事物割裂成“应该是什么”和“是什么”是处理生活最具有欺骗性的方式。

Now how am I going to find out what this flame is which we call love—not how to express it to another but what it means in itself? I will first reject what the church, what society, what my parents and friends, what every person and every book, has said about it because I want to find out for myself what it is. Here is an enormous problem that involves the whole of mankind. There have been a thousand ways of defining it and I myself am caught in some pattern or other according to what I like or enjoy at the moment—so shouldn’t I, in order to understand it, first free myself from my own inclinations and prejudices? I am confused, torn by my own desires, so I say to myself, “First clear up your own confusion. Perhaps you may be able to discover what love is through what it is not.”

现在，我该如何探寻这团我们称之为爱的火焰究竟是什么——不是如何向他人表达爱，而是爱本身的意义？我首先要摒弃教会、社会、父母朋友、所有人以及每本书对爱的诠释，因为我想亲自去发现它究竟是什么。这是一个关乎全人类的巨大难题。关于爱的定义，人们已经提出了无数种，而我自己也常常受困于某种模式，这取决于我当下的喜好——那么，为了真正理解爱，我难道不应该先摆脱自身的倾向和偏见吗？我感到困惑，被自己的欲望撕裂，所以我对自己说：“先理清自己的困惑。或许，你就能通过分辨爱不是什么来发现爱的真谛。”

The government says go and kill for the love of your country. Is that love? Religion says give up sex for the love of God. Is that love? Is love desire? Don’t say no. For most of us it is desire with pleasure, the pleasure that is derived through the senses, through sexual attachment and fulfillment. I am not against sex, but see what is involved in it. What sex gives you momentarily is the total abandonment of yourself, then you are back again with your turmoil, so you want a repetition over and over again of that state in which there is no worry, no problem, no self. You say you love your wife. In that love is involved sexual pleasure, the pleasure of having someone in the house to look after your children, to cook. You depend on her; she has given you her body, her emotions, her encouragement, a certain feeling of security and well-being. Then she turns away from you; she gets bored or goes off with someone else, and your whole emotional balance is destroyed, and this disturbance, which you don’t like, is called jealousy. There is pain in it, anxiety, hate and violence. So what you are really saying is, “As long as you belong to me I love you but the moment you don’t I begin to hate you. As long as I can rely on you to satisfy my demands, sexual and otherwise, I love you, but the moment you cease to supply what I want I don’t like you.” So there is antagonism between you, there is separation, and when you feel separate from another there is no love. But if you can live with your wife without thought creating all these contradictory states, these endless quarrels in yourself, then perhaps—perhaps—you will know what love is. Then you are completely free and so is she, whereas if you depend on her for all your pleasure you are a slave to her. So when one loves there must be freedom, not only from the other person but from oneself.

政府说为了祖国去杀人。那是爱吗？宗教说为了上帝而放弃性欲。那是爱吗？爱就是欲望吗？别说不。对我们大多数人来说，爱是伴随着愉悦的欲望，这种愉悦来自感官，来自性爱的依恋和满足。我并不反对性，但请看清它包含的是什么。性带给你的只是暂时的完全忘我，然后你又回到了内心的挣扎，所以你渴望一次又一次地重复那种没有忧虑、没有烦恼、没有自我的状态。你说你爱你的妻子。这种爱包含着性快感，包含着有人在家照顾孩子、做饭的快感。你依赖她；她给了你她的身体、她的情感、她的鼓励，以及某种安全感和幸福感。然后她离开了你；她感到厌倦，或者和别人在一起，你所有的情感平衡都被打破了，这种你不喜欢的扰乱，就叫做嫉妒。这里面包含着痛苦、焦虑、仇恨和暴力。所以你真正想表达的是：“只要你属于我，我就爱你；但一旦你不属于我，我就开始恨你。只要你能满足我的需求，包括性方面和其他方面，我就爱你；但一旦你无法满足我的需求，我就不喜欢你。”所以你们之间存在着敌意，存在着隔阂，当你感到与对方分离时，爱便不复存在。但如果你能与妻子和平共处，不再让这些矛盾的念头在你心中滋生，不再让你的内心陷入无休止的争吵，那么或许——或许——你就能明白什么是爱。那时，你和她都将获得完全的自由；而如果你依赖她来获得所有快乐，你便成了她的奴隶。所以，爱必须包含自由，不仅是摆脱对方的束缚，更是摆脱自身的束缚。

This belonging to another, being psychologically nourished by another, depending on another—in all this there must always be anxiety, fear, jealousy, guilt; and so long as there is fear there is no love; a mind ridden with sorrow will never know what love is; sentimentality and emotionalism have nothing whatsoever to do with love. And so love is not to do with pleasure and desire.

这种归属感，这种从他人那里获得心理滋养、依赖他人的关系——其中必然伴随着焦虑、恐惧、嫉妒和愧疚；只要恐惧存在，爱便无从谈起；一颗被悲伤折磨的心灵永远不会懂得爱的真谛；感伤和情绪化与爱毫无关系。因此，爱与快乐和欲望无关。

Love is not the product of thought, which is the past. Thought cannot possibly cultivate love. Love is not hedged about and caught in jealousy, for jealousy is of the past. Love is always active, present. It is not “I will love” or “I have loved.” If you know love you will not follow anybody. Love does not obey. When you love there is neither respect nor disrespect.

爱并非思想的产物，思想已成过去。思想无法孕育爱。爱不会被嫉妒所束缚，因为嫉妒已成过去。爱永远是积极的，永远是当下的。它不是“我将要爱”或“我曾经爱过”。如果你懂得爱，你就不会追随任何人。爱不服从。当你爱的时候，既没有尊重，也没有不尊重。

Don’t you know what it means really to love somebody, to love without hate, without jealousy, without anger, without wanting to interfere with what he is doing or thinking, without condemning, without comparing—don’t you know what it means? Where there is love is there comparison? When you love someone with all your heart, with all your mind, with all your body, with your entire being, is there comparison? When you totally abandon yourself to that love there is not the other.

你难道不知道真正爱一个人意味着什么吗？那种不带仇恨、不带嫉妒、不带愤怒、不干涉他所做所想、不带谴责、不带比较的爱——你难道不知道这意味着什么吗？爱在哪里，又怎会有比较呢？当你全心全意、全神贯注、全情投入地爱一个人时，又怎会有比较呢？当你完全沉浸于那份爱中时，便不存在了“他者”。

Does love have responsibility and duty, and will it use those words? When you do something out of duty is there any love in it? In duty there is no love. The structure of duty in which the human being is caught is destroying him. So long as you are compelled to do something because it is your duty you don’t love what you are doing. When there is love there is no duty and no responsibility.

爱是否包含责任和义务？它会使用这些词语吗？当你出于义务去做某事时，其中是否蕴含着爱？义务之中没有爱。人类被困于义务的桎梏中，这正在摧毁他。只要你被迫去做某事，仅仅因为那是你的义务，你就无法真正热爱你所做的事。当爱存在时，便没有义务，也没有责任。

Most parents, unfortunately, think they are responsible for their children and their sense of responsibility takes the form of telling them what they should do and what they should not do, what they should become and what they should not become. The parents want their children to have a secure position in society. What they call responsibility is part of that respectability they worship; and it seems to me that where there is respectability there is no order; they are concerned only with becoming a perfect bourgeois. When they prepare their children to fit into society they are perpetuating war, conflict, and brutality. Do you call that care and love?

不幸的是，大多数父母都认为自己对孩子负有责任，而这种责任感体现在告诉孩子应该做什么、不应该做什么，应该成为什么样的人、不应该成为什么样的人。父母希望孩子在社会上拥有稳固的地位。他们所谓的责任，不过是他们所崇尚的体面的一部分；在我看来，体面之处便没有秩序；他们只关心如何成为一个完美的资产阶级。当他们让孩子适应社会时，他们实际上是在延续战争、冲突和暴行。你管这叫关爱吗？

Really to care is to care as you would for a tree or a plant, watering it, studying its needs, the best soil for it, looking after it with gentleness and tenderness—but when you prepare your children to fit into society you are preparing them to be killed. If you loved your children you would have no war.

真正的关爱，就像对待树木或花草一样，浇水、了解它的需要、选择最适宜的土壤，温柔细心地照料它——但如果你让孩子适应社会，你实际上是在让他们走向死亡。如果你爱你的孩子，就不会有战争。

When you lose someone you love you shed tears; are your tears for yourself or for the one who is dead? Are you crying for yourself or for another? Have you ever cried for another? Have you ever cried for your son who was killed on the battlefield? You have cried, but do those tears come out of self-pity or have you cried because a human being has been killed? If you cry out of self-pity your tears have no meaning because you are concerned about yourself. If you are crying because you are bereft of one in whom you have invested a great deal of affection, it was not really affection. When you cry for your brother who dies, cry for him. It is very easy to cry for yourself because he is gone. Apparently you are crying because your heart is touched, but it is not touched for him, it is only touched by self-pity and self-pity makes you hard, encloses you, makes you dull and stupid.

当你失去挚爱之人时，你会流泪；你的眼泪是为了自己，还是为了逝者？你是在为自己哭泣，还是为他人哭泣？你是否曾为他人哭泣过？你是否曾为战死沙场的儿子哭泣过？你哭过，但这些眼泪是出于自怜，还是因为一个生命的逝去？如果你的眼泪是出于自怜，那么它毫无意义，因为你只关心自己。如果你因为失去一个你倾注了深厚感情的人而哭泣，那并非真正的感情。当你为逝去的兄弟哭泣时，请为他哭泣。很容易因为兄弟的离去而为自己哭泣。表面上，你哭泣是因为你的心被触动了，但那并非为他而动，而是被自怜所触动。自怜会让你变得冷漠、封闭，让你变得麻木、愚钝。

When you cry for yourself, is it love? Crying because you are lonely, because you have been left, because you are no longer powerful—complaining of your lot, your environment—always you in tears? If you understand this, which means to come in contact with it as directly as you would touch a tree or a pillar or a hand, then you will see that sorrow is self-created, sorrow is created by thought, sorrow is the outcome of time. I had my brother three years ago, now he is dead, now I am lonely, aching, there is no one to whom I can look for comfort or companionship, and it brings tears to my eyes.

当你为自己哭泣时，那是爱吗？是因为孤独而哭泣，是因为被抛弃而哭泣，是因为失去了力量而哭泣——抱怨你的命运，你的环境——总是泪流满面？如果你理解了这一点，这意味着像触摸树木、柱子或手一样直接地去感受它，那么你就会明白，悲伤是自我创造的，悲伤是由思想产生的，悲伤是时间的产物。三年前我有了哥哥，现在他去世了，现在我感到孤独、痛苦，没有人可以给我安慰或陪伴，这让我泪流满面。

You can see all this happening inside yourself if you watch it. You can see it fully, completely, in one glance, not take analytical time over it. You can see in a moment the whole structure and nature of this shoddy little thing called “me,” my tears, my family, my nation, my belief, my religion—all that ugliness, it is all inside you. When you see it with your heart, not with your mind, when you see it from the very bottom of your heart, then you have the key that will end sorrow. Sorrow and love cannot go together, but in the Christian world they have idealized suffering, put it on a cross and worshiped it, implying that you can never escape from suffering except through that one particular door, and this is the whole structure of an exploiting religious society.

如果你用心观察，就能看到这一切在你内心深处发生。你只需一眼，就能完整地、彻底地看清它，无需花时间去分析。你只需一瞬间，就能看清这个名为“我”的脆弱小东西的全部结构和本质：我的眼泪、我的家庭、我的国家、我的信仰、我的宗教——所有这些丑陋之处，都存在于你的内心深处。当你用心而非用头脑去看待它，当你从心底深处去看待它，你就掌握了终结悲伤的钥匙。悲伤与爱无法共存，但在基督教世界里，他们却将苦难理想化，将其钉在十字架上并加以崇拜，暗示着除了那扇特定的门之外，你永远无法摆脱苦难。而这正是剥削性宗教社会的整个结构。

So when you ask what love is, you may be too frightened to see the answer. It may mean complete upheaval; it may break up the family; you may discover that you do not love your wife or husband or children—do you?—you may have to shatter the house you have built, you may never go back to the temple.

所以，当你问自己什么是爱时，你可能太害怕面对答案。它可能意味着彻底的颠覆；它可能意味着家庭的破裂；你可能会发现你并不爱你的妻子、丈夫或孩子——你真的爱他们吗？——你可能不得不摧毁你建立的家园，你可能再也回不到圣殿了。

But if you still want to find out, you will see that fear is not love, dependence is not love, jealousy is not love, possessiveness and domination are not love, responsibility and duty are not love, self-pity is not love, the agony of not being loved is not love, love is not the opposite of hate any more than humility is the opposite of vanity. So if you can eliminate all these, not by forcing them but by washing them away as the rain washes the dust of many days from a leaf, then perhaps you will come upon this strange flower, which man always hungers after.

但如果你仍然想探寻答案，你会发现恐惧不是爱，依赖不是爱，嫉妒不是爱，占有欲和控制欲不是爱，责任和义务不是爱，自怜不是爱，不被爱的痛苦也不是爱，爱与恨的反义词并非如谦逊与虚荣的反义词。所以，如果你能消除所有这些，不是强求，而是像雨水洗去树叶上的尘埃那样，将它们自然地洗去，那么或许你就能找到这朵人类一直渴望的奇花。

If you have not got love—not just in little drops but in abundance—if you are not filled with it, the world will go to disaster. You know intellectually that the unity of mankind is essential and that love is the only way, but who is going to teach you how to love? Will any authority, any method, any system, tell you how to love? If anyone tells you, it is not love. Can you say, “I will practice love. I will sit down day after day and think about it. I will practice being kind and gentle and force myself to pay attention to others”? Do you mean to say that you can discipline yourself to love, exercise the will to love? When you exercise discipline and will to love, love goes out of the window. By practicing some method or system of loving you may become extraordinarily clever or more kindly or get into a state of nonviolence, but that has nothing whatsoever to do with love.

如果你没有爱——不是一点点爱，而是满溢的爱——如果你心中没有爱，世界将会走向灾难。你理智上明白人类团结至关重要，爱是唯一的出路，但谁来教你如何去爱呢？任何权威、任何方法、任何体系，会告诉你如何去爱吗？如果有人告诉你，那不是爱。你能说：“我要练习爱。我要日复一日地坐下来思考爱。我要练习善良温柔，强迫自己关注他人”吗？你是说你可以约束自己去爱，锻炼爱的意志吗？当你锻炼约束和爱的意志时，爱就荡然无存了。通过练习某种爱的方法或体系，你或许会变得异常聪明，更加善良，或者达到非暴力的状态，但这与爱毫无关系。

In this torn desert world there is no love because pleasure and desire play the greatest roles, yet without love your daily life has no meaning. And you cannot have love if there is no beauty. Beauty is not something you see—not a beautiful tree, a beautiful picture, a beautiful building, or a beautiful woman. There is beauty only when your heart and mind know what love is. Without love and that sense of beauty there is no virtue, and you know very well that, do what you will—improve society, feed the poor—you will only be creating more mischief, for without love there is only ugliness and poverty in your own heart and mind. But when there is love and beauty, whatever you do is right, whatever you do is in order. If you know how to love, then you can do what you like because it will solve all other problems.

在这个满目疮痍的沙漠世界里，没有爱，因为享乐和欲望占据了主导地位。然而，没有爱，你的日常生活便失去了意义。没有美，你便无法拥有爱。美并非你所见之物——并非美丽的树木、美丽的画作、美丽的建筑或美丽的女子。唯有当你的心灵懂得爱的真谛，美才会存在。没有爱，没有对美的感知，便无从谈起美德。你对此心知肚明，无论你如何努力——改善社会、救济穷人——你只会制造更多的祸患，因为没有爱，你的内心和思想中只有丑陋和贫瘠。但当心中充满爱与美时，你所做的一切都是正确的，一切都是合乎秩序的。如果你懂得如何去爱，你便可以随心所欲，因为爱会解决所有其他问题。

So we reach the point: Can the mind come upon love without discipline, without thought, without enforcement, without any book, any teacher or leader—come upon it as one comes upon a lovely sunset? It seems to me that one thing is absolutely necessary and that is passion without motive—passion that is not the result of some commitment or attachment, passion that is not lust. A man who does not know what passion is will never know love because love can come into being only when there is total self-abandonment.

于是我们来到了这个问题：人的心灵能否在不经约束、不经思考、不经强迫、不借助任何书籍、老师或导师的情况下，自然而然地领悟到爱——就像欣赏美丽的日落一样？在我看来，有一件事是绝对必要的，那就是无动机的激情——并非源于某种承诺或执着，也并非出于欲望的激情。一个不懂得激情为何物的人，永远无法体会到爱，因为爱只有在完全的自我奉献中才能产生。

A mind that is seeking is not a passionate mind and to come upon love without seeking it is the only way to find it—to come upon it unknowingly and not as the result of any effort or experience. Such a love, you will find, is not of time; such a love is both personal and impersonal, is both the one and the many. Like a flower that has perfume, you can smell it or pass it by. That flower is for everybody and for the one who takes trouble to breathe it deeply and look at it with delight. Whether one is very near in the garden or very far away, it is the same to the flower because it is full of that perfume and, therefore, it is sharing with everybody.

一颗苦苦寻觅的心并非一颗充满激情的心，而唯有不经意间邂逅爱，才是找到爱的唯一途径——在不知不觉中，而非出于任何努力或经历。你会发现，这样的爱超越时间；这样的爱既是个人的，又是无形的；既是单一的，又是多元的。如同芬芳的花朵，你可以嗅闻它，也可以视而不见。这朵花属于所有人，也属于那些愿意驻足细细品味、用心欣赏它的人。无论身处花园的近处，还是远在天边，对这朵花而言都是一样的，因为它饱含芬芳，因此，它与所有人分享着这份芬芳。

Love is something that is new, fresh, alive. It has no yesterday and no tomorrow. It is beyond the turmoil of thought. It is only the innocent mind which knows what love is, and the innocent mind can live in the world, which is not innocent. To find this extraordinary thing which man has sought endlessly through sacrifice, through worship, through relationship, through sex, through every form of pleasure and pain, is only possible when thought comes to understand itself and comes naturally to an end. Then love has no opposite, then love has no conflict.

爱是崭新的、鲜活的、充满活力的。它没有昨天，也没有明天。它超越了思绪的纷扰。只有纯洁的心灵才能懂得爱的真谛，而纯洁的心灵才能在这并非纯洁的世界中生存。人类通过牺牲、崇拜、关系、性爱以及各种形式的苦乐，孜孜不倦地追寻着这非凡的事物，而唯有当思想领悟自身，自然而然地止息时，爱才有可能找到它。那时，爱没有对立面，爱没有冲突。

You may ask, “If I find such a love, what happens to my wife, my children, my family? They must have security.” When you put such a question you have never been outside the field of thought, the field of consciousness. When once you have been outside that field you will never ask such a question because then you will know what love is in which there is no thought and, therefore, no time. You may read this mesmerized and enchanted, but actually to go beyond thought and time—which means going beyond sorrow—is to be aware that there is a different dimension called love.

你或许会问：“如果我找到了这样的爱情，我的妻子、孩子、家人怎么办？他们也需要安全感。” 当你提出这样的问题时，你从未真正超越过思维的范畴，超越过意识的范畴。一旦你超越了那个范畴，你就不会再问这样的问题，因为那时你就会明白什么是爱——爱中没有思想，因此也没有时间。你或许会为之着迷，但实际上，超越思想和时间——也就是超越悲伤——意味着意识到存在着一个名为“爱”的全新维度。

But you don’t know how to come to this extraordinary fount, so what do you do? If you don’t know what to do, you do nothing, don’t you? Absolutely nothing. Then inwardly you are completely silent. Do you understand what that means? It means that you are not seeking, not wanting, not pursuing; there is no center at all. Then there is love.

但你不知道如何才能抵达这非凡的源泉，那么你该怎么办呢？如果你不知道该做什么，你就什么也不做，不是吗？什么也不做。然后你的内心就完全寂静无声了。你明白这意味着什么吗？这意味着你不再寻求，不再渴望，不再追求；你心中没有任何中心。然后，爱就存在了。

#↩

KRISHNAMURTI TO HIMSELF

克里希那穆提自述

February 25, 1983

1983年2月25日

There is a tree by the river and we have been watching it day after day for several weeks when the sun is about to rise. As the sun rises slowly over the horizon, over the trees, this particular tree becomes all of a sudden golden. All the leaves are bright with life and as you watch it as the hours pass by, that tree whose name does not matter—what matters is that beautiful tree—an extraordinary quality seems to spread all over the land, over the river. And as the sun rises a little higher the leaves begin to flutter, to dance. And each hour seems to give to that tree a different quality. Before the sun rises it has a somber feeling, quiet, far away, full of dignity. And as the day begins, the leaves with the light on them dance and give it that peculiar feeling that one has of great beauty. By midday its shadow has deepened and you can sit there protected from the sun, never feeling lonely, with the tree as your companion. As you sit there, there is a relationship of deep abiding security and a freedom that only trees can know.

河边有一棵树，几个星期以来，每当太阳即将升起，我们都会守候在它身边。当太阳缓缓升起，越过地平线，掠过树梢，这棵树突然间便染上了一层金色的光辉。所有的叶子都闪耀着勃勃生机，随着时间的流逝，你注视着它，这棵树——它的名字无关紧要——它本身就是一棵美丽的树——一种非凡的特质似乎弥漫在整个土地，流淌在河流之上。随着太阳越升越高，树叶开始摇曳，翩翩起舞。每一刻，这棵树似乎都呈现出不同的面貌。日出之前，它给人一种沉静、宁静、遥远而又充满尊严的感觉。而当白昼来临，阳光洒在树叶上，它们舞动起来，赋予它一种独特的、令人心生敬畏的美感。到了中午，树荫加深，你可以坐在树荫下，躲避烈日，不再感到孤独，因为这棵树就是你的伴侣。当你坐在那里，你会感受到一种深沉而持久的安全感，以及一种只有树木才能体会的自由。

Toward the evening when the western skies are lit up by the setting sun, the tree gradually becomes somber, dark, closing in on itself. The sky has become red, yellow, green, but the tree remains quiet, hidden, and is resting for the night.

傍晚时分，夕阳西下，西方的天空被染得通红，树渐渐变得幽暗，仿佛被黑暗吞噬。天空变幻成红色、黄色和绿色，但树依然静静地隐匿其中，准备迎接夜晚的到来。

If you establish a relationship with it then you have relationship with mankind. You are responsible then for that tree and for the trees of the world. But if you have no relationship with the living things on this earth you may lose whatever relationship you have with humanity, with human beings. We never look deeply into the quality of a tree; we never really touch it, feel its solidity, its rough bark, and hear the sound that is part of the tree. Not the sound of wind through the leaves, not the breeze of a morning that flutters the leaves, but its own sound, the sound of the trunk and the silent sound of the roots. You must be extraordinarily sensitive to hear the sound. This sound is not the noise of the world, not the noise of the chattering of the mind, not the vulgarity of human quarrels and human warfare, but sound as part of the universe.

如果你与树木建立联系，你就与人类建立了联系。你便对这棵树以及世界上所有的树木负有责任。但如果你与地球上的生灵没有联系，你或许会失去与人类、与人性本身的一切联系。我们从未深入探究过树木的本质；我们从未真正触摸过它，感受过它的坚实，它粗糙的树皮，聆听过树木自身的声音。那不是风吹过树叶的声音，不是清晨微风拂过树叶的声音，而是它自身的声音，树干的声响和根系无声的律动。你必须拥有非凡的感知力才能听到这种声音。这声音并非世间的喧嚣，并非思绪纷乱的嘈杂，并非人类争吵和战争的粗俗，而是宇宙本身的声音。

It is odd that we have so little relationship with nature, with the insects and the leaping frog and the owl that hoots among the hills calling for its mate. We never seem to have a feeling for all living things on the earth. If we could establish a deep abiding relationship with nature we would never kill an animal for our appetite, we would never harm, vivisect, a monkey, a dog, a guinea pig for our benefit. We would find other ways to heal our wounds, heal our bodies. But the healing of the mind is something totally different. That healing gradually takes place if you are with nature, with that orange on the tree, and the blade of grass that pushes through the cement, and the hills covered, hidden, by the clouds.

奇怪的是，我们与自然如此疏远，与昆虫、跳跃的青蛙、在山间鸣叫着寻找伴侣的猫头鹰，我们似乎从未对地球上的所有生命产生过任何情感。如果我们能够与自然建立起深厚持久的联系，我们就不会为了满足口腹之欲而杀害动物，也不会为了自身利益而伤害、解剖猴子、狗或豚鼠。我们会找到其他方式来疗愈创伤，治愈身体。但心灵的疗愈则完全不同。当你与自然同在，与树上的橘子、冲破水泥缝隙的草叶、以及被云雾笼罩的山峦相伴时，心灵的疗愈便会逐渐发生。

This is not sentiment or romantic imagination but a reality of a relationship with everything that lives and moves on the earth. Man has killed millions of whales and is still killing them. All that we derive from their slaughter can be had through other means. But apparently man loves to kill things—the fleeting deer, the marvelous gazelle, and the great elephant. We love to kill each other. This killing of other human beings has never stopped throughout the history of man’s life on this earth. If we could, and we must, establish a deep long abiding relationship with nature, with the actual trees, the bushes, the flowers, the grass, and the fast moving clouds, then we would never slaughter another human being for any reason whatsoever. Organized murder is war, and though we demonstrate against a particular war, nuclear, or any other kind of war, we have never demonstrated against war. We have never said that to kill another human being is the greatest sin on earth.

这并非感伤或浪漫的想象，而是我们与地球上所有生命体之间关系的现实。人类已经猎杀了数百万头鲸鱼，而且仍在继续猎杀。我们从鲸鱼身上获取的一切，都可以通过其他途径获得。但显然，人类酷爱杀戮——无论是转瞬即逝的鹿、美丽的瞪羚，还是庞大的大象。我们甚至喜欢互相残杀。纵观人类在地球上的生命史，这种对其他人类的杀戮从未停止过。如果我们能够，而且也必须，与自然——与真正的树木、灌木、花朵、青草以及飞速移动的云朵——建立一种深厚而持久的关系，那么我们就不会出于任何原因而屠杀他人。有组织的谋杀就是战争，尽管我们抗议某场战争，无论是核战争还是其他任何形式的战争，但我们从未真正反对过战争本身。我们从未说过，杀人是世上最大的罪恶。

February 28, 1983

1983年2月28日

Flying at forty-one thousand feet from one continent to another you see nothing but snow, miles of snow; all the mountains and the hills are covered with snow, and the rivers too are frozen. You see them wandering, meandering, all over the land. And far below, the distant farms are covered with ice and snow. It is a long, tiresome flight of eleven hours. The passengers were chattering away. There was a couple behind one and they never stopped talking, never looked at the glory of those marvelous hills and mountains, never looked at the other passengers. Apparently they were absorbed in their own thoughts, in their own problems, in their chatterings. And at last, after a tedious, calm flight, in the dead of winter, you land at the town on the Pacific.

从一个大陆飞到另一个大陆，飞行高度四万一千英尺，映入眼帘的只有雪，绵延数英里的雪；所有的山峦和丘陵都被白雪覆盖，河流也冰封着。你可以看到它们蜿蜒曲折地流淌在大地上。远处的农场也被冰雪覆盖。这是一段漫长而疲惫的十一小时飞行。乘客们叽叽喳喳说个不停。前面有一对夫妇，他们始终喋喋不休，从未欣赏过壮丽的山峦景色，也从未看一眼其他乘客。显然，他们沉浸在自己的思绪、自己的烦恼和自己的闲聊中。最终，在漫长而平静的冬日飞行之后，飞机降落在太平洋沿岸的小镇。

After the noise and the bustle, you leave that ugly, sprawling, vulgar, shouting city and the endless shops selling almost all the same things. You leave all that behind as you go round the coast highway of the blue Pacific, following the seashore, on a beautiful road, wandering through the hills, meeting the sea often; and as you leave the Pacific behind and enter into the country, winding over various small hills, peaceful, quiet, full of that strange dignity of the country, you enter the valley. You have been there for the last sixty years, and each time you are astonished to enter into this valley. It is quiet, almost untouched by man. You enter into this valley, which is almost like a vast cup, a nest. Then you leave the little village and climb to about fourteen hundred feet, passing rows and rows of orange orchards and groves. The air is perfumed with orange blossom. The whole valley is filled with that scent. And the smell of it is in your mind, in your heart, in your whole body. It is the most extraordinary feeling of living in a perfume that will last for about three weeks or more. And there is a quietness in the mountains, a dignity. And each time you look at those hills and the high mountain, which is over six thousand feet, you are really surprised that such a country exists. Each time you come to this quiet, peaceful valley there is a feeling of strange aloofness, of deep silence and the vast spreading of slow time.

喧嚣过后，你离开了那座丑陋、拥挤、庸俗、喧闹的城市，以及那些售卖几乎千篇一律商品的无尽店铺。你沿着蔚蓝太平洋的海岸公路，沿着海岸线，在一条美丽的道路上蜿蜒前行，穿过群山，不时与大海相遇，将这一切都抛在了身后。当你离开太平洋，进入乡村，蜿蜒翻越一座座宁静祥和的小山，感受着乡村特有的庄严，你来到了山谷。过去六十年里，你一直住在这里，每次进入这片山谷，你都会感到无比惊叹。这里静谧安宁，几乎未受人类的侵扰。你走进这片山谷，它宛如一个巨大的杯子，一个温暖的巢穴。然后，你离开小村庄，攀登到大约一千四百英尺的高度，穿过一排排橘子园和橘树林。空气中弥漫着橘花的芬芳。整个山谷都充满了这种香气。这香气萦绕在你的脑海、你的心中、你的全身。这是一种非凡的体验，仿佛置身于一款能持续三周甚至更久的香水之中。山峦间有一种静谧，一种庄严。每次眺望那些山峦，以及那座海拔超过六千英尺的高山，你都会惊叹于世间竟有如此美景。每次来到这片静谧祥和的山谷，都会感受到一种奇异的疏离感，一种深沉的寂静，以及时间仿佛在缓缓流逝的广阔空间里延展。

Man is trying to spoil the valley but it has been preserved. And the mountains that morning were extraordinarily beautiful. You could almost touch them. The majesty, the vast sense of permanency is there in them. And you enter quietly into the house where you have lived for over sixty years and the atmosphere, the air, is, if one can use that word, holy ; you can feel it. You can almost touch it. As it has rained considerably, for it is the rainy season, all the hills and the little folds of the mountain are green, flourishing, full—the earth is smiling with such delight, with some deep quiet understanding of its own existence.

人类试图破坏这片山谷，但它却得以保存。那天早晨的群山美得令人惊叹，仿佛触手可及。它们雄伟壮丽，蕴含着永恒的厚重感。你静静地走进住了六十多年的房子，空气中弥漫着一种神圣的气息，如果可以用这个词的话；你能感受到它，几乎可以触摸到它。正值雨季，雨水充沛，山峦起伏，处处绿意盎然，生机勃勃——大地仿佛在微笑，带着一种对自身存在的深刻而宁静的领悟。

“You have said over and over again that the mind, or if you prefer it, the brain, must be quiet, must empty itself of all the knowledge it has gathered, not only to be free but to comprehend something that is not of time or thought or of any action. You have said this in different ways in most of your talks and I find this awfully difficult, not only to grasp the idea, the depth of it, but the feeling of quiet emptiness, if I can use that word. I never could feel my way into it. I have tried various methods to end the chattering of the mind, the endless occupation with something or other, this very occupation creating its problems. And as one lives one is caught up in all this. This is our daily life, the tedium, the talk that goes on in a family, and if there isn’t talking there is always the television or a book. The mind seems to demand that it should be occupied, that it should move from one thing to another, from knowledge to knowledge, from action to action with the everlasting movement of thought.”

“您曾反复说过，心灵，或者如果您愿意，也可以说是大脑，必须保持平静，必须清空它所积累的所有知识，这不仅是为了获得自由，更是为了理解某种超越时间、超越思想、超越任何行动的事物。您在大多数演讲中都以不同的方式表达过这一点，但我发现这非常难以理解，不仅难以把握其中的理念和深度，也难以体会那种宁静的空虚感——如果我可以用这个词的话。我始终无法真正体会到那种感觉。我尝试过各种方法来结束喋喋不休的思绪，结束对某事无休止的执着，而正是这种执着本身造成了问题。而当我们生活时，我们总是被这一切所困扰。这就是我们的日常生活，单调乏味，家庭中没完没了的谈话，如果没有谈话，那就看电视或读书。心灵似乎要求它必须被占据，必须不断地从一件事跳到另一件事，从一种知识跳到另一种知识，从一个行动跳到另一个行动，永无止境的思维运转。”

As we pointed out, thought cannot be stopped by determination, by a decision of the will, or the urgent pressing desire to enter into that quality of quiet, still emptiness.

正如我们所指出的，思想无法被决心、意志的决定，或者进入那种安静、静谧的空无状态的迫切愿望所阻止。

“I find myself envious for something which I think, which I feel, to be true, which I would like to have, but it has always eluded me, it has always gone beyond my grasp. I have come, as I have often come, to talk with you. Why in my daily life, in my business life, is there not the stability, the endurance, of that quietness? Why isn’t this in my life? I have asked myself what am I to do. I also realize I cannot do much, or I can’t do anything at all about it. But it is there nagging. I can’t leave it alone. If only I could experience it once, then that very memory will nourish me, then that very remembrance will give a significance to a really rather silly life. So I have come to inquire, to probe into this matter: why does the mind—perhaps the word brain may be better—demand that it should be occupied?”

“我发现自己羡慕某种东西，我认为它是真的，我感觉它是真的，我渴望拥有它，但它却总是与我擦肩而过，总是遥不可及。我像往常一样来找你谈谈。为什么在我的日常生活中，在我的事业中，没有那种宁静的稳定和持久？为什么我的生活里没有这种东西？我问过自己，我该怎么办。我也意识到我无能为力，或者说我根本无能为力。但它却一直萦绕在我心头，挥之不去。我无法置之不理。如果我能体验一次，那么那份记忆就能滋养我，那份回忆就能赋予我这略显荒诞的人生以意义。所以我来询问，来探究这个问题：为什么心灵——或许用‘大脑’这个词更贴切——总是渴望被占据？”

March 10, 1983

1983年3月10日

The other day as one was walking along a secluded wooded lane far from the noise and the brutality and the vulgarity of civilization, right away from everything that was put together by man, there was a sense of great quietness, enveloping all things—serene, distant, and full of the sound of the earth. As you walked along quietly, not disturbing the things of the earth around you, the bushes, the trees, the crickets, and the birds, suddenly round a bend there were two small creatures quarreling with each other, fighting in their small way. One was trying to drive off the other. The other was intruding, trying to get into the other’s little hole, and the owner was fighting it off. Presently the owner won and the other ran off. Again there was quietness, a sense of deep solitude. And as you looked up, the path climbed high into the mountains, the waterfall was gently murmuring down the side of the path; there was great beauty and infinite dignity, not the dignity achieved by man that seems so vain and arrogant. The little creature had identified itself with its home, as we human beings do. We are always trying to identify ourselves with our race, with our culture, with those things which we believe in, with some mystical figure, or some savior, some kind of super authority. Identifying with something seems to be the nature of man. Probably we have derived this feeling from that little animal.

前些日子，我沿着一条僻静的林间小路漫步，远离文明的喧嚣、粗暴和庸俗，远离一切人为的痕迹。一种巨大的静谧笼罩着万物——宁静、遥远，充满了大地的声音。我静静地走着，不去惊扰周围的一切，灌木、树木、蟋蟀和鸟儿。突然，转过一个弯，我看到两只小动物在争吵，用它们的方式打闹。一只试图赶走另一只，另一只则试图闯入它的洞穴，而洞穴的主人正在奋力抵抗。最终，主人赢了，另一只逃走了。周围再次陷入静谧，一种深深的孤独感油然而生。我抬头望去，只见小路蜿蜒而上，通往高山，瀑布在路边轻柔地流淌。那里有伟大的美丽和无限的尊严，并非人类所追求的那种虚荣傲慢的尊严。这小家伙像我们人类一样，将自己与家园融为一体。我们总是试图将自己与种族、文化、信仰、神秘人物、救世主或某种至高无上的权威联系起来。认同似乎是人类的本性。或许，我们正是从这只小动物身上汲取了这种情感。

One wonders why this craving, longing, for identification exists. One can understand the identification with one’s physical needs, the necessary things—clothes, food, shelter, and so on. But inwardly, inside the skin as it were, we try to identify ourselves with the past, with tradition, with some fanciful romantic image, a symbol much cherished. And surely in this identification there is a sense of security, safety, a sense of being owned and of possessing. This gives great comfort. One takes comfort, security, in any form of illusion. And man apparently needs many illusions.

人们不禁会问，这种对认同的渴望和渴求究竟为何存在？我们可以理解对自身生理需求的认同，对衣食住行等必需品的认同。但在内心深处，仿佛是潜藏在皮囊之下，我们试图将自己与过去、传统、某种浪漫的幻想形象、某种珍视的象征认同起来。这种认同无疑会带来安全感、归属感，以及被拥有和被占有的感觉。这能带来极大的慰藉。人们会从任何形式的幻象中寻求慰藉和安全感。而人类显然需要许多幻象。

In the distance there is the hoot of an owl and there is a deep-throated reply from the other side of the valley. It is still dawn. The noise of the day has not begun and everything is quiet. There is something strange and holy where the sun arises. There is a prayer, a chant to the dawn, to that strange quiet light. That early morning, the light was subdued, there was no breeze and all the vegetation, the trees, the bushes, were quiet, still, waiting. Waiting for the sun to arise. And perhaps the sun would not come up for another half hour or so, and the dawn was slowly covering the earth with a strange stillness.

远处传来猫头鹰的鸣叫，山谷另一边传来低沉的回应。天还亮着，白昼的喧嚣尚未开始，万物静谧。太阳升起的地方，有一种奇异而神圣的气息。那是献给黎明、献给那奇异静谧之光的祈祷，吟唱。清晨，光线柔和，没有一丝微风，所有的植物、树木、灌木都静静地、静止着，等待着。等待着太阳升起。或许还要过半个小时太阳才会升起，黎明正缓缓地将大地笼罩在一种奇异的静谧之中。

Gradually, slowly, the topmost mountain was getting brighter and the sun was touching it, golden, clear, and the snow was pure, untouched by the light of day.

渐渐地，最高峰变得越来越亮，阳光洒在它身上，金灿灿的，清澈明亮，积雪纯净无瑕，没有被白昼的阳光染到。

As you climbed, leaving the little village paths down below, the noise of the earth—the crickets, the quails and other birds began their morning song, their chant, their rich worship of the day. And as the sun arose you were part of that light and had left behind everything that thought had put together. You completely forgot yourself. The psyche was empty of its struggles and its pains. And as you walked, climbed, there was no sense of separateness, no sense of being even a human being.

当你攀登，离开山下的小村庄小径，大地的声音——蟋蟀、鹌鹑和其他鸟儿开始晨鸣，吟唱着，用它们丰富的生命之歌赞颂着新的一天。当太阳升起，你融入那光芒之中，忘却了所有思绪的束缚。你彻底忘却了自我。心灵的挣扎与痛苦都已消散。当你行走，当你攀登，你不再感到疏离，甚至不再觉得自己是个人。

The morning mist was gathering slowly in the valley, and that mist was you, getting more and more thick, more and more into the fancy, the romance, the idiocy of one’s own life. And after a long period of time you came down, There was the murmur of the wind, insects, the calls of many birds. And as you came down the mist was disappearing. There were streets, shops, and the glory of the dawn was fast fading away. And you began your daily routine, caught in the habit of work, the contentions between man and man, the divisions of identification, the division of ideologies, the preparations for wars, your own inward pain, and the everlasting sorrow of man.

清晨的薄雾在山谷中缓缓聚集，而那薄雾就是你，越来越浓，越来越沉浸于幻想、浪漫和自身生活的愚昧之中。过了许久，你终于落了下来，耳边传来风的低语、昆虫的鸣叫和各种鸟儿的啼鸣。随着你的落下，薄雾渐渐消散。街道、店铺映入眼帘，黎明的光辉也迅速消逝。你开始了日复一日的例行公事，陷入工作的习惯、人与人之间的争斗、身份认同的分裂、意识形态的分歧、战争的准备、你内心的痛苦以及人类永恒的悲伤之中。

March 18, 1983

1983年3月18日

At the bird feeder there were a dozen or more birds chirping away, pecking at the grains, struggling, fighting each other, and when another big bird came they all fluttered away. When the big bird left again they all came back, chattering, quarreling, chirping, making quite a lot of noise. Presently a cat went by and there was a flurry, a screeching and a great to-do. The cat was chased away—it was one of those wild cats, not a pet cat; there are a great many of those wild ones around here of different sizes, shapes, and colors. At the feeder all day long there were birds, little ones and big ones, and then a blue jay came scolding everybody, the whole universe, and chased the other birds away—or rather, they left when it came. They were very watchful for cats. And as the evening drew close all the birds went away and there was silence, quiet, peaceful. The cats came and went, but there were no birds.

鸟食槽边，十几只鸟叽叽喳喳地叫着，啄食着谷粒，争抢着，互相打闹。这时，一只大鸟飞来，它们全都飞走了。大鸟再次飞走后，鸟儿们又飞了回来，叽叽喳喳地叫着，吵吵嚷嚷，热闹非凡。过了一会儿，一只猫走了过来，顿时一片混乱，尖叫声此起彼伏，一片喧闹。猫被赶走了——那是一只野猫，不是家猫；这附近有很多野猫，大小、形状、颜色各异。鸟食槽边整天都有鸟儿，有大有小，后来一只蓝松鸦飞来，仿佛在斥责所有鸟儿，仿佛在斥责整个宇宙，把其他的鸟儿都赶走了——或者更确切地说，是它一来，其他的鸟儿就都飞走了。它们对猫非常警惕。夜幕降临，所有的鸟儿都飞走了，周围一片寂静，安静祥和。猫来来往往，但鸟儿却不见了踪影。

That morning the clouds were full of light and there was promise in the air of more rain. For the past few weeks it had been raining. There is an artificial lake and the waters were right to the top. All the green leaves and the shrubs and the tall trees were waiting for the sun, which hadn’t appeared bright as the Californian sun is; it had not shown its face for many a day.

那天早晨，云层透着光亮，空气中弥漫着即将下雨的气息。过去几周一直都在下雨。这里有一个人工湖，湖水已经漫过湖面。所有的绿叶、灌木和高大的树木都在等待着阳光，但阳光并不像加州的阳光那样灿烂；它已经好几天没有露面了。

One wonders what is the future of mankind, the future of all those children you see shouting, playing—such happy, gentle, nice faces—what is their future? The future is what we are now. This has been so historically for many thousands of years—the living and dying, and all the travail of our lives. We don’t seem to pay much attention to the future. You see on television endless entertainment from morning until late in the night, except for one or two channels, but they are very brief and not too serious. The children are entertained. The commercials all sustain the feeling that you are being entertained. And this is happening practically all over the world. What will be the future of these children? There is the entertainment of sport—thirty, forty thousand people watching a few people in the arena and shouting themselves hoarse. And you also go and watch some ceremony being performed in a great cathedral, some ritual, and that too is a form of entertainment, only you call that holy, religious, but it is still an entertainment—a sentimental, romantic experience, a sensation of religiosity. Watching all this in different parts of the world, watching the mind being occupied with amusement, entertainment, sport, one must inevitably ask, if one is in any way concerned: What is the future? More of the same in different forms? A variety of amusements?

人们不禁会想，人类的未来会怎样？那些欢呼雀跃、嬉戏玩耍的孩子们——他们脸上洋溢着快乐、温柔、美好的笑容——他们的未来又会怎样？未来就是我们现在的状态。数千年来，历史一直如此——生与死，以及我们人生中的所有苦难。我们似乎对未来漠不关心。电视上从早到晚播放着无休止的娱乐节目，除了少数一两个频道之外，其他频道的内容都很简短，也不太严肃。孩子们在娱乐。广告也都在强化这种娱乐的感觉。这种情况几乎遍及世界各地。这些孩子的未来又会怎样？体育赛事也是一种娱乐——三四万人围观赛场上寥寥几人，呐喊到嗓子都哑了。你还可以去大教堂观看一些仪式，一些宗教仪式，那也是一种娱乐，只不过你称之为神圣的、宗教的，但它仍然是一种娱乐——一种感伤的、浪漫的体验，一种宗教情怀。看到世界各地人们沉迷于娱乐、消遣和运动，任何关心未来的人都不得不问：未来会怎样？是换汤不换药，还是丰富多彩的娱乐方式？

So you have to consider, if you are at all aware of what is happening to you, how the worlds of entertainment and sport are capturing your mind, shaping your life. Where is all this leading to? Or perhaps you are not concerned at all? You probably don’t care about tomorrow. Probably you haven’t given it thought, or, if you have, you may say it is too complex, too frightening, too dangerous to think of the coming years—not of your particular old age but of the destiny, if we can use that word, the result, of our present way of life, filled with all kinds of romantic, emotional, sentimental feelings and pursuits, and the whole world of entertainment impinging on your mind. If you are at all aware of all this, what is the future of mankind?

所以，如果你对自身正在发生的事情有所察觉，就必须思考一下，娱乐和体育的世界是如何占据你的思想，塑造你的生活的。这一切最终会走向何方？或许你对此毫不在意？你可能根本不在乎明天。或许你从未想过这个问题，或者，即使想过，你也会觉得未来太过复杂、太过可怕、太过危险——并非指你个人的晚年，而是指我们当下的生活方式的最终结果，如果我们可以用这个词的话。这种生活方式充满了各种浪漫、感性、伤感的情感和追求，整个娱乐世界都在侵蚀着我们的思想。如果你对这一切有所察觉，那么人类的未来究竟会是什么样呢？

As we said earlier, the future is what you are now. If there is no change, not superficial adaptations, superficial adjustments to any pattern—political, religious, or social—but the change that is far deeper, demanding your attention, your care, your affection—if there is not a fundamental change, then the future is what we are doing every day of our life in the present. Change is rather a difficult word. Change to what? Change to another pattern? To another concept? To another political or religious system? Change from this to that? That is still within the realm, or within the field of what is . Change to that is projected by thought, formulated by thought, materialistically determined.

正如我们之前所说，未来就是你现在的样子。如果没有改变，不是对任何模式——政治、宗教或社会——进行肤浅的适应或调整，而是更深层次的、需要你关注、关心和投入的改变——如果没有根本性的改变，那么未来就是我们当下每天的所作所为。改变是一个相当难以捉摸的词。改变成什么？改变成另一种模式？另一种概念？另一种政治或宗教体系？从这个改变成那个？这些仍然在“存在”的范畴之内。而改变成那个则是由思想投射、由思想构建、由物质决定的。

So one must inquire carefully into this word change . Is there a change if there is a motive? Is there a change if there is a particular direction, a particular end, a conclusion that seems sane, rational? Or perhaps a better phrase is “the ending of what is .” The ending, not the movement of what is to “what should be.” That is not change. But if the ending has a motive, a purpose, is a matter of decision, then it is merely a change from this to that. The word decision implies the action of will: “I will do this; I won’t do that.” When desire enters into the act of the ending, that desire becomes the cause of ending. Where there is a cause there is a motive and so there is no real ending at all.

因此，我们必须仔细探究这种“变化”的本质。如果存在动机，这算得上变化吗？如果存在特定的方向、特定的目标、看似合理公正的结论，这算得上变化吗？或许更恰当的说法是“现状的终结”。这里指的是终结，而非现状向“应然”的转变。后者并非变化。但如果终结带有动机、目的，是某种决定的结果，那么它仅仅是从“此”到“彼”的转变。“决定”一词蕴含着意志的行动：“我将做这件事；我不会做那件事。”当欲望介入终结的行为时，这种欲望便成为终结的原因。有原因之处，必有动机，因此根本谈不上真正的终结。

The twentieth century has had a tremendous lot of changes produced by two devastating wars, and the dialectical materialism, and the skepticism of religious beliefs, activities, and rituals, and so on, apart from the technological world, which has brought about a great many changes, and there will be further changes when the computer is fully developed—you are just at the beginning of it. Then when the computer takes over, what is going to happen to our human minds? That is a different question, which we should go into another time.

二十世纪经历了翻天覆地的变化，这不仅源于两场毁灭性的战争，还源于辩证唯物主义、对宗教信仰、活动和仪式的怀疑等等。科技世界也带来了诸多变革，而随着计算机的全面发展，未来还将出现更多变革——我们现在还只是计算机发展的开端。那么，当计算机最终取代人类思维时，我们的思维将会发生怎样的变化呢？这是一个不同的问题，我们以后再来探讨。

When the industry of entertainment takes over, as it is gradually doing now, when the young people, the students, the children, are constantly instigated to pleasure, to fancy, to romantic sensuality, the words restraint and austerity are pushed away, never even given a thought. The austerity of the monks, the sannyasis , who deny the world, who clothe their bodies with some kind of uniform or just a cloth—this denial of the material world is surely not austerity. You probably won’t even listen to this, to what the implications of austerity are. When you have been brought up from childhood to amuse yourself and escape from yourself through entertainment, religious or otherwise, and when most of the psychologists say that you must express everything you feel and that any form of holding back or restraint is detrimental, leading to various forms of neuroticism, you naturally enter more and more into the world of sport, amusement, entertainment, all helping you to escape from yourself, from what you are.

当娱乐产业占据主导地位时——就像现在这样——当年轻人、学生、孩子们不断被诱导去追求享乐、幻想和浪漫的感官享受时，“克制”和“节制”这两个词就被抛诸脑后，甚至从未被考虑过。僧侣、苦行僧的节制，他们否定世俗，用某种制服或仅仅一块布遮蔽身体——这种对物质世界的否定当然不是节制。你可能根本不会听进去，也不会去思考节制的含义。当你从小就被教育要通过娱乐（无论是宗教的还是其他的）来消遣和逃避自我，当大多数心理学家都说你必须表达你所有的感受，任何形式的压抑或克制都是有害的，会导致各种形式的神经质时，你自然而然地会越来越沉迷于运动、娱乐和消遣的世界，所有这些都在帮助你逃避自我，逃避真实的自己。

The understanding of the nature of what you are, without any distortions, without any bias, without any reactions to what you discover you are, is the beginning of austerity. The watching, the awareness, of every thought, every feeling, not to restrain it, not to control it, but to watch it, like watching a bird in flight, without any of your own prejudices and distortions—that watching brings about an extraordinary sense of austerity that goes beyond all restraint, all the fooling around with oneself and all this idea of self-improvement, self-fulfillment. That is all rather childish. In this watching there is great freedom and in that freedom there is the sense of the dignity of austerity. But if you said all this to a modern group of students or children, they would probably look out of the window in boredom because this world is bent on its own pursuit of pleasure.

理解你自身的本质，不带任何扭曲，不带任何偏见，不对你发现的自我做出任何反应，这便是苦行的开端。观察、觉察每一个念头、每一种感受，并非为了抑制它们，也并非为了控制它们，而是像观察飞鸟一样观察它们，不带任何你自身的偏见和扭曲——这种观察会带来一种非凡的苦行感，超越一切束缚，超越一切自我玩弄，超越一切自我提升、自我实现的观念。那些都显得幼稚。在这种观察中蕴藏着巨大的自由，而在这份自由中，蕴藏着苦行的尊严。但如果你把这一切告诉一群现代学生或孩子，他们很可能会无聊地望着窗外，因为这个世界一心追求享乐。

A large, fawn-colored squirrel came down the tree and went up to the feeder, nibbled at a few grains, sat there on top of it, looked around with its large beady eyes, its tail up, curved, a marvelous thing. It sat there for a moment or so, came down, went along the few rocks and then dashed to the tree and up and disappeared.

一只体型较大的、毛色呈淡褐色的松鼠从树上下来，走到喂食器前，啃了几粒谷物，然后坐在上面，用它那双珠子般的大眼睛四处张望，尾巴高高翘起，弯曲着，真是个奇妙的景象。它在那儿待了一会儿，然后下来，沿着几块石头走了一段，接着又飞快地跑回树上，消失不见了。

It appears that man has always escaped from himself, from what he is, from where he is going, from what all this is about—the universe, our daily life, the dying and the beginning. It is strange that we never realize that however much we may escape from ourselves, however much we may wander away—consciously, deliberately, or unconsciously, subtly—the conflict, the pleasure, the pain, the fear, and so on, are always there. They ultimately dominate. You may try to suppress them, you may try to put them away deliberately with an act of will but they surface again. And pleasure is one of the factors that predominates; it too has the same conflicts, the same pain, the same boredom. The weariness of pleasure and the fret are part of this turmoil of our life. You can’t escape it, my friend. You can’t escape from this deep unfathomed turmoil unless you really give thought to it, not only thought but see by careful attention, diligent watching, the whole movement of thought and the self. You may say all this is too tiresome, perhaps unnecessary. But if you do not pay attention to this, give heed, the future is not only going to be more destructive, more intolerable, but without much significance. All this is not a dampening, depressing point of view; it is actually so. What you are now is what you will be in the coming days. You can’t avoid it. It is as definite as the sun rising and setting. This is the share of all man, of all humanity, unless we all change, each one of us, change to something that is not projected by thought.

似乎人类总是在逃避自我，逃避自己的本质，逃避自己的归宿，逃避这一切的意义——宇宙、日常生活、生死轮回。奇怪的是，我们从未意识到，无论我们如何逃避自我，无论我们如何游离——无论是有意识的、刻意的，还是无意识的、微妙的——冲突、快乐、痛苦、恐惧等等，始终存在。它们最终会占据主导地位。你或许试图压制它们，或许试图用意志力刻意将它们抛诸脑后，但它们终究会再次浮现。而快乐正是其中占据主导地位的因素之一；它也同样充满冲突、痛苦和厌倦。对快乐的厌倦和焦虑，正是我们人生动荡的一部分。朋友，你无法逃避。除非你真正思考它，不仅要思考，更要通过细致的观察和勤勉的洞察，去理解思想和自我的整个运动过程，否则你无法逃离这深不可测的动荡。你或许会说这一切太过繁琐，甚至毫无必要。但如果你对此置若罔闻，不加重视，未来不仅会更加充满破坏性，更加难以忍受，而且毫无意义。这并非危言耸听，而是事实。你现在的样子，就是你未来的样子。你无法逃避。这就像太阳升起落下一样确定无疑。除非我们每个人都做出改变，变成某种并非由思想投射出来的存在，否则这就是所有人，全人类的宿命。

May 9, 1983

1983年5月9日

You are already fairly high up, looking down into the valley, and if you climb a mile or more up and up the winding path, passing all kinds of vegetation—live oaks, sage, poison oak—and past a stream that is always dry in the summer, you can see the blue sea far away in the distance, across range after range. Up here it is absolutely quiet. It is so still there isn’t a breath of air. You look down and the mountains look down on you. You can go on climbing up the mountain for many hours, down into another valley and up again. You have done it several times before, twice reaching the very top of those rocky mountains. Beyond them to the north is a vast plain of desert. Down there it is very hot, here it is quite cold; you have to put something on in spite of the hot sun.

你已身处相当高的地方，俯瞰着山谷。如果你沿着蜿蜒的小路向上攀登一英里甚至更远，途经各种各样的植被——栎树、鼠尾草、毒橡树——以及一条夏季总是干涸的小溪，就能看到远处蔚蓝的大海，越过连绵起伏的山脉。这里绝对静谧无声，连一丝空气都感受不到。你向下望去，群山也仿佛在俯视着你。你可以继续攀登这座山峰，几个小时后，再下到另一个山谷，然后再向上攀登。你以前已经这样做过好几次了，其中两次甚至登上了那些岩石嶙峋的山峰之巅。山峰以北是一片广袤的沙漠平原。山下酷热难耐，而这里却十分寒冷；即使烈日当空，你也得穿上衣服。

And as you come down, looking at the various trees, plants, and little insects, suddenly you hear the rattle of a rattlesnake. And you jump, fortunately, away from the rattler. You are only about ten feet away from it. It is still rattling. You look at each other and watch. Snakes have no eyelids. This one was not very long but quite thick, as thick as your arm. You keep your distance and you watch it very carefully, its pattern, its triangular head, and its black tongue flickering in and out. You watch each other. It doesn’t move and you don’t move. But presently, its head and its tail toward you, it slithers back and you step forward. Again it coils up and rattles and you watch each other. And again, with its head and tail toward you, it begins to go back and again you move forward; and again it coils and rattles. You do this for several minutes, perhaps ten minutes or more; then it gets tired. You see that it is motionless, waiting, but as you approach it, it doesn’t rattle. It has temporarily lost its energy. You are quite close to it. Unlike the cobra which stands up to strike, this snake strikes lunging forward. But there was no movement. It was too exhausted, so you leave it. It was really quite a poisonous, dangerous thing. Probably you could touch it but you are disinclined to, though not frightened. You feel that you would rather not touch it and you leave it alone.

当你走下山坡，欣赏着各种树木、花草和小昆虫时，突然听到响尾蛇的尾巴发出沙沙的响声。你吓了一跳，幸好及时跳开了。你离它只有大约十英尺远。它还在摇晃着尾巴。你们互相对视，仔细观察。蛇没有眼睑。这条蛇不算很长，但很粗，和你的手臂一样粗。你保持着距离，仔细观察着它，它的花纹，三角形的头部，还有它伸长伸长的黑色舌头。你们互相观察着。它一动不动，你也一动不动。但过了一会儿，它的头和尾巴朝向你，它向后滑行，你向前迈了一步。它又盘起身子，摇晃着尾巴，你们继续观察着。它再次盘起身子，摇晃着尾巴，开始向后滑行，你又向前迈了一步；它又盘起身子，摇晃着尾巴。你们这样持续了几分钟，也许十分钟甚至更久；然后它就累了。你看到它一动不动，似乎在等待着什么，但当你靠近时，它却没有发出嘶嘶声。它暂时失去了力气。你离它很近。与站立攻击的眼镜蛇不同，这条蛇是猛扑而来。但它一动不动。它太累了，所以你离开了。它确实是一条剧毒的危险生物。或许你可以触摸它，但你并不想这么做，尽管并不害怕。你觉得最好不要碰它，于是你离开了。

And as you come further down you almost step on a quail with about a dozen or more babies. They scatter into the nearby bushes, and the mother too disappears into a bush and they all call to each other. You go down and wait, and if you have the patience to watch, you presently see them all come together under the mother’s wing. It is cool up there and they are waiting for the sun to warm the air and the earth.

再往下走，你差点踩到一群鹌鹑，它们带着十几只小鹌鹑。小鹌鹑们四散奔逃到附近的灌木丛里，鹌鹑妈妈也钻进了灌木丛，它们互相呼唤着。你走下去，静静地等待，如果你有耐心观察，很快就会看到它们都聚集到妈妈的翅膀下。那里很凉爽，它们正等着太阳温暖空气和大地。

You come down across the little stream, past a meadow which is almost losing its green, and return to your room rather tired but exhilarated by the walk and by the morning sun. You see the orange trees with their bright yellow oranges, the rose bushes and the myrtle, and the tall eucalyptus trees. It is all very peaceful in the house.

你沿着小溪走下来，经过一片几乎褪去绿色的草地，回到房间。虽然有些疲惫，但清晨的阳光和散步的疲惫让你精神焕发。你看到橘子树上挂着明亮的金黄色果实，还有玫瑰丛、桃金娘和高大的桉树。屋里一片宁静祥和。

It was a pleasant morning, full of strange activities on the earth. All those little things alive, rushing about, seeking their morning food—the squirrel, the gopher. They eat the tender roots of plants and are quite destructive. A dog can kill them so quickly with a snap. It is very dry, the rains are over and gone, to return again perhaps in four months or more. All the valley below is still glistening. It is strange how there is a brooding silence over the whole earth. In spite of the noise of towns and the traffic, there is something almost palpable, something holy. If you are in harmony with nature, with all the things around you, then you are in harmony with all human beings. If you have lost your relationship with nature you will inevitably lose your relationship with human beings.

这是一个宜人的清晨，大地上充满了奇特的景象。那些小家伙们生机勃勃，四处奔跑，寻找着早晨的食物——松鼠、地鼠。它们啃食植物的嫩根，破坏力十足。一只狗只需一口就能将它们咬死。天气非常干燥，雨季已经结束，或许要四个月甚至更久才能再次降临。山谷下方依然波光粼粼。整个大地笼罩在一种静谧的氛围中，这感觉很奇妙。尽管城镇喧嚣，车水马龙，却仿佛有一种近乎触手可及的神圣感。如果你与自然和谐相处，与周围的一切和谐相处，那么你也就与所有人和谐相处。如果你失去了与自然的联系，你也必然会失去与他人的联系。

A whole group of us sitting at table toward the end of the meal began a serious conversation, as has happened several times before. It was about the meaning of words, the weight of the word, the content of the word, not merely the superficial meaning of the word but the depth of it, the quality of it, the feeling of it. Of course the word is never the actual thing. The description, the explanation, is not that which is described, nor that about which there is an explanation. The word, the phrase, the explanation are not the actuality. But the word is used as a communication of one’s thought, one’s feeling, and the word, though it is not communicated to another, holds the feeling inside oneself. The actual never conditions the brain, but the theory, the conclusion, the description, the abstraction, do condition it. The table never conditions the brain but god does, whether it is the god of the Hindus, Christians, or Muslims. The concept, the image, conditions the brain, not that which is actually happening, taking place.

临近晚餐尾声，我们一群人围坐在桌旁，像之前几次一样，开始了一场严肃的讨论。讨论的话题是词语的意义、词语的分量、词语的内容，不仅仅是词语的表面含义，而是它的深度、品质和感受。当然，词语本身永远不是事物本身。描述、解释，并非被描述的对象，也并非被解释的对象。词语、短语、解释，都不是现实本身。但词语被用来传达思想和情感，即使没有传递给他人，它也能将这种情感铭刻于心。现实本身不会影响大脑，但理论、结论、描述、抽象概念却会。餐桌本身不会影响大脑，但神会，无论是印度教、基督教还是伊斯兰教的神。影响大脑的是概念和意象，而不是正在发生的事情。

To the Christian, the word Jesus or Christ has great significance, great meaning; it evokes a deep sentiment, a sensation. Those words have no meaning to the Hindu, to the Buddhist, or to the Muslim. Those words are not the actual. So those words, which have been used for two thousand years, have conditioned the brain. The Hindu has his own gods, his own divinities. Those divinities, like the Christians’, are the projections of thought, our of fear, out of pleasure, and so on.

对基督徒而言，“耶稣”或“基督”这两个词意义非凡，它能唤起人们内心深处的情感和感受。但这些词语对印度教徒、佛教徒或穆斯林来说却毫无意义。这些词语并非真实存在。因此，这些使用了两千年的词语已经潜移默化地影响了人们的思维。印度教徒有他们自己的神祇，他们自己的神灵。这些神灵，如同基督徒的神灵一样，都是思想的投射，源于恐惧、享乐等等。

It seems that language really doesn’t condition the brain; what does is the theory of the language, the abstraction of a certain feeling and the abstraction taking the form of an idea, a symbol, a person—not the actual person but a person imagined, or hoped for, or projected by thought. All those abstractions, those ideas, conclusions, however strong, condition the brain. But the actual, like the table, never does.

语言本身似乎并不能真正塑造大脑；真正塑造大脑的是语言理论，是对某种感觉的抽象，以及这种抽象以观念、符号、人物（并非真实存在的人，而是想象的、期盼的或思想投射出的人）的形式呈现出来。所有这些抽象概念、观念和结论，无论多么强烈，都会塑造大脑。但现实本身，就像桌子一样，却永远不会。

Take a word like suffering . That word has a different meaning for the Hindu and the Christian. But suffering, however described by words, is shared by all of us. Suffering is the fact, the actual. But when we try to escape from it through some theory, or through some idealized person, or through a symbol, those forms of escape mold the brain. Suffering as a fact doesn’t, and this is important to realize.

以“苦难”一词为例。这个词对印度教徒和基督教徒来说意义不同。但无论用何种语言描述，苦难都是我们所有人共同经历的。苦难是事实，是真实存在的。然而，当我们试图通过某种理论、某个理想化的人物或某种象征来逃避苦难时，这些逃避方式会塑造我们的大脑。而作为事实的苦难则不会，认识到这一点至关重要。

Like the word attachment ; to see the word, to hold it as if in your hand and watch it, feel the depth of it, the whole content of it, the consequences of it, the fact that we are attached—the fact, not the word; that feeling doesn’t shape the brain, put it into a mold, but the moment one moves away from it, that is, when thought moves away from the fact, that very movement away, movement of escape, is not only a time factor, but the beginning of shaping the brain in a certain mold.

就像“依恋”这个词一样；看到这个词，把它握在手中，观察它，感受它的深度，它的全部内容，它的后果，我们依恋的事实——是事实，而不是这个词本身；这种感觉不会塑造大脑，不会把它定型，但当一个人远离它，也就是说，当思想远离这个事实时，这种远离，这种逃避，不仅是一个时间因素，而且是大脑被塑造成某种模样的开始。

To the Buddhist the word Buddha , the impression, the image, creates great reverence, great feeling, devotion; he seeks refuge in the image which thought has created. And as the thought is limited, because all knowledge is always limited, that very image brings about conflict—the feeling of reverence to a person, or to a symbol, or to a certain long-established tradition—but the feeling of reverence itself, divorced from all the external images, symbols, and so on, is not a factor of conditioning the brain.

对佛教徒而言，“佛陀”一词、其印象、其形象，会引发极大的敬畏、强烈的情感和虔诚；他寻求皈依于思想所创造的形象。然而，由于思想是有限的——因为一切知识都是有限的——这种形象本身便会带来冲突——对一个人、一个象征或某种由来已久的传统所产生的敬畏之情——但这种敬畏之情本身，脱离所有外在的形象、象征等等，并非影响大脑的因素。

There, sitting in the next chair, was a modified Christian. And when across the table one mentioned Christ one could immediately feel the restrictive, reverential reserve. That word has conditioned the brain. It is quite extraordinary to watch this whole phenomenon of communication with words, each race giving different significance and meaning to the word and thereby creating a division, a limitation, to the feeling which mankind suffers. The suffering of mankind is common, is shared by all human beings. The Russian may express it in one way, the Hindu, the Christian in another, and so on, but the fact of suffering, the actual feeling of pain, grief, loneliness, that feeling never shapes or conditions the brain. So one becomes very attentive to, aware of, the subtleties of the word, the meaning, the weight of it.

坐在旁边椅子上的是一位信仰有所改变的基督徒。当对面有人提到基督时，立刻就能感受到那种拘谨而敬畏的矜持。这个词已经潜移默化地影响了人们的思维。观察这种用语言交流的现象真是令人匪夷所思：每个种族都赋予同一个词不同的意义和内涵，从而造成了一种隔阂，一种对人类苦难情感的限制。人类的苦难是共通的，是所有人类共同经历的。俄罗斯人或许用一种方式表达，印度教徒用另一种方式，基督徒用另一种方式表达，等等，但苦难本身，痛苦、悲伤、孤独的真实感受，这些感受本身，却从未真正塑造或影响过人们的思维。因此，人们变得异常敏感，对词语的细微差别、意义和分量都异常在意。

The universal, the global feeling of all human beings and their interrelationship, can only come into being when the words nation , tribe , religion , have all disappeared. Either the word has depth, significance, or none at all. For most of us words have very little depth, they have lost their weight. A river is not a particular river. The rivers of America or England or Europe or India are all rivers, but the moment there is identification through a word, there is division. And this division is an abstraction of the river, the quality of water, the depth of the water, the volume, the flow, the beauty of the river.

只有当“民族”、“部落”、“宗教”这些词汇消失时，人类普遍的、全球性的情感及其相互联系才能真正存在。词语要么具有深度和意义，要么毫无意义。对我们大多数人来说，词语的深度很浅，它们已经失去了分量。河流并非指某条特定的河流。美国、英国、欧洲或印度的河流都是河流，但一旦用词语来指代它们，就产生了隔阂。而这种隔阂是对河流本身、水质、深度、水量、流速以及河流之美的抽象化。

May 30, 1983

1983年5月30日

It has been raining here every day for over a month. When you come from a climate like California where the rains stopped over a month ago, where the green fields were drying up and turning brown and the sun was very hot, it is rather startling and surprising to see the green grass, the marvelous green trees and the copper beeches, which are a spreading, light brown, becoming gradually darker and darker. To see them now among the green trees is a delight. They are going to be very dark as the summer comes on. And this earth is very beautiful. Earth, whether it is desert or filled with orchards and green, bright fields, is always beautiful.

这里已经连下了超过一个月的雨。如果你来自像加州那样气候恶劣的地方，那里的雨水在一个多月前就停了，绿色的田野开始干涸泛黄，阳光炙烤着大地，那么看到眼前这片绿草茵茵、绿树成荫，还有那蔓延开来的浅棕色山毛榉，颜色逐渐加深，真是令人惊叹不已。如今，它们在绿树丛中绽放，令人心旷神怡。随着夏季的到来，它们的颜色将会变得更加深沉。这片土地真是太美了。无论它是沙漠，还是遍布果园和绿意盎然的田野，它永远都是美丽的。

To go for a walk in the fields with the cattle and the young lambs, and in the woods with the song of birds, without a single thought in your mind, only watching the earth, the trees, the sheep and hearing the cuckoo calling and the wood pigeons; to walk without any emotion, any sentiment, to watch the trees and all the earth—when you so watch, you learn your own thinking, are aware of your own reactions and do not allow a single thought to escape you without understanding why it came, what was the cause of it. If you are watchful, never letting a thought go by, then the brain becomes very quiet. Then you watch in great silence and that silence has immense depth, a lasting incorruptible beauty.

漫步田野，与牛羊羔儿为伴；徜徉林间，聆听鸟儿歌唱；心中一片空白，只管静静地观察大地、树木、羊群，聆听杜鹃和斑鸠的鸣叫；抛开一切情绪，不带一丝情感，静静地观察树木和大地——当你如此观察时，你便能了解自己的思维，觉察自身的反应，不让任何一个念头悄然溜走，而是探究其缘由。如果你保持警觉，不让任何念头溜走，你的大脑便会变得无比平静。那时，你将在极致的静谧中观察，而那份静谧蕴藏着无比的深邃，一种永恒不朽的美。

The boy was good at games, really quite good. He was also good at his studies; he was serious. So one day he came to his teacher and said, “Sir, could I have a talk with you?” The educator said, “Yes, we can have a talk; let us go out for a walk.” So they had a dialogue. It was a conversation between the teacher and the taught, a conversation in which there was some respect on both sides, and as the educator was also serious, the conversation was pleasant, friendly, and they had forgotten that he was a teacher with a student; the rank was forgotten, the importance of one who knows, the authority, and the other who is curious.

这男孩游戏玩得特别好，真的很厉害。他学习也很好，很认真。有一天，他找到老师说：“老师，我可以和您谈谈吗？”老师说：“当然可以，我们出去走走吧。”于是他们开始交谈。这是一场师生之间的对话，双方都彼此尊重。由于老师也很认真，谈话气氛轻松友好，他们忘记了师生关系，忘记了师生之间的等级差异，忘记了知识渊博、权威和求知欲之间的区别。

“Sir, I wonder if you know what all this is about, why I am getting an education, what part will it play when I grow up, what role have I in this world, why do I have to study, why do I have to marry and what is my future? Of course, I realize I have to study and pass some sort of exams and I hope I will be able to pass them. I will probably live for some years, perhaps fifty, sixty, or more, and in all those years to come what will be my life and the life of those people around me? What am I going to be and what is the point of these long hours over books and hearing the teachers? There might be a devastating war; we might all be killed. If death is all that lies ahead, then what is the point of all this education? Please, I am asking these questions quite seriously because I have heard the other teachers and you too pointing out many of these things.”

“先生，我不知道您是否明白这一切的意义所在，我为什么要接受教育，长大后它会对我的生活产生什么影响，我在这个世界上扮演着怎样的角色，我为什么要学习，为什么要结婚，我的未来又会是怎样的？当然，我知道我必须学习，必须通过各种考试，我也希望自己能够通过。我或许还能活很多年，也许五六十年，甚至更久，那么在未来的岁月里，我的生活以及我身边人的生活将会如何？我将来会成为什么样的人？我花那么多时间读书、听老师讲课的意义何在？也许会爆发一场毁灭性的战争，我们所有人都会丧命。如果死亡是通往未来的唯一道路，那么这一切教育的意义又是什么呢？请您认真地提出这些问题，因为我听到其他老师，也包括您，都指出了这些问题。”

“I would like to take one question at a time. You have asked many questions, you have put several problems before me, so first let us look at perhaps the most important question: What is the future of mankind and of yourself? As you know, your parents are fairly well-off and of course they want to help you in any way they can. Perhaps if you get married they might give you a house, buy a house with all the things necessary in it, and you might have a nice wife—might. So what is it you are going to be? The usual mediocre person? Get a job, settle down with all the problems around you and in you—is that your future? Of course a war may come, but it may not happen; let us hope it does not happen. Let us hope man may come to realize that wars of any kind will never solve any human problem. Men may improve, they may invent better airplanes, and so on, but wars have never solved human problems and they never will. So let us forget for the moment that all of us might be destroyed through the craziness of superpowers, through the craziness of terrorists, or some demagogue in some country wanting to destroy his invented enemies. Let us forget all that for the moment. Let us consider what is your future, knowing that you are part of the rest of the world. What is your future? As I asked, to be a mediocre person? Mediocrity means to go half way up the hill, half way in anything, never going to the very top of the mountain or demanding all your energy, your capacity, never demanding excellence.

“我想一次回答一个问题。你们问了很多问题，也提出了几个难题，所以首先让我们来看一个或许最重要的问题：人类的未来，以及你们自己的未来，会是什么样？你们也知道，你们的父母家境不错，他们当然想尽一切办法帮助你们。也许你们结婚后，他们会给你们买一套房子，一套设施齐全的房子，你们或许还会娶个好妻子——也许吧。那么，你们的未来会是什么样呢？一个平庸之辈？找份工作，安顿下来，忍受着周围和自身所有的烦恼——这就是你们的未来吗？战争当然可能会爆发，但也可能不会；让我们祈祷它不会发生。让我们祈祷人类能够意识到，任何形式的战争都永远无法解决任何人类问题。人类或许会进步，或许会发明更好的飞机等等，但战争从未解决过人类问题，也永远不会解决。所以，让我们暂时忘记，我们所有人都有可能因为超级大国的疯狂而毁灭，因为……恐怖分子，或是某个国家的煽动者，想要摧毁他臆想出来的敌人。我们暂且把这些都抛到脑后。让我们思考一下，作为世界的一部分，你的未来是什么？正如我所问，你的未来是做一个平庸之人吗？平庸意味着在任何事情上都止步于半途，永远无法攀登到顶峰，永远无法发挥出全部的精力和能力，永远无法追求卓越。

“Of course you must realize also that there will be all the pressures from outside—pressures to do this, all the various narrow religious sectarian pressures and propaganda. Propaganda can never tell the truth; truth can never be propagated. So I hope you realize the pressure on you—pressure from your parents, from your society, from the tradition to be a scientist, to be a philosopher, to be a physicist, a man who undertakes research in any field; or to be a businessman. Realizing all this, which you must do at your age, what way will you go? We have been talking about all these things for many terms, and probably, if one may point out, you have applied your mind to all this. So as we have some time together to go around the hill and come back, I am asking you, not as a teacher but with affection as a friend genuinely concerned, what is your future? Even if you have already made up your mind to pass some exams and have a career, a good profession, you still have to ask, is that all? Even if you do have a good profession, perhaps a life that is fairly pleasant, you will have a lot of troubles, problems. If you have a family, what will be the future of your children? This is a question that you have to answer yourself and perhaps we can talk about it. You have to consider the future of your children, not just your own future, and you have to consider the future of humanity, forgetting that you are German, French, English, or Indian. Let us talk about it, but please realize I am not telling you what you should do. Only fools advise, so I am not entering into that category. I am just questioning in a friendly manner, which I hope you realize; I am not pushing you, directing you, persuading you. What is your future? Will you mature rapidly or slowly, gracefully, sensitively? Will you be mediocre, though you may be first class in your profession? You may excel, you may be very, very good at whatever you do, but I am talking of mediocrity of the mind, of the heart, mediocrity of your entire being.”

“当然，你也必须意识到来自外界的各种压力——来自各行各业的压力，各种狭隘的宗教宗派压力和宣传。宣传永远无法传达真相；真相也永远无法传播。所以我希望你能意识到你肩负的压力——来自父母、社会、传统的压力，让你成为科学家、哲学家、物理学家，成为任何领域的研究人员；或者成为商人。在你这个年纪，你必须意识到这一切，那么你会选择哪条路呢？我们已经讨论过这些问题很多次了，而且，恕我直言，你可能已经认真思考过了。所以，趁我们还有时间一起走走，我想问问你，我不是以老师的身份，而是以一个真正关心你的朋友的身份，你的未来是什么？即使你已经下定决心通过考试，拥有一份事业，一份好职业，你仍然需要问问自己，这就是全部吗？即使你确实拥有……”或许你拥有一份体面的职业，过着相当舒适的生活，但你也会面临许多麻烦和问题。如果你组建了家庭，你的孩子未来会怎样？这个问题你必须自己回答，或许我们可以谈谈。你必须考虑孩子的未来，而不仅仅是你自己的未来，你也必须考虑全人类的未来，暂时忘却你是德国人、法国人、英国人还是印度人。让我们来谈谈，但请记住，我不是在告诉你应该怎么做。只有傻瓜才会给人建议，所以我不会落入这个行列。我只是以友好的方式提出一些问题，希望你能明白；我不是在强迫你、指导你或说服你。你的未来会怎样？你会迅速成熟还是缓慢成熟？你会优雅成熟还是心思细腻？即使你在专业领域一流，你最终会平庸吗？你或许会出类拔萃，或许会在任何方面都非常出色，但我说的是思想上的平庸，心灵上的平庸，你整个人存在的平庸。

“Sir, I don’t really know how to answer these questions. I have not given too much thought to it, but when you ask this question, whether I am to become like the rest of the world, mediocre, I certainly don’t want to be that. I also realize the attraction of the world. I also see that part of me wants all that. I want to have some fun, some happy times, but the other side of me also sees the danger of all that, the difficulties, the urges, the temptations. So I really don’t know where I will end up. And also, as you pointed out on several occasions, I don’t know myself what I am. One thing is definite, I really don’t want to be a mediocre person with a small mind and heart, though with a brain that may be extraordinarily clever. I may study books and acquire a great deal of knowledge, but I may still be a very limited, narrow person. Mediocrity, sir, is a very good word which you have used and when I look at it I am getting frightened—not of the word but of the whole implications of what you have shown. I really don’t know, and perhaps in talking it over with you it may clear things up. I can’t so easily talk with my parents. They probably have had the same problems as I have; they may be more mature physically but they may be in the same position as I am. So if I may ask, sir, may I take another occasion, if you are willing, to talk with me? I really feel rather frightened, nervous, apprehensive of my capacity to meet all this, face it, go through it and not become a mediocre person.”

“先生，我真的不知道该如何回答这些问题。我并没有仔细考虑过，但当您问我是否会变得像其他人一样平庸时，我当然不想那样。我也意识到世俗的诱惑。我也明白我内心深处渴望这一切。我想享受快乐时光，但另一方面，我也看到了这一切的危险，那些困难、欲望和诱惑。所以我真的不知道自己最终会走向何方。而且，正如您多次指出的那样，我自己也不了解自己。有一点可以肯定，我真的不想成为一个心胸狭隘、思想平庸的人，即使我拥有非常聪明的头脑。我或许会博览群书，积累丰富的知识，但我可能仍然是一个非常狭隘、缺乏远见的人。先生，您用的‘平庸’这个词非常贴切，当我仔细思考它时，我意识到……”害怕——不是害怕这个词本身，而是害怕你所展示的一切所带来的所有影响。我真的不知道该怎么办，或许跟你好好谈谈能让我明白。我不太好意思跟父母谈。他们可能也遇到过和我一样的问题；他们或许身体更成熟，但处境可能和我一样。所以，先生，如果可以的话，我想再找个机会跟您谈谈。我真的感到很害怕，很紧张，很担心自己是否有能力面对这一切，能否挺过去，能否不让自己变成一个平庸之辈。

It was one of those mornings that has never been before: the near meadow, the still beeches, and the lane that goes into the deeper wood—all was silence. There wasn’t a bird chirping and the nearby horses were standing still. A morning like this, fresh, tender, is a rare thing. There is peace in this part of the land and everything was very quiet. There was that feeling, that sense of absolute silence. It was not a romantic sentimentalism, not poetic imagination. It was and is. A simple thing is all this is. The copper beeches this morning were full of splendor against the green fields stretching to the distance, and a cloud full of that morning light was floating lazily by. The sun was just coming up, there was great peace and a sense of adoration. Not the adoration of some god or imaginative deity but a reverence that is born of great beauty. This morning one could let go of all the things one has gathered and be silent with the woods and the trees and the quiet lawn. The sky was a pale and tender blue and far away across the fields a cuckoo was calling, the wood pigeons were cooing, and the blackbirds began their morning song. In the distance you could hear a car going by. Probably when the heavens are so quiet with loveliness it will rain later on. It always does when the early morning is very clear. But this morning it was all very special, something that has never been before and could never be again.

这是一个前所未见的清晨：近处的草地，静谧的山毛榉，以及通往更深林间的小径——一切都静谧无声。没有鸟鸣，附近的马匹也纹丝不动。这样一个清新、温柔的清晨实属难得。这片土地宁静祥和，一切都静谧无声。那种感觉，那种绝对的静谧，真切存在。这不是浪漫的感伤，也不是诗意的想象。它就是如此，也一直存在。这就是一切的简单。清晨，铜色的山毛榉在远处绵延的绿色田野映衬下显得格外绚丽，一朵沐浴着晨光的云朵懒洋洋地飘过。太阳刚刚升起，周围一片宁静祥和，一种敬畏之情油然而生。这并非对某个神灵或虚构人物的崇拜，而是一种源于绝美景色的敬畏。在这个清晨，人们可以放下所有牵挂，与树林、树木和静谧的草坪融为一体，静静地感受这一切。天空呈现出淡淡的、柔和的蓝色，远处田野上传来杜鹃的啼鸣，斑鸠咕咕的叫声，乌鸫也开始了晨鸣。远处传来汽车驶过的声音。或许，当天空如此宁静美好时，晚些时候就会下雨。清晨晴朗的时候，总是如此。但今天早晨的一切都如此特别，前所未有，也后无来者。

“I am glad you have come of your own accord, without being invited, and perhaps if you are prepared, we can continue with our conversation about mediocrity and the future of your life. One can be excellent in one’s career; we aren’t saying that there is mediocrity in all professions; a good carpenter may not be mediocre in his work but in his daily, inward life, his life with his family, he may be. We both understand the meaning of that word now and we should investigate together the depth of that word. We are talking about inward mediocrity, psychological conflicts, problems and travail. There can be great scientists who yet inwardly lead a mediocre life. So what is going to be your life? In some ways you are a clever student, but for what will you use your brain? We are not talking about your career, that will come later; what we should be concerned about is the way you are going to live. Of course, you are not going to be a criminal in the ordinary sense of that word. You are not, if you are wise, going to be a bully; they are too aggressive. You will probably get an excellent job, do excellent work in whatever you choose to do. So let us put that aside for a moment; but inside, what is your life? Inwardly, what is the future? Are you going to be like the rest of the world, always hunting pleasure, always troubled with a dozen psychological problems?”
