“我很高兴你是自愿前来，而不是受邀而来。如果你准备好了，或许我们可以继续探讨平庸以及你未来的人生。一个人可以在事业上取得卓越成就；我们并不是说所有行业都存在平庸；一个优秀的木匠在工作上或许并不平庸，但在他日常的内心世界，在与家人相处的生活中，他可能很平庸。我们现在都明白了这个词的含义，我们应该一起深入探究它的内涵。我们谈论的是内心的平庸，心理冲突、问题和苦恼。有些伟大的科学家，内心却过着平庸的生活。那么，你的人生将会如何？在某些方面，你是一个聪明的学生，但你打算如何运用你的才智呢？我们现在不是在谈论你的事业，那以后再说；我们应该关注的是你的生活方式。当然，你不会成为通常意义上的罪犯。如果你足够明智，你就不会……”别欺负人；他们太咄咄逼人了。你很可能会找到一份好工作，无论你选择做什么，都会做得很好。所以我们暂且把这些放在一边；但你的内心深处，你的生活是什么样的？你的未来是什么？你会像其他人一样，永远追求享乐，永远被各种各样的心理问题困扰吗？

“At present, sir, I have no problems, except the problems of passing examinations and the weariness of all that. Otherwise I seem to have no problems. There is a certain freedom. I feel happy, young. When I see all these old people I ask myself, am I going to end up like that? They seem to have had good careers or to have done something they wanted to do but in spite of that they become dreary, dull, and they seem never to have excelled in the deeper qualities of the brain. I certainly don’t want to be like that. It is not vanity, but I want to have something different. It is not an ambition. I want to have a good career and all that business but I certainly in no way want to be like these old people who seem to have lost everything they like.”

“先生，目前我没什么问题，除了考试的压力和由此带来的疲惫。除此之外，我似乎没有任何烦恼。我感到很自由，很快乐，很年轻。当我看到那些老年人时，我不禁自问，我最终会变成他们那样吗？他们似乎都拥有过不错的事业，或者做过自己想做的事，但即便如此，他们还是变得沉闷、乏味，似乎从未在更深层次的思维能力方面有所建树。我当然不想变成那样。这不是虚荣，而是我想要一些不同的东西。这不是什么野心。我想要一份好工作，想要一切顺利，但我绝对不想像这些老年人一样，似乎失去了所有自己喜欢的东西。”

“You may not want to be like them but life is a very demanding and cruel thing. It won’t let you alone. You will have great pressure from society whether you live here or in America or in any other part of the world. You will be constantly urged to become like the rest, to become something of a hypocrite, say things you don’t really mean, and if you do marry that may raise problems too. You must understand that life is a very complex affair—not just pursuing what you want to do and being pigheaded about it. These young people want to become something—lawyers, engineers, politicians, and so on; there is the urge, the drive of, ambition for power, money. That is what those old people whom you talk about have been through. They are worn out by constant conflict, by their desires. Look at it, look at the people around you. They are all in the same boat. Some leave the boat and wander endlessly and die. Some seek some peaceful corner of the earth and retire; some join a monastery, become monks of various kinds, taking desperate vows. The vast majority, millions and millions, lead a very small life, their horizon is very limited. They have their sorrows, their joys, and they seem never to escape from them or understand them and go beyond. So again we ask each other, what is our future, specifically, what is your future? Of course you are much too young to go into this question very deeply, for youth has nothing to do with the total comprehension of this question. You may be an agnostic; the young do not believe in anything, but as you grow older then you turn to some form of religious superstition, religious dogma, religious conviction. Religion is not an opiate, but man has made religion in his own image, blind comfort and, therefore, security. He has made religion into something totally unintelligent and impracticable, not something that you can live with. How old are you?”

你或许不想成为他们那样的人，但生活残酷无情，它不会放过你。无论你生活在这里、美国还是世界其他任何地方，你都会面临来自社会的巨大压力。你会不断地被敦促变得和别人一样，变得虚伪，说一些言不由衷的话，如果你结婚了，那也可能会带来问题。你必须明白，生活非常复杂——不仅仅是一味追求自己想做的事，然后固执己见。这些年轻人想要成为律师、工程师、政治家等等；他们渴望权力、渴望金钱。你提到的那些老人也经历过这些。他们被持续不断的冲突和欲望折磨得筋疲力尽。看看你周围的人吧。他们都在同一条船上。有些人离开了船，无休止地漂泊，最终死去。有些人寻找地球上某个宁静的角落隐居；有些人加入寺院，成为各种各样的僧侣，走上绝路。誓言。绝大多数人，数以百万计的人，过着极其狭隘的生活，视野极其有限。他们有悲伤，有快乐，却似乎永远无法摆脱或理解它们，更无法超越它们。所以我们再次彼此询问：我们的未来是什么？具体来说，你的未来是什么？当然，你还太年轻，无法深入思考这个问题，因为年轻与完全理解这个问题无关。你或许是个不可知论者；年轻人什么都不信，但随着年龄增长，你会转向某种形式的宗教迷信、宗教教条或宗教信念。宗教并非鸦片，但人类按照自己的形象创造了宗教，盲目地寻求慰藉和安全感。他把宗教变成了一种完全不理智、不切实际的东西，一种你无法与之共存的东西。你多大了？

“I’m going to be nineteen, sir. My grandmother has left me something when I am twenty-one and perhaps before I go to the university I can travel and look around. But I will always carry this question with me wherever I am, whatever my future. I may marry, probably I will, and have children, and so the great question arises—what is their future? I am somewhat aware of what the politicians are doing throughout the world. It is an ugly business as far as I am concerned, so I think I won’t be a politician. I’m pretty sure of that but I want a good job. I’d like to work with my hands and with my brain but the question will be how not to become a mediocre person like ninety-nine percent of the world. So, sir, what am I to do? Oh, yes, I am aware of churches and temples and all that; I am not attracted to them. I rather revolt against all that—the priests and the hierarchy of authority, but how am I going to prevent myself becoming an ordinary, average, mediocre person?”

“先生，我即将十九岁。我祖母在我二十一岁时给我留了一笔遗产，或许在我上大学之前，我可以去旅行看看。但无论我身在何处，无论我的未来如何，我都会一直带着这个问题。我可能会结婚，很可能也会，然后生儿育女，那么，一个重要的问题就出现了——他们的未来会怎样？我略微了解世界各地政客的所作所为。在我看来，那是一件丑陋的事情，所以我想我不会成为政客。我很确定这一点，但我想要一份好工作。我想从事体力劳动，也想动脑筋，但问题在于，如何才能不沦为像世界上百分之九十九的人那样平庸之辈。所以，先生，我该怎么办？哦，是的，我知道教堂、寺庙之类的，但我对它们不感兴趣。我宁愿反抗这一切——反抗神职人员和等级森严的权力体系，但我该如何避免自己变成一个普通、平庸、平庸的人呢？”

“If I may suggest, never under any circumstances ask ‘how.’ When you use the word how you really want someone to tell you what to do, some guide, some system, somebody to lead you by the hand so that you lose your freedom, your capacity to observe, your own activities, your own thoughts, your own way of life. When you ask ‘how’ you really become a secondhand human being; you lose integrity and also the innate honesty to look at yourself, to be what you are and to go beyond and above what you are. Never, never ask the question ‘how.’ We are talking psychologically, of course. You have to ask ‘how’ when you want to put a motor together or build a computer. You have to learn something about it from somebody. But to be psychologically free and original can only come about when you are aware of your own inward activities, watch what you are thinking and never let one thought escape without observing the nature of it, the source of it. Observing, watching. One learns about oneself much more by watching than from books or from some psychologist or complicated, clever, erudite scholar or professor.

“恕我直言，无论任何情况下都不要问‘怎么做’。当你问‘怎么做’的时候，你其实是想找个人告诉你该怎么做，找个向导，找个系统，找个人牵着你的手，这样你就会失去自由、失去观察的能力、失去自己的活动、自己的思想、自己的生活方式。当你问‘怎么做’的时候，你实际上就变成了一个二手货；你失去了正直，失去了审视自我、做真实的自己、超越自我的内在诚实。永远，永远不要问‘怎么做’。当然，我们这里说的是心理层面。当你想要组装发动机或制造电脑时，你必须问‘怎么做’。你必须向别人学习。但是，只有当你意识到自己的内心活动，观察自己的思维，并且不让任何一个念头未经观察就溜走，不去探究它的本质和来源时，你才能获得心理上的自由和原创性。观察，觉察。一个人通过观察比从书本、心理学家或那些复杂、聪明的理论中更多地了解自己。”博学的学者或教授。

“It is going to be very difficult, my friend. It can tear you in many directions. There are a great many so-called temptations—biological, social—and you can be torn apart by the cruelty of society. Of course, you are going to have to stand alone but that can come about not through force, determination, or desire but when you begin to see the false things around you and in yourself: the emotions, the hopes. When you begin to see that which is false, then there is the beginning of awareness, of intelligence. You have to be a light to yourself and it is one of the most difficult things in life.”

“朋友，这会非常艰难。它会让你四面楚歌。你会面临许多所谓的诱惑——生理上的、社会上的——社会的残酷会让你痛苦不堪。当然，你必须学会独处，但这并非靠强迫、决心或欲望就能实现的，而是当你开始看清你周围和你自身存在的虚假事物时：那些情绪，那些希望。当你开始看清虚假的事物时，觉醒和智慧便开始了。你必须成为自己的光，而这却是人生中最难的事情之一。”

“Sir, you have made it all seem so very difficult, so very complex, so very awesome, frightening.”

“先生，您把一切都描述得如此困难，如此复杂，如此令人敬畏，又如此可怕。”

“I am just pointing all this out to you. It doesn’t mean that facts need frighten you. Facts are there to observe. If you observe them they never frighten you. Facts are not frightening. But if you want to avoid them, turn your back and run, then that is frightening. To stand, to see that what you have done may not have been totally correct, to live with the fact and not interpret the fact according to your pleasure or form of reaction, that is not frightening. Life isn’t very simple. One can live simply but life itself is vast, complex. It extends from horizon to horizon. You can live with few clothes or with one meal a day, but that is not simplicity. So be simple, don’t live in a complicated way, contradictory, and so on, just be simple inwardly. You played tennis this morning. I was watching and you seem to be quite good at it. Perhaps we will meet again. That is up to you.”

我只是想把这些都跟你指出来。这并不意味着事实会让你感到恐惧。事实就在那里，供你观察。如果你观察它们，它们就不会让你感到恐惧。事实本身并不可怕。但如果你想逃避它们，转身逃跑，那才是可怕的。坦然面对，意识到你所做的事可能并不完全正确，接受事实，而不是根据你的喜好或反应方式去解读事实，这并不可怕。生活并不简单。你可以过简单的生活，但生活本身是广阔而复杂的。它绵延不绝。你可以只穿几件衣服，或者一天只吃一顿饭，但这并非简单。所以，保持简单，不要过着复杂、矛盾的生活，保持内心的简单就好。你今天早上打了网球。我看了，你打得相当不错。也许我们会再次相遇。这取决于你。

“Thank you, sir.”

“谢谢您，先生。”

#↩

KRISHNAMURTI’S JOURNAL

克里希那穆提的日记

September 15, 1973

1973年9月15日

It is good to be alone. To be far away from the world and yet walk its streets is to be alone. To be alone walking up the path beside the rushing, noisy mountain stream full of spring water and melting snows is to be aware of that solitary tree, alone in its beauty. The loneliness of a man in the street is the pain of life; he’s never alone, far away, untouched and vulnerable. To be full of knowledge breeds endless misery. The demand for expression, with its frustrations and pains, is that man who walks the streets; he is never alone. Sorrow is the movement of that loneliness.

独处是件好事。远离尘嚣，却漫步街头，便是独处。沿着奔腾喧嚣的山涧小径，感受着泉水与融雪的潺潺流淌，你会注意到那棵孤零零的树，它独自绽放着美丽。街头流浪者的孤独，乃是人生的苦痛；他并非真正孤独，远离尘世，与世隔绝，却又脆弱不堪。知识的充盈，滋生无尽的苦难。渴望表达，以及随之而来的挫折与痛苦，正是那个漫步街头的人；他并非真正孤独。悲伤，乃是那份孤独的流动。

That mountain stream was full and high with the melting snows and the rains of early spring. You could hear big boulders being pushed around by the force of onrushing waters. A tall pine of fifty years or more crashed into the water; the road was being washed away. The stream was muddy, slate-colored. The fields above it were full of wild flowers. The air was pure and there was enchantment. On the high hills there was still snow, and the glaciers and the great peaks still held the recent snows; they will still be white all the summer long.

那条山涧水量充沛，积雪融化，春雨滋润，水位很高。可以听到巨石被奔腾的溪水推来推去的声音。一棵五十年以上的参天松树轰然倒塌，道路也被冲毁。溪水浑浊，呈灰蓝色。溪流上游的田野里开满了野花。空气清新，令人心旷神怡。高高的山丘上依然覆盖着积雪，冰川和巍峨的山峰上还残留着新雪，整个夏天它们都将洁白如雪。

It was a marvelous morning and you could have walked on endlessly, never feeling the steep hills. There was a perfume in the air, clear and strong. There was no one on that path, coming down or going up. You were alone with those dark pines and the rushing waters. The sky was that astonishing blue that only the mountains have. You looked at it through leaves and the straight pines. There was no one to talk to and there was no chattering of the mind. A magpie, white and black, flew by, disappearing into the woods. The path led away from the noisy stream and the silence was absolute. It wasn’t the silence after the noise; it wasn’t the silence that comes with the setting of the sun, nor that silence when the mind dies down. It wasn’t the silence of museums and churches but something totally unrelated to time and space. It wasn’t the silence that mind makes for itself. The sun was hot and the shadows were pleasant.

那是一个美好的清晨，你可以一直走下去，丝毫不会感到陡峭的山坡。空气中弥漫着一种清新浓郁的香气。这条小路上空无一人，无论是下山还是上山。你独自一人，与苍翠的松树和潺潺的溪流为伴。天空湛蓝如洗，只有山峦才有如此美景。你透过树叶和笔直的松树仰望着它。没有人可以交谈，也没有思绪的喧嚣。一只黑白相间的喜鹊飞过，消失在树林深处。小路蜿蜒远离喧嚣的溪流，一片绝对的寂静。这并非喧嚣过后的寂静；并非夕阳西下时的寂静，也非思绪消散后的寂静。它不是博物馆和教堂里的那种寂静，而是一种完全超越时间和空间的存在。它不是心灵创造的寂静。阳光炽热，树影婆娑，令人心旷神怡。

He only discovered recently that there was not a single thought during these long walks, in the crowded streets or on the solitary paths. Ever since he was a boy it had been like that, no thought entered his mind. He was watching and listening and nothing else. Thought, with its associations, never arose. There was no image-making. One day he was suddenly aware how extraordinary it was; he attempted often to think but no thought would come. On these walks, with people or without them, any movement of thought was absent. This is to be alone.

他最近才发现，在这些漫长的散步中，无论是在熙熙攘攘的街道还是在僻静的小路上，他脑中竟然没有一丝思绪。自从孩提时代起，他一直如此，没有任何念头进入他的脑海。他只是观察和聆听，除此之外别无其他。思绪，以及与之相关的联想，从未出现。没有画面生成。有一天，他突然意识到这有多么不同寻常；他常常试图思考，却一个念头都无法产生。在这些散步中，无论是否有人陪伴，任何思绪都无法流动。这就是独处。

Over the snow peaks clouds were forming, heavy and dark; probably it would rain later on but now the shadows were very sharp with the sun bright and clear. There was still that pleasant smell in the air and the rains would bring a different smell. It was a long way down to the chalet.

雪峰之上，乌云密布，沉重而阴沉；或许一会儿会下雨，但现在阳光灿烂，阴影清晰可见。空气中依然弥漫着那股令人愉悦的气息，而雨水会带来另一种气味。通往小木屋的路还很长。

September 17, 1973

1973年9月17日

That evening, walking through the wood there was a feeling of menace. The sun was just setting and the palm trees were solitary against the golden western sky. The monkeys were in the banyan tree, getting ready for the night. Hardly anyone used that path and rarely you met another human being. There were many deer, shy and disappearing into the thick growth. Yet the menace was there, heavy and pervading: it was all around you, you looked over your shoulder. There were no dangerous animals; they had moved away from there; it was too close to the spreading town. One was glad to leave and walk back through the lighted streets. But the next evening the monkeys were still there and so were the deer and the sun was just behind the tallest trees; the menace was gone. On the contrary, the trees, the bushes and the small plants welcomed you. You were among your friends, you felt completely safe and most welcome. The woods accepted you and every evening it was a pleasure to walk there.

那天傍晚，漫步林间，一种不祥的预感油然而生。夕阳西下，棕榈树孤零零地映衬着金色的西天。猴子们栖息在榕树上，准备迎接夜晚的到来。这条小路几乎无人问津，也难得一遇人。林间有很多鹿，它们胆怯地消失在茂密的树丛中。然而，那股不祥的预感却挥之不去，沉重而弥漫：它无处不在，让人不禁回头张望。这里并没有危险的动物；它们早已迁徙离开；这里离不断扩张的城镇太近了。人们庆幸能够离开，走回灯火通明的街道。但第二天傍晚，猴子和鹿依然在那里，太阳也隐没在最高的树后；那股不祥的预感消失了。相反，树木、灌木和小植物都热情地欢迎着你。你仿佛置身于朋友之中，感到无比安全，倍感温暖。森林接纳了你，每天傍晚漫步其中都是一种享受。

Forests are different. There’s physical danger there, not only from snakes but from tigers that were known to be there. As one walked there one afternoon there was suddenly an abnormal silence; the birds stopped chattering, the monkeys were absolutely still and everything seemed to be holding its breath. One stood still. And, as suddenly, everything came to life; the monkeys were playing and teasing each other, birds began their evening chatter, and one was aware the danger had passed.

森林则截然不同。那里危机四伏，不仅有蛇出没，还有老虎出没。一天下午，有人在森林里散步，突然间，周围一片异常的寂静：鸟儿停止了鸣叫，猴子们一动不动，仿佛万物都屏住了呼吸。他停下脚步，静静地站在那里。突然间，一切都恢复了生机：猴子们嬉戏打闹，鸟儿们开始鸣叫，这时他才意识到，危险已经过去。

In the woods and groves where man kills rabbits, pheasants, squirrels, there’s quite a different atmosphere. You are entering into a world where man has been, with his gun and peculiar violence. Then the woods lose their tenderness, their welcome, and here some beauty has been lost and that happy whisper has gone.

在人类猎杀兔子、野鸡、松鼠的树林里，气氛截然不同。你仿佛进入了一个人类曾经存在过的世界，那里充斥着枪支和独特的暴力。在那里，树林失去了温柔，失去了亲切，某种美感消逝了，那令人愉悦的低语也消失了。

You have only one head and look after it, for it’s a marvelous thing. No machinery, no electronic computers can compare with it. It’s so vast, so complex, so utterly capable, subtle, and productive. It’s the storehouse of experience, knowledge, memory. All thought springs from it. What it has put together is quite incredible: the mischief, the confusion, the sorrows, the wars, the corruptions, the illusions, the ideals, the pain and misery, the great cathedrals, the lovely mosques, and the sacred temples. It is fantastic what it has done and what it can do. But one thing it apparently cannot do: change completely its behavior in its relationship to another head, to another man. Neither punishment nor reward seem to change its behavior; knowledge doesn’t seem to transform its conduct. The me and the you remain. It never realizes that the me is the you, that the observer is the observed. Its love is its degeneration; its pleasure is its agony; the gods of its ideals are its destroyers. Its freedom is its own prison; it is educated to live in this prison, only making it more comfortable, more pleasurable. You have only one head, care for it, don’t destroy it. It’s so easy to poison it.

你只有一个脑袋，好好照看它，因为它是个奇妙的东西。任何机器，任何电子计算机都无法与之媲美。它如此庞大，如此复杂，如此全能，如此精妙，如此富有创造力。它是经验、知识和记忆的宝库。一切思想都源于它。它所创造的一切令人难以置信：恶作剧、混乱、悲伤、战争、腐败、幻觉、理想、痛苦和苦难、宏伟的大教堂、美丽的清真寺和神圣的寺庙。它所做和所能做的事情都令人惊叹。但有一件事它显然做不到：彻底改变它与另一个脑袋、与另一个人之间的关系。惩罚和奖励似乎都无法改变它的行为；知识似乎也无法改变它的行为。“我”和“你”依然存在。它从未意识到“我”就是“你”，观察者就是被观察者。它的爱是它的堕落；它的快乐是它的痛苦；它理想的神明是它的毁灭者。它的自由本身就是一座牢笼；它被训练成生活在这座牢笼里，只会让牢笼更加舒适、更加愉悦。你只有一个脑袋，要爱惜它，不要毁掉它。毒害它是如此容易。

He always had this strange lack of distance between himself and the trees, rivers, and mountains. It wasn’t cultivated: you can’t cultivate a thing like that. There was never a wall between him and another. What they did to him, what they said to him never seemed to wound him, nor flattery to touch him. Somehow he was altogether untouched. He was not withdrawn, aloof, but like the waters of a river. He had so few thoughts; no thoughts at all when he was alone. His brain was active when talking or writing but otherwise it was quiet and active without movement. Movement is time and activity is not.

他与树木、河流、山脉之间总是有一种奇特的疏离感。这种疏离感并非刻意营造：你无法人为地创造这种感觉。他与他人之间从未有过隔阂。无论别人对他做什么，说什么，似乎都无法伤害他，奉承也无法触动他。不知为何，他完全不受外界影响。他并非孤僻冷漠，而是像河水一般。他很少思考；独处时，他甚至一片空白。说话或写作时，他的大脑活跃；其他时候，它安静而活跃，却又仿佛静止不动。运动即时间，而活动则非时间。

This strange activity, without direction, seems to go on, sleeping or waking. He wakes up often with that activity of meditation; something of this nature is going on most of the time. He never rejected it or invited it. The other night he woke up, wide awake. He was aware that something like a ball of fire, light, was being put into his head, into the very center of it. He watched it objectively for a considerable time, as though it were happening to someone else. It was not an illusion, something conjured up by the mind. Dawn was coming and through the opening of the curtains he could see the trees.

这种奇特的活动，没有方向，似乎无论睡着还是醒着都在持续进行。他经常在冥想中醒来；这种性质的活动几乎一直都在发生。他从未拒绝过它，也从未主动接受过它。那天晚上，他醒了过来，完全清醒。他意识到，某种像火球或光球的东西，正被放入他的头部，进入头部的中心。他客观地观察了相当长一段时间，仿佛这发生在别人身上一样。这不是幻觉，也不是头脑凭空想象出来的。黎明即将到来，透过拉开的窗帘，他看到了树木。

September 20, 1973

1973年9月20日

The river was particularly beautiful this morning; the sun was just coming over the trees and the village hidden among them. The air was very still and there was not a ripple on the water. It would get quite warm during the day but now it was rather cool and a solitary monkey was sitting in the sun. It was always there by itself, big and heavy. During the day it disappeared and turned up early in the morning on the top of the tamarind tree: when it got warm the tree seemed to swallow it. The golden green flycatchers were sitting on the parapet with the doves, and the vultures were still on the top branches of another tamarind. There was immense quietness and one sat on a bench, lost to the world.

今天早晨的河水格外美丽；太阳刚刚升起，照耀着树木和隐匿在树丛中的村庄。空气静谧无波，河面也平静得如同水面一般。白天会很热，但现在却有些凉爽，一只孤零零的猴子正坐在阳光下。它总是独自待在那里，体型庞大，身形沉重。白天它会消失不见，直到清晨才会出现在罗望子树顶上：天气一暖和，树仿佛就把它吞噬了。金绿鹟和鸽子栖息在树篱上，秃鹫则依然停留在另一棵罗望子树的枝头。周围一片寂静，有人独自坐在长椅上，仿佛与世隔绝。

Coming back from the airport on a shaded road with the parrots, green and red, screeching around the trees, one saw across the road what appeared to be a large bundle. As the car came near, the bundle turned out to be a man lying across the road, almost naked. The car stopped and we got out. His body was large and his head very small; he was staring through the leaves at the astonishingly blue sky. We looked up too to see what he was staring at and the sky from the road was really blue and the leaves were really green. He was malformed and they said he was one of the village idiots. He never moved and the car had to be driven round him very carefully. The camels with their load and the shouting children passed him without paying the least attention. A dog passed, making a wide circle. The parrots were busy with their noise. The dry fields, the villagers, the trees, the yellow flowers were occupied with their own existence. That part of the world was underdeveloped and there was no one or organization to look after such people. There were open gutters, filth and crowding humanity, and the sacred river went on its way. The sadness of life was everywhere, and in the blue sky, high in the air, were the heavy-winged vultures, circling without moving their wings, circling by the hour, waiting and watching.

从机场返回的路上，我们沿着一条绿树成荫的道路行驶，耳边是绿鹦鹉和红鹦鹉在树丛中尖叫。突然，我们看到路对面似乎有个大包裹。车子靠近后，才发现那包裹里躺着一个几乎赤身裸体的男人。车子停了下来，我们下了车。他身形庞大，脑袋却很小；他正透过树叶凝视着湛蓝的天空。我们也抬头去看他究竟在看什么，从路上看，天空确实湛蓝，树叶也确实翠绿。他身体畸形，人们说他是村里的一个傻子。他一动不动，车子只能小心翼翼地绕着他行驶。驮着货物的骆驼和喧闹的孩子们从他身边经过，却丝毫没有注意到他。一条狗经过，绕着他转了一大圈。鹦鹉们依旧叽叽喳喳地叫个不停。干涸的田野、村民、树木、黄色的花朵，都各自沉浸在自己的世界里。这片土地还很落后，没有人或组织来照顾这些人。那里有敞开的沟渠、污秽和拥挤的人群，而神圣的河流依然奔流不息。生活的悲伤无处不在，在蔚蓝的天空中，高高的空中，沉重的秃鹫盘旋着，翅膀纹丝不动，一盘旋一小时，等待着，注视着。

What is sanity and insanity? Who is sane and who is insane? Are the politicians sane? The priests, are they insane? Those who are committed to ideologies, are they sane? We are controlled, shaped, pushed around by them, and are we sane?

什么是理智，什么是疯狂？谁是理智的，谁是疯狂的？政客们理智吗？牧师们疯狂吗？那些忠于某种意识形态的人理智吗？我们被他们控制、塑造、摆布，我们理智吗？

What is sanity? To be whole, nonfragmented in action, in life, in every kind of relationship, that is the very essence of sanity. Sanity means to be whole, healthy and holy. To be insane, neurotic, psychotic, unbalanced, schizophrenic, whatever name you might give to it, is to be fragmented, broken up in action and in the movement of relationship, which is existence. To breed antagonism and division, which is the trade of the politicians who represent you, is to cultivate and sustain insanity, whether they are dictators or those in power in the name of peace or some form of ideology. And the priest: look at the world of the priesthood. He stands between you and what he and you consider truth, savior, God, heaven, hell. He is the interpreter, the representative; he holds the keys to heaven; he has conditioned man through belief, dogma, and ritual; he is the real propagandist. He has conditioned you because you want comfort, security, and you dread tomorrow. The artists, the intellectuals, the scientists, admired and flattered so much—are they sane? Or do they live in two different worlds—the world of ideas and imagination with its compulsive expression, wholly separate from their daily life of sorrow and pleasure?

什么是理智？理智的本质在于行动、生活以及各种人际关系中保持完整、不分裂的状态。理智意味着完整、健康和神圣。而精神错乱、神经质、精神病、失衡、精神分裂症，无论你如何称呼它，都意味着行动和人际关系（即存在本身）的分裂和瓦解。那些代表你们的政客们，他们的惯用伎俩是制造对抗和分裂，这无异于培养和维持疯狂，无论他们是独裁者，还是以和平或某种意识形态之名掌权的人。还有神父：看看神职人员的世界吧。他横亘在你和他以及你所认同的真理、救世主、上帝、天堂、地狱之间。他是诠释者，是代表；他掌握着天堂的钥匙；他通过信仰、教条和仪式来塑造人类；他是真正的宣传者。他塑造了你们，因为你们渴望舒适和安全，并且恐惧明天。艺术家、知识分子、科学家们，他们备受推崇和奉承——他们神志清醒吗？还是他们生活在两个不同的世界里——一个是充满思想和想象的世界，他们沉浸于这种世界，并进行着强烈的表达，这与他们充满悲伤和快乐的日常生活完全割裂开来？

The world about you is fragmented and so are you and its expression is conflict, confusion, and misery: you are the world and the world is you. Sanity is to live a life of action without conflict. Action and idea are contradictory. Seeing is the doing and not ideation first and action according to the conclusion. This breeds conflict. The analyzer himself is the analyzed. When the analyzer separates himself as something different from the analyzed, he begets conflict, and conflict is the area of the unbalanced. The observer is the observed and therein lies sanity, the whole, and with the holy is love.

你周围的世界支离破碎，你自身亦是如此，而这种支离破碎的表现形式便是冲突、混乱和痛苦：你即世界，世界即你。理智在于过一种没有冲突的行动生活。行动与理念是矛盾的。观察即行动，而非先构思再根据结论行动。后者会滋生冲突。分析者本身就是被分析的对象。当分析者将自身与被分析的对象区分开来时，冲突便会产生，而冲突正是失衡的体现。观察者即是被观察的对象，而理智、完整便蕴藏其中，神圣之中亦有爱。

September 27, 1973

1973年9月27日

It was a temple in ruins, with its roofless long corridors, gates, headless statues, and deserted courtyards. It had become a sanctuary for birds and monkeys, parrots and doves. Some of the headless statues were still massive in their beauty; they had a still dignity. The whole place was surprisingly clean and one could sit on the ground to watch the monkeys and chattering birds. Once, very long ago, the temple must have been a flourishing place with thousands of worshipers, with garlands, incense, and prayer. Their atmosphere was still there, their hopes, fears, and their reverence. The holy sanctuary was gone long ago. Now the monkeys disappeared as it was growing hot, but the parrots and doves had their nests in the holes and crevices of the high walls. This old ruined temple was too far away for the villagers to further destroy it. Had they come they would have desecrated the emptiness.

那是一座破败的寺庙，长长的走廊没有了屋顶，大门残破，无头的雕像散落一地，庭院也空无一人。这里成了鸟猴、鹦鹉和鸽子的栖身之所。有些无头雕像依然雄伟壮丽，散发着一种静谧的尊严。整个地方出奇地干净，人们可以坐在地上，观赏猴子和叽叽喳喳的鸟儿。很久很久以前，这座寺庙一定曾是香火鼎盛的圣地，成千上万的信徒前来朝拜，花环飘香，祈祷声此起彼伏。昔日的氛围、希望、恐惧和敬畏之情依然萦绕于此。神圣的殿堂早已不复存在。如今，随着天气转热，猴子们也渐渐消失，而鹦鹉和鸽子则在高墙的缝隙和洞穴里筑巢。这座古老的寺庙遗址离村民们太远了，他们不会再去破坏它。如果他们来了，只会玷污这片空旷的土地。

Religion has become superstition and image-worship, belief and ritual. It has lost the beauty of truth; incense has taken the place of reality. Instead of direct perception there is in its place the image carved by the hand or the mind. The only concern of religion is the total transformation of man. And all the circus that goes on around it is nonsense. That’s why the truth is not to be found in any temple, church, or mosque, however beautiful they are. Beauty of truth and the beauty of stone are two different things. One opens the door to the immeasurable and the other to the imprisonment of man; the one to freedom and the other to the bondage of thought. Romanticism and sentimentality deny the very nature of religion, nor is it a plaything of the intellect. Knowledge in the area of action is necessary to function efficiently and objectively, but knowledge is not the means of the transformation of man; knowledge is the structure of thought and thought is the dull repetition of the known, however modified and enlarged. There is no freedom through the ways of thought, the known.

宗教已沦为迷信和偶像崇拜，沦为信仰和仪式。它失去了真理之美；香火取代了现实。直接的感知被手工或头脑雕刻的形象所取代。宗教唯一关注的是人的彻底改造。而围绕它的一切喧嚣都是无稽之谈。因此，无论寺庙、教堂还是清真寺多么美丽，真理都无处可寻。真理之美与石头之美截然不同。前者开启通往无限的大门，后者则将人囚禁；前者通往自由，后者则将人束缚于思想的枷锁之中。浪漫主义和感伤主义否定了宗教的本质，宗教也并非智力的玩物。行动领域的知识对于高效客观地行事固然必要，但知识并非改造人的手段；知识是思想的结构，而思想是对已知事物的枯燥重复，无论这些重复如何修改和扩展。通过既有的思维方式和已知事物，无法获得自由。

The long snake lay very still along the dry ridge of the rice fields, lusciously green and bright in the morning sun. Probably it was resting or waiting for some careless frog. Frogs were being shipped then to Europe to be eaten as a delicacy. The snake was long and yellowish, and very still; it was almost the color of the dry earth, hard to see, but the light of day was in its dark eyes. The only thing that was moving, in and out, was its black tongue. It could not have been aware of the watcher who was somewhat behind its head. Death was everywhere that morning. You could hear it in the village; the great sobs as the body, wrapped in a cloth, was being carried out; a kite was streaking down on a bird; some animal was being killed; you heard its agonizing cries. So it went on day after day: death is always everywhere, as sorrow is.

那条长蛇静静地躺在稻田干涸的田埂上，稻田在晨光中显得格外翠绿明亮。它或许是在休息，或许是在等待某个粗心的青蛙。那时，青蛙正被运往欧洲，作为美味佳肴食用。这条蛇又长又黄，一动不动；它的颜色几乎和干涸的泥土一样，难以辨认，但它那双深邃的眼睛里却闪烁着日光。唯一在动的，是它那黑色的舌头，时而伸进，时而伸出。它不可能察觉到身后有人在注视着它。那天早晨，死亡无处不在。在村子里，你能听到死亡的气息：裹着布的尸体被抬出去时，人们发出阵阵啜泣；一只风筝呼啸着砸向一只鸟；某种动物被杀死了；你能听到它痛苦的哀鸣。日复一日，死亡如影随形，悲伤也无处不在。

The beauty of truth and its subtleties are not in belief and dogma, they never are where man can find them for there is no path to its beauty; it is not a fixed point, a haven of shelter. It has its own tenderness, whose love is not to be measured; nor can you hold it, experience it. It has no market value to be used and put aside. It is there when the mind and heart are empty of the things of thought. The monk or the poor man are not near it, nor the rich; neither the intellectual nor the gifted can touch it. The one who says he knows has never come near it. Be far away from the world and yet live it.

真理之美及其精妙之处，不在于信仰和教条，它们也从不在人所能寻觅之处，因为通往真理之美的道路并不存在；它并非固定的点，也非避风港。它拥有自身的温柔，那份爱无法衡量；你既无法拥有它，也无法体验它。它没有市场价值，可以被利用和弃置。当心灵和思想空无一物时，它便会显现。僧侣或穷人无法接近它，富人亦然；知识分子或天才也无法触及它。自称知晓真理的人，从未真正接近过它。远离尘世，却仍能活在其中。

The parrots were screeching and fluttering around the tamarind tree that morning; they begin early their restless activity, with their coming and going. They were bright streaks of green with strong, red, curved beaks. They never seemed to fly straight but always zigzagging, shrieking as they flew. Occasionally they would come to sit on the parapet of the veranda; then you could watch them, but not for long; they would be off again with their crazy and noisy flight. Their only enemy seemed to be man. He puts them in a cage.

那天清晨，鹦鹉们在罗望子树周围尖叫着、扑腾着翅膀；它们一大早就开始躁动不安地飞来飞去。它们羽毛翠绿，喙又粗又红，弯曲有力。它们似乎从来不直线飞行，总是之字形飞行，边飞边尖叫。偶尔，它们会飞到阳台的栏杆上栖息；这时你可以观察它们，但时间不长；它们又会飞走，继续疯狂而喧闹地飞行。它们唯一的敌人似乎就是人类。人类把它们关进了笼子里。

October 4, 1973

1973年10月4日

As a young boy, he used to sit by himself under a large tree near a pond in which lotuses grew; they were pink and had a strong smell. [Krishnamurti is describing his own childhood.] From the shade of that spacious tree, he would watch the thin, green snakes and the chameleons, the frogs and the water snakes. His brother, with others, would come to take him home. It was a pleasant place under the tree, with the river and the pond. There seemed to be so much space, and in this the tree made its own space. Everything needs space. All those birds on telegraph wires, sitting so equally spaced on a quiet evening, make the space for the heavens.

小时候，他常独自坐在池塘边一棵大树下，池塘里长满了粉红色的莲花，散发着浓郁的香气。[克里希那穆提在描述自己的童年。] 在那棵枝繁叶茂的大树荫下，他会观察细长的绿蛇、变色龙、青蛙和水蛇。他的哥哥和其他小伙伴会来接他回家。树下是个令人愉悦的地方，有河流和池塘相伴。那里似乎有大片的空间，而大树也占据了这片空间。万物都需要空间。那些栖息在电线上的鸟儿，在静谧的夜晚均匀地排列着，它们为苍穹创造了空间。

The two brothers would sit with many others in the room with pictures; there would be a chant in Sanskrit and then complete silence; it was the evening meditation. The younger brother would go to sleep and roll over and wake up only when the others got up to leave. The room was not too large and within its walls were the pictures, the images of the sacred. Within the narrow confines of a temple or church, man gives form to the vast movement of space. It is like this everywhere; in the mosque it is held in the graceful lines of words. Love needs great space.

两兄弟会和许多其他人一起坐在挂满照片的房间里；房间里会响起梵文吟诵，然后一片寂静；这是晚间冥想。弟弟会睡着，翻个身，直到其他人起身离开才醒来。房间不大，墙壁上挂满了照片，神圣的影像。在寺庙或教堂狭小的空间里，人赋予了广阔的空间以形式。这在任何地方都是如此；在清真寺里，它体现在优美的经文中。爱需要广阔的空间。

To that pond would come snakes and occasionally people; it had stone steps leading down to the water where grew the lotus. The space that thought creates is measurable and so is limited; cultures and religions are its product. But the mind is filled with thought and is made up of thought; its consciousness is the structure of thought, having little space within it. But this space is the movement of time, from here to there, from its center toward its outer lines of consciousness, narrow or expanding. The space which the center makes for itself is its own prison. Its relationships are from this narrow space but there must be space to live; that of the mind denies living. Living within the narrow confines of the center is strife, pain, and sorrow and that is not living.

蛇会游到那个池塘边，偶尔也会有人来；池塘边有石阶通往水边，莲花就生长在那里。思想创造的空间是可测量的，因此也是有限的；文化和宗教都是思想的产物。但心灵充满了思想，也由思想构成；它的意识是思想的结构，内部空间很小。然而，这个空间就是时间的流动，从这里到那里，从它的中心向外延伸的意识边界，或窄或宽。中心为自己创造的空间是它自身的牢笼。它的关系都源于这个狭窄的空间，但生活必须要有空间；心灵的空间否定了生活。生活在中心的狭小空间里是纷争、痛苦和悲伤，那不是生活。

The space, the distance between you and the tree, is the word, knowledge, which is time. Time is the observer who makes the distance between himself and the trees, between himself and what is . Without the observer, distance ceases. Identification with the trees, with another or with a formula, is the action of thought in its desire for protection, security. Distance is from one point to another and to reach that point time is necessary; distance only exists where there is direction, inward or outward. The observer makes a separation, a distance between himself and what is ; from this grows conflict and sorrow. The transformation of what is takes place only when there is no separation, no time, between the seer and the seen. Love has no distance.

你与树之间的空间，你与树之间的距离，就是语言，就是知识，而知识就是时间。时间是观察者，它在自身与树木之间，在自身与存在之间，制造了距离。没有观察者，距离便不复存在。认同树木，认同他人，认同某种公式，是思想出于寻求保护和安全感而采取的行动。距离是从一点到另一点，而到达那一点需要时间；距离只存在于有方向的地方，无论是向内还是向外。观察者制造了一种分离，一种自身与存在之间的距离；由此滋生冲突和悲伤。只有当观察者与被观察者之间不再有分离，不再有时间时，存在之物的转变才会发生。爱没有距离。

The brother died and there was no movement in any direction away from sorrow. This nonmovement is the ending of time. It was among the hills and green shadows that the river began and with a roar it entered the sea and the endless horizons. Man lives in boxes with drawers, acres of them, and they have no space; they are violent, brutal, aggressive, and mischievous; they separate and destroy each other. The river is the earth and the earth is the river; each cannot exist without the other.

兄弟去世，悲伤的情绪无法驱散。这种停滞不前，便是时间的终结。河流发源于群山绿荫之间，咆哮着奔向大海，奔向无垠的地平线。人类生活在层层叠叠的盒子里，空间狭小，毫无容身之处；他们暴力、残暴、好斗、邪恶；他们彼此分离，互相毁灭。河流即大地，大地即河流；二者缺一不可。

There are no ends to words but communication is verbal and nonverbal. The hearing of the word is one thing and the hearing of no word is another; the one is irrelevant, superficial, leading to inaction; the other is nonfragmentary action, the flowering of goodness. Words have given beautiful walls but no space. Remembrance, imagination, are the pain of pleasure, and love is not pleasure.

言语无穷无尽，但沟通既有口头的，也有非口头的。听到言语是一回事，没有听到言语又是另一回事；前者无关紧要、流于表面，导致无所作为；后者则是不间断的行动，是善意的绽放。言语筑起了美丽的墙壁，却无法创造空间。回忆、想象，是快乐的痛苦，而爱并非快乐本身。

The long, thin, green snake was there that morning; it was delicate and almost lost among the green leaves; it would be there, motionless, waiting and watching. The large head of the chameleon was showing; it lay along a branch; it changed its colors quite often.

那条细长的绿蛇那天早晨就在那里；它身形纤细，几乎隐没在绿叶之中；它会一直待在那里，一动不动，等待着，观察着。变色龙硕大的脑袋露了出来；它趴在一根树枝上；它经常变换颜色。

April 10, 1975

1975年4月10日

In the silence of deep night and in the quiet still morning when the sun is touching the hills, there is a great mystery. It is there in all living things. If you sit quietly under a tree, you would feel the ancient earth with its incomprehensible mystery. On a still night when the stars are clear and close, you would be aware of expanding space and the mysterious order of all things, of the immeasurable and of nothing, of the movement of the dark hills and the hoot of an owl. In that utter silence of the mind this mystery expands without time and space. There’s mystery in those ancient temples built with infinite care, with attention, which is love. The slender mosques and the great cathedrals lose this shadowy mystery for there is bigotry, dogma, and military pomp. The myth that is concealed in the deep layers of the mind is not mysterious; it is romantic, traditional, and conditioned. In the secret recesses of the mind, truth has been pushed aside by symbols, words, images; in them there is no mystery, they are the churnings of thought. In knowledge and its action there is wonder, appreciation, and delight. But mystery is quite another thing. It is not an experience, to be recognized, stored up, and remembered. Experience is the death of that incommunicable mystery; to communicate you need a word, a gesture, a look, but to be in communion with that, the mind, the whole of you, must be at the same level, at the same time, with the same intensity as that which is called mysterious. This is love. With this the whole mystery of the universe is open.

在深夜的寂静中，在清晨阳光轻抚山峦的静谧中，蕴藏着一种伟大的奥秘。它存在于万物之中。如果你静静地坐在树下，你会感受到古老的大地及其难以捉摸的神秘。在繁星点点的静谧夜晚，你会感知到宇宙的扩张和万物神秘的秩序，感知到无垠与虚无，感知到幽暗山峦的律动和猫头鹰的鸣叫。在那彻底的心灵寂静中，这种奥秘超越了时间和空间。那些精心建造的古老庙宇也蕴藏着奥秘，它们倾注了无限的爱与关怀。纤细的清真寺和宏伟的大教堂却失去了这种朦胧的奥秘，因为那里充斥着偏见、教条和军事化的排场。隐藏在心灵深处的迷思并非神秘，而是浪漫的、传统的、受制约的。在心灵的隐秘角落，真理已被符号、文字和图像所掩盖；它们之中并无神秘，它们只是思想的翻腾。知识及其运用中蕴含着惊奇、欣赏和喜悦。但神秘则截然不同。它并非一种体验，无需被认知、储存和记忆。体验会扼杀那不可言说的神秘；沟通需要言语、姿态、眼神，但要与之相通，你的心灵，你的整个身心，必须与那被称为神秘的事物处于同一层次、同一时刻、以同样的强度。这就是爱。由此，宇宙的全部奥秘都将揭开。

This morning there wasn’t a cloud in the sky; the sun was in the valley and all things were rejoicing, except man. He looked at this wondrous earth and went on with his labor, his sorrow and passing pleasures. He had no time to see; he was too occupied with his problems, with his agonies, with his violence. He doesn’t see the tree and so he cannot see his own travail. When he’s forced to look, he tears to pieces what he sees, which he calls analysis, runs away from it or doesn’t want to see. In the art of seeing lies the miracle of transformation, the transformation of what is . The “what should be” never is. There’s vast mystery in the act of seeing. This needs care, attention, which is love.

今天早晨万里无云，阳光洒满山谷，万物欢欣雀跃，唯独人例外。他望着这奇妙的大地，却依然埋头于劳作、悲伤和转瞬即逝的享乐之中。他无暇欣赏，只顾着自己的烦恼、痛苦和暴戾。他看不到那棵树，也就看不到自己的苦难。当他被迫面对时，他却将所见之物撕成碎片，称之为分析，要么逃避，要么选择视而不见。观看的艺术蕴藏着转变的奇迹，转变的本质。“应然”的事物永远不会存在。观看的行为本身就蕴含着巨大的奥秘。这需要关怀，需要关注，而这便是爱。

April 14, 1975

1975年4月14日

A very large serpent was crossing a wide cart road just ahead of you—fat, heavy, moving lazily; it was coming from a largish pond a little way off. It was almost black and the light of the evening seen falling on it gave to its skin a high polish. It moved in a leisurely way with lordly dignity of power. It was unaware of you as you stood quietly watching; you were quite close to it; it must have measured well over five feet and it was bulging with what it had eaten. It went over a mound and you walked toward it, looking down upon it a few inches away, its forked black tongue darting in and out; it was moving toward a large hole. You could have touched it for it had a strange attractive beauty. A villager was passing by and called out to leave it alone because it was a cobra. The next day the villagers had put there on the mound a saucer of milk and some hibiscus flowers. On that same road further along there was a bush, high and almost leafless, that had thorns almost two inches long, sharp, grayish, and no animal would dare to touch its succulent leaves. It was protecting itself and woe to anyone that touched it. There were deer there in those woods, shy but very curious; they would allow themselves to be approached but not too close and if you did they would dart away and disappear among the undergrowth. There was one that would let you come quite close if you were alone, bright-eyed, with its large ears forward. They all had white spots on a russet-brown skin; they were shy, gentle and ever-watchful, and it was pleasant to be among them. There was a completely white one, which must have been a freak.

一条体型巨大的蛇正横穿你前方宽阔的马车道——它肥胖、沉重，行动懒散；它来自不远处一个较大的池塘。蛇身几乎通体漆黑，傍晚的灯光洒在它身上，使它的皮肤闪闪发亮。它步伐悠闲，带着一种高贵的威严。你静静地站在那里观察它，它却浑然不觉；你离它很近；它肯定超过五英尺长，肚子鼓鼓囊囊的，显然是吃饱喝足了。它爬过一个小土堆，你朝它走去，俯视着它几英寸远的地方，它分叉的黑色舌头伸进伸出；它正朝着一个大洞游去。你几乎可以触摸到它，因为它有一种奇异的吸引力。一个村民路过，喊道别，说这是一条眼镜蛇。第二天，村民们在土堆上放了一碟牛奶和一些木槿花。沿着那条路再往前走，长着一丛高高的、几乎光秃秃的灌木，上面长着近两英寸长的尖刺，呈灰褐色，没有动物敢碰它肥美的叶子。它在保护自己，谁要是碰了它，必遭殃。那片树林里有鹿，它们既害羞又好奇；它们允许人靠近，但不能靠得太近，否则就会迅速逃走，消失在灌木丛中。有一只鹿，如果你独自一人，它会让你靠得很近，它眼睛明亮，耳朵竖在前面。它们都长着赤褐色皮肤上的白色斑点；它们害羞、温顺、时刻保持警惕，和它们在一起感觉很愉快。还有一只通体雪白的鹿，那一定是只异类。

The good is not the opposite of the evil. It has never been touched by that which is evil, though it is surrounded by it. Evil cannot hurt the good but the good may appear to do harm and so evil gets more cunning, more mischievous. It can be cultivated, sharpened, expansively violent; it is born within the movement of time, nurtured and skillfully used. But goodness is not of time; it can in no way be cultivated or nurtured by thought; its action is not visible; it has no cause and so no effect. Evil cannot become good, for that which is good is not the product of thought; it lies beyond thought, like beauty. The thing that thought produces thought can undo, but it is not the good; as it is not of time, the good has no abiding place. Where the good is, there is order, not the order of authority, punishment, and reward; this order is essential, for otherwise society destroys itself and man becomes evil, murderous, corrupt, and degenerate. For man is society; they are inseparable. The law of the good is everlasting, unchanging and timeless. Stability is its nature and so it is utterly secure. There is no other security.

善并非恶的对立面。它从未被恶所触及，即便它身处恶的包围之中。恶无法伤害善，但善却可能看似作恶，因此恶变得更加狡猾、更加阴险。它可以被培养、强化、肆意蔓延；它诞生于时间的流逝之中，被滋养并被巧妙地运用。但善并非源于时间；它无法通过思想来培养或滋养；它的作用不可见；它没有原因，因此也没有结果。恶无法变成善，因为善并非思想的产物；它超越思想，如同美一般。思想所产生的事物可以摧毁思想，但它并非善；因为善并非源于时间，所以它没有永恒的居所。善所在之处，便是秩序，但并非权威、惩罚和奖赏的秩序；这种秩序至关重要，否则社会将自我毁灭，人类将变得邪恶、残暴、腐败和堕落。因为人即社会；二者密不可分。善的法则永恒不变，不受时间限制。稳定是其本质，因此它绝对安全。除此之外，别无其他安全可言。

#↩

KRISHNAMURTI TO HIMSELF

克里希那穆提自述

March 30, 1984

1984年3月30日

Walking down the straight road on a lovely morning, it was spring, and the sky was extraordinarily blue; there wasn’t a cloud in it, and the sun was just warm, not too hot. It felt nice. And the leaves were shining and a sparkle was in the air. It was really a most extraordinarily beautiful morning. The high mountain was there, impenetrable, and the hills below were green and lovely. And as you walked along quietly, without much thought, you saw a dead leaf, yellow and bright red, a leaf from the autumn. How beautiful that leaf was, so simple in its death, so lively, full of the beauty and vitality of the whole tree and the summer. Strange that it had not withered. Looking at it more closely, one saw all the veins and the stem and the shape of that leaf. That leaf was all the tree.

在一个美好的清晨，沿着笔直的道路漫步。那时正是春天，天空湛蓝得令人惊叹，万里无云，阳光温暖宜人，并不灼热。感觉真好。树叶闪闪发光，空气中弥漫着晶莹的光芒。这真是一个美得令人窒息的清晨。高耸入云的山峰巍峨险峻，山脚下的群山绿水葱茏，景色宜人。你静静地走着，漫不经心地，突然看到一片枯叶，黄红交织，那是秋天的落叶。这片叶子多么美丽啊，它凋零得如此简单，却又如此生机勃勃，充满了整棵树和整个夏天的活力与生机。它竟然没有枯萎，真是奇妙。仔细观察，你会看到它所有的脉络、叶柄和形状。这片叶子就是整棵树。

Why do human beings die so miserably, so unhappily, with a disease, old age, senility, the body shrunk, ugly? Why can’t they die naturally and as beautifully as this leaf? What is wrong with us? In spite of all the doctors, medicines, and hospitals, operations and all the agony of life, and the pleasures too, we don’t seem able to die with dignity, simplicity, and with a smile.

为什么人类的死亡如此悲惨、如此痛苦，伴随着疾病、衰老、老年痴呆、身体萎缩、容貌丑陋？为什么他们不能像这片叶子一样自然、优雅地死去？我们到底出了什么问题？尽管有医生、药物、医院、手术，经历了人生的所有痛苦和快乐，我们似乎仍然无法有尊严、平静、面带微笑地死去。

Once, walking along a lane, one heard behind one a chant, melodious, rhythmic, with the ancient strength of Sanskrit. One stopped and looked around. An eldest son, naked to his waist, was carrying a terracotta pot with a fire burning in it. He was holding it in another vessel and behind him were two men carrying his dead father, covered with a white cloth, and they were all chanting. One knew what that chant was, one almost joined in. They went past and one followed them. They were going down the road chanting, and the eldest son was in tears. They carried the father to the beach where they had already collected a great pile of wood and they laid the body on top of that heap of wood and set it on fire. It was all so natural, so extraordinarily simple: there were no flowers, there was no hearse, there were no black carriages with black horses. It was all very quiet and utterly dignified. And one looked at that leaf, and a thousand leaves of the tree. The winter brought that leaf from its mother on to that path and it would presently dry out completely and wither, be gone, carried away by the winds and lost.

有一次，我沿着一条小路走着，突然听到身后传来一阵吟唱，旋律优美，节奏明快，带着古老的梵语韵味。我停下脚步，环顾四周。只见一个赤裸着上身的长子，手里提着一个陶罐，罐里燃着火。他用另一个容器托着陶罐，身后跟着两个男人，抬着他父亲的遗体，遗体上盖着一块白布。他们都在吟唱。我听懂了那是什么吟唱，几乎就要跟着唱起来。他们走了过去，我跟了上去。他们沿着路走着，一路吟唱，长子泪流满面。他们把父亲抬到海滩上，那里已经堆好了一大堆木柴，我把遗体放在木柴堆上，点燃了它。一切都那么自然，那么简单：没有鲜花，没有灵车，也没有黑色马车。一切都那么安静，那么庄严。我看着那片叶子，看着树上成千上万片叶子。冬天把那片叶子从母叶带到了那条小路上，它很快就会完全干枯凋零，消失不见，被风吹走，最终遗失。

As you teach children mathematics, writing, reading, and all the business of acquiring knowledge, they should also be taught the great dignity of death, not as a morbid, unhappy thing that one has to face eventually, but as something of daily life—the daily life of looking at the blue sky and the grasshopper on a leaf. It is part of learning, as you grow teeth and have all the discomfort of childish illnesses. Children have extraordinary curiosity. If you see the nature of death, you don’t explain that everything dies, dust to dust, and so on, but without any fear you explain it to them gently and make them feel that the living and the dying are one—not at the end of one’s life after fifty, sixty, or ninety years, but that death is like that leaf. Look at the old men and women, how decrepit, how lost, how unhappy, and how ugly they look. Is it because they have not really understood either the living or the dying? They have used life, they waste away their life with incessant conflict, which only exercises and gives strength to the self, the “me,” the ego. We spend our days in such varieties of conflict and unhappiness, with some joy and pleasure, drinking, smoking, late nights, and work, work, work. And at the end of one’s life one faces that thing called death and is frightened of it. One thinks it can always be understood, felt deeply. The child with his curiosity can be helped to understand that death is not merely the wasting of the body through disease, old age, and some unexpected accident, but that the ending of every day is also the ending of oneself every day.

当你教孩子们数学、写作、阅读以及所有获取知识的技能时，也应该教他们死亡的尊严，不是把它当作最终不得不面对的病态不幸之事，而是把它当作日常生活的一部分——就像每天看着蓝天和树叶上的蚱蜢一样。这是学习的一部分，就像长牙和经历各种儿童疾病带来的不适一样。孩子们有着非凡的好奇心。如果你了解死亡的本质，你不会直接告诉他们万物终将消亡，尘归尘，土归土等等，而是会毫无畏惧地温柔地向他们解释，让他们感受到生与死是一体的——不是在五十年、六十年或九十年后生命的终结，而是像那片树叶一样自然而然地到来。看看那些老人，他们多么衰老，多么迷茫，多么痛苦，多么憔悴。是因为他们没有真正理解生与死的意义吗？他们虚度光阴，在无休止的冲突中浪费生命，而这些冲突只会强化自我、强化“我”、强化自我意识。我们终日沉浸在各种各样的冲突和痛苦中，偶尔也会有些许快乐和享乐，饮酒、吸烟、熬夜，以及没日没夜的工作。到了生命的尽头，我们不得不面对死亡，并对其感到恐惧。我们总以为死亡是可以理解的，可以深刻地感受到的。我们可以引导充满好奇心的孩子理解，死亡不仅仅是身体因疾病、衰老或意外事故而消亡，而是每一天的结束，也是我们自身的终结。

There is no resurrection; that is superstition, a dogmatic belief. Everything on earth, on this beautiful earth, lives, dies, comes into being and withers away. To grasp this whole movement of life requires intelligence, not the intelligence of thought, or books, or knowledge, but the intelligence of love and compassion, with its sensitivity. One is very certain that if the educator understands the significance of death and the dignity of it, the extraordinary simplicity of dying—understands it not intellectually but deeply—then he may be able to convey to the student, to the child, that dying, the ending, is not to be avoided, is not something to be frightened of, for it is part of one’s whole life, so that as the student, the child, grows up he will never be frightened of the ending. If all the human beings who have lived before us, past generations upon generations, still lived on this earth, how terrible it would be. The beginning is not the ending.

没有复活；那是迷信，是教条式的信仰。地球上的一切，在这美丽的地球上，都在经历生老病死，诞生，消逝。要领悟生命的这全部循环，需要的是智慧，不是思想的智慧，也不是书本或知识的智慧，而是爱与慈悲的智慧，以及其中蕴含的敏锐。可以肯定的是，如果教育者理解死亡的意义和尊严，理解死亡的非凡纯粹——不是从理性层面，而是从内心深处去理解——那么他或许就能向学生、向孩子传达这样的信息：死亡，也就是生命的终结，并非需要回避，也并非令人恐惧，因为它是生命的一部分。这样，随着学生、孩子长大成人，他们就不会再惧怕生命的终结。如果所有在我们之前、过去世世代代生活在这片土地上的人类都还活着，那该是多么可怕啊！开始并非结束。

And one would like to help—no, that’s the wrong word—one would like in education to bring death into some kind of reality, actuality, not of someone else dying but of each one of us, however old or young, having inevitably to face that thing. It is not a sad affair of tears, of loneliness, of separation. We kill so easily, not only the animals for one’s food but the vast unnecessary killing for amusement, called sport—killing a deer because that is the season. Killing a deer is like killing your neighbor. You kill animals because you have lost touch with nature, with all the living things on this earth. You kill in wars for so many romantic, nationalistic, political ideologies. In the name of God you have killed people. Violence and killing go together.

人们想要帮助——不，用词不当——人们想要在教育中将死亡带入某种现实，一种真实感，不是别人的死亡，而是我们每个人，无论老幼，都不可避免地要面对死亡。死亡并非悲伤的泪水、孤独和离别。我们如此轻易地杀戮，不仅为了食物而猎杀动物，还为了娱乐而进行大量不必要的杀戮，这种娱乐被称作运动——比如因为到了季节就猎杀一头鹿。猎杀一头鹿就像杀害你的邻居。你杀害动物，是因为你与自然失去了联系，与地球上所有生灵失去了联系。你为了各种浪漫的、民族主义的、政治的意识形态而在战争中杀戮。你以神的名义杀人。暴力和杀戮总是如影随形。

As one looked at that dead leaf with all its beauty and color, maybe one would very deeply comprehend, be aware of, what one’s own death must be, not at the very end but at the very beginning. Death isn’t some horrific thing, something to be avoided, something to be postponed, but rather something to be with day in and day out. And out of that comes an extraordinary sense of immensity.

当人们凝视着那片枯叶，欣赏它曾经的美丽与色彩时，或许会深刻地领悟到，死亡的真谛并非终结，而是开端。死亡并非恐怖之事，并非需要逃避或延缓之事，而是需要日复一日面对之事。由此，一种非凡的浩瀚感油然而生。

#↩

PART 3

第三部分

Life’s Questions

人生问题

As well as giving thousands of public talks and having many private discussions with individuals, Krishnamurti invited questions from those who attended the yearly gatherings in many countries. Even in later years, when the questions were written, rather than spoken from the audience, these were always explored afresh, spontaneously, “together as friends” as he often reminded his listeners.

除了发表数千场公开演讲和与个人进行多次私人讨论外，克里希那穆提还邀请参加每年在世界各地举行的聚会的人们提问。即使在晚年，问题不再由听众现场提出，而是以书面形式呈现，这些问题也总是能得到全新的、自发的探讨，正如他经常提醒听众的那样，“大家像朋友一样一起探讨”。

He was involved in frequent meetings and seminars with scientists, educators, and the students and staff members of the schools founded by the various Krishnamurti Foundations. He held dialogues with psychiatrists and psychologists, professionals of almost every kind, and with the trustees of the foundations responsible for arranging his talks and travels, disseminating the teachings and maintaining the schools.

他经常与科学家、教育家以及克里希那穆提基金会旗下各学校的学生和教职员工举行会议和研讨会。他与精神病学家、心理学家、几乎所有领域的专业人士以及负责安排他的演讲和旅行、传播教义和维持学校运营的基金会理事们进行对话。

Krishnamurti considered the proper education of the young to be of crucial concern for each generation. He inspired the founding of schools which bore his name in India, England, and the United States. Visiting them often, and sitting informally with students and teachers, he would talk with them of the need to learn about themselves. Beyond their becoming academically capable, he stressed the need to be whole and integrated human beings with a concern for all humanity and the global environment.

克里希那穆提认为，对年轻人进行恰当的教育对每一代人都至关重要。他启发了在印度、英国和美国创办以他名字命名的学校。他经常访问这些学校，与学生和老师们进行非正式的交流，探讨了解自我的必要性。除了培养他们的学术能力之外，他还强调他们必须成为身心健全、人格健全的人，并关心全人类和全球环境。

This part includes questions taken from accounts in The Collected Works , Beginnings of Learning , The Wholeness of Life , forty years of public meetings, as well as dialogues with students and teachers, and trustees of the various foundations. Each of these extracts conveys Krishnamurti’s eagerness to explore significant themes with openness, and his refusal to speak as an authority.

这部分内容包括摘自《全集》、《学习的开端》、《生命的完整性》、四十年来公开演讲的记录，以及与学生、教师和各基金会理事的对话。每一段摘录都体现了克里希那穆提渴望以开放的心态探索重要主题，以及他拒绝以权威身份发言的态度。

We are reminded that the answers are in the penetration of the questions themselves.

我们应该意识到，答案就蕴藏在问题本身之中。

#↩

WHAT IS IT TO BE SERIOUS?

认真到底意味着什么？

If we can begin by considering what it is to be serious, then perhaps our investigation into the whole process of our thinking and responding to the various challenges of life will have deeper significance.

如果我们能从思考什么是严肃开始，那么我们对思考和应对生活中各种挑战的整个过程的研究或许会具有更深远的意义。

What do we mean by being serious? And are we ever really serious? Most of us think very superficially; we never sustain a particular intention and carry it through because we have so many contradictory desires, each desire pulling in a different direction. One moment we are serious about something, and the next it is forgotten, and we pursue a different object at a different level. And is it possible to maintain an integrated outlook toward life? I think this is a fairly important question to consider because I wonder how many of us are serious at all? Or are we serious only about those things which give us satisfaction and have but a temporary meaning?

我们所说的“认真”究竟是什么意思？我们真的认真过吗？我们大多数人的思考都非常肤浅；我们从未真正坚持过某个特定的目标并将其付诸实践，因为我们内心充斥着太多相互矛盾的欲望，每个欲望都指向不同的方向。我们可能前一刻还对某件事很认真，下一刻就把它抛诸脑后，转而追求另一个层面上的目标。那么，我们是否有可能保持一种完整的人生观呢？我认为这是一个相当值得思考的问题，因为我不禁想知道，我们当中究竟有多少人是真正认真的？或者，我们是否只对那些能给我们带来满足感却又转瞬即逝的事物才认真？

So I think it would be very interesting not merely to listen to a talk which I happen to be giving, but earnestly to try to find out together what it means to be serious. When a petty mind gives its effort to being serious, its seriousness is bound to be very shallow because it is without any understanding of the deeper significance of its own process. One may give one’s energies to a particular object, spiritual or mundane, but as long as the mind remains petty, complex, without any understanding of itself, its serious activities will have very little significance. That is why it seems to me very important, especially at this time when there are so many complex problems, so many challenges, that a few of us at least should have a sustained interest in trying to find out if it is possible to be earnest or serious without being distracted by the superficial activities of the mind.

所以我认为，与其仅仅聆听我碰巧要发表的演讲，不如认真地共同探究“严肃”的真正含义，这将非常有趣。当一颗狭隘的心试图表现得严肃时，这种严肃必然肤浅，因为它对自身行为的深层意义一无所知。一个人或许会将精力投入到某个特定的对象，无论是精神上的还是世俗的，但只要他的心智依然狭隘、复杂，对自身缺乏了解，那么他所谓的严肃行为就毫无意义。正因如此，我认为，尤其是在当今这个充满诸多复杂问题和挑战的时代，我们当中至少应该有人持续关注并努力探究，是否有可能在不被肤浅的思维活动所干扰的情况下，真正做到严肃认真。

I don’t know if you are interested in this problem, but it is surely quite important to find out why most people are not really serious because it is only a serious mind that can pursue a particular activity to its end and discover its significance. If one is to be capable of action which is integral, one must understand the ways of one’s own mind, and without that understanding, merely to be serious has very little meaning. I wonder if any of you are following all this, and whether I am explaining myself?

我不知道你们是否对这个问题感兴趣，但弄清楚为什么大多数人并不真正认真对待某件事确实非常重要，因为只有真正认真的人才能将某项活动做到极致，并发现其意义。如果一个人想要做出完整而有意义的行动，就必须了解自己的思维方式；否则，仅仅认真对待这件事本身意义不大。不知道你们是否理解我的意思，我是否解释清楚了？

We see the disintegrating process that is going on in the world. The old social order is breaking down, the various religious organizations, the beliefs, the moral and ethical structures in which we have been brought up, are all failing. Throughout our so-called civilization, whether Indian, European, or whatever it be, there is corruption, and every form of useless activity is being carried on. So, is it possible for you and me to be aware of this whole process of disintegration and, stepping out of it as individuals, be serious in our intention to create a totally different kind of world, a different kind of culture, civilization? Do you think we could discuss this instead of my giving a talk?

我们目睹了世界正在发生的瓦解过程。旧的社会秩序正在崩溃，各种宗教组织、信仰、我们从小接受的道德伦理体系都在瓦解。在我们所谓的文明中，无论是印度文明、欧洲文明还是其他任何文明，都充斥着腐败，各种无用之事层出不穷。那么，你我是否有可能意识到这一瓦解过程，并作为个体从中抽身而出，认真地去创造一个截然不同的世界、一种截然不同的文化、一种截然不同的文明呢？你认为我们能否就此展开讨论，而不是让我发表长篇大论？

The problem is this: Being caught up in this social, religious, and moral disintegration, how can we as individuals break away and create a different world, a different social order, a different way of looking at life? Is this a problem to any of you, or are you content merely to observe this disintegration and respond to it in the habitual manner? Can we this evening discuss this problem together, think it right through, and resolve it in ourselves? Do you think it would be profitable to discuss what we mean by change?

问题在于：身处这种社会、宗教和道德的瓦解之中，我们作为个体该如何挣脱束缚，创造一个不同的世界、不同的社会秩序、不同的人生观？你们当中有人也面临这个问题吗？还是你们仅仅满足于旁观这种瓦解，并以惯常的方式应对？今晚我们能否一起探讨这个问题，深入思考，并在我们自身中找到解决之道？你们认为讨论一下“改变”的含义是否有益？

Questioner : Let us discuss seriousness.

提问者：我们来谈谈严肃性吧。

Krishnamurti : What do we mean by seriousness? To be serious, to be earnest, surely implies the capacity to find out what is true. Can I find out what is true if my mind is tethered to any particular point of view? If it is bound by knowledge, by belief, if it is caught in the conditioning influences that are constantly impinging upon it, can the mind discover anything new? Does not seriousness imply the total application of one’s mind to any problem of life? Can a mind which is only partially attentive, which is contradictory within itself, however much it may attempt to be serious, ever respond adequately to the challenge of life? Is a mind that is torn by innumerable desires, each pulling in a different direction, capable of discovering what is true, however much it may try? And is it not, therefore, very important to have self-knowledge, to be serious in the process of understanding the self, with all its contradictions? Can we discuss that?

克里希那穆提：我们所说的严肃是什么意思？严肃、认真，当然意味着有能力去探寻真理。如果我的思想被某种特定的观点所束缚，我还能探寻真理吗？如果它被知识、信仰所限制，如果它被不断影响它的制约因素所困，我的思想还能发现任何新的东西吗？严肃难道不意味着将我的思想完全投入到人生的任何问题中吗？一个只部分专注、内心充满矛盾的思想，无论它多么努力地想要严肃，真的能够充分应对人生的挑战吗？一个被无数欲望撕裂、每个欲望都朝着不同方向拉扯的思想，无论它多么努力，真的能够发现真理吗？因此，拥有自我认知，认真地去理解自我及其所有矛盾之处，难道不是非常重要的吗？我们能讨论一下这个问题吗？

Q : Would you kindly tell us if life and the problems of life are the same?

问：请问生活和生活中遇到的问题是否相同？

K : Can you separate the problems of life from life itself? Is life different from the problems which life awakens in us? Let us take that one question and follow it right through.

K：你能把生活中的问题和生活本身区分开来吗？生活和生活在我们心中唤起的问题有什么区别？让我们就这个问题展开讨论。

Q : What about the atomic and the hydrogen bombs? Can we discuss that?

问：原子弹和氢弹呢？我们可以讨论一下吗？

K : That involves the whole problem of war and how to prevent war, does it not? Can we discuss that so as to clarify our own minds, pursue it seriously, earnestly, to the end and thereby know the truth of the matter completely?

K：这涉及到战争以及如何防止战争的整个问题，不是吗？我们能否讨论这个问题，以便理清思路，认真、严谨地探讨到底，从而彻底了解事情的真相？

What do we mean by peace? Is peace the opposite, the antithesis, of war? If there were no war, would we have peace? Are we pursuing peace, or is what we call peace merely a space between two contradictory activities? Do we really want peace, not only at one level, economic or spiritual, but totally? Or is it that we are continually at war within ourselves and, therefore, outwardly? If we wish to prevent war, we must obviously take certain steps, which really means having no frontiers of the mind because belief creates enmity. If you believe in communism and I believe in capitalism, or if you are a Hindu and I am a Christian, obviously there is antagonism between us. So, if you and I desire peace, must we not abolish all the frontiers of the mind? Or do we merely want peace in terms of satisfaction, maintaining the status quo after achieving a certain result?

我们所说的和平究竟是什么意思？和平是战争的对立面吗？如果没有战争，我们还能拥有和平吗？我们追求的是真正的和平，还是我们所谓的和平仅仅是两种相互矛盾的行为之间的一种空间？我们真的想要和平吗？不仅仅是经济或精神层面的和平，而是全方位的和平？或者，我们内心深处其实一直处于战争状态，因此也对外在世界充满战争？如果我们想要避免战争，显然必须采取一些措施，这实际上意味着打破思想的界限，因为信仰会滋生敌意。如果你信仰共产主义，我信仰资本主义；或者你是印度教徒，我是基督徒，那么我们之间显然存在对立。所以，如果我们都渴望和平，难道不应该消除所有思想上的界限吗？或者，我们想要的和平仅仅是一种满足感，一种在达到某种结果后维持现状的和平？

You see, I don’t think it is possible for individuals to stop war. War is like a giant mechanism that, having been set going, has gathered great momentum, and probably it will go on and we shall be crushed, destroyed in the process. But if one wishes to step out of that mechanism, the whole machinery of war, what is one to do? That is the problem, is it not? Do we really want to stop war, inwardly as well as outwardly? After all, war is merely the dramatic outward expression of our inward struggle, is it not? And can each one of us cease to be ambitious? Because as long as we are ambitious, we are ruthless, which inevitably produces conflict between ourselves and other individuals, as well as between one group or nation and another. This means, really, that as long as you and I are seeking power in any direction, power being evil, we must produce wars. And is it possible for each one of us to investigate the process of ambition, of competition, of wanting to be somebody in the field of power, and put an end to it? It seems to me that only then can we as individuals step out of this culture, this civilization that is producing wars.

你看，我认为个人不可能阻止战争。战争就像一台巨大的机器，一旦启动，便会积蓄巨大的动力，而且很可能会继续下去，最终我们会被碾碎、被摧毁。但如果有人想要摆脱这台机器，摆脱整个战争的运作机制，那该怎么办呢？这才是问题的关键，不是吗？我们真的想要停止战争吗？无论是内心的还是外在的？毕竟，战争只不过是我们内心斗争的戏剧性外在表现，不是吗？我们每个人都能停止野心勃勃吗？因为只要我们野心勃勃，我们就会变得冷酷无情，这必然会导致我们与他人之间，以及不同群体或国家之间的冲突。这意味着，只要你我还在任何方向上追求权力——权力本身就是邪恶的——我们就必然会制造战争。我们每个人是否有可能去审视野心、竞争、渴望在权力领域有所作为的过程，并最终终结它呢？在我看来，只有到那时，我们个人才能走出这种制造战争的文化、这种文明。

Let us discuss this. Can we as individuals put an end in ourselves to the causes of war? One of the causes is obviously belief, the division of ourselves as Hindus, Buddhists, Christians, communists, or capitalists. Can we put all that aside?

让我们来探讨一下这个问题。作为个体，我们能否从自身做起，消除战争的根源？其中一个根源显然是信仰，是我们自身因宗教信仰而产生的分裂，例如印度教徒、佛教徒、基督教徒、共产主义者或资本家。我们能否将这一切抛诸脑后？

Q : All the problems of life are unreal, and there must be something real on which we can rely. What is that reality?

问：生活中所有的问题都是不真实的，一定存在一些真实的东西让我们依靠。那么，这种真实是什么呢？

K : Do you think the real and the unreal can so easily be divided? Or does the real come into being only when I begin to understand what is unreal? Have you even considered what the unreal is? Is pain unreal? Is death unreal? If you lose your bank account, is that unreal? A man who says, “All this is unreal; therefore, let us find the real,” is escaping from reality.

K：你认为真实与虚幻可以如此轻易地划分吗？还是说，只有当我开始理解什么是虚幻时，真实才会出现？你有没有想过什么是虚幻？痛苦是虚幻的吗？死亡是虚幻的吗？失去银行账户是虚幻的吗？一个说“这一切都是虚幻的，所以，让我们去寻找真实”的人，其实是在逃避现实。

Can you and I put an end in ourselves to the factors that contribute to war within and without? Let us discuss that, not merely verbally, but really investigate it, go into it earnestly and see if we can eradicate in ourselves the cause of hate, of enmity, this sense of superiority, ambition, and all the rest of it. Can we eradicate all this? If we really want peace, it must be eradicated, must it not? If you would find out what is real, what is God, what is truth, you must have a very quiet mind, and can you have a quiet mind if you are ambitious, envious, if you are greedy for power, position, and all that? So, if you are really earnest, really serious in wanting to understand what is true, must not these things be put away? Does not earnestness, seriousness, consist in understanding the process of the mind, of the self, which creates all these problems, and dissolving it?

你我能否从自身消除导致内外战争的因素？让我们来探讨这个问题，不仅仅是口头上的讨论，而是真正地去探究，认真地深入研究，看看我们能否根除自身仇恨、敌意、优越感、野心以及其他一切罪恶的根源。我们能否根除这一切？如果我们真的渴望和平，就必须根除这些罪恶，不是吗？如果你想探寻什么是真实，什么是上帝，什么是真理，你必须拥有一颗非常平静的心。如果你野心勃勃、嫉妒成性、贪婪权力、地位等等，你还能拥有平静的心吗？所以，如果你真的渴望、真的认真地想要了解什么是真理，难道不应该摒弃这些吗？真正的渴望和认真，难道不在于理解并化解产生所有这些问题的心灵和自我运作机制吗？

Q : How can we uncondition ourselves?

问：我们如何才能摆脱自身固有的条件？

K : But I am showing you. What is conditioning? It is the tradition that has been imposed upon you from childhood, or the beliefs, the experiences, the knowledge, that one has accumulated for oneself. They are all conditioning the mind.

K：但我现在要向你展示。什么是条件反射？它指的是你从小就被灌输的传统观念，或者你自身积累的信仰、经验和知识。它们都在制约着你的心智。

Now, before we go into the more complex aspects of the question, can you cease to be a Hindu, with all its implications, so that your mind is capable of thinking, responding, not according to a modified Hinduism, but completely anew? Can there be in you a total revolution so that the mind is fresh, clear, and, therefore, capable of investigation? That is a very simple question. I can give a talk about it, but it will have no meaning if you merely listen and then go away agreeing or disagreeing, whereas if you and I can discuss this problem and go through it together to the very end, then perhaps our talking will be worthwhile.

现在，在我们深入探讨这个问题的复杂层面之前，请先思考：你能否摆脱印度教的一切束缚，不再受其影响，从而使你的思想能够以全新的方式思考和回应，而不是按照某种改良后的印度教教义？你能否经历一场彻底的变革，使你的思想清新、澄澈，从而具备探究的能力？这是一个非常简单的问题。我可以就此展开讨论，但如果你只是听完后就表示同意或反对，那将毫无意义。然而，如果我们能够共同探讨这个问题，直至最终达成共识，那么我们的谈话或许才会有意义。

So, can you and I who wish to have peace, or who talk about peace, eradicate in ourselves the causes of antagonism, of war? Shall we discuss that?

那么，你我这些渴望和平或谈论和平的人，能否消除自身存在的敌对和战争根源呢？我们来讨论一下这个问题吧？

Q : Are individuals impotent against the atomic and hydrogen bombs?

问：个人是否对原子弹和氢弹无能为力？

K : They are going on experimenting with these bombs in America, in Russia, and elsewhere, and what can you and I do about it? So what is the point of discussing this matter? You may try to create public opinion by writing to the papers about how terrible it is, but will that stop the governments from investigating and creating the H-bomb? Are they not going to go on with it anyhow? They may use atomic energy for peaceful as well as destructive purposes, and probably within five or ten years they will have factories running on atomic energy; but they will also be preparing for war. They may limit the use of atomic weapons, but the momentum of war is there, and what can we do? Historical events are in movement, and I don’t think you and I living here in Banaras can stop that movement. Who is going to care? But what we can do is something completely different. We can step out of the present machinery of society, which is constantly preparing for war, and perhaps by our own total inward revolution, we shall be able to contribute to the building of a civilization which is altogether new.

K：他们在美国、俄罗斯和其他地方继续进行这些炸弹的试验，你我能做什么呢？那么讨论这件事的意义何在？你或许可以写信给报纸，讲述这件事有多么可怕，以此来引导舆论，但这能阻止各国政府继续研究和制造氢弹吗？他们难道不会继续下去吗？他们或许会将原子能用于和平目的，也可能用于毁灭性目的，而且可能在五到十年内，他们就会拥有以原子能为动力的工厂；但他们同时也在为战争做准备。他们或许会限制原子武器的使用，但战争的势头已经形成，我们又能做什么呢？历史的进程正在发生，我认为你我这些生活在瓦拉纳西的人无法阻止这一进程。谁会在乎呢？但我们可以做一些完全不同的事情。我们可以跳出当前社会这台不断备战的机器，或许通过我们自身的彻底变革，我们就能为建设一个全新的文明做出贡献。

After all, what is civilization? What is the Indian or the European civilization? It is an expression of the collective will, is it not? The will of the many has created this present civilization in India, and cannot you and I break away from it and think entirely differently about these matters? Is it not the responsibility of serious people to do this? Must there not be serious people who see this process of destruction going on in the world, who investigate it, and who step out of it in the sense of not being ambitious and all the rest of it?

毕竟，文明究竟是什么？印度文明或欧洲文明又是什么？它难道不是集体意志的体现吗？印度现今的文明正是由多数人的意志所创造的，难道你我难道不能摆脱它，以截然不同的视角看待这些问题吗？难道严肃的人不应该这样做吗？难道不应该有一些严肃的人，看到世界上正在发生的这种破坏进程，去探究它，然后以一种不带野心、不计较其他种种的方式，跳出这个进程吗？

What else can we do? But, you see, we are not willing to be serious, that is the difficulty. We don’t want to tackle ourselves, we want to discuss something outside, far away.

我们还能怎么办呢？但是，你看，我们都不愿意认真对待这件事，这就是问题所在。我们不想面对自己，我们只想讨论一些无关紧要的事情，一些遥远的事情。

Q : There must be some people who are very serious, and have they solved their problems or the problems of the world?

问：肯定有一些人非常严肃，他们解决自己的问题还是解决世界问题了？

K : That is not a serious question, is it? It is like my saying that others have eaten when I myself am hungry. If I am hungry I will inquire where food is to be had, and to say that others are well-fed is irrelevant; it indicates that I am not really hungry. Whether there are serious people who have solved their problems is not important. Have you and I solved our problems? That is much more important, is it not? Can a few of us discuss this matter very seriously, earnestly pursue it and see what we can do, not merely intellectually, verbally, but actually?

K：这不是个严肃的问题，对吧？这就像我说别人都吃饱了，而我自己却饿着肚子。如果我饿了，我会去问哪里有吃的，说别人吃饱了毫无意义；这说明我其实并不饿。有没有严肃的人解决了他们的问题并不重要。重要的是你我解决了自己的问题吗？这才是更重要的，不是吗？我们几个人能不能认真地讨论一下这个问题，认真地去探究，看看我们能做些什么，不仅仅是在理论上、在口头上，而是在实际行动上？

Q : Is it really possible for us to escape the impact of modern civilization?

问：我们真的有可能摆脱现代文明的影响吗？

K : What is modern civilization? Here in India it is an ancient culture on which have been superimposed certain layers of Western culture like nationalism, science, parliamentarianism, militarism, and so on. Now, either we shall be absorbed by this civilization, or we must break away and create a different civilization altogether. It is an unfortunate thing that we are so eager merely to listen, because we listen in the most superficial manner, and that seems to be sufficient for most of us. Why does it seem so extraordinarily difficult for us seriously to discuss and to eradicate in ourselves the things that are causing antagonism and war?

K：什么是现代文明？在印度，它是一种古老的文化，其上叠加了西方文化的某些层面，例如民族主义、科学、议会制度、军国主义等等。现在，我们要么被这种文明同化，要么就必须脱离它，创造一种完全不同的文明。不幸的是，我们如此热衷于倾听，因为我们只是以最肤浅的方式倾听，而这似乎对我们大多数人来说就足够了。为什么我们很难认真地讨论并根除我们自身那些导致对抗和战争的因素呢？

Q : We have to consider the immediate problem.

问：我们必须考虑眼前的难题。

K : But in considering the immediate problem you will find that it has deep roots; it is the result of causes which lie within ourselves. So, to resolve the immediate problem, should you not investigate the deeper problems?

K：但是，仔细思考眼前的难题，你会发现它根源很深；它是我们自身内在原因造成的。所以，要解决眼前的难题，难道不应该探究更深层次的问题吗？

Q : There is only one problem, and that is to find out what is the end of life.

问：只有一个问题，那就是如何定义生命的终点。

K : Can we discuss that really seriously, go into it completely, so that we know for ourselves what is the end of life? What is life all about, where is it leading? That is the question, not what is the purpose of life. If we merely seek a definition of the purpose of life, you will define it in one way and I in another, and we shall wrangle and choose which is the better definition according to our idiosyncrasies. Surely that is not what the question means. He wants to know what is the end of all this struggle, this search, this constant battle, this coming together and parting, birth and death. What is the whole of existence leading to? What does it mean?

K：我们能不能认真地讨论一下这个问题，彻底深入探讨，这样我们才能真正明白生命的终点是什么？生命的意义是什么，它最终会走向何方？这才是问题的关键，而不是生命的目的是什么。如果我们仅仅寻求对生命目的的定义，你会用一种方式定义它，我会用另一种方式定义它，然后我们就会争论不休，根据各自的喜好选择哪个定义更好。这肯定不是问题的本意。他想知道的是，所有这些奋斗、探索、持续不断的斗争、相聚与离别、生与死的最终结果是什么？整个存在的意义是什么？它究竟意味着什么？

Now, what is this thing which we call life? We know life only through self-consciousness, do we not? I know I am alive because I speak, I think, I eat, I have various contradictory desires, conscious and unconscious, various compulsions, ambitions, and so on. It is only when I am conscious of these, that is, as long as I am self-conscious, that I know I am alive. And what do we mean by being self-conscious? Surely, I am self-conscious only when there is some kind of conflict; otherwise I am unconscious of myself. When I am thinking, making effort, arguing, discussing, putting it this way or that, I am self-conscious. The very nature of self-consciousness is contradiction.

那么，我们称之为“生命”的东西究竟是什么呢？我们只有通过自我意识才能认识生命，不是吗？我知道我活着，因为我会说话，会思考，会吃饭，我有各种各样相互矛盾的欲望，有意识的，也有无意识的，还有各种各样的冲动、抱负等等。只有当我意识到这些的时候，也就是说，只要我保持自我意识，我就知道自己活着。那么，我们所说的自我意识又是什么意思呢？当然，只有当存在某种冲突时，我才会有自我意识；否则，我就意识不到自己。当我思考、努力、争论、讨论、这样那样地表达时，我就处于自我意识状态。自我意识的本质就是矛盾。

Consciousness is a total process, it is the hidden as well as the active, the open. Now, what does this process of consciousness mean, and where is it leading? We know birth and death, belief, struggle, pain, hope, ceaseless conflict. What is the significance of it all? To find out its true significance is what we are trying to do. And one can find out its true significance only when the mind is capable of investigation; that is, when it is not anchored to any conclusion. Is that not so?

意识是一个完整的过程，它既是隐秘的，也是活跃的，既是开放的。那么，意识的这个过程意味着什么？它又将引向何方？我们知晓生与死、信仰、奋斗、痛苦、希望、无休止的冲突。这一切的意义何在？探寻其真正的意义正是我们努力的目标。而只有当心灵具备探究的能力，也就是说，当心灵不执着于任何既定结论时，我们才能探寻其真正的意义。难道不是吗？

Q : Is it investigation, or reinvestigation?

问：是调查，还是重新调查？

K : There is reinvestigation only when the mind is tethered, repetitive and, therefore, constantly reinvestigating itself. But to be free to investigate, to find out what is true, surely that requires a mind that is not held in the bondage of any conclusion.

K：只有当思维受到束缚、陷入重复，因而不断地自我审视时，才会出现重新审视。但要自由地进行审视，探寻真理，无疑需要一颗不受任何既定结论束缚的心灵。

Now, can you and I find out what is the significance of this whole struggle, with all its ramifications? If that is one’s intention and one is serious, earnest, can one’s mind have any conclusion about it? Must one not be open to this confusion? Must one not investigate it with a free mind to find out what is true? So, what is important is not the problem but to see if it is possible for the mind to be free to investigate and find out the truth of it.

现在，你我能否探究这场斗争及其所有后果的意义所在？如果这是你的意图，并且你认真、诚恳地想要探究，你的头脑能否得出任何结论？难道你不应该对这种困惑保持开放的态度吗？难道你不应该以自由的头脑去探究它，找出真相吗？所以，重要的不是问题本身，而是你的头脑是否有可能自由地去探究并找出真相。

Can the mind be free from all conclusions? A conclusion is merely the response of a particular conditioning, is it not? Take the conclusion of reincarnation. Whether reincarnation is factual or not is irrelevant. Why do you have that conclusion? Is it because the mind is afraid of death? Such a mind, believing in a certain conclusion which is the result of fear, hope, longing, is obviously incapable of discovering what is true with regard to death. So, if we are at all serious, our first problem, even before we ask what this whole process of life means, is to find out whether the mind can be free from all conclusions.

人的心智能否摆脱一切结论？结论不过是对某种特定条件反射的回应，不是吗？以轮回转世为例。轮回转世是否属实并不重要。重要的是，你为何会得出这个结论？是因为心智惧怕死亡吗？这样的心智，执着于某种源于恐惧、希望和渴望的结论，显然无法探寻死亡的真相。因此，如果我们真的想认真思考这个问题，那么在我们探究生命的意义之前，首要问题便是：人的心智能否摆脱一切结论？

Q : Do you mean that for serious thinking the mind must be completely empty?

问：你的意思是说，要进行严肃的思考，大脑必须完全放空吗？

K : What do we mean by freedom? What does it mean to be free? You assume that if the mind is free, not tethered to any conclusion, it is in a state of vacuum. But is it? We are trying to find out the truth of what is a free mind. Is a mind free that has concluded? If I read Shankara, Buddha, Einstein, Marx—it does not matter who it is—and reach a conclusion or believe in a certain system of thought, is my mind free to investigate?

K：我们所说的自由是什么意思？自由的意义是什么？你认为，如果思想是自由的，不受任何结论的束缚，那么它就处于一种真空状态。但事实真是如此吗？我们试图探寻自由思想的真相。一个已经得出结论的思想是自由的吗？如果我阅读商羯罗、佛陀、爱因斯坦、马克思——无论他们是谁——并得出某个结论或相信某种思想体系，我的思想还能自由地进行探究吗？

Q : Has comparison no place in the process of investigation?

问：在调查过程中，比较难道没有作用吗？

K : Comparing what? Comparing one conclusion with another, one belief with another? I want to find out the significance of this whole process of life, with its struggle, its pain, its misery, its wars, its appalling poverty, cruelty, enmity; I want to find out the truth of all that. To do so must I not have a mind that is capable of investigation? And can the mind investigate if it has a conclusion, or compares one conclusion with another?

K：比较什么？比较一个结论和另一个结论，比较一种信念和另一种信念吗？我想探究整个人生过程的意义，包括它的挣扎、痛苦、悲惨、战争、骇人的贫困、残酷和仇恨；我想探寻这一切的真相。要做到这一点，难道我不需要一颗能够探究的头脑吗？如果头脑已经有了结论，或者只是将一个结论与另一个结论进行比较，它还能进行探究吗？

Q : Can a mind be called free if it has only a tentative conclusion?

问：如果一个人的思想只有暂时的结论，那么这个思想还能被称为自由的吗？

K : Tentative or permanent, a conclusion is already a bondage, is it not? Do, please, think with me a little. If one wants to find out whether there is such a thing as God, what generally happens? By reading certain books or listening to the arguments of some learned person, one is persuaded that there is God, or one becomes a communist and is persuaded that there isn’t. But if one wants to find out the truth of the matter, can one belong to either side? Must not one’s mind be free from all speculation, from all knowledge, all belief?

K：无论是暂时的还是永久的结论，它本身就是一种束缚，不是吗？请和我一起思考一下。如果一个人想要探究上帝是否存在，通常会发生什么？通过阅读某些书籍或聆听某些学者的论证，他要么被说服相信上帝存在，要么成为共产主义者，并被说服相信上帝不存在。但是，如果一个人想要探寻真相，他可以属于任何一方吗？难道人的思想不应该摆脱一切臆测、一切知识、一切信仰吗？

Now, how is the mind to be free? Will the mind ever be free if it follows a method to be free? Can any method, any practice, any system, however noble, however new or tried out for centuries, make the mind free? Or does the method merely condition the mind in a particular way, which we then call freedom? The method will produce its own results, will it not? And when the mind seeks a result through a method, the result being freedom, will such a mind be free?

那么，心灵如何才能获得自由？如果心灵遵循某种获得自由的方法，它就能获得真正的自由吗？任何方法、任何实践、任何体系，无论多么高尚、多么新颖，或者多么经过数百年实践，都能使心灵获得自由吗？或者，这种方法仅仅是以一种特定的方式约束心灵，而我们却称之为自由？方法本身会产生其自身的结果，不是吗？当心灵通过某种方法寻求结果，而这个结果就是自由时，这样的心灵就能获得真正的自由吗？

Look, suppose one has a particular belief, a belief in God, or what you will. Must one not find out how that belief has come into being? This does not mean that you must not believe, but why do you believe? Why does the mind say, “This is so”? And can the mind discover how beliefs came into being?

假设一个人持有某种信念，比如信仰上帝，或者其他什么。难道他不应该探究这种信念是如何产生的吗？这并非意味着你不应该相信，而是说你为什么会相信？为什么你的头脑会说“事情就是这样”？而你的头脑又能否发现信念是如何产生的呢？

You see insecurity in everything about you, and you believe in a Master, in reincarnation, because that belief gives you hope, a sense of security, does it not? And can a mind that is seeking security ever be free? Do you follow? The mind is seeking security, permanency; it is moved by a desire to be safe, and can such a mind be free to find out what is true? To find out what is true, must not the mind let go of its beliefs, put away its desire to be secure? And is there a method by which to let go of the beliefs which give you hope, a sense of security? You see, this is what I mean by being serious.

你觉得周围的一切都充满不安全感，你相信上师，相信轮回，因为这种信仰能给你带来希望和安全感，不是吗？一颗寻求安全感的心，真的能获得自由吗？你明白吗？心在寻求安全感和永恒；它被一种想要安稳的渴望所驱使，这样的心真的能自由地去探寻真理吗？为了探寻真理，心难道不应该放下它的信仰，放下它对安全的渴望吗？那么，有没有什么方法可以让你放下那些给你带来希望和安全感的信仰呢？你看，这就是我所说的认真。

Q : Are there periods of freedom in the conditioned mind?

问：在受制约的思维中，是否存在自由的时期？

K : Are there periods or gaps of freedom in the conditioned mind? Which is it that you are aware of, the freedom or the conditioned mind? Please take this question seriously. Our minds are conditioned, that is obvious. One’s mind is conditioned as a Hindu, as a communist, this or that. Now can the conditioned mind ever know freedom, or only what it imagines to be freedom? And can you be aware of how your mind is conditioned? Surely, that is our problem, not what freedom is. Can you just be aware of your conditioning, which is to see that your mind functions in a particular manner? We are not talking of how to alter it, how to bring about a change; that is not the question. Your mind functions as a Hindu or a modified Hindu, as a Christian or a communist; it believes in something. Are you aware of that?

K：在受制约的心灵中，是否存在自由的时期或空白？你意识到的是自由，还是受制约的心灵？请认真对待这个问题。我们的心灵是受制约的，这是显而易见的。一个人的心灵被制约为印度教徒、共产主义者等等。那么，受制约的心灵能否真正了解自由，还是只能了解它想象中的自由？你能意识到你的心灵是如何受制约的吗？当然，这才是我们的问题所在，而不是自由是什么。你能仅仅意识到你的心灵是如何受制约的吗？也就是说，你能意识到你的心灵以某种特定的方式运作吗？我们不是要讨论如何改变它，如何带来改变；这不是问题的关键。你的心灵以印度教徒或改良版的印度教徒、基督徒或共产主义者的方式运作；它相信某些东西。你意识到这一点吗？

Q : Freedom is not an acquisition but a gift.

问：自由不是一种获得的东西，而是一种恩赐。

K : That is a supposition. If freedom were a gift it would only be for the chosen few, and that would be intolerable. Do you mean to say that you and I cannot think it out and be free? You see, sir, that is what I am saying: we are not serious. To know how one is conditioned is the first step toward freedom. But do we know how we are conditioned? When you make a red mark on your forehead, when you put on the sacred thread, do puja , or follow some leader, are not those the activities of a conditioned mind? And can you drop all that so that in dropping it you will find out what is true? That is why it is only to the serious that truth is shown, not to those who are merely seeking security and are caught in some form of conclusion. I am just saying that when the mind is tethered to any particular conclusion, whether temporary or permanent, it is incapable of discovering something new.

K：那只是个假设。如果自由是一种恩赐，那它只会赐予少数人，而这令人无法容忍。您的意思是说，你我无法独立思考并获得自由吗？先生，您看，我的意思正是如此：我们不够认真。了解自身受制约的程度是通往自由的第一步。但我们真的了解自己受制约的程度吗？当你额头上点上红印，戴上圣线，进行祭祀，或者追随某个领袖时，这些难道不是受制约的心灵的行为吗？你能放下这一切，从而在放下的过程中发现真理吗？正因如此，真理只向认真思考的人显现，而不是向那些仅仅寻求安稳、被某种既定观念束缚的人显现。我只是想说，当心灵被任何特定的结论所束缚时，无论这个结论是暂时的还是永久的，它都无法发现新的事物。

Q : A scientist has data. Is he prepared to give up those data?

问：一位科学家拥有数据。他愿意放弃这些数据吗？

K : Are you talking as a scientist or as a human being? Even the poor scientist, if he wants to discover anything, has to put aside his knowledge and conclusions, because they will color any discovery. Sir, to find out, we must die to the things we know.

K：您是以科学家的身份还是以普通人的身份在说话？即使是可怜的科学家，如果他想有所发现，也必须抛开自己的知识和结论，因为它们会影响任何发现。先生，为了探寻真相，我们必须舍弃已知的一切。

Q : Can the unconditioning of the mind be done at the conscious or unconscious level, or both?

问：心灵的去制约可以在有意识的层面上进行，也可以在无意识的层面上进行，或者两者兼而有之？
