K : Sir, what is the mind? There is the conscious mind and the unconscious mind. The conscious mind is occupied with the everyday duties—it observes, thinks, argues, attends to a job, and so on. But are we aware of the unconscious mind? The unconscious mind is the repository of racial instinct, it is the residue of this civilization, of this culture, in which there are certain urges, various forms of compulsion. And can this whole mind, the unconscious as well as the conscious, uncondition itself?

K：先生，什么是心智？心智分为意识和无意识。意识负责日常事务——观察、思考、辩论、工作等等。但我们是否意识到无意识的存在？无意识是种族本能的储存库，是这种文明、这种文化的遗存，其中包含着某些冲动和各种形式的强迫。那么，整个心智，包括意识和无意识，能否摆脱自身的束缚呢？

Now, why do we divide the mind as the conscious and the unconscious? Is there such a definite barrier between the conscious and the unconscious mind? Or are we so taken up with the conscious mind that we have never considered or been open to the unconscious? And can the conscious mind investigate, probe into the unconscious, or is it only when the conscious mind is quiet that the unconscious promptings, hints, urges, compulsions come into being? So, the unconditioning of the mind is not a process of the conscious or of the unconscious; it is a total process which comes about with the earnest intention to find out if your mind is conditioned.

那么，我们为什么要将心智划分为意识和无意识呢？意识和无意识之间真的存在如此泾渭分明的界限吗？还是我们过于沉浸于意识之中，以至于从未考虑过或敞开心扉去接纳无意识？意识能否探究无意识，还是只有当意识安静下来时，无意识的提示、暗示、冲动和强迫才会显现？因此，心灵的解脱并非意识或无意识的独立过程；它是一个完整的过程，需要我们真诚地想要探寻自己的心灵是否受到制约。

Please look at this and experiment with it. What is important is the total, earnest intention to find out if your mind is conditioned so that you discover your conditioning, and do not just say that your mind is or is not conditioned. When you look into a mirror you see your face as it is; you may wish that some parts of it were different, but the actual fact is shown in the mirror. Now, can you look at your conditioning in a similar way? Can you be totally aware of your conditioning without the desire to alter it? You are not aware of it totally when you wish to change it, when you condemn it, or compare it with something else. But when you can look at the fact of your conditioning without comparison, without judgment, then you are seeing it as a total thing, and only then is there a possibility of freeing the mind from that conditioning.

请仔细观察并尝试一下。重要的是要全然真诚地去探究你的心智是否受到制约，从而发现这种制约，而不是仅仅断言你的心智是否受到制约。当你照镜子时，你看到的是自己真实的模样；你或许希望某些部分有所不同，但镜子里呈现的却是真实的自己。现在，你能否以类似的方式看待你的制约呢？你能否完全觉察到你的制约，而不想要改变它？当你想要改变它、谴责它或将它与别的事物进行比较时，你就无法完全觉察到它。但是，当你能够不带比较、不带评判地看待你的制约时，你才能将其视为一个完整的整体，也只有那时，才有可能将心智从制约中解脱出来。

You see, when the mind is totally aware of its conditioning, there is only the mind: there is no “you” separate from the mind. But when the mind is only partially aware of its conditioning, it divides itself, it dislikes its conditioning or says it is a good thing; and as long as there is condemnation, judgment, or comparison, there is incomplete understanding of conditioning and, therefore, the perpetuation of that conditioning, whereas, if the mind is aware of its conditioning without condemning or judging, but merely watching it, then there is a total perception, and you will find, if you so perceive it, that the mind frees itself from that conditioning.

你看，当心完全觉察到自身的制约时，就只有心本身，没有一个与心分离的“你”。但当心只是部分觉察到自身的制约时，它就会分裂自身，厌恶自身的制约，或者说它是好事；只要存在谴责、评判或比较，对制约的理解就不完整，因此制约也会持续存在。然而，如果心觉察到自身的制约，却不加以谴责或评判，而只是观察它，那么就存在一种完整的觉察。如果你这样觉察，你会发现心便能从制约中解脱出来。

This is what I mean by being serious. Experiment with this, not just casually, but seriously watch your mind in action all the time—when you are at the dinner table, when you are talking, when you are walking—so that your mind becomes entirely aware of all its activities. Then only can there be freedom from conditioning and, therefore, the total stillness of the mind in which alone it is possible to find out what is truth. If there is not that stillness, which is the outcome of a total understanding of conditioning, your search for truth has no meaning at all, it is merely a trap.

这就是我所说的认真对待。要认真地尝试，不是随意地，而是时刻认真地观察你的思维活动——在餐桌旁，在说话时，在走路时——让你的思维完全觉察到它的所有活动。只有这样，才能摆脱制约，从而达到心灵的完全平静，唯有在这种平静中，才能发现真理。如果没有这种平静（这是对制约的完全理解的结果），你对真理的探寻就毫无意义，只会陷入陷阱。

Banaras, India, January 9, 1955

印度瓦拉纳西，1955年1月9日

#↩

CAN WE CREATE A NEW CULTURE?

我们能否创造一种新文化？

I think that one of the greatest problems confronting man at this present time is the question of creativeness, how to bring about the creative release of the individual, and if we can consider the question, not merely verbally, but go into it very deeply, perhaps we shall be able to discover the full significance of that word creativeness . It seems to me that this is the real issue, not what kind of political reform to work for, or what kind of religion to follow. How is it possible to bring about the creative release of the individual, not only at the beginning of his existence, but throughout life? That is, how is the individual to have abundant energy rightly directed so that his life will have expansive and profound significance?

我认为，当今人类面临的最大问题之一是创造力问题，即如何激发个体的创造力。如果我们能够深入思考这个问题，而不仅仅是停留在口头上，或许就能发现“创造力”一词的全部意义。在我看来，这才是真正的问题所在，而不是应该推行何种政治改革，或者信奉何种宗教。如何才能激发个体的创造力，不仅在其生命之初，而且贯穿其一生？也就是说，如何才能使个体拥有充沛的精力，并正确地引导这些精力，从而使其生命具有广阔而深刻的意义？

I feel that revolution is necessary at the most profound level, not fragmentary revolution, but integrated revolution, a total revolution starting not from the outside but from within; and to bring about that total revolution, surely we must understand the ways of our own thought, the whole process of our thinking, which is self-knowledge. Without the foundation of self-knowledge, what we think has very little meaning. So it is important, is it not, that from the very beginning we should understand the process of our thinking, the ways of our mind; and the revolution must take place, not in any given department of thought, but in the totality of the mind itself. But before we go into that, I think it is essential to find out what it means to listen.

我认为，我们需要一场最深刻的革命，不是零散的革命，而是整体的革命，一场从内而外、彻底的革命；而要实现这场彻底的革命，我们必须理解自身的思维方式，理解我们思考的整个过程，也就是自我认知。没有自我认知的基础，我们的思考就毫无意义。所以，从一开始就理解我们的思维过程，理解我们心灵的运作方式，这难道不重要吗？这场革命必须发生在心灵的整体之中，而不是思想的某个特定领域。但在深入探讨之前，我认为至关重要的是要弄清楚倾听的意义。

Very few of us listen directly to what is being said, we always translate or interpret it according to a particular point of view, whether Hindu, Muslim, or communist. We have formulations, opinions, judgments, beliefs through which we listen, so we are actually never listening at all; we are only listening in terms of our own particular prejudices, conclusions, or experiences. We are always interpreting what we hear, and obviously that does not bring about understanding. What brings about understanding, surely, is to listen without any anchorage, without any definite conclusion, so that you and I can think out the problem together, whatever the problem may be. If you know the art of listening, you will not only find out what is true in what is being said, but you will also see the false as false and the truth in the false; but if you listen argumentatively, then it is fairly clear that there can be no understanding, because argument is merely your opinion against another opinion, or your judgment against another, and that actually prevents the understanding or discovery of the truth in what is being said.

我们当中很少有人真正倾听别人所说的话，我们总是根据某种特定的视角——无论是印度教、伊斯兰教还是共产主义——去翻译或解读。我们带着既定的观念、意见、判断和信仰去倾听，所以实际上我们根本没有真正倾听；我们只是在用自己的偏见、结论或经验去理解。我们总是在诠释我们听到的内容，而这显然无法带来理解。真正带来理解的，是抛开一切预设，抛开任何既定的结论去倾听，这样你我才能共同思考问题，无论问题是什么。如果你懂得倾听的艺术，你不仅能发现话语中的真伪，还能看穿谬误，在谬误中发现真理；但如果你带着争辩的心态去倾听，那么很显然，你不可能真正理解，因为争论不过是你的观点反对另一种观点，或是你对另一种观点的判断，而这实际上阻碍了我们对话语中真理的理解或发现。

So, is it possible to listen without any prejudice, without any conclusion, without interpretation? Because it is fairly obvious that our thinking is conditioned, is it not? We are conditioned as Hindus, or communists, or Christians, and whatever we listen to, whether it is new or old, is always apprehended through the screen of this conditioning; therefore, we can never approach any problem with a fresh mind. That is why it is very important to know how to listen, not only to what is being stated, but to everything. It is clearly necessary that a total revolution should take place in the individual, but such a revolution cannot take place unless there is effortless comprehension of what is truth. Effort at any level is obviously a form of destruction, and it is only when the mind is very quiet, not making an effort, that understanding takes place. But with most of us, effort is the primary thing; we think effort is essential, and that very effort to listen, to understand, prevents comprehension, the immediate perception of what is true and what is false.

那么，我们是否有可能做到不带任何偏见、不带任何结论、不带任何诠释地聆听呢？因为我们的思维显然是受制约的，不是吗？我们被印度教徒、共产主义者或基督教徒等身份所束缚，无论我们听到什么，无论是新的还是旧的，总是透过这种束缚的滤镜去理解；因此，我们永远无法以全新的视角看待任何问题。正因如此，学会聆听至关重要，不仅要聆听正在被讲述的内容，还要聆听一切。显然，个人需要经历一场彻底的变革，但除非能够毫不费力地领悟真理，否则这样的变革无法发生。任何程度的努力显然都是一种破坏，只有当心灵完全平静，不加任何努力时，才能真正理解。但对我们大多数人来说，努力才是最重要的；我们认为努力是必不可少的，而正是这种聆听、理解的努力，反而阻碍了我们真正理解，阻碍了我们对真假的直接感知。

Now, being aware of your conditioning, and yet being free of it, can you listen so as to comprehend what is being said? Can you listen without making an effort, without interpreting, which is to give total attention? For most of us, attention is merely a process of concentration, which is a form of exclusiveness, and as long as there is the resistance of exclusive thinking, a total revolution obviously cannot take place, and it is imperative, I feel, that such a revolution should take place in the individual, for only in that revolution is there creative release.

现在，意识到自身固有的思维模式，却又摆脱了它的束缚，你能否真正倾听并理解对方所说的话？你能否不加思考、不加诠释地倾听，也就是全神贯注？对我们大多数人来说，注意力仅仅是一种集中的过程，而集中本身就是一种排他性。只要排他性思维的阻力依然存在，彻底的变革显然就无法发生。我认为，这种变革必须在个体层面发生，因为唯有在变革中，才能获得创造性的释放。

So, the mind is conditioned by modern education, by society, by religion, and by the knowledge and the innumerable experiences which we have gathered; it is shaped, put into a mold, not only by our environment, but also by our own reactions to that environment and to various forms of relationship.

因此，人的思想受到现代教育、社会、宗教以及我们所积累的知识和无数经验的影响；它不仅受到环境的影响，而且受到我们自身对环境和各种关系的反应的影响，被塑造、定型。

Please bear in mind that you are not merely listening to me, but are actually observing the process of your own thinking. What I am saying is only a description of what is taking place in your own mind. If one is at all aware of one’s own thinking, one will see that a mind that is conditioned, however much it may try to change, can only change within the prison of its own conditioning, and such a change is obviously not revolution. I think that is the first thing to understand—that as long as our minds are conditioned as Hindus, Muslims, or what not, any revolution is within the pattern of that conditioning and is, therefore, not a fundamental revolution at all. Every challenge must always be new, and as long as the mind is conditioned, it responds to challenge according to its conditioning; therefore, there is never an adequate response.

请记住，你不仅是在听我说话，实际上是在观察你自身的思维过程。我所说的只是对你自身思维过程的描述。如果一个人对自己的思维有所觉察，就会明白，一个受制约的思维，无论它如何努力改变，都只能在自身制约的牢笼内改变，而这样的改变显然并非革命。我认为这是首先要理解的——只要我们的思维仍然受制于印度教、伊斯兰教或其他宗教的观念，任何革命都只能在既定的模式内进行，因此根本算不上根本性的革命。每一个挑战都必须是全新的，而只要思维仍然受制约，它就会按照既定的模式来应对挑战；因此，永远不存在完美的应对方式。

Now, we all know that there is a great crisis in the world at the present time; there is enormous poverty and the constant threat of war. That is the challenge, and our problem is to respond adequately, completely, totally to this challenge, which is impossible if we do not understand the process of our own thinking. Our thinking is obviously conditioned; we always respond to any challenge as Hindus, Muslims, communists, socialists, Christians, and so on, and that response is fundamentally inadequate; hence the conflict, the struggle, not only in the individual, but between groups, races, and nations. We can respond totally, adequately, fully, only when we understand the process of our thinking and are free from our conditioning, that is, when we are no longer reacting as Hindus, communists, or what you will, which means that our response to challenge is no longer based on our previous conditioning. When we have ceased to belong to any particular race or religion, when each one of us understands his background, frees himself from it, and pursues what is true, then it is possible to respond fully, and that response is a revolution.

现在，我们都知道当今世界正面临着一场巨大的危机：贫困现象极其普遍，战争的威胁也挥之不去。这就是我们面临的挑战，而我们的问题在于如何充分、全面、彻底地应对这一挑战。如果我们不了解自身的思维过程，这一切都无从谈起。我们的思维显然受到制约；我们总是以印度教徒、穆斯林、共产主义者、社会主义者、基督徒等等的身份来回应任何挑战，而这种回应从根本上来说是不够的；因此，冲突和斗争不仅存在于个人之间，也存在于群体、种族和国家之间。只有当我们理解自身的思维过程并摆脱制约时，我们才能做出全面、充分、彻底的回应。也就是说，当我们不再以印度教徒、共产主义者或其他任何身份来回应挑战时，我们对挑战的回应就不再基于我们以往的思维模式。当我们不再属于任何特定的种族或宗教，当我们每个人都了解自己的背景，摆脱它，并追求真理时，就有可能做出全面的回应，而这种回应就是一场革命。

It is only the religious man who can bring about a fundamental revolution, but the man who has a belief, a dogma, who belongs to any particular religion, is not a religious man. The religious man is he who understands the whole process of so-called religion, the various forms of dogma, the desire to be secure through certain formulas of ritual and belief. Such an individual breaks away from the framework of organized religion, from all dogma and belief, and seeks the highest; and it is he who is truly revolutionary because every other form of revolution is fragmentary and, therefore, inevitably brings about further problems. But the man who is seeking to find out what is truth, what is God, is the real revolutionary because the discovery of what is truth is an integrated response and not a fragmentary response.

只有虔诚的信徒才能带来根本性的革命，而仅仅拥有某种信仰或教条，隶属于某个特定宗教的人，并非真正的信徒。真正的信徒理解所谓宗教的整个运作过程，理解各种教条的形式，理解人们渴望通过特定的仪式和信仰形式来获得安全感。这样的人会挣脱有组织的宗教框架，摆脱一切教条和信仰，追求至高境界；他才是真正的革命者，因为其他任何形式的革命都是零散的，因此必然会带来更多的问题。而那些寻求探寻真理、探寻上帝的人，才是真正的革命者，因为对真理的发现是一个整体性的回应，而非零散的回应。

Is it possible, then, for the mind to be aware of its own conditioning and thereby bring about freedom from its conditioning? The mind’s conditioning is imposed by society, by the various forms of culture, religion, and education, and also by the whole process of ambition, the effort to become something, which is itself a pattern imposed on each one of us by society, and there is also the pattern which the individual creates for himself in his response to society.

那么，人的心智是否有可能意识到自身的制约，从而摆脱这种制约呢？心智的制约来自社会，来自各种形式的文化、宗教和教育，也来自整个追求抱负的过程——即努力成为某种人的努力，而这种抱负本身也是社会强加于我们每个人的一种模式；此外，个体在回应社会的过程中，也会创造出属于自己的模式。

Now, can we as individuals be aware of our conditioning, and is it possible for the mind to break down all this limitation so that it is free to discover what is truth? Because it seems to me that unless we do free the mind from its conditioning, all our social problems, our conflicts in relationship, our wars and other miseries, are bound to increase and multiply, which is exactly what is happening in the world, not only in our private lives, but in the relationship between individuals and groups of individuals, which we call society.

那么，作为个体，我们能否意识到自身受到的制约？心灵是否有可能突破所有这些限制，从而自由地发现真理？因为在我看来，除非我们能够将心灵从制约中解放出来，否则我们所有的社会问题、人际冲突、战争和其他苦难都必然会加剧和蔓延，而这正是当今世界正在发生的事情，不仅体现在我们的私人生活中，也体现在我们称之为社会的个体之间以及个体群体之间的关系中。

Taking that whole picture into consideration and knowing all the significance of it, is it possible for the mind to be aware of its conditioning and liberate itself? Because it is only in freedom that there can be creativeness, but freedom is not a reaction to something. Freedom is not a reaction to the prison in which the mind is caught; it is not the opposite of slavery. Freedom is not a motive. Surely, the mind that is seeking truth, God, or whatever name you like to give it, has no motive in itself. Most of us have a motive because all our life, in our education and in everything that we do, our action is based on a motive, the motive either of self-expansion or self-destruction. And can the mind be aware of and liberate itself from all those bondages which it has imposed upon itself in order to be secure, to be satisfied, in order to achieve a personal or a national result?

考虑到所有这些因素，并了解其全部意义，人的心灵是否有可能意识到自身的制约并自我解放？因为只有在自由中才能产生创造力，但自由并非对某种事物的反应。自由并非对心灵囚禁的牢笼的反抗；它并非奴役的反面。自由并非动机。诚然，寻求真理、上帝，或任何你喜欢赋予它的名称的心灵，本身并无动机。我们大多数人都有动机，因为我们一生中，在教育中，在所做的一切事情中，我们的行为都基于某种动机，要么是自我扩张，要么是自我毁灭。那么，人的心灵能否意识到并摆脱所有它为了获得安全感、满足感、为了实现个人或国家目标而强加于自身的束缚呢？

I think the revolution of which I am talking is possible only when the mind is very quiet, very still. But that quietness of the mind does not come through any effort—it comes naturally, easily, when the mind understands its own process of action, which is to understand the whole significance of thinking. So the beginning of freedom is self-knowledge, and self-knowledge is not in the withdrawal from life but is to be discovered in the relationships of our everyday existence. Relationship is the mirror in which we can see ourselves factually, without any distortion, and it is only through self-knowledge, seeing ourselves exactly as we actually are, undistorted by any interpretation or judgment, that the mind becomes quiet, still. But that stillness of mind cannot be sought after, it cannot be pursued; if you pursue and bring about stillness of mind, it has a motive, and such stillness is never still because it is always a movement toward something and away from something.

我认为我所说的这场革命只有在心灵非常平静、非常安宁的时候才有可能发生。但这种心灵的平静并非通过任何努力就能获得——它自然而然地到来，当心灵理解了自身的运作过程，也就是理解了思考的全部意义时，它便会水到渠成。因此，自由的开端是自我认知，而自我认知并非在于脱离生活，而是在我们日常生活的各种关系中发现。关系就像一面镜子，让我们能够客观地、毫无扭曲地看到自己。只有通过自我认知，看到我们真实的模样，不受任何诠释或评判的扭曲，心灵才能变得平静、安宁。但这种心灵的平静无法刻意追求，也无法刻意追求；如果你刻意追求并促成心灵的平静，它就带有某种动机，而这种平静永远不会真正静止，因为它始终是一种趋向某种事物或远离某种事物的运动。

So there is freedom only through self-knowledge, which is to understand the total process of thinking. Our thinking at present is merely a reaction, the response of a conditioned mind, and any action based on such thinking is bound to result in catastrophe. To discover what is truth, what is God, there must be a mind that has understood itself, which means going into the whole problem of self-knowledge. Only then is there the total revolution, which alone brings about a creative release, and that creative release is the perception of what is truth, what is God.

因此，唯有通过自我认知才能获得自由，即理解思维的整个过程。我们目前的思维仅仅是一种反应，是受制约的思维的回应，任何基于这种思维的行动都必然导致灾难。要发现真理，发现上帝，就必须拥有一个已经理解自身的心灵，这意味着要深入探究自我认知的整个问题。唯有如此，才能带来彻底的变革，唯有这种变革才能带来创造性的释放，而这种创造性的释放正是对真理和上帝的感知。

I think it is always important to ask fundamental questions: but when we do ask a fundamental question, most of us are seeking an answer, and then the answer is invariably superficial, because there is no yes or no answer to life. Life is a movement, an endless movement, and to inquire into this extraordinary thing called life, with all its innumerable aspects, one must ask fundamental questions and never be satisfied with answers, however satisfactory they may be, because the moment you have an answer, the mind has concluded, and conclusion is not life—it is merely a static state. So what is important is to ask the right question and never be satisfied with the answer, however clever, however logical, because the truth of the question lies beyond the conclusion, beyond the answer, beyond the verbal expression. The mind that asks a question and is merely satisfied with an explanation, a verbal statement, remains superficial. It is only the mind that asks a fundamental question and is capable of pursuing that question to the end that can find out what is truth.

我认为提出根本性问题始终至关重要：但当我们提出根本性问题时，大多数人都在寻求答案，而答案往往流于表面，因为生命没有非此即彼的答案。生命是一种运动，一种永无止境的运动，为了探究这名为“生命”的非凡事物及其无数层面，我们必须提出根本性问题，并且永远不要满足于答案，无论答案多么令人满意，因为一旦有了答案，思维就得出结论，而结论并非生命本身——它仅仅是一种静止的状态。因此，重要的是提出正确的问题，并且永远不要满足于答案，无论答案多么巧妙，多么合乎逻辑，因为问题的真谛超越了结论，超越了答案，超越了语言的表达。提出问题却仅仅满足于解释、满足于语言陈述的思维，始终停留在表面。只有提出根本性问题并能够追问到底的思维，才能发现真理。

Questioner : In India today we see a growing disregard of all sensitive feeling and expression. Culturally we are a feeble, imitative country; our thinking is smug and superficial. Is there a way to break through and contact the source of creativity? Can we create a new culture?

提问者：如今在印度，我们看到人们越来越忽视所有敏感的情感和表达。从文化上看，我们是一个软弱、模仿成性的国家；我们的思维自满而肤浅。有没有办法突破这种困境，触及创造力的源泉？我们能否创造一种新的文化？

Krishnamurti : Sir, this is not only a question for Indians, it is a human question; it is asked in America, in England, and elsewhere. How to bring about a new culture, a creativity that is explosive, abundant, so that the mind is not imitative? A poet, a painter longs for that, so let us inquire into it.

克里希那穆提：先生，这不仅是印度人的问题，也是全人类的问题；美国、英国和其他地方都在问这个问题。如何创造一种新的文化，一种爆发式、丰富的创造力，使人的思想不再是模仿的？诗人、画家都渴望这种文化，所以让我们来探究这个问题吧。

What is civilization, what is culture as we know it now? It is the result of the collective will, is it not? The culture we know is the expression of many desires unified through religion, through a traditional moral code, through various forms of sanction. The civilization in which we live is the result of the collective will, of many acquisitive desires and, therefore, we have a culture, a civilization, which is also acquisitive. That is fairly clear.

文明是什么？我们今天所知的文化又是什么？它难道不是集体意志的产物吗？我们所知的文化，是众多欲望通过宗教、传统道德准则和各种形式的制裁而统一起来的体现。我们所处的文明是集体意志的产物，是众多占有欲的产物，因此，我们拥有的文化、文明，也是一种占有欲的文化。这一点显而易见。

Now, within this acquisitive society, which is the result of the collective will, we can have many reformations, and we do occasionally bring about a bloody revolution, but it is always within the pattern because our response to any challenge, which is always new, is limited by the culture in which we have been brought up. The culture of India is obviously imitative, traditional; it is made up of innumerable superstitions, of belief and dogma, the repetition of words, the worship of images made by the hand and by the mind. That is our culture, that is our society, broken up into various classes, all based on acquisitiveness; and if we do become nonacquisitive in this world, we are acquisitive in some other world, we want to acquire God, and so on. So our culture is essentially based on acquisitiveness, worldly and spiritual; and when occasionally there is an individual who breaks away from all acquisitiveness and knows what it is to be creative, we immediately idolize him, make him into our spiritual leader or teacher, thereby stifling ourselves.

如今，在这个由集体意志造就的、充满占有欲的社会里，我们可以进行许多改革，偶尔也会爆发血腥革命，但这一切都遵循着既定的模式，因为我们对任何挑战（而挑战总是新的）的回应都受到我们成长文化的限制。印度的文化显然是模仿性的、传统的；它由无数的迷信、信仰和教条、词语的重复以及对手工和精神所创造的形象的崇拜构成。这就是我们的文化，这就是我们的社会，它被划分成不同的阶层，而所有这些阶层都建立在占有欲之上；即使我们在这个世界上变得不占有欲，我们在另一个世界里仍然会占有欲，我们想要获得神灵，等等。因此，我们的文化本质上是建立在占有欲之上的，无论是世俗的还是精神的。偶尔会出现一个摆脱一切占有欲，懂得创造的人，我们会立刻把他奉为偶像，把他当作我们的精神领袖或老师，从而扼杀了自己。

As long as we belong to the collective culture, collective civilization, there can be no creativeness. It is the man who understands this whole process of the collective, with all its sanctions and beliefs, and who ceases to be either positively or negatively acquisitive—it is only such a man who knows the meaning of creativeness, not the sannyasi who renounces the world and pursues God, which is merely his particular form of acquisitiveness. The man who realizes the whole significance of the collective, and who breaks away from it because he knows what is true religion, is a creative individual, and it is such action that brings about a new culture. Surely, that is always the way it happens, is it not?

只要我们身处集体文化、集体文明之中，创造力便无从谈起。唯有那些理解集体运作全貌及其所有准则和信条，并停止一切形式的占有欲（无论积极还是消极）的人，才真正懂得创造力的真谛。那些遁世修行、追求神的苦行僧，不过是他们占有欲的一种特殊表现形式。真正领悟集体意义，并因知晓真宗教而选择脱离集体的人，才是富有创造力的个体。正是这样的行动，孕育出新的文化。难道不是吗？

The truly religious man is not the one who practices so-called religion, who holds to certain dogmas and beliefs, who performs certain rituals or pursues knowledge, for he is merely seeking another form of gratification. The man who is truly religious is completely free from society, he has no responsibility toward society; he may establish a relationship with society, but society has no relationship with him. Society is organized religion, the economic and social structure, the whole environment in which we have been brought up, and does that society help man to find God, truth—it matters little what name you give it—or does the individual who is seeking God create a new society? That is, must not the individual break away from the existing society, culture, or civilization? Surely, in the very breaking away he discovers what is truth, and it is that truth which creates the new society, the new culture.

真正虔诚的人并非那些践行所谓宗教、恪守某些教条和信仰、举行某些仪式或追求知识的人，因为他们只不过是在寻求另一种形式的满足。真正虔诚的人完全脱离社会，他对社会没有任何责任；他可以与社会建立联系，但社会与他之间没有任何联系。社会是有组织的宗教，是经济和社会结构，是我们成长的整个环境。那么，这个社会究竟是帮助人找到上帝、真理——无论你如何称呼它——还是寻求上帝的个人创造了一个新的社会？也就是说，个人难道不应该脱离现有的社会、文化或文明吗？的确，正是在脱离的过程中，他发现了真理，而正是这真理创造了新的社会、新的文化。

I think this is an important question to ponder over. Can the man who belongs to society—it does not matter what society—ever find truth, God? Can society help the individual in that discovery, or must the individual, you and I, break away from society? Surely, it is in the very process of breaking away from society that there is the understanding of what is truth, and that truth then creates the ripples which become a new society, a new culture. The sannyasi , the monk, the hermit renounces the world, renounces society, but his whole pattern of thinking is still conditioned by society; he is still a Christian or a Hindu, pursuing the ideal of Christianity or of Hinduism. His meditations, his sacrifices, his practices, are all essentially conditioned and, therefore, what he discovers as truth, as God, as the absolute, is really his own conditioned reaction. Hence, society cannot help man to find out what is truth. Society’s function is to limit the individual, to hold him within the boundary of respectability. Only the man who understands this whole process, whose action is not a reaction, can find out what is truth, and it is the truth that creates a new culture, not the man who pursues truth.

我认为这是一个值得深思的重要问题。身处社会之中的人——无论属于哪个社会——能否找到真理，找到上帝？社会能否帮助个人发现真理？或者，个人，你我，必须脱离社会？诚然，正是在脱离社会的过程中，人们才能领悟真理，而真理又会激起涟漪，最终形成新的社会，新的文化。苦行僧、僧侣、隐士舍弃世俗，舍弃社会，但他们的整个思维模式仍然受到社会的制约；他们仍然是基督徒或印度教徒，追求着基督教或印度教的理想。他们的冥想、他们的奉献、他们的修行，本质上都受到制约，因此，他们所发现的真理、上帝、绝对，实际上只是他们自身受制约的反应。因此，社会无法帮助人发现真理。社会的功能在于限制个人，将他们束缚在体面的界限之内。只有理解整个过程的人，其行动不是反应，才能发现真理，而真理才能创造新文化，而不是追求真理的人。

I think this is fairly clear and simple; it sounds complicated, but it is not. Truth brings about its own action. But the man who is seeking truth and acting, however worthy and noble he may be, only creates further confusion and misery. He is like the reformer who is merely concerned with decorating the prison walls, with bringing more light, more lavatories, or what you will, into the prison, whereas, if you understand this whole problem of how the mind is conditioned by society, if you allow truth to act and do not act according to what you think is truth, then you will find that such action brings about its own culture, its own civilization, a new world which is not based on acquisitiveness, on sorrow, on strife, on belief. It is the truth that will bring about a new society, not the communists, the Christians, the Hindus, the Buddhists, or the Muslims. To respond to any challenge according to one’s conditioning is merely to expand the prison, or to decorate its bars. It is only when the mind understands and is free from the conditioning influences which have been imposed upon it, or which it has created for itself, that there is the perception of truth, and it is the action of that truth which brings into being a new society, a new culture.

我认为这相当清晰明了；听起来复杂，实则不然。真理自会引发行动。然而，那些寻求真理并付诸行动的人，无论其品德多么高尚，最终只会制造更多的混乱和痛苦。他们就像那些只关心美化监狱墙壁、增添更多光线、更多厕所或其他设施的改革者一样。然而，如果你理解了思想如何受社会制约的整个问题，如果你允许真理发挥作用，而不是按照你自认为的真理行事，那么你会发现，这样的行动会带来它自身的文化、它自身的文明，一个不建立在贪婪、悲伤、纷争和信仰之上的新世界。唯有真理才能带来新的社会，而不是共产主义者、基督徒、印度教徒、佛教徒或穆斯林。按照自身的固有观念去应对任何挑战，只不过是在扩建监狱，或者装饰它的牢笼。只有当心灵理解并摆脱了强加于它或它自己创造的制约因素的影响时，才能感知真理，而正是这种真理的行动创造了一个新的社会，一种新的文化。

That is why it is very important for a country like this not to impose upon itself the superficial culture of the West nor, because it is confused, to return to the old, to the Puranas, to the Vedas. It is only a confused mind that wants to return to something dead, and the important thing is to understand why there is confusion. There is confusion, obviously, when the mind does not understand, when it does not respond totally, integrally to something new, to any given fact.

因此，对于这样一个国家来说，至关重要的是既不要将西方肤浅的文化强加于自身，也不要因为迷茫而回归旧约，回归往昔，回归吠陀经。只有迷茫的心灵才会想要回归死寂的事物，而关键在于理解迷茫的根源。显然，当心灵无法理解，无法对新事物、对任何既定事实做出全面、完整的回应时，迷茫便会产生。

Take the fact of war, for example. If you respond to it as a Hindu who believes in ahimsa , you say, “I must practice nonviolence,” and if you happen to be a nationalist, your response is nationalistic, whereas the man who sees the truth of war, which is the fact that war is destructive in itself, and who lets that truth act, does not respond in terms of any society, in terms of any theory or reform. Truth is neither yours nor mine, and as long as the mind interprets or translates that truth, we create confusion. That is what the reformers do, what all the saints have done who have tried to bring about a reformation in a certain social order. Because they translate truth to bring about a given reform, that reform breeds more misery and hence needs further reform.

以战争为例。如果你是一个信奉非暴力（ahimsa）的印度教徒，你会说：“我必须践行非暴力。”如果你恰好是一个民族主义者，你的回应就是民族主义的。然而，真正看清战争真相——战争本身具有破坏性——并顺应这一真相的人，不会以任何社会、任何理论或改革的视角来回应战争。真相既不属于你，也不属于我，只要头脑试图诠释或转化真相，我们就会制造混乱。这就是改革者所做的，也是所有试图在特定社会秩序中推行改革的圣人们所做的。因为他们为了推行某种改革而诠释真相，而这种改革反而滋生了更多的苦难，因此需要进一步的改革。

To perceive what is truth there must be a total freedom from society, which means a complete cessation of acquisitiveness, of ambition, of envy, of this whole process of becoming. After all, our culture is based on becoming somebody, it is built on the hierarchical principle—the one who knows and the one who does not know, the one who has and the one who has not. The one who has not is everlastingly struggling to have, and the one who does not know is forever pushing to acquire more knowledge, whereas the man who does not belong to either, his mind is very quiet, completely still, and it is only such a mind that can perceive what is truth and allow that truth to act in its own way. Such a mind does not act according to a conditioned response; it does not say, “I must reform society.” The truly religious man is not concerned with social reform, he is not concerned with improving the old, rotting society because it is truth and not reform that is going to create the new order. I think if one sees this very simply and very clearly, the revolution itself will take place.

要领悟真理，就必须完全摆脱社会的束缚，这意味着彻底停止贪婪、野心、嫉妒，以及所有追求自我的过程。毕竟，我们的文化建立在“成为某人”的基础之上，它基于等级制度——有知者与无知者，拥有者与无产者。无产者永无止境地挣扎求得，无知者永无止境地追求更多知识，而那些不属于这两类人的人，他们的内心非常平静，完全静止，只有这样的心灵才能领悟真理，并让真理以其自身的方式发挥作用。这样的心灵不会受制于条件反射；它不会说：“我必须改革社会。”真正虔诚的人并不关心社会改革，也不关心如何改善腐朽的旧社会，因为创造新秩序的是真理，而非改革。我认为，如果人们能够如此简单清晰地理解这一点，革命本身就会发生。

The difficulty is that we do not see, we do not listen, we do not perceive things directly and simply as they are. After all, it is the innocent mind—innocent though it may have lived a thousand years and had a multitude of experiences—that is creative, not the cunning mind, not the mind that is full of knowledge and technique. When the mind sees the truth of any fact and lets that truth act, that truth creates its own technique. Revolution is not within society but outside of it.

困难在于我们视而不见，听而不闻，无法直接、简单地感知事物本来的样子。毕竟，真正具有创造力的是纯真的心灵——即便它已活过千年，拥有无数经验——而非狡诈的心灵，也非充满知识和技巧的心灵。当心灵洞悉任何事实的真相，并让真相发挥作用时，真相便会创造出它自身的方法。革命不在社会内部，而在于社会之外。

Q : The fundamental problem that faces every individual is the psychological pain which corrodes all thinking and feeling. Unless you have an answer and can teach the ending of pain, all your words have little meaning.

问：每个人面临的根本问题是心理痛苦，它会腐蚀所有的思想和情感。除非你能找到解决痛苦的方法，并能教导人们如何摆脱痛苦，否则你说的所有话都毫无意义。

K : Sir, what is teaching? Is teaching merely communication, words? Why do you want to be taught? And can another teach you how to end pain? If you could be taught how to end pain, would pain cease? You may learn a technique for ending pain, physical or psychological, but in the very process of ending one particular pain, a new pain comes into being.

K：先生，什么是教学？教学仅仅是沟通、语言吗？您为什么想学习？别人能教您如何止痛吗？如果能教您如何止痛，疼痛就会消失吗？您或许能学会止痛的技巧，无论是生理上的还是心理上的，但在止住一种疼痛的过程中，新的疼痛又会产生。

So what is the problem, sirs? Surely, the problem is not how to end pain. I can tell you not to be greedy, not to be ambitious, not to have beliefs, to free the mind from all desire for security, to live in complete uncertainty, and so on, but those are mere words. The problem is to experience directly the state of complete uncertainty, to be without any feeling of security, and that is possible only if you understand the total process of your own thinking, or if you can listen with your whole being, be completely attentive without resistance. To end sorrow, pain, either one must understand the ways of the mind, of desire, will, choice, going into that completely, or else listen to find the truth. The truth is that as long as there is a point in the mind which is moving toward another point, that is, as long as the mind is seeking security in any form, it will never be free from pain. Security is dependency, and a mind that depends has no love. Without going through all the process of examination, observation, and awareness, just listen to the fact, let the truth of the fact operate, and then you will see that the mind is free from pain. But we do neither; we neither see, observe to find out what is truth, nor do we listen to the fact with our whole being, without translating, twisting, interpreting it. That is, we neither pursue self-knowledge, which also brings an end to pain, nor do we merely observe the fact without distortion, as we look at our face in the mirror. All that we want is to know how to end pain, we want a ready-made formula by which to end it, which means, really, that we are lazy, there is not that extraordinary energy which is necessary to pursue the understanding of the self. It is only when we understand the self—not according to Shankara, Buddha, or Christ, but as it actually is in each one of us in relation to people, to ideas, and to things—that there is the cessation of pain.

那么，先生们，问题究竟是什么呢？当然，问题不在于如何结束痛苦。我可以告诉你们不要贪婪，不要野心勃勃，不要执着于任何信仰，要让心灵摆脱对安全感的渴望，要生活在完全的不确定性之中，等等，但这都只是空谈。问题在于直接体验完全不确定性的状态，体验没有任何安全感，而这只有在你理解自身思维的完整过程，或者能够全神贯注地聆听，毫无抗拒地全然专注时才有可能。要结束悲伤和痛苦，要么必须理解心灵、欲望、意志和选择的运作方式，并完全沉浸其中；要么就去聆听，去寻找真理。真理是，只要心灵中存在一个指向另一个点的念头，也就是说，只要心灵还在以任何形式寻求安全感，它就永远无法摆脱痛苦。安全感是依赖，而依赖的心灵没有爱。无需经历审视、观察和觉察的整个过程，只需聆听事实，让事实的真理发挥作用，你就会发现心灵已摆脱痛苦。然而，我们却两者都没有做到；我们既不去观察、去探寻真理，也不用全然投入地聆听事实，而是不断地对其进行翻译、扭曲和诠释。也就是说，我们既不去追求自我认知——而自我认知也能终结痛苦——也不去像照镜子那样，不加任何扭曲地观察事实。我们想要的只是知道如何终结痛苦，我们想要一个现成的公式来终结痛苦，这实际上意味着我们很懒惰，我们缺乏那种追求自我认知所必需的非凡能量。只有当我们真正理解自我——不是按照商羯罗、佛陀或基督的教义，而是理解自我在我们每个人身上与人、与观念、与事物之间真实的关系——痛苦才会真正止息。

Bombay, February 16, 1955

孟买，1955年2月16日

#↩

CAN YOU UNDERSTAND THE FACT

你能理解这个事实吗？

OF EMPTINESS?

空虚？

Questioner : Beyond all superficial fears there is a deep anguish, which eludes me. It seems to be the very fear of life—or perhaps of death. Or is it the vast emptiness of life?

提问者：在所有肤浅的恐惧之外，有一种难以捉摸的深切痛苦。这似乎是对生命的恐惧——或许是对死亡的恐惧。又或许是对生命浩瀚空虚的恐惧？

Krishnamurti : I think most of us feel this; most of us feel a great sense of emptiness, a great sense of loneliness. We try to avoid it, we try to run away from it, we try to find security, permanency, away from this anguish.

克里希那穆提：我想我们大多数人都有这种感觉；我们大多数人都感到一种巨大的空虚感，一种巨大的孤独感。我们试图逃避它，试图逃离它，试图寻找安全感、稳定感，远离这种痛苦。

Or, we try to be free of it by analyzing the various dreams, the various reactions. But it is always there, eluding us, and not to be resolved so easily and so superficially. Most of us are aware of this emptiness, of this loneliness, of this anguish. And, being afraid of it, we seek security, a sense of permanency, in things or property, in people or relationship, or in ideas, beliefs, dogmas, in name, position, and power. But can this emptiness be banished by merely running away from ourselves? And is not this running away from ourselves one of the causes of confusion, pain, misery, in our relationships and, therefore, in the world?

或者，我们试图通过分析各种梦境和反应来摆脱它。但它始终存在，难以捉摸，无法轻易地、肤浅地解决。我们大多数人都意识到这种空虚、这种孤独、这种痛苦。正因为害怕它，我们才在物质或财产、人际关系、观念、信仰、教条、名誉、地位和权力中寻求安全感和永恒感。但仅仅逃避自我就能消除这种空虚吗？而这种逃避自我难道不正是我们人际关系乃至整个世界混乱、痛苦和不幸的根源之一吗？

So, this is a question not to be brushed aside as being bourgeois, or stupid, or merely for those who are not active socially, religiously. We must examine it very carefully and go into it fully. As I said, most of us are aware of this emptiness, and we try to run away from it. In running away from it, we establish certain securities, and then those securities become all-important to us because they are the means of escape from our particular loneliness, emptiness, or anguish. Your escape may be a Master, it may be thinking yourself very important, it may be giving all your love, your wealth, jewels, everything, to your wife, to your family; or it may be social or philanthropic activity. Any form of escape from this inward emptiness becomes all-important and, therefore, we cling to it desperately. Those who are religiously-minded cling to their belief in God, which covers up their emptiness, their anguish; and so their belief, their dogma, becomes essential—and for these they are willing to fight, to destroy each other.

所以，这个问题不应被轻描淡写地归为资产阶级问题、愚蠢问题，或者仅仅是那些不活跃于社会和宗教活动的人才会关心的问题。我们必须非常仔细地审视它，并深入探讨它。正如我所说，我们大多数人都意识到了这种空虚，并试图逃避它。在逃避的过程中，我们建立了一些安全感，而这些安全感对我们来说变得至关重要，因为它们是我们逃离特定孤独、空虚或痛苦的途径。你的逃避方式可能是找到一位导师，可能是自认为非常重要，可能是把所有的爱、财富、珠宝，一切都给予你的妻子和家人；也可能是参与社会活动或慈善活动。任何形式的逃离这种内心空虚的方式都变得至关重要，因此，我们拼命地依附于它。那些有宗教信仰的人则依附于他们对上帝的信仰，这种信仰掩盖了他们的空虚和痛苦；因此，他们的信仰、他们的教条变得至关重要——为了这些，他们愿意战斗，甚至互相毁灭。

Obviously, then, any escape from this anguish, from this loneliness, will not solve the problem. On the contrary, it merely increases the problem and brings about further confusion. So, one must first realize the escapes. All escapes are on the same level; there are no superior or inferior escapes, there are no spiritual escapes apart from the mundane. All escapes are essentially similar; and if we recognize that the mind is constantly escaping from the central problem of anguish, of emptiness, then we are capable of looking at emptiness without condemning it or being afraid of it. As long as I am escaping from a fact, I am afraid of that fact, and when there is fear, I can have no communication with it. So, to understand the fact of emptiness, there must be no fear. Fear comes only when I am trying to escape from it, because in escaping, I can never look at it directly. But the moment I cease to escape, I am left with the fact. I can look at it without fear, and then I am able to deal with the fact.

显然，任何逃避这种痛苦、这种孤独的方式都无法解决问题。相反，它只会加剧问题，带来更大的困惑。因此，首先必须认识到逃避的本质。所有的逃避都处于同一层次；没有高低之分，也没有脱离世俗的灵性逃避。所有的逃避本质上都是相似的；如果我们认识到心念始终在逃避痛苦、逃避空性的核心问题，那么我们就能直面空性而不加以谴责或恐惧。只要我逃避某个事实，我就会害怕那个事实，而恐惧使我无法与它沟通。所以，要理解空性的本质，就必须消除恐惧。恐惧只在我试图逃避它时才会出现，因为在逃避的过程中，我永远无法直视它。但当我停止逃避的那一刻，我便能直面这个事实。我可以毫无畏惧地直视它，然后我就能面对这个事实。

So, that is the first step—to face the fact, which means not to escape through money, through amusement, through the radio, through beliefs, through assertions, or through any other means, because that emptiness cannot be filled by words, by activities, by beliefs. Do what we will, that anguish cannot be wiped away by any tricks of the mind, and whatever the mind does with regard to it will only be an avoidance. But when there is no avoidance of any kind, then the fact is there, and the understanding of the fact does not depend on the inventions or the projections or calculations of the mind. When one is confronted with the fact of loneliness, with that immense anguish, the vast emptiness of existence, then one will see whether that emptiness is a reality or merely the result of naming, of terming, of self-projection. Because, by giving it a name, by giving it a term, we have condemned it, have we not? We say it is emptiness, it is loneliness, it is death, and these words, death , loneliness , emptiness , imply a condemnation, a resistance, and through resistance, through condemnation, we do not understand the fact.

所以，第一步就是面对现实，这意味着不要用金钱、娱乐、广播、信仰、断言或其他任何方式逃避，因为那种空虚无法被言语、活动或信仰填满。无论我们做什么，那种痛苦都无法被任何心智的诡计抹去，心智对它所做的一切都只是逃避。但当没有任何逃避时，事实就在那里，对事实的理解不再依赖于心智的虚构、投射或算计。当一个人直面孤独的现实，直面那巨大的痛苦，直面存在的浩瀚空虚时，他就会明白，那空虚究竟是真实存在的，还是仅仅是命名、定义、自我投射的结果。因为，通过给它命名，通过给它贴上标签，我们岂不是已经否定了它吗？我们说它是空虚，它是孤独，它是死亡，而这些词语，死亡，孤独，空虚，都蕴含着谴责，一种抵抗，而通过抵抗，通过谴责，我们无法理解事实。

To understand the fact that we call emptiness, there must be no condemnation, no naming, of the fact. After all, the recognition of the fact creates the center of the “me,” and the “me” is empty, the “me” is only words. When I do not name the fact, give it a term, when I do not recognize it as this or that, is there loneliness? After all, loneliness is a process of isolation, is it not? Surely, in all our relationships, in all our efforts in life, we are always isolating ourselves. That process of isolation must obviously lead to emptiness, and without understanding the whole process of isolation, we shall not be able to resolve this emptiness, this loneliness. But when we understand the process of isolation, we shall see that emptiness is merely a thing of words, mere recognition; and the moment there is no recognition, no naming of it, and hence no fear, emptiness becomes something else, it goes beyond itself. Then it is not emptiness, it is aloneness—something much vaster than the process of isolation.

要理解我们称之为“空”的这一事实，就必须对它不加谴责，不加命名。毕竟，对这一事实的认知创造了“我”的中心，而“我”是空的，“我”不过是文字而已。当我不再命名这一事实，不再给它贴上标签，不再把它识别为这个或那个时，孤独还存在吗？毕竟，孤独是一个隔离的过程，不是吗？当然，在我们所有的人际关系中，在我们所有的人生努力中，我们总是在自我隔离。这种隔离的过程显然必然会导致空虚，如果我们不理解隔离的整个过程，我们就无法化解这种空虚，这种孤独。但是，当我们理解了隔离的过程，我们就会明白，空虚仅仅是文字，仅仅是认知；而当不再认知它，不再命名它，因而也不再恐惧时，空虚就变成了另一种东西，它超越了自身。那么，那不是空虚，而是孤独——比隔离的过程要宏大得多。

Now, must we not be alone? At present we are not alone—we are merely a bundle of influences. We are the result of all kinds of influences—social, religious, economic, hereditary, climatic. Through all those influences, we try to find something beyond, and if we cannot find it, we invent it, and cling to our inventions. But when we understand the whole process of influence at all the different levels of our consciousness, then, by becoming free of it, there is an aloneness which is uninfluenced; that is, the mind and heart are no longer shaped by outward events or inward experiences. It is only when there is this aloneness that there is a possibility of finding the real. But a mind that is merely isolating itself through fear can have only anguish; and such a mind can never go beyond itself.

难道我们不应该孤独吗？目前我们并非孤独——我们不过是各种影响的集合体。我们是各种影响的产物——社会、宗教、经济、遗传、气候等等。我们试图通过所有这些影响去寻找超越自身的东西，如果找不到，我们就创造它，并执着于我们创造的东西。但是，当我们理解了意识各个层面上所有影响的整个过程，从而摆脱它们，就能获得一种不受影响的孤独；也就是说，心灵不再受外在事件或内在体验的塑造。只有当拥有这种孤独时，才有可能找到真实。但是，仅仅因为恐惧而自我封闭的心灵只会充满痛苦；这样的心灵永远无法超越自身。

With most of us, the difficulty is that we are unaware of our escapes. We are so conditioned, so accustomed to our escapes, that we take them as realities. But if we will look more deeply into ourselves, we will see how extraordinarily lonely, how extraordinarily empty, we are under the superficial covering of our escapes. Being aware of that emptiness, we are constantly covering it up with various activities, whether artistic, social, religious, or political. But emptiness can never finally be covered—it must be understood. To understand it, we must be aware of these escapes, and when we understand the escapes, then we shall be able to face our emptiness. Then we shall see that the emptiness is not different from ourselves, that the observer is the observed. In that experience, in that integration of the thinker and the thought, this loneliness, this anguish, disappears.

对我们大多数人来说，困难在于我们意识不到自己一直在逃避现实。我们如此习惯于逃避，以至于将它们视为现实。但如果我们更深入地审视自己，就会发现，在这些逃避的表象之下，我们是多么的孤独，多么的空虚。意识到这种空虚，我们不断地用各种活动来掩盖它，无论是艺术的、社交的、宗教的还是政治的。但空虚永远无法被彻底掩盖——它必须被理解。为了理解它，我们必须意识到这些逃避，当我们理解了这些逃避，我们才能直面自己的空虚。那时我们就会明白，空虚与我们自身并无二致，观察者即是被观察者。在那种体验中，在思考者与思想的融合中，这种孤独，这种痛苦，都将消失。

Paris, May 7, 1950

巴黎，1950年5月7日

#↩

WHAT IS OUR BASIC PROBLEM?

我们面临的根本问题是什么？

I think most of us are easily satisfied with explanations, and we do not seem able to go beyond mere words and directly experience something original for ourselves. We are always repeating like gramophone records, merely following some authority who promises a certain result.

我认为我们大多数人都很容易满足于解释，似乎无法超越文字的局限，直接亲身体验一些原创的事物。我们总是像唱片机一样重复播放，仅仅追随某个权威人士所承诺的某种结果。

Now, it seems to me that religion is something entirely different. It is not this worship of words, nor is it the projection of symbols and the experiencing of those symbols. Religion is the experiencing of that which lies beyond the measure of the mind; but to experience that state, to realize the immensity of it, one really has to understand the process of one’s own thinking. Most of us are indifferent to the impressions, to the pressures, to the vitality of existence; we are easily satisfied, and some of us dare not even look at the problems about us and within ourselves.

现在，在我看来，宗教完全是另一回事。它并非对文字的崇拜，也不是对符号的投射和对这些符号的体验。宗教是对超越心智范畴之物的体验；但要体验那种状态，要领悟它的浩瀚，就必须真正理解自身的思维过程。我们大多数人对各种印象、压力和存在的活力漠不关心；我们很容易满足，有些人甚至不敢正视我们周围和我们自身存在的问题。

So I think it would be worthwhile if we could look at our problems, not theoretically or abstractly, but actually, and see what our problems really are. Not that we are going to resolve the problem of war, or put an end to the butchery that is going on, but we are easily led away by the very enormity of these issues, and there is not that clarity of thinking which can come into being only when we begin with ourselves, not with somebody or something else. The world problem is our problem because we are the world. What we think does affect the world; what we do does affect society. The individual problem is directly related to the world problem, and I do not think we are giving sufficient importance to the power of individual thinking and action. Historically I am sure you will find that it is always individuals who produce the great movements that are brought about.

所以我认为，如果我们能够真正地、而不是从理论或抽象的角度审视我们的问题，看清问题的本质，那将是值得的。这并不是说我们就能解决战争问题，或者结束正在发生的屠杀，而是说我们很容易被这些问题的庞大规模所迷惑，而只有当我们从自身出发，而不是从他人或事物出发时，才能获得清晰的思考。世界问题就是我们的问题，因为我们就是世界的一部分。我们的思想会影响世界；我们的行为会影响社会。个人问题与世界问题息息相关，而我认为我们没有充分重视个人思考和行动的力量。我相信，纵观历史，你会发现，那些伟大的运动总是由个人推动的。

So we have to look first and foremost at our own problems because they are directly related to world problems, and then perhaps we shall come out of it with a different outlook, a fresh impulse, an explosive vitality.

所以，我们首先要审视自身的问题，因为它们与世界问题直接相关，然后或许我们就能从中获得不同的视角、新的动力和爆发性的活力。

Now, what is our basic problem? As students, or businessmen, as politicians, engineers, or so-called seekers of the truth, whatever that may be, what fundamentally is our problem?

那么，我们的基本问题是什么？作为学生、商人、政治家、工程师，或者所谓的真理追求者（无论真理是什么），我们根本的问题是什么？

First of all, it seems to me that the world is rapidly changing and that the Western civilization, with its mechanization, its industrialization, its scientific discoveries, its tyranny, parliamentarianism, capital investment, and so on, has left a tremendous imprint on our minds. And we have created through the centuries a society of which we are a part and which says that we must be moral, righteous, virtuous, that we must conduct ourselves in accordance with a certain pattern of thought which promises the eventual achievement of reality, God, or truth.

首先，在我看来，世界正在飞速变化，西方文明及其机械化、工业化、科学发现、专制、议会制度、资本投资等等，都在我们的思想中留下了深刻的印记。几个世纪以来，我们创造了一个我们身处其中的社会，这个社会告诉我们，我们必须道德高尚、正直善良、品德高尚，我们必须按照某种特定的思维模式行事，这种模式承诺最终能够实现现实、上帝或真理。

So there is a contradiction in us, is there not? We live in this world of greed, envy, and sexual appetites, of emotional pressures, mechanization, and conformity, with the government efficiently controlling our various demands, and at the same time we want to find something greater than mere physical satisfaction. There is an urge to find reality, God, as well as to live in this world. We want to bring that reality into this world. We say that to live in this world we have to earn money, that society demands that we be acquisitive, envious, competitive, ambitious; and yet, living in this world, we want to bring the other thing into being. We may have all our physical needs provided, the government may bring about a state in which we have a great measure of outward security, but inwardly we are starving. So we want the state which we call religion, this reality which brings a new impulse, an explosive vitality to action.

所以，我们自身存在着矛盾，不是吗？我们生活在一个充满贪婪、嫉妒和性欲的世界，一个充满情感压力、机械化和盲从的世界，政府高效地控制着我们的各种需求，与此同时，我们又渴望找到超越肉体满足的更高层次的东西。我们既渴望在这个世界生存，也渴望找到真正的自我，找到上帝。我们想要将这种真正的自我带入这个世界。我们说，为了在这个世界生存，我们必须赚钱，社会要求我们贪婪、嫉妒、竞争、雄心勃勃；然而，生活在这个世界上，我们却又渴望创造另一种东西。我们或许能够满足所有物质需求，政府或许能够创造一个让我们拥有高度外在安全感的社会，但我们的内心却在饥渴。因此，我们渴望那种我们称之为宗教的状态，那种能够带来新的动力、一种爆发式活力的现实。

Surely, that is my problem, that is your problem. How are we to live in this world, where living implies competition, acquisitiveness, ambition, the aggressive pursuit of our own fulfillment, and also bring into being the perfume of something which is beyond? Is such a thing possible? Can we live in this world and yet have the other? This world is becoming more and more mechanized; the thoughts and actions of the individual are increasingly controlled by the State. The individual is being specialized, educated in a certain pattern to follow a daily routine. There is compulsion in every direction, and living in such a world, can we bring into being that which is neither outward nor inward, but which has a movement of its own and requires a mind that is astonishingly swift, a mind that is capable of intense feeling, intense inquiry? Is that possible? Unless we are neurotic, unless we are mentally peculiar, surely that is our problem.

这当然是我的问题，也是你的问题。我们该如何在这个世界生存？这个世界充满了竞争、贪婪、野心，以及对自我实现的咄咄逼人的追求，同时又能创造出超越世俗的芬芳？这有可能吗？我们能否在这个世界里生活，同时又拥有另一种境界？这个世界正变得越来越机械化；个人的思想和行为越来越受到国家的控制。个人被专业化，被按照某种模式教育，以遵循日常的例行程序。四面八方都充斥着强制，生活在这样的世界里，我们能否创造出既非外在也非内在，而是拥有自身运行规律，需要惊人敏捷的思维，能够感受强烈情感、进行深入探究的思维？这可能吗？除非我们患有神经症，除非我们精神异常，否则这肯定就是我们的问题所在。

Now, any intelligent man can see that going to temples, doing puja , and all the other nonsense that goes on in the name of religion is not religion at all; it is merely a social convenience, a pattern which we have been taught to follow. Man is educated to conform to a pattern, not to doubt, not to inquire; and our problem is how to live in this world of envy, greed, conformity, and the pursuit of personal ambition, and at the same time to experience that which is beyond the mind, call it God, truth, or what you will. I am not talking about the God of the temples, of the books, of the gurus, but of something far more intense, vital, immense, something which is immeasurable.

任何一个有智慧的人都能看出，去寺庙、做礼拜，以及其他所有以宗教之名进行的无稽之谈，根本就不是宗教；它不过是一种社会便利，一种我们被教导要遵循的模式。人被教育要顺从某种模式，不要怀疑，不要探究；而我们面临的问题是，如何在这个充满嫉妒、贪婪、盲从和追求个人野心的世界里生存，同时又能体验到超越心智的存在——你可以称之为上帝、真理，或者任何你想称呼它的东西。我说的不是寺庙里的上帝、经书里的上帝、大师们口中的上帝，而是某种更加强烈、更加鲜活、更加浩瀚、更加无法衡量的存在。

So, living in this world with all these problems, how am I to capture the other? Is that possible? Obviously not. I cannot be envious and yet find out what God or truth is; the two are contradictory, incompatible. But that is what most of us are trying to do. We are envious, we are carried along by the old momentum, and at the same time we dream of finding out whether there is God, whether there is love, truth, beauty, a timeless state. If you observe your own thinking, if you are at all aware of the operation of your own mind, you will see that you want to have one foot in this world and one foot in that other world, whatever it may be. But the two are incompatible, they cannot be mixed. Then what is one to do?

所以，生活在这个充满各种问题的世界里，我该如何把握另一个世界呢？这可能吗？显然不可能。我不可能既嫉妒又探寻上帝或真理；这两者是矛盾的，互不相容的。但我们大多数人却都在试图这样做。我们嫉妒，我们被旧有的惯性裹挟，同时又梦想着探寻是否存在上帝，是否存在爱、真理、美，是否存在永恒的状态。如果你观察自己的思维，如果你对自己的思维运作有所觉察，你就会发现，你渴望一只脚踏在这个世界，一只脚踏在另一个世界，无论那世界是什么。但这两者是互不相容的，它们无法融合。那么，我们该怎么办呢？

Do you understand, sirs? I realize that I cannot mix reality with something which has no reality. How can a mind that is agitated by envy, that is living in the field of ambition, greed, understand something which is completely still and which has a movement of its own in that stillness? As an intelligent human being I see the impossibility of such a thing. I also see that my problem is not to find God because I do not know what that means. I may have read innumerable books on the subject, but such books are merely explanations, words, theories which have no actuality for a person who has not experienced that which is beyond the mind. And the interpreter is always a traitor, it does not matter who that interpreter is.

先生们，你们明白吗？我意识到我无法将现实与不存在的事物混为一谈。一个被嫉妒所扰乱、生活在野心和贪婪之中的心灵，又怎能理解完全静止却又在静止中自有其动的事物呢？作为一个有智慧的人，我明白这是不可能的。我也明白，我的问题不在于寻找上帝，因为我不知道那意味着什么。我或许读过无数关于这个主题的书籍，但这些书不过是解释、文字和理论，对于一个没有体验过超越思维之物的人来说，它们毫无意义。而且，解释者永远都是叛徒，无论解释者是谁。

My problem, then, is not to find truth, God, because my mind is incapable of it. How can a stupid, petty mind find the immeasurable? Such a mind can talk about the immeasurable, write books about it; it can fashion a symbol of truth and garland the symbol, but that is all on the verbal level. So, being intelligent and aware of this fact, I say, “I must begin with what I actually am, not with what I should be. I am envious, that is all I know.”

所以，我的问题不在于寻找真理，上帝，因为我的头脑根本无法做到。一个愚钝狭隘的头脑，又怎能领悟那不可测度的真理呢？这样的头脑或许可以谈论那不可测度的真理，可以为此著书立说；它可以塑造真理的象征，并为之披上华丽的外衣，但这都只是语言层面的表达。因此，我既有智慧，也明白这一点，所以我说：“我必须从我真实的自我出发，而不是从我应该成为的自我出发。我嫉妒，仅此而已。”

Now, is it possible for me, while living in this society, to be free of envy? To say it is or is not possible is an assumption and, therefore, has no value. To find out if one can do it requires intensity of inquiry. Most of you will say it is impossible to live in this world without envy, without greed. Our whole social structure, our code of morality is based on envy, so you assume it is not possible and that is the end of it, whereas a man who says, “I don’t know if there is a reality or not, but I want to find out; and to find out my mind must obviously be free of envy, not just in patches, but totally, because envy is a movement of agitation”—it is only such a man who is capable of real inquiry. We shall go into that presently.

那么，生活在这样的社会里，我有可能摆脱嫉妒吗？断言是否可能只是一种假设，因此毫无意义。要弄清是否能够做到，需要深入探究。你们大多数人会说，在这个世界上，没有嫉妒、没有贪婪是不可能的。我们整个社会结构，我们的道德准则都建立在嫉妒之上，所以你们认为这是不可能的，仅此而已。然而，如果有人说：“我不知道是否存在这样的现实，但我想要弄清楚；而要弄清楚这一点，我的内心显然必须彻底摆脱嫉妒，不是偶尔摆脱，而是完全摆脱，因为嫉妒是一种躁动不安的情绪”——只有这样的人才能进行真正的探究。我们稍后会深入探讨这一点。

So my problem is not to inquire into reality, but to find out whether, living in this world, I can be free of envy. Envy is not mere jealousy, though jealousy is part of it, nor is it merely being concerned because someone else has more than I. Envy is the state of a mind which is demanding more and more all the time—more power, more position, more money, more experience, more knowledge. And demanding the “more” is the activity of a mind which is self-centered.

所以，我的问题不在于探究现实，而在于弄清楚，生活在这个世界上，我能否摆脱嫉妒。嫉妒并非仅仅是羡慕，尽管羡慕包含羡慕的成分，也并非仅仅是因为别人拥有的比我多而感到不安。嫉妒是一种不断索取更多东西的心态——更多的权力、更高的地位、更多的金钱、更多的经验、更多的知识。而这种对“更多”的渴求，正是以自我为中心的心态所导致的。

Now, can I live in this world and be free of self-centered activity? Can I cease to compare myself with somebody else? Being ugly, I want to be beautiful; being violent, I want to be nonviolent. Wanting to be different, to be “more,” is the beginning of envy—which does not mean that I blindly accept what I am. But this desire to be different is always in relation to something which is comparatively greater, more beautiful, more this or more that, and we are educated to compare in this way. It is our daily craving to compete, to surpass, and we are satisfied with being envious, not only consciously but also unconsciously.

那么，我能否在这个世界里摆脱以自我为中心的行为？我能否停止与他人比较？我丑陋，却渴望美丽；我暴力，却渴望非暴力。想要与众不同，想要“更好”，是嫉妒的开端——但这并不意味着我会盲目地接受自己。然而，这种想要与众不同的渴望总是与某种相对更伟大、更美丽、更优越的事物相关，而我们从小就被教育要以这种方式进行比较。竞争、超越是我们每日的渴望，我们不仅有意识地，而且无意识地，都满足于嫉妒。

You feel that you must become somebody in this world, a great man or a rich man, and if you are fortunate you say it is because you have done good in the past—all that nonsense about karma, and so on. Inwardly also you want to become somebody—a saint, a virtuous man—and if you observe this whole movement of becoming, this pursuit of the “more,” both outwardly and inwardly, you will see that it is essentially based on envy. In this movement of envy your mind is held, and with such a mind, can you discover the real? Or is that an impossibility? Surely, to discover the real, your mind must be completely free of envy; there can be no demand for the “more,” either openly or in the hidden recesses of the unconscious. And if you have ever observed it, you will know that your mind is always pursuing the “more.” You had a certain experience yesterday, and you want more of it today; or, being violent, you want to be nonviolent, and so on. These are all the activities of a mind which is concerned with itself.

你觉得自己必须在这个世界上有所成就，成为一个伟人或富翁，如果你足够幸运，你会说这是因为你过去行善积德——诸如此类关于因果报应的无稽之谈。你的内心也渴望成为一个圣人、一个德行高尚的人——如果你观察这种追求“更多”的整个过程，无论外在还是内在，你都会发现它本质上是建立在嫉妒之上的。你的心被这种嫉妒的驱使所束缚，而带着这样的心，你又能发现真相吗？或者说，这根本不可能？当然，要发现真相，你的心必须完全摆脱嫉妒；无论在公开场合还是在潜意识深处，都不能再有对“更多”的渴求。如果你曾经观察过，你就会知道你的心总是在追求“更多”。你昨天经历了某种事情，今天就想要更多；或者，你原本暴力，今天就想要非暴力，等等。这些都是以自我为中心的思维活动。

Now, is it possible for the mind to be free from this whole process? That is my inquiry, not whether there is or there is not God. For an envious mind to seek God is such a waste of time; it has no meaning except theoretically, intellectually, as an amusement. If I really want to find out whether there is God or not, I must begin with myself; that is, the mind must be totally free from envy, and I can assure you, that is an enormous task. It is not just a matter of playing with words.

那么，人的心灵是否有可能摆脱这一切呢？这才是我的疑问，而非上帝是否存在。对于一个心怀嫉妒的人来说，探寻上帝纯属浪费时间；除了理论上的、智力上的、娱乐消遣之外，毫无意义。如果我真的想弄清上帝是否存在，我必须从自身开始；也就是说，心灵必须完全摆脱嫉妒，我可以向你保证，这是一项极其艰巨的任务。这绝非玩弄文字游戏那么简单。

But you see, most of us are not concerned with that; we do not say, “I will free my mind from envy.” We are concerned with the world, with what is happening in Europe, with the mechanization of industry—anything to get away from the central point, which is that I cannot help to bring about a different world until I as an individual have changed fundamentally. To see that one must begin with oneself is to realize an enormous truth; but most of us overlook it; we easily brush it aside because we are concerned with the collective, with changing the social order, with trying to bring about peace and harmony in the world.

但你看，我们大多数人并不关心这一点；我们不会说：“我要让自己摆脱嫉妒。”我们关心的是世界，是欧洲正在发生的事情，是工业的机械化——总之，我们什么都想逃避核心问题，那就是除非我个人发生根本性的改变，否则我无法改变世界。认识到必须从自身做起，这本身就是一个意义非凡的真理；但我们大多数人却视而不见；我们轻易地将其抛诸脑后，因为我们关心的是集体，是改变社会秩序，是努力在世界上实现和平与和谐。

Few people are concerned with themselves except in the sense of achieving success. I do not mean that kind of concern. I mean being concerned with the transformation of oneself. But first of all, most of us do not see the importance, the truth, of change; and secondly, we do not know how to change, how to bring about this astonishing, explosive transformation within ourselves. Changing in mediocrity, which is to change from one pattern to another, is no change at all.

除了追求成功之外，很少有人真正关心自己。我指的并非这种意义上的关心，而是指关注自身的转变。首先，我们大多数人看不到改变的重要性，看不到改变的真谛；其次，我们不知道如何改变，如何才能在自身内部实现这种惊人的、翻天覆地的转变。在平庸中改变，也就是从一种模式转变为另一种模式，根本算不上改变。

This explosive transformation is the result of all one’s energy coming together to solve the fundamental problem of envy. I am taking that as the central issue, though there are many other things involved in it. Have I the capacity, the intensity, the intelligence, the swiftness, to pursue the ways of envy, and not just say, “I must not be envious”? We have been saying that for centuries, and it has no meaning. We have also said, “I must follow the ideal of non-envy,” which is equally absurd, because we project the ideal of non-envy and are envious in the meantime.

这种爆发式的转变源于一个人所有能量的汇聚，旨在解决嫉妒这一根本问题。我将此视为核心问题，尽管其中还涉及许多其他方面。我是否具备能力、强度、智慧和敏捷性，去探究嫉妒之道，而不仅仅是说“我不能嫉妒”？几个世纪以来，我们一直这样说，但这毫无意义。我们也说过“我必须遵循不嫉妒的理想”，这同样荒谬，因为我们一边标榜着不嫉妒的理想，一边又嫉妒他人。

Please observe this process. The fact is that you are envious, while the ideal is the state of non-envy, and there is a gap between the two that has to be filled through time. You say, “Eventually I shall be free of envy”—which is an impossibility, because it has to happen now or never. You cannot set some future date on which you will be non-envious.

请观察这个过程。事实是，你现在心怀嫉妒，而理想状态是不嫉妒，两者之间存在着一道鸿沟，需要时间去弥合。你说：“总有一天我会摆脱嫉妒”——这是不可能的，因为要么现在就做到，要么永远做不到。你无法设定一个未来日期，让你在那个日期之后不再嫉妒。

So, is it possible for me to have the capacity to inquire into and be totally free from envy? How does that capacity arise? Does it arise through any method or practice? Do I become an artist by practicing a particular technique day after day? Obviously not. The desire to have that capacity is a selfish movement of the mind, whereas if I do not try to cultivate it, but begin to inquire into the whole process of envy, then the means of totally dissolving envy is already there.

那么，我是否有可能具备探究并彻底摆脱嫉妒的能力呢？这种能力是如何产生的？它是否需要通过某种方法或练习才能获得？我是否可以通过日复一日地练习某种特定的技巧而成为艺术家？显然不是。渴望拥有这种能力是一种自私的思维活动，而如果我不去刻意培养它，而是开始探究嫉妒的整个过程，那么彻底消除嫉妒的方法就已经存在了。

Now, in what manner do I inquire into the process of envy? What is the motive behind that inquiry? Do I want to be free of envy in order to be a great man, in order to be like Buddha, Christ, and so on? If I inquire with that intention, with that motive, such inquiry projects its own answer, all of which will only perpetuate the monstrous world which we have now. But if I begin to inquire with humility, that is, not with a desire to achieve success, then an entirely different process is taking place. I realize that I have not got the capacity to be free of envy, so I say, “I shall find out,” which means that there is humility from the very beginning. And the moment one is humble, one has the capacity to be free of envy. But the man who says, “I must have that capacity, and I am going to get it through these methods, through this system”—such a man is lost, and it is such people who have created this ugly, treacherous world.

那么，我该如何探究嫉妒的根源呢？探究背后的动机是什么？我是否想摆脱嫉妒，从而成为一个伟大的人，像佛陀、基督等等那样？如果我带着这样的意图和动机去探究，那么探究本身就会投射出答案，而这些答案只会延续我们如今身处的这个丑恶的世界。但如果我以谦卑之心去探究，也就是说，不以追求成功为目的，那么就会发生截然不同的过程。我意识到自己没有摆脱嫉妒的能力，所以我说：“我会找到答案”，这意味着从一开始就怀有谦卑之心。而当一个人谦卑时，他就拥有了摆脱嫉妒的能力。但是，那些说“我必须拥有这种能力，我要通过这些方法、这个体系来获得它”的人——这样的人已经迷失了方向，正是这样的人创造了这个丑陋、充满阴谋的世界。

A mind that is really humble has an immense capacity for inquiry, whereas the mind that is under the burden of knowledge, that is crippled with experience, with its own conditioning, can never really inquire. A humble mind says, “I do not know, I shall find out”—which means that finding out is never a process of accumulation. Not to accumulate you must die every day, and then you will find, because you are fundamentally, deeply, humble, that this capacity to inquire comes of itself, it is not a thing that you have acquired. Humility cannot be practiced, but because there is humility, your mind has the capacity to inquire into envy, and such a mind is no longer envious.

真正谦逊的心灵拥有巨大的探究能力，而背负知识重担、被经验束缚、受制于自身习性的心灵，则永远无法真正探究。谦逊的心灵会说：“我不知道，我要去发现”——这意味着发现绝非积累的过程。若要避免积累，你必须每日超越自我，如此你便会发现，因为你从根本上、深深地谦逊，这种探究能力自然而然地产生，而非后天习得。谦逊无法习得，但正因为拥有谦逊，你的心灵才具备探究嫉妒的能力，而这样的心灵也不再嫉妒。

A mind which says, “I do not know,” and which does not want to become something has totally ceased to be envious. Then you will find that righteousness has quite a different meaning. Righteousness is not respectability; it is not conformity; it has nothing to do with social morality, which is mere convenience, a manner of living made respectable through centuries of compulsion, conformity, pressure, and fear. A mind that is really humble, in the sense I have explained, will create its own righteousness, which is not the righteousness of a pattern. It is the righteousness of living from humility and discovering from moment to moment what is truth.

一颗说“我不知道”且不愿成为某种人的心，便彻底丧失了嫉妒之心。那时，你便会发现，正义的意义截然不同。正义并非体面，也非循规蹈矩，它与社会道德毫无关系——社会道德不过是权宜之计，是几个世纪以来在强制、顺从、压力和恐惧的驱使下才得以体面的生活方式。一颗真正谦卑的心，正如我所解释的，会创造属于它自己的正义，这正义并非一种模式化的正义，而是源于谦卑的生活，源于在每时每刻中发现真理的正义。

So your problem is not the world of newspapers, ideas, and politicians, it is the world within yourself—but you have to realize, to feel the truth of this, and not merely agree because the Gita or some bearded gentleman says it is so. If you are aware of that inner world and are watching yourself without condemnation or justification from day to day, from moment to moment, then in that awareness you will find there is a tremendous vitality. The mind that is accumulating is frightened to die, and such a mind can never discover what is truth. But to a mind that is dying every minute to everything that it has experienced, there comes an astonishing vitality because every moment is new; and only then is the mind capable of discovery.

所以，你的问题不在于报纸、思想和政客的世界，而在于你的内心世界——但你必须意识到，必须感受到这一点的真谛，而不仅仅是因为《薄伽梵歌》或某个留着胡子的绅士这么说就盲目认同。如果你觉察到那个内在世界，并且日复一日、时时刻刻不带谴责或辩解地审视自己，那么在这种觉察中，你会发现蕴藏着巨大的活力。不断积累的头脑害怕死亡，这样的头脑永远无法发现真理。但对于每时每刻都在向过往经历中死去的头脑来说，一种惊人的活力油然而生，因为每一刻都是崭新的；只有这样，头脑才能有所发现。

It is good to be serious, and we are very rarely serious in our life. I do not mean just listening to somebody who is serious, or being serious about something, but having the feeling of seriousness in ourselves. We know very well what it is to be gay, flippant, but very few of us know the feeling of being deeply serious without an object to make us serious—that state in which the mind approaches every situation, however gay, happy, or exciting, with serious intent. So it is good to spend an hour together in this way, being serious in our inquiry, because life for most of us is very superficial, a routine relationship of work, sex, worship, and so on. The mind is always on the surface, and to go below the surface seems to be an enormously difficult task. What is necessary is this state of explosiveness, which is real revolution in the religious sense, because it is only when the mind is explosive that it is capable of discovering or creating something original, new.

认真是件好事，但我们在生活中却很少真正认真。我指的并非仅仅是倾听别人认真的讲话，或者认真对待某件事，而是我们自身拥有认真的态度。我们很清楚什么是轻浮、玩世不恭，但很少有人体验过那种无需任何目的就能保持严肃的状态——在这种状态下，无论面对多么轻松、快乐或令人兴奋的情况，我们的心智都会以严肃的态度去面对。因此，花一个小时以这种方式一起探讨是有益的，因为对我们大多数人来说，生活非常肤浅，充斥着工作、性、宗教等等的例行公事。我们的思想总是停留在表面，想要深入其中似乎是一项极其艰巨的任务。我们需要的是一种爆发性的状态，这在宗教意义上是一场真正的革命，因为只有当思想爆发时，它才能发现或创造出原创的、全新的事物。

Bombay, February 10, 1957

孟买，1957年2月10日

#↩

HOW DO YOU APPROACH THE PROBLEMS

你如何看待这些问题？

OF LIVING?

生存？

I think it might be worthwhile if we went into the question of how quickly the mind deteriorates and what are the primary factors that make the mind dull, insensitive, quick to respond. I think it would be significant if we could go into this question of why the mind deteriorates, because perhaps in understanding that, we may be able to find out what is really a simple life.

我认为，探讨心智衰退的速度以及导致心智迟钝、麻木、反应过快的主要因素，或许会很有意义。如果我们能够探究心智衰退的原因，那将意义非凡，因为或许通过理解这一点，我们就能找到真正简单的生活是什么。

We notice as we grow older that the mind—the instrument of understanding, the instrument with which we probe into any problem, to inquire, to question, to discover—if misused, deteriorates, disintegrates, and it seems to me that one of the major factors of this deterioration of the mind is the process of choice.

随着年龄的增长，我们注意到，思维——理解的工具，我们用来探究任何问题、询问、质疑、发现的工具——如果被滥用，就会衰退、瓦解，在我看来，导致思维衰退的主要因素之一就是选择的过程。

All our life is based on choice. We choose at different levels of our existence. We choose between white and blue, between one flower and another flower, between certain psychological impulses of like and dislike, between certain ideas, beliefs, accepting some and discarding others. So our mental structure is based on this process of choice, this continuous effort at choosing, distinguishing, discarding, accepting, rejecting. And in that process there is constant struggle, constant effort. There is never a direct comprehension, but always the tedious process of accumulation, of the capacity to distinguish, which is really based on memory, on the accumulation of knowledge and, therefore, there is this constant effort made through choice.

我们的一生都建立在选择之上。我们在存在的各个层面上都做出选择。我们在白色和蓝色之间做出选择，在不同的花朵之间做出选择，在喜欢和厌恶等心理冲动之间做出选择，在不同的观念和信念之间做出选择，接受一些，摒弃另一些。因此，我们的心智结构建立在选择的过程之上，建立在持续不断地选择、区分、舍弃、接受和拒绝的努力之上。在这个过程中，存在着持续不断的斗争和努力。我们永远无法直接理解，而总是需要经历一个漫长的积累过程，一个辨别能力的积累过程，而这种能力实际上建立在记忆和知识的积累之上。因此，我们需要通过选择来进行持续不断的努力。

Now, is not choice ambition? Our life is ambition. We want to be somebody, we want to be well thought of, want to achieve a result. If I am not wise, I want to become wise. If I am violent, I want to become nonviolent. The “becoming” is the process of ambition. Whether I want to become the biggest politician or the most perfect saint, the ambition, the drive, the impulse of becoming is the process of choice, is the process of ambition, which is essentially based on choice.

那么，选择不就是抱负吗？我们的人生就是抱负。我们渴望成为某个重要人物，渴望被人认可，渴望取得成就。如果我不够睿智，我就想变得睿智；如果我性格暴戾，我就想变得不暴力。“成为”的过程就是抱负的过程。无论我想成为最伟大的政治家还是最完美的圣人，这种抱负、这种动力、这种成为的冲动，本质上都是选择的过程，都是抱负的过程，而抱负的本质就是选择。

So, our life is a series of struggles, a movement from one ideological concept, formula, desire, to another, and in this process of becoming, in this process of struggle, the mind deteriorates. The very nature of this deterioration is choice, and we think choice is necessary, choice from which springs ambition.

所以，我们的人生就是一系列的挣扎，是从一种意识形态、模式、欲望向另一种意识形态、模式、欲望的转变，而在这个转变的过程中，在这个挣扎的过程中，心智会逐渐衰退。这种衰退的本质就是选择，而我们认为选择是必要的，野心正是源于选择。

Now, can we find a way of life which is not based on ambition, which is not of choice, which is a flowering in which the result is not sought? All that we know of life is a series of struggles ending in result; and those results are being discarded for greater results. That is all we know.

那么，我们能否找到一种不以野心为基础、不以选择为目的、不追求结果的生活方式呢？我们所知的人生不过是一系列以结果告终的奋斗；而这些结果又被我们为了追求更大的结果而抛弃。这就是我们所知的一切。

In the case of the man who sits alone in a cave, in the very process of making himself perfect there is choice, and that choice is ambition. The man who is violent tries to become nonviolent; that very becoming is ambition. We are not trying to find out whether ambition is right or wrong, whether it is essential to life, but whether it is conducive to a life of simplicity. I do not mean the simplicity of a few clothes; that is not a simple life. The putting on of a loincloth does not indicate a man that is simple; on the contrary, it may be that by the renunciation of the outer things, the mind becomes more ambitious, for it tries to hold on to its own ideal, which it has projected and which it has created. So if we observe our own ways of thinking, should we not inquire into this question of ambition? What do we mean by it, and is it possible to live without ambition? We see that ambition breeds competition—whether in children, in school, or among the big politicians, all the way up. This ambition produces certain industrial benefits, but in its wake, obviously there is the darkening of the mind, the technological conditioning, so that the mind loses its pliability, its simplicity and, therefore, is incapable of directly experiencing. Should we not inquire, not as a group but as individuals, you and I, should we not find out what this ambition means, whether we are at all aware of this ambition in our life?

对于独自隐居山洞的修行者而言，在自我完善的过程中，选择至关重要，而这种选择便是野心。暴力之人试图变得非暴力，这种转变本身也是一种野心。我们并非要探究野心的对错，也并非要探究它是否是人生的必需品，而是要探究它是否有助于过上简朴的生活。我指的并非衣着简朴，那并非简朴的生活。身着缠腰布并不代表一个人就简朴；相反，或许正是因为舍弃了外在的事物，心灵才变得更加雄心勃勃，因为它试图坚守自己构想和创造的理想。因此，如果我们审视自身的思维方式，难道不应该探究一下野心的本质吗？我们所说的野心究竟是什么？没有野心，我们是否能够生活？我们看到，野心滋生竞争——无论是在孩童时期、学校里，还是在政坛高层，无一例外。这种雄心壮志固然带来了一些工业效益，但随之而来的显然是思想的蒙蔽和技术的束缚，使人的思想失去了灵活性和纯粹性，因而无法直接体验。我们难道不应该，不是以群体的视角，而是以你我为个体，去探究这种雄心壮志的真正含义，探究我们是否在生活中真正意识到了这种雄心壮志的存在吗？

When we offer ourselves to serve the country to do noble work, is there not in it the fundamental element of ambition, which is the way of choice? And is not, therefore, choice a corruptive influence in our life because it prevents the flowering? The man who flowers is the man who is, who is not becoming.

当我们甘愿为国效力，从事崇高的事业时，其中难道不包含着雄心壮志的根本要素——选择吗？而选择难道不正是阻碍我们绽放的腐蚀力量吗？真正绽放的人，是那些已经存在而非正在成长的人。

Is there not a difference between the flowering mind and the becoming mind? The becoming mind is a mind that is always growing, becoming, enlarging, gathering experience as knowledge. We know that process full well in our daily life, with all its results, with all its conflicts, its miseries and strife, but we do not know the life of flowering. And is there not a difference between the two which we have to discover—not by trying to demarcate, to separate, but to discover—in the process of our living? When we discover this, we may perhaps be able to set aside this ambition, the way of choice, and discover a flowering, which is the way of life, which may be true action.

绽放的心灵与成长的心灵之间难道没有区别吗？成长的心灵是一种不断成长、不断变化、不断扩展、不断积累经验并最终获得知识的心灵。我们在日常生活中对这个过程了如指掌，包括它带来的所有结果、冲突、痛苦和纷争，但我们却不了解绽放的生命状态。这两者之间难道没有我们需要去发现的区别吗？这种区别不是通过试图划定界限、将二者割裂开来，而是通过探索发现——在我们生活的进程中。当我们发现这一点时，或许就能放下这种野心，放下选择的道路，去发现一种绽放的生命状态，一种真正的生命之道。

So if we merely say that we must not be ambitious without the discovery of the flowering way of life, the mere killing of ambition destroys the mind also because it is an action of the will, which is the action of choice. So is it not essential for each one of us to find out in our lives the truth of ambition? We are all encouraged to be ambitious; our society is based on the strength of the drive toward a result. And in that ambition there are inequalities which legislation tries to level out, to alter. Perhaps that way, that approach to life, is essentially wrong, and there might be another approach, which is the flowering of life, which could express itself without accumulation. After all, we know when we are conscious of striving after something, of becoming something; that is ambition, the seeking of a result.

因此，如果我们仅仅说，在未发现生命的真谛之前，就不应该有野心，那么仅仅扼杀野心也会摧毁心灵，因为它是一种意志行为，一种选择行为。那么，我们每个人难道不应该在生活中探寻野心的真谛吗？我们都被鼓励要有野心；我们的社会建立在追求结果的驱动力之上。而这种野心本身就存在不平等，立法试图消除和改变这种不平等。或许这种方式，这种生活态度，本质上是错误的，或许还有另一种方式，那就是生命的绽放，它无需积累就能展现自身。毕竟，当我们意识到自己在追求什么，成为什么的时候，我们就知道，那就是野心，是对结果的追求。

But there is an energy, a force in which there is a compulsion without the process of accumulation, without the background of the “me,” of the self, of the ego; that is the way of creativity. Without understanding that, without actually experiencing that, our life becomes very dull; our life becomes a series of endless conflicts in which there is no creativity, no happiness. And perhaps if we can understand not by discarding ambition but by understanding the ways of ambition—by being open, by comprehending, by listening to the truth of ambition—perhaps we may come upon that creativity in which there is a continuous expression which is not the expression of self-fulfillment but is the expression of energy without the limitation of the “me.”

但有一种能量，一种力量，它蕴含着一种无需积累、无需“我”、无需自我、无需小我的内在驱动力；这便是创造之道。若不理解它，若不真正体验它，我们的生活便会变得枯燥乏味；我们的生活会沦为无休止的冲突，其中毫无创造力，毫无幸福可言。或许，如果我们不是摒弃野心，而是理解野心的运作方式——以开放的心态，以领悟之心，以聆听之心的真谛——我们或许就能找到那份创造力，其中蕴含着一种持续不断的表达，它并非自我实现的表达，而是超越“我”的局限，展现能量的表达。

Questioner : In the worst of misery, most of us live on hope. Life without hope seems dreadful and inevitable, and yet very often this hope is nothing but illusion. Can you tell us why hope is so indispensable to life?

提问者：在最悲惨的时刻，我们大多数人靠希望活着。没有希望的生活似乎可怕且无法避免，然而很多时候，这种希望不过是幻觉。您能告诉我们，为什么希望对生活如此不可或缺吗？

Krishnamurti : Is it not the very nature of the mind to create illusion? Is not the very process of thinking the result of memory, of verbalized thought, which creates an idea, a symbol, an image to which the mind clings?

克里希那穆提：难道心智的本质不就是创造幻觉吗？难道思考的过程本身不就是记忆、是语言化思维的结果吗？这种思维过程创造了一个观念、一个符号、一个图像，而心智则执着于此？

I am in despair; I am in sorrow; I have no way of resolving it; I do not understand how to resolve it. If I understand it, then there is no need for hope. It is only as long as I do not understand how to bring about the dissolution of a particular problem that I depend on a myth, on an idea of hope. If you observe your own mind, you will see that when you are in discomfort, in conflict, in misery, your mind seeks a way away from it. The process of going away from the problem is the creation of hope.

我感到绝望，我感到悲伤，我无计可施，我不明白该如何解决。如果我明白了，那就无需抱有希望。只有当我无法理解如何化解某个具体问题时，我才会依赖于一种神话，一种希望的观念。如果你观察自己的内心，你会发现，当你感到不适、冲突或痛苦时，你的内心会寻求逃避之法。逃避问题的过程，正是希望的产生。

The mind going away from the problem creates fear; the very movement of going away, the flight from the problem, is fear. I am in despair because I have done something which is not right, or some misery comes upon me, or I have done a terrible wrong, or my son is dead, or I have very little to eat. My mind, not being able to resolve the problem, creates a certainty, something to which it can cling, an image which it carves by the hand or by the mind. Or the mind clings to a guru, to a book, to an idea which sustains me in my difficulties, in my miseries, in my despair, and so I say I shall have a better time next life, and so on and on and on.

逃避问题会滋生恐惧；逃避本身，这种逃避行为，就是恐惧。我感到绝望，可能是因为我做错了事，或者遭遇了不幸，或者犯下了滔天大罪，或者我的儿子去世了，或者我食不果腹。我的心无法解决问题，于是便创造出一种确定性，一种可以依附的东西，一种它用手或用心雕刻出来的形象。或者，我的心执着于某个导师、一本书、某种理念，这些都能支撑我度过难关、苦难和绝望，于是我告诉自己来世会更好，如此循环往复，永无止境。

As long as I am not capable of resolving my problem, my sorrow, I depend on hope; it is indispensable. Then I fight for that hope. I do not want anyone to disturb that hope, that belief. I make that belief into an organized belief, and I cling to that because out of that, I derive happiness; because I have not been able to solve the problem which is confronting me, hope becomes the necessity.

只要我无法解决我的问题，我的悲伤，我就依赖希望；希望不可或缺。于是，我为这份希望而战。我不希望任何人动摇这份希望，这份信念。我将这份信念组织起来，并紧紧抓住它，因为我从中获得幸福；因为我无法解决摆在我面前的问题，希望就成了必需品。

Now, can I solve the problem? If I can understand the problem, then hope is not necessary; then depending on an idea or an image or a person is not necessary because dependence implies hope, implies comfort. So the problem is whether hope is indispensable, whether I can resolve my problem, whether there is a way to find out how not to be in sorrow—that is my problem, not how to dispense with hope.

现在，我能解决这个问题吗？如果我能理解问题，那么希望就不是必需的；那么依赖某种想法、形象或人就不是必需的，因为依赖意味着希望，意味着慰藉。所以问题在于希望是否不可或缺，我能否解决我的问题，是否存在摆脱悲伤的方法——这才是我的问题，而不是如何摆脱希望。

Now, what is the factor essential to the understanding of a problem? Obviously, if I wish to understand the problem, there must be no formula, there must be no conclusion, there must be no judgment. But if we observe our minds we will see that we are full of conclusions; we are steeped in formulas with which we hope to resolve the problem. And so we judge, we condemn. And so, as long as we have a formula, a conclusion, a judgment, a condemnatory attitude, we shall not understand the problem.

那么，理解问题的关键因素是什么呢？显然，如果我想理解问题，就不能预设任何公式，不能预设任何结论，也不能预设任何判断。但如果我们审视自己的思维，就会发现我们满脑子都是结论；我们被各种公式所束缚，并试图用它们来解决问题。于是，我们开始评判，开始谴责。因此，只要我们心中存有公式、结论、判断或谴责的态度，我们就无法真正理解问题。

So the problem is not important, but how we approach the problem. The mind that is wishing to comprehend a problem must not be concerned with the problem, but with the workings of its own machinery of judgment. Do you follow?

所以，重要的不是问题本身，而是我们如何看待问题。想要理解一个问题，大脑不应专注于问题本身，而应专注于自身判断机制的运作。你明白吗？

I started out with the establishment of a hope, saying that it is essential because without hope I am lost. So my mind is occupied with hope, I occupy it with hope. But that is not my problem; my problem is the problem of sorrow, of pain, of mistakes. Is even that my problem, or is my problem how to approach the problem itself? So what is important is how the mind regards the problem.

我一开始就试图建立希望，因为希望至关重要，没有希望我就会迷失方向。所以我的心中充满希望，我让自己的身心都充满希望。但这并非我的问题所在；我的问题在于悲伤、痛苦和错误。即便如此，这真的是我的问题吗？或者，我的问题在于如何面对这些问题本身？所以，重要的是心灵如何看待这个问题。

I have altogether moved away from hope because hope is illusory, it is unreal, it is not factual. I cannot deal with something which is not factual, which has been created by the mind.
