It is not something real; it is illusory, so I cannot grapple with it. What is real is my sorrow, my despair, the things that I have done, the crowded memories, the aches, and the sorrows of my life. How I approach the aches and sorrows and miseries in my life is important, not hope, because if I know how I approach them, then I shall be able to deal with them.

我已经彻底放弃了希望，因为希望是虚幻的，是不真实的，并非事实。我无法面对非事实的事物，无法应对由头脑创造出来的事物。它并非真实存在，而是虚幻的，所以我无法与之抗衡。真实存在的是我的悲伤、我的绝望、我做过的事、那些纷乱的记忆、痛苦以及我生命中的种种苦难。重要的是我如何面对生命中的痛苦、悲伤和苦难，而不是希望本身，因为如果我知道如何面对它们，我就能应对它们。

So what is important is not hope but how I regard my problem. I see that I always regard my problem in the light of judgment—either condemning, accepting, or trying to transform it—or looking at it through glasses, through the screen of formulas of what somebody has said in the Bhagavad Gita, what the Buddha or the Christ has said. So my mind, being crippled by these formulas, judgments, quotations, can never understand the problem, can never look at it. So can the mind free itself from these accumulated judgments?

所以，重要的不是希望，而是我如何看待我的问题。我发现我总是带着评判的眼光看待我的问题——要么谴责它，要么接受它，要么试图改变它——或者说，我总是戴着有色眼镜，透过《薄伽梵歌》里某些人说过的话、佛陀或基督说过的话这些公式化的滤镜来看待它。因此，我的心智被这些公式化的说法、评判和引文所束缚，永远无法理解问题，永远无法真正审视它。那么，心智真的能够摆脱这些累积的评判吗？

Please follow this carefully—not my words, but how you approach your problem. What we are always doing is pursuing the hope and everlastingly being frustrated. If I fail with one hope, I substitute another and so I go on and on. And as I do not know how to approach, how to understand the problem itself, I resort to various escapes. But if I knew how to approach the problem, then there is no necessity for hope. So what is important is to find out how the mind regards the problem.

请仔细体会——不是我的话，而是你如何看待问题。我们总是执着于希望，却总是失望。如果一个希望破灭，我就用另一个希望来代替，如此循环往复。因为我不知道该如何着手，如何理解问题本身，所以我只能寻求各种逃避。但如果我知道如何着手解决问题，那么就无需抱有希望。所以，重要的是弄清楚你的内心是如何看待这个问题的。

Your mind looks at a problem. It looks at it, obviously, with a condemnatory attitude. It condemns it in distinguishing it, in reacting to it, or it wants to change it into something which it is not. If you are violent, you want to change into nonviolence. Nonviolence is unreal, it is not factual; what is real is violence. Now to see how you approach the problem, with what attitude—whether you condemn it, whether you have the memories of what the so-called teachers have said about it—that is what is important.

你的思维会审视一个问题。很显然，它会带着谴责的态度去审视它。它会谴责它，无论是通过区分它、对它做出反应，还是想要把它变成它原本不是的东西。如果你是暴力主义者，你会想要变成非暴力主义者。非暴力是不真实的，它不符合事实；真实存在的是暴力。现在，重要的是你如何看待这个问题，你以怎样的态度看待它——你是否谴责它，你是否还记得那些所谓的老师们对这个问题说过的话。

Can the mind eradicate these conditions, free itself from these conditions, and look at the problem? Can it be unconcerned with how to free itself from these conditions? If it is concerned with it, then you create another problem out of it. But if you can see how these conditions prevent you from looking at the problem, then these conditions have no value because the problem is important, pain is important, sorrow is important. You cannot call sorrow an idea and brush it aside. It is there.

心灵能否消除这些束缚，摆脱这些束缚，从而直面问题？它能否不去关注如何摆脱这些束缚？如果它执着于此，那么你便会由此制造出另一个问题。但如果你能看清这些束缚是如何阻碍你直面问题的，那么这些束缚便毫无价值，因为问题本身很重要，痛苦很重要，悲伤也很重要。你不能把悲伤仅仅当作一种观念而置之不理。它就在那里。

So, as long as the mind is incapable of looking at the problem, as long as it is not capable of resolving the problem, there must be various escapes from the problem, and the escapes are hopes; they are the defense mechanism.

所以，只要人的思维无法正视问题，无法解决问题，就必然会有各种各样的逃避方式，而这些逃避方式就是希望；它们就是防御机制。

The mind will always create problems. But what is essential is that when we make mistakes, when we are in pain, to meet these mistakes, these pains, without judgment, to look at them without condemnation, to live with them and to let them go by. And that can only happen when the mind is in the state of noncondemnation, without any formula; which means, when the mind is essentially quiet, when the mind is fundamentally still; then only is there the comprehension of the problem.

心智总会制造问题。但关键在于，当我们犯错、当我们痛苦时，要以不评判、不谴责的态度面对这些错误和痛苦，与它们共存，并让它们随风而逝。而这只有在心智处于一种不谴责、不带任何预设的状态时才能实现；也就是说，当心智真正平静、根本安宁时，才能真正理解问题所在。

Q : Will you please tell us what you mean by the words our vocation ? I gather you mean something different from the ordinary connotation of these words.

问：请问您能否解释一下您所说的“我们的使命”是什么意思？我感觉您指的是与这个词的通常含义不同的意思。

K : Each one of us pursues some kind of vocation—the lawyer, the soldier, the policeman, the businessman, and so on. Obviously, there are certain vocations which are detrimental to society—the lawyer, the soldier, the policeman, and the industrialist who is not making other men equally rich.

K：我们每个人都从事某种职业——律师、士兵、警察、商人等等。显然，有些职业对社会有害——比如律师、士兵、警察，以及那些没有让其他人同样致富的实业家。

When we want, when we choose a particular vocation, when we train our children to follow a particular vocation, are we not creating a conflict within society? You choose one vocation and I choose another, and does that not bring about conflict between us? Is that not what is happening in the world because we have never found out what is our true vocation? We are only being conditioned by society, by a particular culture, to accept certain forms of vocations which breed competition and hatred between man and man. We know that, we see it.

当我们想要选择某种职业，当我们培养孩子从事某种职业时，我们难道不是在社会内部制造冲突吗？你选择一种职业，我选择另一种，这难道不会在我们之间引发冲突吗？这难道不是因为我们从未找到自己真正的使命，而导致世界陷入这种境地吗？我们只是被社会、被特定的文化所塑造，去接受某些滋生竞争和仇恨的职业形式。我们明白这一点，我们也亲眼目睹了这一切。

Now, is there any other way of living in which you and I can function in our true vocations? Is there not one vocation for man? Are there different vocations for man? We see that there are: you are a clerk, I polish shoes, you are an engineer, and I am a politician. We see innumerable varieties of vocations and we see they are all in conflict with each other. So man, through his vocation, is in conflict, in hatred, with man. We know that. With that we are familiar every day.

那么，除了职业之外，还有没有其他的生活方式，能让你我从事自己真正擅长的职业呢？难道人类只有一种职业吗？难道人类有多种不同的职业吗？我们看到，确实有：你是职员，我是擦鞋匠；你是工程师，我是政治家。我们看到了数不胜数的职业，也看到它们彼此冲突。因此，人通过其职业，与人之间产生了冲突，甚至仇恨。我们都知道这一点。我们每天都对此习以为常。

Now let us find out if there is not one vocation for man. If we can all find it, then the expression of different capacities will not bring about conflict between man and man. I say there is only one vocation for man. There is only one vocation, not many. The one vocation for man is to find out what is real.

现在让我们来探究一下，人类是否只有一个使命。如果我们都能找到自己的使命，那么不同才能的展现就不会导致人与人之间的冲突。我认为人类只有一个使命。使命只有一个，而不是很多。人类唯一的使命就是探寻真理。

If I and you are finding out what is truth, which is our true vocation, then in the search of that we will not be in competition. I shall not be competing with you, I shall not fight you, though you may express that truth in a different way; you may be the Prime Minister; I shall not be ambitious and want to occupy your place because I am seeking equally with you what is truth. Therefore, as long as we do not find out that true vocation of man, we must be in competition with each other, we must hate each other; and whatever legislation you may pass, on that level you can only produce further chaos.

如果我和我的人都在探寻真理，探寻我们真正的使命，那么在追寻真理的过程中，我们就不会彼此竞争。我不会与你竞争，也不会与你争斗，即便你以不同的方式表达真理；即便你身居首相之位；我也不会心怀野心，想要取代你的位置，因为我与你一样，都在探寻真理。因此，只要我们尚未找到人类的真正使命，我们就必然彼此竞争，彼此憎恨；而你通过的任何法律，在这个层面上都只会造成更大的混乱。

So, is it not possible from childhood, through right education, through the right educator, to help the boy, the student, to be free to find out what is the truth about everything—not just truth in the abstract, but to find out the truth of all relationships—the boy’s relationship to machinery, his relationship to nature, his relationship to money, to society, to government and so on? That requires, does it not, a different kind of teacher, who is concerned with helping or giving the boy, the student, freedom—so that he begins to investigate the cultivation of intelligence, which can never be conditioned by a society which is always deteriorating.

那么，难道不能从孩提时代起，通过正确的教育，通过合适的教育者，帮助男孩、学生自由地去探寻万物的真相吗？这不仅仅是抽象的真相，而是探寻所有关系的真相——男孩与机器的关系、与自然的关系、与金钱的关系、与社会的关系、与政府的关系等等。这难道不需要一种不同的教师吗？这种教师致力于帮助男孩、学生获得自由，从而引导他们开始探索如何培养智慧，而这种智慧绝不能被一个不断衰败的社会所束缚。

So, is there not one vocation for man? Man cannot exist in isolation, he exists only in relationship, and when in that relationship there is no discovery of truth, the discovery of the truth of relationship, then there is conflict.

那么，难道人类就没有唯一的使命吗？人不能孤立存在，他只能在关系中存在；而当这种关系中没有发现真理，没有发现关系的真谛时，就会产生冲突。

There is only one vocation for you and me. And in the search of that, we shall find the expression wherein we shall not come into conflict, we shall not destroy each other. But it must begin surely through right education, through the right educator. The educator also needs education. Fundamentally, the teacher is not merely the giver of information, but brings about, in the student, the freedom, the revolt, to discover what is truth.

你我只有一个共同的使命。在追寻这个使命的过程中，我们将找到一种彼此和谐、互不相让的表达方式。但这必须从正确的教育，从正确的教育者开始。教育者自身也需要接受教育。从根本上讲，教师不仅仅是信息的传递者，更是在学生心中激发自由和反抗精神，去发现真理。

Q : When you answer our questions, what functions—memory or knowledge?

问：当您回答我们的问题时，您指的是记忆功能还是知识功能？

K : It is really quite an interesting question, is it not? Let us find out.

K：这确实是个很有意思的问题，不是吗？让我们一起来探究一下。

Knowledge and memory are the same, are they not? Without knowledge, without the accumulation of knowledge, which is memory, can you reply? The reply is the verbalization of a reaction, is it not? There is this question asked: What is functioning, memory or knowledge? I am only saying memory and knowledge are the same thing essentially, because if you have knowledge but have no memory of it, it will have no value.

知识和记忆是一回事，不是吗？没有知识，没有知识的积累（也就是记忆），你能回答吗？回答不就是对某种反应的口头表达吗？有人问：究竟是记忆还是知识在起作用？我只是想说，记忆和知识本质上是一回事，因为如果你拥有知识却没有记忆，那么这些知识就毫无价值。

You are asking what functions when I answer a question. Is knowledge functioning? Is memory functioning? Now what is it that is functioning with most of us? Please follow this. What is functioning with most of us when you ask a question? Obviously knowledge. When I ask you the way to your house, knowledge is functioning, memory is functioning. And with most of us that is all that functions because we have accumulated knowledge from the Bhagavad Gita or from the Upanishads or from Marx or from what Stalin has said or what your pet guru says or your own experience, your own accumulated reactions, and from that background, you reply. That is all we know. That is the actual fact. In your business that is what is functioning. When you build a bridge, that is what is functioning.

你问的是我回答问题时，什么在起作用？是知识在起作用吗？是记忆在起作用吗？那么，对我们大多数人来说，真正起作用的是什么呢？请仔细想想。当我们大多数人提问时，什么在起作用？显然是知识。当我问你回家的路时，知识在起作用，记忆也在起作用。对我们大多数人来说，这就是全部，因为我们积累了来自《薄伽梵歌》、奥义书、马克思、斯大林的言论、你崇拜的导师的教诲，或者你自身的经验、你自身积累的反应等知识，并以此为背景进行回答。这就是我们所知道的一切。这就是事实。在你的工作中，这就是起作用的。当你建造一座桥梁时，也是它起作用。

When you write a poem, there are two functions going on—the verbalization, the memory; and the creative impulse. The creative impulse is not memory, but when expressed it becomes memory.

写诗时，有两个功能在起作用——语言表达，即记忆；以及创作冲动。创作冲动本身并非记忆，但当它被表达出来时，就变成了记忆。

So without memory, verbalization, the verbalizing process, there is no possibility of communication. If I do not use certain words, English words, I could not talk to you. The very talking, the verbalization, is the functioning of memory. Now the question is: What is functioning when the speaker is answering, memory or something else? Memory, obviously, because I am using words. But is that all?

所以，如果没有记忆、语言表达以及语言表达的过程，沟通就无从谈起。如果我不使用某些词汇，比如英语词汇，我就无法与你交谈。说话本身，也就是语言表达，正是记忆运作的体现。现在的问题是：当说话者回答问题时，究竟是什么在运作？是记忆，还是其他什么？显然是记忆，因为我使用了词汇。但仅此而已吗？

Am I replying from the accumulated memories of innumerable speeches I have made during the last twenty years, which I keep on repeating like a gramophone record machine? That is what most of us are. We have certain actions, certain patterns of thought, and we keep on repeating them. But the repetition of words is entirely different to that because that is the way of communication.

我是否只是在重复过去二十年无数次演讲的记忆，就像一台自动播放唱片的机器一样？我们大多数人都是如此。我们有固定的行为模式和思维模式，并且不断重复。但重复言语则截然不同，因为言语是沟通的方式。

By the repetition of experience, the experiences are gathered and stored away and, like a machine, I repeat from that experience, from that storehouse. Here again, there is repetition, which is again the memory functioning.

通过经验的重复，经验被积累并储存起来，就像机器一样，我从这些经验、从这些储存库中重复操作。这里又出现了重复，这同样是记忆在运作。

So you are asking if it is possible, while I am speaking, that I am really experiencing, not answering from experience? Surely there is a difference between the repetition of experience and the freedom of experiencing, which is being expressed through memory, which is the verbalization. Please listen. This is not difficult to understand.

所以你的意思是，我说话的时候，是否有可能真正地在体验，而不是在根据经验回答问题？重复经验和自由体验之间肯定存在区别，后者是通过记忆表达出来的，也就是语言表达。请听我说。这并不难理解。

I want to find out what ambition means, all that it implies. Do I really, now as I am speaking, investigate afresh the whole process of ambition? Or do I repeat the investigation which I have made yesterday about ambition, which is merely repetition? Is it not possible to investigate, to experience anew all the time, and not merely rely on a record, on memory, on the experience of yesterday? Is it not possible to flower, to be, all the time, now as I am speaking, without the repetitious experience of yesterday, though I use words to communicate?

我想探究野心究竟意味着什么，它蕴含着什么。此刻，当我开口说话时，我真的是在重新审视野心的整个过程吗？还是我只是在重复昨天对野心的探究，那不过是重复而已？难道我们不能不断地探索，不断地体验，而不仅仅依赖于记录、记忆和昨天的经验吗？难道我们不能在此刻，当我开口说话时，不断地绽放，不断地存在，而不依赖于昨天的重复经验，即使我用语言来交流吗？

Your question is: What is functioning when I am speaking? If I am repeating merely what I have said ten days ago, then it is of very little value. But if I am experiencing as I am talking, not an imaginative feeling, but actually, then what is functioning? The flowering is functioning, not through self-expression, not the “me” functioning, which is memory.

你的问题是：我说话时，究竟是什么在起作用？如果我只是重复十天前说过的话，那它就毫无价值。但如果我说话时是在体验，不是凭空想象的感觉，而是真切的感受，那么究竟是什么在起作用？是“绽放”在起作用，它并非通过自我表达，并非通过“我”的运作——后者指的是记忆。

So it is very important, not for me alone but for all of us, to find out if we can keep our minds from being this storehouse of the past, and whether the mind can be stable on the waters of life and let the memories float by without clinging to any particular memory, and when necessary to use that memory as we do use it when we communicate. Which means the mind constantly letting the past float by, never identifying itself with it, never being occupied with it; so that the mind is firm, not in experience, not in memory, not in knowledge, but firm, stable in the process, in the way of experiencing continuously.

所以，这不仅对我个人而言至关重要，对我们所有人来说也同样重要：我们必须弄清楚，能否让我们的心灵不成为过往的仓库，能否让心灵在人生的波涛中保持稳定，让记忆随波逐流而不执着于任何特定的记忆，并在必要时像交流时那样运用这些记忆。这意味着心灵要不断地让过去随波逐流，从不认同过去，从不被过去所占据；如此，心灵的稳固便不在于经验、记忆或知识，而在于持续体验的过程和方式。

So, that is the factor which brings about no deterioration, so that the mind constantly renews. A mind that accumulates is already in decay. But the mind that allows memories to go by and is firm in the way of experiencing—such a mind is always fresh, it is always seeing things anew. That capacity can only come when the mind is very quiet. That quietness, that stillness, is not induced, cannot come about through any discipline, through any action of will, but when the mind understands the whole process of accumulation of knowledge, memory, experience. Then it establishes itself on the waters of life, which are always moving, living, vibrant.

因此，正是这种因素使得心灵不会衰退，从而不断更新。积累的心灵本身就已经在衰败。但允许记忆流逝、并坚定体验方式的心灵——这样的心灵总是清新的，总是以全新的视角看待事物。这种能力只有在心灵非常平静时才能获得。这种平静，这种安宁，并非人为诱导，无法通过任何训练或意志行为获得，而是当心灵理解了知识、记忆和经验积累的整个过程时才能实现。那时，它便能安住于生命之水，那水永远流动、鲜活、充满活力。

Q : With what should the mind be occupied? I want to meditate. Would you please tell me on what I should meditate?

问：冥想时应该专注于什么？我想冥想，请问我应该冥想什么？

K : Now, let us find out what meditation is. You and I are going to find out. I am not going to tell you what meditation is. We are both going to discover it afresh.

K：现在，让我们一起来了解一下冥想是什么。你和我都会去发现。我不会直接告诉你冥想是什么。我们俩都会重新认识它。

The mind that has learned to meditate, which is to concentrate, the mind that has learned the technique of shutting out everything and narrowing down to a particular point—such a mind is incapable of meditation. That is what most of us want. We want to learn to concentrate, to be occupied with one thought to the exclusion of every other thought, and we call that meditation. But it is not meditation. Meditation is something entirely different, which we are going to find out.

学会冥想（也就是集中注意力）的头脑，学会了屏蔽一切干扰、专注于某一点的头脑——这样的头脑是无法真正冥想的。而这正是我们大多数人所追求的。我们想要学会集中注意力，想要专注于一个念头，排除其他一切杂念，我们称之为冥想。但这并非冥想。冥想完全是另一回事，我们稍后会探讨。

So our first problem is why does the mind demand that it should be occupied? Do you understand? My mind says, “I must be occupied with something, with worry, with memory, with a passion, or with how not to be passionate, or how to get rid of something, or to find a technique which will help me to build a bridge.” So the mind, if you observe, demands constant occupation, does it not? That is why you say, “My mind must be occupied with the word Om ,” or you repeat “ Ram Ram ”; or you are occupied with drinking. The word Om , the words Ram Ram , or drinking are all the same because the mind wants to be occupied, because it says if it is not occupied it will do some mischief, if it is not occupied it will drift away. If the mind is not occupied, then what is the purpose of life? So you invent a purpose of life—noble, ignoble, or transcendental—and cling to that, and with that you are occupied. It is the same whether the mind is occupied with God or whether it is occupied with business, because the mind says consciously or unconsciously it must be occupied.

所以，我们首先要问的是，为什么心需要被占据？你明白吗？我的心会说：“我必须忙于某件事，比如忧虑、回忆、激情，或者思考如何摆脱激情，或者思考如何摆脱某些东西，或者思考如何找到一种能帮助我搭建桥梁的方法。”所以，如果你仔细观察，心其实需要不断地被占据，不是吗？这就是为什么你会说：“我的心必须专注于‘唵’这个字”，或者你会重复“拉姆拉姆”；或者你会专注于喝酒。无论是“唵”这个字、“拉姆拉姆”还是喝酒，本质上都是一样的，因为心想要被占据，因为它认为如果不被占据，它就会作恶，如果不被占据，它就会迷失方向。如果心没有被占据，那么人生的意义又是什么呢？所以你给自己设定一个人生目标——高尚的、卑微的，或是超凡脱俗的——然后执着于此，并以此为生。无论你的心思是放在上帝身上，还是放在工作上，结果都一样，因为无论你的心智是有意识还是无意识地告诉你，它必须有所事事。

So, the next thing is to find out why the mind demands occupation. Please follow this. We are meditating now. This is meditation. Meditation is not a state at the end. Freedom is not to be got at the end; freedom is at the beginning. If you have no freedom in the beginning, you have no freedom at the end. If you have no love now, you will have no love in ten years. So what we are doing now is to find out what meditation is. And the very inquiry into what meditation is is to meditate.

所以，接下来我们要做的就是探究为什么人的心需要被占据。请仔细听。我们现在正在冥想。这就是冥想。冥想并非终点。自由并非终点才能获得；自由始于起点。如果你一开始没有自由，那么你最终也不会有自由。如果你现在没有爱，那么十年后你也不会有爱。所以我们现在所做的，就是探寻冥想的本质。而探寻冥想本质的，正是冥想本身。

The mind says, “I must be occupied with God, with virtue, with my worries, or with my business concern,” so it is incessantly active in its occupation. The mind can only exist as long as it is active, as long as it is conscious of itself in action, not otherwise. The mind knows itself as being when it is occupied, when it is acting, when it has results. It knows itself as existing when it is in motion. The motion is occupation toward a result, toward an idea, or denial of that idea negatively.

心灵会说：“我必须专注于上帝、美德、忧虑或事务”，因此它不停地忙碌着。心灵只有在活跃时才能存在，只有在它意识到自身在行动时才能存在，否则它便不存在。心灵在忙碌、行动、产生结果时才意识到自身的存在。它在运动中才意识到自身的存在。这种运动是对结果、对某种观念的追求，或是对这种观念的否定。

I am conscious of myself only when there is motion, in and out. So consciousness is this motion of action, outward and inward, this breathing out of responses, of reactions, of memories, and then collecting them back again. So my mind is—I am—only when I am thinking, when I am in conflict with a thing, when there is suffering, when there is occupation, when there is strain, when there is choice.

只有当身体有运动，有呼吸时，我才能意识到自身的存在。所以，意识就是这种向外和向内的行动，就是呼出回应、反应和记忆，然后再将它们重新收集起来的过程。因此，我的心智——我——只有在我思考时，只有在我与事物冲突时，只有在痛苦中，只有在忙碌时，只有在紧张时，只有在选择时才存在。

So the mind knows itself as in motion when it is ambitious and drags itself there, and seeing that ambition is dull, it says, “I will occupy myself with God.” The occupation of the mind with God is the same as the occupation of the mind with money. We think that the man whose mind is occupied with God is more sacred than the man who is thinking of money, but they are factually both the same; both want results, both need to be occupied. So, can the mind be without occupation? That is the problem.

所以，当心智充满野心并驱使自己去追求时，它便意识到自身处于运动状态；而当它发现野心枯燥乏味时，便会说：“我要专注于上帝。”心智专注于上帝与专注于金钱并无二致。我们认为专注于上帝的人比满脑子想着金钱的人更神圣，但实际上他们并无二致；两者都渴望结果，都需要有所事事。那么，心智可以无所事事吗？这才是问题的关键所在。

Can the mind be blank, without comparing, because the “more” is the way of the mind knowing that it exists? The mind that knows it exists is never satisfied with what is ; it is always acquiring, comparing, condemning, demanding more and more. In the demand for, in the movement of, the “more,” it knows itself as existing, which is what we call self-consciousness, the conscious on the surface and the unconscious. This is our life, this is the way of our everyday existence.

心灵能否一片空白，不去比较，因为“更多”正是心灵认知自身存在的方式？认知自身存在的心灵永远不会满足于现状；它总是不断地获取、比较、评判、索取更多。在对“更多”的渴求和追求中，它认知了自身的存在，这就是我们所说的自我意识，即表层的意识和无意识。这就是我们的生活，这就是我们日常存在的方式。

I want to know what meditation is, so I say I want to be occupied with meditation. I want to find out what meditation is, so my mind is again occupied with meditation. So, can the occupied mind ever be capable of meditation? Meditation, surely, is the understanding of the ways of the mind. If I do not know how my mind operates, functions, works, how can I meditate? How can I really find out what is truth? So the mind must find out how it is occupied; then it begins to see with what it is occupied, and then finds that all occupations are the same because the mind then is filling itself with words, with ideas, with constant movement, so that there is never a quietness.

我想知道什么是冥想，所以我说我想专注于冥想。我想弄明白什么是冥想，所以我的心再次专注于冥想。那么，被各种念头占据的心真的能够冥想吗？冥想，当然是对心智运作方式的理解。如果我不知道我的心智是如何运作的，我又如何冥想呢？我又如何真正地发现真理呢？所以，心智必须先弄清楚它被什么占据；然后它开始观察自己被什么占据，然后发现所有的占据都是相同的，因为心智那时充满了言语、观念和持续不断的活动，所以永远无法平静下来。

When the mind occupies itself with the discovery of what love is, it is another form of occupation, is it not? It is like the man who is occupied with passion.

当人的心思专注于探寻爱的本质时，这不也是一种不同的专注吗？这就像一个人沉浸于激情之中一样。

When you say you must find out the truth, will you find truth? Or does truth come into being only when the mind is not occupied, when the mind is empty to receive, not to gather, not to accumulate? Because you can only receive once. But if what you have received you make into memory with which you are occupied, then you will never receive again. Because the receiving is from moment to moment. Therefore, it is of timelessness.

当你说你必须探寻真相时，你真的能找到真相吗？还是说，只有当心灵空无一物，能够全然接受、不收集、不积累时，真相才会显现？因为你只能接受一次。但如果你把已经接受的事物变成记忆，并沉浸其中，那么你将永远无法再次接受。因为接受是存在于每个当下，因此，它是永恒的。

So the mind, which is of time, cannot receive the timeless. So the mind must be completely still, empty, without any movement in any direction. And that can only take place with a mind that is not occupied—not occupied with the “more,” with a problem, with worry, with escapes; not conditioned in any belief, in any image, in any experience. It is only when the mind is totally free, then only is there a possibility of immense profound stillness; and in that stillness that which is eternal comes into being. That is meditation.

因此，受时间支配的心灵无法领悟永恒。所以，心灵必须完全静止、空无一物，没有任何方向的动静。而这只有在心灵不受任何占据时才能实现——不受“更多”、问题、忧虑、逃避的占据；不受任何信念、任何意象、任何经验的束缚。只有当心灵完全自由时，才有可能达到无比深邃的静止；而在这静止之中，永恒之物便得以显现。这就是冥想。

Bombay, March 11, 1953

孟买，1953年3月11日

#↩

WHAT IS THE CENTRAL CORE OF

什么是核心？

YOUR THINKING?

你的想法是什么？

1

Krishnamurti : What is the central core of your thinking? You know there is peripheral thinking, which is not really important, but at the center, what is the momentum, the movement of that thinking? What is that “me” that is so concerned with itself? I think about myself, that is the core, the heart of my thinking. And on the periphery I think about various things, the people here, the trees, a bird flying by, but these things don’t really very much matter unless there is a crisis on the periphery that affects the “me,” and the “me” reacts. Now what is that center from which you think, which is the “me”? And why is there this continual occupation about oneself? I am not saying it is right or wrong, but we see that we are occupied with ourselves. Why?

克里希那穆提：你思考的核心是什么？你知道，存在外围的思考，那并不重要，但核心思考的动力和方向是什么？那个如此关注自身的“我”又是什么？我思考我自己，这就是我思考的核心。在外围，我会思考各种各样的事情，这里的人，树木，飞过的鸟儿，但除非外围发生危机影响到“我”，而“我”做出反应，否则这些事情其实并不重要。那么，你思考的中心，也就是“我”，究竟是什么？为什么我们会如此持续地关注自身？我不是说这种关注是对是错，但我们确实看到我们如此关注自身。为什么？

Student : Because we think it is important.

学生：因为我们认为这很重要。

K : Why do you give it importance?

K：你为什么这么重视它？

S : When you are a child you have to.

S：当你还是个孩子的时候，你就必须这样做。

K : Why do you think about yourself so much? See what is involved in this. Thinking about oneself isn’t just a very small affair. You think about yourself in relation to another with like and dislike; and you think about yourself, identifying yourself with another. I think about the person I have just left, or the person I think I like, or the person with whom I have quarreled, or the person whom I love. I have identified myself with all those people, haven’t I?

K：你为什么总是想着自己？想想这背后牵涉到什么。想着自己可不是什么小事。你会把自己和别人联系起来，产生喜欢或不喜欢的感觉；你会把自己和别人等同起来。我会想起我刚离开的那个人，或者我自认为喜欢的那个人，或者和我吵过架的那个人，或者我爱的那个人。我把自己和这些人都联系在了一起，不是吗？

S : What do you mean by identify?

S：你说的“识别”是什么意思？

K : I love you, I have identified myself with you. Or I have hurt her and you identify yourself with her and get angry with me. See what has happened: I have said something to her which is harmful and unpleasant; you are her friend and you identify yourself with her and get angry with me. So that is part of the self-centered activity, isn’t it? Are you sure?

K：我爱你，所以我把自己代入到你这边。或者，我伤害了她，你把自己代入到她那边，然后生我的气。你看，事情是这样的：我对她说了一些伤人又难听的话；你是她的朋友，你把自己代入到她那边，然后生我的气。所以，这也是一种以自我为中心的行为，不是吗？你确定吗？

S : But isn’t it the other person who is identifying with you?

S：但难道不是对方在认同你吗？

K : Is it or is it not? Let’s inquire. I like you, I am very fond of you—what does that mean? I like your looks, you are a good companion and so on. It means what?

K：到底是不是？我们来探讨一下。我喜欢你，我很喜欢你——这到底是什么意思？我喜欢你的外貌，你是个很好的伴侣等等。这到底意味着什么？

S : It means you are a better companion than other people and so I like being with you.

S：这意味着你比其他人更适合做伴侣，所以我喜欢和你在一起。

K : Go a little deeper. What does it mean?

K：再深入探讨一下。它到底是什么意思？

S : You keep that person to yourself and exclude others.

S：你把那个人单独留给自己，不让其他人接触。

K : That is part of it, but go on further.

K：这只是其中一部分，但请继续深入探讨。

S : It is pleasing to be with that person.

S：和那个人在一起很愉快。

K : It is pleasing to be with that person and it is not pleasing with another person. So my relationship with you is based on my pleasure. If I don’t like you I say, “I’ll be off.” My pleasure is my concern, as is my hurt, my anger. So self-concern isn’t just thinking about myself and identifying with this or that possession, person, or book. There is the peripheral occupation, and also I am comparing myself with you; that is going on all the time, but from a center.

K：和这个人在一起很愉快，和其他人在一起就不愉快。所以我和你的关系建立在我的愉悦感之上。如果我不喜欢你，我会说：“我走了。”我的愉悦感、我的伤痛、我的愤怒，都是我关注的焦点。所以，自我关注不仅仅是想着自己，认同于某样东西、某个人或某本书。它包含着外围的关注，而且我还会拿自己和你比较；这种比较无时无刻不在发生，但它源于我的内心。

S : You read about the refugees in India and you haven’t a personal relationship with them but you do identify with them.

S：你读到关于印度难民的故事，虽然你和他们没有私人关系，但你会对他们感同身受。

K : Why do I identify myself with those people who have been killed and chased out of East Pakistan? I watched them the other day on television. This is happening everywhere, not only in Pakistan. It is appalling. Now you say you identify yourself with all those refugees; what do you feel?

K：为什么我会认同那些在东巴基斯坦被杀害和驱逐的人们？前几天我在电视上看到了他们的遭遇。这种情况并非只发生在巴基斯坦，而是在世界各地。这太可怕了。你说你认同所有这些难民；你对此有何感想？

S : Sympathy.

S：同情。

K : Go on, explore it, unravel it.

K：继续，去探索，去解开它。

S1 : Anger against the people who caused this.

S1：对造成这一切的人感到愤怒。

S2 : Frustration because you can’t do anything about it.

S2：因为无能为力而感到沮丧。

K : You get angry with the people who do these things, who kill the young men and chase out old women and children. Is that what you do? You identify with this and reject that. What is the structure, the analysis, of this identification?

K：你会对那些做这些事的人感到愤怒，那些杀害年轻人、驱逐老妇老幼的人。你也是这样吗？你认同这些，排斥那些。这种认同的结构和分析是什么？

S : You don’t feel secure.

S：你没有安全感。

K : Through identification you feel that you could do something? Move on.

K：通过认同感，你觉得自己可以做点什么？那就继续前进。

S : Even by taking one side you feel that you have a certain chance to do something.

S：即使只选择站在某一方，你也会觉得你有一定的机会去做某件事。

K : Say I am anti-Catholic; I identify myself with a group who are anti-clerical. Identifying myself with those, I feel I can do something. But go further, it is still me doing something about it, it is still the occupation with myself. I have identified myself with something I consider greater, like India, communism, Catholicism, and so on, or with my family, my God, my belief, my house, you who have hurt me. What is the reason for this identification?

K：假设我反天主教；我认同于一个反教权主义的群体。认同于他们，我觉得我能做点什么。但更进一步说，这仍然是我在做些什么，仍然是我在自我反思。我认同于一些我认为更伟大的事物，比如印度、共产主义、天主教等等，或者我的家人、我的上帝、我的信仰、我的家，以及伤害过我的你们。这种认同的理由是什么？

S : I separate myself from the rest of the world and in identifying with something bigger, that something becomes my ally.

S：我将自己与世界其他地方隔离开来，并通过认同更伟大的事物，使那个事物成为我的盟友。

K : Yes, but why do you do this? I identify myself with you because I like you. I don’t identify myself with him because I don’t like him. And I identify myself with my family, with my country, with my God, with my belief. Now why do I identify with anything at all? I don’t say it is right or wrong, but what is behind this identification?

K：是啊，但你为什么要这么做？我认同你是因为我喜欢你。我不认同他，因为我不喜欢他。我认同我的家庭、我的国家、我的上帝、我的信仰。那么，我为什么要认同任何事物呢？我不是说这种认同是对是错，而是这种认同背后究竟是什么？

S : Inward confusion.

S：内心的混乱。

K : Is it?

K：是吗？

S : You are afraid.

S：你害怕了。

K : Push further.

K：继续推进。

S : The confusion is caused by the identification.

S：这种混乱是由身份识别引起的。

K : Is it? I am questioning you and you must question me too. Don’t accept what I am saying, inquire. This whole process of identification, why does it happen? And if I don’t identify myself with you, or with something, I feel frustrated. Are you sure?

K：是吗？我在质疑你，你也必须质疑我。不要轻易接受我的说法，要追问。这种认同的过程，为什么会发生？如果我无法认同你，或者认同任何事物，我就会感到沮丧。你确定吗？

S : You feel unfulfilled, empty.

S：你感到空虚，没有成就感。

K : Go on. I feel sad, frustrated, not fulfilled, insufficient, empty. Now I want to know why I identify myself with a group, with a community, with feelings, ideas, ideals, heroes, and all the rest of it. Why?

K：继续说。我感到悲伤、沮丧、空虚、无所事事、力不从心。现在我想知道，为什么我会认同某个群体、某个社群、某些情感、理念、理想、英雄等等。为什么？

S : I think it is in order to have security.

S：我认为这是为了安全起见。

K : Yes. But what do you mean by that word security ?

K：是的。但是你说的“安全”是什么意思呢？

S : Alone I am weak.

S：我孤身一人时很虚弱。

K : Is it because you cannot stand alone?

K：是因为你无法独立吗？

S : It is because you are afraid to stand alone.

S：那是因为你害怕孤身一人。

K : You are frightened of being alone so, therefore, you identify?

K：你害怕孤独，所以你认同这种观点？

S : Not always.

S：不总是如此。

K : But it is the core, the root of it. Why do I want to identify myself? Because then I feel safe. I have pleasant memories of people and places so I identify myself with that. I see that in identification I am much more secure. Right?

K：但这是核心，是根源。我为什么想要认同自己？因为那样我会感到安全。我对人和地方都有美好的回忆，所以我认同这些。我发现，认同感能让我更有安全感。对吧？

S : I don’t know if you want to talk about this particular aspect, but if I see the killing in Vietnam is wrong, and there is a group of anti-war demonstrators in Washington, then I go and join them.

S：我不知道你是否想谈谈这个方面，但如果我认为越南的杀戮是错误的，而华盛顿又有一群反战示威者，那么我就会去加入他们。

K : Now wait a minute. There is an anti-war group and I join them. I identify myself with them because in identifying with a group of people who are doing something about it, I am also doing something about it; by myself I cannot do anything. But belonging to a group of people who demonstrate, who write articles, I am actively taking part in stopping the war. That is the identification. We are not saying the results of that identification are good or bad, but why does the human mind want to identify itself with something?

K：等等。我加入了一个反战组织。我认同他们，因为认同一个正在为反战采取行动的群体，我也在为反战做贡献；单凭我一个人什么也做不了。但加入一个示威游行、撰写文章的群体，我就是在积极参与制止战争。这就是认同的意义。我们并不是说这种认同的结果好坏，而是想探讨人类的思维为什么会想要认同某种事物。

S : When is it action and when is it identification?

S：什么时候是行动，什么时候是认同？

K : I am coming to that. First, I want to be clear in myself and in talking it over find out why I should identify. And when necessary I will identify. That is, I must first understand what it means to cooperate. Then, when I am really deeply cooperating, then I will know when not to cooperate. Not the other way round. I don’t know if you see this. If I know what is involved in cooperation, which is a tremendous thing—to work together, to live together, to do things together—when I understand that, then I will know when not to cooperate.

K：我这就说到重点。首先，我想理清思路，通过反复讨论，弄清楚我为什么要认同这种做法。必要时，我会认同。也就是说，我必须先理解合作的意义。然后，当我真正深入地合作之后，我就会知道何时不该合作。而不是反过来。我不知道你是否明白这一点。如果我了解合作的内涵——合作是一件意义非凡的事情——共同工作、共同生活、共同做事——当我理解了这一点，我就会知道何时不该合作。

Now I want to know why I identify myself with anything. Not that I shouldn’t identify if there is a necessity of identification in action, but before I find out how to act, or with whom I can cooperate, I want to find out why there is this urge to identify. To have security, is that the reason? Because you are far from your country, from your family, you identify with this house, with a group, to be safe, protected. The identification takes place because you feel, Here I am secure. So is the reason you identify because you are insecure? Is that it? Insecurity means fear, uncertainty, not knowing what to think, being confused. So you need protection; it is good to have protection. Is that the reason that you identify?

现在我想知道我为什么会认同任何事物。并非说我不应该认同，如果行动中确实需要认同，但在弄清楚如何行动或与谁合作之前，我想先弄清楚这种认同的冲动从何而来。是为了获得安全感吗？因为你远离祖国，远离家人，所以你认同这所房子，认同这个群体，是为了获得安全感和保护。这种认同感的产生是因为你觉得“在这里我很安全”。那么，你认同的原因是因为你缺乏安全感吗？是这样吗？不安全感意味着恐惧、不确定、不知所措、困惑。所以你需要保护；有保护是好事。这就是你认同的原因吗？

What is the next step? In myself I am uncertain, unclear, confused, frightened, and insufficient; therefore, I identify myself with a belief. Now what happens?

下一步该怎么做？我内心充满迷茫、困惑、恐惧和无力感；因此，我把自己等同于某种信念。现在会发生什么？

S : I find I am still insecure.

S：我发现自己仍然缺乏安全感。

K : No. I have identified myself with certain ideologies. What happens then?

K：不。我已经认同了某些意识形态。那接下来会发生什么？

S : You try to make that your security.

S：你试图把那当作你的安全保障。

K : I have given various reasons for this identification—because it is rational, it is workable, all the rest of it. Now what happens when I have identified myself with it?

K：我已经给出了各种理由来解释我的这种认同——因为它合乎逻辑，行之有效，等等。那么，当我认同了这种认同之后，会发生什么呢？

S : You have a conflict.

S：你们之间存在冲突。

K : Look what happens. I have identified myself with an ideology, with a group of people, or a person; it is part of me. I must protect that, mustn’t I? Therefore, if it is threatened I am lost, I am back again to my insecurity. So what takes place? I am angry with anybody who attacks or doubts it. Then what is the actual thing that takes place?

K：你看发生了什么。我把自己认同于某种意识形态、某个群体或某个人；它成了我的一部分。我必须保护它，不是吗？因此，如果它受到威胁，我就迷失了方向，我又回到了不安全的状态。那么结果是什么呢？我会对任何攻击或质疑它的人感到愤怒。那么，实际发生了什么呢？

S : Conflict.

S：冲突。

K : I have identified myself with an ideology. I must protect it because it is my security and I resist anybody who threatens that with a contradictory ideology. So where I have identified myself with an ideology there must be resistance; I build a wall around what I have identified myself with. Where there is a wall, it must create division. Then there is conflict. I don’t know if you see all this?

K：我认同某种意识形态。我必须捍卫它，因为它关乎我的安全，我会抵制任何用与之相悖的意识形态威胁到它的人。所以，凡是我认同的意识形态，就必然存在抵制；我会在我认同的周围筑起一道墙。有墙的地方，必然会造成分裂。然后就会产生冲突。我不知道你是否明白这一切？

Now what is the next step? Go on.

下一步是什么？继续。

S1 : What is the difference between identification and cooperation?

S1：认同与合作之间有什么区别？

S2 : It seems there has to be more understanding of cooperation.

S2：看来我们需要对合作有更深入的了解。

K : You know what it means to cooperate, to work together? Can there be cooperation when there is identification? Do you know what we mean by identification? We have examined the anatomy of it. Cooperation means to work together. Can I work with you if I have identified myself with an ideology and you are identified with another ideology? Obviously not.

K：你知道合作、共同工作的意义吗？如果存在认同，还能合作吗？你知道我们说的认同是什么意思吗？我们已经分析过认同的本质。合作意味着共同工作。如果我认同某种意识形态，而你认同另一种意识形态，我们还能合作吗？显然不能。

S : But people have to work together.

S：但人们必须齐心协力。

K : Is that cooperation?

K：这算是合作吗？

S : No.

S：否。

K : See what is involved. Because of our identification with an ideology we work together; you protect it and I protect it. It is our security—in the name of God, in the name of beauty, in the name of anything. We think that is cooperation. Now what takes place? Can there be cooperation when there is identification with a group?

K：看看这里面牵涉到什么。因为我们认同某种意识形态，所以我们合作；你保护它，我也保护它。这是我们的安全——以神的名义，以美的名义，以任何名义。我们认为这就是合作。那么，结果如何呢？当人们认同某个群体时，还能有合作吗？

S : No, because there is division. I find myself in conflict with members of the group, because I keep identifying with them.

S：不，因为存在分歧。我发现自己与团体成员之间存在冲突，因为我总是认同他们。

K : Look what is happening. You and I have identified ourselves with that ideology. Our interpretation of that ideology may be—

K：看看现在发生了什么。你我都认同了那种意识形态。我们对那种意识形态的解读可能是——

S : Different.

S：不一样。

K : Of course. If you vary in the interpretation of that ideology, you are deviating; therefore, we are in conflict. Therefore, we must both agree about that ideology completely. Is that possible?

K：当然。如果你对这种意识形态的解读有所不同，你就偏离了正轨；因此，我们就产生了冲突。所以，我们必须对这种意识形态完全达成一致。这可能吗？

S : That is exactly what happens with a school. Instead of an ideology, you identify with a school and each person has his own concept.

S：学校的情况正是如此。人们认同的不是某种意识形态，而是学校本身，每个人都有自己的一套理解。

K : Yes, quite right. Why?

K：是的，完全正确。为什么？

S : I sense that sometimes there is conflict here for just the reason you were giving when talking about an ideology. If you and I identify with the school, we think we are cooperating, but there isn’t that spirit.

S：我感觉有时候这里确实存在冲突，原因正如你刚才谈到意识形态时所说的那样。如果我们认同这所学校，我们以为是在合作，但实际上并没有那种合作精神。

K : Therefore, I am asking, can there be cooperation when there is identification?

K：因此，我想问的是，当存在身份认同时，还能进行合作吗？

S : No.

S：否。

K : Do you know what you are saying? [Laughter.] That is how everything in this world is working. Is that the truth? That where there is identification there can be no cooperation? It is a marvelous thing to discover the truth of this. Not your opinion, or my opinion, but the truth, the validity of it. Therefore, we have to find out what we mean by cooperation. You see that there can be no cooperation when there is identification with an idea, with a leader, with a group, and so on. Then what is cooperation in which there is no identification?

K：你知道你在说什么吗？[笑声] 世间万物皆如此运转。这就是真理吗？认同之处，便无合作可言？发现这一真理，真是一件奇妙的事。不是你的观点，也不是我的观点，而是真理本身，是它的有效性。因此，我们必须弄清楚合作的含义。你看，当认同于某种理念、某个领导者、某个群体等等时，合作便无从谈起。那么，不认同于任何事物的合作，又是什么呢？

S : Acting in response to the situation itself.

S：根据实际情况采取行动。

K : I am not saying you are not right, but can we work together when you and I think differently? When you are concerned with yourself and I am concerned with myself? And one of the reasons is that knowing we cannot cooperate when we are thinking of ourselves, we try to identify ourselves with an ideology, hoping thereby to bring about cooperation. But if you don’t identify, what is cooperation?

K：我不是说你不对，但是当我们想法不同的时候，我们还能合作吗？当你只关心自己，我也只关心自己的时候？其中一个原因是，我们知道如果只考虑自己就无法合作，所以我们试图认同某种意识形态，希望以此促成合作。但是如果没有认同，合作又从何谈起呢？

Here we are at Brockwood, in a school. We see there cannot be cooperation when there is identification with the school, with an idea, with a program, with a particular policy of this and that. And also we see that identification is the cause of all division. Then, what is cooperation? To work together —not about something. Do you see the difference? So before you do something together, what is the spirit of cooperation—the feeling, the inwardness of it—what is that feeling?

我们现在在布罗克伍德，在一所学校里。我们看到，当人们对学校、某种理念、某个项目或某项政策产生认同感时，合作就不可能存在。我们也看到，这种认同感是所有分裂的根源。那么，什么是合作？是共同努力——而不是为了某个特定的事情。你明白其中的区别吗？所以在你们共同做某件事之前，合作的精神是什么？那种感觉，那种内在的感受——那种感觉究竟是什么？

S : Understanding, being completely open to it.

S：理解，完全接受它。

K : Go a little deeper. We said identification is not cooperation. Are you quite sure on that point? And are you quite clear that cooperation cannot exist when each of us is concerned with himself? When you are concerned with yourself, you have no spirit of cooperation, you only cooperate when it pleases you. So what does it mean to cooperate? What does it mean to cooperate when there is no “me”? Otherwise you can’t cooperate. I may try to cooperate around an idea, but there is always the “me” that is trying to identify itself with the thing that I am doing. So I must find out why it is that I am thinking about myself all day long: how I look; that somebody is better than me; why somebody has hurt me, or somebody has said, “What a nice person you are.” Why am I doing this all day long? And at night too, when I’m asleep this goes on: “I am better than you”; “I know what I am talking about”; “It is my experience”; “You are stupid, I am clever.” Why?

K：再深入探讨一下。我们说过认同并不等于合作。你对此非常确定吗？你是否清楚地认识到，当我们每个人都只关注自身时，合作就不可能存在？当你只关注自身时，你就没有合作精神，你只会在自己乐意的时候才合作。那么，合作的意义是什么？当没有“我”的时候，合作的意义又是什么？否则，合作就无从谈起。我或许会尝试围绕某个想法进行合作，但总有一个“我”试图将自己与我正在做的事情认同起来。所以我必须弄清楚，为什么我整天都在想着自己：我的外貌如何；有人比我优秀；为什么有人伤害了我，或者有人说“你真是个好人”。为什么我整天都在想这些？甚至到了晚上，当我睡着的时候，这些想法依然存在：“我比你强”；“我知道自己在说什么”；“这是我的经验”；“你很笨，我很聪明”。为什么？

S : It seems a lot of it becomes a habit.

S：很多事情似乎都会变成习惯。

K : What is habit?

K：什么是习惯？

S : Not being aware.

S：不知情。

K : No. What is habit? Not how is it formed.

K：不。什么是习惯？不是习惯是如何形成的。

S : Repetition of a movement.

S：重复动作。

K : Right. Why is there a repetition of this movement? Why is habit formed? You will see something extraordinary if you go slowly. We have all got short hair or long hair; why? Because others do it?

K：没错。为什么这种行为会不断重复？为什么会养成习惯？如果你慢慢来，你会发现一些非凡的事情。我们都有短发或长发；为什么？因为别人都这样做吗？

S : Is that habit or imitation?

S：那是习惯还是模仿？

K : See what takes place. First you imitate others, then you say, “Short hair is square.”

K：看看会发生什么。一开始你模仿别人，然后你说，“短发很土气。”

S : Is a custom a habit too?

S：习俗也是一种习惯吗？

K : Yes. I don’t want to go too quickly into this. Isn’t all thinking habit? You agree?

K：是的。我不想这么快就深入探讨这个问题。难道所有的思考不都是一种习惯吗？你同意吗？

S : Well, it is something you do over and over again.

S：嗯，这是你反复做的事情。

K : Go on, see what you can discover for yourself when we go into this whole question of habit.

K：继续，看看当我们深入探讨习惯这个问题时，你能发现些什么。

S : It is really a situation with an old reaction, isn’t it?

S：这确实是一种老套的反应，不是吗？

K : A new situation we meet with old responses. Is not identification a habit?

K：面对新情况，我们却用老方法应对。难道认同不是一种习惯吗？

S : Yes.

S：是的。

K : Because you are insecure. So do you know the nature of this machinery that makes for habit? Are you aware that you are always operating by habit? To get up at six o’clock every day, to believe, to smoke, not to smoke, to take drugs. You follow? Everything is reduced to habit—it may be of a week, ten days, or fifty years, but the habit is formed. Why does the mind fall into this groove? Haven’t you asked yourself why you have a habit? Have you watched your mind working in habit?

K：因为你缺乏安全感。那么，你知道这种习惯的形成机制的本质吗？你意识到自己总是受习惯支配吗？每天六点起床，相信某件事，抽烟，不抽烟，吸毒。你明白吗？一切都归结为习惯——可能是一周，十天，也可能是五十年，但习惯已经形成。为什么人的思维会陷入这种模式？你难道没有问过自己为什么会有习惯吗？你观察过自己的思维是如何受习惯支配的吗？

S1 : It is easier.

S1：这更容易。

S2 : It takes really a lot of energy to live without habit.

S2：没有习惯的生活真的需要耗费很多精力。

K : I am coming to that. Don’t jump, move from step to step. I am asking myself: Why does the mind always live in habit? I thought that yesterday, I still think that today, and I will think the same about it tomorrow—with slight modifications perhaps. Now why does the mind do this?

K：我正要说到这一点。别急，一步一步来。我一直在问自己：为什么人的思维总是受习惯束缚？我昨天这么想，今天依然这么想，明天可能还会这么想——或许会略有不同。那么，人的思维为什么会这样呢？

S : One is half asleep.

S：我半睡半醒。

K : We said laziness is part of it. What else? It feels easier with habits.

K：我们说过懒惰是原因之一。还有什么呢？养成习惯会更容易些。

S : One is afraid of the unknown.

S：人总是害怕未知的事物。

K : I want to go a little deeper than that.

K：我想更深入地探讨一下。

S : The mind is afraid that if it doesn’t maintain thinking in the same way, it will itself be threatened.

S：人的思维害怕，如果它不继续以同样的方式思考，它自身就会受到威胁。

K : Which means what?

K：那是什么意思？

S : It sees a certain kind of order in habit.

S：它从习惯中看到了某种秩序。

K : Is habit order?

K：习惯是秩序吗？

S : You can form a certain structure with habit, but that is not necessarily order.

S：习惯可以形成某种结构，但这不一定是秩序。

K : Which means that the mind functions in habit for various reasons, like a machine. It is easier, it avoids loneliness, fear of the unknown, and it implies a certain order to say, “I will follow that and nothing else.” Now why does the mind function in a groove, which is habit?

K：这意味着，出于各种原因，人的思维会像机器一样，按照习惯运转。这样做更轻松，可以避免孤独和对未知的恐惧，而且它暗示着某种秩序，让人觉得“我会遵循这个，别的都不做”。那么，为什么人的思维会按照某种固定的模式（也就是习惯）运转呢？

S : Its nature is that.

S：它的本质就是这样。

K : But if you say that, then you stop inquiring. We know the reasons that the mind functions in habit; are you actually aware of it? The highly psychopathic person has a habit which is completely different from others. A neurotic person has certain habits. We condemn that habit but accept others. So why does the mind do this? I want to go into it deeper, I want to see why it does it and whether the mind can live without habit.

K：但如果你这么说，那就等于停止了探究。我们知道思维习惯运作的原因；你真的意识到这一点吗？高度精神病态的人的习惯与其他人截然不同。神经质的人也有一些习惯。我们谴责某些习惯，却接受其他习惯。那么，为什么思维会这样做呢？我想更深入地探究，我想看看它这样做的原因，以及思维是否能够脱离习惯而存在。

S : Because it feels it is the personality.

S：因为感觉这就是个性。

K : We said that the personality, the ego, the “me” which says, “I am frightened, I want order, laziness, all that are different facets of the ‘me.’” Can the mind live without habit? Except for the biological habits, the regular functioning of the body, which has its own mechanism, its own intelligence, its own machinery. Why does the mind accept habit so quickly? The question, “Can it live without habit?” is a tremendous question. To say that there is God, that there is a savior, is a habit. And to say there is no savior, but only the State, is another habit. So the mind lives in habit. Does it feel more secure in habit?

K：我们说过，人格、自我、那个“我”，它会说：“我害怕，我渴望秩序，我懒惰”，所有这些都是“我”的不同面向。人的思维可以脱离习惯而存在吗？除了生物性的习惯，也就是身体的正常运转——它有自己的机制、自己的智慧、自己的机器——之外，为什么思维如此轻易地接受习惯？“思维可以脱离习惯而存在吗？”这个问题意义重大。说有上帝，有救世主，是一种习惯。说没有救世主，只有国家，也是一种习惯。所以，思维生活在习惯之中。它在习惯中会感到更安全吗？

S : Yes.

S：是的。

K : Go slowly. Which means what? Functioning in the field of the known, it feels safe. The known is habit, right?

K：慢慢来。这意味着什么？在已知领域运作会让人感到安全。已知就是习惯，对吧？

S : Even then, we still say we don’t feel safe.

S：即使这样，我们仍然觉得不安全。

K : Because the known may change or may be taken away or get something added to it. But the mind is always functioning in the field of the known because there it feels secure. So the known is the habit, the known is knowledge—that is, knowledge of science, of technology, and the knowledge of my own experiences. And in that there is mechanical habit. Now I am asking: Can the mind move from the known—not into the unknown, I don’t know what that means—but be free and move away from the borders of the known?

K：因为已知事物可能会改变，可能会消失，也可能会增添新的内容。但人的思维总是在已知领域内运作，因为在那里它感到安全。所以，已知就是习惯，已知就是知识——也就是科学知识、技术知识以及我自身经验的知识。而其中就包含着机械的习惯。现在我想问的是：人的思维能否从已知领域出发——不是进入未知领域，我不知道那意味着什么——而是获得自由，超越已知领域的边界？

Look. If I know everything about the internal combustion engine, I can continue experimenting in the same direction, but there is a limitation. I must find something new, there must be some other way to create energy.

你看，即便我对内燃机了如指掌，我仍然可以沿着这个方向继续做实验，但这终究是个局限。我必须找到新的方法，必须找到其他产生能量的方式。

S : Would the mind say that if it wanted the security of the known?

S：如果人的思维想要的是已知事物带来的安全感，它会这么说吗？

K : I am not talking about security at the moment.

K：我现在不谈安全问题。

S : Are you saying that there has to be a break in continuity in technology in order for something new to happen?

S：你的意思是说，技术发展必须打破连续性，才能出现新的事物吗？

K : That’s right. That is what takes place. Otherwise man couldn’t have invented the jet engine; he had to look at the problem differently.

K：没错。事情就是这样。否则人类就不可能发明喷气式发动机；他必须换个角度看待这个问题。

My mind always works in the field of the known, the modified, which is habit. In relationship with human beings, in thought—which is the response of memory and always within the field of the known—I am identifying myself with the unknown through the known. The mind must function with the known because otherwise one couldn’t talk, but I am asking if it can also function without any habit.

我的思维总是在已知、已改变的领域运作，也就是习惯。在与人交往中，在思考中——思考是对记忆的回应，也始终局限于已知领域——我通过已知来认同未知。思维必须在已知的基础上运作，否则就无法交流，但我质疑的是，思维是否也能脱离任何习惯而运作。

S : Does the mind ask that question because acting out of habit is unsuccessful?

S：人们之所以会问这个问题，是因为习惯性行为不成功吗？

K : I am not thinking of success.

K：我没有考虑成功。

S : But what would make the mind ask this?

S：但是是什么原因导致人们产生这样的疑问呢？

K : My mind says, this isn’t good enough, I want more. It wants to find out more, and it can’t find it within the field of the known, it can only expand that field.

K：我的大脑告诉我，这还不够好，我想要更多。它想要了解更多，但它无法在已知领域内找到答案，它只能扩展这个领域。

S : But it has to realize the limitation.

S：但它必须意识到自身的局限性。

K : I realize it, and I say to myself: I can function within the field of the known, I can always expand it or contract it, horizontally, vertically, in any way, but it is always within the field of the known. My mind says I understand that very well. And so, being curious, it says: Can the mind live, can it function, without habit?

K：我意识到了这一点，然后我对自己说：我可以在已知领域内运作，我可以随时扩展或收缩它，水平方向、垂直方向，任何方向都可以，但它始终都在已知领域内。我的头脑告诉我，我非常理解这一点。于是，出于好奇，它问道：没有习惯，头脑还能生存、还能运作吗？

S : Is that a different question?

S：这是另一个问题吗？

K : Now I am talking psychologically, inwardly. Apparently all life, all the mental activity in the psyche, is a continuity of habit.

K：我现在是从心理层面，从内在层面来谈。显然，所有的生活，所有心理活动，都是习惯的延续。

S : Is there really an impetus or something—

S：真的有什么推动力之类的吗？

K : I am creating an impetus. The mind is itself creating the impetus to find out—not because it wants to find something.

K：我是在创造一种动力。人的思维本身就在创造探索的动力——并非因为它想要找到什么。

S : This is a very touchy point. This seems to be the key to some difficulty. Why—if I may just ask the question—does the mind say: I see the need for living without psychological habit?

S：这是一个非常敏感的问题。这似乎是某些困难的关键所在。请允许我问一句，为什么人的思维会说：我意识到需要摆脱心理习惯？

K : I don’t see the need, I am not positing anything. I am only saying I have seen the mind in operation in the field of the known—contracting, expanding horizontally or vertically, or reducing it to nothing, but always within that area. And my mind asks, if there is a way of living—I don’t know it, I don’t even posit it—in which there is no habit at all.

K：我不觉得有必要，我也没有提出任何假设。我只是说，我观察到思维在已知领域中的运作——收缩、横向或纵向扩张，或者将其缩小到虚无，但始终都在这个领域之内。我的思维在问，是否存在一种生活方式——我不知道，我甚至没有假设——在这种生活方式中，完全没有任何习惯。

So we come back. Do you know what you are thinking about all day? You say, “Yes, I am thinking about myself, vaguely or concretely, or subtly, or in a most refined manner, but always around that.” Can there be love when the mind is occupied with itself all the time? You say no; why?

所以我们又回到了原点。你知道你整天都在想什么吗？你说：“是的，我一直在想我自己，有时模糊，有时具体，有时微妙，有时又极其精妙，但总是围绕着我自己。”当一个人的思想始终被自身占据时，还能有爱吗？你说不能；为什么？

S : Because if you are thinking about yourself all the time, you can’t—

S：因为如果你总是想着自己，你就无法——

K : Therefore, you can never say, “I love you,” until you stop thinking about yourself. When a man feels ambitious, competitive, imitative, which is part of thinking about oneself, can there be love?

K：所以，除非你停止想着自己，否则你永远无法说出“我爱你”。当一个男人感到雄心勃勃、好胜、模仿，而这些都是想着自己的表现时，还能有爱吗？

So we have to find a way of living in which habit is not. But habit can be used—the known can be used, I won’t call it habit—in a different way, depending on the circumstances, the situation, and so on. So is love habit? Pleasure is habit, isn’t it? Is love pleasure?

所以我们必须找到一种不依赖习惯的生活方式。但是习惯——或者说已知的事物，我不会称之为习惯——可以根据不同的情况、情境等等，以不同的方式加以利用。那么，爱是习惯吗？快乐是习惯，不是吗？爱是快乐吗？

S : What do you mean by love, sir?

S：先生，您说的“爱”是什么意思？

K : I don’t know. I will tell you what it is not; and when that is not in you, the other is. Listen to this: Where the known is, love is not.

K：我不知道。我会告诉你它不是什么；当你心中没有那种东西时，另一种东西就出现了。听着：凡是已知存在的地方，就没有爱。

S : So one has to find out first what habit is, and then about non-habit.

S：所以首先要弄清楚什么是习惯，然后再弄清楚什么是非习惯。

K : We have found it. We have said that habit is the continuation of action within the field of the known. The known is the tomorrow. Tomorrow is Sunday and I am going out for a drive; I know that, I have arranged it. Can I say, “Tomorrow I will love”?

K：我们找到了答案。我们说过，习惯是在已知领域内持续行动的结果。已知领域就是明天。明天是星期天，我要出去兜风；我知道这一点，我已经安排好了。我能说“明天我会去爱”吗？

S1 : No.

S1：编号。

S2 : I do.

S2：我愿意。

K : What do you mean, “I will love you tomorrow”?

K：你说的“我明天还会爱你”是什么意思？

S : We promise that.

S：我们保证。

K : In a church, you mean? That means love is within the field of the known and, therefore, within time.

K：你是说在教堂里吗？那意味着爱存在于已知领域之内，因此也存在于时间之内。

S : But if you love once, can you suddenly stop loving?

S：但是如果你爱过一次，你能突然停止爱吗？

K : I loved you once; I am bored with you now!

K：我曾经爱过你；现在我对你感到厌倦了！

S : If you love someone today, you can love him tomorrow.

S：如果你今天爱一个人，明天你依然会爱他。

K : How do you know? I love you today, but you want to be sure that I’ll love you tomorrow. Therefore, I say, “I’ll love you, darling, tomorrow.”

K：你怎么知道？我今天爱你，但你想确定我明天也爱你。所以，我说：“亲爱的，我明天也爱你。”

S : That is something else.

S：那又是另一回事了。

K : I am asking: Has love a tomorrow? Habit has a tomorrow because it continues. Is love a continuity? Is love identification?—I love my wife, my son, my God?

K：我想问的是：爱有明天吗？习惯有明天，因为它会延续。爱是一种延续吗？爱是一种认同吗？——我爱我的妻子、我的儿子、我的上帝？

Therefore, you have to really understand—not just verbally—the whole process, the structure and the nature of the known, the whole field of it inwardly, how you function always within that field, thinking from that field. The tomorrow you can grasp because it is projected from the known. To really understand this you have to understand all that we have said; you have to know what you think and why, and you have to observe it.

因此，你必须真正理解——不仅仅是口头上理解——整个过程、已知事物的结构和本质，理解它内在的整个领域，理解你如何始终在这个领域中运作，如何从这个领域出发思考。你之所以能够把握未来，是因为它源于已知。要真正理解这一点，你必须理解我们所说的一切；你必须知道你在想什么以及为什么想，并且你必须观察它。

S : You can know what you think, but you don’t always know why you think it.

S：你可以知道自己在想什么，但你并不总是知道你为什么会这么想。

K : Oh, yes, it is fairly simple. I want to know why I think, why thought comes in. Yesterday I went to the tailor and I forgot my watch there. Last night I looked for it and I thought about it and said, “How lazy of me, how inconsiderate on my part to leave it there, giving trouble.” All that went through the mind.

K：哦，是的，这很简单。我想知道我为什么会思考，为什么会有思考。昨天我去裁缝店，把手表忘在那儿了。昨晚我找手表的时候，一直在想这件事，然后我说：“我真懒，真没考虑周到，把它落在那里，给大家添麻烦了。” 诸如此类的想法在我脑海里闪过。

S : When you say it was inconsiderate of you, you were identifying yourself.

S：你说你这样做很不体贴，其实你是在暴露自己的身份。

K : No, I forgot the watch. Which means they have to take the trouble to look after it, someone might take it, they will be responsible, all that. And I thought about it, and I know why this whole momentum of thinking arose from that. I watched the whole flow of thought. You can know the beginning and the ending of thought. You look so mystified! I have thought about it and I can end it. I left the watch there and I thought it might get lost; I have had it for a long time, I have cared for it; I would give it away, but not lose it. And if it is lost, finished. I don’t think any more about it.

K：不，我把表忘了。这意味着他们得费心照看，万一被人拿走了，他们得负责，等等等等。我想了想，我知道为什么会突然冒出这么多想法。我观察了整个思路。你可以知道一个想法的开始和结束。你看上去好困惑！我已经想过了，我可以结束了。我把表放在那儿，担心它会丢；我戴了很久，一直很爱惜它；我会把它送人，但不能弄丢。如果丢了，那就完了。我不再想这件事了。

Now, to watch every thought, to be aware of it! Any thought is significant if you penetrate it; you can see the origin of it and the ending of it—not go on and on.

现在，要观察每一个念头，觉察它！任何念头，只要你深入理解，都是有意义的；你可以看到它的起源和终结——而不是无休止地纠缠下去。

S : And you say that if you see why the thought originated, you will be able to see the ending of it?

S：你的意思是，如果你看到了一个想法的起源，你就能看到它的结局？

K : No, look. Is there an individual thought separate from another thought? Are all thoughts separate or are they interrelated? What do you say?

K：不，你看。是否存在独立于其他思想的个体思想？所有思想都是相互独立的，还是彼此关联？你怎么看？

S : They are interrelated.

S：它们是相互关联的。

K : Are you sure?

K：你确定吗？

S : Well, they all come from one another.

S：嗯，它们都是相互关联的。

K : If I understand their interrelationship, or if there is an understanding of the background from which all thought springs—

K：如果我理解了它们之间的相互关系，或者如果我理解了所有思想产生的背景——

S : That is the difficult point.

S：这就是难点所在。

K : To watch without any question of wanting an answer means infinite watchfulness. Not impatience. Watch carefully, then everything comes out. If you and I quarrel, I don’t want to carry it in my mind, in thought, I want to finish it. I’ll come to you and say, “I am sorry, I didn’t mean it”; and it is finished. But do I do that?

K：不求任何答案地观察，意味着无限的警觉，而非急躁。仔细观察，一切自然水落石出。如果我们吵架了，我不想让它一直萦绕在心头，我想把它解决掉。我会去找你，说：“对不起，我不是故意的”；然后就结束了。但我会这么做吗？

Have you learned a lot—not have learned, but are you learning, seeing what it means to learn?

你是否学到了很多——不是已经学到了很多，而是正在学习，明白了学习的意义？

Brockwood Park, June 19, 1971

布罗克伍德公园，1971年6月19日

2

Student : We were talking about why one can’t say that one loves someone.

学生：我们当时在讨论为什么一个人不能说自己爱某人。

Krishnamurti : Can we approach it in a different way? Do you know what aggressiveness is? It means opposition, to go against. From that arises the question: How are you going to meet life when you have passed through here and are so-called educated? Do you want to be swallowed up by the society, the culture in which you live, or are you going to oppose it, revolt against it, which will be a reaction and not a total action? Are you going to step into the easy way of life, conform, imitate, adjust to the pattern, whatever that pattern be, whether it be the establishment, or an establishment of a different kind, and so on? Or are you going to be a totally different human being, who is aware and knows he has to meet adversity and opposition and that, therefore, there is no easy way of satisfaction? Because most of us want a life of ease, of comfort, without trouble, which is almost impossible. And if you do meet opposition, will you run away from it? If you don’t like some place, certain people, a job, will you move away, run away from it to do something else that will be satisfactory? Do you use others for your own satisfaction? And is love the use of others, either sexually or as companionship, or for one’s own satisfaction—not superficially but much more deeply?

克里希那穆提：我们能否换个角度来看待这个问题？你知道什么是攻击性吗？它意味着反对，意味着对抗。由此引出一个问题：当你走过人生，接受了所谓的教育之后，你将如何面对生活？你是想被你所处的社会和文化所吞噬，还是想反抗它，反抗它？这是一种被动的反应，而非主动的行动。你是想选择安逸的生活方式，顺从、模仿、适应某种模式，无论那模式是什么，无论是既定的体制，还是其他类型的体制等等？还是想成为一个截然不同的人，一个意识到自己必须面对逆境和反对，因而明白没有捷径可走的人？因为我们大多数人都想要轻松舒适、毫无烦恼的生活，但这几乎是不可能的。如果你真的遇到了反对，你会逃避吗？如果你不喜欢某个地方、某些人或一份工作，你会搬走、逃离它，去做其他让你满意的事情吗？你会利用他人来满足自己的欲望吗？爱是否就是利用他人，无论是性方面的利用、陪伴方面的利用，还是为了满足自己的欲望——不仅仅是肤浅的，而是更深层次的利用？

How are you going to meet all this, which is what life is? The so-called educated people in the world, who have been to college, to university, have good jobs, fit into a place and stay there and advance there, have their own troubles, their own adversities. One may pass some exam and get a job, or one may have been educated technologically. But psychologically, one doesn’t know anything about oneself. One is unhappy, miserable because one can’t get this or that. One quarrels with one’s husband or wife. And they are all very educated people who read books but disregard the whole field of life. And uneducated people do the same.

你打算如何面对这一切？这就是生活。世界上那些所谓的受过教育的人，上过大学，有好工作，适应环境，在那里生活并不断晋升，他们也有自己的烦恼和逆境。一个人或许通过了考试，找到了工作，或者接受过技术教育。但在心理层面，他们却对自己一无所知。他们不快乐，很痛苦，因为他们得不到这样或那样的东西。他们和伴侣争吵。他们都是受过高等教育的人，他们读书，却忽视了生活的方方面面。而那些没有受过教育的人也一样。

You are going to be educated. I don’t know why, but you are going to be. And then what? Lead a comfortable life? Not that one is against comfort, but if one is seeking comfort in life it becomes rather shoddy, rather shallow, and you have to conform to a tremendous extent to the structure of the culture in which you live. And if you revolt against the culture and join a group, which has its own pattern, you have to fit into that too.

你会接受教育。我不知道为什么，但你肯定会接受教育。然后呢？过上舒适的生活吗？并非反对舒适，但如果一个人追求的是舒适，那生活就会变得粗糙、肤浅，而且你必须在很大程度上适应你所处文化的结构。如果你反抗这种文化，加入一个有自己模式的群体，你也必须融入其中。

Most human beings throughout the world want to be safe, secure, comfortable, lead a life of indulgence, a life in which they do not have too much opposition, where they conform superficially, but revolt against conforming, become superficially respectable but are inwardly rebellious, have a job, get married, have children and responsibility. But because the mind wants something much more than that, they are discontented, running from one thing to another. Seeing all of this—not just one segment, one fraction of it, but the whole of the map—what are you all going to do? Or is it a question that you cannot possibly answer at your age? You are too young, perhaps, with your own occupations, so the other can wait.

世界上大多数人都渴望安全、安稳、舒适的生活，过着享乐主义的生活，一个没有太多反对的声音的生活，表面上顺从，内心却反抗顺从；表面上受人尊敬，内心却叛逆；拥有一份工作，结婚生子，承担起责任。但因为人的内心渴望远不止于此，所以他们感到不满，不断地奔波于各种事物之间。看到这一切——不仅仅是其中的一部分，而是整幅图景——你们打算怎么做？或者，这个问题在你们这个年纪根本无法回答？也许你们还太年轻，忙于自己的事业，所以这个问题可以以后再说。

S : One knows what one would like to do.

S：每个人都知道自己想做什么。

K : Do you know what you want to do?

K：你知道自己想做什么吗？

S : I know what I’d like to do.

S：我知道我想做什么。

K : What would you like to do? Like? I might like to be the Queen of England, or the greatest something or other, but I can’t, I haven’t got the capacity. So when you say you’d like to do something, that gives you pleasure, that gives you satisfaction. That is what everybody wants: comfort, pleasure, satisfaction. “This is what I want to do because I feel happy doing it.” And when you find opposition along that path, you don’t know how to meet it and then you try to escape from it.

K：你想做什么？比如？我可能想当英国女王，或者成为某个最伟大的人物，但我做不到，我没有那个能力。所以，当你说你想做某件事时，那件事能给你带来快乐和满足感。这正是每个人都想要的：舒适、快乐和满足感。“我想做这件事，因为做这件事让我感到快乐。”而当你在这条路上遇到阻力时，你不知道该如何应对，于是你就会想方设法逃避。

You know, this is really a very difficult question; it is not easy to say what one would like to do. This is a very complex question. That is why I said, “Is this asking too much?” Or, at your age, are you already beginning to have an inkling of what you want to do, not only for the next year but for the rest of your life?

你知道，这真是一个很难回答的问题；要说出自己想做什么并不容易。这是一个非常复杂的问题。所以我才问：“这个问题是不是太苛刻了？”或者，在你这个年纪，你是否已经开始对未来想做什么有了些许想法，不仅是明年，更是你的一生？

S : We are not too young.

S：我们年纪不算小。

K : I don’t know. I don’t know whether you are too old or too young. It is for you to answer, not for me. I am putting this to you, for you to find out.

K：我不知道。我不知道你年纪太大还是太小。这应该由你来回答，而不是我。我把这个问题抛给你，让你自己去思考。

S : Some of us are already too old. We are already shaped. Already we have had experiences that make us all very bored with life.

S：我们当中有些人已经太老了。我们已经定型了。我们已经经历过很多事情，让我们对生活感到非常厌倦。

K : You know, the other day we were talking about the fact that we are always thinking about ourselves. And when you are thinking about yourself, isn’t it generally around what gives you the greatest pleasure? “I want to do that, because it is going to give me tremendous satisfaction.” So how do you meet all these things? Shouldn’t you be educated not only in geography, history, mathematics, and all the rest of it, but also in this field, where you have to discover for yourself how to live in this monstrous world? Isn’t that part of education? Now how could you set about educating yourself to meet this life? Do you expect somebody else to educate you, as they educate you in mathematics and other subjects?

K：你知道，前几天我们还在讨论我们总是想着自己。而当你想着自己的时候，是不是通常都在想着什么能给你带来最大的快乐？“我想做这件事，因为它会给我带来巨大的满足感。”那么，你该如何满足所有这些需求呢？难道你不应该不仅学习地理、历史、数学等等学科，还要学习这方面的知识吗？在这个你必须自己去探索如何在这个残酷的世界中生存的领域，难道这不也是教育的一部分吗？那么，你该如何进行自我教育，以应对这样的人生呢？你指望别人像教你数学和其他学科那样来教你这方面吗？

S : No.

S：否。

K : No? You are quite sure? If nobody is going to educate you in the psychological, inward, way of living, how are you going to do it? How are you going to educate yourself? You know what is happening in the world? Apart from the monstrosities and wars and butcheries and all the terrible things that are going on, people who think they know are trying to educate you—and not just in the technological world that is clear, simple, and factual.

K：不？你很确定吗？如果没人教你如何进行心理上的、内在的、生活方式方面的教育，你打算怎么做？你打算如何自学？你知道世界上正在发生什么吗？除了那些暴行、战争、屠杀以及所有可怕的事情之外，那些自认为懂得多的人正在试图教育你——而且不仅仅是在那些清晰、简单、基于事实的科技领域。

The other day on television some bishop said: “The knowledge of God is love and if you don’t have knowledge of God you can’t live, life becomes meaningless.” Now there is that statement made most emphatically by a well-known bishop, or whatever he was, and I listened to it and I said: I am learning, I want to find out. I want to be educated. He has reasonable explanations, and you look at his collar, or his coat, or his beret, and you say, “Oh, he is a priest, he is an old man, he is repeating old stuff, that is nothing,” and you push him away. And then a man comes along and offers you a pattern of living which seems reasonable, logical; and because of his personality, the way he looks, dresses, walks—you know all the tricks—you say, “Yes, he has got something.” And you listen to him. And through the very act of listening you are being conditioned by what he says, aren’t you?

前几天电视上，一位主教说：“认识上帝就是爱，如果你不认识上帝，你就无法生存，生命将变得毫无意义。” 这番话出自一位知名主教之口，或者不管他是什么身份，语气极其肯定。我听了之后心想：我正在学习，我想弄明白。我想接受教育。他给出了一些看似合理的解释，但你看看他的衣领、外套或贝雷帽，就会想：“哦，他是个牧师，是个老头，老生常谈，没什么大不了的。” 然后你就把他拒之门外。接着，又有人出现，向你展示一种看似合理、合乎逻辑的生活方式；因为他的个性、外表、穿着、走路方式——你知道他那些惯用的伎俩——你会说：“嗯，他肯定有道理。” 然后你就听他讲。而你，正是通过聆听这个行为，被他所说的话潜移默化地影响着，不是吗？

S : It depends how you listen.

S：这取决于你怎么听。

K : If you don’t know how to listen to that bishop, you will say, “How reasonable, he says we have lived this way for two thousand years, this is the right way, with the knowledge of God.” I listen to him and there is something that appeals to me and I accept it. I have been influenced by him. And I am also influenced by a man who says, “Do this and you will have enlightenment.” So I am being influenced all around. What shall I do? I want to educate myself because I see very well nobody is going to educate me in that field. Because they have never educated themselves, they have never gone into themselves and examined, explored, searched out, looked and watched; they have always conformed to a pattern. And they are trying to teach me how to live within that pattern, whether it is the Zen pattern, or the Christian, or the communist pattern. They have not educated themselves in the sense we are talking about, though they may be clever in argument and in dialectics.

K：如果你不懂得如何聆听那位主教的话，你就会说：“多么有道理啊，他说我们两千年来一直这样生活，这是正确的方式，因为我们认识上帝。”我听他讲，有些东西很吸引我，我就接受了。我受到了他的影响。我也受到另一个人的影响，他说：“这样做你就能开悟。”所以我受到各方的影响。我该怎么办？我想自学，因为我很清楚，没有人会教我这方面的知识。因为他们从未自学过，从未深入内心审视、探索、探寻、观察；他们总是墨守成规。他们试图教我如何在这种模式下生活，无论是禅宗的模式、基督教的模式还是共产主义的模式。他们并没有像我们所说的那样自学，尽管他们可能很擅长辩论和辩证法。

So as nobody is going to help me to educate myself inwardly, how shall I begin? I see that if I don’t do that I will become a lopsided human being. I may be very good at writing an essay and getting a degree, but then what? And the whole of the rest of my life is neglected. So how shall I educate myself, become mature in a field where very few people have taken the trouble to investigate, to inquire? Or they have done it and imposed their thinking on others, not helped them to find out for themselves.

既然没人会帮我进行自我提升，那我该如何开始呢？我意识到，如果我不这样做，我就会变成一个不完整的人。我或许很擅长写论文，也能拿到学位，但那又怎样呢？我人生的其他方面都被忽略了。那么，我该如何提升自己，在这个鲜有人费心研究、探究的领域里变得成熟呢？即便有人研究过，也只是把自己的想法强加于人，而不是引导别人自己去发现。

Do you understand what I am talking about? Freud, Jung, Adler, and other analysts, who have gone into this and stated some facts, traced all behavior to childhood conditioning. They have laid down a certain pattern and you can investigate in that direction and get more information, but that is not you learning about yourself; you are learning according to somebody else. Knowing what life is, what is happening in the world—wars, antagonism, politicians, priests, hippies with their little bit of philosophy, people who take drugs, the makers of communes, and the hatred between various classes—how will you set about finding out for yourself? Take all that is there outwardly, and inwardly people are ambitious, greedy, envious, brutal, violent, exploiting each other. These are facts, I am not exaggerating.

你明白我在说什么吗？弗洛伊德、荣格、阿德勒和其他一些分析家，他们都研究过这个问题，并提出了一些事实，他们将所有行为都追溯到童年时期的条件反射。他们建立了一种特定的模式，你可以朝着这个方向研究，获得更多信息，但这并非你了解自己；你是在根据别人的说法去了解自己。你了解生活是什么，世界上正在发生什么——战争、对抗、政客、牧师、嬉皮士及其略带哲学色彩的理论、吸毒者、公社的建立者，以及不同阶级之间的仇恨——你打算如何着手自己去发现真相？看看外面的世界，你会发现，人们内心野心勃勃、贪婪、嫉妒、残暴、暴力，互相剥削。这些都是事实，我绝非夸大其词。

Seeing all this, what shall I do? Shall I conform to some pattern, which is comforting, which is what I want to do, a fulfillment for myself? Because if you don’t have a certain spark, a flame in you now at the age of fifteen, sixteen, twenty, or twenty-five, it is going to be very difficult when you are fifty. Then it is much more difficult to change. So, what shall I do? How shall I face all this, look at it, listen to all the terrible noise in the world—the priests, the technicians, the clever men, the workers, the strikes that are going on? Shall I choose a particular noise that appeals to me and follow that noise for the rest of my life? What shall I do? This is a tremendous problem, it is not a simple problem.

看到这一切，我该怎么办？我是否应该墨守成规，遵循某种让我感到舒适、符合我心意、能让我感到满足的模式？因为如果你在十五、十六、二十或二十五岁时，心中没有某种火花，没有某种激情，那么到了五十岁，一切都会变得异常艰难。那时，改变就更加困难了。所以，我该怎么办？我该如何面对这一切，如何看待它，如何倾听这世间所有嘈杂的声音——牧师的声音、技术人员的声音、聪明人的声音、工人的声音，以及正在进行的罢工？我是否应该选择某种吸引我的声音，然后终其一生追随它？我该怎么办？这是一个极其棘手的问题，绝非易事。

S : I want to experiment.

S：我想做个实验。

K : Experiment?

K：实验？

S : Well, let things come to me.

S：嗯，顺其自然吧。

K : Listen to what I am saying. Seeing all this, I don’t know what to do. Not knowing what to do, I am going to find an easy way out as I generally do. Don’t fool yourself. This is a tremendously complex problem.

K：听我说。看到这一切，我不知道该怎么办。正因为不知道该怎么办，我才会像往常一样找个简单的办法逃避。别自欺欺人了。这可是个极其复杂的问题。

S : But to find the easy way out is still not real.

S：但是，找到捷径仍然不是真正的出路。

K : Wait, I am not at all sure. I face all this tremendous uproar that is going on, the shouting, the pushing, and I find there is an easy way out—I become a monk. That is what is happening in certain parts of the world, because people don’t trust politicians, scientists, technicians, preachers, anymore. They say, “I am going to withdraw from all this and become a solitary monk with a begging bowl”; they are doing it in India. Or not knowing what to do, you drift, carrying on from day to day, not bothering. Or if you must find a way out you force yourself, or you join a group that thinks it is tremendously advanced. Is that what you are all going to do?

K：等等，我一点也不确定。我面对着这一切巨大的喧嚣，叫喊声、推搡声，却发现有一条简单的出路——我出家为僧。世界上某些地方正在发生这样的事，因为人们不再信任政客、科学家、技术人员、传教士。他们说：“我要退出这一切，做一个拿着钵盂的隐士”；印度人就是这么做的。或者，不知道该怎么办，就随波逐流，日复一日，漠不关心。或者，如果你必须找到出路，就强迫自己，或者加入一个自认为非常先进的团体。你们都是这么打算的吗？

If I had a daughter or a son here, that would be my concern as a parent. I would feel tremendously concerned. And Brockwood is concerned; it is tremendously important. You can all go to colleges and universities and get degrees and jobs, but that is too simple. That is, a way out doesn’t solve anything either. So if I had a son or a daughter, I would ask how they are going to be educated in the field where they themselves don’t take an interest, and where others don’t know how to help them to understand that enormous field that has been neglected.

如果我在这里有个女儿或儿子，这会是我作为父母最关心的问题。我会非常担忧。布罗克伍德也很担忧；这至关重要。你们都可以上大学，拿到学位，找到工作，但这太简单了。也就是说，仅仅找到一条出路并不能解决任何问题。所以，如果我有个儿子或女儿，我会问他们，在他们自己不感兴趣的领域，在其他人也不知道如何帮助他们理解这个被忽视的庞大领域的情况下，他们将如何接受教育。

So I would say to a daughter or son, “Look, listen to all this, listen to all the noise that is going on in the world. Don’t take sides, don’t jump to any conclusions, but just listen. Don’t say one noise is better than another noise; they are all noises, so just listen first. And listen also to your own noise, your chattering, your wishes—‘I want to be this and I don’t want to be that’—and find out what it means to listen. Find out, don’t be told. Discuss it with me and find out what it means first. Find out what it means to think, why you think, what is the background of your thinking. Watch yourself, but don’t become self-centered in that watching. Be tremendously concerned, in watching, about further enlargement of yourself.” If you watch yourself, there is a tremendous danger of self-centeredness.

所以我会对我的女儿或儿子说：“听着，听听这一切，听听这世间所有的喧嚣。不要站队，不要妄下结论，只需倾听。不要说哪种喧嚣比哪种喧嚣更好；它们都是喧嚣，所以首先要倾听。也要倾听你自己的喧嚣，你的喋喋不休，你的愿望——‘我想成为这样，我不想成为那样’——并弄清楚倾听的意义。自己去发现，不要被动接受。先和我讨论，弄清楚它的意义。弄清楚思考的意义，你为什么思考，你的思考背景是什么。观察自己，但不要在观察中变得以自我为中心。在观察的过程中，要格外关注自身的进一步发展。”如果你只关注自己，就存在着极大的自我中心的危险。

If I were a parent I would be tremendously concerned with the problem, the question, of how to educate people in this field where there is no real understanding or help. I would discuss to find out how you think, why you think, and what you think. Not in order to change it, not to suppress it, not to overcome it, but to find out why you think at all. Question it! I don’t know if you have noticed that most books, all the social, religious, moral, ethical structure, the relationship between man and man, are based on thinking. “This is right, this is wrong, this should be, this must not be”—it is based on the structure of thought. I want to find out if that is the way of living, to base everything on thought, on what I like and what I don’t like, what I want to do, what I don’t want to do.

如果我是一位家长，我会非常关注这个问题：在这个领域，人们缺乏真正的理解和帮助，我们该如何教育他们？我会与他们讨论，了解他们的思考方式、思考原因以及思考内容。我的目的不是为了改变他们，不是为了压制他们，也不是为了克服他们，而是为了探究他们思考的根本原因。质疑它！我不知道你是否注意到，大多数书籍，以及所有的社会、宗教、道德、伦理结构，还有人与人之间的关系，都建立在思考之上。“这是对的，这是错的，这应该是，这不应该是”——这一切都基于思维的结构。我想探究，如果一切都建立在思考之上，建立在我喜欢什么、不喜欢什么、我想做什么、我不想做什么之上，这是否就是我们生活的准则。

Brockwood Park, June 24, 1971

布罗克伍德公园，1971年6月24日

#↩

WHAT IS THE RELATION BETWEEN

它们之间是什么关系？

KRISHNAMURTI’S TEACHING AND TRUTH?

克里希那穆提的教义和真理？

1

Questioner 1 : Can we discuss the relation between Krishnamurti’s teaching and truth?

提问者 1：我们能否讨论一下克里希那穆提的教义与真理之间的关系？

Questioner 2 : Is there such a thing as a teaching at all, or is there only truth?

提问者 2：是否存在教义这种东西，还是只有真理？

Krishnamurti : Is it the expression of truth? There are two things involved. The speaker is either talking out of the silence of truth, or he is talking out of the noise of an illusion, which he considers to be the truth.

克里希那穆提：这是真理的表达吗？这里面包含两层含义。说话者要么是在真理的寂静中发声，要么是在他误以为是真理的幻象的喧嚣中发声。

Q : That is what most people do.

问：大多数人都是这么做的。

K : So which is it that he is doing?

K：所以他到底在做什么？

Q : There could be a confusion between the word and truth.

问：人们可能会将这个词与真相混淆。

K : No, the word is not the truth. That’s why we said either he is talking out of the silence of truth or out of the noise of illusion.

K：不，言语并不等同于真理。所以我们说，他要么是在真理的沉默中说话，要么是在幻象的喧嚣中说话。

Q : But because one feels that he is speaking out of the silence of truth, there is a greater possibility for the word to be taken as truth.

问：但是，因为一个人觉得自己是在用言语表达真理，所以他的话更有可能被当作真理。

K : No, let’s go slowly, for this is interesting. Who is going to judge, who is going to see the truth of the matter? The listener, the reader? You who are familiar with Indian scriptures, Buddhism, the Upanishads, and know most of the contents of all that, are you capable of judging? How shall we find out? You hear him talking about these things and you wonder if he is really speaking out of this extraordinary silence of truth, or as a reaction and from a conditioned childhood, and so on. That is to say, either he is talking out of his conditioning or out of the other. How will you find out? How will you approach this problem?

K：不，我们慢慢来，因为这很有意思。谁来评判？谁来看清真相？是听众，还是读者？你们熟悉印度经典、佛教、奥义书，并且了解其中大部分内容，你们有能力做出判断吗？我们该如何辨别？你们听他谈论这些，不禁会想，他究竟是出于对真理非凡的领悟，还是出于某种反应，出于童年时期形成的观念等等？也就是说，他要么是受制于某种观念，要么是出于另一种观念。你们该如何辨别？你们该如何看待这个问题？

Q : Is it possible for me to find out if what is meeting that teaching is the noise within myself?

问：我有可能找出这种教学方式的依据是否是我内心的噪音吗？

K : That’s why I am asking you. What is the criterion, the measure that you apply so you can say, “Yes, that is it”? Or do you say, “I don’t know”? I am asking what you do. Or do you not know but are examining, investigating, not whether he is speaking out of silence or conditioning, but watching the truth of what he is saying? I would want to know whether he was speaking out of this or out of that. But as I don’t know, I am going to listen to what he is saying and see if it is true.

K：所以我才问你。你判断的标准是什么？你用什么标准来判断“是的，就是这样”？还是你会说“我不知道”？我想问的是你的具体做法。或者你不知道，但你正在观察、调查，不是在探究他说话是出于沉默还是某种习惯，而是在观察他所说的话是否属实？我想知道他说话是出于什么原因。但既然我不知道，我就会认真听他说什么，看看他说的是否属实。

Q : But what sees it as true?

问：但谁认为这是真的呢？

K : Say one is fairly alive to things. One listens to this man and one wants to find out whether what he says is mere words or the truth.

K：假设一个人对事物比较敏感。他听这个人说话，想要弄清楚他说的究竟是空话还是真话。

Q : When I have come to the conclusion that it is the truth, then I am already not listening.

问：当我认定某事是真理时，我就不会再听了。

K : No, I don’t know. My whole life is concerned with this problem; it is not just for a few years or a few days. I want to know the truth of this matter. Is he speaking out of experience or from knowledge, or not out of any of these things? Most people speak out of knowledge, so we are asking that question.

K：不，我不知道。我一生都在关注这个问题；它不是几年或几天的事。我想知道这件事的真相。他是出于经验还是知识，或者两者都不是？大多数人都是基于知识说话，所以我们才问这个问题。

I don’t know how you would find out. I’ll tell you what I would do. I would put his personality, his influence, all that, completely aside. Because I don’t want to be influenced; I am skeptical, doubtful, so I am very careful. I listen to him, and I don’t say, “I know” or “I don’t know,” but I am skeptical. I want to find out.

我不知道你该如何查明真相。但我可以告诉你我会怎么做。我会完全抛开他的个性、他的影响力等等一切因素。因为我不想受人影响；我生性多疑，所以我非常谨慎。我会听他说话，但我不会说“我知道”或“我不知道”，但我会保持怀疑。我想弄清楚真相。

Q : Skeptical means you are inclined to doubt it, which is already a bias—

问：怀疑意味着你倾向于质疑它，这本身就是一种偏见——

K : Oh, no! I am skeptical in the sense that I don’t accept everything that is being said.

K：哦，不！我持怀疑态度，因为我不会接受所有说法。

Q : But you lean toward doubting. It’s negation.

问：但你倾向于怀疑。这是一种否定。

K : Oh, no. I would rather use the word doubt , in the sense of questioning. Let’s put it that way. I say to myself, “Am I questioning out of my prejudice?” This question has never been put to me before, I am exploring it. I would put everything else aside, all the personal reputation, charm, looks. I am not going to accept or reject, I am going to listen to find out. Am I prejudiced? Am I listening to him with all the knowledge I have gathered about religion, of what the books have said, what other people have said, or what my own experience tells me?

K：哦，不。我更愿意用“怀疑”这个词，它的意思是质疑。这么说吧。我会问自己：“我的质疑是出于偏见吗？”这个问题以前从未有人问过我，我正在探索它。我会把其他一切都放在一边，包括个人名声、魅力和外貌。我不会接受或拒绝，我会倾听以求知。我是否带有偏见？我是否运用了我所掌握的关于宗教的知识，包括书籍上的论述、他人的言论以及我自己的经验来聆听他的话？

Q : No. I may be listening to him precisely because I have rejected all that.

问：不。我之所以会听他的，恰恰是因为我拒绝了所有这些观点。

K : Have I rejected it? Or am I listening to him with all that? If I have rejected that, then I am listening very carefully to what he has to say.

K：我拒绝了吗？还是我带着这些想法在听他说话？如果我拒绝了，那么我现在正在非常认真地听他说话。

Q : Or I am listening with everything that I already know of him?

问：或者我是带着我对他的既有认知去听的？

K : I have said that I have put away his reputation. Am I listening to him with the knowledge that I have acquired through books, through experience and, therefore, I am comparing, judging, evaluating? Then I can’t find out whether what he is saying is the truth. But is it possible for me to put aside all that? I am passionately interested to find out.
