So for the time being, while I am listening at least, I will put aside everything I have known. Then I proceed. I want to know, but I am not going to be easily persuaded, pulled into something by argument, cleverness, logic. Now am I capable of listening to what he is saying with complete abandonment of the past? It comes to that. Are you? Then my relationship to him is entirely different. Then I am listening out of silence.

K：我说过我已经把他的名声抛诸脑后了。我是否带着从书本和经验中获得的知识去听他说话，从而不自觉地进行比较、评判和评估？如果是这样，我就无法判断他说的是否属实。但我能做到完全放下这一切吗？我非常渴望弄清真相。所以，至少在聆听的这段时间里，我会暂时放下我所知道的一切。然后我再继续。我想知道答案，但我不会轻易被说服，也不会被辩论、聪明才智或逻辑所左右。现在，我能否完全抛开过去，认真聆听他所说的话？关键就在这里。你能做到吗？如果能做到，我与他的关系就完全不同了。那时，我是在静默中聆听。

This is really a very interesting question. I have answered for myself. There are a dozen of us here, how would you answer it? How do you know that what he is talking about is the truth?

这真是一个很有意思的问题。我自己已经有了答案。我们这里有十几个人，你们会怎么回答呢？你们怎么知道他说的就是真的呢？

Q : I wouldn’t be concerned with that word truth . When you use the word truth , you indicate you have the ability to judge what is true, or you already have a definition of truth, or you know what truth is, which means you will not be listening to what somebody is saying.

问：我并不担心“真理”这个词。当你使用“真理”这个词时，就表明你有能力判断什么是真理，或者你已经对真理有了定义，或者你知道什么是真理，这意味着你不会倾听别人所说的话。

K : Don’t you want to know whether he is speaking falsehood, out of a conditioned mind, from a rejection and, therefore, out of a reaction?

K：难道你不想知道他是否因为受到拒绝而产生抵触情绪，从而说出谎言吗？

Q1 : I realize that in order to listen to anybody, I can’t listen with a conditioned mind.

Q1：我意识到，为了倾听任何人，我不能带着先入为主的观念去倾听。

Q2 : Another question which arises is: I reject all this knowledge and listen in silence. Is truth in that silence?

问题二：另一个问题是：我拒绝接受所有这些知识，默默聆听。真理就在那沉默之中吗？

K : I don’t know. That is one of the things I have got to find out. How would you answer this question?

K：我不知道。这是我需要弄清楚的事情之一。你会如何回答这个问题？

Q : I think first of all you can be sensitive to what is false. In other words, to see if there is something false, something incoherent.

问：我认为首先你应该对错误的东西很敏感。换句话说，要能看出是否存在错误或不连贯的地方。

K : Logic can be very false.

K：逻辑可能完全错误。

Q : Yes, I don’t mean just logic, but you can be sensitive to the whole communication to see if there is some deception. I think one of the questions implied here is: Are you deceiving yourself?

问：是的，我指的不仅仅是逻辑，而是要对整个沟通过程保持敏感，看看是否存在欺骗。我认为这里隐含的问题之一是：你是否在自欺欺人？

K : Again, forgive me for asking, but how do you know he is speaking the truth? Or is he deceiving himself and is caught in an illusion which gives him a feeling that he is telling the truth? What do you answer?

K：请原谅我再次询问，但你怎么知道他说的是真话？或者他是在自欺欺人，陷入了一种错觉，让他觉得自己说的是真话？你会怎么回答？

Q : One goes into it oneself. One cannot accept it without going deeply into it.

问：这需要自己去深入了解。不深入了解就无法接受。

K : But one can deceive oneself so appallingly.

K：但是人可以如此可怕地欺骗自己。

Q : You go through the layers of all those deceptions and beyond them.

问：你一层层地揭开所有这些谎言，并超越它们。

K : If I were a stranger I might say: You have listened to this man for a long time, how do you know he is telling the truth? How do you know anything about it?

K：如果我是个陌生人，我可能会说：你听这个人说了这么久，你怎么知道他说的都是真话？你怎么知道这些事？

Q : I could say that I have looked at what you have said, and each time I was able to test it to see if it was right. I have not found anything that was contradictory.

问：我可以说，我仔细阅读了您所说的内容，并且每次都进行了验证，以确认其正确性。我没有发现任何矛盾之处。

K : No. The question was: How do you find out the truth? Not about contradiction, logic, all that. One’s own sensitivity, one’s own investigation, one’s own delving, is that enough?

K：不。问题是：如何才能找到真相？不是关于矛盾、逻辑之类的。而是靠个人的感知力、个人的调查、个人的探究，这就足够了吗？

Q : If one goes all the way, if one goes through all the possible self-deceptions and then goes so far as to say that in the moments when one is listening one feels there is a change in oneself, it may not be a total revolution, but there is a change.

问：如果一个人走到底，如果一个人经历了所有可能的自我欺骗，然后甚至说，当他聆听时，他感觉自己发生了变化，这可能不是彻底的革命，但确实发生了变化。

K : That can happen when you go for a walk and look at the mountains and are quiet, and when you come back to your home certain things have taken place. You follow what I am saying?

K：当你散步、欣赏山景、享受宁静时，这种情况可能会发生。当你回到家时，一些事情就发生了。你明白我的意思吗？

Q : Yes. We listen to people who speak from knowledge, and we listen to you, and there is something totally different.

问：是的。我们会听取有见识的人的意见，也会听取你的意见，这完全不同。

K : Have you answered the question?

K：你回答这个问题了吗？

Q : Someone wrote to me and asked if I agreed with everything Krishnamurti said. “Didn’t he tell you that you should doubt everything he said?” The only way I could answer was to say: “Look, to me it is self-evident.”

问：有人写信问我是否同意克里希那穆提的所有观点。“他不是告诉过你，你应该怀疑他说的每一句话吗？” 我只能回答说：“你看，对我来说，这是不言而喻的。”

K : It may be self-evident to you and yet an illusion. It is such a dangerous, delicate thing.

K：这或许对你来说不言而喻，但实际上却是一种错觉。它是如此危险而又微妙的事情。

Q : I think that for thought it is not at all possible to be sure about this matter. It is typical of thought that it wants to be sure that it is not deceiving itself, that it is listening to truth. Thought will never give up that question, and it is right for thought never to give up questioning, but thought cannot touch it, cannot know about it.

问：我认为，对于思想而言，在这个问题上是完全不可能确定的。思想的典型特征是，它想要确定自己没有自欺欺人，想要确定自己听到的是真理。思想永远不会放弃这个问题，思想也永远不会放弃质疑，这是正确的，但思想无法触及它，也无法了解它。

K : Dr. Bohm and I had a discussion of this kind in a different way. If I remember rightly, we said: Is there such a silence which is not the word, which is not imagined or induced? Is there such a silence, and is it possible to speak out of that silence?

K：我和博姆博士也以另一种方式讨论过类似的问题。如果我没记错的话，我们当时说：是否存在这样一种沉默，它不是言语，不是想象出来的，也不是人为诱导出来的？是否存在这样的沉默，我们是否有可能从这种沉默中发出声音？

Q : The question was whether the words are coming from perception, from the silence, or from the memory.

问：问题是这些词语是来自感知、来自沉默，还是来自记忆。

K : Yes.

K：是的。

Q : The question is whether the words that are used are communicating directly and are coming out of the emptiness, out of the silence, or not.

问：问题在于所使用的词语是否直接传达信息，是否来自空虚，来自沉默。

K : That is the real question.

K：这才是真正的问题。

Q : As we used to say, like the drum which vibrates to the emptiness within.

问：正如我们过去常说的，就像鼓声在内心的空虚中振动。

K : Yes. Are you satisfied by this answer, by what the others have said?

K：是的。你对这个答案，或者其他人的回答满意吗？

Q : No.

问：不。

K : Then how do you find out?

K：那你怎么查明呢？

Q : The very words you are using deny the possibility of being satisfied and of working at it intellectually. It is something that has nothing to do with those things.

问：你用的这些话本身就否定了获得满足感和进行理性思考的可能性。这与这些都无关。

K : Look, suppose I love you and trust you. Because I trust you and you trust me, whatever you say won’t be a lie and I know you won’t deceive me under any circumstances. You won’t tell me something which is not actual to you.

K：听着，假设我爱你，信任你。因为我信任你，你也信任我，所以你说的任何话都不会是谎话，我知道你在任何情况下都不会欺骗我。你不会告诉我任何对你来说不真实的事情。

Q : I might do something out of ignorance.

问：我可能会因为无知而做出某些事。

K : But say you trust me and I trust you. There is a relationship of trust, confidence, affection, love; like a man and a woman when they are married, they trust each other. Now is that possible here? Because, as she points out, I can deceive myself with logic, with reason, with all these things. Millions of people have done it. I can also see the danger of loving the priest: he can play havoc with me.

K：但假设你信任我，我也信任你。这其中存在着信任、信心、爱慕和爱情；就像夫妻之间那样，彼此信任。现在，这种情况可能存在吗？因为正如她所指出的，我可以用逻辑、理性以及所有这些东西欺骗自己。千百万人都这样做过。我也看到了爱上神父的危险：他可能会让我陷入混乱。

Q1 : If one has affection for someone, one projects all kinds of illusions onto him.

Q1：如果一个人喜欢某人，就会把各种各样的幻想投射到他身上。

Q2 : I think the trust, the investigation, logic, and all that, go together with love.

Q2：我认为信任、调查、逻辑等等，都与爱密不可分。

K : That is a very dangerous thing too.

K：那也是非常危险的事情。

Q : Isn’t there any way to avoid danger?

问：难道就没有办法避免危险吗？

K : I don’t want to be caught in an illusion.

K：我不想陷入幻觉中。

Q : So can we say that truth is in the silence out of which the teaching comes?

问：那么我们是否可以说，真理就存在于教义产生的沉默之中？

K : But I want to know how the silence comes! I might invent it. I might have worked to have a silent mind for years, conditioned it, kept it in a cage, and then say, “Marvelous, I am silent.” There is that danger. Logic is a danger. Thought is a danger. So I see all the dangers around me. I am caught in all these dangers and I want to find out if what that man is saying is the truth.

K：但我很想知道沉默是如何产生的！我可能凭空捏造了它。我可能多年来一直努力让自己的头脑保持沉默，把它训练得像个牢笼，然后说：“太好了，我沉默了。” 这就是危险所在。逻辑是危险的。思考是危险的。所以我看到了我周围的所有危险。我被所有这些危险所困，我想弄清楚那个人说的到底是不是真的。

Q : Are we saying that perception has to be pure and in the realm of silence—the real realm of silence, not a fantasy—in order to be able to even come close to this question?

问：我们是不是在说，只有当感知纯粹且处于寂静的境界——真正的寂静境界，而不是幻想的境界——才能接近这个问题？

K : Dr. Bohm is a scientist, a physicist; he is clear-thinking, logical. Suppose someone goes to him and asks, “Is what Krishnamurti says the truth?” How is he going to answer?

K：博姆博士是一位科学家，一位物理学家；他思维清晰，逻辑严密。假设有人去问他：“克里希那穆提说的是真话吗？”他会如何回答？

Q : Doesn’t Dr. Bohm, or anybody, have to go beyond the limitations of logic?

问：博姆博士或者任何人，难道不需要超越逻辑的局限性吗？

K : Somebody comes to him and asks, “Tell me, I really want to know from you, please tell me if that man is speaking the truth.”

K：有人来问他：“告诉我，我真的很想知道，请告诉我那个人说的是不是真话。”

Q : But you are then saying use the instrument of logic to find out?

问：但你的意思是说要用逻辑工具来找出答案吗？

K : No. I am very interested because I have heard so many people who are illogical and careless say he is speaking the truth. But I go to a serious thinker, careful with the use of words, and ask, “Please tell me if he is telling the truth, not some crooked thing covered up.” How is he going to answer me?

K：不。我对此很感兴趣，因为我听过太多不讲逻辑、草率行事的人说他说的是真话。但我去找一位思维严谨、用词谨慎的人，问他：“请告诉我，他说的到底是不是真话，而不是什么掩盖的谎言。”他会怎么回答我呢？

Q : The other day when that man said you may be caught in a rut, and you looked at it, what happened then?

问：那天那个人说你可能会陷入困境，你仔细想了想，然后发生了什么？

K : I looked at it in several different ways and I don’t think I am caught in a groove, but yet I might be. So after examining it very carefully, I left it. Something takes place when you leave it alone after an examination; something new comes into it.

K：我从好几个不同的角度审视过它，我觉得自己并没有陷入某种固定的模式，但也许确实如此。所以，在仔细审视之后，我决定先放一放。审视之后，如果放一放，就会发生一些变化；一些新的东西会随之而来。

Now I am asking you: Please tell me if that man is speaking the truth.

现在我问你们：请告诉我，那个人说的是不是真话。

Q : For me it is a reality. I can’t communicate it to you. This is what I have found out and you have to find it out for yourself. You have to test it in your own mind.

问：对我来说，这是事实。我无法向你解释。这是我自己的发现，你必须自己去发现。你必须自己去验证。

K : But you may be leading me up the garden path.

K：但你可能是在误导我。

Q : That is all I can say. I can’t really communicate it.

问：我只能说这么多了。我真的无法表达清楚。

K : You may be up the garden path yourself.

K：你可能自己也误入歧途了。

Q : It seems to me I would want to know what he is bringing to bear on the answer to this question. Is it science? Is it logic? Is it his own intelligence? I would want to know out of what he was going to answer me.

问：我觉得我应该知道他回答这个问题时运用了什么方法。是科学？是逻辑？还是他自己的智慧？我想知道他打算用什么来回答我的问题。

K : How do you in your heart of hearts, as a human being, know that he is speaking the truth? I want to feel it. I object to logic and all that. I have been through that before. Therefore if all that is not the way, then what is?

K：作为一个人，你如何从内心深处确信他说的是真话？我想用心去感受。我反对逻辑之类的东西。我以前就经历过。所以，如果这些都不是方法，那什么才是呢？

Q : There are people who are very clever, who speak of things which are very similar, who have grasped this intellectually very well and say they are speaking from truth.

问：有些人非常聪明，他们谈论的事情非常相似，他们从理智上很好地理解了这一点，并声称他们所说的是真理。

K : Yes, they are repeating in India now: “You are the world.” That is the latest catchword!

K：是的，现在印度人都在说：“你就是世界。”这是最新的流行语！

Q : In order to communicate that, I have to speak out of the silence you were referring to.

问：为了表达这个意思，我必须打破你所说的沉默。

K : No, please be simple with me. I want to know if Krishnamurti is speaking the truth. Dr. Bohm has known Krishnamurti for several years. He has a good, trained mind so I go to him and ask him.

K：不，请您直截了当地告诉我。我想知道克里希那穆提说的是不是真话。博姆博士认识克里希那穆提好几年了。他思维敏捷，受过良好的训练，所以我去找他问问。

Q : All he can say is, “I know this man, this is how he affects me. He has changed my life.” And suddenly a note may be struck in the other one.

问：他只能说：“我认识这个人，他就是这样影响我的。他改变了我的人生。”然后，对方可能突然也说了些什么。

K : No. I want it straight from the horse’s mouth!

K：不，我要直接从当事人那里得到答案！

Q : But you said you wanted proof.

问：但你说过你想要证据。

K : I don’t. It is a very serious question, it isn’t just a dramatic or intellectual question. This is a tremendous question.

K：我不这么认为。这是一个非常严肃的问题，它不仅仅是一个戏剧性或学术性的问题。这是一个意义重大的问题。

Q : Can one ever get an answer? Or is that person asking a false question to begin with?

问：这个问题最终能得到答案吗？或者说，提问者一开始就问错了问题？

K : Is he?

K：是吗？

Q : I think I could say to him that when we did discuss these things it was from the emptiness, and that I felt it was a direct perception.

问：我想我可以告诉他，当我们讨论这些事情的时候，那是源于内心的空虚，而且我觉得那是一种直接的感知。

K : Yes. Is direct perception unrelated to logic?

K：是的。直接感知与逻辑无关吗？

Q : It doesn’t come from logic.

问：这并非源于逻辑。

K : But you are logical all the same.

K：但你依然很有逻辑。

Q : That may come later, not at that moment.

问：那可能以后会发生，但不是现在。

K : So you are telling me: I have found out that man is telling the truth because I had a direct perception, an insight into what he is saying.

K：所以你的意思是：我发现那个人说的是真话，因为我直接感知到、洞察到他所说的话。

Q : Yes.

问：是的。

K : Now, be careful, because I have heard a disciple of some guru saying exactly the same thing.

K：不过，你要小心，因为我曾听某个大师的弟子说过完全一样的话。

Q : I have also heard a guru say this but a little later by looking at it logically I saw the thing was nonsense. When I was looking at the fact and the logic I saw that it did not fit. So I would say that in addition to direct perception I have constantly examined this logically.

问：我也听一位大师说过类似的话，但后来我仔细思考了一下，发现这完全是无稽之谈。当我审视事实和逻辑时，发现两者根本对不上。所以，除了直接感受之外，我也一直在用逻辑来检验这件事。

K : So you are saying that perception has not blinded you and with that perception goes logic also.

K：所以你的意思是，感知并没有蒙蔽你的双眼，而感知也与逻辑相辅相成。

Q : Yes, logic and fact.

问：是的，逻辑和事实。

K : So perception first, then logic. Not first logic, then perception.

K：所以是先感知后逻辑，而不是先逻辑后感知。

Q : Yes. That is what it always has to be.

问：是的，必须如此。

K : So through perception and then with logic, you see that it is the truth. Hasn’t this been done by the devout Christians?

K：所以通过感知，再运用逻辑，你会发现这就是真理。虔诚的基督徒不也是这样做的吗？

Q : Logic is not enough, because we have to see how people actually behave as well. I see that Christians say certain things, but when we look at the whole of what they do it doesn’t fit.

问：光靠逻辑是不够的，我们还要观察人们的实际行为。我看到基督徒说一些话，但当我们审视他们的全部行为时，就会发现这些话并不一致。

K : Isn’t there a terrible danger in this?

K：这难道没有可怕的危险吗？

Q : I am sure there is a danger.

问：我确信存在危险。

K : So you are now saying that one has to walk in danger.

K：所以你现在的意思是，人必须冒着危险前行。

Q : Yes.

问：是的。

K : Now I begin to understand what you are saying. One has to move in a field which is full of danger, full of snakes and pitfalls.

K：我现在开始明白你的意思了。人必须在一个充满危险、遍布毒蛇和陷阱的领域里前进。

Q : Which means one has to be tremendously awake.

问：这意味着一个人必须保持高度清醒。

K : So I have learned from talking to him that this is a very dangerous thing. He has said you can only understand whether Krishnamurti is speaking the truth if you are really prepared to walk in a field which is full of pitfalls. Is that right?

K：所以，我跟他谈过之后了解到，这是一件非常危险的事情。他说，只有当你真正准备好踏入一个充满陷阱的领域时，你才能理解克里希那穆提说的是否是真理。是这样吗？

Q : Yes.

问：是的。

K : It is a field which is full of mines, the razor’s edge path. Are you prepared to do that? One’s whole being says, “Be secure.”

K：这是一片布满地雷的领域，一条如刀锋般锋利的道路。你准备好了吗？人的本能会告诉你：“一定要安全。”

Q : That is the only way to do anything.

问：这是做任何事的唯一方法。

K : I have learned to be aware of the dangers around me and also to face danger all the time and, therefore, to have no security. The inquirer might say, “This is too much,” and go away! So this is what I want to get at. Can the mind, which has been conditioned for centuries to be secure, abandon that and say, “I will walk into danger”? That is what we are saying. It is logical, but in a sense it is illogical.

K：我已经学会了时刻警惕周围的危险，也学会了直面危险，因此，我根本没有安全感。提问者可能会说：“这太过分了”，然后走开！这就是我想表达的。一个被几个世纪以来训练成追求安全的思维，能否放弃这种思维，说：“我要走进危险”？这就是我们想表达的意思。这听起来合乎逻辑，但从某种意义上说，又不合逻辑。

Q : In principle that is the way all science works.

问：原则上，所有科学都是这样运作的。

K : Yes, that is right. So it also means I don’t trust anybody, any guru, any prophet. I trust my wife because she loves me and I love her, but that is irrelevant.

K：是的，没错。所以这也意味着我不信任任何人，任何大师，任何先知。我信任我的妻子，因为她爱我，我也爱她，但这无关紧要。

Q : The word danger has to be explained too. From one point it is dangerous, and from another it isn’t. I have to investigate. My conditioning is very dangerous.

问：危险这个词也需要解释。从某种角度来看，它是危险的；从另一种角度来看，它又不危险。我需要调查一下。我的训练方式非常危险。

K : So we’re saying: “I have walked in danger and I have found the logic of this danger. Through the perception of the danger I have found the truth of what Krishnamurti is saying. And there is no security, no safety in this, whereas all the others give me safety.”

K：所以我们想说的是：“我曾身处险境，也找到了这种危险的逻辑。通过对危险的感知，我发现了克里希那穆提所说的真理。而这其中没有任何安全感，其他一切都无法给我带来安全感。”

Q : Security becomes the ultimate danger.

问：安全反而成了最大的危险。

K : Of course.

K：当然。

Q : What you have described is actually the scientific approach. They say every statement must be in danger of being false; it has been put that way.

问：你刚才描述的其实就是科学方法。他们说，任何陈述都可能存在错误的风险；他们就是这么说的。

K : That is perfectly right. I have learned a lot. Have you? A man comes from Seattle or Sheffield or Birmingham and is told, “I have found that what he says is the truth because I have had a perception and that perception stands logically.” It is not outside of reason. And in that perception I see that where I walk is full of pitfalls, of danger. Therefore, I have to be tremendously aware. Danger exists when there is no security. And the gurus, the priests, all offer security. Seeing the illogic of it I accept this illogic too.

K：你说得完全正确。我学到了很多。你呢？一个人从西雅图、谢菲尔德或伯明翰来到这里，有人告诉他：“我发现他说的都是真理，因为我有一种感觉，而且这种感觉合乎逻辑。”这并非不合情理。在这种感觉中，我看到我所走的道路充满了陷阱和危险。因此，我必须时刻保持警惕。没有安全感，危险就存在。而那些大师、牧师们都在提供安全感。既然他们提供的不是逻辑，我也接受这种非逻辑。

Q : I am not sure that you should call it illogical. It is not illogical but it is the way logic has to work.

问：我不确定是否应该称之为不合逻辑。它并非不合逻辑，而是逻辑运作的方式。

K : Of course. Are we saying that direct perception, insight, and the working out of it demand great logic, a great capacity to think clearly? But the capacity to think clearly will not bring about insight.

K：当然。我们是不是在说，直接感知、洞察力以及对洞察力的运用都需要极强的逻辑思维能力和清晰的思考能力？但清晰的思考能力本身并不能带来洞察力。

Q : But if the logic does not bring about perception, what does it do exactly?

问：但是如果逻辑不能带来感知，那它究竟能起到什么作用呢？

K : It trains, it sharpens the mind. But that certainly won’t bring about an insight.

K：它能训练思维，磨砺头脑。但这肯定不会带来顿悟。

Q : It is not through the mind that the perception comes.

问：感知并非来自头脑。

K : That all depends on what you mean by the mind. Logic makes the mind sharp, clear, objective, and sane. But that won’t give you the other. Your question is: How does the other come about?

K：这完全取决于你对“心智”的定义。逻辑使心智敏锐、清晰、客观、理智。但这并不能让你拥有“他者”。你的问题是：他者是如何产生的？

Q1 : No. That was not my question. Logic clears the mind, but is the mind the instrument of perception?

问题一：不，那不是我的问题。逻辑能使头脑清晰，但头脑是感知的工具吗？

Q2 : Yes, that is what we said, that it clears the mind of confusion, of the debris.

Q2：是的，我们就是这么说的，它可以清除头脑中的混乱和杂念。

Q1 : The debris may come if you don’t have logic.

Q1：如果没有逻辑，可能会产生混乱。

K : You might remain in the debris if you don’t have logic.

K：如果你没有逻辑，你可能会一直陷在废墟中。

Q : If the perception is a real perception and so the truth, why does it then need the discipline of logic to examine it?

问：如果感知是真实的感知，也就是真理，那么为什么还需要逻辑的约束来检验它呢？

K : We said perception works out logically. It does not need logic. Whatever it does is reasonable, logical, sane, objective.

K：我们说过，感知本身是合乎逻辑的。它不需要逻辑。它所做的一切都是合理的、合乎逻辑的、理智的、客观的。

Q : It is logical without an intent to make it so.

问：即使没有刻意为之，它也是合乎逻辑的。

K : That’s it.

K：就是这样。

Q : It is like saying that if you see what is in this room correctly, you will not find anything illogical in what you see.

问：这就像说，如果你正确地看待这个房间里的东西，你就不会发现你所看到的东西有任何不合逻辑之处。

K : All right. Will the perception keep the confusion, the debris, away all the time so that the mind never accumulates it and doesn’t have to keep clearing it away? That was your question, wasn’t it?

K：好的。这种感知能否一直清除混乱和杂念，使大脑永远不会积累它们，也不必不断地清理它们？这才是你的问题，对吧？

Q : I think perception can reach the stage at which it is continually keeping the field clear. I say that it can reach that stage for a certain moment.

问：我认为感知可以达到一种境界，即持续保持视野清晰。我说的是，它可以在某个特定时刻达到这种境界。

K : At a certain moment I have perception. But during the interval between the perceptions there is a lot of debris being gathered. Our question is: Is perception continuous so that there is no collection of the debris? Put it round the other way: Does one perception keep the field clear?

K：在某个特定时刻，我会有感知。但在感知之间的间隔期间，会积累很多杂念。我们的问题是：感知是否连续，以至于不会积累杂念？换句话说：一次感知能否保持视野清晰？

Q : Can one make a difference between insight and perception?

问：洞察力和感知之间有区别吗？

K : Don’t break it up yet. Take those two words as synonymous. We are asking: Is perception from time to time, with intervals? During those intervals a lot of debris collects and, therefore, the field has to be swept again. Or does perception in itself bring about tremendous clarity in which there is no debris?

K：先别急着拆开来看。把这两个词当作同义词。我们想问的是：感知是否时断时续，存在间隔？在这些间隔期间，会积聚很多杂念，因此需要重新清理。还是说，感知本身就能带来一种极致的清晰，其中没有任何杂念？

Q : Are you saying that once it happens it will be there forever?

问：你的意思是说，一旦发生，它就会永远存在吗？

K : That is what I am trying to get at. Don’t use the words continuous , never again . Keep to the question of whether, once perception has taken place, the mind can collect further debris, confusion. It is only when that perception becomes darkened by the debris that the process of getting rid of it begins. But if there is perception why should there be a collecting, gathering?

K：这正是我要表达的意思。不要用“持续”、“永不再来”之类的词。要坚持思考这样一个问题：一旦感知发生，心灵是否还能积累更多的杂念和混乱。只有当感知被这些杂念蒙蔽时，清除的过程才会开始。但是，既然感知存在，为什么还要有积累和聚集的过程呢？

Ojai, California, 22 March, 1977

加利福尼亚州奥海，1977年3月22日

2

Krishnamurti : We were asking how one can know that what Krishnamurti is saying is true. He might be caught in his own conditioning, illusions, and not being able to free himself from them, have put together a series of observations, words, and calls them truth. How do you know whether what he is saying is actual, truthful, and lasting?

克里希那穆提：我们当时在问，如何才能确定克里希那穆提所说的是真理。他或许深陷于自身的习性、幻觉之中，无法自拔，于是将一系列观察和言论拼凑在一起，称之为真理。我们如何才能确定他所说的是真实的、永恒的、永恒不变的呢？

Dr. Bohm said that when one has an insight, a direct perception into what is being said, then there is no doubt that it is the truth. Having that insight you can work it out logically to show that the perception is true. But is that perception brief, only to be had at intervals and, therefore, gathering a lot of debris—those things that block perception—or is one perception enough? Does it open the door so that there is insight all the time?

博姆博士说，当一个人获得洞察力，直接感知到所说的话时，毫无疑问那就是真理。有了这种洞察力，你就可以进行逻辑推演，证明这种感知是正确的。但是，这种感知是短暂的，只能间歇性地获得，因此会积累许多干扰因素——那些阻碍感知的事物——还是说一次感知就足够了？它是否能打开一扇门，使人时刻拥有洞察力？

Questioner : Does that mean that you would never have any confusion?

提问者：那是不是意味着你永远不会感到困惑？

K : Yes, we came to that point. One has a perception, an insight, and that insight has its own capacity for reason, logic, and action. That action is complete, because the perception is complete for the moment. Will further action confuse perception? Or, having perception, is there no further confusion?

K：是的，我们讨论到了这一点。一个人有了感知，有了洞察力，而这种洞察力本身就具备推理、逻辑和行动的能力。这种行动是完整的，因为当下的感知也是完整的。进一步的行动会混淆感知吗？或者说，有了感知，就不会再有混淆了？

Q : I think we were saying that there is danger in this. If you say, “My action is always right—”

问：我认为我们刚才说的是这样做有危险。如果你说，“我的行为永远是正确的——”

K : Oh, that is dangerous!

K：哦，那太危险了！

Q : We also said that logic has its danger. One could think one has an insight when one has not.

问：我们也说过，逻辑是有危险的。一个人可能会自以为有洞察力，而实际上并没有。

K : Suppose I have the capacity to reason it out and act and then say: That is a perfect, complete action. Some people who read the Gita act according to it and they call that insight. Their action is patterned after their reading. They say this action is complete. I have heard many of them say this, as do Catholics and Protestants who are completely immersed in the Bible. So we are treading on very dangerous ground and, therefore, are greatly aware of it.

K：假设我有能力进行推理并采取行动，然后说：这是一个完美、完整的行动。一些读过《薄伽梵歌》的人会按照书中的教导行事，他们称之为顿悟。他们的行动是按照他们的阅读方式来制定的。他们说这样的行动是完美的。我听过很多这样的人这么说，就像那些完全沉浸在《圣经》中的天主教徒和新教徒一样。所以，我们正行走在非常危险的境地，因此，我们对此非常清楚。

Q : You also said that the mind tries to find security in all this.

问：您还说过，人的思维会试图在这一切中寻找安全感。

K : The mind has always been seeking security and when that security is threatened it tries to find security in insight, in direct perception.

K：人的心灵一直在寻求安全感，当这种安全感受到威胁时，它会试图在洞察力、直接感知中寻找安全感。

Q : In the illusion of insight.

问：在洞察力的错觉中。

K : Yes, but it makes the insight into security. The next question is: Must there be a constant breaking of perception? That is, one day one sees very clearly, one has direct perception; then that fades away and there is confusion. Then again there is a perception and an action, followed by confusion, and so on. Is that so? Or is there no further confusion after these deep insights?

K：是的，但这确实能让人洞察安全。下一个问题是：感知是否必须不断中断？也就是说，有一天，人们看得非常清楚，拥有直接的感知；然后这种感觉消退了，取而代之的是困惑。之后，又会出现新的感知和行动，紧接着又是困惑，如此反复。真是这样吗？或者说，在这些深刻的洞察之后，就不会再有困惑了？

Q : Are we saying this perception is whole?

问：我们是不是说这种看法是完整的？

K : Yes, if the perception is complete, whole, then there is no confusion at any time. Or, one may deceive oneself that it is whole and act upon it, which brings confusion.

K：是的，如果感知是完整、圆满的，那么任何时候都不会感到困惑。或者，人们可能会自欺欺人地认为感知是完整的，并据此行事，这反而会带来困惑。

Q : There is also a possible danger that one has a genuine perception, an insight, and is not fooling oneself, and that out of that comes a certain action. But then one could fall into making whatever that action was into a formula and stop having the insight. Let’s say that out of an insight which was real a certain action came. One then thinks that is the way things should be.

问：还有一种潜在的危险是，一个人可能拥有真实的感知和洞察力，并非自欺欺人，并由此采取了某种行动。但随后，他可能会将这种行动变成一种固定的模式，从而失去洞察力。假设某种行动源于真实的洞察力，那么他就会认为事情就应该是这样。

K : That is what generally happens.

K：通常情况下就是这样。

Q : But isn’t that a corruption of the perception, just making a pattern out of the action instead of continuing to look? It is like being able to really look at something; for instance, looking out of the window and seeing something. But then you don’t look out again and you think everything is the way it was. It may have totally changed. The perception starts out being genuine, but you don’t continue to look, have insight.

问：但这难道不是对感知的一种扭曲吗？只是把行为模式套用到某种行为模式上，而不是继续观察？这就像你能够真正地观察某件事物；例如，你向窗外望去，看到了一些东西。但之后你不再向外看，就认为一切都和以前一样。它可能已经完全改变了。你的感知最初是真实的，但你没有继续观察，没有获得洞察力。

K : Yes. Scientists may have an insight in some specialized field and that insight is put into a category of science unrelated to their lives. But we are talking of a perception that is not only in the field of action but also in daily life.

K：是的。科学家可能在某些专业领域有独到的见解，而这种见解往往被归入与他们生活无关的科学范畴。但我们这里讨论的是一种不仅存在于行动领域，也存在于日常生活中的认知。

Q : As a whole and so there is a continuity.

问：作为一个整体，因此具有连续性。

K : Yes.

K：是的。

Q : But I still don’t think we have gone into the question of danger. You said that one day a man came to you and said maybe you were stuck in a groove.

问：但我仍然认为我们还没有深入探讨危险的问题。你说过有一天有人来找你，说你可能陷入了一种固定的模式。

K : Yes, caught in a rut.

K：是的，陷入了困境。

Q : You didn’t say immediately, “I know I am not because I have had a perfect insight.”

问：你并没有立即说：“我知道我不是，因为我已经有了完美的洞察力。”

K : Ah, that would be deadly!

K：啊，那可就糟了！

Q : But rather, you said you looked at it for several days.

问：但你却说你研究了好几天。

K : Of course.

K：当然。

Q : I am trying to find out what we are driving at. Perhaps we are saying that there may be an insight which never goes back into confusion. But we are not saying there is one.

问：我想弄清楚我们到底想表达什么。或许我们想说的是，可能存在一种洞察，它能让我们摆脱困惑。但我们并没有断言这种洞察一定存在。

K : Yes, that’s right. Now would you say that when there is complete perception—not an illusory perception—there is no further confusion?

K：是的，没错。那么，您认为当感知完全正确——而不是产生错觉——时，就不会再有困惑了吗？

Q : It seems reasonable to say that.

问：这么说似乎合情合理。

K : That means from day to day there is no confusion at all.

K：这意味着每天的工作都不会有任何混乱。

Q : Then why did you feel it necessary to look into it?

问：那你为什么觉得有必要调查此事呢？

K : Because I may deceive myself. Therefore, it is dangerous ground and I must be alert, I must watch it.

K：因为我可能会自欺欺人。因此，这是一片危险的领域，我必须保持警惕，必须密切关注。

Q : Are we seeing as an insight now that when there is an insight of that kind there is no further confusion? But we may deceive ourselves nevertheless.

问：我们现在是否意识到，一旦有了这种洞察力，就不会再有任何困惑了？但我们仍然可能自欺欺人。

K : Yes. Therefore, we must be watchful.

K：是的。因此，我们必须保持警惕。

Q : Do you mean after the real insight you could then deceive yourself?

问：你的意思是，在真正领悟之后，你可能会自欺欺人吗？

K : No. You have a deep insight, complete, whole. Someone comes along and says: “Look, you are deceiving yourself.” Do you instantly say, “No, I am not deceiving myself because my perception was complete”? Or do you listen and look at it all afresh? It doesn’t mean that you are denying the complete perception; you are again watching if it is real or illusory.

K：不。你拥有深刻、完整、全面的洞察力。如果有人走过来对你说：“你看，你是在自欺欺人。”你会立刻说：“不，我没有自欺欺人，因为我的感知是完整的”吗？还是你会倾听，然后重新审视这一切？这并不意味着你否定了完整的感知；你是在再次观察它是真实的还是虚幻的。

Q : That is not necessarily an intellectual process?

问：那未必是一个智力活动？

K : No, no. I would say both. It is intellectual as well as nonverbal.

K：不，不。我认为两者都是。它既包括智力活动，也包括非语言活动。

Q : Is perception something that is always there and it is only that we—

问：感知是否一直存在，而仅仅是我们——

K : That leads to dangerous ground. The Hindus say that God is always there inside you, the abiding deep divinity, or soul, or Atman , and it is covered up. Remove the confusion, the debris, and it is found inside. Most people believe that. I think that is a conclusion. You conclude that there is something divine inside, a soul, the Atman , or whatever you like to call it. And from a conclusion you can never have a total, complete perception.

K：这很容易陷入危险的境地。印度教徒说，神始终存在于你的内心深处，那永恒的神性、灵魂或阿特曼，只是被掩盖了。去除迷雾和杂念，它就在你的内心深处。大多数人都相信这一点。我认为这是一种结论。你得出结论，认为内心深处存在某种神性，一个灵魂、阿特曼，或者你喜欢称之为任何名字的东西。而从结论出发，你永远无法获得完整、全面的认知。

Q : But this leads to another problem, because if you deny that, then what makes one step out of the stream? Does it mean that the stepping out is for certain individuals only?

问：但这又引出了另一个问题，因为如果你否认这一点，那么是什么构成了脱离主流的行为？这是否意味着只有某些特定个体才能脱离主流？

K : When you say “certain individuals” I think you are putting the wrong question, aren’t you?

K：你说“某些人”的时候，我觉得你问错了问题，不是吗？

Q : No. If the possibility exists for everyone—

问：不。如果每个人都有这种可能性——

K : Yes, the possibility exists for human beings.

K：是的，人类有这种可能性。

Q : For the totality?

问：就整体而言？

K : For human beings.

K：为了人类。

Q : Then there is some energy, which—

问：那么就存在一些能量，即——

K : Which is outside of them or which is in them.

K：哪个在它们之外，哪个在它们之内。

Q : Yes. We don’t know.

问：是的，我们不知道。

K : Therefore, don’t come to any conclusion. If from a conclusion you think you perceive, then that perception is conditioned; therefore, it is not whole.

K：因此，不要妄下结论。如果你从某个结论中认为自己有所领悟，那么这种领悟就是有条件的；因此，它并不完整。

Q : Does that mean that there would not be the possibility of a deepening of perception?

问：这是否意味着不存在加深感知的可能性？

K : You can’t deepen insight. You can’t deepen perception. You perceive the whole, that’s all.

K：你无法加深洞察力，也无法加深感知。你只能感知整体，仅此而已。

Q : What do you mean then by saying there was this mind into which you could continually go more deeply?

问：那么，你所说的“你可以不断深入探索这种思维方式”是什么意思呢？

K : That is something else.

K：那又是另一回事了。

Q : Are you saying that perception, if it is partial, is not perception?

问：您的意思是，如果感知是不完整的，那就不能称之为感知吗？

K : Of course, obviously not.

K：当然，显然不是。

Q : You mentioned watchfulness after perception.

问：你提到了感知之后的警觉性。

K : What happened was that a man came up to me and said, “You are getting old, you are stuck in a groove.” And I listened to it. For a couple of days I thought about it. I looked at it and said to myself, “He may be right.”

K：事情是这样的，有个男人走过来对我说：“你老了，你墨守成规了。” 我听了这话。我思考了两天。我仔细想了想，心想：“他说的也许有道理。”

Q : You are almost suggesting that it could be possible.

问：你这话几乎是在暗示这有可能发生。

K : No, I wanted to examine it. Not say it could or could not.

K：不，我只是想探究一下，而不是说它能不能做到。

Q : To be caught in habit after a perception, could that not ever happen again, at certain levels?

问：在某种认知之后，如果陷入某种习惯，这种情况是否永远不会再次发生，至少在某些层面上是这样？

K : There is partial perception and total perception; let’s divide it into those two. When there is total perception, there is no further confusion.

K：知觉有部分知觉和完全知觉之分，我们就把它分成这两类。当知觉达到完全知觉时，就不会再有任何困惑了。

Q : You don’t get caught in habit?

问：你不会陷入习惯吗？

K : There is no further confusion. Because it is so.

K：不存在任何疑问。因为事实就是如此。

Q : What if something happens to the brain physically?

问：如果大脑发生物理损伤怎么办？

K : Then of course it is gone.

K：那它当然就消失了。

Q : So there seems to be a limitation to what you say, because one assumes that the brain remains healthy.

问：所以你的说法似乎存在局限性，因为人们假设大脑保持健康。

K : Of course, it assumes that the whole organism is healthy. If there is an accident, your brain suffers concussion and something is injured, then it is finished.

K：当然，这前提是整个机体都健康。如果发生意外，你的大脑受到脑震荡或其他损伤，那就完了。

Q : The major danger is that we would mistake a partial perception for the total.

问：最大的危险在于我们会把片面的认知误认为是整体的认知。

K : One has to go into the question of what perception is. How do you come to it? That is very important, isn’t it? You cannot have perception if your daily life is in disorder, confused, contradictory. That is obvious.

K：我们必须探究感知究竟是什么。你是如何获得感知的？这非常重要，不是吗？如果你的日常生活混乱、困惑、矛盾，你就不可能拥有感知。这一点显而易见。

Q : Doesn’t this perception mean that there is constant renewal?

问：这种看法难道不意味着事物在不断更新吗？

K : No. Is that energy outside or inside? She is asking that question all the time.

K：不。那能量是在外部还是内部？她一直在问这个问题。

Q : Isn’t outside and inside an artificial division? Is that a real thing, or is it just an illusion?

问：内外之分难道不是人为的吗？这种划分是真实存在的，还是仅仅是一种错觉？

K : She said that this perception needs energy. That energy may be an external energy, a mechanical energy, or a nonmechanistic energy which may exist deeply inside you. Both are mental concepts. Would you agree to that? Both are conclusions which one has either accepted because tradition has said so, or one has come to that conclusion by oneself. Any form of conclusion is detrimental to perception. So what does perception mean? Can I have perception if I am attached to my position, to my wife, to my property?

K：她说这种感知需要能量。这种能量可以是外在的能量，机械的能量，也可以是深藏于你内心的非机械的能量。两者都是心理概念。你同意吗？两者都是结论，要么是因为传统如此教导而接受的，要么是自己得出的结论。任何形式的结论都会损害感知。那么，感知究竟意味着什么？如果我执着于我的地位、我的妻子、我的财产，我还能拥有感知吗？

Q : It colors the act of perceiving.

问：它影响感知行为。

K : Yes, but take the scientists. They have their families, their attachments; they want position, money, and all the rest of it, but they have an insight.

K：是的，但以科学家为例。他们有家庭，有牵挂；他们想要职位、金钱以及其他一切，但他们有洞察力。

Q : It is not total.

问：这还不是全部。

K : So we are saying that total perception can only take place when in your daily life there is no confusion.

K：所以我们的意思是，只有在日常生活中没有混乱的情况下，才能实现完全的感知。

Q : May we look more closely into that, because couldn’t it be that a total perception can take place in spite of that and wipe it away?

问：我们能否更仔细地研究一下这个问题，因为有没有可能尽管存在这种情况，但仍然会产生一种完全的感知，并将其抹去？

K : I can see if the windows are not clean my view is confused.

K：如果窗户不干净，我的视线就会模糊。

Q : Would that mean that there is a conditioned insight?

问：那是否意味着存在条件反射式的领悟？

K : If I am in fear, my perception will be very partial. That is a fact.

K：如果我感到恐惧，我的感知就会非常片面。这是事实。

Q : But don’t you need perception to end fear?

问：但是，难道不需要认知才能消除恐惧吗？

K : Ah, but in investigating fear I have a total perception of fear.

K：啊，但在研究恐惧的过程中，我对恐惧有了全面的感知。

Q : Surely if there is fear or attachment, even one’s logic would be distorted.

问：如果心中有恐惧或执念，那么人的逻辑必然也会扭曲。

K : One is frightened; as we said, that distorts perception. But in investigating, observing, going into fear, understanding it profoundly, in delving into it, I have perception.

K：人会感到恐惧；正如我们所说，恐惧会扭曲感知。但是，在调查、观察、深入恐惧、深刻理解恐惧、探究恐惧的过程中，我才能获得感知。

Q : Are you implying that there are certain things you can do which will make for perceptions, which means although you have fear and it distorts, the distortion is not so total that you cannot investigate it. There is still that possibility, although you are distorting through fear?

问：你的意思是说，有些事情可以通过一些行为来形成认知，也就是说，即使你感到恐惧，恐惧会扭曲你的认知，但这种扭曲并非完全无法察觉，你仍然可以对其进行探究。即使你因为恐惧而产生认知扭曲，仍然存在探究的可能性吗？

K : I realize that I am distorting perception through fear.

K：我意识到我因为恐惧而扭曲了认知。

Q : That’s right, then I begin to look at fear.

问：没错，然后我就开始研究恐惧。

K : I investigate it, look into it.

K：我会调查清楚，仔细研究一下。

Q : In the beginning I am also distorting it.

问：一开始我也对其进行了歪曲。

K : Therefore, I am watching every distortion. I am aware of every distortion that is going on.

K：因此，我正在密切关注每一种扭曲现象。我清楚地知道正在发生的每一种扭曲现象。

Q : But you see, I think the difficulty lies there. How can I investigate when I am distorting?

问：但是你看，我认为难点就在这里。当我扭曲事实时，我该如何进行调查呢？

K : Wait, just listen. I am afraid and I see fear has made me do something that is a distortion.

K：等等，听我说。我很害怕，而且我发现恐惧让我做出了扭曲的事情。

Q : But before I can see that, the fear has to fade away.

问：但在我看到这一切之前，恐惧必须先消失。

K : No, I am observing fear.

K：不，我观察到的是恐惧。

Q : But I cannot observe fear if I am afraid.

问：但如果我感到害怕，我就无法察觉恐惧。

K : Take a fact—that you are afraid. You are conscious of it. That means that you become aware of the fact that there is fear. And you observe also what that fear has done. Is that clear?

K：举个例子——你感到害怕。你意识到了这一点。这意味着你意识到了恐惧的存在。而且你也观察到了这种恐惧造成的后果。明白了吗？

Q : Yes.

问：是的。

K : And you look more and more into it. In looking very deeply into it you have an insight.

K：你会越深入研究它。当你深入研究之后，你就会有所领悟。

Q : I may have an insight.

问：我或许有个想法。

K : No, you will have insight, which is quite different.

K：不，你会获得洞察力，这完全不同。

Q : What you are saying is that this confusion due to fear is not complete, that it is always open to mankind to have insight.

问：你的意思是说，这种由恐惧引起的混乱并不是彻底的，人类始终有机会获得洞察力。

K : To one who is investigating, who is observing.

K：对于调查者、观察者而言。

Q : If you try to investigate something else while you are afraid, you get lost in fear. But it is still open to you to investigate fear.

问：如果你在恐惧中试图探究其他事物，你会迷失在恐惧之中。但你仍然可以探究恐惧本身。

K : Yes, quite right. One suffers and sees what it does. In observing it, investigating it, opening it up, in the very unrolling of it you have a certain insight. That is all we are saying. That insight may be partial. Therefore, one has to be aware that it is partial. Its action is partial and it may appear complete, so watch it.

K：是的，完全正确。人会经历痛苦，并观察它的影响。在观察、探究、剖析它的过程中，在它逐渐展开的过程中，你会获得某种洞见。这就是我们所要表达的全部。这种洞见可能是片面的。因此，人必须意识到它是片面的。它的作用是片面的，尽管它看起来可能很完整，所以要密切关注它。

Q : Very often it looks as if it is totally impossible to have an insight, since you say, “If you are distorting how will you look?” But you are also saying that, as a matter of fact, when you have a distortion, the one thing you can look at is the distortion.

问：很多时候，你似乎完全不可能获得洞察力，因为你说，“如果你扭曲事实，你会看起来怎么样？”但你也说过，事实上，当你出现扭曲时，你唯一可以关注的就是这种扭曲本身。

K : That’s right.

K：没错。

Q : That factually you have that capacity.

问：事实上，你确实具备这种能力。

K : One has that capacity.

K：人有这种能力。

Q : You can look at that. The fear which creates the distortion can be looked at; so you can’t say that no perception whatsoever is possible.

问：你可以研究一下。造成认知扭曲的恐惧是可以研究的；所以你不能说完全不可能存在任何感知。

K : That’s just it, then you have locked the door.

K：就是这样，你把门锁上了。

Q : Could one say that the fear can look at itself?

问：可以说恐惧能够审视自身吗？

K : No, no. One is afraid. In looking at that fear—not having an insight, just watching it—you see what it does, what its action is.

K：不，不。人会感到恐惧。当你审视这种恐惧——不是要领悟什么，只是观察它——你就会看到它的作用，它的行为是什么。

Q : You mean by looking, being aware of it.

问：你的意思是说，通过观察、意识到它。

K : Without any choosing, being aware. And you see what fear does. In looking at it more extensively, deeply, widely, suddenly you have an insight into the whole structure of fear.

K：无需选择，只需觉察。你就会明白恐惧的本质。当你更广泛、更深入、更全面地审视它时，你突然就能洞悉恐惧的整个结构。

Q : But still, in that moment of fear, I am fear.

问：但是，在恐惧的那一刻，我就是恐惧本身。

K : How you observe fear matters; whether you observe it as an observer or the observer is that . You perceive that the observer is the observed, and in this action there is distortion, confusion. And you examine that confusion, which is born of fear, and in the very process of examination you have an insight. Do it, you will see it—if you don’t limit yourself; in saying, “I am too frightened, I can’t look,” you run away from it.

K：你如何观察恐惧至关重要；你是以观察者的身份观察它，还是观察者本身就是被观察者。你意识到观察者就是被观察者，而这种行为本身就存在扭曲和混乱。你需要审视这种源于恐惧的混乱，并在审视的过程中获得洞见。去做吧，你就会明白——前提是你不设限自己；如果你说“我太害怕了，我不敢看”，你就是在逃避它。

Q : To simplify it perhaps too much, when we said one can’t see through the window because it is dirty and it distorts, the action of examining the fear, the distorting factor, is the cleansing of the window.

问：为了简化说明，我们说因为窗户脏了，所以看不见，那么审视恐惧、审视扭曲因素的行为，就是清洁窗户。

K : How you observe, how you investigate, that is the real thing. That is, perception can take place only when there is no division between the observer and the observed. Perception can take place only in the very act of exploring. To explore implies that there is no division between the observer and the observed. Therefore, you are watching the movement of fear and in the very watching of it there is an insight. I think that is clear.

K：你如何观察，如何调查，这才是关键。也就是说，只有当观察者和被观察者之间没有隔阂时，感知才能发生。感知只能在探索的行为本身中发生。探索意味着观察者和被观察者之间没有隔阂。因此，你是在观察恐惧的动向，而正是在观察恐惧的过程中，洞察才会出现。我想这一点很清楚。

And yet you see, Krishnamurti says, “I have never done this.”

然而，克里希那穆提却说：“我从未这样做过。”

Q : Never gone through all this? Then how do you know somebody else can?

问：你没经历过这些吗？那你怎么知道别人能做到？

K : That’s just it. Let’s discuss it. Suppose you have not gone through all this, but you see it instantly. Because you see it instantly, your capacity to reason explains all this. Another listens and says, “I’d like to get that.” I don’t have to go through that whole process.

K：正是如此。我们来讨论一下。假设你没有经历过所有这些过程，但你却能立刻明白。因为你能立刻明白，你的推理能力就能解释这一切。另一个人听完后说：“我也想明白。” 我不需要经历整个过程。

Q : Are you saying that all we have been discussing just now is merely a pointer to something else? We don’t have to go through all that.

问：您的意思是说，我们刚才讨论的所有内容都只是指向其他事情的引子吗？我们不必经历所有这些。

K : Yes. I want to get at that.

K：是的，我想弄清楚这一点。

Q : In other words, that helps to clear the ground in some way?

问：换句话说，这有助于以某种方式清理场地吗？

K : Yes.

K：是的。

Q : It is not really the main point.

问：这并不是重点。

K : No.

K：否。

Q : Are you saying there is a shortcut?

问：你的意思是说有捷径吗？

K : No, no shortcut. Must you go through fear, jealousy, anxiety, attachment? Or can you clear the whole thing instantly? Must one go through all this process?

K：不，没有捷径。你必须经历恐惧、嫉妒、焦虑和执着吗？还是可以瞬间消除所有这些情绪？一个人必须经历所有这些过程吗？

Q : You previously said that you have never done this. And by having that immediate total perception you are able to see what those with the dirty windows can do to clean them. But that isn’t necessary; there is perhaps a direct, an immediate, way for those who haven’t—

问：您之前说过您从未这样做过。通过这种直接而全面的感知，您能够看到那些窗户脏兮兮的人可以如何清洁它们。但这并非必要；对于那些从未这样做过的人来说，或许有一种直接、即时的方法——

K : No. First put the question, see what comes out of it. Dr. Bohm says to Krishnamurti, “You have probably not gone through all this. Because you have a direct, a total, insight you can argue with reason, with logic; you can act. You are always talking from that total perception; therefore, what you say can never be distorted.” And another listens to all this and says: “I am frightened, I am jealous, I am this, I am that, and, therefore, I can’t have total perception.” So I observe attachment, or fear, or jealousy, and I have an insight.

K：不。先提出问题，看看会得到什么结果。玻姆博士对克里希那穆提说：“你可能没有经历过这一切。因为你拥有直接、完整的洞察力，所以你可以用理性、用逻辑来辩论；你可以行动。你总是从这种完整的感知出发来说话；因此，你所说的话永远不会被扭曲。” 而另一个人听了这一切后却说：“我害怕，我嫉妒，我是这样，我是那样，因此，我无法拥有完整的感知。” 所以，我观察到了执着、恐惧或嫉妒，然后我获得了洞察力。

Is it possible through investigating, through awareness and discovering that the observer is the observed and that there is no division, in the very process of investigation—in which we are observing without the observer and see the totality of it—is it possible to free all the rest? I think that is the only way.

通过调查研究，通过觉察和发现观察者即被观察者，二者之间并无隔阂，是否有可能在调查研究的过程中——在这个过程中，我们无需观察者本身，就能看到事物的整体——解放其他一切？我认为这是唯一的途径。

Q : Is it possible not to have certain fears, jealousy, attachment? Could that be part of one’s conditioning if one were raised in a certain way, or went to a certain school?

问：是否有可能完全没有某些恐惧、嫉妒和依恋？这是否可能是由于在某种特定环境下长大或就读于某种特定学校而形成的？

K : But there may be deeper layers. You may not be totally conscious of them, you may not be totally aware of the deeper fears. You may say, “Superficially I am all right, I have none of these things.”

K：但可能还有更深层次的原因。你可能并没有完全意识到它们，你可能并没有完全意识到内心深处的恐惧。你可能会说：“表面上我很好，我没有这些问题。”

Q : But if one went to a certain school, would the kind of learning and investigation that would take place in such a school clear the way toward the possibility?

问：但是，如果一个人去某所学校就读，那么这所学校里进行的学习和研究是否会为实现这一目标铺平道路？

K : Obviously. What we are talking about is whether one must go through all this process.

K：显然。我们现在讨论的是是否必须经历所有这些过程。

Q : Couldn’t we remove from the problem the personal aspect? We are discussing what is open to mankind rather than to any individual.

问：我们能否将个人因素从问题中剔除？我们讨论的是全人类都面临的问题，而不是任何个人面临的问题。

K : Yes. Is it open to any human being without going through all this process?

K：是的。任何人都可以不经过所有这些程序就获得它吗？

Q : By “this process,” do you mean involvement with the fear?

问：您所说的“这个过程”，是指卷入恐惧之中吗？

K : With fear, sorrow, jealousy, attachment. Must you go through all that, step by step, or can a human being see the whole thing at a glance? And that very glance is the investigation and the complete, total perception?

K：伴随着恐惧、悲伤、嫉妒、执着。你必须一步一步地经历这一切吗？还是说，人可以一眼看清全貌？而这第一眼，就是探究，就是完整、彻底的感知？

Q : Which is what you mean when you say the first step is the last.

问：这就是你所说的“第一步是最后一步”的意思吗？

K : Yes, total perception.

K：是的，完全感知。

Q : Then what would one’s responsibility be toward someone who is in sorrow?

问：那么，对于一个悲伤的人，我们应该承担怎样的责任？

K : The response to that human being is the response of compassion. That’s all. Nothing else.

K：对那个人的回应就是同情。仅此而已。没有别的。

Q : For instance, if you see an injured bird, it is very easy to deal with that because it really doesn’t require very much of you. But when you come into contact with a human being, he has a much more complex set of needs.

问：例如，如果你看到一只受伤的鸟，处理起来非常容易，因为这真的不需要你付出太多。但当你接触到人时，他的需求就复杂得多。

K : What can you do actually? Somebody comes to you and says, “I am in deep sorrow.” Do you talk to them out of compassion, or from a conclusion, or out of your own particular experience of sorrow, which has conditioned you? Do you answer according to your conditioning? A Hindu who is conditioned in a certain way says, “My dear friend, I am so sorry, but in the next life you will live better. You suffered because you did this and that,” and so on. Or a Christian would respond from some other conclusion. And he takes comfort in it. Because a man who is suffering wants some sort of solace, someone on whose lap he can put his head. So what he is seeking is comfort and avoidance of this terrible pain. Will you offer him any of those escapes? Whatever comes out of compassion will help him.

K：你究竟能做些什么呢？有人来找你说：“我非常悲伤。”你会出于同情心与他们交谈，还是基于某种结论，又或是出于你自身悲伤经历的制约？你会根据自己的固有观念来回答吗？一个受某种观念影响的印度教徒会说：“我亲爱的朋友，我很抱歉，但你来世会过得更好。你受苦是因为你做了这样那样的事。”等等。或者一个基督徒会基于其他的结论来回应。他从中得到安慰。因为一个正在受苦的人渴望某种慰藉，渴望有人可以依靠。所以他寻求的是安慰，是逃避这可怕的痛苦。你会给他提供任何逃避的方式吗？任何出于同情心的回应都会对他有所帮助。

Q : Are you saying that as far as sorrow is concerned you can’t directly help anyone, but the energy of compassion itself may be of help?

问：您的意思是，就悲伤而言，您无法直接帮助任何人，但同情心本身的力量可能会有所帮助吗？

K : That’s right; that’s all.

K：没错，就这些。

Q : But many such wounded spirits will come and I think it is going to be a problem to know how to deal with them.

问：但是会有很多像这样受伤的灵魂出现，我认为如何对待他们将是一个问题。

K : There is no problem if you are compassionate. Compassion doesn’t create problems. It has no problems; therefore, it is compassionate.

K：只要你富有同情心，就不会有问题。同情心不会制造问题。它本身没有问题；因此，它就是富有同情心的。

Q : You are saying that total compassion is the highest intelligence?

问：您的意思是说，全然的慈悲心是最高的智慧？

K : Of course. If there is compassion, that compassion has its own intelligence and that intelligence acts. But if you have no compassion and no intelligence, then your conditioning makes you reply according to whatever another wants. I think that is fairly simple.

K：当然。如果心中有慈悲，那慈悲本身就蕴含着智慧，而这种智慧会付诸行动。但如果你既没有慈悲也没有智慧，那么你的固有思维模式就会让你按照他人的意愿行事。我觉得这道理很简单。

To go back to the other question, must a human being go through the whole process? Has no human being said, “I won’t go through all this; I absolutely refuse to go through all this”?

回到之前的问题，人必须经历整个过程吗？难道没有人说过：“我不想经历这一切；我绝对拒绝经历这一切”吗？

Q : But on what basis does one refuse? It wouldn’t make sense to refuse to do what is necessary.

问：但有什么理由拒绝呢？拒绝做必须要做的事情是说不通的。

K : Of course. You see, we are such creatures of habit. Because my father is conditioned, generations after generations are conditioned, and I am conditioned. And I accept it; I work in it and I operate with it. But if I say, “I won’t ever operate in my conditioned responses,” something else may take place. Then, if I realize I am a bourgeois, I don’t want to become an aristocrat or a militant, I refuse to be a bourgeois, which doesn’t mean I become a revolutionary, or join Lenin or Marx; those are all bourgeois to me. So something does take place. I reject the whole thing. You see, a human being never says, “I will reject the whole thing.” I want to investigate that.

K：当然。你看，我们都是习惯的奴隶。因为我父亲受制于某种观念，一代又一代人受制于某种观念，我也受制于某种观念。我接受它；我受其影响，我顺应它行事。但如果我说，“我永远不会再受制于我的条件反射”，那么事情可能会有所不同。比如，如果我意识到自己是资产阶级，我不想成为贵族或激进分子，我拒绝成为资产阶级，但这并不意味着我会成为革命者，或者加入列宁或马克思的阵营；在我看来，这些都是资产阶级的。所以，事情确实会发生。我拒绝这一切。你看，人永远不会说，“我要拒绝这一切”。我想探究这一点。

Q : Do you mean that even to say, “I am going to get rid of the whole thing,” is not necessary?

问：你的意思是，即使说“我要彻底摆脱它”也是没有必要的吗？

K : Of course. I mean saying, “I won’t be a bourgeois,” is just words.

K：当然。我的意思是，说“我不会成为资产阶级”只不过是说说而已。

Q : But isn’t the key to this somewhere in desire? There is some sort of desire for continuity, for security.

问：但关键难道不在于欲望吗？人们渴望延续性，渴望安全感。

K : That’s right. Bourgeois implies continuity, security, it implies belonging to something, a lack of taste, vulgarity, all that.

K：没错。资产阶级意味着延续性、安全感，意味着归属感，意味着缺乏品味、庸俗等等。

Q : But Krishnaji, if you are saying that Krishnamurti never said this, never had the need to say it, we can only conclude that you are some kind of freak.

问：但是克里希纳吉，如果你说克里希那穆提从未说过这话，也从未需要说过这话，那我们只能得出结论，你是个怪人。

K : No, no. You can say he is a freak, but it doesn’t answer the question. Krishnamurti says, “I have not touched all this.” Somebody asks, “Why should I go through all this?” Don’t say Krishnamurti is a freak, but how it happens.

K：不，不。你可以说他是个怪人，但这并不能回答问题。克里希那穆提说：“我还没有接触过这一切。”有人会问：“我为什么要经历这一切？”不要说克里希那穆提是个怪人，而是要探究这一切是如何发生的。

Q : In saying, “I won’t be a bourgeois,” you are discovering it in yourself.

问：当你说“我不会成为资产阶级”时，你其实是在发现自己身上有资产阶级的特质。

K : No, no. That is a different matter. If somebody says to you, “I have never been through all this,” what do you do? Do you say he is a freak? Or would you say, “How extraordinary; is he telling the truth? Has he deceived himself?” You discuss with him. Then your question is, “How does it happen?” You are a human being, he is a human being; you want to find out.

K：不，不。那是另一回事。如果有人对你说：“我从来没经历过这些”，你会怎么做？你会说他是个怪胎吗？还是你会说：“真不可思议；他说的是真话吗？他是不是自欺欺人了？”你会和他讨论。然后你会问：“这是怎么回事？”你是人，他也是人；你想弄清楚。

Q : You ask in what way we are different. He is a human being that has never been through all that, and yet he points out.

问：你问我们有何不同。他是一个从未经历过这一切的人，但他却能指出这一点。

K : No, he has never been through it. Don’t say he points out. Don’t you ask that question: “How does it happen; must I go through all this?” Do you ask that?

K：不，他从未经历过这些。别说他指出来了。你别问：“怎么会发生这种事？我必须经历这一切吗？”你会问这种问题吗？

Q : You are taking two widely separate things. One is the uncontaminated person who never had to go through the process because he was never in the soup.

问：你把两件事混为一谈了。一件是未受污染的人，他从未接触过汤，所以无需经历这个过程。

K : Leave out why he didn’t go through it.

K：别说他为什么没经历这个过程。

Q : But most other people, apparently, are in some form of—

问：但显然，大多数其他人都处于某种形式的——

K : Conditioning—

K：体能训练——

Q1 : —in some form of contamination—it may be fear or something else. Therefore, the person who has already got this sickness—let’s call it that—says “This man has never been sick for a day in his life.” What good is it to examine that, because one is already sick in some form.

问题一：——某种形式的污染——可能是恐惧或其他原因。因此，已经患上这种疾病（我们姑且这么称呼它）的人会说：“这个人一生中从未生过病。” 探究这一点又有什么用呢？因为一个人已经以某种形式患病了。

Q2 : The question is, how can a human being who is sick in some way get out of it directly without going through endless self-exploration?

Q2：问题是，一个人如果患有某种疾病，如何才能不经过无休止的自我探索而直接摆脱疾病？

K : Can we put the whole thing differently? Do you seek excellence, not excellence, for instance, in a building, but the essence of excellence? Then everything falls away, doesn’t it? Or do you seek excellence in a certain direction and never the essence of excellence? As an artist I seek excellence in my painting and get caught in that. A scientist gets caught in something else. But an ordinary human being, not a specialist, just an average intelligent human being who does not take drugs, does not smoke, is fairly intelligent and decent; if he sought the essence of excellence, would this happen? The essence would meet all this. I wonder if I am conveying something?

K：我们能不能换个说法？比如说，你追求的不是建筑本身的卓越，而是卓越的本质？如果是这样，一切岂不都变得无关紧要了？或者你追求的是某个方向上的卓越，而从未触及卓越的本质？作为一名艺术家，我追求绘画的卓越，并深陷其中。科学家则沉溺于其他事物。但一个普通人，并非专家，只是一个智力中等、不吸毒、不抽烟、相当聪明且品行端正的人；如果他追求的是卓越的本质，结果会是这样吗？本质会涵盖一切。我不知道我是否表达清楚了什么？

Q : Does it exist apart from this manifestation?

问：除了这种表现形式之外，它是否还存在？

K : Listen carefully first. Don’t object or reject and say if and but. That very demand for excellence, how you demand it, brings the essence of it. You demand it passionately. You demand the highest intelligence, the highest excellence, the essence of it, and when fear arises, then you—

K：先仔细听。不要反对，不要拒绝，也不要说“如果”和“但是”。你对卓越的追求，你追求的方式，本身就蕴含着卓越的精髓。你满怀热情地追求卓越。你追求最高的智慧，最高的卓越，追求卓越的精髓，而当恐惧升起时，你——

Q : Where does the demand come from?

问：需求来自哪里？

K : Demand it! Don’t say, “Where does it come from?” There may be a motive, but the very demand washes it all away. I wonder if I am conveying anything?

K：直接问！别问“这东西从哪儿来的？”也许他们有动机，但问本身就能消除一切疑虑。我不知道我这样说到底有没有传达什么信息？

Q : You are saying to demand this excellence, which we don’t know.

问：您的意思是要追求这种我们并不了解的卓越品质。

K : I don’t know what is beyond it, but I want to be morally excellent.

K：我不知道彼岸是什么，但我想要在道德上做到卓越。

Q : Does that mean goodness?

问：那是不是意味着善良？

K : I demand the excellence of goodness, I demand the excellent flower of goodness. In that very demand there is a demand for the essence.

K：我追求至善至美，我追求至善至美的极致之美。这追求本身就包含着对本质的追求。

Q : Does perception come from this demand?

问：这种认知是否源于这种需求？

K : Yes, that’s right.

K：是的，没错。

Q : Could you go into what you call this demand?

问：您能否详细谈谈您所说的这种需求？

K : It is not a demand which means asking, a demand that means imploring, wanting. Cut out all those.

K：这不是请求，不是恳求，也不是索取。把这些都去掉。

Q : It doesn’t mean those?

问：不是指那些吗？

K : No, no.

K：不，不。

Q : But then you are back with prayer.

问：但后来你又回到了祈祷这件事上。

K : Oh, no. Leave out all that.

K：哦，不。把那些都别说了。

Q : You are really saying that the impossible is possible to the average intelligent human being?

问：你的意思是说，对于普通智力正常的人来说，不可能的事情也是可能的吗？

K : We are saying that, yes, which is not a conclusion, which is not a hope. I say it is possible for the average human being, who is fairly clean, who is fairly decent, fairly kind, who is not a bourgeois.

K：我们说的是，是的，但这并非结论，也并非希望。我说的是，对于一个相当干净、相当体面、相当善良、非资产阶级的普通人来说，这是有可能的。

Q : Traditionally we are conditioned to believe that there are special people with no conscious content of consciousness, so it is very difficult for someone like me to feel that one could really be completely free of it.

问：传统观念认为，有些人没有意识内容，所以像我这样的人很难相信一个人真的可以完全摆脱意识。

K : You see, you have not listened. K says to you, please listen first, don’t bring in all these objections. Just listen to what he is saying. That is, what is important in life is the supreme excellence, which has its own essence. That’s all. And to demand does not mean begging or praying, getting something from somebody.

K：你看，你根本没听进去。K跟你说，请先听我说，别带上这些反对意见。就听他说什么。那就是，人生最重要的就是至高无上的卓越，它有其自身的本质。仅此而已。而要求并不意味着乞求或祈祷，也不是指从别人那里得到什么。

Q : The point is, we find we confuse demand with desire.

问：关键在于，我们发现我们常常把需求和欲望混淆起来。

K : Of course.

K：当然。

Q : There must be no beliefs.

问：必须没有任何信仰。

K : No beliefs, no desire.

K：没有信仰，没有欲望。

Q : You see, when people feel that they want to give up desire then there is a danger of giving up this demand as well.

问：你看，当人们觉得他们想要放弃欲望时，就存在放弃这种需求的危险。

K : How can we put this? Let’s find a good word for it. Would the word passion be suitable? There is passion for this, passion for excellence.

K：我们该怎么表达呢？找个合适的词来形容吧。“热情”这个词合适吗？我们对这件事充满热情，对卓越充满热情。

Q : Does it imply that this passion has no object?

问：这是否意味着这种激情没有对象？

K : You see how you immediately form a conclusion. Burning passion, not for something. The communists are passionate about their ideas. That passion is very, very petty and limited. The Christians have passion for missionary work; that passion is born of the love of Jesus. That again is not passion, it is very narrow. Putting all that aside, I say, “Passion!”

K：你看，你很快就得出结论了。所谓的热情，并非针对某件事物。共产主义者对他们的理念充满热情。但这种热情非常狭隘，非常狭隘。基督徒对传教工作充满热情；这种热情源于对耶稣的爱。但这也不是真正的热情，它非常狭隘。抛开所有这些不谈，我说的是：“热情！”

Q : As you were just saying, people have had some vision, or a dream of something, and that has developed a great energy. But you are saying it is not a dream, it is not a vision, but it is nevertheless some perception of this excellence.

问：正如您刚才所说，人们曾经有过某种愿景或梦想，并由此迸发出巨大的能量。但您现在却说这不是梦想，也不是愿景，而是一种对卓越的感知。

K : All those passions feed the ego, feed the “me,” make “me” important, consciously or unconsciously. We are cutting out all that. There is a young boy who has a passion to grow up into an extraordinary human being, into something original.

K：所有这些激情都在滋养自我，满足“我”的欲望，让“我”变得重要，无论是有意识的还是无意识的。我们正在剔除所有这些。这里有一个男孩，他渴望成长为一个非凡的人，一个独一无二的人。

Q : He sees that it is possible.

问：他认为这是有可能的。

K : Yes.

K：是的。

Q : And, therefore, he has the passion.

问：因此，他充满热情。

K : Yes, that’s right. It is possible. Is that what is missing in most human beings? Not passion, but the welling up of... I don’t know how to put it. There is this passion in a human being who demands the supreme excellence, not in what he writes in his books, but the feeling of it. You know this, don’t you? That may shatter everything else. Again, that human being didn’t demand it. He says, “I never even asked for it.”

K：是的，没错。这完全有可能。这难道不是大多数人所缺失的吗？不是激情，而是某种……我不知道该怎么形容。有些人追求极致卓越，这种追求并非体现在他们书中所写的内容上，而是体现在他们内心的感受上。你明白这一点，对吧？这种感受可能会摧毁其他一切。再说一遍，这样的人并没有强求过它。他说：“我甚至从未奢求过它。”

Q : Perhaps that is due to conditioning. We are conditioned to mediocrity, not to make this demand. That is what you mean by mediocrity.

问：或许这是环境造成的。我们习惯了平庸，而不是提出这样的要求。这就是你所说的平庸。

K : Yes, of course. Mediocrity is lack of great passion—not for Jesus, or for Marx, or whatever it is.

K：当然。平庸就是缺乏强烈的热情——不是对耶稣的热情，也不是对马克思的热情，或者对其他任何东西的热情。

Q : We are not only conditioned to mediocrity but to direction, so the demand is always to have some direction.

问：我们不仅习惯了平庸，也习惯了有方向，所以我们总是需要一些方向。

K : The demand is a direction, quite right.

K：需求就是方向，没错。

Q : To have a demand without any direction—

问：提出没有方向的需求——

K : That’s right. I like the word demand because it is a challenge.

K：没错。我喜欢“需求”这个词，因为它代表着挑战。

Q : Doesn’t a demand without direction imply that it is not in time?

问：没有明确方向的需求，岂不是意味着它不及时吗？

K : Of course. It demands no direction, no time, no person. So, does total insight bring this passion? Total insight is the passion.

K：当然。它不需要任何指导，不需要时间，也不需要任何人。那么，完全的洞察力是否带来了这种热情？完全的洞察力本身就是热情。

Q : They can’t be separate.

问：它们无法分离。

K : Total insight is the flame of passion that wipes away all confusion. It burns away everything else. Don’t you then act as a magnet? The bees go toward the nectar. In the same way don’t you act as a magnet when you are passionate to create? Is it that there is this lack of fire? That may be the thing that is missing. If there is something missing, I would ask for it.

K：全然的洞察力如同激情之火，它能驱散一切迷茫，烧尽其他一切。难道你不会像磁铁一样吸引他人吗？蜜蜂会趋向花蜜。同样，当你充满创作热情时，难道你不会像磁铁一样吸引他人吗？是不是缺少了这股激情？或许这就是你所缺失的。如果真的缺少了什么，我会寻求它。

Q1 : Could we talk about the relationship between the conditioned and the unconditioned mind, and whether it is only possible to ask for small things, or can we somehow leap beyond that into something bigger?

问题一：我们能否谈谈有条件的心智和无条件的心智之间的关系，以及我们是否只能祈求小事，或者我们能否超越这一点，追求更大的目标？

Q2 : Whatever the “me” asks for, the asking in a direction is the small thing.

Q2：无论“我”提出什么要求，提出要求本身就是一件小事。

K : Quite right.

K：完全正确。

Q : We have to ask for the unlimited, for the unconditioned.

问：我们必须追求无限的、无条件的。

K : She is really asking what the relationship is between the conditioned and the unconditioned. Also, what is the relationship between two human beings when one is unconditioned and the other is not? There is no relationship.

K：她实际上是在问，有条件反射和无条件反射之间究竟是什么关系。还有，如果两个人中一个没有条件反射，另一个有条件反射，他们之间又是什么关系呢？他们之间没有任何关系。

Q : How can you say that there is no relationship between the unconditioned and the conditioned human being?

问：你怎么能说未受制约的人和受制约的人之间没有关系呢？

K : There is no relationship from the conditioned to the unconditioned. But the unconditioned has a relationship to the other.

K：条件反射与非条件反射之间没有关系。但非条件反射与条件反射之间存在关系。

Q : But logically one could ask if there is an essential difference between the unconditioned and the conditioned. Because if you say there is, then there is duality.

问：但从逻辑上讲，我们可以问，无条件和有条件之间是否存在本质区别？因为如果你说存在本质区别，那么就存在二元性。

K : What do you mean by essential difference?

K：你所说的本质区别是什么意思？

Q : Let’s say difference in kind. If there is an essential difference between the conditioned and the unconditioned there is duality.

问：我们姑且称之为本质区别。如果条件反射和无条件反射之间存在本质区别，那么就存在二元性。

K : I see what you mean. X is conditioned, Y is not conditioned. X thinks in terms of duality, his very conditioning is duality. But duality has no relationship with Y, yet Y has a relationship with X.

K：我明白你的意思了。X 受制约，Y 不受制约。X 的思维方式是二元对立的，他所受的制约本身就是二元对立。但二元对立与 Y 无关，而 Y 却与 X 有关联。

Q : Because there is no duality.

问：因为不存在二元性。

K : Yes. Y has no duality; therefore, there is a relationship. You also asked another question: Essentially, deeply, is there a difference? Are not both the same?

K：是的。Y没有二元性；因此，它们之间存在某种关系。你还问了另一个问题：本质上，从根本上讲，它们之间有区别吗？它们难道不是一回事吗？

Q : Could one ask the question in another way? Is the conditioning only superficial?

问：这个问题可以换一种方式问吗？这种条件反射仅仅是表面上的吗？

K : No. Then we are lost.

K：不。那我们就完了。

Q : The world couldn’t be unconditioned, could it?

问：世界不可能不受任何制约，对吧？

K : The world is “me” and “I” am the world.

K：世界就是“我”，“我”就是世界。

Q : That is an absolute fact only to the unconditioned.

问：只有未受外界影响的人才会认为这是绝对事实。

K : Oh, not at all. Be careful, it is so. It is an obvious fact.

K：哦，完全不是。小心点，事实就是如此。这是显而易见的事实。

Q : You mean that only the unconditioned can perceive that?

问：你的意思是只有未受制约的人才能感知到这一点吗？

K : I am refuting it. I say it isn’t quite like that.

K：我不同意这种说法。我认为事实并非如此。

Q : I mean it in the sense that I may say, “I am the world, the world is me,” but I revert to an action that is a contradiction to that. Therefore, it is not an absolute fact for me. There may be moments when the fact of it is seen by me.

问：我的意思是，我可能会说“我即世界，世界即我”，但我的行为却与之相悖。因此，对我而言，这并非绝对事实。或许在某些时刻，我会意识到它的存在。

K : Yes. Do you mean: I say to myself very clearly, “I am the world and the world is me”?

K：是的。你的意思是：我非常清楚地告诉自己，“我就是世界，世界就是我”？

Q : I see it.

问：我看到了。

K : I feel it.

K：我感觉到了。

Q : I feel it, yes.

问：我感觉到了，是的。

K : And I act contrary to that, which is, I act personally, selfishly—“my,” “me.” That is a contradiction to the fact that the world is me and I am the world. A person can say this merely as an intellectual conclusion, or a momentary feeling.

K：而我的行为却与之相反，我的行为是出于个人私利——“我的”、“我”。这与“世界即我，我即世界”这一事实相矛盾。一个人或许会把这仅仅当作一种理性的结论，或者一种瞬间的感受。

Q : It is not an intellectual conclusion, because I am stating my position, but I accept that for you the position is totally different.

问：这不是一个理性的结论，因为我只是在陈述我的立场，但我承认你的立场与我完全不同。

K : No, you don’t even have to accept that. See the fact, which is, when one says, “I am the world and the world is me,” there is no me. But one’s house has to be insured; I may have children; I have to earn a living. But there is no me. See the importance of it. There is no me all the time. I function, but there is no me which is seeking a higher position and all that. Though I am married, I am not attached, I don’t depend on a wife or husband. The appearances may give you the impression that the me is operating, but actually, to a man who feels, “The world is me and I am the world,” to him there is no me. To you, looking at him, there is. That human being lives in this world, he must have food, clothes and shelter, a job, transportation, all that, yet there is no me.

K：不，你甚至不必接受这一点。你看，事实是，当一个人说“我就是世界，世界就是我”时，其实“我”并不存在。但一个人的房子需要保险；他可能需要孩子；他需要谋生。但“我”并不存在。明白这一点的重要性吗？“我”并非时时刻刻都存在。我运转着，但并不存在一个追求更高地位的“我”。即使我已婚，我也没有依附于任何人，我并不依赖妻子或丈夫。表面上的“我”似乎在运转，但实际上，对于一个认为“世界就是我，我就是世界”的人来说，“我”并不存在。在你看来，他确实存在。这个人生活在这个世界上，他需要食物、衣服、住所、工作、交通工具等等，然而“我”却并不存在。

So when the world is me and I am the world, there is no me. Can that state, that quality operate in all directions? It must operate in all directions. When you say, “I am the world and the world is me,” and there is no me, there is no conditioning. Then I don’t put the question: In that unconditioned state does the conditioned exist? When a human being says, “I am the world and the world is me,” there is no I.

所以，当世界即我，我即世界时，便不存在“我”。这种状态，这种特质，能否向各个方向运作？它必须向各个方向运作。当你说道：“我即世界，世界即我”，而“我”已然不存在，也就不存在任何条件。那么，我便不会提出这样的问题：在这种无条件的状态下，条件是否存在？当一个人说“我即世界，世界即我”时，便不存在“我”。

Q : Therefore, the other person also is not there. There is no you.

问：因此，另一个人也不存在。你也不存在。

K : There is no me, there is no you. When you ask if the conditioned exists in this state you are asking a wrong question. That is what I was getting at. Because when there is no I there is no you.

K：没有“我”，也没有“你”。当你问在这种状态下条件反射是否存在时，你问错了问题。这就是我想说的。因为当没有“我”时，也就没有“你”。

Q : The question is: How does that person see the kind of confusion that arises around “I” and “you”? He sees what is going on in the world, that people are generally confused about this.

问：问题是：这个人如何看待围绕“我”和“你”产生的这种混淆？他看到的是世界上正在发生的事情，那就是人们普遍对此感到困惑。

K : I exist; there is you and me. And you also think the same thing. So we keep this division everlastingly. But when you and I really realize, have profound insight, that the world is me and I am the world, there is no me.

K：我存在；有你，也有我。你也这么想。所以我们永远维持着这种分裂。但当你我真正意识到，拥有深刻的领悟，意识到世界即是我，我即世界时，便不再有“我”的存在。

Q : There is no me and no you. No means everything.

问：没有“我”，也没有“你”。“无”意味着一切。

K : The world of living, everything.

K：生活的世界，一切的一切。

Q : Then the question whether there is an essential difference between this and that, the unconditioned and the conditioned, doesn’t arise because there is no “between.”

问：那么，是否存在本质区别，无条件的和有条件的，这个问题就不会出现，因为根本没有“中间”的概念。

K : Yes, that’s right. There is no “you,” there is no “I” in that state, which doesn’t include the conditioned state. Is this too abstract?

K：是的，没错。在这种状态下，既没有“你”，也没有“我”，这种状态也不包括条件反射状态。这样说是不是太抽象了？

Q : Why do you have to say, “I am the world” first, and then deny this?

问：为什么你先说“我就是世界”，然后又否认这一点？

K : Because it is an actuality.

K：因为这是事实。

Q : But then you imply that the “I” is still there if I say, “I am the world.”

问：但这样一来，如果我说“我就是世界”，那么“我”就仍然存在了。

K : That is merely a statement. It is an actual fact that I am the world.

K：那只是一种说法。事实上，我就是世界。

Q : Whatever I mean by the word I , I also mean by the word world .

问：我所说的“我”所指的，也是我所说的“世界”所指的。

K : Yes.

K：是的。

Q : So we don’t need those two words.

问：所以我们不需要那两个字。

K : Yes, you and I, remove that.

K：是的，你和我，把那段删掉。

Q : There is just everything.

问：这里什么都有。

K : No, this is very dangerous. If you say I am everything—

K：不，这很危险。如果你说我就是一切——

Q : I am trying to find out what you mean by “the world.”

问：我想弄清楚你所说的“世界”是什么意思。

K : If you say, “I am everything,” then the murderer, the assassin, is part of me.

K：如果你说“我就是一切”，那么凶手、刺客也是我的一部分。

Q : Suppose I say, “I am the world” instead, does that change it?

问：如果我说“我就是世界”，情况会改变吗？

K : [laughing] All right. I see the actual fact that I am the result of the world. The world means killing, wars, the whole of society. I am the result of that.

K：（笑）好吧。我明白了，我就是这个世界的产物。这个世界意味着杀戮、战争，意味着整个社会。我就是这一切的产物。

Q : And I see everybody is the result of that.

问：我认为每个人都是这种现象的结果。

K : Yes. I am saying the result is “I” and “you.”

K：是的。我的意思是，结果是“我”和“你”。

Q : And that separation.

问：还有那种分离。

K : When I say, “I am the world,” I am saying all that.

K：当我说“我就是世界”时，我的意思就是所有这些。

Q : You mean to say I am generated by the world, I am identified with everything.

问：你的意思是说，我是由世界创造的，我与万物认同。

K : Yes. I am the product of the world.

K：是的。我是这个世界的产物。

Q : The world is the essence of what I am.

问：世界是我存在的本质。

K : Yes. I am the essence of the world. It is the same thing. When there is a deep perception of that, not verbal, not intellectual, not emotional, not romantic, but profound, there is no you or me. I think that holds logically. But there is a danger. If I say, “The world is me, I am everything,” I’ll accept everything.

K：是的。我就是世界的本质。这是一样的。当对这一点有深刻的领悟时——不是语言上的，不是理性的，不是情感上的，也不是浪漫的，而是深刻的——就没有你我之分了。我认为这在逻辑上是成立的。但这其中也存在危险。如果我说，“世界就是我，我就是一切”，那我就会接受一切。

Q : You are really saying that one is the product of the whole of society.

问：你实际上是在说，人是整个社会的产物。

K : Yes.

K：是的。

Q : But I am also of the essence of the whole of society.

问：但我也是整个社会的组成部分。

K : Yes. I am really the essential result of all this.

K：是的。我就是这一切的最终结果。

Q : Does it help to use the word ego ?

问：使用“自我”这个词有帮助吗？

K : It is the same thing, it doesn’t matter. You see, when you say “me,” or “ego,” there is a possibility of deception that the “I” is the very essence of God. You know about that superstition.

K：都一样，没区别。你看，当你用“我”或者“自我”这个词的时候，就可能产生一种错觉，认为“我”就是上帝的本质。你知道这种迷信。

Q : The Atman .

问：阿特曼。

K : Yes.

K：是的。

Q : But there is still another question. Is the unconditioned mind also a product of all this? Then we come to a contradiction.

问：但还有一个问题。无条件的心智也是这一切的产物吗？这样一来，我们就陷入了矛盾。

K : No, there is no contradiction. Without using the word I , it can be said the result of the world is this. The result of the world is that also. We are two human beings, which means the result has created the “I” and the “you.” When there is an insight into the result there is no “result.”

K：不，这并不矛盾。不用“我”这个字，也可以说世界的结果是这样的，世界的结果是那样的。我们是两个人，这意味着世界的结果创造了“我”和“你”。当对结果有了洞察力时，就不存在“结果”了。

Q : The result changes and vanishes when we see it.

问：结果在我们看到的时候会发生变化并消失。

K : That means there is no result. Therefore, “you” and “I” don’t exist. That is an actual fact for a man who says, “I am not the result.” You see what it means? There is no causation in the mind and, therefore, there is no effect. Therefore, it is whole, and any action born of it is causeless and without effect.

K：这意味着没有结果。因此，“你”和“我”都不存在。对于一个说“我不是结果”的人来说，这是一个事实。你明白这意味着什么吗？心中没有因果关系，因此也没有果。因此，它是完整的，任何由此产生的行为都是无因无果的。

Q : You have to make that clear, in the sense that you still use cause and effect concerning ordinary, mechanical things.

问：你必须把这一点说清楚，因为你仍然会用因果关系来解释普通的、机械的事物。

K : Quite. This human being, X, is a result. And Y is a result. X says, “I,” and Y says, “I”; therefore, there is “you” and “I.” X says, “I see this,” and investigates, goes into it, and he has an insight. In that insight the two results cease. Therefore, in that state there is no cause.

K：正是如此。这个人X是结果，Y也是结果。X说“我”，Y也说“我”；因此，就有了“你”和“我”。X说“我看到了这一点”，然后他去探究、去深入，并获得了顿悟。在这种顿悟中，这两个结果都消失了。因此，在这种状态下，没有了原因。

Q : There is no cause and no effect although it may leave a residue in the mind.

问：虽然可能会在脑海中留下痕迹，但既无因也无果。

K : Let’s go into it. In that state there is no result, no cause, no effect. That mind acts out of compassion. Therefore, there is no result.

K：我们来深入探讨一下。在那种状态下，没有结果，没有原因，也没有果。那种心念出于慈悲而行动。因此，没有结果。

Q : But in some sense it would look as if there were a result.

问：但从某种意义上说，这似乎是一个结果。

K : But compassion has no result. A is suffering; he says to X, “Please help me to get out of my suffering.” If X really has compassion his words have no result.

K：但是，怜悯并不会奏效。A正在受苦，他对X说：“请帮我摆脱痛苦。”如果X真的心怀怜悯，他的话也不会有任何效果。

Q : Something happens, but there is no result.

问：发生了一些事，但没有结果。

K : That’s it.

K：就是这样。

Q : But I think people generally are seeking a result.

问：但我认为人们普遍都在寻求结果。

K : Yes. Let’s put it another way. Does compassion have a result? When there is result there is cause. When compassion has a cause then you are no longer compassionate.

K：是的。我们换个说法。同情心有结果吗？有结果就意味着有原因。当同情心有了原因，那么你就不再是同情心了。

Q : But compassion also acts.

问：但同情心也能起到作用。

K : Compassion is compassion, it doesn’t act. If it acts because there is a cause and an effect, then it is not compassion: it wants a result.

K：同情就是同情，它不会采取行动。如果因为存在因果关系而采取行动，那就不是同情了：它想要的是一个结果。

Q : It acts purely.

问：它纯粹地发挥作用。

K : It wants a result.

K：它想要一个结果。

Q : What makes it want a result is the idea of separation. Somebody says, “There is a person suffering, I would like to produce the result that he is not suffering.” But that is based on the idea that there is “me” and “he.”

问：它之所以渴望得到某种结果，是因为其中存在分离的观念。有人会说：“有人在受苦，我希望他不再受苦。”但这其实是基于“我”和“他”二元对立的观念。

K : That’s it.

K：就是这样。

Q : There is no “he” and no “I.” There is no room, no place, to have this result.

问：这里既没有“他”，也没有“我”。没有空间，没有地方，容不下这样的结果。

K : It is a tremendous thing! One has to look at it very, very carefully. Look, the world is me and I am the world. When I say “me,” “you” exist; both of us are there. The “you” and the “I” are the results of man’s misery, of selfishness, and so on; it is a result. When one looks into the result, goes into it very, very deeply, the insight brings about a quality in which “you” and “I”—who are the result—don’t exist. This is easy to agree to verbally, but when you see it deeply there is no “you” and no “me.” Therefore, there is no result; which means compassion. The person upon whom that compassion acts wants a result. We say, “Sorry, there is no result.” But the man who suffers says, “Help me to get out of this,” or, “Help me to bring back my son, my wife.” He is demanding a result. This thing has no result. The result is the world.

K：这真是不可思议！必须非常非常仔细地审视它。你看，世界就是我，我就是世界。当我说“我”的时候，“你”也存在；我们两个都在那里。“你”和“我”是人类苦难、自私等等的结果；它是一个结果。当我们审视这个结果，深入探究它时，这种洞察力会带来一种特质，在这种特质中，“你”和“我”——作为结果本身——并不存在。这很容易用言语表达，但当你真正深入地理解它时，你会发现没有“你”，也没有“我”。因此，没有结果；这意味着慈悲。接受慈悲的人想要一个结果。我们说：“抱歉，没有结果。”但受苦的人会说：“帮帮我摆脱困境”，或者，“帮帮我找回我的儿子，我的妻子。”他是在寻求一个结果。这件事本身没有结果。结果就是世界。

Q : Does compassion affect the consciousness of man?

问：慈悲心会影响人的意识吗？

K : Yes. It affects the deep layers of consciousness. The “I” is the result of the world; the “you” is the result of the world. And to the man who sees this deeply, with a profound insight, there is no “you” or “I.” Therefore, that profound insight is compassion, which is intelligence. And the intelligence says, if you want a result I can’t give it to you, I am not the product of a result. Compassion says, this state is not a result; therefore, there is no cause.

K：是的。它影响着意识的深层。“我”是世界的产物；“你”也是世界的产物。而对于能够深刻洞察这一切的人来说，既没有“你”，也没有“我”。因此，这种深刻的洞察就是慈悲，慈悲即智慧。智慧会说，如果你想要一个结果，我无法给你，因为我并非结果的产物。慈悲会说，这种状态并非结果；因此，它没有原因。

Q : Does that mean there is no time either?

问：那是不是意味着也没有时间了？

K : No cause, no result, no time.

K：没有原因，就没有结果，也没有时间。

Ojai, California, March 24, 1977

加利福尼亚州奥海，1977年3月24日

#↩

PART 4

第四部分

You Are the World

你就是世界

In the last two decades of his life, Krishnamurti continued to divide his time between India, Europe, and the United States, giving public talks, holding dialogues with small groups, and meeting with individuals. An extremely important feature of this period were the gatherings at Saanen, in Switzerland. Held for twenty-five consecutive years, these were perhaps the strongest international focus of his work.

在克里希那穆提生命的最后二十年里，他继续往返于印度、欧洲和美国之间，发表公开演讲，与小团体对话，并与个人会面。这一时期一个极其重要的特征是在瑞士萨南举行的聚会。这些聚会连续举办了二十五年，或许是他工作中最具国际影响力的一次。

Krishnamurti’s life for over sixty years was always public; except for brief periods of illness and withdrawal for rest, his talks and meetings continued until his death in Ojai, California, in February 1986. In all that time the message of his talks was in essence as it had been in the early years: Truth is a pathless land; each of us represents all humanity and one needs to be a light to oneself, free of all authority. In conveying these teachings, Krishnamurti explored the abiding themes of thought, time, suffering, death, space, silence, and the sacred. In his talks and writings too, he touched, sometimes almost reluctantly because it might become stimulation or escape, on the inner wellspring of his life’s work.

克里希那穆提六十余年的一生始终与公众保持着密切联系；除了短暂的病痛和隐居休息之外，他的演讲和聚会一直持续到1986年2月在加州奥海去世。在他漫长的一生中，他演讲的核心信息与早年一样：真理是一片没有路径的土地；我们每个人都代表着全人类，每个人都需要成为自己的光，摆脱一切权威的束缚。在传达这些教义的过程中，克里希那穆提探讨了思想、时间、苦难、死亡、空间、寂静和神圣等永恒的主题。在他的演讲和著作中，他也触及了他毕生事业的内在源泉，有时他几乎是勉强地触及这一点，因为他担心这会成为一种刺激或逃避。

Krishnamurti provided a religious language that was extremely appropriate for the twentieth century. Ranging from the poetic to the meticulously precise, this language conveys nuances and insights for which previously accepted “mystical” language was frequently inadequate. From the beginning of his life until the end, his talks—remarkable in their range and universality—were always a process of joint exploration.

克里希那穆提提供了一种极其契合二十世纪的宗教语言。这种语言兼具诗意和严谨，能够传达以往被普遍接受的“神秘主义”语言往往难以表达的细微差别和深刻见解。从他生命的开始到结束，他那些涵盖范围广泛、普世性极强的演讲，始终是一个共同探索的过程。

When Mary Lutyens, one of Krishnamurti’s biographers, asked him to convey the core of his message, he did so, and this one page summation, The Core of Krishnamurti’s Teaching , begins the final part of the book. It is followed by selections from public talks given in Ojai, California; Saanen, Switzerland; Brockwood Park, England; New Delhi; and Washington, D.C.

当克里希那穆提的传记作者之一玛丽·卢蒂恩斯请他阐述其教义的核心时，他照做了。这篇题为《克里希那穆提教义的核心》的单页总结，开启了本书的最后一部分。紧随其后的是他在加利福尼亚州奥海、瑞士萨嫩、英国布罗克伍德公园、新德里和华盛顿特区等地发表的公开演讲选段。

This part of the book expresses the work of the final decade of his long life. The themes are quintessentially what they have been since the outset; there is, however, an evolution of expression, which underpins the relevance of Krishnamurti’s teachings for all time.

本书的这一部分展现了克里希那穆提漫长生命中最后十年的创作成果。其主题本质上与他早期作品并无二致；然而，表达方式却有所演变，这恰恰凸显了克里希那穆提教义的永恒价值。

#↩

THE CORE OF KRISHNAMURTI’S TEACHING

克里希那穆提教义的核心

The core of Krishnamurti’s teaching is contained in the statement he made in 1929 when he said “Truth is a pathless land.” Man cannot come to it through any organization, through any creed, through any dogma, priest, or ritual, nor through any philosophical knowledge or psychological technique. He has to find it through the mirror of relationship, through the understanding of the contents of his own mind, through observation, and not through intellectual analysis or introspective dissection. Man has built in himself images as a sense of security—religious, political, personal. These manifest as symbols, ideas, beliefs. The burden of these dominates man’s thinking, relationships, and daily life. These are the causes of our problems, for they divide man from man in every relationship. His perception of life is shaped by the concepts already established in his mind. The content of his consciousness is this consciousness. This content is common to all humanity. The individuality is the name, the form, and superficial culture he acquires from his environment. The uniqueness of the individual does not lie in the superficial but in the total freedom from the content of consciousness.

克里希那穆提教义的核心蕴含在他1929年的那句话中：“真理是一片没有路的土地。”人无法通过任何组织、任何信条、任何教条、任何祭司或任何仪式，也无法通过任何哲学知识或心理学技巧抵达真理。他必须通过人际关系的镜子，通过理解自身内心的内容，通过观察，而非通过理性的分析或内省式的剖析，来寻找真理。人会在自身内部构建各种意象，以此获得安全感——宗教的、政治的、个人的。这些意象以符号、观念和信仰的形式显现。这些意象的重负主宰着人的思想、人际关系和日常生活。它们正是我们问题的根源，因为它们在每一种关系中都将人与人分隔开来。他对生活的感知是由他头脑中已建立的概念塑造的。他意识的内容就是这种意识本身。这种内容是全人类共通的。而所谓的个性，则是他从环境中习得的名称、形式和肤浅的文化。个体的独特性不在于外表，而在于完全摆脱意识内容的束缚。
