Freedom is not a reaction; freedom is not choice. It is man’s pretense that because he has choice he is free. Freedom is pure observation without motive; freedom is not at the end of the evolution of man, but lies in the first step of his existence. In observation one begins to discover the lack of freedom. Freedom is found in the choiceless awareness of our daily existence.

自由并非一种反应，也并非一种选择。人类自以为拥有选择权就意味着自由，这只是一种错觉。真正的自由是纯粹的、不带任何动机的观察；自由并非人类进化的终点，而是存在于其存在的起点。在观察中，人们开始发现自由的缺失。自由存在于我们对日常存在的无选择的觉知之中。

Thought is time. Thought is born of experience, of knowledge, which are inseparable from time. Time is the psychological enemy of man. Our action is based on knowledge and, therefore, time, so man is always a slave to the past.

思想即时间。思想源于经验和知识，而经验和知识又与时间密不可分。时间是人类心理上的敌人。我们的行动基于知识，因此也基于时间，所以人类始终是过去的奴隶。

When man becomes aware of the movement of his own consciousness he will see the division between the thinker and the thought, the observer and the observed, the experiencer and the experience. He will discover that this division is an illusion. Then only is there pure observation, which is insight without any shadow of the past. This timeless insight brings about a deep radical change in the mind.

当人觉察到自身意识的流动时，他便会看清思考者与思想、观察者与被观察者、体验者与体验之间的割裂。他会发现，这种割裂不过是一种幻觉。唯有那时，才能拥有纯粹的观察，那是一种不带任何过往阴影的洞察。这种超越时间的洞察，会给心灵带来深刻而根本的改变。

Total negation is the essence of the positive. When there is negation of all those things which are not love—desire, pleasure—then love is, with its compassion and intelligence.

彻底的否定是肯定的本质。当所有非爱的事物——欲望、快乐——都被否定时，爱就存在了，它带着慈悲和智慧。

London, October 21, 1980

伦敦，1980年10月21日

#↩

TOTAL ACTION WITHOUT REGRET

全力以赴，毫无悔意

1

Thought has created this world, the world of politics, the world of economics, the world of business, of social morality and all the religious structures. All our problems and all our desires to find answers to problems are within that consciousness, within the field that thought has created. So thought is trying to find answers to the mess it has made in our personal relationships, in our relationship with the community. Even your meditations, even your gods, your Christs, and your Buddhas are the creations of thought, which is matter, which can only operate within the field of time. We think that through thought, through will, through ambition, through drive and aggression, through substituting new religions for the old traditions, we can solve all the problems of personal relationship.

思想创造了这个世界，政治的世界、经济的世界、商业的世界、社会道德的世界以及所有宗教结构。我们所有的问题以及我们寻求答案的渴望都存在于这种意识之中，存在于思想所创造的领域之中。因此，思想试图为它在我们人际关系、我们与社群的关系中所造成的混乱寻找答案。甚至你的冥想，甚至你的神灵、你的基督和你的佛陀，都是思想的产物，而思想本身就是物质，它只能在时间的场域中运作。我们认为，通过思想、通过意志、通过野心、通过动力和侵略性，通过用新的宗教取代旧的传统，我们就能解决所有人际关系的问题。

Is there an answer to all the problems through the operation of thought? If thought will give no answer to all the problems, then what will?

思维活动能否解决所有问题？如果思维活动无法解决所有问题，那么什么才能解决？

What is consciousness? What is the operation of thought? All your meditations are in that area; all your pursuits of pleasure, fear, greed, envy, brutality, violence, are within that field. And thought is always endeavoring to go beyond that, asserting the ineffable, the unnamable, unknowable. The content of consciousness is consciousness. Your consciousness or another’s consciousness is its content. If it is born in India, then all the traditions, superstitions, hopes, fears, sorrows, anxieties, violence, sexual demands, aggression, the beliefs, dogmas, and creeds of that country are the content of its consciousness. Yet the content of consciousness is extraordinarily similar, whether one is born in the East or in the West.

什么是意识？什么是思维的运作？你所有的冥想都属于这个范畴；你对快乐、恐惧、贪婪、嫉妒、残暴和暴力的追求，也都在这个领域之内。而思维总是试图超越这个范畴，探寻那不可言喻、不可命名、不可知的事物。意识的内容就是意识本身。你的意识，或者他人的意识，就是它的内容。如果一个人出生在印度，那么印度的所有传统、迷信、希望、恐惧、悲伤、焦虑、暴力、性欲、侵略性，以及该国的信仰、教条和信条，都是他意识的内容。然而，无论一个人出生在东方还是西方，意识的内容都惊人地相似。

Look at your own consciousness, if you can. If you are brought up in a religious culture as a Christian, you believe in saviors, rituals, creeds, and dogmas on one side and, on the other side, you accept social immorality, wars, nationalities and their divisions that restrict economic expansion and deny consideration for others. The content of your consciousness is your personal unhappiness, your ambitions, your fears, your greeds, your aggressiveness, your demands, your loneliness, your sorrow, your lack of relationship with another, the isolation, frustration, confusion, misery. All that is consciousness whether you are of the East or the West—with variations, with joys, with more knowledge or less knowledge. Without that content, there is no consciousness as we know it.

如果可以，请审视一下你自己的意识。如果你成长于基督教的宗教文化中，一方面你相信救世主、仪式、信条和教条，另一方面你又接受社会不道德、战争、民族主义及其造成的分裂——这些都限制了经济发展，也剥夺了对他人的关怀。你意识的内容是你个人的不幸、你的野心、你的恐惧、你的贪婪、你的攻击性、你的要求、你的孤独、你的悲伤、你与他人关系的缺失、你的孤立、挫败、困惑和痛苦。无论你来自东方还是西方——尽管存在差异、喜悦、知识的多少不同——所有这些都构成了意识。没有这些内容，就没有我们所知的意识。

All education is based on the acquiring of more knowledge, more information, but functioning always within this area. Any political reformation based on a new philosophy is an invention still within that area. And so man goes on suffering, unhappy, lonely, fearful of death and of living, hoping for some great leader to come and take him out of his misery, a new savior, a new politician. In this confusion we are so irresponsible that out of our own disorder we are going to create tyrants, hoping they will create order within this area. This is what is happening outside of us and inside. Any leader we choose will be like us; we will not choose a leader who is totally different from us. That is the actual picture of our life: conflict inside and outside, struggle, opposition to one another, appalling selfishness.

一切教育都以获取更多知识、更多信息为基础，但始终局限于这一领域。任何基于新哲学的政治改革，也仍然是这一领域内的发明。因此，人类继续受苦，不幸、孤独，恐惧死亡和生存，期盼着一位伟大的领袖出现，将他们从苦难中解救出来，一位新的救世主，一位新的政治家。在这种混乱中，我们如此不负责任，以至于在自身的混乱中制造出暴君，希望他们能在这个领域内建立秩序。这就是我们内外正在发生的事情。我们选择的任何领袖都会与我们相似；我们不会选择一个与我们截然不同的领袖。这就是我们生活的真实写照：内外冲突、斗争、彼此对立、令人震惊的自私。

When there is so much sorrow in the world it is necessary to find out for oneself—through careful, slow, patient, hesitating investigation—if there is any other way of solving all these problems other than through the operation of thought. Is there an action which is not based on thought? Is there an intelligence which is not the function or the result of thought, which is not put together by thought, which does not come about through cunning, through friction and struggle, something entirely different?

当世间充满如此多的悲伤时，我们必须通过仔细、缓慢、耐心、犹豫的探究，亲自去发现，除了思维运作之外，是否还有其他方法可以解决所有这些问题。是否存在一种不基于思维的行动？是否存在一种智慧，它并非思维的功能或结果，并非由思维构建而成，并非通过狡诈、摩擦和斗争而产生，而是源于某种完全不同的事物？

To communicate one has to listen not just to the speaker but to the very action of listening. How does one listen? Does one ever really listen at all? Is one free to listen, or does one always listen with the cunning operations of thought, with interpretation or prejudice? One has to listen, if one is free, to the content of one’s consciousness, to listen not only to what is at the surface, which is fairly simple, but to the deeper layers of it. That means to listen to the totality of consciousness.

要进行有效沟通，不仅要倾听说话者，还要倾听倾听本身。如何倾听？我们真的能做到倾听吗？我们能否自由地倾听，还是总是带着狡黠的思维运作、诠释或偏见去倾听？如果我们能够自由地倾听，就必须倾听自身意识的内容，不仅要倾听表面的、相对简单的信息，还要倾听更深层次的信息。这意味着倾听意识的整体。

How does one listen to and look at one’s consciousness?

如何聆听和审视自己的意识？

The speaker was born in a certain country where he absorbed all the prejudices, the irrationalities and the superstitions, the beliefs, the class differences, as a Brahmin. There the young mind absorbed the tradition, the rituals, the extraordinary orthodoxy, and the tremendous discipline imposed by that group upon itself. And then he moves to the West; and again he absorbs from all that is there. The content of his consciousness is what has been put into it, what he has learned, what his thoughts are, and its own emotions, which thought recognizes. That is the content and the consciousness of this person. Within that area he has all the political, religious, personal, communal problems. All the problems are there. And not being able to solve them himself, he looks to books, to others, asking what to do, how to meditate, what to do about personal relationship with his wife, or his girlfriend, his parents. Should he believe in Jesus or in Buddha or the new guru who comes along with a lot of nonsense? He is searching for a new philosophy of life, a new philosophy of politics, and so on, all within this area.

演讲者出生在一个国家，作为一名婆罗门，他吸收了那里所有的偏见、非理性、迷信、信仰和阶级差异。在那里，他年轻的心灵吸收了传统、仪式、非凡的正统观念以及该群体强加于自身的严苛纪律。然后他移居西方；他又从那里吸收了一切。他意识的内容就是他所接受的一切，他所学到的一切，他的思想，以及他自身的情感——思想能够识别这些情感。这就是这个人的意识和内容。在这个范围内，他包含了所有政治、宗教、个人和社会问题。所有的问题都在那里。由于无法独自解决这些问题，他求助于书籍，求助于他人，询问该怎么做，如何冥想，如何处理与妻子、女友、父母的个人关系。他应该相信耶稣、佛陀，还是那个带着一堆胡言乱语而来的新上师？他正在探索一种新的生活哲学、一种新的政治哲学等等，所有这些都属于这个领域。

Man has done this from time immemorial, but there is no answer within that area. You may meditate for hours, sitting in a certain posture, breathing in a special way, but it is still within that area because you want something out of your meditation.

自古以来，人类就一直在这样做，但在这个领域内却找不到答案。你或许可以冥想数小时，保持某种特定的姿势，以特殊的方式呼吸，但这仍然局限于这个领域，因为你想要从冥想中获得某种东西。

So there is this content of consciousness: dull, stupid, traditional thought, recognizing all its emotions—otherwise they are not emotions. Always it is thought, which is the response of memory, knowledge, and experience operating. Now, can the mind look at it? Can you look at the operation of thought?

所以意识的内容是这样的：迟钝、愚钝、传统的思维，它能识别出所有的情绪——否则它们就不是情绪。它始终是思维，是记忆、知识和经验运作的结果。那么，心灵能审视它吗？你能审视思维的运作吗？

When you look, who is the observer who is looking at the content? Is it different from the content? This is really a very important question to ask, and to which to find an answer. Is the observer different from the content and, therefore, capable of changing it and going beyond it? Or is the observer the same as the content? First, look. If the observer—the “I” that looks, the “me” that looks—is different from the observed, then there is a division between the observer and the observed and, therefore, conflict: “I must not do this; I should do that”; “I must get rid of my particular prejudice,” and I adopt a new prejudice; “I must get rid of my old gods,” and I take on new gods. So when there is a division between the observer and the observed, there must be conflict. That is a principle, that is a law. So, do I observe the content of my consciousness as if I were an outsider looking in, altering the pieces and moving the pieces to different places? Or am I the observer, the thinker, the experiencer, the same as that which is observed, experienced, thought?

当你观察时，观察内容的观察者是谁？他与内容本身有何不同？这的确是一个非常重要的问题，需要我们去寻找答案。观察者是否与内容不同，因而能够改变内容并超越内容？或者，观察者与内容本身是同一回事？首先，让我们观察。如果观察者——那个观察的“我”，那个观察的“自我”——与被观察的对象不同，那么观察者与被观察对象之间就存在着隔阂，从而产生冲突：“我不能这样做；我应该那样做”；“我必须摒弃我固有的偏见”，结果我却接受了新的偏见；“我必须抛弃我旧的信仰”，结果我却接受了新的信仰。因此，当观察者与被观察对象之间存在隔阂时，冲突必然存在。这是一个原则，一条法则。那么，我是否像一个局外人那样观察我的意识内容，随意地改变其中的碎片，并将它们移动到不同的位置呢？或者，我作为观察者、思考者、体验者，与被观察、被体验、被思考的对象是同一回事吗？

If I look at the content of my consciousness as an outsider observing, then there must be conflict between what is observed and the observer. There must be conflict, and in that conflict we live: the “me” and the “not me,” “we” and “they.” If “I,” the observer, am different from anger, I try to control it, suppress it, dominate it, overcome it, and there is conflict. But is the observer different at all? Or is he essentially the same as the observed? If he is the same, then there is no conflict, is there? The understanding of that is intelligence. Then intelligence operates and not conflict.

如果我以旁观者的身份审视自己的意识内容，那么被观察的对象与观察者之间必然存在冲突。冲突必然存在，而我们正是在这种冲突中生存：“我”与“非我”，“我们”与“他们”。如果作为观察者的“我”与愤怒不同，我就会试图控制它、压制它、支配它、克服它，于是冲突就产生了。但是，观察者真的与被观察的对象不同吗？或者，他本质上与被观察的对象相同？如果他与被观察的对象相同，那么就不会有冲突，对吗？理解这一点就是智慧。如此一来，智慧而非冲突便开始发挥作用。

It would be a thousand pities if you did not understand this simple thing. Man has lived in conflict. He wants peace through conflict. And there can never be peace through conflict; however many armaments you may have against another’s equally strong armaments, there will never be peace. Only when intelligence operates will there be peace, the intelligence that comes when one understands that there is no division between the observer and the observed. The insight into that very fact, that very truth, brings this intelligence.

如果你不明白这个简单的道理，那将是莫大的遗憾。人类生活在冲突之中，渴望通过冲突获得和平。然而，和平永远不可能通过冲突实现；无论你拥有多少武器，即使对方也拥有同样强大的武器，和平也永远不会到来。只有当智慧发挥作用时，和平才会出现；这种智慧源于理解观察者与被观察者之间并无界限。正是对这一事实、这一真理的洞察，带来了这种智慧。

This is a very serious thing, for then you will see that you have no nationality; you may have a passport but you have no nationality. You have no gods. There is no outside authority, nor inward authority. The only authority then is intelligence. It is not the cunning intelligence of thought, which is mere knowledge operating within a certain area, and that is not intelligence.

这是一件非常严重的事情，因为你会发现自己没有国籍；你或许有护照，但你没有国籍。你没有神明。既没有外在权威，也没有内在权威。那时唯一的权威就是智慧。但这并非狡猾的思维智慧，思维智慧仅仅是在特定领域内运作的知识，那并非真正的智慧。

So this is the first thing to understand when you look at your consciousness: the division between the thinker and the thought, between the observer and the observed, between the experiencer and the experienced is false, for they are one. There is no thinker if you do not think. Thought has created the thinker. That is the first thing to understand, to have an insight into the truth of, the fact of, as palpable as you sitting there, so that there is no conflict between the observer and the observed.

所以，当你审视自己的意识时，首先要明白的是：思考者与思想、观察者与被观察者、体验者与被体验者之间的界限是虚假的，因为它们本为一体。如果你不思考，就没有思考者。思想创造了思考者。这是首先要理解的，要洞察到这个真理，这个事实，它如此真切，就像你坐在那里一样触手可及，这样观察者与被观察者之间就不会存在冲突。

So, what is the content of your consciousness, the hidden as well as the open? Can you look at it— and not make an effort ?

那么，你的意识内容是什么？包括隐藏的和显露的？你能直视它而不费力吗？

You can find this out, not just sitting there, but in your relationships. That is the mirror in which you will see, not by closing your eyes, or by going off into the woods and thinking up some dreams. In the actual fact of your relationship with man, woman, your neighbor, your politician, your gods, your gurus, you will observe your reactions, your attitudes, your prejudices, your images, your constant groping. The content is in that. What you are doing now is merely ploughing, and you can only sow when you observe your relationships and see what actually is taking place. You can look as much as you like and begin to distinguish various qualities and tendencies, but if you look as an observer different from the observed then you are bound to create conflict and, therefore, further suffering. When you have an insight, see the truth that the observer is the observed, then conflict ceases altogether. Then a totally different kind of energy comes into operation.

你无需静坐冥想，就能在人际关系中找到答案。这才是你真正能看清自己的镜子，而不是闭上双眼，或是遁入林中冥想。在你与男人、女人、邻居、政客、神明、导师的真实关系中，你会观察到自己的反应、态度、偏见、形象以及持续不断的摸索。答案就在其中。你现在所做的只是耕耘，只有当你观察你的人际关系，看清正在发生的一切时，才能真正播种。你可以尽情观察，并开始区分各种特质和倾向，但如果你以一个与被观察者不同的观察者视角去看待事物，那么你必然会制造冲突，从而带来更多的痛苦。当你获得洞察力，看清观察者本身就是被观察者的真相时，冲突便会彻底消失。那时，一种截然不同的能量便会开始运作。

There are different kinds of energy. There is physical energy from good food; there may be energy created by emotionalism, sentimentality; there is energy created by thought through various conflicts and tensions. Within that field of energy we have lived, and we are still trying to find greater energy within that field to solve our problems. There is a different kind of energy, or the continuation of this energy in a totally different form, when the mind is operating completely, not in the field of thought but intelligently.

能量有多种类型。有来自美食的物质能量；有源于情感和感伤的能量；也有源于各种冲突和紧张的思考的能量。我们一直生活在这些能量场中，并且仍在努力从中寻找更大的能量来解决我们的问题。当心智完全脱离思维的局限，转而以智慧的方式运作时，就会出现另一种能量，或者说，这种能量以一种截然不同的形式延续下来。

Can the mind observe its content without any choice as to the content, not choosing any part of the content, any part of the piece, but observing totally? Now, how is it possible to observe totally? When I look at a map of France, as I come from England and cross the Channel, I see the road leading to Gstaad. I can tell the mileage, I can see the direction. All that is very simple because it is marked on the map and I follow it. In doing that, I do not look at any other part of the map; I know the direction in which I want to go and that direction excludes all others. In the same way, a mind that is seeking in a given direction does not see the whole. If I want to find something that I think is real, then the direction is set and I follow that direction and my mind is incapable of seeing the totality. Now, when I look at the content of my consciousness, which is the same as yours, I have set a direction—to go beyond it. A movement in a particular direction, seeking a certain pleasure, not wanting to do this or that, makes one incapable of seeing the whole. If I am a scientist, I see only in a certain direction. If I am an artist, there again. If I have a certain talent or gift, I see only a certain direction. So the mind is incapable of seeing the totality and the immensity of that totality if there is a movement in a particular direction. So can the mind have no direction at all?

心灵能否在不选择任何内容的情况下观察其内容，不选择内容的任何部分，不选择作品的任何片段，而是整体地观察？那么，如何才能做到整体地观察呢？当我从英国穿越英吉利海峡来到法国，看到一张法国地图时，我能看到通往格施塔德的道路。我可以知道里程，也能看到方向。这一切都很简单，因为地图上已经标明，我只需沿着它走。这样做时，我不会去看地图的其他部分；我只知道自己要去的方向，而这个方向排除了所有其他方向。同样，一颗朝着特定方向寻求的心灵也无法看到整体。如果我想找到我认为真实存在的东西，那么方向就被设定好了，我沿着这个方向走，我的心灵就无法看到整体。现在，当我观察我的意识内容时——它和你的意识内容一样——我已经设定了一个方向——超越它。朝着某个特定方向前进，追求某种特定的快乐，不愿做这做那，都会使人无法看到整体。如果我是一名科学家，我的视野就只能局限于某个方向。如果我是一名艺术家，情况也是如此。如果我拥有某种才能或天赋，我的视野也只能局限于某个方向。因此，如果思维朝着某个特定方向发展，就无法看到整体及其浩瀚无垠。那么，思维是否可能完全没有方向呢？

This is a difficult question. Please listen to it. Of course, the mind has to have direction when I go from here to the house, or when I have to drive a car, when I have to perform some technical function; but I am talking of a mind that understands the nature of direction and, therefore, is capable of seeing the whole. When it sees the whole, it can then also operate in direction. If I have the whole picture in mind, then I can take in the detail; but if my mind only operates in details, then I cannot take in the whole. If I am concerned with my opinions, with my anxieties, with what I want to do, with what I must do, I cannot see the whole. Obviously. If I come from India with my prejudices, superstitions, and traditions, I cannot see the whole. So can the mind be free of direction? Which does not mean that it is without direction. When it operates from the whole, the direction becomes clear, very strong and effective; but when the mind only operates in a direction according to the pattern it has set for itself, then it cannot see the whole.

这是一个难题，请仔细听我说。当然，当我从这里回家，或者开车，或者执行某些技术性操作时，我的思维需要方向；但我说的是理解方向本质的思维，因此，它能够看到整体。当它看到整体时，它就能有方向地运作。如果我心中有整体的画面，我就能注意到细节；但如果我的思维只关注细节，我就无法看到整体。如果我只关注我的观点、我的焦虑、我想做什么、我必须做什么，我就看不到整体。显而易见。如果我带着我的偏见、迷信和传统从印度来到这里，我就看不到整体。那么，思维可以摆脱方向吗？但这并不意味着它没有方向。当它从整体出发运作时，方向就会变得清晰、强大而有效；但是，当思维只按照自己设定的模式朝某个方向运作时，它就看不到整体。

There is the content of my consciousness. The content makes my consciousness. Now, can the mind look at it as a whole? Can it just look without any direction, without any judgment, without any choice? That implies no observer at all, for the observer is the past. Can it look with that intelligence which is not put together by thought? For thought is the past. Do it. It requires tremendous discipline; not the discipline of suppression, control, imitation, or conformity, but a discipline that is an act in which the truth is seen. The operation of truth creates its own action, which is discipline.

这就是我意识的内容。内容造就了我的意识。现在，心智能否将它视为一个整体？它能否不带任何方向、不带任何评判、不带任何选择地去观察？这意味着根本不存在观察者，因为观察者即是过去。它能否以那种并非由思维构建的智慧去观察？因为思维即是过去。去做吧。这需要极大的自律；并非压抑、控制、模仿或顺从的自律，而是一种在行动中得以洞察真理的自律。真理的运作会创造它自身的行动，而这行动本身就是一种自律。

Can your mind look at its content when you talk to another, in your gestures, in the way you walk, in the way you sit and eat, in the way you behave? Behavior indicates the content of your consciousness, whether you are behaving according to pleasure, reward, or pain, which are part of your consciousness. The psychologists say that, so far, man has been educated on the principle of punishment and reward, hell and heaven. Now, they say that we must be educated only on the principle of reward, that we must not punish but reward—which is the same thing. To see the absurdity of punishment and reward is to see the whole. When you see the whole, intelligence functions when you act, and you are not then behaving according to reward or punishment.

当你与人交谈、你的手势、你的走路方式、你的坐姿、你的饮食方式、你的一举一动时，你的思维能否审视自身的内容？行为反映了你意识的内容，无论你的行为是出于愉悦、奖励还是痛苦——这些都是你意识的一部分。心理学家认为，迄今为止，人类一直被灌输着奖惩、天堂与地狱的观念。而现在，他们说我们应该只接受奖励的教育，我们应该奖励而非惩罚——这二者本质上是一回事。看清奖惩的荒谬之处，才能看清事物的全貌。当你看清全貌时，你的行为中便会展现出智慧，而你的行为也不再受奖惩的驱使。

Behavior exposes the content of your consciousness. You may hide yourself behind a polished behavior, a behavior that is very carefully drilled, but such behavior is merely mechanical. From that arises another question: Is the mind entirely mechanical, or is there any portion of the brain that is not mechanical at all?

行为揭示了你意识的内容。你或许能用一套精心修饰、反复练习的举止来掩饰自己，但这种举止仅仅是机械的。由此引出了另一个问题：思维完全是机械的吗？或者说，大脑中是否存在完全非机械的部分？

To go over what has been said: Outside of us, in the political world, in the economic world, in the religious world, in the social world, and so on, mankind is searching. There are gods, new gurus, new leaders. And when you observe all this very clearly you see that man is functioning within the field of thought. Thought, essentially, is never free. Thought is always old because thought is the response of memory as knowledge and experience. Thought is matter. It is of the material world, and thought is trying to escape from that material world into a nonmaterial world. But trying to escape into the nonmaterial world by thought is still material. We have all the moral, social, and economic problems of the individual and the collective. The individual is essentially, intrinsically, part of the collective. The individual is not different from the collective; he may have different tendencies, different occupations, different moods, and so on, but he is intrinsically part of the culture, which is society.

回顾一下之前所说的：在我们之外，在政治界、经济界、宗教界、社会界等等领域，人类都在不断探索。有神灵，有新的导师，有新的领袖。当你清晰地观察这一切时，你会发现人类是在思想的领域中运作的。思想本质上永远无法摆脱。思想总是陈旧的，因为思想是对记忆（即知识和经验）的回应。思想是物质的。它属于物质世界，而思想试图从物质世界逃逸到非物质世界。但是，试图通过思想逃逸到非物质世界仍然是物质的。我们面临着个人和集体的所有道德、社会和经济问题。个人本质上是集体的一部分。个人与集体并无本质区别；他可能有不同的倾向、不同的职业、不同的情绪等等，但他本质上是文化（即社会）的一部分。

Now, those are facts as to what is going on about us. The facts as to what is going on inside us are very much the same. We are trying to find an answer to the major problems of our human life through the operation of thought—thought which the Greeks imposed upon the West, with their political philosophy, with their mathematics, and so on. Thought has not found an answer and it never will. So we must go then into the whole structure of thought and the content that it has created as consciousness. We must observe the operation of thought in relationship, in our daily life. That observation implies having an insight as to whether it is a fact that the observer is different from the observed, for if there is a difference there must inevitably be conflict, just as there is between two ideologies. Ideologies are the inventions of thought, conditioned by the culture in which they have developed.

以上是关于我们周围发生的事情的事实。关于我们内心发生的事情的事实也大同小异。我们试图通过思维的运作来寻找人类生活中重大问题的答案——这种思维方式是希腊人通过他们的政治哲学、数学等等强加给西方的。然而，思维并没有找到答案，也永远不会找到。因此，我们必须深入探究思维的整个结构，以及它作为意识所创造的内容。我们必须观察思维在日常生活中的运作方式。这种观察意味着要洞察观察者与被观察者之间是否存在差异，因为如果存在差异，就必然会产生冲突，正如两种意识形态之间存在冲突一样。意识形态是思维的产物，受到其所处文化环境的制约。

Now, can you, in your daily life, observe this? In such observation you will find out what your behavior is, whether it is based on the principle of reward and punishment—as most of our behavior is, however polished and refined. From that observation one begins to learn what real intelligence is. Not the intelligence that is obtained from a book, or out of experience; that is not intelligence at all. Intelligence has nothing whatsoever to do with thought. Intelligence operates when the mind sees the whole, the endless whole—not my country, my problems, my little gods, my meditations. It sees the whole implication of living. And this quality of intelligence has its own tremendous energy.

现在，你能在日常生活中观察到这一点吗？通过这样的观察，你会发现自己的行为是怎样的，它是否基于奖惩原则——尽管我们大多数的行为，无论多么精雕细琢，都是如此。从这种观察中，人们开始了解真正的智慧是什么。不是从书本或经验中获得的智慧；那根本不是智慧。智慧与思维毫无关系。智慧在心灵洞察整体，那无尽的整体时发挥作用——不是我的国家，我的问题，我的小神，我的冥想。它洞察生活的全部意义。而这种智慧本身就蕴含着巨大的能量。

Saanen, July 14, 1974

萨嫩，1974年7月14日

2

We were saying that the world outside us and inside us is in a chaotic condition and that the politicians, the leaders, the priests, are all trying to solve our problems in the field of thought. This has been so for centuries upon centuries. But one sees that suffering still goes on: there are endless wars, governments are more or less corrupt, politicians play a crooked game, and ideologies and systems have taken the place of morality and intelligence. Seeing all this, objectively, without any prejudice, without being dedicated to any particular ideology or any system, one observes that thought is divisive and that excellence in thought is not necessarily excellence in conduct.

我们曾说过，我们身处的世界和我们内心的世界都处于混乱状态，政治家、领袖、神职人员都在试图从思想层面解决我们的问题。这种情况已经持续了数个世纪。然而，我们看到苦难仍在继续：战争无休止，政府或多或少腐败，政客们玩弄权术，意识形态和制度取代了道德和智慧。客观地看待这一切，不带任何偏见，不偏袒任何特定的意识形态或制度，就会发现思想本身具有分裂性，思想上的卓越并不一定等同于行为上的卓越。

We are concerned with something that one has to go through, investigate deeply, as deeply as one can, verbally and nonverbally. That demands a great deal of care, affection and consideration, a sense of intimate communication with each other. It demands that you and I share the thing together. You share it not by just listening to a series of words or ideas or concepts—because they are not ideas or concepts with which to agree or disagree—but rather, by really taking part in it with all your heart, with all your mind, with all your energy. Such serious concern and commitment do reveal a great deal, not only the source of our thought and its mischief, but also the source of action.

我们所关注的是需要亲身经历、深入探究的事情，要尽可能深入地探究，无论是口头的还是非口头的。这需要极大的关怀、爱意和体贴，需要彼此之间亲密的交流。它要求你我共同参与其中。这种参与并非仅仅是聆听一系列的词语、想法或概念——因为它们并非需要赞同或反对的想法或概念——而是要真正地、全心全意、全神贯注地投入其中。这种认真的关注和投入确实能揭示很多东西，不仅揭示我们思想的根源及其弊端，也揭示行动的源泉。

We live by action; we cannot possibly avoid action. You may withdraw from the world into a monastery, take vows, but that is still action. You may specialize in a particular field which gives you an opportunity for your talent and a career—that is action. Action is also in relationship between you and another. The movement of life is action.

我们因行动而活；我们不可能避免行动。你可以遁世隐居，发愿遁世，但这仍然是行动。你可以专攻某个领域，从而获得发挥才能和发展事业的机会——这也是行动。行动也存在于你与他人的关系之中。生命的律动即是行动。

Thought, in civilizations so far, has produced actions which are conflicting, contradictory, opposing; therefore, breeding great mischief and misery. Is excellence in thought and, therefore, action, possible? Or is there always conflict when thought produces action? This is your life, and if you would understand your life, your behavior, your conduct, your relationship, your confusion, to find out what to do so that action is excellent at all levels, then you must ask if there is an action that is not fragmented by thought. Thought is fragmentary in its very nature and yet through thought you are trying to find at all levels an action which will not be contradictory, which will not be regretful, which will be whole, total, complete. Is there an action that is supremely excellent yet is not based on the movement of thought?

迄今为止，人类文明中的思想所产生的行动往往是相互冲突、自相矛盾、彼此对立的，因此滋生了巨大的祸患和苦难。思想乃至行动的卓越是否可能？或者说，思想产生行动时，冲突是否总是存在的？这是你的人生，如果你想理解你的人生、你的行为、你的举止、你的人际关系、你的困惑，从而找到在各个层面都追求卓越的行动之道，那么你必须扪心自问：是否存在一种不受思想割裂的行动？思想的本质就是割裂的，然而你却试图通过思想在各个层面找到一种不自相矛盾、不令人后悔、完整、圆满的行动。是否存在一种至臻至善，却并非基于思想活动的行动呢？

Why is thought—upon which we live, upon which our whole social morality is dependent—divisive? Thought is matter. It is the response of the past. It creates the movement of time as yesterday, today, and tomorrow. Thought has its source and root in the past and, having its root in the past, it must create time as movement. One sees that by its very nature, by its very function and structure, thought has its being essentially in the past. It lives in tradition, in the accumulated knowledge that society has acquired, and in the great accumulation of scientific knowledge, all of which is in the past. Thought is essentially a movement from the past. Therefore, it must be divisive. It can pretend, or speculate, or conceive, that it is beyond time; it can imagine a timeless state, but it is still thought. It can pretend that it is going beyond its own limits, but it is still thought. So thought creates a boundary of time around itself, and that is the factor of division.

为什么思想——我们赖以生存、我们整个社会道德赖以维系的——会造成分裂？思想是物质，是对过去的回应，它创造了时间的流逝，即昨天、今天和明天。思想的源泉和根基在于过去，而既然根基在于过去，它就必然创造时间的流逝。我们可以看到，思想的本质、功能和结构都决定了它的存在本质上是在过去。它存在于传统之中，存在于社会积累的知识之中，存在于浩瀚的科学知识之中，而所有这些都属于过去。思想本质上是从过去出发的运动。因此，它必然是分裂的。它可以假装、推测或设想自己超越时间；它可以想象一个永恒的状态，但它仍然是思想。它可以假装自己超越了自身的局限，但它仍然是思想。因此，思想在自身周围创造了一个时间的边界，而这正是分裂的根源。

We are all reared in the field of thought. Education is a movement in thought, the getting of more and more knowledge, the refinement of thought. Thought, being divisive, whatever action it creates must be fragmented, which therefore gives rise to conflict. This is a principle. Man has lived, historically as we know it, in a series of crises and responses, which inevitably breed more conflict. One sees it in the modern world. There is a crisis: thought tries to answer it and, in the very answering of it, more problems are created. One country supplies arms to another knowing well that that is going to create more trouble, and so on, and so on.

我们都是在思想的领域中成长起来的。教育是思想的运动，是获取更多知识、完善思想的过程。思想本身具有分裂性，它所产生的任何行动都必然是碎片化的，因此必然导致冲突。这是一个普遍规律。纵观历史，人类一直生活在一系列危机和应对之中，而这些危机和应对又不可避免地会滋生更多的冲突。在现代世界，我们便能看到这一点。危机出现，思想试图解决它，然而，在解决危机的过程中，却又制造了更多的问题。一个国家明知向另一个国家提供武器会造成更多麻烦，却仍然这样做，如此循环往复。

So can thought ever bring about an action that is total, whole, sane, not contradictory? Our life is contradictory: we live at different levels—at the business level, the family level, the scientific level, the religious level, or at the artistic level—each opposing the other, each specializing in his own department. Specialization becomes exclusive and, therefore, contradictory and, therefore, destructive. Thought, trying to be excellent in its action, specializes and brings about more conflict, more division. Each specialization has its own ambitious end; each career has its own reward, which is contradictory, opposed to affection, care, consideration, and love. Looking at it, one asks if there is an action that is whole, not fragmentary, an action in which there is no regret, no sense of fulfillment, no sense of frustration.

那么，思想真的能够促成一种完整、健全、理智且不自相矛盾的行动吗？我们的生活充满矛盾：我们生活在不同的层面——商业层面、家庭层面、科学层面、宗教层面或艺术层面——彼此对立，各自专注于自己的领域。专业化变得排他，因此也变得自相矛盾，进而造成破坏。思想力求在行动中做到卓越，却也因此走向专业化，带来更多的冲突和分裂。每一种专业化都有其雄心勃勃的目标；每一种职业都有其自身的回报，而这些回报本身就是矛盾的，与情感、关怀、体贴和爱相悖。由此看来，人们不禁要问：是否存在一种完整而非支离破碎的行动？是否存在一种行动，其中没有遗憾、没有成就感、也没有挫败感？

Is there such an action? That is what we are asking all our life, for whatever we do brings a certain pain, a certain confusion, or a certain reward in the pursuit of which we create more division. It is inevitable and natural and logical to ask if there is an action that is not born out of the movement of thought.

是否存在这样的行动？我们终其一生都在追问这个问题，因为我们所做的每一件事都会带来某种痛苦、某种困惑，或者某种回报，而追求这些回报的过程中，我们又会制造更多的分裂。因此，我们必然会问：是否存在一种行动并非源于思想的流动？这个问题既是不可避免的，也是自然而然的，更是合乎逻辑的。

I will go into something which may appear to be different, but which is not. We need energy. We have physical energy, emotional energy, the energy of hate, the energy of lust, the energy of great passion, and the energy of great tension that is brought about through the sense of frustration, division, and lack of fulfillment. As one gets older, the body becomes rather worn out, disease and pain come, and energy wastes away. Most of our energy is the product of conflict—I am this, I should be that—or of fright and the aggressive desire to continue in a given direction. There is the energy that is brought about through commitment to an ideal—the whole communist world is based on that, from Lenin until now, destroying people by the millions to get what it thinks is right. That gives one tremendous energy. The saint, dedicated to an ideal, to a picture, to an imagination, to a formula, has an extraordinary energy. The idealists have an extraordinary energy. In any form of specialization, energy is required. The more you specialize, the more energy you have. This is what one sees not only in oneself but also outside.

我要谈的这个话题看似不同，实则不然。我们需要能量。我们有体力、情感能量、仇恨的能量、欲望的能量、激情的能量，以及因挫败感、分裂感和空虚感而产生的巨大紧张能量。随着年龄增长，身体日渐衰弱，疾病和疼痛接踵而至，能量也随之消磨殆尽。我们的大部分能量都源于冲突——“我是这样的，我应该是那样的”——或是恐惧以及执着于既定方向的强烈渴望。还有一种能量源于对理想的执着——整个共产主义世界正是建立在这种执着之上，从列宁到今天，为了实现其自认为的“正确”，不惜屠杀数百万人。这种执着赋予人巨大的能量。那些献身于理想、理想、理想、理想主义的圣人，拥有非凡的能量。理想主义者也拥有非凡的能量。任何形式的专业化都需要能量。你越是专业化，你的能量就越大。这不仅体现在自身，也体现在外部世界。

Thought creates its own energy. To produce such a marvelous machine as a submarine, one must have tremendous energy and cooperation, energy that is brought about through an idea, through organized thought. And this kind of energy is always—in the deep sense of that word—destructive, because it is divisive.

思想本身就能创造能量。要制造出潜艇这样精妙的机器，必须拥有巨大的能量和协作精神，而这种能量源于思想，源于有组织的思考。这种能量——从其深层含义来看——总是具有破坏性的，因为它会造成分裂。

Now, is there an energy that is not destructive, that is not divisive, that is not mechanical, not based on idea or a commitment to an ideology? Is there an energy that is not in any way involved in the field of time as thought, movement?

那么，是否存在一种不具破坏性、不具分裂性、不具机械性、不基于理念或意识形态的能量呢？是否存在一种与时间、思想、运动等领域完全无关的能量呢？

Life is action. In the very living, all relationship is action, movement in action. And that movement, that action, is based on thought. At present, all political, religious, social, and economic life, and moral relativism, are based on thought, which is divisive, contradictory, and breeding misery. Is there an action totally unrelated to all that? To find out, one must have energy. It is not mere intellectual energy, with all its accumulated knowledge, nor emotional energy, which is recognizable by thought and, therefore, still part of thought, but an energy that can bring about a total transformation in the very process of the mind. To inquire very deeply into whether there is an action that is not based on the movement of thought, you need a great deal of energy, not the energy of trying to find an end, not the energy that you have when you are moving in a particular direction, but the energy that can change the content of consciousness.

生命即行动。在生命本身之中，一切关系皆是行动，是行动中的运动。而这种运动，这种行动，都基于思想。如今，一切政治、宗教、社会和经济生活，以及道德相对主义，都基于分裂的、矛盾的、滋生苦难的思想。是否存在一种与这一切完全无关的行动？要找到答案，就必须拥有能量。这并非仅仅是积累了所有知识的智力能量，也并非能够被思想识别、因而仍属于思想范畴的情感能量，而是一种能够彻底改变心智运作过程的能量。要深入探究是否存在一种不基于思想运动的行动，你需要大量的能量，不是那种试图寻找终点的能量，也不是那种朝着特定方向前进的能量，而是那种能够改变意识内容的能量。

To put it differently, one knows what the content of one’s consciousness is—if one is at all awake and aware, attending to one’s behavior, watching, listening. The desire to change that content is a movement in a particular direction. That does give energy but it is divisive. Yet one realizes that the content must be totally changed because we cannot go on as we are unless we want to destroy the whole of humanity. The content makes consciousness. Therefore, when there is total transformation of the content there is a different kind of—I won’t call it consciousness—a different level altogether. To bring about that change, one needs tremendous energy.

换句话说，一个人如果保持清醒和觉察，关注自己的行为，观察和倾听，就能了解自己意识的内容。想要改变这种内容，就如同朝着某个特定方向前进。这种渴望固然能带来能量，但也具有分裂性。然而，人们意识到，意识的内容必须彻底改变，因为如果我们继续维持现状，最终只会毁灭整个人类。意识的内容构成了意识。因此，当意识的内容发生彻底转变时，就会出现一种不同的——我不会称之为意识——完全不同的层次。要实现这种转变，需要巨大的能量。

So there must be freedom from direction. Please see the logic of it, the sanity of it. There must be freedom from a conclusion. Although a conclusion may give one a great deal of energy, it is a kind of energy that is wasteful. The mind must be free of the response of thought. It must be free of ideals because they again have direction. The mind must be free of all the divisive movements of thought, as nationality, as race, as religion.

所以，我们必须摆脱方向的束缚。请理解其中的逻辑和道理。我们必须摆脱结论的束缚。虽然结论或许能给人带来巨大的能量，但这是一种浪费的能量。心灵必须摆脱思维的束缚。它必须摆脱理想的束缚，因为理想本身就带有方向性。心灵必须摆脱一切分裂性的思维模式，例如民族、种族和宗教。

Now, can your mind be free of all that? If it cannot, then do what you will—stand on your head for ten thousand years, or meditate sitting in a posture breathing rightly for another ten thousand years—you will never find the other.

现在，你的心能摆脱这一切吗？如果不能，那么无论你做什么——倒立一万年，或者以正确的姿势静坐呼吸冥想一万年——你也永远找不到另一种境界。

So, can the mind see how stupid, how unintelligent, ideals are? Can it see the truth of it, not just say that they are wrong and put them away? For when you see the truth of it, you are free of it—not as when you logically or historically examine something, but as when you see something poisonous and you drop it. There is no conflict because intelligence sees that it is stupid to go the way of ideals. Can you free your mind from all this?

那么，人的心智能否看清那些理想是多么愚蠢、多么不明智？它能否洞悉其中的真相，而不仅仅是断言它们是错误的，然后弃之不顾？因为当你洞悉其中的真相时，你便能摆脱它——这并非像你从逻辑或历史的角度审视事物那样，而是像你发现有毒之物并将其丢弃那样。这其中并无冲突，因为理智会明白，追随理想是愚蠢的。你能否将你的心智从这一切中解脱出来？

Do you free it one thing at a time, or do you free it totally? If you free it one thing at a time, that takes energy—looking at how stupid nationality is and dropping it; looking at ideals and seeing that they do not lead anywhere, that they breed conflict, and dropping them. Will you free the mind layer by layer, which will take time, which will take analysis? Traditionally it is said that you must go step by step, that first you must get rid of this, control your body, breathe rightly. Not only traditional but modern psychology says to go step by step, analyze, tear away layer by layer. You can spend years until you die doing that. Will you go through that process taking long years? Now, is that not a wastage of energy? If it is, then how shall the mind empty itself of its content so that it has a totally different kind of energy, a totally different existence? Is there a way of looking at all this totally and, therefore, being totally free of it?

你是一点一点地释放它，还是彻底地释放它？如果一点一点地释放，那需要耗费精力——比如，看清民族主义的愚蠢并抛弃它；看清理想，意识到它们毫无意义，只会滋生冲突并抛弃它们。你会一层一层地释放心灵吗？这需要时间，需要分析。传统上说，你必须循序渐进，首先要摆脱这些束缚，控制你的身体，正确呼吸。不仅传统心理学如此，现代心理学也说要循序渐进，分析，一层一层地剥离。你可能会花上好几年，直到生命终结。你会经历这样一个耗时漫长的过程吗？这难道不是在浪费精力吗？如果是，那么心灵该如何清空自身的内容，从而拥有完全不同的能量，完全不同的存在方式呢？有没有一种方法可以全面地看待这一切，从而彻底地摆脱它呢？

The content of my mind is the content of your mind. The content of your consciousness is the content of my consciousness, slightly modified, with a little more or a little less color, a little more or a little less elaboration, more artistry and less something else, but more or less the same. The mind becomes aware of this and it says, “How can I be aware of the totality of it, not only of the conscious but the unconscious?” I know I can strip layer after layer, both of the conscious as well as of the unconscious; I know I can go through that process, taking time, analyzing, knowing the danger of analysis. I can do that. That is the traditional, accepted way to do this. And I see that that takes infinite time, because every step in analysis must be accurate, otherwise the next step will be corrupted by the previous analysis. So, each analysis must be complete, true, and final, otherwise I am lost. And who is the analyzer? Is not the analyzer the analyzed? So I see that that is not going to do a thing.

我的思想内容就是你的思想内容。你的意识内容就是我的意识内容，略有不同，色彩或多或少，细节或多或少，艺术性或少或多，但本质上大体相同。心灵意识到这一点后会问：“我如何才能意识到它的全部，不仅是意识层面，还有无意识层面？”我知道我可以一层层剥开意识和无意识；我知道我可以经历这个过程，花时间去分析，也明白分析的风险。我可以这样做。这是传统的、公认的方法。但我发现这需要无限的时间，因为分析的每一步都必须准确，否则下一步就会被之前的分析所误导。所以，每一次分析都必须完整、真实、最终，否则我就会迷失方向。那么，谁是分析者呢？分析者不就是被分析者吗？所以我明白，这样做毫无意义。

So what am I to do? What is my mind to do when it has seen the absurdity of this?

那我该怎么办？当我的大脑意识到这一切的荒谬之处后，它该如何应对？

Now, has it actually seen the absurdity of it, or does it imagine it has seen it because somebody has said that it is absurd? We are secondhand people, so am I accepting the authority of another when I say it is absurd? That is a verbal assertion without any reality. That acceptance has no validity; it does not produce results. So the mind discards authority, whether it is traditional or the authority I have cultivated out of my own desires and selfishness, my authority which asserts that I know. The mind totally discards authority. Not the authority of law, obviously, but the psychological authority of someone who tells you what to do because you are in confusion and look to somebody who will free you from that confusion, out of your disorder creating the authority. It is historically so. Wherever there is disorder, a man springs up and tyrannically brings about some kind of order, which is total disorder. So, can the mind put away authority because it sees the truth about it, the significance of it, the nature of it? Not just as a reaction against authority, as we do, because when you react against authority you are creating another authority. That is obvious.

那么，它真的看清了其中的荒谬之处吗？还是仅仅因为有人说它荒谬，就自以为看清了？我们都是二手信息，所以当我说它荒谬时，我是在接受他人的权威吗？那只是空洞的口头断言，没有任何现实意义。这种接受毫无效力，也无法产生任何结果。因此，心灵会摒弃权威，无论是传统的权威，还是我出于自身欲望和自私而培养的权威——那种声称自己无所不知的权威。心灵会彻底摒弃权威。显然，这里指的不是法律的权威，而是心理上的权威——那种在你迷茫困惑、寻求解脱、摆脱混乱时，告诉你该怎么做的人的权威。历史上的确如此。哪里有混乱，哪里就会有人出现，以暴君的方式强加某种秩序，而这种秩序本身就是彻底的混乱。那么，心灵真的能够因为看清了权威的真相、意义和本质而抛弃它吗？这不仅仅是对权威的一种反抗，因为我们通常都是这样做的，因为当你反抗权威时，你实际上是在创造另一种权威。这一点显而易见。

Can the mind, your mind, be free of the traditional approach of analysis, introspectively trying to improve? Because you see the truth of being free of authority; therefore, there is no guru, no savior, there are no steps through meditation to come upon something extraordinary. There is something extraordinary, but not through this way. Can the mind put away all this, deny all this, without any resistance? To do that you must look. You must look outwardly and inwardly; hear the music of the world and the discord of the world and the music inwardly and the discord outwardly, because both are the same. We are an intrinsic part of the world. To do this we require energy and this energy is not brought about by concepts, by words. This energy comes when you have insight into the disorder of a mind that functions mechanically in the movement of thought. So, no belief, no idea, no concept, no ideal, no commitment of any kind in that field. Then, through negation of what is false—not through resistance or reaction to the false—through choiceless rejection of what is false, you have a different kind of energy.

你的心智，能否摆脱传统的分析方法，不再内省地试图自我提升？因为你看到了摆脱权威的真相；因此，没有上师，没有救世主，也没有通过冥想就能获得非凡境界的步骤。非凡之物确实存在，但并非通过这种方式。你的心智能否毫无抗拒地放下这一切，否定这一切？要做到这一点，你必须观察。你必须向外观察，向内观察；聆听世界的乐章，也聆听世界的纷争，聆听内在的乐章，聆听外在的纷争，因为二者本为一体。我们是世界不可分割的一部分。要做到这一点，我们需要能量，而这种能量并非来自概念，并非来自言语。这种能量源于你洞察到思维机械运作的紊乱状态。因此，在这个领域，你不应抱有任何信念、想法、概念、理想或任何形式的承诺。然后，通过否定虚假的事物——而不是通过抵抗或对虚假事物的反应——通过毫不犹豫地拒绝虚假的事物，你就能获得一种不同的能量。

It is simple enough. If you climb a mountain you must discard all the things that you have been carrying on the plain, you must put them all aside. It is far more important to understand attachment and the corrupting factors of thought—which are attachment and power, domination in different forms, the corruption of property and possessions—than to search, or to take vows.

道理很简单。如果你要攀登一座山，就必须抛弃所有在平原上携带的东西，把它们全部放下。理解执着和思想中腐蚀人心的因素——执着和权力、各种形式的支配、财产和所有物的腐化——远比寻觅或发誓重要得多。

Most of us are attached to possessions, whether it is an antique table, which you look after and polish very carefully, or a house, or a person, a group, an idea, or a particular form of experience. Why is the mind attached—to our looks, our hair, our worries? There are so many things we are attached to. Why? And then, knowing that possessions in any form are one of the major corrupting factors in life we say, “Do not possess, have a few clothes that are necessary, but do not possess, take a vow of nonpossession.” In that there is a lot of travail: “I want that; I must give it up, I have taken a vow.” Possessions corrupt, and we say we must be detached from possessions, so then there is all the conflict involved in that. Understanding attachment is much more important than detachment.

我们大多数人都有对物质的执着，无论是精心保养擦拭的古董桌，还是房子、人、群体、理念，甚至是某种特定的体验。为什么我们的心会执着于外貌、发型、忧虑？我们执着于如此之多的事物。为什么？明明知道任何形式的占有都是人生中主要的腐蚀因素之一，我们却说：“不要拥有，拥有几件必需的衣物即可，不要拥有太多，发誓不占有。”然而，这其中却充满了挣扎：“我想要那个；我必须放弃它，我已经发过誓了。”占有会使人腐化，而我们却说必须摆脱占有，于是，这其中就充满了矛盾。理解执着远比摆脱执着重要得多。

Why is there attachment? Not how to be detached, but why is the mind attached? Why are you attached to your house, to your wife, to your girl, to your ideas, to your meditations, to your systems? Why? What would happen if you were not attached?

为什么会有执着？不是如何超脱，而是为什么心会执着？为什么你会执着于你的房子、你的妻子、你的女友、你的想法、你的冥想、你的各种体系？为什么？如果你不执着，会发生什么？

Attachment gives a certain occupation to the mind; you constantly think about something. The brain and the mind say, “I must be occupied with something”—with my god, with my sex, with my drink; “I must be occupied”—with the kitchen, or with some social order, or commune, or whatever it is. Out of this demand for occupation there is attachment, holding on to something. Why must the mind be so occupied? What would happen if it were not so occupied? Would it go astray? Would it disintegrate? Would it feel utterly naked, empty? Does the fear of that emptiness demand occupation and, therefore, give importance to the furniture, the book, the idea, and so on? It is out of the empty feeling and loneliness, from not being totally whole, that the mind is attached. Can the mind live, be vital, energetic, full of depth, without attachment? Of course it can.

执着赋予心灵某种占据；你会不断地思考某些事物。大脑和心灵会说：“我必须忙于某事”——我的神、我的性、我的酒；“我必须忙于”——厨房、某种社会秩序、公社，或者其他任何事物。正是出于这种对占据的需求，才产生了执着，执着于某些事物。为什么心灵必须如此忙碌？如果它不如此忙碌会怎样？它会误入歧途吗？它会瓦解吗？它会感到彻底赤裸、空虚吗？对这种空虚的恐惧是否促使我们寻求占据，从而赋予家具、书籍、想法等等以重要性？正是出于这种空虚感和孤独感，源于不完整的自我，心灵才产生了执着。没有执着，心灵还能存在吗？还能充满活力、精力充沛、富有深度吗？当然可以。

Is love attachment? Not that love is detachment. When love is attached or detached then it is painful, which we all know; we go through that ugly state.

爱是执着吗？并非说爱就是超脱。当爱变得执着或超脱时，都会带来痛苦，我们都知道这一点；我们都会经历那种痛苦的境地。

Power is another form of corruption—political power, religious power, power in the business world, power in the exercise of a certain talent that one has. When you dominate somebody, your cook or your servant, your wife or your husband, there is tremendous pleasure. That is another factor of corruption. That energy, which is so necessary to bring about a transformation in the content of consciousness, is dissipated in all these ways. Can you see all this as fact, as a dangerous fact? Not a relative danger, but a total danger for human beings.

权力是另一种形式的腐败——政治权力、宗教权力、商业权力、运用自身才能所获得的权力。当你支配他人时，无论是你的厨师、仆人、妻子还是丈夫，都会产生巨大的快感。这也是腐败的因素之一。那种对于意识内容转变至关重要的能量，却以各种方式被消耗殆尽。你能把这一切看作事实吗？一个危险的事实？不是相对的危险，而是对人类的全面危险。

Now, if you see that as real danger, as you would see the danger of a falling rock, you move away from it instantly and you are free of it. To observe this, you need a certain sensitivity, physical as well as psychological, and you cannot have this sensitivity if you are indulging in all kinds of things—drink, sex, overworking. So, if you are at all serious, if you give your attention, your care, your affection to this, then you will see for yourself that out of this freedom from the division that thought has created, there is another kind of energy, which is intelligence. That intelligence is not put together by thought. It is not the cunning intelligence of a politician or a priest or a businessman. It comes out of the freedom that is perceiving the falseness, the unreality of all that. Can your mind see it totally? It cannot see it totally if it has any direction at all.

如果你把那视为真正的危险，就像你看到落石的危险一样，你会立刻远离它，从而摆脱它。要做到这一点，你需要一定的敏感度，包括生理和心理上的敏感度。如果你沉溺于各种事物——饮酒、性爱、过度劳累——你就无法拥有这种敏感度。所以，如果你认真对待，如果你把注意力、关怀和爱都投入到这件事上，你就会亲眼看到，从这种摆脱思想所造成的分裂的自由中，会涌现出另一种能量，那就是智慧。这种智慧并非由思想构建而成。它不是政客、牧师或商人那种狡猾的智慧。它源于对一切虚假、不真实本质的觉察。你的头脑能完全看清这一点吗？如果它有任何方向性，就无法完全看清。

An intelligent mind acts in the field of thought intelligently, sanely, without resistance. It is free from the structure and implications of attachment, from the action of attachment, from the pursuit of power with all its complications, the ruthlessness of it. It sees the dividing process of thought, and seeing that clearly, totally, it has energy. That energy is intelligence. Having that energy, that intelligence, it can operate in the field of thought, not the other way round.

智慧的心灵在思维领域中以理智、清醒、无阻碍的方式运作。它不受执着结构及其影响，不受执着行为的束缚，不受对权力及其所有复杂纠葛和残酷无情的追求的影响。它洞察思维的分裂过程，并清晰、完整地认识到这一点，从而获得能量。这种能量就是智慧。拥有这种能量和智慧，它才能在思维领域中运作，而不是反过来被思维所束缚。

One can see that there is no division between the outside and the inside, it is an interrelationship. One sees that, and one also sees that one needs energy to transform the mind. So one discards everything that is wasteful, everything that is psychological, everything that breeds division and conflict within the mind. It can be done only when there is an observation of it, not a resistance to it. There is such observation only when the observer is the observed. The observer is the past, put together by thought in terms of experience, knowledge, memory, tradition; they are the essence of the observer. What it observes, which is the result of thought, is still thought. The chaos in the world, the misery, the starvation, the poverty, the brutality, the violence, the mess that is going on, the madness that is going on, is created by thought. And it is the observer who says, “I must change all that”—if he is at all intelligent, if he is at all awake and not concerned with his own little pattern of life. But is the observer different from what he observes? He is put together by thought also, so he is the observed. Now when the understanding of that takes place, not as a verbal statement but as a reality, conflict ceases and the mind goes beyond the limitations that thought has imposed on action.

人们可以看到，内外之间并无泾渭分明的界限，它们彼此相互关联。人们看到这一点，也看到，转变心智需要能量。因此，人们摒弃一切浪费的、一切心理层面的、一切滋生内心分裂与冲突的事物。唯有观察而非抗拒，才能做到这一点。而只有当观察者本身就是被观察者时，才能进行这样的观察。观察者是过去，是思想根据经验、知识、记忆和传统构建而成的；它们构成了观察者的本质。它所观察的事物，是思想的结果，仍然是思想。世间的混乱、苦难、饥饿、贫困、残暴、暴力、正在发生的混乱和疯狂，都是思想造成的。正是观察者会说：“我必须改变这一切”——如果他足够明智，如果他足够清醒，并且不执着于自己狭隘的生活模式。但是，观察者与他所观察的事物之间真的存在区别吗？他也是由思想构建而成，因此他也是被观察的对象。当人们理解到这一点时——不是将其视为口头陈述，而是将其视为一种现实——冲突便会停止，心灵也将超越思想对行动的限制。

Now can you do this? If you cannot, why not? Is it because you are indolent, lazy, indifferent, not only to your own sorrow, to your own suffering, to your own misery, but to the misery of millions of people, to what is going on in Russia, in India, and elsewhere? Are you totally indifferent to all that, because you want to find God, you want to meditate, you want to learn how to breathe properly, how to have the right kind of sexual relationship, and so on? If you are concerned with the whole of humanity, not just your neighbor or your wife but with the whole of humanity, then when you see that whole you can put the detail in order. But without the perception of the whole you cannot put the detail in order. The politicians, the analysts, the priests, fail to see this. It is only you and I, if we are utterly responsible, concerned, serious, committed, who will be able to meet these problems because we have seen the whole and, therefore, are extraordinarily alive and intelligent and yet able to function in detail.

现在你能做到吗？如果不能，为什么？是因为你懒惰、懈怠、冷漠吗？不仅对你自己的悲伤、痛苦和不幸漠不关心，也对千百万人的苦难漠不关心，对俄罗斯、印度和其他地方正在发生的事情漠不关心吗？你对这一切都完全漠不关心，仅仅因为你想寻找上帝，你想冥想，你想学习如何正确呼吸，如何拥有正确的性关系等等吗？如果你关心的是全人类，而不仅仅是你的邻居或妻子，而是全人类，那么当你看到这个整体时，你就能理清细节。但如果没有对整体的感知，你就无法理清细节。政客、分析家、牧师都看不到这一点。只有你我，如果我们完全负责、关心、认真、投入，才能应对这些问题，因为我们看到了整体，因此我们充满活力、智慧非凡，并且能够处理好细节。

Saanen, July 16, 1974

萨嫩，1974年7月16日

3

We have talked of understanding our actions, of our behavior and the content of consciousness. Unless we understand the nature and the structure of this consciousness in which we act, through which all our behavior and all our thinking takes place, it seems to me we shall always be floundering, confused, always living in constant battle within ourselves and outside. We shall never be able to find peace, a sense of deep inward tranquility. In a world that is getting madder and madder every day, where there is so much brutality, violence, deception, and chicanery, it is so necessary that all of us should understand this immense problem of living.

我们谈论过理解我们的行为、我们的举止以及意识的内容。除非我们理解我们行动所处的意识的本质和结构——我们所有的行为和思考都源于此——否则在我看来，我们将永远迷失方向，困惑不已，永远生活在内心和外部世界的持续斗争之中。我们将永远无法找到平静，无法获得深层的内心安宁。在这个日益疯狂的世界里，充斥着如此多的残暴、暴力、欺骗和诡计，我们每个人都必须理解这个关乎生存的巨大难题。

We are going to concern ourselves now with what is called materialism. Materialism means evaluating life as matter, matter in its movement and modification, also matter as consciousness and will. We have to go into it to find out if there is anything more than matter and if we can go beyond it. This is not merely an intellectual amusement and investigation but rather a deep inquiry as to whether our minds and our whole social, economic, and religious life is entirely material. Is all existence, including consciousness and will, the movement and modification of matter?

现在我们要探讨的是所谓的唯物主义。唯物主义意味着将生命视为物质，物质的运动和变化，以及作为意识和意志的物质。我们必须深入探究，才能发现是否存在超越物质的存在，以及我们是否能够超越物质。这并非仅仅是智力上的消遣和探索，而是对我们思想以及整个社会、经济和宗教生活是否完全由物质构成的深刻探究。一切存在，包括意识和意志，是否都是物质的运动和变化？

We are ruled by our senses—taste, smell, touch, and so on; they play a great part in our life. The brain, if you examine it, if you are rather aware of its activities, holds in its cells memory as experience and knowledge. What these cells hold is material; so thought, the capacity to think, is matter. And you can imagine, or construct through thought, as thought, “otherness”; that is to say, other than matter—but it is still matter as imagination. We know that we live in a material world, based on our sensations, desires, and emotions, and we construct a content of consciousness that is essentially the product of thought. We know that, if we do not just romanticize but go into it very deeply and seriously; yet, knowing that, we say there must be “otherness,” something beyond that. So thought begins to investigate “the other.” But when thought investigates “the other,” it is still material. It is important to understand this because we are all so romantically minded; all our religions are sentimental and romantic. Living in this very small field of materialism, we want to have something much greater beyond. That is a natural desire. So thought constructs a verbal or nonverbal structure of God, otherness, immensity, timelessness, and so on. But it is still the product of thought, so it is still material.

我们受感官支配——味觉、嗅觉、触觉等等；它们在我们的生活中扮演着重要角色。如果你仔细观察大脑，如果你对它的活动有所了解，就会发现大脑的细胞中储存着记忆，即经验和知识。这些细胞储存的是物质；因此，思想，即思考的能力，也是物质。你可以想象，或者说通过思想构建“他者”；也就是说，他者是物质之外的存在——但作为想象，它仍然是物质。我们知道我们生活在一个物质世界里，这个世界基于我们的感觉、欲望和情感，我们构建的意识内容本质上是思想的产物。我们知道这一点，如果我们不只是浪漫化地看待它，而是深入而严肃地去理解它；然而，即便如此，我们仍然认为必然存在“他者”，某种超越物质的东西。于是，思想开始探索“他者”。但当思想探索“他者”时，它仍然是物质的。理解这一点很重要，因为我们都如此浪漫；我们所有的宗教都充满了感伤和浪漫。生活在物质主义的狭小领域中，我们渴望拥有超越物质的更宏大的存在。这是一种自然的欲望。因此，思想构建了关于上帝、他者性、浩瀚、永恒等等的语言或非语言结构。但它仍然是思想的产物，因此仍然是物质的。

So thought creates the form outside, thinking that that form, that image, that prototype, is not material. But that form is the product of thought; the ideal is still the product of thought, so it is still material. If you go to India or elsewhere in the East, they will tell you they accept that, but they say there is a higher self, there is a superconsciousness, which dominates the material, or encloses the material—as in the West you have the soul. They call it by a Sanskrit word, Atman . But the Atman , the superconsciousness, the soul, is still the product of thought. Thought is matter; whatever its movements, inside, outside, in trying to go beyond itself, it is still material.

因此，思想创造了外在的形式，并认为这种形式、这种形象、这种原型并非物质性的。但这种形式是思想的产物；理想仍然是思想的产物，因此它仍然是物质性的。如果你去印度或东方其他地方，他们会告诉你他们接受这种观点，但他们会说存在一个更高的自我，一种超意识，它主宰着物质，或者说包含着物质——就像西方所说的灵魂一样。他们用梵语称之为“阿特曼”（Atman）。但阿特曼，超意识，灵魂，仍然是思想的产物。思想是物质；无论它在内在、外在，还是试图超越自身，它仍然是物质性的。

So the question arises: Is the mind mechanical? That is, in your mind, are your thoughts, your feelings, your reactions, your responsibilities, your relationships, your ways, your opinions, and so on, merely mechanical; that is, responding according to conditioning, according to environmental influence? If that is the totality of the mind, then we live in a tremendous, inescapable prison.

于是问题来了：心智是机械的吗？也就是说，你心中的思想、情感、反应、责任、人际关系、行为方式、观点等等，仅仅是机械的吗？仅仅是按照既定的条件反射和环境影响做出反应吗？如果这就是心智的全部，那么我们就生活在一个巨大的、无法逃脱的牢笼里。

This has been the problem of man right through the ages. He knows he lives by the senses, by his desires, by touch, by appetites—sexual, intellectual, and otherwise—and he questions: “Is that all?” Then he begins to invent the gods, the supergods, superconsciousness, and so on and so on. Having invented and projected a form, he pursues it, thinking he is tremendously idealistic or tremendously religious. But his pursuit of what he calls “God” or truth is still the pursuit of the product of thought, which is material. See what he has been doing. See what his churches, temples, and the mosques have done to him, to each one of us. Sense this great deception on which he has been fed, which he thinks is extraordinarily idealistic. When one realizes that, in seriousness, it is rather a shock, because one is stripped of all illusion.

这自古以来就是人类的问题。他知道自己靠感官、靠欲望、靠触觉、靠各种渴求——性欲、智力以及其他方面的——而活，于是他质疑：“难道就只有这些吗？”然后他开始创造神灵、超神、超意识等等。他创造并投射出一种形式，便去追求它，自以为是无比理想主义或无比虔诚。但他所追求的所谓“上帝”或真理，仍然是对思想产物的追求，而思想产物是物质的。看看他一直在做什么。看看他的教堂、寺庙和清真寺对他、对我们每个人造成了什么影响。感受一下他被灌输的这种巨大的欺骗，他自以为这种欺骗极其理想主义。当一个人认真地意识到这一点时，会感到震惊，因为他所有的幻想都被剥夺了。

If one has gone that far, one then begins to ask if there is a movement other than the movement of thought. How does one find out? If one is trying to find out if there is something beyond the material, then one must examine what is the cause of one’s search. Is the cause of one’s search an escape from this? Cause means motive. Is all one’s inquiry motivated? Because if it is, the root of that is either the seeking of pleasure or the escape from fear. Or, if it is from total dissatisfaction with what is , then it projects its own answer. Therefore, to inquire into “the other,” my mind must be without cause.

如果已经走到这一步，接下来就会开始追问，除了思维的运动之外，是否还存在其他运动？如何才能找到答案？如果想要探寻物质之外是否存在某种东西，就必须审视自己探寻的根源。探寻的根源是否在于逃避现实？原因意味着动机。所有的探究都带有动机吗？如果是这样，那么其根源要么是追求快乐，要么是逃避恐惧。或者，如果源于对现状的彻底不满，那么它就会投射出自己的答案。因此，要探究“他者”，我的心必须无因无果。

We said, and we are saying again, that there must be a transformation in the mind, not peripheral reformation but a revolution deep in the mind, to solve the problems that thought has created, whether they are religious, economic, social, or moral. If one is really serious, not flippant, not merely amused by intellectual theories or philosophies that are invented by thought, then one must be concerned and totally committed to this question of transforming the content of consciousness. For it is the content that makes up consciousness, as we said. And we asked who the entity is that is to change it. We said that the observer is the observed and that when there is a division between the observer and the observed, the “me” and the “not me,” then there is conflict. That conflict is essentially a waste of energy. And when you look into it and find that the observer is the observed, you remove conflict altogether and you have enormous energy because it is no longer wasted in conflict.

我们说过，而且我们现在再次强调，必须进行一场心灵的变革，不是表面上的改革，而是心灵深处的革命，才能解决思想所造成的各种问题，无论这些问题是宗教的、经济的、社会的还是道德的。如果一个人是真正认真对待这个问题，而不是轻率地对待，不是仅仅对思想创造出来的理论或哲学感到好笑，那么他就必须关注并全身心地投入到转变意识内容的这个问题中。因为正如我们所说，正是内容构成了意识。我们提出了一个问题：究竟是谁能够改变它？我们说，观察者就是被观察者；当观察者和被观察者之间，即“我”和“非我”之间存在分裂时，就会产生冲突。这种冲突本质上是一种能量的浪费。当你深入探究并发现观察者就是被观察者时，你就彻底消除了冲突，并获得了巨大的能量，因为能量不再浪费在冲突之中。

Now this energy is either in the field of thought or it is an energy totally different from thought. For a mind that is burdened, conditioned, and shaped by materialistic thought, is there a movement other than that of thought? To find that out, we must look into the cause of this search. Where there is a cause there is time. The cause produces an effect and that effect again becomes a cause. It is not really difficult because this is our life; it becomes difficult when you treat it, or look at it, as something apart from our daily life.

这种能量要么存在于思想领域，要么是一种与思想截然不同的能量。对于一个被物质主义思想束缚、制约和塑造的心灵而言，除了思想之外，是否存在其他运动？要找到答案，我们必须探究这种探索的根源。有因必有果。因产生果，而果又成为因。这其实并不难，因为这就是我们的生活；难就难在你把它当作与日常生活无关的东西来对待或看待时。

Put it differently. What is virtue, morality? Is morality transient? Is morality relative? Or is it absolute? For us, in the modern world, morality is relative, and that relativism is nearly destroying us. So one asks: What is virtue? Is there an absolute virtue, a sense of no hate under any circumstances? Is there a complete peace, an absolute peace, which can never be disturbed? Can one live without any sense of violence? Or is violence relative, hate modified, and so on? So what is virtue? If you hit me and I hit you back and apologize for it later, that becomes relative. If I have a cause for hating you, or disliking you, or being violent, that cause makes my action not complete and, therefore, relative. Is there a way of living which has no cause? Because the moment you have a cause, living becomes relative. If I have cause to love you—because you give me comfort, psychologically, physically, sexually, morally—it is not love. So where there is a cause, action must be relative. But when there is no cause, action will be absolute.

换句话说，什么是美德？什么是道德？道德是短暂的吗？道德是相对的吗？还是绝对的？对我们现代社会而言，道德是相对的，而这种相对主义几乎正在摧毁我们。因此，人们不禁要问：什么是美德？是否存在绝对的美德，即在任何情况下都不怀有仇恨？是否存在一种完全的和平，一种永远不会被打扰的绝对和平？一个人能否在没有任何暴力意识的情况下生活？或者说，暴力是相对的，仇恨是可以改变的，等等？那么，什么是美德？如果你打了我，我还击了你，事后又道歉，那么这就变成了相对的。如果我有理由恨你、不喜欢你，或者对你施暴，那么这个理由就使我的行为不完整，因此也是相对的。是否存在一种没有理由的生活方式？因为一旦你有了理由，生活就变成了相对的。如果我有理由爱你——因为你在心理上、生理上、性方面、道德上都给了我安慰——那不是爱。所以，只要有理由，行为就必然是相对的。但如果没有原因，行动就会是绝对的。

See what takes place in your life, not in the explanation I am giving. If I depend on you, if I am attached to you, that dependence and attachment have a cause. It is because I am lonely, or I am unhappy, or I want companionship; I want your love, your affection, your care, and so I am attached to you. From that attachment there is great sorrow, there is pain. Because you do not love me, or you only tolerate me, or give me a little of your affection and turn to somebody else, there is jealousy, antagonism, hate, and all the rest that follows. Where there is a cause, then action, morality, must be relative.

看看你生活中发生了什么，而不是我给出的解释。如果我依赖你，如果我依恋你，这种依赖和依恋是有原因的。那是因为我孤独，或者我不快乐，或者我渴望陪伴；我渴望你的爱、你的关怀、你的照顾，所以我依恋你。这种依恋会带来巨大的悲伤和痛苦。因为你不爱我，或者你只是容忍我，或者你只给我一点点爱就转向别人，所以就会产生嫉妒、敌意、仇恨以及随之而来的一切负面情绪。既然有原因，那么行为和道德就必然是相对的。

Can the mind be free of form, free of the ideal, of form as a cause, so that the mind is capable of going beyond itself? It is very simple really; words make it so difficult. Words are necessary in order to communicate, but if you merely live at the verbal level they are absolutely useless. It is like ploughing, ploughing, ploughing—and you destroy the earth by merely ploughing.

心灵能否摆脱形式、摆脱理念、摆脱形式作为因果关系，从而超越自身？其实很简单，只是语言使之变得复杂。语言是沟通的必要条件，但如果你仅仅停留在语言层面，它们就毫无用处。这就像耕地、耕地、再耕地——你仅仅耕地就会破坏土地。

We have this problem, which man right from the beginning has sought to solve, which is: Is all life mechanical? Is all life material? Is all existence, including mind and consciousness and will, matter? Is your whole life that? You may pretend it is not, but actually it is that. Being enclosed in that, thought creates a form, the ideal of the supreme, the highest form of excellence, great nobility, the gods, as well as all the other things that thought has put together in the world, the immense technological movement. It is all matter. And living on this shore as we are, with our wars, our hatreds, our appalling politics—living on this side of the river, which is matter, the mind says, “I want to go across; there must be something there because this life is too stupid.” And it is stupid: just to go to the office, to earn money, to take responsibility, to struggle, compete, worry, to despair, to have anxieties, immense sorrows, and then die. We say that is not good enough. We may put it more philosophically, in more extravagant or romantic language, but we see it is stupid and we want something more.

我们面临着这样一个问题，自人类诞生之初，我们就一直在试图解决它：所有生命都是机械的吗？所有生命都是物质的吗？所有存在，包括心灵、意识和意志，都是物质吗？你的整个人生都是如此吗？你或许会假装并非如此，但实际上它就是如此。受制于物质，思想创造了一种形式，至高无上的理想，卓越的最高形式，伟大的高贵，神祇，以及思想在世间构建的一切，包括浩瀚的科技运动。这一切都是物质。而我们生活在这岸边，饱受战争、仇恨和令人震惊的政治之苦——生活在河流的这一侧，也就是物质的这一侧，我们的思想会说：“我想去对岸；那里一定有什么东西，因为这人生太愚蠢了。”而这人生的确愚蠢：只是去上班，挣钱，承担责任，奋斗，竞争，忧虑，绝望，承受焦虑和巨大的悲伤，然后死去。我们说，这还不够好。我们或许可以用更哲学化、更夸张或更浪漫的语言来表达，但我们都明白这是愚蠢的，我们想要一些更好的东西。

Then we say: “How are we to cross this river to the other shore?” We ask, “Who will take us across?” When we ask that question, there is the priest, the guru, the man who knows, and he says, “Follow me”—and then we are done, because he is exactly like us, because he still functions within the field of thought. He has created the gods, Jesus, Buddha, Krishna. He has created the form and that form is as materialistic as your sensations; it is the product of thought. Now, if that is absolutely clear and there is no romantic escape, no ideological washing of the hands, no seeking comfort and all the other things that lead to illusions, if it is absolutely clear that any modification within the field of consciousness is merely moving from one object to another within the field of thought, then what is the mind to do? Or not to do?

然后我们说：“我们该如何渡过这条河到达对岸？”我们问：“谁能带我们过河？”当我们问这个问题时，祭司、古鲁、自以为是的人就会出现，他们会说：“跟我来”——然后一切就结束了，因为他和我们完全一样，因为他仍然在思想的领域中运作。他创造了神，耶稣、佛陀、克里希纳。他创造了形式，而这种形式和你的感官一样是物质性的；它是思想的产物。现在，如果这一点完全清楚，没有浪漫的逃避，没有意识形态上的推卸责任，没有寻求慰藉以及所有其他导致幻觉的东西，如果意识领域内的任何改变都仅仅是在思想领域内从一个对象转移到另一个对象，那么心灵应该做什么？或者不应该做什么？

First, such a mind must be in total order, material order, because if it is in disorder it cannot go away from itself. Thought is matter and all its activity within consciousness has created extraordinary confusion and disorder. Politically, religiously, socially, morally, in relationships, in every direction it has created disorder. And that is your life. Unless there is absolute order—and I am using the word absolute not relative —unless there is absolute order within that area, any cause to move away from that area is still the product of disorder. So there must be order.

首先，这样的心灵必须处于完全的秩序之中，物质的秩序，因为如果它处于混乱之中，就无法摆脱自身。思想即物质，它在意识中的一切活动都造成了极大的混乱和无序。在政治、宗教、社会、道德、人际关系等各个方面，它都造成了混乱。而这就是你的生活。除非存在绝对的秩序——我用的是绝对的秩序，而非相对的秩序——除非该领域内存在绝对的秩序，否则任何偏离该领域的原因仍然是混乱的产物。因此，秩序必不可少。

Now, how does this order come about politically, religiously, intellectually, morally, physically, in relationships—an absolute order, not a convenient order, not a relative order? How is the mind, which has been trained, educated, conditioned, to live in disorder and to accept disorder, to bring order in itself? Bear in mind, that if you say there is an outside agency which will bring order, then that outside agency is the product of thought and, therefore, it will create contradiction—and, therefore, disorder . If you say the action of will will bring about order, then what is will? “I will do that”—look at it, find out. When you are aggressive, when you say, “I must do that,” what is that will that is in action? Is it not desire, a projected end to be achieved, the achieving of an end projected by thought as an ideal, as a form, as an original pattern? Can thought bring order? That is the way the politicians and the priests and all the so-called reformers are trying to achieve it. Thought has created disorder . So what is one to do?

那么，这种秩序——一种绝对的秩序，而非权宜之计或相对秩序——是如何在政治、宗教、智力、道德、物质以及人际关系中产生的呢？一个被训练、被教育、被制约到生活在混乱之中并接受混乱的心灵，又如何能自行创造秩序呢？请记住，如果你说存在一种外在力量能够带来秩序，那么这种外在力量本身就是思想的产物，因此，它会制造矛盾——进而制造混乱。如果你说意志的行动能够带来秩序，那么意志究竟是什么？“我会做这件事”——仔细观察，找出答案。当你咄咄逼人，当你说道“我必须做这件事”时，究竟是什么意志在发挥作用？难道不是欲望，是需要达成的预设目标，是思想所预设的理想、形式或原始模式的实现吗？思想能够带来秩序吗？这正是政客、牧师以及所有所谓的改革者试图实现秩序的方式。思想已经制造了混乱。那么，我们该怎么办呢？

Can the mind, your mind, observe, see, this disorder? One is in disorder. One sees that the exercise of will, the following of another, having desire to overcome disorder, is still within the field of disorder. So one says to oneself, “What am I to do; what is the mind to do?” First of all, does one know disorder? Does the mind see disorder, or does it know only the description of disorder? You describe to me a mountain, its beauty, its snow, its lines against the blue sky, the depth of shadows in the forest, the running waters, the murmur of trees, the beauty of it all. You describe it to me and the description catches my mind and I live with that description. But the description is not that which is described. So one asks oneself, “Am I caught in the description, or am I actually seeing disorder?” One is intellectual, the other is factual. Now, is the mind observing its disorder, which means no word, not being caught in the description, but merely observing this enormous disorder? Can the mind so observe? And in observing its own disorder, is there an “observer” looking at it, or is there no observer at all, but merely the observing?

心智，你的心智，能否观察、感知到这种混乱？人身处混乱之中。人会发现，意志的运用，追随他人，渴望克服混乱，却仍然身处混乱的范畴之内。于是人会问自己：“我该怎么办？心智该怎么办？”首先，人是否了解混乱？心智是否能感知混乱，还是仅仅知晓对混乱的描述？你向我描述一座山，它的美丽，它的积雪，它在蓝天映衬下的线条，森林中阴影的深邃，潺潺的流水，树木的低语，这一切的美好。你向我描述，这描述抓住了我的心智，我便沉浸在这描述之中。但这描述并非被描述之物。于是人会问自己：“我是被描述所困，还是我真的看到了混乱？”前者是理性的，后者是事实的。那么，心智是否在观察自身的混乱——这意味着无言的混乱——它是否没有被描述所困，而仅仅是在观察这巨大的混乱？心智能否如此观察？在观察自身的混乱时，是否存在一个“观察者”在观察它，或者根本没有观察者，而仅仅是观察本身？

I observe you, I see you. I met you last year; you were pleasant or unpleasant to me; you flattered or insulted me, or neglected me. The memory of that remains. This year I meet you and the memory responds. That memory is the past and also that memory is the observer. Of course. Can the mind observe all the disorder, social and moral and so on, which is created by thought, in which I am, which is part of me? Can it observe this disorder without the observer? If the observer is there looking at disorder, then there is a division between the observer and the observed. In that division, conflict takes place: “I must control it, I must change it, I must suppress it, I must overcome it,” and so on. Now when the observer is not, and there is only observation, then there is no conflict, there is merely observing. Then there is energy to go beyond disorder.

我观察你，我看见你。去年我遇见了你；你对我或友好或不友好；你奉承我或侮辱我，或冷落我。那段记忆犹存。今年我遇见你，记忆有所回应。那段记忆既是过去，也是观察者本身。当然。心灵能否观察到所有由思想创造的混乱——社会的、道德的等等——而我身处其中，它构成了我的一部分？它能否在没有观察者的情况下观察到这种混乱？如果观察者在那里注视着混乱，那么观察者和被观察者之间就存在着隔阂。在这种隔阂中，冲突产生：“我必须控制它，我必须改变它，我必须压制它，我必须克服它”，等等。而当观察者不存在，只有观察时，就没有冲突，只有单纯的观察。那时，便有超越混乱的能量。

Where there is division, there must be disorder. The observer, rooted in the past, is essentially the factor of division. Now can the mind see the truth of that and observe the actual disorder of your life, not the description? Can it observe your disorder, your confusion, your anxieties, your contradictions, your selfish demands, all that? Observe. And if it observes without the observer there is then the going beyond it, which means total order, not relative order but mathematical order that is essential before you can go any further. Without order in the material world, in the world of matter, in the world of thought, the mind has no basis, no foundation on which to move.

哪里有分裂，哪里就必然有混乱。执着于过去的观察者，本质上就是分裂的根源。那么，心灵能否看清这个真相，观察你生活中真正的混乱，而不是对混乱的描述？它能否观察你的混乱、你的困惑、你的焦虑、你的矛盾、你的自私需求，以及所有这一切？观察吧。如果它能够超越观察者本身进行观察，那么便能超越它，这意味着绝对的秩序，而非相对的秩序，而是数学意义上的秩序——这是你继续前进的必要前提。如果物质世界、物质世界、思想世界都失去了秩序，心灵便失去了根基，失去了前进的动力。

Therefore, there must be observation of behavior. Do I behave according to a motive, according to circumstances? Is my behavior pragmatic, or is it under all circumstances the same? Not the same in the sense of copying a pattern; is it a behavior that is never relative, that is not based on reward and punishment? Inquire into it, observe it and you will find how terrible your behavior is, how you look to a superior and inferior and all the other things you do. There is never a constant movement free of the motive of reward and punishment.

因此，必须观察自己的行为。我的行为是出于某种动机，还是受环境影响？我的行为是务实的，还是在任何情况下都一成不变？这里说的“一成不变”并非指照搬某种模式；而是指一种永不相对、不基于奖惩的行为。深入探究，仔细观察，你会发现自己的行为有多么糟糕，你如何看待上级和下级，以及你所做的其他一切。没有任何行为能够完全摆脱奖惩的动机。

Then also you have to inquire into relationship in the material world. Relationship is of the highest importance, because life is relationship. What is your relationship? Have you any relationship? Relationship means to respond adequately to any challenge. As I inquire into relationship, is my relationship with another personal and intimate, or not so intimate? Is it based on my opinions, my memories, my hurts, my demands, my sexual appetites? If my relationship to you is relative, it changes: I am moody one day, not moody the next day, the next day I am affectionate, and the third day I hate you, and the fourth day I love you, and so on, and so on. If that relationship is not satisfactory, I will go to somebody else. This is the game that we have been playing for centuries. Now it is more open, more extravagant, more vulgar, that is all.

那么，你还得探究物质世界中的关系。关系至关重要，因为生命本身就是关系。你的关系是什么？你拥有任何关系吗？关系意味着能够恰当地应对任何挑战。当我探究关系时，我与他人的关系是亲密而私人的，还是并非如此？它是否建立在我的观点、我的记忆、我的伤痛、我的要求、我的性欲之上？如果我与你的关系是相对的，它就会变化：我今天情绪低落，明天可能就平静下来，后天可能对你充满爱意，第三天可能恨你，第四天可能又爱你，如此循环往复。如果这种关系无法令人满意，我就会去找别人。这就是我们几个世纪以来一直在玩的游戏。如今，它变得更加公开、更加放纵、更加庸俗，仅此而已。

So my mind has to find out what its relationships actually are. Unless there is complete harmony in the material world in which I live, which is part of me, in me, which is my consciousness, the mind cannot possibly go beyond itself. That is why your meditations, your postures, your breathing exercises, your going to India and searching, are so utterly meaningless.

所以，我的心智必须弄清它与万物之间的关系。除非我所生活的物质世界——也就是我的一部分，存在于我之内，即我的意识——达到完全的和谐，否则心智就不可能超越自身。这就是为什么你的冥想、你的体式、你的呼吸练习、你去印度寻觅真理，都毫无意义的原因。

So, is my relationship relative? Is all relationship relative? Or is there no relationship at all except when the division as the “me” and the “you” does not exist? I am related to you because I love you, because you give me food, clothes, shelter, you give me sex, you give me companionship. I have built a marvelous image about you; we may get annoyed with each other, irritated, but that is trivial. And I hold on to you; I am attached to you, and in that attachment there is great pain, there is great sorrow, suffering, torture, jealousy, antagonism. And then I say to myself, “I must be free of that.” And in freeing myself from that I attach myself to somebody else. And the game begins again. So I say to myself, “What is this relationship? Is there a relationship? Can there ever be a relationship?” There is the “me” that is pursuing my appetites, my ambitions, my greed, my fears, my wanting to have more prestige, greater position, and so on; and there is the other also pursuing his or her own demands. Is there any relationship possible at all between two human beings, each functioning with and pursuing his own exclusive, selfish, demands?

那么，我的这种关系是相对的吗？所有的关系都是相对的吗？或者，只有当“我”和“你”的界限消失时，关系才存在？我与你存在关系，因为我爱你，因为你给我食物、衣服、住所，你给我性，你给我陪伴。我为你构建了一个美好的形象；我们或许会彼此生气，彼此烦躁，但这无关紧要。我紧紧抓住你；我依恋你，而这种依恋中充满了巨大的痛苦、悲伤、折磨、痛苦、嫉妒和敌意。然后我对自己说：“我必须摆脱这一切。”然而，当我摆脱这一切时，我又依恋上了别人。于是，一切又重新开始。所以我问自己：“这究竟是什么关系？真的存在关系吗？关系有可能存在吗？”这里有追求自身欲望、野心、贪婪、恐惧、渴望获得更高声望、更大地位等等的“我”；也有追求自身需求的“他者”。两个人各自都只关注自身排他性的、自私的需求，他们之间究竟还有可能存在任何关系吗？

There may be no relationship in that direction, but there may be relationship when there is no “me” at all. When the “me,” as thought, is nonexistent, I am related; then I am related to you, the trees, the mountains, to the rivers, to human beings. That means love—does it not?—which has no cause.

或许在那条方向上不存在任何关系，但当“我”完全不存在时，关系或许就存在了。当作为思想的“我”不复存在时，我便与万物相连；那时，我与你、树木、山川、河流、人类都相连。那岂不就是爱吗？——一种无因之爱。

Consciousness, with its content, is within the field of matter. The mind cannot possibly go beyond that unless it has complete order within itself and conflict in relationship has come totally to an end—which means a relationship in which there is no “me.”

意识及其内容都存在于物质领域之中。除非意识内部达到完全的秩序，关系中的冲突彻底消除——这意味着一种不存在“我”的关系——否则心智不可能超越物质领域。

This is not just a verbal explanation: the speaker is telling you what he lives, not what he talks about; if he does not live it, it is hypocrisy, a dirty thing to do.

这不仅仅是口头上的解释：说话者是在告诉你他亲身经历的，而不是他谈论的；如果他没有身体力行，那就是虚伪，是件卑鄙的事情。

When the mind has order and the sense of total relationship, then what takes place? Then the mind is not seeking at all, it is not capable of any kind of illusion. That is absolutely necessary, because thought can invent any experience, any kind of vision, any kind of superconsciousness and all the rest of it. There is no ideal, there is no form, there is only behavior, which is order and the sense of relationship for the whole of man. There you have the foundation.

当心灵拥有秩序和整体关系感时，会发生什么？那时，心灵不再寻求任何东西，也不再受任何幻觉的影响。这至关重要，因为思想可以虚构任何体验、任何景象、任何超意识等等。没有理想，没有形式，只有行为，而行为本身就是秩序和对整个人类关系感的体现。这就是基础。

Now another question arises from this: Is the brain totally conditioned? This brain of mankind has had thousands and thousands of experiences; it is educated with a great deal of accumulated knowledge from books and elsewhere, and that is there in the brain. And thought operates only within that field of the known. It can invent a field that says, “Apart from knowing, ‘I’ am there,” but that is too silly. So my mind is asking: Is the whole brain conditioned by the economic, social, environmental, religious, culture it has lived in? Is the mind, in which is included the brain, totally conditioned within the borders of time? Is the mind a complete slave?

由此引出另一个问题：大脑是否完全受制约？人类的大脑经历了成千上万次的体验；它吸收了来自书籍和其他途径的大量知识，这些知识都储存在大脑中。而思维只能在已知领域内运作。它可以虚构一个领域，声称“除了认知之外，‘我’还存在于此”，但这未免太过荒谬。因此，我的疑问是：整个大脑是否都受到其所处的经济、社会、环境、宗教和文化环境的制约？包含大脑在内的心灵是否完全受制于时间的限制？心灵是否完全沦为奴隶？

Do not say yes or no, for then you have settled it, then there is nothing more into which to inquire. But a mind that is asking, groping, looking, without any motive, without any direction, says, “Is the mind totally conditioned and, therefore, mechanical?” And you see that it is mechanical when it is functioning in the field of knowledge, whether scientific, technological, or the priestly tradition. It is mechanical; there is repetition, repetition, repetition. That is what is going on—the repetition of desire, sexual or otherwise, repeating, repeating, repeating. Therefore, the mind asks itself, “Is the totality of this thing mechanical, or is there, in this field of the mind, an area that is not mechanical?” Can the mind be free of causation, for where there is causation, all movement as thought must be mechanical.

不要轻易回答“是”或“否”，因为那样就等于盖棺定论，也就无从探究。然而，一颗漫无目的、摸索前行的心，会问自己：“心智是否完全受制于条件反射，因而也是机械的？”你会发现，当它在知识领域运作时，无论是科学的、技术的，还是宗教传统，它的确是机械的。它是机械的；其中充斥着重复、重复、再重复。这就是正在发生的事情——欲望的重复，无论是性欲还是其他欲望，都在重复、重复、再重复。因此，心智会问自己：“这一切是否都是机械的？或者，在心智的这个领域中，是否存在一个非机械的区域？”心智能否摆脱因果关系？因为只要存在因果关系，所有作为思想的运动都必然是机械的。

Saanen, July 18, 1974

萨嫩，1974年7月18日

4

Our chief concern is the transformation, the radical change, of the human mind. The human mind includes the brain, the heart, the organism as a whole, the mind that has created this world around us, the world of corruption, violence, brutality, vanity, and all the structures that bring about war. We are concerned with the change of the content of consciousness because the content makes consciousness. Unless that radical revolution, that psychological change, comes about, there will be no end to conflict, no end to suffering and all the violence that is going on throughout the world.

我们最关注的是人类思维的转变，是根本性的改变。人类思维包括大脑、心脏、整个有机体，以及创造了我们周围这个世界——一个充满腐败、暴力、残暴、虚荣以及所有导致战争的结构——的思维。我们关注的是意识内容的改变，因为内容造就了意识。除非发生这场根本性的革命，这场心理上的转变，否则冲突、苦难以及世界各地正在发生的一切暴力都将永无止境。

This change cannot possibly be brought about without knowing oneself, self-knowledge.
