This is not knowledge of the “higher self” or knowledge of some “supreme consciousness,” for they are still within the field of thought. Unless one understands one’s self, the self of every day—what it thinks, what it does, its devotions, its deceptions, its ambitions, all its self-centered activities, its identification with something noble or ignoble, the state or some ideal—one is still within the field of the “me.” Unless one understands that narrowing field, of which one is so little aware—the field in which there is the unconscious as well as the conscious, which is concerned with the individual ego, its individual ambitions and reactions, which are essentially a part of the whole, part of the community, part of the culture in which it lives—unless we understand that radically, the content of consciousness cannot possibly be transformed.

若不认识自己，即自我认知，这种改变绝不可能实现。这并非对“更高自我”或某种“至高意识”的认知，因为它们仍处于思维的范畴之内。除非一个人理解自己的自我，理解日常的自我——它的所思所想、所作所为、它的虔诚、它的欺骗、它的抱负、它所有以自我为中心的活动、它对某种高尚或卑劣之物的认同、对国家或某种理想的认同——否则，他仍然囿于“我”的范畴。除非一个人理解那个日益缩小的领域，而我们对此却知之甚少——那个既包含无意识也包含意识的领域，它关乎个体的自我、个体的抱负和反应，而这些本质上都是整体的一部分，是社群的一部分，是其所处文化的一部分——否则，除非我们从根本上理解这一点，否则意识的内容就不可能发生转变。

“Understanding” is not an intellectual, an emotional, or a passing, thing. It is something that comes with action and, therefore, it is a complete understanding and not a partial understanding. In understanding oneself, one’s consciousness and its content—for there is no consciousness without content—one sees there are two principal factors, pleasure and fear. They cannot be separated. Where there is the pursuit, the insistence on, and the demand for pleasure, there must be in its wake fear. In understanding fear, one must not disregard the fact of pleasure.

“理解”并非一种理性的、情感的或转瞬即逝的东西。它源于行动，因此，它是完整的理解，而非片面的理解。在理解自身、理解自身的意识及其内容（因为没有内容就没有意识）的过程中，人们会发现其中有两个主要因素：快乐和恐惧。二者密不可分。凡是追求、坚持和需要快乐的地方，必然伴随着恐惧。在理解恐惧时，人们绝不能忽视快乐的存在。

Thought is the measure of fear. Thought is the response of memory, which is experience and knowledge stored up in the brain cells and tissues. Thought is matter. The whole world is constructed from thought, is based in its very nature and substance and activity on thought. One has to find out whether it is thought that has bred fear. Not how to be free of fear; freedom from fear will inevitably come about when one understands the structure, the nature, and the functioning of thought.

思想是恐惧的尺度。思想是对记忆的反应，而记忆则是储存在脑细胞和组织中的经验和知识。思想本身就是物质。整个世界由思想构成，其本质、构成和活动都建立在思想之上。我们必须探究恐惧是否源于思想。我们不必探究如何摆脱恐惧；当我们理解了思想的结构、本质和运作方式时，摆脱恐惧自然而然就会到来。

When one observes the whole process of thought—which has created the world with all its religions, with all its gods, with its saviors, which has created the materialistic world in which we live—one sees that, as long as we function there and remain there, fear must continue. Fear is the cause of loneliness, of deprivation, both physical and psychological; it is the cause of attachment to property, to people, ideas, concepts, nationalities, families. As long as there is this functioning of thought within the material world—and it has to function in that world—fear must remain. What else has one if one lives in that world, for there one must seek security, physical or psychological! As long as the mind seeks material security, as long as the mind asserts a permanency, there must be fear. Yet the brain can only function effectively, objectively, rationally, if it has complete security. That is obvious. When it has no security, it seeks security in belief in gods, in symbols, in ideologies, in nationalities, which leads to neurotic action. As long as I call myself a nationalist of a particular country, I am behaving neurotically; I bring about conflict and division between people. That is one of the causes of fear. When you realize that, when you are aware of its whole nature, are you still a nationalist? If you are, there must be the continuance of pleasure and of fear.

当我们观察整个思维过程——它创造了世界及其所有宗教、所有神祇、所有救世主，创造了我们赖以生存的物质世界——就会发现，只要我们身处其中，恐惧就必然存在。恐惧是孤独和匮乏的根源，无论是生理上的还是心理上的；它是对财产、人、观念、概念、民族和家庭执着的根源。只要思维在物质世界中运作——而它必须在这个世界中运作——恐惧就必然存在。如果生活在那个世界里，除了恐惧，我们还能拥有什么呢？因为在那里，我们必须寻求安全感，无论是生理上的还是心理上的！只要心灵寻求物质上的安全感，只要心灵执着于某种永恒性，恐惧就必然存在。然而，大脑只有在拥有完全的安全感时，才能有效、客观、理性地运作。这一点显而易见。当大脑缺乏安全感时，它就会在对神祇、符号、意识形态和民族的信仰中寻求安全感，而这会导致神经质的行为。只要我自称是某个国家的民族主义者，我的行为就带有神经质的色彩；我会在人民之间制造冲突和分裂。这正是恐惧的根源之一。当你意识到这一点，当你真正了解它的本质时，你还会是民族主义者吗？如果你还是，那么快乐和恐惧必然会同时存在。

If the mind lives totally in the material world, then nothing exists but matter, which is thought, consciousness and will. If the mind lives there, fear will go on, because there, there is nothing else but the demand for material security and permanency. Where there is that demand, there must be fear.

如果心灵完全沉浸于物质世界，那么除了物质（即思想、意识和意志）之外，别无他物。如果心灵如此，恐惧便会持续存在，因为在那里，除了对物质安全和永恒的需求之外，别无其他。而哪里有这种需求，哪里就必然有恐惧。

There are all the various fears concealed in the very recesses of one’s consciousness: racial, collective, the fear of famine, and so on. There are hidden fears and extraordinarily subtle forms of pleasure. There is fear, both conscious and unconscious, the fear of death, of loneliness, of losing a job, the fear of what people will say, the fear of your own attachments and of losing them, the fear of not succeeding, not becoming great. Can they all be exposed—and without analysis? We have seen the futility of analysis, how the analyzer and the analyzed are the same. So, what is a mind to do when it realizes the absurdity, the falseness, of analysis or introspective examination?

每个人的意识深处都隐藏着各种各样的恐惧：种族恐惧、集体恐惧、饥荒恐惧等等。既有隐秘的恐惧，也有极其微妙的愉悦。恐惧既有意识的，也有无意识的：对死亡的恐惧、对孤独的恐惧、对失业的恐惧、对他人议论的恐惧、对自身依恋的恐惧以及失去依恋的恐惧、对失败的恐惧、对无法成就伟业的恐惧。所有这些恐惧都能被揭示出来吗？而且无需分析？我们已经看到了分析的徒劳，分析者和被分析者其实是同一人。那么，当一个人意识到分析或内省的荒谬和虚假时，他该如何是好？

To understand what the mind is to do, we must go into the question of meditation. When we use the word meditation , hear it as though you have never heard the word before. What is meditation? Not how to meditate; that is irrelevant, because the moment you understand what meditation is, it happens naturally, like breathing. To find out what meditation is, the real meaning, can you learn from another? Volumes have been written about it. People have meditated according to a particular system—Zen or the many, many varieties and methods of the Hindu systems. They all imply an end to be achieved through control. Control implies a controller. And is the controller different from the controlled? The meditative groups, with their systems and their philosophies, say, “Control your thought!” Thought wanders about and that wandering about is a wastage of energy; therefore, they say thought must be absolutely held, disciplined, subjugated in the pursuit of that thing called enlightenment, God, truth, what you will, the nameless. That implies a controller, obviously. And who is the controller? Is he different in quality, in nature, from that which he says he is going to control? This is very important to understand.

要理解心智的运作方式，我们必须深入探讨冥想。当我们提到“冥想”这个词时，请先假设你从未听过它。什么是冥想？不是如何冥想；这无关紧要，因为一旦你理解了冥想的本质，它就会自然而然地发生，就像呼吸一样。要了解冥想的本质和真正含义，你能从他人那里学习吗？关于冥想的著作汗牛充栋。人们根据特定的体系进行冥想——禅宗，或是印度教体系中种类繁多的冥想方法。所有这些体系都暗示着一个需要通过控制来达成的目标。控制意味着控制者的存在。那么，控制者和被控制者之间有什么区别呢？冥想团体及其各自的体系和哲学都宣称：“控制你的思想！”思想四处游荡，而这种游荡是一种能量的浪费；因此，他们认为必须绝对地控制、约束、驾驭思想，以追求所谓的觉悟、上帝、真理，或者任何你想称呼的无名之物。这显然意味着一个控制者的存在。那么，谁是控制者呢？他所声称要控制的那个人，在本质和本性上是否有所不同？理解这一点至关重要。

The speaker wants to point out that one can live completely in daily life, without any control, against all the traditions, against all your education, your social and moral behaviors. To live a life absolutely without any controls means you have to understand very, very deeply who is the controller and what is the controlled, for this is part of meditation. Is the controller different from that which he is controlling, which is thought? Some say the controller is different, that he is the higher self, that he is part of the higher consciousness, that he is the essence of understanding or the essence of the past, which has accumulated so much knowledge. But the controller is still within the field of thought; and however much that thought may be elevated, it is still within the area of time and measure.

演讲者想要指出的是，一个人可以完全摆脱一切控制，违背所有传统、所有教育、社会和道德规范，过着完全自由自在的日常生活。要过一种完全不受控制的生活，就意味着你必须非常深刻地理解谁是控制者，什么又是被控制的，因为这是冥想的一部分。控制者与他所控制的对象——思想——有何不同？有人说控制者不同，他是更高的自我，是更高意识的一部分，是理解的本质，或是积累了无数知识的过去的本质。但控制者仍然处于思想的范畴之内；无论思想多么高深，它仍然受制于时间和尺度。

Do you see the truth of this? Not the verbal acceptance of it, or the intellectual comprehension of it, but the truth that all the gods, Christian or Hindu, all of them, are the invention of thought. Thought can project itself into all kinds of states, into all kinds of illusions, and when thought says there is the higher self, it is still within the field of thought and, therefore, that higher self is still matter.

你明白其中的真相吗？不是口头上的接受，也不是理性上的理解，而是所有神祇——无论是基督教的还是印度教的——都是思想的产物。思想可以投射到各种各样的状态，各种各样的幻象之中。当思想声称存在更高的自我时，它仍然处于思想的范畴之内，因此，那个更高的自我仍然是物质。

When you see that the controller is the controlled, the whole aspect of meditation changes. Meditation means the emptying of consciousness of its content. Then only can the mind and the brain be absolutely quiet. That absolute—not relative—that absolute quietness is necessary to observe. Not to experience! Experiences we have had, of every kind, and thought desires more experience, including the experience of another state, another dimension. We are fed up with this world and its experiences; they are boring, they are limited, confined, narrow, and we want an experience which is totally different. Now, to experience involves recognition. If I do not recognize, is there an experience? I have had the experience of looking at a mountain, the beauty of it, the shadow, the lovely deep blue of an early morning, the whole sense of something extraordinary and magnificent. That experience cannot exist if there is no relationship to the past. And so experience implies recognition from the past. And the mind wants to experience something supreme. But to recognize it, it must already have had it . Therefore, it is not the supreme, it is still the projection of thought.

当你意识到控制者即是被控制者时，冥想的整个层面就改变了。冥想意味着清空意识的内容。唯有如此，心智才能达到绝对的平静。这种绝对的——而非相对的——绝对的平静，是观察所必需的，而非体验所必需的！我们拥有各种各样的体验，而思想渴望更多的体验，包括体验另一种状态，另一个维度。我们厌倦了这个世界及其体验；它们枯燥乏味，局限狭隘，我们想要一种截然不同的体验。然而，体验包含着认知。如果我不认知，体验还能存在吗？我曾体验过凝视一座山峰，它的美丽，它的阴影，清晨那迷人的深蓝色，以及那种非凡而壮丽的感受。如果没有与过去的联系，这种体验便不复存在。因此，体验意味着对过去的认知。而心智渴望体验某种至高无上的事物。但要认知它，它必须已经拥有过它。因此，它并非至高无上的事物，它仍然是思想的投射。

Meditation is that in which there is no experience. In that there is no element of time, which implies movement and direction. Direction implies will. Can the mind empty itself of time, direction, and movement, which implies the ending of thought? That is the whole problem.

冥想是一种没有体验的状态。在这种状态下，时间的概念不复存在，而时间意味着运动和方向。方向又意味着意志。心灵能否摆脱时间、方向和运动，从而彻底消除念头？这才是问题的关键所在。

We need knowledge to function; to speak any language, we need knowledge; to drive a car, we need knowledge; to do anything, we need knowledge. What place has knowledge in meditation? Or has it no place at all? It has no place because knowledge is merely a continuation of the past, it is still the movement of time. So can the mind empty itself of the past and come upon that area of itself that is not touched by thought? We have only operated, so far, within the area of thought as knowledge. Is there any other part, any other area of the mind, which includes the brain, which is not touched by human struggle, pain, anxiety, fear and all the violence, all the things that man has made through thought? The discovery of that area is meditation.

我们需要知识才能正常生活；要说任何语言，我们需要知识；要开车，我们需要知识；要做任何事，我们都需要知识。那么，知识在冥想中扮演什么角色呢？或者说，它根本没有位置？它没有位置，因为知识仅仅是过去的延续，它仍然是时间的流逝。那么，心灵能否摆脱过去的束缚，抵达那片不受思维触及的领域呢？迄今为止，我们所做的一切都局限于作为知识的思维领域。心灵中是否还有其他部分，其他区域，包括大脑在内，不受人类的挣扎、痛苦、焦虑、恐惧以及所有暴力——所有人类通过思维所创造的事物——的影响？发现那片区域就是冥想。

That implies the discovery of whether thought can come to an end yet still operate when necessary in the field of knowledge. We need knowledge, otherwise we cannot function, we would not be able to speak, nor be able to write, and so on. Knowledge is necessary to function and its functioning becomes neurotic when status becomes all-important, which is the entering of thought as the “me.” So knowledge is necessary and yet meditation is to discover, or come upon, or to observe, an area in which there is no movement of thought. Can the two live together, harmoniously, daily ?

这意味着要探究思想能否终结，却仍能在必要时在知识领域发挥作用。我们需要知识，否则我们将无法正常生活，无法说话，无法写作等等。知识是正常生活的必要条件，而当地位变得至关重要时，这种运作就会变得神经质，因为思想会以“我”的视角进入我们的生活。因此，知识是必要的，而冥想则是去发现、抵达或观察一个思想静止的领域。这两者能否和谐共存，日复一日？

Yoga exercises are excellent to keep the body healthy, and so on. But through them you can never come upon the other, never! Because if you give them all importance, you are not giving importance to the understanding of yourself, which is to be watchful, to be aware, to give attention to what you are doing, every day of your life. That is, to give attention to how you speak and what you say, to what you think, how you behave, whether you are attached, whether you are frightened, whether you are pursuing pleasure, and so on, to be aware of the whole movement of thought. If you are and you are really serious about it, then you will have established right relationship. Obviously. When all things about us are chaotic, when the world is going to pieces, as it is, relationship becomes extraordinarily important. When there is the establishing of total relationship, whole relationship—not between you and me, but human relationship with the whole of the world—then you have the basis for meditation.

瑜伽练习对保持身体健康固然极好，等等。但通过它们，你永远无法抵达彼岸，永远不可能！因为如果你把所有重心都放在练习上，你就忽略了对自身的理解，而这种理解意味着保持警觉，保持觉察，关注你每天的所作所为。也就是说，关注你的言谈举止，关注你的思想，关注你的行为，关注你是否执着于某些事物，是否感到恐惧，是否在追求享乐等等，关注你思想的整个流动。如果你做到了，并且真的认真对待，那么你就能建立起正确的关系。这是显而易见的。当周围的一切都混乱不堪，当世界分崩离析时，关系就显得尤为重要。当建立起完整的关系，整体的关系——不是你我之间的关系，而是人类与整个世界的关系——那么你就拥有了冥想的基础。

From there you can go on to behavior, how you behave. If your behavior is based on pleasure or on reward, it is not behavior. It is merely the pursuit of pleasure, and from that fear arises. Relationship, behavior, and order are absolutely essential if you want to go into the question of meditation. If you have not laid this foundation, then do what you like, stand on your head and breathe in and out for the next ten thousand years and repeat words, words, but there will be no meditation. If you have the money, you can go to India. But I do not know why you go, you will find no enlightenment there. Enlightenment is where you are . And where you are, you have to understand yourself. Having established that, laid the foundation there of order—not mechanical order but order which is virtue from moment to moment, which is not following a pattern, not the order of the establishment, not the order or the virtue of society, which is immoral—then you can go into the question of finding out what meditation is.

从这里你可以继续探讨行为，探讨你的行为方式。如果你的行为基于享乐或奖励，那并非真正的行为，而仅仅是对享乐的追求，恐惧也由此而生。如果你想深入探讨冥想，关系、行为和秩序至关重要。如果你没有打好这个基础，那么无论你做什么，倒立呼吸一万年，重复念诵词句，都不会有冥想。如果你有钱，你可以去印度。但我不知道你为什么要去，你在那里找不到觉悟。觉悟就在你身边。而你身边，你必须了解自己。在你确立了这一点，并在那里奠定了秩序的基础——不是机械的秩序，而是当下即是美德的秩序，不是墨守成规，不是遵循既定的秩序，也不是社会的秩序或美德（因为那是不道德的）——之后，你才能去探寻冥想的真谛。

Meditation implies a quality of mind that is absolutely silent. Not made silence, not a contrived act brought about through will, but a silence that comes naturally when you have established order, relationship, and behavior. Silence is necessary. If my mind is chattering, as most minds are, in that chatter there may be a period of silence. Between two chatterings there may be a period of silence. But that is not silence. Silence is not the absence of noise; it is not the absence of conflict. Silence comes only when the content of consciousness has been completely understood and gone beyond, which means the observer and the observed are one and there is no controller. When there is no controller—which does not mean that you live a life of nondiscipline—when there is no controller, no observer, then action is instantaneous and it brings a great deal of energy.

冥想意味着一种绝对寂静的心灵状态。这种寂静并非刻意营造，也非意志力强加，而是当你建立起秩序、关系和行为准则时自然而然产生的。寂静是必要的。如果我的思绪纷乱，就像大多数人的思绪一样，那么在纷乱之中或许会有一段寂静。两次纷乱之间或许也会有一段寂静。但这并非真正的寂静。寂静并非没有噪音，也并非没有冲突。只有当意识的内容被完全理解并超越时，寂静才会到来。这意味着观察者与被观察者合二为一，不再有控制者。当不再有控制者——这并不意味着你可以放纵生活——当不再有控制者，不再有观察者时，行动便会瞬间发生，并带来巨大的能量。

Meditation means the emptying of consciousness of its content and that happens only when you observe your consciousness and its content without the observer. Can you look at your wife, your husband, your girl, your boy, or the mountain, without the observer? The observer is the past. As long as there is the observer, he will inevitably translate everything he observes in terms of the past; therefore, he is the maker of time. He divides the observed and the observer. In that there is conflict. When there is observation without the observer, there is no conflict, no past; there is only the fact and you have the energy to go beyond it. Do it and you will find out.

冥想意味着清空意识的内容，而这只有在你观察自己的意识及其内容时才会发生，因为此时你无需借助观察者。你能不借助观察者，去观察你的妻子、丈夫、女友、男友，或是山峦吗？观察者即是过去。只要观察者存在，他就必然会用过去来解读他所观察到的一切；因此，他是时间的创造者。他将观察对象与观察者割裂开来。这其中便存在冲突。当观察时不再需要借助观察者，冲突便不复存在，过去也随之消失；唯有事实存在，而你拥有超越事实的能量。尝试一下，你就会明白。

Meditation implies a gathering of all energy. You have established order, relationship, behavior; therefore, you are not dissipating energy in that field. That energy is necessary to look without the observer and you have the energy to go beyond. With that energy, which has not been dissipated, the mind sees that there is an area which is not touched by thought. But all this requires tremendous attention and discipline. It is not just a plaything for immature people. Meditation requires tremendous discipline. The word discipline means to learn—not control, subjugate, imitate, and conform. Discipline means to learn. From the word discipline comes “disciple,” one who is willing to learn from the master, to learn . But here there is neither a disciple nor a master but only the act of learning, all the time. And that requires a great deal of attention, a great deal of energy, so that you are watching and thus, you create no illusions. It is so easy to create illusions; they come when you are pursuing, demanding, wanting, an experience. Desire creates illusions.

冥想意味着所有能量的汇聚。你已经建立了秩序、关系和行为模式；因此，你不会将能量耗散于此。这种能量对于超越观察者的视角至关重要，你也拥有超越观察者的能量。凭借这种未被耗散的能量，你的心智能够感知到一片未被思维触及的领域。但这需要极大的专注和自律。它并非不成熟之人的玩物。冥想需要极强的自律。自律意味着学习——而非控制、征服、模仿和顺从。自律意味着学习。“门徒”一词源于自律，指愿意向师父学习的人。但在这里，既没有门徒也没有师父，只有持续不断的学习行为。这需要极大的专注和能量，让你保持觉察，从而避免产生任何幻觉。产生幻觉是如此容易；当你追求、索取、渴望某种体验时，幻觉便会滋生。欲望会创造幻觉。

All this implies a mind that is very, very serious and a heart that is of love, that has never been hurt. We human beings, from childhood on, are hurt. Our parents hurt us, and in the business world we are hurt. We are hurt in every direction, and when we are hurt we cannot possibly love. So is it possible for a mind that has been hurt to be free of all that hurt, which is part of consciousness? You will find, when you look at it, that it is utterly and irrevocably possible to empty all hurts and, therefore, to love, to have compassion. To have compassion means to have passion for all things, not just between two people, but for all human beings, for all things of the earth, the animals, the trees, everything the earth contains. When we have such compassion we will not despoil the earth as we are doing now, and we will have no wars.

这一切都意味着一颗极其严肃认真的心，一颗充满爱、从未受过伤害的心。我们人类，从孩提时代起，就饱受伤害。父母伤害我们，在商界也伤害我们。我们四面八方都受到伤害，而当我们受伤时，就无法去爱。那么，一颗饱受伤害的心，是否有可能摆脱所有伤害——这些伤害是意识的一部分呢？当你仔细审视时，你会发现，完全且不可逆转地消除所有伤害是可能的，因此，我们就能去爱，去拥有慈悲。拥有慈悲意味着对万物充满热情，不仅是对两个人之间的情感，而是对所有人类，对地球上的一切，动物，树木，地球上的一切。当我们拥有这样的慈悲时，我们就不会像现在这样破坏地球，也不会有战争。

To a mind that is serious, totally dedicated, concerned, meditation means something extraordinary, something immense. In meditation, mind discovers space. Space is held within a room and there is space outside it. Thought as the “me” creates the narrow space in which it acts; it has created, through hurt, through all kinds of reasons, walls within which it lives. There is that narrow space and the space which thought has created outside of itself. Is there a space which has no frontiers, which has no boundaries and, therefore, no center? This is meditation, to find out.

对于一颗严肃、全神贯注、充满关切的心而言，冥想意味着非凡之事，意义深远之事。在冥想中，心灵发现空间。空间既存在于房间之内，也存在于房间之外。作为“我”的念头创造了它所活动的狭小空间；它因伤痛，因种种原因，筑起了它栖居的围墙。存在着这狭小的空间，以及念头在其自身之外创造的空间。是否存在一个没有边界、没有界限，因而也没有中心的空间？这就是冥想，去探寻。

As long as there is a center, the “me” or the idea of the “me,” with all its attachments, that very center creates a space around itself. Where there is a center, there must be a border. The border may be extended, but it is still limited by the space that the center has created. Meditation means to come upon that space in which there is no center; therefore, no direction; therefore, no time. Without meditation and the coming upon that thing which is not able to be experienced, which is not to be put into words, which has no time, which has no continuity, life has very little meaning. You may have a lot of money, or no money; you may be attached to your property, to your wife, to your friend, or you may worship your particular little god, which thought has invented, but as long as you live there, there will be suffering, pain, anxiety, and violence. And that has no meaning in itself, obviously. Only when you come upon this space—not invent it, not project it, not bring it about through any system—then only does life have an extraordinary sense of beauty and meaning.

只要存在一个中心，即“我”或“我”的概念，以及它所依附的一切，这个中心本身就会在其周围创造一个空间。哪里有中心，哪里就必然有边界。边界可以延伸，但它仍然受限于中心所创造的空间。冥想意味着抵达那个没有中心的空间；因此，没有方向；因此，没有时间。如果没有冥想，没有抵达那个无法体验、无法言说、没有时间、没有连续性的事物，生命就几乎没有意义。你可能拥有很多钱，也可能一无所有；你可能执着于你的财产、你的妻子、你的朋友，或者你可能崇拜你思想所创造的某个小神，但只要你活在那里，就会有痛苦、悲伤、焦虑和暴力。显然，这些本身毫无意义。只有当你抵达这个空间——不是创造它，不是投射它，也不是通过任何系统来实现它——生命才会拥有非凡的美感和意义。

Saanen, July 28, 1974

萨嫩，1974年7月28日

#↩

A RELATIONSHIP WITH THE WORLD

与世界的关系

1

We are the world. The world is you and me, the world is not separate from you and me. We have created this world—the world of violence, the world of wars, the world of religious divisions, sex, anxieties, the utter lack of communication with each other, with no sense of compassion, consideration for another. Wherever one goes in any country throughout the world, human beings, that is, you and another, suffer; we are anxious, we are uncertain, we don’t know what is going to happen. Everything has become uncertain. Right through the world as human beings we are in sorrow, fear, anxiety, violence, uncertain of everything, insecure. There is a common relationship between us all. We are the world essentially, basically, fundamentally. The world is you, and you are the world. Realizing that fundamentally, deeply, not romantically, not intellectually but actually, then we see that our problem is a global problem. It is not my problem or your particular problem, it is a human problem.

我们就是世界。世界就是你和我，世界与你我密不可分。我们创造了这个世界——一个充满暴力、战争、宗教分裂、性、焦虑、人与人之间彻底缺乏沟通、缺乏同情心和对他人的体谅的世界。无论你走到世界哪个国家，无论你走到哪里，人类，也就是你和其他人，都在遭受苦难；我们焦虑不安，我们茫然无措，我们不知道未来会发生什么。一切都变得不确定。作为人类，我们遍布世界各地，都处于悲伤、恐惧、焦虑、暴力之中，对一切都感到不确定，缺乏安全感。我们彼此之间存在着一种共同的关系。从本质上讲，从根本上讲，我们就是世界。世界就是你，你就是世界。从根本上、深刻地认识到这一点，不是浪漫的，也不是理性的，而是切身地认识到，我们就会明白，我们的问题是全球性的问题。这不是我个人的问题，也不是你个人的问题，而是全人类的问题。

So we are dealing with the human, global problem, which is that you as a human being are living in a disintegrating world. So when we talk about relationship, we are talking about the relationship of man to man. When you understand that relationship, then you can come very much closer, which is the relationship between you and your neighbor, you and your wife, you and your son, and so on. Unless you have a global, universal, sense of the whole human being, you will live merely in fragments, as an American, or a European, a communist, a socialist, a Hindu, or a Buddhist—and all the rest of the divisions that man has made. We are concerned with mankind, which is you. Wherever you go, man is suffering, man is afraid, man wants to find out if there is some truth anywhere—if there is any god, if there is anything sacred, whether there is an eternity or only the ending of life and whether man can ever be free from fear, find an end to sorrow.

所以，我们面对的是人类的全球性问题，那就是你作为一个人，生活在一个分崩离析的世界里。当我们谈论关系时，我们指的是人与人之间的关系。当你理解了这种关系，你就能与他人建立更紧密的联系，这种联系包括你与邻居、你与妻子、你与儿子等等之间的关系。除非你对整个人类有全球性的、普世的认知，否则你只能生活在碎片化的世界中，比如美国人、欧洲人、共产主义者、社会主义者、印度教徒、佛教徒——以及人类制造的所有其他分裂。我们关注的是全人类，也就是你。无论你走到哪里，人们都在遭受苦难，都在恐惧，都在渴望探寻真理——是否存在神，是否存在神圣之物，是否存在永恒，还是只有生命的终结，以及人类是否能够摆脱恐惧，找到悲伤的终点。

When we say man we mean woman also; let us not quarrel about words, it becomes rather childish.

我们说“男人”的时候也包括女人；我们不要纠结于字眼，那样很幼稚。

In our examination together, there is no authority, there is no teacher and the taught, there is no guru and the disciple; therefore, there is no authority. In the psychological world, in the world of the spirit, there is no authority. You are not following the speaker or accepting what he is saying. It is good to have a great deal of skepticism, but that skepticism must be kept on a leash, and you must know when to let it go and when to hold it. In examining this vast problem of existence, both of us must be very clear and understand that there is no authority, the one who knows and the other who does not know. Together we are looking into this. Whether you are capable of looking is a different matter. Whether you are intensely, consistently, pursuing the investigation depends on you. If you do not have the energy, the intention, the necessary persistence, then you make authority. If you are lazy, indolent, then you give authority to another. Or if you are disorderly in your life and you see orderliness in another then you make him into an authority. So, please, we are going together to examine without any sense of authority, which means there is freedom to look. Because one of the causes of this disintegrating society in which we live is that we are followers; we accept spiritual authority, the intermediary, the priest, the analyst, as our guide in matters of the spirit. We become incapable when we give ourselves over to another to find out about ourselves. We don’t seem to be able to look into ourselves and examine very closely the whole of human existence—which is yourself. If we are examining, investigating together, and there is no authority, only freedom to examine, see the beauty of it: then you and I have a relationship.

在我们共同的探索中，没有权威，没有老师和学生，没有上师和弟子；因此，没有权威。在心理世界，在精神世界，没有权威。你并非在追随说话者，也并非在接受他所说的话。保持高度的怀疑精神是好事，但这种怀疑精神必须加以约束，你必须知道何时该放手，何时该坚持。在探索这个宏大的存在问题时，我们双方都必须非常清楚，并理解没有权威，没有谁知道谁不知道。我们正在共同探究这个问题。你是否有能力去探究是另一回事。你是否能够投入、持续地进行探究，取决于你自己。如果你缺乏精力、意愿和必要的毅力，那么你就是在赋予权威。如果你懒惰懈怠，那么你就是在把权威赋予他人。或者，如果你生活混乱，而你看到别人井然有序，那么你就是在把他当作权威。所以，请允许我们一起进行一次不带任何权威的审视，这意味着我们可以自由地观察。因为我们所处的这个社会日渐瓦解的原因之一，就是我们盲从；我们接受精神权威、中间人、牧师、分析师等作为我们在精神领域的指引。当我们把自己交给他人去了解自己时，我们就失去了自我。我们似乎无法审视自身，也无法仔细审视整个人类存在——而这本身就是我们自己。如果我们一起审视、一起探索，没有权威，只有审视的自由，那么你就会明白其中的美妙之处：你我之间便建立了一种关系。

In the human being and in the society in which he lives, one of the basic causes of this disintegration, this breaking up, is the utter lack of religious spirit. Religion means accumulating all your energy to investigate truth; to find out, to come upon that state of mind or consciousness in which there is truth that is not invented by thought. One of the factors of disintegration is the utter lack of the religious mind, and another is the lack of morality—not a Christian morality, or Hindu morality, or the morality of permissiveness; morality implies orderliness, basic order. It is not order according to a pattern, according to the convenience of environment, but an order that comes when you understand the nature of disorder, and that morality is a thing that is living.

在人类自身及其所处的社会中，导致这种瓦解和分裂的根本原因之一，便是宗教精神的彻底缺失。宗教意味着倾注所有精力去探寻真理；去发现，去达到那种并非由思想臆造的真理的境界或意识状态。瓦解的因素之一是宗教精神的彻底缺失，另一个因素则是道德的缺失——并非基督教的道德，也非印度教的道德，更非放纵的道德；道德意味着秩序，意味着基本的秩序。这种秩序并非依附于某种模式，也并非为了迎合环境的便利，而是当你理解了混乱的本质，并认识到道德本身就是一种鲜活的事物时，秩序便会自然而然地产生。

This disintegrating world is your mind. You are the essence of society, you are the basis of society in your relationships. And when there is no relationship then there is disintegration. So what is relationship? Relationship is the basis of our existence, the basis of our society, and unless there is deep understanding of that and a transformation in that relationship, we cannot go further into the question of meditation, what is religion, what is truth, and so on. So that is the bedrock upon which we must stand clearly.

这个分崩离析的世界就是你的心智。你是社会的本质，你的人际关系构成了社会的基础。当人际关系消失时，社会就会瓦解。那么，什么是人际关系？人际关系是我们存在的基础，是我们社会的基础。除非我们深刻理解人际关系，并在此基础上进行转变，否则我们无法进一步探讨冥想、宗教、真理等等问题。因此，这才是我们必须牢牢把握的基石。

We must find out what it means to have right relationship, accurate relationship. The word accurate means factually correct. What is relationship? What does it mean to be related to another—at the physical level, sexual level, psychological level, emotional level, intellectual level, and at the level of what one calls love? If that whole nature and structure of relationship is not understood clearly and lived daily, to go to meditate is utterly infantile, has no meaning, because then meditation becomes merely a futile escape. Unless you establish right relationship between you and another, that being the very basis of existence, trying to meditate becomes an evasion of the actual that leads to all kinds of neurotic, destructive results.

我们必须弄清何为正确的关系，何为准确的关系。“准确”一词指的是事实正确。那么，关系究竟是什么？与他人建立联系意味着什么——在生理层面、性层面、心理层面、情感层面、智力层面，以及人们所谓的爱的层面？如果不能清晰地理解关系的本质和结构，并将其融入日常生活，那么冥想就显得幼稚无知，毫无意义，因为那样冥想就沦为徒劳的逃避。除非你与他人之间建立起正确的关系——这才是存在的根本——否则，试图冥想就只是逃避现实，最终只会导致各种神经质的、破坏性的后果。

So what is actual relationship in our daily life with each other? If you examine it very closely, and are not afraid, see what is taking place. You have an image about yourself, don’t you? You have a picture, an idea, a concept of yourself, and the person you are related to has his or her concept, her image, her picture about herself. Please, you are looking at yourself, you are not merely listening to these words. Words are a mirror, and the mirror becomes useless when you are looking at yourself actually. So you and the other, man and woman, boy or girl, or husband and wife, and so on, each human being, has a picture, an image, a conclusion, an idea about herself or himself.

那么，我们日常生活中人与人之间真正的关系究竟是什么呢？如果你仔细审视，并且不畏惧，就会发现其中的奥秘。你对自己有一个认知，不是吗？你对自己有一个画面、一个想法、一个概念，而与你相关的人也对自己有他/她自己的认知、形象和画面。请注意，你是在审视自己，而不仅仅是在听这些话。语言就像一面镜子，当你真正审视自己时，这面镜子就失去了意义。所以，你和他人，男人和女人，男孩和女孩，夫妻等等，每个人都对自己有一个认知、一个印象、一个结论、一个想法。

If you have lived with another for a week, or a hundred weeks, you have made a picture of the other, and the other has made a picture of you. That is a fact, isn’t it? Are you afraid to look at that picture? That picture has been built through many days, many years, many incidents: nagging, pleasure, comfort, fear, domination, possession, attachment, and so on and so on and so on. Each person has an image of the other. That is an actuality, isn’t it? And you call that relationship. That is a relationship between two pictures, between two images. Right? You are not agreeing with the speaker, you are looking at the fact. These pictures or images or conclusions are memories, which each has put together, stored up in the brain. And they are reacting to each other according to those images. You have been hurt, and that hurt is a memory, stored up in the brain, and that reacts. So our relationship is not actual but from memories. If you are married, you have built a picture about your wife, and the wife has built a picture, an image about you. Those pictures, those images are the nagging, the casual remarks, the hurts, the pleasures, the comforts, the sexual memories, all that. And the relationship is between these two verbal pictures in memory; it is not actual; and, therefore, there is always division and conflict. When you have been hurt in that relationship, it is the image you have built about yourself that has been hurt.

如果你和另一个人共同生活了一周，或者一百周，你就会给对方留下印象，对方也会给你留下印象。这是事实，不是吗？你害怕面对这幅印象吗？这幅印象是由无数个日日夜夜、无数次的相处经历构建而成的：唠叨、愉悦、舒适、恐惧、支配、占有、依恋等等。每个人都对对方有一个印象。这是现实，不是吗？而你称之为关系。这其实是两幅印象、两个影像之间的关系。对吗？你并非在赞同说话者的观点，而是在审视事实。这些印象、影像或结论都是记忆，是彼此拼凑起来、储存在大脑中的。它们会根据这些印象相互影响。你曾受到伤害，而这种伤害也是一种记忆，储存在大脑中，并会引发反应。所以，我们的关系并非基于现实，而是基于记忆。如果你已婚，你也会给妻子留下印象，妻子也会给你留下印象。那些画面，那些影像，是那些挥之不去的念头、那些不经意的言语、那些伤痛、那些快乐、那些慰藉、那些性爱的回忆，所有的一切。而这种关系存在于记忆中这两个语言化的画面之间；它并非真实存在；因此，分裂和冲突总是存在的。当你在那段关系中受到伤害时，你所构建的自我形象也受到了伤害。

I wonder if you are actually observing it in yourself, or listening to the speaker and agreeing with the speaker. They are two different facts. If you are agreeing with the speaker, that has very little significance. Do you actually see that you have built an image about yourself and that hurt exists because of that image?

我想知道你是否真的在观察自己，还是只是在听演讲者发言并表示赞同。这两者截然不同。如果你只是赞同演讲者，那意义不大。你是否真正意识到，你已经为自己塑造了一个形象，而这种伤害正是源于这个形象？

So in this relationship of human beings, hurt has taken place. The image has been hurt. Unless you heal that image totally there must always be conflict. There are past hurts and you may receive further hurts. You have been hurt in the past; unfortunately this happens from childhood—in school, in college, at home. Right throughout life one is hurt, and because one is hurt, one builds a wall around oneself to resist, not to be hurt anymore. And when one builds a wall around oneself, division takes place. You may say, “I love you,” but it is just words, because a division exists.

所以，在人际关系中，伤害已经发生。彼此的形象受到了伤害。除非你彻底治愈这种形象，否则冲突将永远存在。过去已有伤痛，你也可能再次受到伤害。你过去曾受过伤害；不幸的是，这种情况从童年就开始了——在学校、大学、家里。人的一生都在遭受伤害，正因为如此，人们才会筑起一道墙来抵御伤害，不再受伤害。而当一个人筑起这道墙时，隔阂就产生了。你或许会说“我爱你”，但这仅仅是空话，因为隔阂已经存在。

Is it possible not to be hurt at all? Which doesn’t mean build a wall of resistance so that nothing can touch you, but to live without resistance, which means never to be hurt.

是否有可能完全不受伤害？这并不是说要筑起一道抵御一切的屏障，让任何东西都无法触及你，而是说要生活在没有抵抗的状态中，这意味着永远不会受到伤害。

Do you know what it means to be hurt? When a child is compared with another, that is a hurt. Any form of comparison hurts. Any form of imitation, conformity, hurts, not only verbally but deeply. And when one is hurt, out of that hurt there is violence. So is it possible never to be hurt? How are we to deal with past hurts and prevent future hurts? We will find out.

你知道受伤是什么滋味吗？当一个孩子被拿来和另一个孩子比较时，那就是伤害。任何形式的比较都会造成伤害。任何形式的模仿和从众都会造成伤害，不仅是言语上的伤害，更是心灵深处的伤害。而当一个人受到伤害时，这种伤害往往会滋生暴力。那么，我们有可能永远不受伤吗？我们该如何处理过去的伤害，又该如何预防未来的伤害呢？我们将一一探寻答案。

When you say, “I am hurt,” what is this “I” that is hurt? You say, “You have hurt me”—by your word, by a gesture, by discourtesy, and so on and so on—what is hurt? Is it not the image that you have built about yourself? Please, do look at it. That image is one of the factors that society, education, and environment have built in you. “You” are that picture, that image, the name, the form, the characteristics, the idiosyncrasies, and so on. All that is you, the picture, the image which you are. And that image has been hurt. You have a conclusion about yourself, that you are this or that, and when that conclusion is disturbed you are hurt. So can you live without a conclusion, without a picture, without an image about yourself? As long as you have an image about yourself, you are everlastingly hurt. You may resist it, you may build a wall around yourself, but when there is a wall around yourself, when you withdraw, there is a division, and where there is a division there must be conflict—as with the Arab and the Jew, the Hindu and the Muslim, the communist and the noncommunist. Where there is a division, it is the law that there must be conflict.

当你说“我受伤了”时，这个受伤的“我”究竟是什么？你说“你伤害了我”——用你的言语、你的举动、你的无礼等等——究竟是什么受伤了？难道不是你对自己塑造的形象吗？请仔细审视一下。这个形象是社会、教育和环境在你身上塑造的因素之一。“你”就是那幅画，那个形象，那个名字、那个形态、那些特征、那些怪癖等等。所有这一切构成了你，构成了你本身的那幅画，那个形象。而这个形象受到了伤害。你对自己有一个结论，认为你是这样或那样，当这个结论被动摇时，你就会受伤。那么，你能没有结论，没有画像，没有自我形象吗？只要你对自己有一个形象，你就永远处于受伤的状态。你或许会抗拒，或许会筑起高墙将自己围起来，但当你筑起高墙，当你退缩时，分裂便会产生；而分裂之处，必然伴随着冲突——就像阿拉伯人和犹太人、印度教徒和穆斯林、共产主义者和非共产主义者之间那样。分裂之处，必然伴随着冲突，这是必然规律。

So is it possible not to be hurt at all? That is, to have an innocent mind, a mind that is incapable of being hurt. It is very important to find out if one can live that in daily life. Not go off to some monastery or some community where you all agree together, becoming mushy and sentimental, but actually in daily life to find out if you can live without an image and, therefore, never be hurt, which means never to have conflict, never to have psychological division. We are going to find out. We are going to examine whether it is possible to live that way.

那么，是否有可能完全不被伤害呢？也就是说，拥有一颗纯洁无瑕、不会受伤的心灵。弄清楚自己能否在日常生活中做到这一点至关重要。这并非是要去某个寺院或团体，在那里大家意见一致，变得矫揉造作、多愁善感，而是要在日常生活中真正地去探索，看看自己能否放下成见，从而永远不被伤害，这意味着永远不与人冲突，永远不经历心理分裂。我们将去寻找答案。我们将去探究，是否真的能够这样生活。

First be aware that one has this image. When I have an image about myself and that is hurt, and my wife has an image about herself and she is hurt, how can we have any kind of relationship? So is it possible not to have an image, which means not to be hurt? One has been hurt in the past, and one has resisted it, built a wall around oneself, is frightened of being hurt more; therefore, withdraws, becomes isolated. Now how will you deal with the past hurts? Will you analyze why you have been hurt, the causes of your hurt? Will you go into it analytically?

首先要意识到，每个人都有自己的形象。如果我对自己有一个受伤的形象，而我的妻子也对自己有一个受伤的形象，我们又怎能建立任何关系呢？那么，是否有可能不形成任何形象，从而避免受伤呢？过去，有些人曾受过伤害，他们抗拒这种伤害，在自己周围筑起一道墙，害怕再次受伤；因此，他们选择退缩，变得孤立。现在，你将如何处理过去的伤痛？你会分析自己受伤的原因吗？你会深入分析吗？

Look at the analytical tradition. We have accepted analysis as part of our life. If you cannot analyze yourself you go to the professional. What is the process of analysis? There is the analyzer and the analyzed. See the division already. But is not the analyzer the analyzed? So you have created an artificial division between the analyzer and the analyzed, but in actuality the analyzer is the analyzed. So there is a fundamental error in the process of analysis. And in the process of analysis you take time—days, months, years—playing the game and enriching each other in your own peculiar ways, financially and emotionally, and all the rest of it. So, realizing that fundamental error in the process of analysis, how is one to be free of all the past hurts, and any hurts that may come in the future?

看看分析的传统。我们已经把分析视为生活的一部分。如果你无法进行自我分析，就会去找专业人士。分析的过程是什么？分析者与被分析者之间存在着泾渭分明的界限。但分析者不就是被分析者吗？你人为地在分析者和被分析者之间制造了一种隔阂，但实际上，分析者本身就是被分析者。因此，分析过程存在一个根本性的错误。在分析过程中，你会花费时间——数天、数月、数年——玩弄这种游戏，并以各自独特的方式在经济、情感以及其他方面相互滋养。那么，意识到分析过程中的这个根本性错误之后，一个人该如何摆脱过去所有的伤痛，以及未来可能出现的任何伤痛呢？

The speaker and you are sharing this question, to find out actually, in daily life, whether it is possible to live without a single hurt, because then you will know what love is.

说话者和你正在探讨这个问题，是为了弄清楚在日常生活中是否有可能在没有受到任何伤害的情况下生活，因为那样你才能真正了解什么是爱。

Hurt and flattery are the same, aren’t they? Both are different forms of hurts. You are flattered, and you like it, and the flatterer becomes your friend. So that also is another form of encouraging the image. The one you want, the other you don’t want. We are now dealing only with what we don’t want, which is not to be hurt; but we want the other, which is pleasurable, which is comforting, pleasing to the images that we have. So both are the same. Now how am I, how is a human being, to be free of hurt? So we have to go into the question of what it is to be attentive.

伤害和奉承其实是一样的，不是吗？它们都是伤害的不同表现形式。你受到奉承，并且喜欢这种感觉，奉承者也成了你的朋友。所以，奉承也是强化某种形象的一种方式。你想要一个，不想要另一个。我们现在只讨论我们不想要的，也就是不被伤害；但我们想要的是另一个，即愉悦的、令人感到安慰的、符合我们既有形象的东西。所以，两者本质上是一样的。那么，我，或者说一个人，该如何才能摆脱伤害呢？这就需要我们去探究“专注”的本质是什么。

What does it mean to attend? If you know what it means to attend, it may solve the problem. Have you ever given total attention to anything? Complete attention in which there is no center from which you attend? When there is a center from which you attend then there is a division. Let’s put it differently. You know what it is to be aware. One is aware of the trees under which we are sitting, aware of the branches, the color of the branches and their thickness, of the leaves, the shadows, aware of all the nature, the beauty of it. [The Ojai talks took place in the open in a grove of oaks.] Then you are also aware of sitting on the ground, the color of the carpet, the microphone. And can you be aware of all this, the microphone, the carpet, the earth, the color of the leaves, and so on, the blue shirt, be aware of all that without any choice? To look at it without any choice, judgment, just to look.

专注意味着什么？如果你明白专注的意义，或许就能解决问题。你是否曾全神贯注于某件事？那种完全的专注，没有任何中心点？当你有一个中心点时，就会产生隔阂。换个说法。你知道什么是觉察。你会觉察到我们坐着的树，觉察到树枝，觉察到树枝的颜色和粗细，觉察到树叶，觉察到阴影，觉察到大自然的一切，觉察到它的美丽。[奥海的演讲是在一片橡树林中露天举行的。] 然后你也会觉察到自己坐在地上，觉察到地毯的颜色，觉察到麦克风。你能否觉察到这一切——麦克风、地毯、泥土、树叶的颜色等等，还有那件蓝色的衬衫——而不加任何选择地觉察到这一切？不加任何选择、不加任何评判地去观察它，只是单纯地观察。

If you can look without any judgment, without any choice, just observe, in that observation there is no observer. The moment the observer comes in prejudice begins, the like and the dislike, “I prefer this, I don’t prefer that,” division takes place. So there is attention only when there is no entity who says, “I am attending.” Please, it is important to understand this. Because if there is attention, when there is an awareness in which there is no choice, no judgment, merely observation, then you will see you will never be hurt again, and the past hurts are wiped away. But the moment the observer comes in then the observer gets hurt.

如果你能不带任何评判，不加任何选择地观察，那么在观察之中，便不存在观察者。一旦观察者介入，偏见便随之而来，好与坏，“我喜欢这个，我不喜欢那个”，分裂便产生了。因此，只有当没有“我在关注”这样的主体介入时，才能真正地关注。请务必理解这一点。因为如果存在关注，如果存在一种没有选择、没有评判、只有观察的觉知，那么你会发现你将不再受到伤害，过去的伤痛也会被抹去。但一旦观察者介入，观察者自身也会受到伤害。

So, when there is complete attention, there is no hurt. If someone says the speaker is a fool or arrogant; in listening to the word and giving complete attention to it, there is no past hurt or future hurt because there is no entity who is observing. Please, this is very important, because as long as there is a division there must be conflict. It is very important, in dealing with fear, with pleasure, with sorrow, with death, to see that as long as there is a division between the observer, the experiencer, the thinker and the thought, there must inevitably be conflict, division, fragmentation and, therefore, disintegration. So can you observe the tree, yourself, your neighbor, observe life completely attentively? Then can you observe with total attention the picture that you have about yourself? And when you give that complete attention is there a picture at all?

所以，当全神贯注时，就不会有伤害。如果有人说说话者愚蠢或傲慢；那么，在聆听言语并全神贯注时，就不会有过去的伤害或未来的伤害，因为没有旁观者的存在。请记住，这一点非常重要，因为只要存在分裂，就必然存在冲突。在面对恐惧、快乐、悲伤和死亡时，我们必须明白，只要观察者、体验者、思考者和思想之间存在分裂，就必然存在冲突、分裂、碎片化，最终导致瓦解。那么，你能否全神贯注地观察树木、观察自己、观察邻居、观察生活？你能否全神贯注地观察你对自己的认知？当你全神贯注时，你的认知中是否还存在？

When there is no image, no picture, no conclusion, then what is the relationship between two human beings? Now our relationship is based on division, which is an obvious fact. The man goes to the office where he is brutal and ambitious, greedy; then he comes home and he says, “Darling, how lovely you are.” So there is contradiction in our life and, therefore, our life is a constant battle and, therefore, there is no relationship. To have real human relationship is to have no image whatsoever, no picture, no conclusion. And it is quite complex, because you have memories. Can you be free of memories of yesterday’s incidents? All that is implied. Then what is the relationship between two human beings who have no images? You will find out if you have no image. That may be love.

当没有形象、没有画面、没有结论时，两个人之间的关系又是什么呢？如今，我们的关系建立在分裂之上，这显而易见。一个人去办公室时冷酷无情、野心勃勃、贪婪成性；回到家，他却说：“亲爱的，你真可爱。”我们的生活充满矛盾，因此，我们的生活是一场永无休止的斗争，因此，关系也就不存在了。真正的人际关系意味着没有任何形象、画面或结论。这其实很复杂，因为记忆无处不在。你能摆脱对昨日事件的记忆吗？这一切都不言而喻。那么，两个没有形象的人之间的关系又是什么呢？当你不再有形象时，你就会明白。那或许就是爱。

So can one live, actually in daily life, without division; which means without war, without conflict?

那么，在日常生活中，我们真的可以生活在没有分裂、没有战争、没有冲突的世界里吗？

Ojai, April 3, 1976

奥海，1976年4月3日

2

All our life is based on thinking. All our actions are the result of thought, either from the deep past, or from immediate necessities according to environment. Thought guides our whole life. Thought has divided us into nations, classes, into religious sects, beliefs—with their dogmas, rituals. Thought has built the churches—Catholic, Protestant, Hindu, and the various Eastern religious structures and propaganda. I think this is irrefutable fact.

我们的生活建立在思考之上。我们的一切行为都是思考的结果，或源于遥远的过去，或源于当下环境的需要。思考指引着我们的一生。思考将我们划分为不同的国家、阶级、宗教派别和信仰——以及它们的教条和仪式。思考构建了教会——天主教、新教、印度教以及各种东方宗教的组织和宣传体系。我认为这是无可辩驳的事实。

What is thought? Why has it become such an extraordinarily important factor in our life? Our education, our relationship is based on thought, on image, verbal structure. It is all put together by thought. Why is it that thought has become so persistent, continuous, and divisive?

思想是什么？为什么它在我们生活中变得如此重要？我们的教育、人际关系都建立在思想、图像和语言结构之上。这一切都由思想构建而成。为什么思想变得如此持久、持续，又如此具有分裂性？

In examining why thought has become so extraordinarily important, we have also to go into the question of consciousness. Consciousness is filled with thought and the things of thought. Whether it is conscious or unconscious, deep down it is still the movement of thought, from the past, meeting the present, and creating the future. All that is the movement of thought. Movement implies time. Thought implies measurement. So thought is a movement, time and measure. What is the process of thought? What is the nature and the structure of thought? That is our life: we act, we live according to certain patterns laid down by thought, consciously or unconsciously, deep down. It seems extraordinarily important to understand thought because thought has divided people, nationally, geographically, according to their beliefs, according to their dogmas. Thought has built up the whole memorial structure as the “me” and the “you,” the ego, the personality, and so on.

在探究思想为何变得如此重要时，我们也必须深入探讨意识的问题。意识充满了思想以及思想的种种事物。无论这种思想是有意识的还是无意识的，其本质都是思想的运动：从过去出发，与现在相遇，并创造未来。这一切都是思想的运动。运动意味着时间。思想意味着度量。因此，思想既是运动，又是时间，也是度量。那么，思想的过程是什么？思想的本质和结构是什么？这就是我们的生活：我们行动，我们生活，都遵循着思想设定的某些模式，无论是有意识的还是无意识的，都根植于我们的内心深处。理解思想似乎至关重要，因为思想已经将人们按国家、地域、信仰和教条划分开来。思想构建了整个记忆结构，形成了“我”与“你”、自我、人格等等。

We are trying to find out if there is another consciousness that is not put together by thought and, therefore, we must examine this consciousness as we know it, which is filled with the things of thought. What is the source of thinking? Why is thinking, thought, fragmentary? From where does thought come? What is the nature of consciousness, and why is that consciousness filled with all this movement of thought? One must discover for oneself what is the beginning of thought.

我们试图探寻是否存在一种并非由思维构建的意识，因此，我们必须审视我们所知的、充满思维的意识。思维的源泉是什么？为什么思维，也就是思想，是碎片化的？思想从何而来？意识的本质是什么？为什么意识中充满了思想的种种活动？我们必须自己去发现思想的起源。

Isn’t thought a reaction of memory? Memory is knowledge stored up as experience. There is an experience, knowledge of that experience as memory, and the response of that memory is thinking. So the source of thinking is in the past. So thought springs from the past. If you examine it, all our lives are based in the past, our roots are in the past. Knowledge is the past, there is no knowledge of the future, or of the present. There is knowledge of the present only when there is a complete understanding of what the structure and the nature of the past is—and ending it.

思想难道不是记忆的反应吗？记忆是储存为经验的知识。存在着经验，对经验的认知以记忆的形式存在，而对这种记忆的反应就是思想。因此，思想的源泉在于过去。所以，思想源于过去。仔细审视，你会发现我们所有的生活都根植于过去，我们的根基也在于过去。知识就是过去，我们无法预知未来，也无法预知现在。只有当我们彻底理解过去的结构和本质，并终结过去之后，才能真正了解现在。

So thought is the response of the movement from the past. The past is stored up in the brain as experience and knowledge. And why is thought fragmentary? Why has thought built divisions between people—as Christians, Buddhists, communists, socialists, capitalists, believers and nonbelievers, and so on? Is there an action that is not based on thought, that is not divisive, that is not fragmentary, in which there is no regret, pain, sorrow? The fragmentary process is seen in our daily life as the “me” and the “you,” “we” and “they,” the Christian, the non-Christian, and so on and so on and so on. That fragment of thought may think there is God, but God then is still the product of a fragment.

所以，思想是对过去运动的回应。过去以经验和知识的形式储存在大脑中。那么，为什么思想是碎片化的？为什么思想会在人与人之间制造隔阂——比如基督徒、佛教徒、共产主义者、社会主义者、资本家、信徒和非信徒等等？是否存在一种不基于思想、不具分裂性、不具碎片化的行为，其中不包含悔恨、痛苦和悲伤？这种碎片化的过程在我们日常生活中表现为“我”和“你”、“我们”和“他们”、“基督徒”、“非基督徒”等等。这种碎片化的思想或许认为上帝存在，但上帝仍然是碎片化的产物。

Thought has filled our consciousness with its own fragments, and then thought says, “I must go beyond this fragment, I must find enlightenment, I must find God, I must find truth, I must find Nirvana,” whatever you like to call it. A fragment is trying to understand that which is whole—that which is sane, healthy, holy—the word whole implies all that. So the fragment has been trying to grasp or come upon that which is whole. So it meditates, it controls, it tries to follow a system in order to arrive at that, but it is still the movement of time as a fragment in measure.

思想将自身的碎片充斥着我们的意识，然后思想说：“我必须超越这碎片，我必须找到觉悟，我必须找到上帝，我必须找到真理，我必须找到涅槃”，无论你怎么称呼它。碎片试图理解整体——那理智、健康、神圣的事物——“整体”一词蕴含着这一切。因此，碎片一直在试图把握或抵达整体。所以它冥想，它控制，它试图遵循某种体系以达到目标，但它仍然是时间流逝中碎片化的存在。

So why is thought a fragment? Why has it become a fragment? Why has thought divided you and me, we and they, the Buddhist, communist, socialist? Can thought see the whole? Can thought see itself as a fragment? Or can it never see itself, see its own limitation, see its own fragmentary movement and, therefore, never see the whole?

那么，为什么思想是碎片化的？为什么它会变成碎片化的？为什么思想会分裂你我、我们与他们、佛教徒、共产主义者、社会主义者？思想能看到整体吗？思想能看到自身的碎片化吗？或者它永远无法看到自身，看不到自身的局限性，看不到自身碎片化的运动，因此也永远无法看到整体？

Now leave it there for the moment and we will come to it in a different way.

暂时先放在这里，我们以后再用另一种方式来讨论这个问题。

Does one realize, see that one’s consciousness is its content? The content of consciousness makes consciousness. If you are a Christian, the content of your consciousness, all the beliefs, the dogmas, the rituals, the reactions, the attachments, the anxieties, the fears, the sorrows, the aspirations, the images which you have built about yourself and about others, all your conclusions, your prejudices, all that is the content of your consciousness. It is so. So your consciousness is made up of the things it contains. And the content of consciousness is filled by the things of thought—your scholastic knowledge, the knowledge of your own experiences, prejudices, and so on. So your consciousness is fragmentary. And within that area we are trying to find reality, truth, by expanding it, trying to go beyond it.

你是否意识到，你的意识就是它的内容？意识的内容构成了意识本身。如果你是基督徒，那么你意识的内容，包括你所有的信仰、教条、仪式、反应、执着、焦虑、恐惧、悲伤、渴望，以及你对自己和他人的认知，你所有的结论和偏见，所有这些都构成了你意识的内容。的确如此。所以，你的意识是由它所包含的事物构成的。而意识的内容则由思想填充——你的学术知识、你自身的经验、偏见等等。因此，你的意识是碎片化的。而我们正是在这个碎片化的领域中，试图通过拓展它、超越它来寻找现实和真理。

Are you just accepting my words or are you observing for yourself, watching the content of your own consciousness, and seeing that it is filled with all the things that you have accumulated? Not only the things you have accumulated, but what the past generations have accumulated—the traditions, the manner of behaving. All that is your consciousness, and because it is fragmentary and, therefore, divisive, it must always be in conflict. Thought realizes this and then says to itself, “I must go beyond it”—through meditation, through control, through suppression, through various forms of enlarging consciousness. This is the game we are playing all the time, holding on to our content, and trying to go beyond it.

你只是接受我的话，还是在亲自观察，审视你自身意识的内容，并发现它充满了你积累的一切？不仅是你积累的，还有过去几代人积累的——传统、行为方式。所有这些都构成了你的意识，而由于它是碎片化的，因而具有分裂性，它必然总是处于冲突之中。思想意识到这一点，然后告诉自己：“我必须超越它”——通过冥想、控制、压抑，通过各种形式的意识扩展。这就是我们一直在玩的游戏：执着于我们已有的内容，并试图超越它。

So thought cannot see the whole, because it is fragmentary. If thought could see the whole it would be the whole, it would not make an effort to be the whole—the whole being healthy, not divisive, sane, and holy. But it is not. Now, the observer is fragmentary; it says, “I am conscious of the limitations of my thought.” That observer is the past and the past, which is fragmentary, makes every action fragmentary. The past is the knowledge, experience, all the things that human beings have gathered together for centuries and centuries. And we think the ascent of man lies through knowledge. One questions whether knowledge is the instrument of ascent, although various professors and experts say knowledge is the way because knowledge is the past. The movement of thought is time, and we think time will make us progress, evolve, grow, but time is also fragmentary.

所以，思想无法看到整体，因为它本身就是碎片化的。如果思想能够看到整体，它本身就会成为整体，它就不会费力去追求整体——一个健康、不分裂、理智且神圣的整体。但事实并非如此。如今，观察者本身也是碎片化的；它说：“我意识到我思想的局限性。”这个观察者就是过去，而碎片化的过去使得每一个行动都带有碎片化的特征。过去是知识、经验，是人类几个世纪以来积累的一切。我们认为人类的进步在于知识。人们不禁要问，知识真的是进步的工具吗？尽管许多教授和专家都认为知识是途径，因为知识本身就是过去。思想的运动就是时间，我们认为时间会让我们进步、进化、成长，但时间本身也是碎片化的。

There are two kinds of time: physical, chronological time by the watch—yesterday, today, and tomorrow—and the psychological time of “I will be,” a psychological tomorrow, where I shall be able to achieve enlightenment, where I will be perfect. But is there psychological time at all, or is it still the invention of thought? We are trying to find out if there is an action that is not based on the past and, therefore, divisive. Is there an action that is complete, whole, not caught in the net of time?

时间有两种：一种是物理的、按时间顺序排列的时间，例如手表上的“昨天”、“今天”和“明天”；另一种是心理上的时间，即“我将成为”的未来，一个心理上的明天，在那里我将能够证悟，我将臻于完美。但是，心理时间真的存在吗？或者它仅仅是思想的产物？我们试图探寻是否存在一种不基于过去、因而也无所依附的行动。是否存在一种完整、圆满、不受时间束缚的行动？

After seeing the action, the movement that is going on in the world—and in ourselves, which is the world—one wants to find out if there is an action not based on a conclusion—because conclusion is the movement of thought—action that is not based on an ideal, which is again fragmentary, action not based on a prejudice, an action that is every moment whole, complete, so that in that action there are no regrets, no sorrows, no pain. Don’t you want to find such an action? We live with action that is painful, in which there is always uncertainty, regrets—“I wish I hadn’t done that.” One knows the action that brings regret, pain, sorrow, confusion, and so on, and one wants to find out if there is an action that is whole and, therefore, complete; into which none of the regrets, or the poisonous movements, enter. I think this is what whatever is intelligent in a human being demands, and not being able to find it one invents an outside agency—if I can reach God, then I will know complete action. He will never reach God because God is his own invention! So we are going to find out if there is an action that is whole, sane, healthy, rational and, therefore, holy.

在目睹世间万物——以及我们自身（即世界本身）——的种种行动和运动之后，人们不禁想要探寻是否存在一种不基于任何结论的行动——因为结论不过是思维的产物——一种不基于理想（理想本身也是碎片化的）、不基于偏见的行动，一种每一刻都完整圆满的行动，以至于其中没有任何遗憾、悲伤或痛苦。难道你不想找到这样的行动吗？我们生活在充满痛苦的行动之中，其中总是充斥着不确定性和遗憾——“我真希望我没做过那件事”。人们熟知那些带来遗憾、痛苦、悲伤、困惑等等的行动，因此，人们想要探寻是否存在一种完整圆满的行动；一种没有任何遗憾或有害念头的行动。我认为这就是人类智慧所追求的，而当人们无法找到它时，便会臆造出一种外在的力量——如果我能与上帝沟通，那么我就能领悟到圆满的行动。他永远无法接近上帝，因为上帝是他自己创造出来的！所以我们要探究是否存在一种完整、理智、健康、理性，因而也是神圣的行为。

Why has thought invented an ideal? The ideal is the opposite of what is . The ideal is in the future, and what is is actual. One does not know how to deal with the actual, how to understand it, how to go beyond it and, therefore, not being able to understand it, one projects an ideal, which is fictitious, which is not actual. So there is the division between what is and the ideal and, hence, conflict. Thought, being fragmentary, is not capable of understanding what is actually in the present. It thinks it will understand by creating an ideal and trying to follow that ideal and, therefore, it brings more and more conflict. But if one is capable of looking at the present, the actual, the what is , without the principle, without the ideal, without the observer, who is the past, then one meets the actual.

为什么思想要创造理想？理想与现实截然相反。理想存在于未来，而现实是真实存在的。人们不知道如何面对现实，如何理解它，如何超越它，因此，由于无法理解现实，人们便投射出一个理想，一个虚构的、非现实的理想。于是，现实与理想之间产生了分裂，冲突也由此产生。思想本身是碎片化的，它无法理解当下的真实存在。它以为可以通过创造一个理想并试图遵循这个理想来理解现实，因此，它带来了越来越多的冲突。但是，如果一个人能够抛开原则、抛开理想、抛开作为过去的观察者，去审视当下、审视现实、审视“存在”，那么他就能触及现实本身。

Can one look at what is without a prejudice, without prejudgment? Can you look at what is without the observer, who is the past? Say you are envious of people, how do you look at that envy? Are you looking at it as an observer who is different from envy? You look at it as though you are separate from envy, but the fact is that you are envy. You are not the observer who is different; the observer himself is that. So the observer is the observed. Please, this is really very important to understand. When you have grasped the truth that the observer is the observed, then that which is observed undergoes radical change. What prevents a radical change of what is is the interference of the observer, who is the past. To understand this removes all conflict.

能否不带偏见、不带预设地看待事物本身？能否抛开作为“过去”的观察者，去看待事物本身？假设你嫉妒别人，你会如何看待这种嫉妒？你是否以一个与嫉妒不同的观察者的身份去看待它？你似乎认为自己与嫉妒分离，但事实上，你就是嫉妒本身。你并非那个不同的观察者；观察者本身就是那个不同的观察者。因此，观察者即是被观察者。请记住，理解这一点至关重要。当你领悟到观察者即是被观察者的真谛，被观察者便会发生根本性的改变。阻碍事物发生根本性改变的，正是作为“过去”的观察者的干预。理解这一点，便能消除一切冲突。

We are educated to conform to the division of the observer and the observed, and the observer is always trying to do something about the observed. He says, “I am envious; I will find it reasonable to be envious; if I am not envious what will happen in society?”; I suppress it, rationalize it, or justify it, which are all a process of conflict. Out of that conflict we have all kinds of violence. But the actual fact is that the observer is the observed. And, therefore, the division ends. When there is only observation of the fact, the fact undergoes radical transformation. So can one live a life in which there is no conflict whatsoever? That is to be perfectly sane. It is the unbalanced, the insane, who are always in conflict.

我们受教育要遵循观察者与被观察者的二元对立，而观察者总是试图对被观察者做些什么。他会说：“我嫉妒；我认为嫉妒是合理的；如果我不嫉妒，社会会变成什么样？”；我会压抑这种嫉妒，为它辩解，或者为它开脱，所有这些都是冲突的过程。各种暴力都源于这种冲突。但事实是，观察者本身就是被观察者。因此，这种二元对立就此终结。当只有对事实的观察时，事实本身就会发生根本性的转变。那么，人能否过上完全没有冲突的生活呢？那才是真正的理智。只有那些精神失常、精神错乱的人，才会永远处于冲突之中。

So one wants to find a way of living in which there is no conflict, in which thought, which is the movement in time as measure, which creates division, can realize its own limitation and function where it is absolutely necessary, and not enter into the psychological field at all. Thought has built the psyche, the psychological states, which is me, my ego. And thought is fragmentary; therefore, what it has created, the “me,” is fragmentary. Then thought says, “I must integrate with the whole”—which is an impossibility. So can thought realize, itself, that it is a fragment, and that whatever movement it makes must be fragmentary? Can it realize that there is an action that is not fragmentary, which can only take place when the observer is the observed, and that in that, that which is undergoes a radical change.

因此，人们想要找到一种没有冲突的生活方式，在这种方式中，思想——作为时间尺度上的运动，它制造分裂——能够认识到自身的局限性，并在绝对必要的地方发挥作用，而完全不涉足心理领域。思想构建了心灵，构建了心理状态，也就是我，我的自我。而思想是碎片化的；因此，它所创造的“我”也是碎片化的。然后思想说：“我必须融入整体”——这是不可能的。那么，思想能否意识到自身是碎片化的，以及它所做的任何运动都必然是碎片化的？它能否意识到存在一种非碎片化的行动，这种行动只能在观察者成为被观察者时发生，并且在这种状态下，存在本身会发生根本性的改变？

Our consciousness is filled with the things of thought and, therefore, our consciousness is fragmentary. Is there a consciousness that is not fragmentary, and can thought find it? Is there a consciousness that is not put together by thought? We have divided the universe as the “me” and the “you,” “we” and “they,” good and evil. We have divided it, that is, thought has divided it. And then thought says to itself, “Is there a consciousness that is not put together by me?” Now how are you, a human being, going to find out if there is a consciousness that is not put together by thought? Man has tried this for millennia. It isn’t just now that we are trying it. He has said there must be another consciousness that is not this kind of consciousness. And so he says, “I must control thought; there must be a system by which thought can be controlled, and then when thought is controlled, held, perhaps I will know what the other is.” And this is the whole basis of meditation: control thought. But he doesn’t ask who the controller is. The controller is still thought.

我们的意识充斥着思想，因此，我们的意识是碎片化的。是否存在一种不碎片化的意识？思想能否找到它？是否存在一种并非由思想构建的意识？我们将宇宙划分为“我”与“你”、“我们”与“他们”、“善”与恶。是我们划分了它，也就是说，是思想划分了它。然后，思想会问自己：“是否存在一种并非由我构建的意识？”那么，作为一个人，你该如何找到这种并非由思想构建的意识呢？人类已经尝试了数千年。我们并非刚刚开始尝试。人类认为，一定存在另一种不同于这种意识的意识。于是，人类说：“我必须控制思想；一定存在一种可以控制思想的系统，然后，当思想被控制、被掌控时，或许我就能知道另一种意识是什么。”这就是冥想的全部基础：控制思想。但他并没有追问谁是控制者。控制者仍然是思想。

So, to find out, to come upon that which is not put together by thought, we have to understand the place of thought as knowledge and where thought has no place whatsoever, without suppressing it. Thought has a place as knowledge in our daily, superficial activities: driving a car, working in a factory, writing. It is only possible to give knowledge its right place when you have understood the whole nature of thinking. The psyche, the “me,” has been put together by thought—my virtue, my temperament, my desires, my ambitions, my peculiar idiosyncrasies, my experience as opposed to your experience. Those are all the result of thought. Thought as knowledge has its right place, but it has no place in the psyche. That means, can the mind, can this whole structure of the psyche cease to be? Then only is there a totally different kind of consciousness—which you will never find through meditation.

所以，为了探寻，为了领悟那些并非由思维构建的事物，我们必须理解思维作为知识的地位，以及思维完全无处容身之处，但又不压制它。思维作为知识存在于我们日常的、肤浅的活动中：开车、在工厂工作、写作。只有当你理解了思维的全部本质，才能赋予知识应有的位置。心灵，即“我”，是由思维构建的——我的美德、我的性情、我的欲望、我的抱负、我独特的个性、我与你截然不同的经历。这些都是思维的结果。作为知识的思维自有其存在的意义，但在心灵中却无处容身。这意味着，心灵，这整个心灵结构，能否不复存在？只有那时，才会存在一种截然不同的意识——而这种意识你永远无法通过冥想找到。

All the things that thought has put together is reality. But thought has not put together the mountain or the tree, and that is also a reality. All the gods, all the rituals, all the mischief that is being made in the world by thought, is a reality—war is a reality, killing people is a reality, the violence, the brutality, the callousness, the destruction, is a reality made by thought, put together by thought. The mountains, the trees, the rivers, the beauty of the sky, is a reality but it is not put together by thought. Belief is a reality put together by thought but it is neurotic. The neuroticism is a reality. And truth is not reality. Thought can never touch truth. Then what is the relationship between truth and reality?

一切由思想组合而成的事物都是现实。但山川树木并非由思想构成，而它们也是现实。所有的神灵、所有的仪式、所有由思想在世间制造的祸害，都是现实——战争是现实，杀戮是现实，暴力、残暴、冷漠、毁灭，都是由思想创造、由思想组合而成的现实。山川树木、河流河流、天空之美，都是现实，但它们并非由思想构成。信仰是思想组合而成的现实，但它是神经质的。神经质本身也是一种现实。而真理并非现实。思想永远无法触及真理。那么，真理与现实之间究竟存在怎样的关系呢？

We have examined the nature of thought. We said thought is a material process, matter, because it is stored up in the brain, part of the cell, which is matter. So thought is a material process in time, in movement. And whatever that movement creates is reality—the neurotic as well as the so-called fragmentary are realities. The actual is a reality, like the microphone. And nature is also a reality. So what is truth? Can thought, which is fragmentary, which is caught up in time, mischievous, violent, find truth, truth being the whole, that which is sacred, holy? And if it cannot find it, then what is the relationship of thought, of reality, to that which is absolute?

我们已经探讨了思维的本质。我们说过，思维是一种物质过程，是物质，因为它储存在大脑中，而大脑是细胞的一部分，细胞本身也是物质。所以，思维是时间中、运动中的物质过程。而这种运动所创造的一切就是现实——神经质的以及所谓的碎片化都是现实。实际存在本身也是一种现实，就像麦克风一样。自然也是一种现实。那么，真理是什么？思维，这种碎片化的、受时间束缚的、充满恶意和暴力的思维，能够找到真理吗？真理是整体，是神圣的、圣洁的。如果它找不到真理，那么思维，这种现实，与绝对真理之间又存在着怎样的关系呢？

You know, all this demands meditation. This is real meditation, not the things imported into this country by the gurus. Can consciousness, which is its content, ever expand to include consciousness of truth? Or does this consciousness of the psyche, the “me” with all its content, have to end before the perception of what is truth? One has to find out what is the nature of the psyche, which has been put together by thought. What is “me”—the vanity, the arrogance, the desire to achieve, to become successful—to which one clings so desperately? What is the nature of it? How has it come about? Because if that exists, the other cannot be. If I am egotistic, as long as that psychic center exists, truth cannot possibly be, because truth is the whole.

你知道，这一切都需要冥想。这是真正的冥想，而不是那些大师们引进到这个国家的那些东西。意识，作为其内容，能否扩展到包含真理的意识？或者，这种心灵的意识，即包含其所有内容的“我”，是否必须在感知真理之前就终结？我们必须探寻心灵的本质，它是由思想构建而成的。“我”——虚荣、傲慢、渴望成就、渴望成功——究竟是什么？它如此执着于此，它的本质是什么？它是如何产生的？因为如果它存在，其他一切就不可能存在。如果我是自我中心的，只要这个心灵中心存在，真理就不可能存在，因为真理是整体。

So how is the mind—the mind being all the senses, the emotions, the memories, the prejudices, the principles, the ideals, memories, experiences, the totality of that, which is the psyche, which is the me—how is that to end and yet act in this world? Is that possible?

那么，心灵——心灵包含所有感官、情感、记忆、偏见、原则、理想、记忆、经验，即心灵的整体，即“我”——它如何才能结束，又如何在这个世界上发挥作用？这可能吗？

To find that out one must go very deeply into the question of fear, the very complex problem of pleasure, and the question of sorrow and whether sorrow can ever end. Man has lived with sorrow for millennia upon millennia. He hasn’t been able to end it. And one must also go into the question of what is death and love. Because all that is the matrix of the me. So this is a very, very serious affair, it is not just a thing to be played with. One must give one’s whole life to understand this. To live in this world completely, sanely, without the psyche; not escape, not go off into some monastery or commune, but to live here, in this mad, insane, and murderous world where there is so much corruption, where politics are divorced from ethics. To live in this world sanely, without the psyche, the “me,” is a tremendous challenge. That requires a mind that can think meticulously, correctly, objectively, having all the senses fully awakened, not drugged by alcohol, speed, and all the rest of it. You must have a very healthy mind, and when it is drugged or smoking, drinking, you do not have a healthy mind; all that destroys the mind, makes the mind dull.

要找到答案，就必须深入探究恐惧、快乐的复杂问题，以及悲伤——悲伤是否终将消逝。人类与悲伤相伴数千年，却始终无法摆脱它。此外，还必须探究死亡和爱的本质，因为这一切都构成了“我”的母体。所以，这是一件极其严肃的事情，绝非儿戏。我们必须倾尽一生去理解它。在这个世界上，完全清醒地生活，摆脱“我”的束缚；不是逃避，不是遁入修道院或公社，而是生活在这个疯狂、荒诞、充满杀戮的世界，在这个腐败横行、政治与伦理脱节的世界。在这个世界上，清醒地生活，摆脱“我”的束缚，这本身就是一个巨大的挑战。这需要一颗思维缜密、正确、客观，且所有感官都完全清醒的心智，而不是被酒精、安非他命或其他毒品麻痹的头脑。你必须拥有非常健康的头脑，而当你的头脑被毒品、香烟或酒精麻痹时，你就无法拥有健康的头脑；所有这些都会摧毁头脑，使头脑迟钝。

Ojai, April 4, 1976

奥海，1976年4月4日

3

If one single human being understands radically the problem of fear and resolves it, not tomorrow or some other day but instantly, he affects the whole consciousness of mankind. That is a fact. As we have said, your consciousness is not your private property, it is the result of time, of thousands of incidents, experiences, that are put together by thought. That consciousness is in constant movement. It is like a stream, a vast river of which you are a part. So there is no particularization; and if you go into it very deeply, there is no individuality. You may not like that, but look at it. Individual means an entity who is undivided, indivisible, who is not fragmented, who is not broken up but is a whole being. But most of us, unfortunately, are fragmented, broken up, divided, like the rest of the world—unhappy, concerned, confused, miserable, aching, frightened.

如果一个人能够从根本上理解恐惧的问题并立即解决它，而不是等到明天或以后，他就能影响全人类的意识。这是事实。正如我们所说，你的意识并非你的私有财产，它是时间的产物，是无数事件和经历通过思想组合而成的结果。这种意识处于持续运动之中。它就像一条溪流，一条浩瀚的河流，而你只是其中的一部分。因此，意识中不存在特殊性；如果你深入探究，你会发现它并不存在个体性。你或许不喜欢这样，但请仔细思考。个体指的是一个不可分割、不可分裂、不破碎、不支离破碎的整体。但不幸的是，我们大多数人都是支离破碎、支离破碎的，就像世界上其他人一样——不快乐、忧虑、困惑、痛苦、悲伤、恐惧。

So we are going together to explore the question of fear and whether it can end. We are sharing it together. Fear can be very little or an enormous burden. There is fear of losing a job, fear of not being successful, fear of death, fear of not being loved, fear of loneliness, isolation, fear of deep insecurity, the fear of being dependent, fear of not doing the right thing, or the fear of following the rest of the crowd, or being left behind. You know what fears are. Man has never been able psychologically to be free of fears. Fear has burdened his mind, darkened his outlook. He does not know how to deal with these fears; therefore, he escapes from them into violence, brutality, arrogance, bitterness.

所以，我们一起来探讨恐惧的问题，以及它是否可以终结。我们共同分享这个问题。恐惧可大可小，轻则微不足道，重则难以承受。人们害怕失去工作，害怕失败，害怕死亡，害怕不被爱，害怕孤独，害怕被孤立，害怕极度缺乏安全感，害怕依赖他人，害怕做错事，害怕随波逐流，害怕被落下。你们都知道恐惧是什么。人类在心理上从未真正摆脱过恐惧。恐惧压垮了他们的心，蒙蔽了他们的双眼。他们不知道该如何应对这些恐惧；因此，他们选择逃避，诉诸暴力、残暴、傲慢和怨恨。

What is the root cause of fear? Please look into yourself. Use the words as a mirror to discover your own fear and as you observe find out the root of it; not the branches, the leaves, the trivialities of fear, but the fundamental cause of fear. Because if there is fear psychologically, inwardly, every action becomes distorted, and there is no meticulous, clear observation.

恐惧的根源是什么？请审视内心。用文字作镜，发现你内心的恐惧，并在观察中找出它的根源；不是恐惧的枝叶、琐碎之处，而是恐惧的根本原因。因为如果内心深处存在恐惧，那么你的每一个行为都会扭曲，你也就无法进行细致清晰的观察。

What is the root of fear? Is it not being able to find complete security, psychologically, inwardly? Complete, total certainty, security. Is it that we are seeking permanency, something that will endure, that will last, that is final? Is there the uncertainty of not being? First let us see if there is security psychologically; because we may be seeking psychological security and, therefore, creating insecurity in the outward world. What is security, psychologically, inwardly? What do we mean by being secure, having firm, certain, enduring, unshakable, immovable, security so that nothing can shake it, break it down? Is that what you are seeking in relationship between each other? Having complete knowledge and depending on that knowledge to give us stability? That means seeking permanency, something that nothing can change and, therefore, eternity in the sense of putting an end to time.

恐惧的根源是什么？是无法在心理上、在内心深处找到完全的安全感吗？是完全的、彻底的确定性、安全感吗？我们是否在寻求永恒，某种能够持续、长久、最终的事物？是否存在着不存在的不确定性？首先，让我们看看心理上是否存在安全感；因为我们可能正在寻求心理上的安全感，因此反而会在外部世界中制造不安全感。心理上、在内心深处，安全感究竟是什么？我们所说的安全感，是指拥有坚定、确定、持久、不可动摇、不可撼动的安全感，以至于没有任何东西能够动摇它、摧毁它吗？这是否就是你在彼此关系中所寻求的？拥有完全的知识，并依靠这些知识来获得稳定？这意味着寻求永恒，某种任何事物都无法改变的事物，因此，也意味着寻求终结时间的永恒。

So, is time one of the factors of fear? There is time by the watch, time as yesterday, today, and tomorrow. Chronological time is necessary, it is there. Is there psychological time? Is there for me, for you, psychologically, tomorrow? If there is not, there is immense fear. If you are confronted with the fact that there is no tomorrow psychologically, your whole foundation is shaken; because tomorrow you are going to have greater pleasure, tomorrow you will be better, tomorrow you will achieve, tomorrow you will get rid of your fear. So psychologically is there tomorrow?

那么，时间是恐惧的因素之一吗？手表上的时间，昨天、今天、明天，都是时间。时间是必要的，它确实存在。那么，心理上的时间存在吗？对我而言，对你而言，心理上真的存在明天吗？如果不存在，就会产生巨大的恐惧。如果你面对着心理上没有明天的现实，你的整个根基都会动摇；因为明天你会拥有更大的快乐，明天你会变得更好，明天你会有所成就，明天你会摆脱恐惧。所以，心理上真的存在明天吗？

Tomorrow means time. Tomorrow implies thought, which is in itself fragmentary; it has created psychological time, in which you will move from what is to “what should be.” So is time a factor of fear? Time exists, but is there time at all psychologically: to make an effort to be something? Or, is fear of not being? What is this everlasting demand for self-expression, the “me” expressing itself, the “me” and the “you,” the “I,” the ego? Tackle this, because it is your life, and if you understand this and are free of fear, you open the door to heaven.

明天意味着时间。明天意味着思考，而思考本身就是碎片化的；它创造了心理时间，在这个时间里，你会从“现实”走向“理想”。那么，时间是恐惧的因素吗？时间确实存在，但心理层面上真的存在时间吗？用来努力成为某种人？或者，恐惧源于不存在？这种对自我表达的永恒渴望，这种“我”的表达，“我”与“你”，“我”，即自我，究竟是什么？正视这个问题，因为这关乎你的人生，如果你理解了这一点，并且摆脱了恐惧，你就打开了通往天堂的大门。

What is this “me” that says, “I must be,” “I must meditate,” “I must find God,” “I must realize,” “I must be happy,” “I am lonely,” “I must be successful,” “I am frightened,” “I must be told”? Is it not the name, Mr. So-and-so, the form, the form being the body that you see in the mirror, and all the associated memories, all the concepts about yourself, the image about yourself, the image that says, “I am much better than you are”? Are they not all put together by thought? Thought itself is a fragment, and the activity of that fragment is not only the “me,” but the fragments it has created all round you—separate nations, separate classes, wars, the whole of that. And thought is a material process in time. Thought is the response of memory, experience, knowledge, stored up in the brain.

这个“我”究竟是什么？它说着“我必须存在”、“我必须冥想”、“我必须找到上帝”、“我必须领悟”、“我必须快乐”、“我很孤独”、“我必须成功”、“我很害怕”、“我必须被告知”？难道它不是“某某先生”这个名字，不是“形体”——也就是你在镜子里看到的那个身体，以及所有与之相关的记忆、所有关于你自身的概念、关于你的形象，那个告诉你“我比你强得多”的形象？难道它们不都是由思想组合而成的吗？思想本身就是一个碎片，而这个碎片的活动不仅构成了“我”，还构成了它在你周围创造的各种碎片——不同的国家、不同的阶级、战争，以及所有这一切。思想是一个在时间中发生的物质过程。思想是对储存在大脑中的记忆、经验和知识的回应。

So the “me” to which we cling is fictitious. That may be the root cause of fear, clinging to something that is nonexistent. So, there is the fictitious, imagined me, a picture, a symbol, an idea, an image, put together by thought in time, which is a material process, measurement. And that “me,” being uncertain of its very existence, deeply, in the very depths of one’s being, may be the deep fundamental cause of fear. That doesn’t mean that if you have no “me” you cannot live in this world. On the contrary.

所以，我们所执着的“我”是虚构的。这或许是恐惧的根源——执着于并不存在之物。因此，存在着一个虚构的、想象的“我”，一幅图画、一个符号、一个观念、一个图像，由思想在时间中构建而成，而时间本身就是一个物质过程，一种衡量标准。而这个“我”，由于其自身存在的不确定性，在人的内心深处，或许正是恐惧的根本根源。但这并不意味着，如果你没有“我”，你就无法在这个世界上生存。恰恰相反。

Now can you look at the movement of time? Time is movement. The ending of that movement is putting a stop to time. That is one of the major factors of meditation, so that time comes to an end, psychologically. So deep-rooted fear is the movement of thought in time, which is a material process, which has created an artificial structure called the “me,” and having created it clings to it. Thought clings to a fragment that it has created, and thought itself is a fragment. There is fear in relationship, because in relationship we have created the image of you and me. The man and the woman each has an image of the other, a picture, a symbol, put together by time, of many days, many years, or an hour. And their relationship is between these two images. Look into it and you will see the actuality of it. We cling to the picture, to the image, and we are frightened of losing that image. So we are forced to look at each other totally differently if there is no image.

现在你能观察一下时间的流动吗？时间即是运动。运动的终结就是时间的停止。这是冥想的主要因素之一，即在心理层面上让时间终结。因此，根深蒂固的恐惧是思想在时间中的运动，这是一个物质过程，它创造了一个名为“我”的人造结构，并且一旦创造了它，就紧紧抓住它不放。思想紧紧抓住它所创造的碎片，而思想本身也是一个碎片。恐惧存在于人际关系中，因为在人际关系中，我们创造了你和我之间的形象。男人和女人各自拥有对方的形象，一幅图画，一个符号，由时间——可能是许多天、许多年，也可能只是一个小时——组合而成。他们的关系就存在于这两个形象之间。深入观察，你就会明白其中的本质。我们紧紧抓住这幅图画，这幅形象，我们害怕失去它。所以，如果没有这幅图画，我们就不得不以完全不同的视角看待彼此。

We have described in words the nature, the quality, the structure, of this thing called fear. Now, knowing that the description is not the described, can you look not at the description but at the fact? Can you look at it? That is, can you observe it?

我们已经用文字描述了恐惧这种东西的本质、特质和结构。现在，既然我们知道描述并非被描述之物，那么你能否不去看描述本身，而是去看事实呢？你能否正视它？也就是说，你能否观察它？

It is very important to learn how to observe. There is an art in observation. “Art” means putting things in their proper place, putting everything where it belongs. Can you observe this thing called fear? Are you, the observer, different from the thing observed? When you are angry, or envious, or jealous, or whatever it is, are you different from that feeling which we have named as “jealousy”? Or you are jealousy? So the observer is the observed. To put it differently, is the thinker different from his thought? Or again differently, is the experiencer different from the experience? If he is not different, then why do you seek experiences? If there is no difference between the observer and the observed, then there is only the observed. Then there is only thinking, not the thinker different from thought.

学会观察至关重要。观察是一门艺术。“艺术”意味着将事物放在合适的位置，让一切都各归其位。你能观察到恐惧这种东西吗？作为观察者的你，与被观察的对象有何不同？当你生气、嫉妒、羡慕，或者其他任何情绪时，你与我们称之为“嫉妒”的那种感觉有何不同？或者你就是嫉妒本身？所以，观察者就是被观察者。换句话说，思考者与他的思想有何不同？或者再换个说法，体验者与体验有何不同？如果他没有不同，那么你为何还要追求体验？如果观察者和被观察者之间没有区别，那么就只有被观察者。那么就只有思考，而不是与思想不同的思考者。

You want experiences. You are bored with the experiences that you have had already, the daily experiences of sex, this, that, and the other, so you want other experiences—experience of god, experience of enlightenment, experience of Jesus, experience of Krishna consciousness. And you have never asked who the experiencer is, and whether he is different from the experienced. You want to experience Krishna consciousness, or the consciousness of Jesus, or something else, but to experience that, you must recognize it, mustn’t you? That means you have already known it . Therefore, the experiencer is the experienced.

你想要体验。你厌倦了已有的体验，比如每日的性爱、其他种种，所以你想要其他的体验——体验神、体验开悟、体验耶稣、体验克里希那意识。你从未问过体验者是谁，他与被体验者有何不同。你想体验克里希那意识，或者耶稣的意识，或者其他什么，但要体验它，你必须先认识它，不是吗？这意味着你已经知道它了。因此，体验者就是被体验者。

So can you look at fear without the observer? Because you are the fear, fear isn’t different from you. When you are angry, is that anger different from you? If you say it is different, then you try to control it, then you try to rationalize it, then you try to do something about it. But if the observer is the observed, you can’t do anything about it, you are that. So observe fear without the observer.

那么，你能抛开观察者的身份去审视恐惧吗？因为你就是恐惧本身，恐惧与你并无二致。当你愤怒时，愤怒与你自身有何不同？如果你认为它与你不同，那么你就会试图控制它，试图为它辩解，试图采取行动。但如果观察者本身就是被观察的对象，你就无能为力，因为你就是恐惧本身。所以，抛开观察者的身份去审视恐惧吧。

One realizes in observing that fear is not different from the observer. When the observer is the observed there is fundamental change in that which is observed. When there is division between the observer and the observed, in that division there is conflict. I say I must get rid of it, I must control it, or ask why should I not have fear, why should I not have neurotic actions out of those fears. There is always contradiction, division, and, therefore, conflict—which is a wastage of energy. It is a wastage of energy when there is conflict, trying to control, running away, going to somebody to tell me how to get rid of fear. All those are factors of wasting energy. If you don’t waste energy—and that only takes place when the observer is the observed—then you have that immense energy to transform what is . The very observation is the energy which transforms “that which is.” Get this, and then you will see that you are completely free from psychological fears.

观察者会发现，恐惧与观察者本身并无二致。当观察者成为被观察者时，被观察的对象便会发生根本性的改变。当观察者与被观察者之间存在隔阂时，这种隔阂便会产生冲突。我会说我必须摆脱恐惧，我必须控制它，或者会问自己为什么不应该感到恐惧，为什么不应该因为恐惧而做出神经质的行为。矛盾、隔阂总是存在的，因此也必然会产生冲突——而冲突本身就是一种能量的浪费。当冲突发生时，试图控制、逃避、寻求他人指导如何摆脱恐惧，这些都是能量的浪费。所有这些都是能量的浪费。如果你不浪费能量——而这只有在观察者成为被观察者时才会发生——那么你便拥有了巨大的能量去转化“存在”。观察本身就是转化“存在”的能量。领悟这一点，你就会发现，你将彻底摆脱心理恐惧的束缚。

If you have listened with all your heart and your mind, then when you get up you are free of fear. That means you have listened. That means it is your problem and it is absolutely necessary to solve it, not tomorrow, but instantly. That is, when you perceive something, then you act instantly, and that perception is only possible when the perceiver is the perceived, because there you have total energy. Total observation is only possible when there is no observer—the observer being the past. When there is that total attention given to observation, that which is observed undergoes a fundamental transformation. Got it? Do it!

如果你全心全意地聆听，那么当你醒来时，你将不再恐惧。这意味着你已经聆听。这意味着这是你的问题，而且必须立即解决，不是明天。也就是说，当你感知到某事时，你必须立即行动。而这种感知只有在感知者即被感知者时才有可能，因为那时你拥有全部的能量。只有当没有观察者——观察者即过去——时，才能进行全然的观察。当全然的注意力集中于观察时，被观察的事物将发生根本性的转变。明白了吗？去做吧！

Ojai, April 10, 1976

奥海，1976年4月10日

4

Why does the human mind pursue pleasure? We are not saying that there should not be pleasure, but we are going to investigate into the nature of pleasure because apparently human beings are everlastingly committed to pleasure.
