Why is there this great demand for pleasure, the easiest way of action, the most comfortable way of living, the pursuit not only of physical, sensory pleasures, but psychological pleasures? And the ultimate pleasure is God, enlightenment. What is pleasure? It may be the other side of the coin of fear. Most human beings disregard fear, do not know how to deal with fear, and pursue pleasure constantly.

人类的心灵为何追求快乐？我们并非否定快乐的存在，而是要探究快乐的本质，因为人类似乎永远都在追求快乐。为何人类如此渴望快乐，追求最便捷的行动方式、最舒适的生活方式，不仅追求生理和感官上的愉悦，也追求心理上的快乐？而最终的快乐，便是神性，是觉悟。快乐究竟是什么？它或许是恐惧的另一面。大多数人忽视恐惧，不知如何应对恐惧，却不断地追求快乐。

Through culture, through tradition, through our habits, the environment, and so on, part of our brain has become mechanistic. Is pleasure mechanistic? Is it the repetition of a certain delight of yesterday, either sexual or otherwise, which becomes a memory, and we pursue the memory as pleasure? We are concerned with the transformation of the human mind. We cannot live as we are living. There must be a radical change in our minds, in our hearts, in our whole way of living, and so it is very important to find out why we human beings have been caught in this everlasting pursuit of pleasure.

通过文化、传统、习惯、环境等等，我们大脑的一部分已经变得机械化。快乐也是机械性的吗？它是否只是对昨日某种愉悦（无论是性方面的还是其他方面的）的重复，这种愉悦最终会变成记忆，而我们又将这种记忆当作快乐来追求？我们关注的是人类思维的转变。我们不能再像现在这样生活下去了。我们的思想、我们的内心、我们的整个生活方式都必须发生根本性的改变，因此，探究我们人类为何会陷入这种永无止境的快乐追求之中至关重要。

Now look at it. Yesterday there were some delightful incidents, something that you liked immensely happened. That is registered in the brain, it becomes a memory. Then thought says, “I must have more of that.” It is the repetition of an incident which is over, which was considered pleasure by thought, the pursuit of it today and tomorrow. That is mechanistic, mechanical, obviously.

现在想想。昨天发生了一些令人愉快的事情，一些你非常喜欢的事情。这些都被大脑记录下来，变成了记忆。然后，你的思维会说：“我必须再来一次。” 这就是对已经结束的事件的重复，而这些事件曾被你的思维视为快乐，你今天和明天都在追求它。这显然是机械的、机械式的。

What is the difference between pleasure, enjoyment, and joy? There are three things: pleasure, enjoyment, and joy. You can cultivate pleasure—taste, all sensory activities. Can you cultivate enjoyment? Or can you cultivate joy? Joy comes uninvited, by some curious chance. You find yourself suddenly, extraordinarily, unspeakably happy. Then thought takes it over and says, “I must have more of it.” So the moment thought interferes with that thing called joy, which is uninvited, it becomes pleasure. Therefore, it becomes mechanistic.

快乐、享受和喜悦之间有什么区别？快乐、享受和喜悦是三者。你可以培养快乐——味觉，以及所有感官活动。你能培养享受吗？你能培养喜悦吗？喜悦往往不期而至，仿佛是某种奇妙的巧合。你会发现自己突然间感到无比幸福，这种幸福难以言喻。然后，思维占据了主导，并说：“我必须拥有更多。” 因此，当思维干预到那不期而至的喜悦时，它就变成了享受。因此，它变得机械化了。

So that is our life, a way of living, that is constantly repetitive, constantly going over something that was, that is already dead, making it live through thought and pursuing that as pleasure. You can look at something beautiful, the trees and the clouds and the light. But when thought comes in and says, “That was a most lovely thing,” it is already finished. So can you watch the beauty of nature, the beauty of this world, with all your senses and not let thought come in? Then enjoyment is completely for the moment, but when thought takes it over, it becomes pleasure and it becomes mechanistic. Please, this requires a mind with a tremendous sense of alertness, watchfulness, awareness. Experiment with it now as we are talking. Look at the trees, the sunlight, the beauty of the hills, the shadows, the playing of those shadows among the hills, the valleys. It is a delight. Can you watch it without thought coming into it, and end it there, not wanting to continue it? What has continuity becomes mechanistic. In that which has an ending, there is a new beginning. Got it?

这就是我们的生活，一种不断重复的生活方式，不断地重温那些已经逝去的事物，通过思考赋予它们新的生命，并以此为乐。你可以欣赏美丽的景色，比如树木、云朵和阳光。但当思绪涌入，说“那真是太美好了”时，一切就结束了。那么，你能否用所有的感官去欣赏自然之美，欣赏这世界的美好，而不让思绪进入你的视野呢？那样，享受就完全属于当下。但当思绪占据主导，它就变成了机械式的享乐。请记住，这需要一颗拥有极强警觉性、敏锐观察力和觉察力的心。就在我们谈话的此刻，不妨尝试一下。看看树木，看看阳光，看看山峦的美景，看看光影，看看光影在山峦和山谷间交错的景象。那是一种享受。你能否在不让思绪进入的情况下欣赏这一切，并就此结束，不再想要继续？持续的事物会变得机械。而结束的事物，往往蕴藏着新的开始。知道了？

Now, you had an insight into this, didn’t you? Please, watch it carefully. You had an insight; is that insight the product of thought? So you have found something. That is, when there is an insight and action through insight, it is not mechanistic. Insight or intelligence is not the product of thought; it is nonmechanistic action. Whenever thought takes over the moment of delight, it becomes mechanistic. You saw that. The perception of that is intelligence, isn’t it? Can you act always according to that intelligence, not according to the repetitive movement of thought? Do you see the difference?

现在，你对此有所领悟，对吧？请仔细观察。你有所领悟；那么，这种领悟是思考的产物吗？所以你有所发现。也就是说，当领悟产生并付诸行动时，它并非机械式的。领悟或智慧并非思考的产物；它是非机械式的行动。每当思考凌驾于愉悦的瞬间之上，它就变成了机械式的。你看到了。对这种愉悦的感知就是智慧，不是吗？你能否始终按照这种智慧行事，而不是按照重复的思维模式行事？你明白其中的区别吗？

So we see the movement of pleasure, based upon desire, desire being sensation. To watch the trees, the clouds, the heavens and the stars and the moon, is a tremendous sensation if you watch it with all your senses. Then thought comes in. So where there is sensation plus thought there is a desire. That is, the sensations, the activity of the senses at their highest, plus thought, is desire. Do you see that? How do you see it? You see it because your intelligence is observing it. That intelligence is not the product of thought.

所以我们看到，愉悦的流动源于欲望，而欲望即感觉。如果你用所有感官去观察树木、云朵、天空、星辰和月亮，那将是一种巨大的感觉。然后，思想便随之而来。因此，感觉加上思想，便产生了欲望。也就是说，感觉，即感官活动达到顶峰的状态，加上思想，就构成了欲望。你明白了吗？你是如何明白的？你明白是因为你的智慧在观察它。而这种智慧并非思想的产物。

Have you considered why human beings suffer, both biologically as well as inwardly, why there are tears? What is this suffering, this sorrow? Can it ever end, or is it an everlasting movement from the beginning of mankind to our end? Must man put up with it, live with it?

你是否思考过人类为何会遭受痛苦，无论是生理上的还是心理上的？为何会有眼泪？这痛苦、这悲伤究竟是什么？它会终结吗？还是说，它会从人类诞生之初一直延续到我们生命的终结？人类是否必须忍受它，与它共存？

Organized religions, based on authority and belief, have never solved this problem. Christianity says somebody suffered for you, and you carry on. Hindus and the Buddhists have their own explanations. So man has lived with sorrow from the most ancient days. Can sorrow end? If there is no ending to sorrow, there is no compassion, there is no love. We think suffering is necessary, or we think there is no solution to suffering; therefore, we must escape from it. And we have developed a marvelous network of escapes.

以权威和信仰为基础的有组织的宗教从未解决这个问题。基督教说有人为你受苦，所以你继续生活下去。印度教和佛教也有各自的解释。因此，自古以来，人类就与悲伤相伴。悲伤可以终结吗？如果悲伤永无止境，就不会有怜悯，也不会有爱。我们认为苦难是必要的，或者我们认为苦难无解；因此，我们必须逃避它。而我们已经发展出一套精妙绝伦的逃避之道。

What is sorrow? There is this thing called sorrow, which is pain, grief, loneliness, a sense of total isolation, no hope, no sense of relationship or communication, total isolation. Mankind has lived with this great thing and perhaps cultivated it because he does not know how to resolve it. We are going to find out if there is an end to sorrow, because without the ending of sorrow there is no love. When there is love will you suffer for another? When there is love will there be sorrow? You might have sympathy, kindliness, generosity, sharing, but love is something totally different, a different dimension, which one can come upon only when sorrow ends.

什么是悲伤？世间存在一种叫做悲伤的东西，它是痛苦、悲伤、孤独、彻底的孤立感、绝望、与人失去联系和沟通的能力，以及完全的孤立。人类一直与这种巨大的痛苦共存，或许还助长了它，因为人类不知道如何化解它。我们将探寻悲伤是否有尽头，因为没有悲伤的终结，就没有爱。当爱存在时，你会为他人承受痛苦吗？当爱存在时，还会有悲伤吗？你或许会有同情、善良、慷慨和分享，但爱却截然不同，它属于另一个维度，只有当悲伤终结之时，才能抵达。

There is sorrow when someone dies whom you “love.” You feel utterly lonely when you have lost someone upon whom you have depended. When you feel that you cannot climb the ladder of success, when someone whom you think you love does not return it, when your beliefs, in which you have false security, are shattered; when your mother or father dies, or son or brother dies, there is sorrow.

当你“爱”的人去世时，你会感到悲伤。当你失去你依赖的人时，你会感到无比孤独。当你觉得自己无法攀登成功的阶梯，当你以为自己爱的人没有回应你的爱，当你赖以获得虚假安全感的信念破碎时；当你的父母、儿子或兄弟去世时，你会感到悲伤。

What actually takes place when you suffer? Not biologically, physiologically, but psychologically, which is much more penetrating, much deeper, much more excruciating. You may shed tears, escape from it, never look at it, but it is always there. Sorrow is the lot of human beings, everyone knows it. We escape from it, rationalize it, justify it, or say that every human being suffers so I must suffer. Or if you are prejudiced religiously, you say it is the work of God. Now all those are ways and means of escaping from the fact of what is , which is sorrow. Now if you don’t escape, that is, if there is no rationalizing, no avoiding, no justifying, just remaining with that totality of suffering, without the movement of thought, then you have all that energy to comprehend the thing that you call sorrow.

当你遭受痛苦时，究竟发生了什么？并非生理上的，而是心理上的，这种心理上的痛苦更加深刻、更加剧烈、更加难以承受。你或许会流泪，或许会逃避，或许会视而不见，但它始终存在。悲伤是人类的宿命，人人皆知。我们逃避它，为它辩解，为它开脱，或者说每个人都会受苦，所以我也必须受苦。如果你有宗教偏见，你会说这是上帝的旨意。所有这些都是逃避现实——也就是悲伤——的方式。如果你不逃避，也就是说，如果你不去辩解、不回避、不开脱，只是全然地感受着痛苦，不去思考，那么你就能拥有足够的能量去理解你称之为悲伤的事物。

If you remain without a single movement of thought, with that which you have called sorrow, there comes a transformation in that which you have called sorrow. That becomes passion. The root meaning of sorrow is passion. When you escape from it, you lose that quality which comes from sorrow, which is complete passion, which is totally different from lust and desire. When you have an insight into sorrow and remain with that thing completely, without a single movement of thought, out of that comes this strange flame of passion. And you must have passion, otherwise you can’t create anything.

如果你能全然放下一切杂念，静静地感受你所谓的悲伤，那么悲伤本身就会发生转变，转化为激情。悲伤的本义就是激情。当你逃避悲伤时，你便失去了悲伤所蕴含的那种特质——纯粹的激情，它与欲望截然不同。当你洞悉悲伤，并全然地与它同在，不带一丝杂念时，那奇异的激情之火便会从中燃起。你必须拥有激情，否则你将一事无成。

Out of passion comes compassion. Compassion means passion for all things, for all human beings. So there is an ending to sorrow, and only then you will begin to understand what it means to love.

慈悲源于激情。慈悲意味着对万物、对所有人的热情。如此，悲伤终将消逝，唯有如此，你才能开始理解爱的真谛。

So one has to have an insight into fear, insight into relationship, insight into the whole structure and nature of thought, thought that breeds fear, that pursues pleasure, and into the ending of sorrow. If you have an insight into all that, you have that intelligence that transforms your mechanistic activity into something totally nonmechanistic. Don’t go away and think about it! You have no time. When you think about what has been said, then your thinking becomes traditional, mechanistic, and empty, but as you are sitting there, sharing this thing, it is happening now. It must happen now, otherwise it will not ever happen, because thought will prevent it. Thought has no insight. Have an insight into what we have pointed out, knowing the description is not the described, and it must take place instantly, now. Thinking about it is just a waste of time. When you are sharing something, you are sharing it now.

所以，你必须洞察恐惧，洞察人际关系，洞察思想的整体结构和本质——那些滋生恐惧、追求享乐的思想，以及终结悲伤的思想。如果你洞察了这一切，你就拥有了那种智慧，能将你机械式的行为转化为完全非机械式的行为。别走开去思考！你没有时间。当你思考刚才所说的内容时，你的思维就会变得传统、机械、空洞，但当你坐在那里分享这件事时，它正在发生。它必须现在就发生，否则它永远不会发生，因为思想会阻止它。思想没有洞察力。要洞察我们指出的内容，明白描述并非事实，而且它必须立即发生，就在此刻。思考它只是浪费时间。当你分享某件事时，你就是在分享当下。

Ojai, April 11, 1976

奥海，1976年4月11日

5

We have loaded the word love with so much meaning, mostly sensual. Using that word, knowing all the complications of that word, the meaning of that word, we must explore together the structure and the nature of that thing called love.

我们赋予了“爱”这个词太多含义，其中大部分是感官上的。在使用这个词，了解它所有复杂的含义之后，我们必须共同探索“爱”的结构和本质。

Is love desire or pleasure? What is desire and how does it arise? How does it flower? What is the root of it? How does it come into being? Apparently for most of us love is intimately connected with desire—sexually, psychologically, biologically, and spiritually. The objects of desire vary, but the root of desire is the same. So how does desire come into being in each one of us?

爱是欲望还是快乐？欲望是什么？它如何产生？如何萌芽？它的根源是什么？它如何形成？显然，对我们大多数人来说，爱与欲望紧密相连——在性、心理、生理和精神层面都是如此。欲望的对象各不相同，但欲望的根源却是一样的。那么，欲望在我们每个人身上是如何产生的呢？

Religions based on belief, religions of authority, which are not religion at all, have said that to serve God you must be free of desire. So the monks, the Indian sannyasis , try to suppress desire, and in the process of repression identify themselves with an image, with a name, and thereby think they have solved the problem. They are burning inside with desire but they suppress it through rituals, through discipline, through every form of conformity, effort. This has been a great problem for human beings who are very serious to find out if there is truth, because desire breeds illusion. Desire breeds experiences, and when you cling to an experience, that becomes an illusion. We have identified love with desire.

那些基于信仰的宗教，那些权威至上的宗教——它们根本算不上宗教——声称侍奉上帝必须摆脱欲望。于是，僧侣，那些印度的苦行僧，试图压抑欲望，并在压抑的过程中将自己与某种形象、某种名号等同起来，以此自以为解决了问题。他们内心燃烧着欲望，却通过仪式、纪律、各种形式的顺从和努力来压制它。这对于那些认真探寻真理的人来说一直是个难题，因为欲望滋生幻觉。欲望孕育体验，而当你执着于某种体验时，它就变成了幻觉。我们把爱等同于欲望。

Is not desire sensation—that is, the activity of the senses, plus thought? Sensations plus thought is desire. Is that fact or just a statement of an idea? Can you look at something with all your senses completely? And in that looking end it and not let thought come into the activity of sensation? That is, when you look at the trees, the mountains, the face of a human being, the endless movement of the sea, with all your senses, all your eyes and ears and nerves, can you look at it completely and not allow thought to come in, to interfere with it? Then your perception is whole, whereas when thought interferes with that perception, it becomes fragmentary. So desire is fragmentary.

欲望难道不是感觉——也就是感官活动加上思想吗？感觉加上思想就是欲望。这是事实还是仅仅是一种观念的陈述？你能否用所有感官完整地观察某物？并在观察的过程中完全专注于它，而不让思想介入感觉活动？也就是说，当你用所有感官，用你的眼睛、耳朵和神经去观察树木、山峦、人的面容、无尽的大海时，你能否完整地观察它，而不让思想介入，不让它干扰观察？那时你的感知是完整的；而当思想干扰感知时，感知就会变得支离破碎。欲望也是如此。

Unfortunately, or fortunately—it is up to you—we have identified desire with that thing called love. Is love desire? Is love attachment? When you are attached to something you are that. When you have totally identified with something, you are that. Why is there this urge to identify, to be attached? Why is one human being attached to another? Does not attachment breed fear, fear of losing what one is attached to? Being attached, you may become jealous, frightened, anxious, which are obvious phenomena. You are attached because of your own insufficiency, loneliness. And so out of your own insufficiency, loneliness, a sense of lacking, you cling to another. So is attachment love? Where there is attachment there must be exploitation. And we use that word love to cover up all this. And is love jealousy?

不幸的是，或者幸运的是——这取决于你——我们把欲望等同于所谓的爱。爱是欲望吗？爱是执着吗？当你执着于某物时，你就成了那物本身。当你完全认同于某物时，你就成了那物本身。为什么会有认同、执着的冲动？为什么人会执着于另一个人？执着难道不会滋生恐惧吗？害怕失去所执着之物？执着会让你嫉妒、害怕、焦虑，这些都是显而易见的现象。你之所以执着，是因为你自身的不足和孤独。因此，出于自身的不足、孤独和匮乏感，你紧紧抓住另一个人。那么，执着就是爱吗？哪里有执着，哪里就必然有剥削。而我们用“爱”这个词来掩盖这一切。爱就是嫉妒吗？

None of these things exist as attachment when you have understood that that emptiness in yourself can never be filled by something else. You have to look at it. You have to not escape from it, observe it totally. Then you will see that loneliness goes completely away. Then there is not that lonely attachment. Then perhaps one will know what love is. In attachment there is fear, there is anxiety, there is hate, all the conflicts in relationship; and where there is conflict can there be love? Where there is ambition, can there be love? When you strip yourself of ambition, anxiety, attachment, and understand deeply the meaning and the significance of pleasure and desire, then you perhaps come upon that strange thing called love. And out of that comes compassion. Compassion is the highest form of intelligence. When you have compassion and, therefore, intelligence, you will do the right thing at the right moment. I hope you are following, not verbally, but actually in your hearts, in your minds, doing it.

当你明白自身那份空虚永远无法被其他事物填满时，所有这些执着便不复存在。你必须正视它，不能逃避，必须全然地观察它。那时你会发现，孤独感彻底消失了。那时，孤独的执着也就不复存在了。那时，或许你才能真正理解什么是爱。执着中蕴藏着恐惧、焦虑、仇恨，以及人际关系中所有的冲突；而冲突之中，爱又怎能存在？野心之中，爱又怎能存在？当你卸下野心、焦虑和执着，深刻理解快乐和欲望的意义与价值时，或许你就能邂逅那名为爱的奇妙之物。而慈悲，正是由此而生。慈悲是智慧的最高境界。当你拥有慈悲，因而也拥有智慧时，你就能在恰当的时机做出恰当的抉择。我希望你们不仅在口头上，更要在内心深处，在思想中，真正地践行着这些教诲。

And there is the question of what death is. It is rather strange to talk about it on a lovely morning, but it is part of life. Not to go into the full meaning of that word, and know what it implies, to shut ourselves away from it, to escape from it, to avoid it, not to talk about it, is to divide life, which is a total movement. We must go into this question. Not only for the aged, but also for the young; we are all involved in this. So what does living mean, and what does dying mean? What do we mean by living, our daily living? An effort, a struggle, a conflict, pleasure, anxiety, uncertainty, fear of losing a job, or having a job, trying to get a better job, and so on, constant struggle, constant effort, fear, anxiety, with occasional joy—this is our life, if you are honest about it. This is our everyday existence. To that endless struggle we cling, and say that is living.

还有个问题，那就是死亡究竟是什么。在一个美好的早晨谈论死亡或许有些奇怪，但它却是生命的一部分。如果我们不去探究“死亡”一词的全部含义，不去了解它所蕴含的意义，如果我们把自己封闭起来，逃避它，回避它，不去谈论它，那就等于割裂了生命——一个整体的运动。我们必须去思考这个问题。这不仅对老年人而言如此，对年轻人也是如此；我们每个人都与此息息相关。那么，活着意味着什么？死亡又意味着什么？我们所说的“活着”，我们日常生活的意义是什么？努力、奋斗、冲突、快乐、焦虑、不确定、害怕失去工作，或者拥有工作，努力寻找更好的工作等等，持续不断的奋斗、持续不断的努力、恐惧、焦虑，偶尔夹杂着喜悦——如果你诚实地面对自己，这就是我们的生活。这就是我们日常的存在。我们执着于这无休止的奋斗，并称之为“活着”。

And what then is dying? The ending of this so-called living? Is it a biological ending? Or the ending of this immense stream which man has created of conflict, sorrow, pain, anxiety? Please, it is your life we are talking about, not a description of the speaker’s life, or somebody else’s life. It is your life, your daily life with which we are concerned. Unless there is a radical transformation in that daily life we are going to create more and more misery for ourselves and for other human beings, which is actually what is going on. So what is dying?

那么，死亡究竟是什么？是所谓“生命”的终结吗？是生物学意义上的终结吗？还是人类所创造的这股巨大的冲突、悲伤、痛苦和焦虑之流的终结？请记住，我们谈论的是你的生命，而不是说话者自身或他人的生命描述。我们关注的是你的生命，是你日常生活的点点滴滴。除非你的日常生活发生根本性的转变，否则我们将为自己和他人制造越来越多的痛苦，而这正是我们正在经历的。那么，死亡究竟是什么？

There is a biological death through accident, through disease. And the body, the organism, wears itself out and comes to an end. The body has its own intelligence, but we have destroyed that intelligence through drink, through drugs, through constant effort, battle. Through various drugs and chemicals, medicines, we have destroyed that innate intelligence of the organism, and so the body dies by constant strain, usage.

生物性死亡包括意外和疾病。身体，也就是有机体，会耗尽自身能量，最终走向终结。身体本身拥有智慧，但我们通过酗酒、吸毒、持续不断的努力和斗争，摧毁了这种智慧。通过各种药物和化学物质，我们摧毁了有机体与生俱来的智慧，因此，身体最终会因持续的压力和过度使用而死亡。

Is it possible for the organism, this biological instrument with its brain, never to deteriorate? Our brain as it gets older deteriorates. Can the brain be young all the time and not deteriorate? When there is constant friction, constant effort, constant struggle, biologically as well as psychologically, the brain must deteriorate. Is there a way of living without effort and so the brain is always young, fresh, active, decisive? It is possible. Is one aware daily of the constant battle in oneself—trying to be something, trying to imitate, trying to conform, becoming the ideal, which is the mechanical process? Do you know, are you conscious that you are doing this? Don’t ask how to stop it, how to break the mechanical routine, but be aware of it without any choice, just look at it, because if you introduce an effort you have already destroyed it. Can you observe without any choice the mechanical movement of the brain, or rather one part of the brain that has been cultivated for centuries upon centuries to act mechanically? Just be aware of it, not try to correct it, not try to alter it, because from trying to alter it comes conflict. As we said, where there is duality, difference between the observer and the observed, there must be conflict. When there is no observer but merely observation then there is no conflict.

有机体，这个拥有大脑的生物装置，有可能永不衰退吗？随着年龄增长，我们的大脑会衰退。大脑有可能永远年轻而不衰退吗？当持续不断的摩擦、努力和斗争持续进行时，无论从生理上还是心理上，大脑都必然会衰退。是否存在一种无需努力就能保持大脑永远年轻、敏锐、活跃和果断的生活方式？这是可能的。你是否每天都意识到自己内心持续不断的斗争——试图成为某种人，试图模仿，试图顺从，试图成为理想，这本身就是一个机械的过程？你是否意识到自己正在这样做？不要问如何停止它，如何打破这种机械的惯例，而是要无条件地意识到它的存在，观察它，因为一旦你试图改变它，就已经破坏了它。你能否无条件地观察大脑的机械运动，或者更确切地说，观察大脑中某个经过几个世纪的训练而机械运作的部分？只需意识到这一点，不要试图纠正它，不要试图改变它，因为试图改变它只会带来冲突。正如我们所说，凡是有二元性的地方，凡是有观察者和被观察者之间的差异的地方，就必然存在冲突。当没有观察者，只有观察本身时，就不会有冲突。

If you are totally aware during the day of all the mechanical movement, the ways of your thinking, desire, then you will find at night when you go to sleep, in spite of what all the scientists say, there are no dreams. The mind, the brain is quiet because all your problems, all your activities have been dissolved during the day, if you are attentive, are watchful, aware. Then when you go to sleep there is peace; the brain may be in movement but it is a quiet movement, it is not an agitated, anxious movement. Therefore, the brain brings order in itself, so the brain becomes young, fresh. It cannot be young and fresh and decisive if there is any form of hurt. When it is free of hurt, the brain has no resistance.

如果你白天全然觉察到所有机械的运动、你的思维方式和欲望，那么到了晚上入睡时，你会发现，尽管科学家们都这么说，但实际上并没有梦。因为你白天的所有问题和活动都已消弭，所以你的心智和大脑才会平静下来。如果你保持专注、警觉和觉察，那么当你入睡时，你会感到平静；大脑或许仍在运转，但那是一种平静的运转，而非躁动不安的运转。因此，大脑会自我调节，从而变得年轻、充满活力。如果大脑受到任何形式的伤害，它就无法保持年轻、充满活力和果断。当大脑摆脱了伤害，它便不会有任何抵触情绪。

Apart from the biological ending of the organism, what is death? What is it that you are so frightened of? Is it the ending of your experiences? The ending of your knowledge? The ending of all the things that you are attached to, psychologically? Biologically, when death takes place, whatever you are attached to does end. You are not going to carry your house, your furniture, your books and even your gurus—the Catholic guru, or the Protestant guru, or the Indian guru—with you. So what is it that human beings are so dreadfully frightened of? They are frightened of something ending, of ending psychologically, inwardly.

除了生物体本身的终结，死亡究竟是什么？你究竟在恐惧什么？是你所有经历的终结？是你所有知识的终结？是你所有心理执念的终结？从生物学的角度来看，死亡发生时，你所执念的一切都将终结。你不可能带着你的房子、家具、书籍，甚至你的精神导师——无论是天主教的、新教的还是印度教的——一起离开。那么，人类究竟在恐惧什么？他们恐惧的是某种终结，是心理层面、内在层面的终结。

And knowing it is going to end we want comfort, so we say there must be a continuity. The ancient Hindus said there is a continuity, which is called reincarnation. They said you will be reborn next life according to what you have done in this life. If you have behaved properly, decently, morally, in the next life you are going to be better, and through a series of incarnations, and depending on your behavior, you will ultimately come to the highest principle. That is a very comforting theory, and millions believe in that. The Buddhist attitude is that life is a constant flux, a constant movement and when that manifests, an enclosure takes place which becomes the “you,” the “me,” which through time, through constant movement, undergoes change. And of course the Christians have their own belief in the resurrection; they believe that their own deity woke up from death physically.

我们知道一切终将结束，所以渴望慰藉，因此我们说必然存在某种延续性。古印度教徒认为存在这种延续性，即轮回。他们说，你会根据今生的所作所为，在来世重生。如果你行为端正、体面、道德高尚，那么来世你会更好，通过一系列的轮回，最终，根据你的行为，你会达到至高境界。这是一个非常令人慰藉的理论，数以百万计的人相信它。佛教的观点是，生命是一个持续流动、不断运动的过程，当这种流动显现时，便形成了一种封闭的状态，这种状态构成了“你”、“我”，而随着时间的推移，通过不断的运动，这种封闭的状态也会发生变化。当然，基督教也有他们自己的复活信仰；他们相信他们的神从死亡中复活了。

We are saying something entirely different. Please listen because you will see, if you really understand this thing, that there is a timeless movement, a timeless state. First, we said, the world is you, and you are the world. All human beings, radically, basically, are afraid, anxious, in sorrow, confused, unhappy, with occasional joy; psychologically it is a constant movement, wherever human beings are it is the same stream. It is the same stream; therefore, you are the world and the world is you. That is a fact. You may have different temperament, different gifts, capacities, idiosyncrasies, but those are the responses of the culture in which you have lived. But the basic stream is the same.

我们说的完全是另一回事。请仔细听，因为如果你真正理解了这一点，你就会明白，存在着一种永恒的运动，一种永恒的状态。首先，我们说过，世界就是你，你就是世界。所有人类，从根本上来说，都是恐惧、焦虑、悲伤、困惑、不快乐，偶尔也会有喜悦；从心理层面来说，这是一种持续不断的运动，无论人类身处何地，这股潮流都是一样的。它是同一条潮流；因此，你就是世界，世界就是你。这是事实。你或许拥有不同的性情、不同的天赋、不同的能力、不同的个性，但这些都是你所处文化环境的产物。但这条基本的潮流是相同的。

Therefore, there is no individuality. Individuality implies a wholeness, an indivisible entity, and you are not that indivisible entity. You are divided, broken up; therefore, you are not actually an individual, indivisible. You become totally individual in the complete sense of that word when you are whole, in which there is no fragmentary action. The word whole means healthy, sane, holy. You are the world and the world is you, and you are caught in that constant stream. But sorrow can be ended, fear can be ended—not tomorrow, actually now; then you are out of that stream—not you, there is a manifestation, which is out of that stream or freed from that stream, because that stream is time.

因此，个体性并不存在。个体性意味着完整性，意味着不可分割的整体，而你并非那不可分割的整体。你是分裂的，支离破碎的；因此，你实际上并非一个不可分割的个体。当你完整时，你才能真正成为完整意义上的个体，那时，一切行动都将不再有碎片化。完整意味着健康、理智、神圣。你即世界，世界即你，你被卷入那永不停息的洪流之中。但悲伤可以终结，恐惧可以终结——不是明天，而是现在；那时，你将脱离那洪流——并非是你，而是一种显现，它脱离了那洪流，或从那洪流中解脱出来，因为那洪流便是时间。

That stream is time. So you have to find out whether time has a stop. Time has a stop when there is no longer the movement of that stream. That stream is fear, that stream is conflict, that stream is sorrow, and all the confusion man has built through thought. So that is the stream of time. When there is an ending to that stream, time has stopped; therefore, there is a totally different dimension.

那条流淌的便是时间。所以你必须弄清楚时间是否会停止。当那条流淌的停止时，时间便停止了。那条流淌的便是恐惧，那条流淌的便是冲突，那条流淌的便是悲伤，以及人类通过思想所构建的一切混乱。这就是时间的流淌。当那条流淌的终结，时间便停止了；因此，便进入了一个截然不同的维度。

So the thing that we are afraid of losing when death takes place is the structure that thought has built as “me,” the form, the name, and the attachment to the form and to that name, which are pain, pleasure, anxiety. All that is the “me,” the “you.” You can say there is a higher me, but that is still the product of thought. So that movement in which human beings are caught is the movement of time, driven by thought. The greater the volume of that stream the greater is the volume of thought. And when that stream, which is our consciousness with all its content, comes to an end, then time has a stop and, therefore, there is a totally different dimension. And when you understand this, not verbally, but deeply, and live it daily—and it can be done—then you will see that death has a totally different significance.

所以，死亡发生时，我们害怕失去的，是思想构建的“我”的结构——形式、名称，以及对形式和名称的执着，也就是痛苦、快乐和焦虑。所有这些都是“我”、“你”。你可以说存在一个更高的“我”，但那仍然是思想的产物。因此，人类所处的这种运动，实际上是由思想驱动的时间运动。思想的洪流越大，思想的量也就越大。当这股洪流——也就是我们意识及其所有内容——终止时，时间也就停止了，因此，一个截然不同的维度出现了。当你真正理解这一点，不是用语言表达，而是深刻地理解，并将其融入日常生活——这是可以做到的——你就会明白，死亡有着完全不同的意义。

Ojai, April 17, 1976

奥海，1976年4月17日

6

One has been talking for the last fifty years and more, seeing a lot of people, talking over not only their personal problems, but the global problems of human beings, the vast confusion, the misery, the extraordinary lack of clarity. And through all these days and years it becomes more and more clear that unless human beings radically transform themselves, we may destroy not only ourselves but the earth. So it seems to us that there must be a group of people who are utterly serious, who are concerned, not superficially, not adjusting themselves to environment and circumstances, but deeply, and who will live a life that is whole, complete, noble, full of intensity and clarity. Otherwise we waste the short years we have.

过去五十多年来，我一直在与人交谈，探讨的不仅是个人问题，还有人类面临的全球性问题，例如巨大的困惑、苦难和极度的迷茫。经过这么多年，我们越来越清楚地认识到，除非人类彻底改变自身，否则我们不仅会毁灭自己，还会毁灭地球。因此，我们认为必须有一群人，他们真正认真对待这些问题，他们并非流于表面，并非随波逐流，而是深入思考，他们渴望过上完整、充实、高尚、充满激情和清晰的生活。否则，我们将虚度短暂的青春。

So we have talked about various things, like the utter lack of relationship between human beings; we have talked about the process of thought as a material movement in time and said that thought is totally inadequate to solve our human problems because thought has created them. Thought cannot solve them because thought is a fragment, a material process and a movement of measure. We also talked about fear and the ending of it, about understanding the whole complex problem of pleasure and of the ending of sorrow, and we talked about love and death.

所以我们谈了很多事情，比如人与人之间关系的彻底缺失；我们谈到思维过程是时间中的一种物质运动，并指出思维完全不足以解决我们人类的问题，因为这些问题正是思维造成的。思维无法解决这些问题，因为思维只是碎片，是一种物质过程，一种尺度运动。我们也谈到了恐惧及其终结，谈到了理解快乐的复杂问题以及悲伤的终结，我们还谈到了爱与死亡。

As we are concerned with the very deep problem of existence, we must not put aside the whole question of religion, meditation, and whether there is anything sacred, holy.

既然我们关注的是存在的深刻问题，我们就不能忽视宗教、冥想以及是否存在神圣事物等问题。

To hear correctly is an art. To see things as they are is also an art. And to learn, not from others, the whole content of one’s human consciousness, which is the result of millennia of human endeavor, human sorrow, human agony, anxiety. It is all there in us. In learning to look at, to listen to all the content of that consciousness, in the observation of that consciousness, is action.

正确聆听是一门艺术。如实地看待事物也是一门艺术。而学习，而非从他人那里获取，则是学习人类意识的全部内容——这意识是数千年来人类努力、悲伤、痛苦和焦虑的结晶。这一切都存在于我们自身之中。学会观察、聆听这意识的全部内容，观察这意识本身就是一种行动。

We are going to discuss religion together, because religion is the creative factor of a new culture. If there is no religion then the culture dies, civilization goes to pieces. Considering what the world is like, with all its brutality, violence, wars, divisions, class hatreds, and so on, which all indicate degeneration of the human mind, it behooves us to discover for ourselves what religion is. Is it a gathering of beliefs? Is it performing rituals, repeating endless words which have really no meaning at all? Is it going on Sunday morning to a church, or to a temple, or to a mosque, and repeating some chant, some words? If one asks oneself seriously, what is the necessity of any belief, of any conclusion? Beliefs, conclusions, divide people. In this little village there are five or six divisions of Christianity. And throughout the world there is much division brought about by so-called religions—the Hindu, the Buddhist, the Muslim, and the Christian, and their innumerable sects. So what is the importance of any belief at all? Or does belief prevent the understanding of what truth is?

我们将一起探讨宗教，因为宗教是新文化的创造因素。如果没有宗教，文化就会消亡，文明就会瓦解。鉴于当今世界的种种残酷、暴力、战争、分裂、阶级仇恨等等，所有这些都表明人类精神的堕落，我们有必要自己去探寻宗教的本质。宗教是信仰的集合吗？是进行仪式，重复那些毫无意义的无休止的词句吗？是星期天早上去教堂、寺庙或清真寺，念诵一些经文吗？如果我们认真地扪心自问，任何信仰、任何结论的必要性究竟何在？信仰和结论只会造成分裂。在这个小村庄里，基督教就有五六个不同的教派。在全世界，所谓的宗教——印度教、佛教、伊斯兰教和基督教，以及它们数不胜数的教派——都造成了巨大的分裂。那么，任何信仰的意义究竟何在呢？或者说，信仰会阻碍人们理解真理吗？

Is religion divorced from daily life, or is religion a movement that brings order in our life? If religion is divorced from our daily life it can only create further confusion, further conflict.

宗教是脱离日常生活的吗？还是说宗教是一种能为我们的生活带来秩序的运动？如果宗教脱离日常生活，只会造成更多的混乱和冲突。

To find out the meaning of religion, one must have order in one’s life. Our life is confused, contradictory, disorderly, fragmented, broken up; how can such a life have order? Order is not the acceptance of a blueprint. Order comes only when one realizes, is aware fully, without any choice, of one’s own confusion, one’s own daily disordered life. From awareness without any choice of disorder comes order; that is, from the understanding, from the observation of our daily life, which is disorderly. Such observation is not based on condemnation, rationalization, judgment. From that choiceless awareness comes order and this order is a living thing; therefore, it is constantly moving. Although to the modern generation, morality means nothing, morality in essence is order. And without order how can there be clarity?

要探寻宗教的意义，人必须在生活中拥有秩序。我们的生活混乱、矛盾、无序、支离破碎；这样的生活怎能有秩序？秩序并非接受某种既定的模式。秩序唯有在完全觉察到自身的混乱和日常无序时才会出现，而这种觉察并非出于任何选择。秩序源于对无序的觉察，即源于对我们无序日常生活的理解和观察。这种观察并非基于谴责、辩解或评判。秩序源于这种不加选择的觉察，而这种秩序是鲜活的，因此它始终处于变化之中。尽管对现代人而言，道德毫无意义，但道德的本质就是秩序。没有秩序，又怎能有清晰的认知？

Part of this touches the question of meditation; without order in one’s life, without being totally moral in one’s daily activity, how can you even think of meditating? You may sit cross-legged for the rest of your life, for the next ten incarnations or a million incarnations, breathe in a certain way that you have learned in India, but you will never come upon that which is truth because your life is disorderly. Therefore, you must bring order into that life before you even think of meditating; if you “meditate” without having order, it is a marvelous escape and, therefore, without any significance, without any meaning. Please do realize this. Meditation is the most marvelous thing, but not your kind of meditation. There must be order in our relationship, and that can only exist when there is no fear. Order is not put together by thought. If it is put together by thought then it will create further disorder.

这其中一部分涉及到冥想的问题；如果生活没有秩序，日常行为没有完全的道德准则，你又怎能想到要冥想呢？你或许会盘腿而坐，度过余生，甚至十世轮回，或者百万世轮回，用你在印度学到的某种方式呼吸，但你永远无法触及真理，因为你的生活混乱无序。因此，你必须先在生活中建立秩序，才能考虑冥想；如果你在缺乏秩序的情况下“冥想”，那只是一种奇妙的逃避，因此也毫无意义。请务必明白这一点。冥想固然奇妙，但并非你所理解的那种冥想。我们的关系中必须有秩序，而秩序只有在没有恐惧的情况下才能存在。秩序并非由思想构建而成。如果由思想构建，只会造成更大的混乱。

To find, or come upon, that which is most sacred, most holy, there must be a life based solidly on order. And the importance of all meditations is to come upon that silence. Even biologically, physiologically, to see anything clearly, to look at the trees, the light on the leaves, the green grass, and the hills and to see them clearly your mind must be quiet, mustn’t it? It is so simple, we make it so complex. To see anything clearly, to observe clearly, you must have a quiet mind, mustn’t you? If you are chattering, chattering, you won’t see the tree, you won’t see the depth of the shadow, the beauty of a trunk or a limb. You can only see it when your mind is quiet.

要想找到或领悟到至圣之物，必须先建立在秩序之上的生活。所有冥想的意义就在于抵达那份宁静。即便从生物学、生理学的角度来看，要想清晰地看到任何事物，比如树木、树叶上的光影、绿草和山丘，你的心必须平静下来，不是吗？道理如此简单，我们却把它复杂化了。要想清晰地看到任何事物，清晰地观察，你必须拥有平静的心，不是吗？如果你喋喋不休，喋喋不休，你就看不到树木，看不到阴影的深邃，看不到树干或树枝的美丽。只有当你的心平静下来时，你才能看到这一切。

See the fact of it, the reason of it, the logic of it, that you can see something clearly only when your mind is silent. You cannot hear what somebody else is saying if you are talking to yourself all the time. So if you want to hear somebody clearly you must be quiet. So silence is absolutely necessary to perceive outwardly and inwardly. The outward and the inward are the same movement, they are not different. It is one unitary movement, but we have divided it as the inner and the outer. By observing the outer clearly, you then discover the inner, and then see that it is one movement. To see this clearly you must look, observe silently.

明白事实，明白其中的缘由和逻辑：只有当你的心静下来时，你才能看得清清楚楚。如果你一直自言自语，就听不到别人在说什么。所以，如果你想听得清楚，就必须保持安静。因此，安静对于感知外在和内在是绝对必要的。外在和内在是同一运动，它们并非不同。它们是一个统一的运动，但我们将其分为内在和外在。通过清晰地观察外在，你就能发现内在，然后明白它们是一个整体。要清晰地看到这一点，你必须静静地观察。

We are investigating together the meaning and the depth of that thing called religion, to find out if there is anything incorruptible, untouched by thought, which is not an illusion, which is not the projection of one’s own desire, or an experience, but something that has never been touched by thought, something totally original. And to come upon that we said there must be order in daily life, which is the essence of virtue.

我们共同探究宗教的意义和深度，以求找到某种不受思想侵蚀、不朽不灭的事物，它并非幻象，并非个人欲望的投射，也非某种经验，而是从未被思想触及的、完全原创的事物。为了达到这种境界，我们认为日常生活必须有秩序，因为秩序是美德的本质。

There are different kinds of silence, aren’t there? There is the silence between two noises—is that silence? There is silence between two thoughts—is that silence? There is so-called peace between two wars—is that peace? So what is silence? Is it put together by thought? Is it contrived? Is it something that is manufactured because you understand that if you want to see “heaven” you must be silent? Then you say, “How am I to be silent? Teach me how to be silent.” Out of the desire to find out what silence is, people begin to invent systems, methods, ways to come upon that.

寂静有很多种，不是吗？两种声音之间的寂静——那是寂静吗？两个念头之间的寂静——那是寂静吗？两场战争之间的所谓和平——那是和平吗？那么，寂静究竟是什么？它是思想构建的吗？它是人为制造的吗？还是因为你明白，想要见到“天堂”，就必须保持寂静，所以才人为制造出来的？于是你问：“我该如何保持寂静？请教我如何保持寂静。”出于探寻寂静本质的渴望，人们开始发明各种体系、方法和途径，试图找到它。

Now if once you understand this you will never touch any system; because what is implied in a system and a practice? Repetition, practice, practice, practice, control, make an effort, which is, become mechanical. As we have said, part of our brain has become mechanical. We said thought in its essence is mechanical, because thought is the repetition, or the reaction, of memory. And when you already live a life that is mechanical and try to go beyond that mechanical life by introducing another mechanical process, which is systems, methods, practices, you are still mechanical. So when once you see the truth of this, the logic, the reason of this, you will never touch systems, methods, practices. Anything that is contrived, put together by thought—however beautiful, however logical, however ancient, traditional—makes the mind more mechanical and eventually dull. The very seeing of the truth of that ends the demand for systems, methods.

一旦你理解了这一点，你就不会再碰任何系统了；因为系统和实践的本质是什么？重复、练习、再练习、再练习、控制、努力，最终都会变得机械化。正如我们所说，我们大脑的一部分已经变得机械化了。我们说过，思维的本质是机械的，因为思维是对记忆的重复或反应。当你已经过着机械化的生活，却试图通过引入另一种机械化的过程——系统、方法、实践——来超越这种机械化的生活时，你仍然是机械的。所以，一旦你看清了其中的真相、逻辑和原因，你就不会再碰任何系统、方法、实践了。任何由人为设计、由思维拼凑而成的东西——无论多么优美、多么合乎逻辑、多么古老、多么传统——都会使思维变得更加机械化，最终变得迟钝。看清这个真相本身，就意味着对系统和方法的渴求已经终结。

If silence is not put together by thought, then what is it? To see clearly you must be silent, to hear clearly the mind must not be chattering. If you see the truth of it, then it happens. You do not have to make an effort to be silent.

如果沉默并非由思想构成，那它又是什么？要想看得清楚，你必须保持沉默；要想听得清楚，你的思绪就不能纷乱。如果你领悟了其中的真谛，它自然而然就会发生。你无需刻意去保持沉默。

So what is that which is silent? We will look at it by examining awareness. What is awareness, to be aware? When you are sitting there you are aware of the trees, the shadows, the light on the leaves, the movement of the leaves. [The talk is taking place in the open in an oak grove.] If you are looking at the tree you are aware of it. Can you look at it without verbalization? Just look without naming it, without giving it a quality, or description, just observe.

那么，什么是寂静呢？我们将通过考察觉知来探究它。觉知是什么？觉知本身又是什么？当你坐在那里时，你会觉察到树木、阴影、树叶上的光线以及树叶的摇曳。[谈话在一片橡树林中进行。] 如果你注视着那棵树，你就会觉察到它。你能否不加言语地注视它？只是观察，不去命名它，不去赋予它任何特质或描述，只是单纯地观察。

We never just observe: we look and say, “How beautiful,” “How ugly,” “How useful,” depending on our conditioning. So we never observe things as they are. Now can you observe, see the beauty of this whole land, all the hills, their quietness, their shadows, just observe without any reaction of thought, without any reaction of like and dislike? Just to observe, that is awareness. Be aware of the universe around you, then be aware of the universe inside. The universe inside is much more complex. The universe inside is our whole consciousness. And the consciousness is its content. The universe inside is much more complex, much more subtle, and if one has the energy, the capacity, the intensity, and the clarity, to go into it, there is a tremendous depth in that. So, be aware first of the outer, look at it, and be aware of all your reactions to it, and then go beyond your reactions and observe. Now in the same way go into the universe of yourself, which is your consciousness, with all its content, with its experiences, with its knowledge, with its likes, with its fears, anxieties, sorrow, pain. Be conscious of that enormous content that man has added to for thousands of years, be aware of that.

我们从未真正地观察过：我们看着，然后说“多么美丽”、“多么丑陋”、“多么有用”，这取决于我们的固有观念。所以我们从未真正地观察过事物本来的样子。现在，你能否观察一下，看看这片土地的美丽，所有的山丘，它们的宁静，它们的阴影，只是观察，不带任何念头，不带任何好恶之分？仅仅是观察，那就是觉知。觉知你周围的宇宙，然后觉知你内在的宇宙。内在的宇宙要复杂得多。内在的宇宙就是我们全部的意识。而意识就是它的内容。内在的宇宙更加复杂，更加微妙，如果一个人拥有足够的能量、能力、强度和清晰度去深入其中，就会发现其中蕴藏着巨大的深度。所以，首先觉知外在的一切，观察它，觉知你对它的所有反应，然后超越你的反应，去观察。现在，同样地，进入你自身的宇宙，也就是你的意识，进入它的一切内容，它的经历，它的知识，它的喜好，它的恐惧、焦虑、悲伤和痛苦。意识到人类数千年来不断丰富着这浩瀚的内容，觉察到这一切。

Can one be aware totally? Or must one take one segment after another, one layer after another, one fragment after another? The content of consciousness makes up consciousness; if there is no content there is no consciousness, as we know it. Will you understand the content of consciousness bit by bit? Or is there an understanding of it totally? The content of your consciousness is your conditioning—as a Christian, as a socialist, by the climate, by the food, by all the things that man has done to himself and to others, his identifications, his beliefs. All that is consciousness. To understand that consciousness, will you examine it portion by portion? Or is there a way of looking at it wholly, so that you don’t have to take time?

人能否完全觉知？还是必须逐段逐层、逐层逐节、逐个片段地去理解？意识的内容构成意识本身；如果没有内容，就没有我们所知的意识。你会一点一点地理解意识的内容吗？还是说，存在一种对意识的全面理解？你意识的内容就是你的各种制约因素——作为基督徒、作为社会主义者，受气候、食物的影响，受人类自身及他人所作所为的影响，受其认同和信仰的影响。这一切构成了意识。为了理解这种意识，你会逐部分地审视它吗？还是说，存在一种整体性的视角，让你无需花费时间去理解它？

There is a way of looking at it wholly, not fragment by fragment. And that is only possible if you understand awareness. So there is awareness of the world outside you, watching your reactions to the world outside you, and observing without reactions the world outside you. And move from the outer to the inner with all the content, which is your consciousness, to observe it. First you will react to it, naturally: “I don’t like,” “I like,” “How beautiful this is,” “How pleasurable that was,” “I wish I could keep a little bit of this,” and so on and so on and so on. Watch that reaction and then go beyond it. If you go beyond it then, you see the whole content instantly.

有一种方法可以整体地看待事物，而不是零零碎碎地看待。而这只有在你理解了觉知之后才有可能。所以，你需要觉知你之外的世界，观察你对外部世界的反应，以及不带反应地观察外部世界。然后，带着你意识的全部内容，从外部世界转向内部世界，去观察它。首先，你自然会对它做出反应：“我不喜欢”、“我喜欢”、“这真美”、“这真令人愉悦”、“我希望我能保留一点”，等等等等。观察这种反应，然后超越它。如果你超越了它，你就能立刻看到全部的内容。

This is part of meditation: to see the outer actually as it is, not what you wish it to be, the wars, the antagonisms, the hatreds, the innumerable insults and hurts that human beings receive, the sorrow, the pain, the anxiety, the loneliness, lack of love, to observe all that. Then what takes place? Then you will see that energy is being gathered, because there is order and, therefore, there is no wastage of energy. When there is mathematical order in your daily life, there is no wastage of energy. It is only when there is no order that there is wastage of energy. When there is order, there is the accumulation of energy. And with that energy observe the world and yourself, and realize the world out there and here are the same movement. There is the accumulation of energy when there is an observation without the observer. The observer is the past, the past being all your prejudices, your opinions, your conclusions, your traditional responses. The observer is the past and the observer meets the present, the what is , and tries to translate it according to his past conclusions. Right? That gives to the past further movement in time as the future. You are the result of the past. That is a fact. Part of your brain is the result of a series of adventures, happenings, incidents, experiences, as knowledge, and knowledge is always the past. That movement of the past meets the present and translates the present, or modifies the present according to the past and so gives a further movement into the future. The past meeting the present is a movement; the present is also a movement; if the past meeting the present ends there, which means no movement, then time has a stop.

这是冥想的一部分：如实地观察外在世界，而不是你希望它成为的样子——战争、敌对、仇恨、人类遭受的无数侮辱和伤害、悲伤、痛苦、焦虑、孤独、爱的缺失——观察这一切。然后会发生什么？你会发现能量正在积聚，因为秩序存在，因此能量不会浪费。当你的日常生活井然有序时，能量就不会浪费。只有当缺乏秩序时，能量才会浪费。当秩序存在时，能量就会积累。用这种能量去观察世界和你自己，并意识到外在世界和你自身是同一运动。当观察者不带任何主观感受时，能量就会积累。“观察者”指的是过去，过去指的是你所有的偏见、观点、结论和固有的反应。观察者即过去，观察者与当下相遇，与“存在”相遇，并试图根据过去的结论来解读当下。对吗？这使得过去在时间中继续向前发展，成为未来。你是过去的产物。这是事实。你大脑的一部分是一系列冒险、事件、经历和经验的产物，它们构成了知识，而知识总是源于过去。过去的这种运动与现在相遇，并根据过去来解读或修正现在，从而推动未来向前发展。过去与现在的相遇是一种运动；现在也是一种运动；如果过去与现在的相遇就此结束，意味着没有运动，那么时间就停止了。

So meditation then is bringing about order in life, and thereby gathering great energy, and ending conflict between the observer and the observed, which adds further energy. When there is a division between the observer and the observed there must be conflict. When you are angry, at the moment of anger, at the second of anger, there is no division; but a second later a division takes place: “I must not be angry,” or, “Why shouldn’t I be angry?” Where there is a division, there must be conflict. Conflict with all its violence is a wastage of energy. The gathering of total energy is the beginning of silence.

因此，冥想旨在为生活带来秩序，从而积聚巨大的能量，并消除观察者与被观察者之间的冲突，进而获得更多能量。当观察者与被观察者之间出现隔阂时，冲突便不可避免。当你愤怒时，在愤怒的那一刻，愤怒的瞬间，并不存在隔阂；但仅仅一秒之后，隔阂便出现了：“我不能生气”，或者，“我为什么不应该生气？”哪里有隔阂，哪里就必然有冲突。冲突及其所有的暴力行为都是能量的浪费。积聚全部能量，便是寂静的开始。

We live confused lives, our consciousness is in turmoil, constantly in battle, constantly choosing, denying, asserting, dominating, being attached. It is in constant struggle, boiling all the time; and that boiling is a wastage of energy. For that turmoil to come to an end is part of meditation. Not by control. The moment you control, who is the controller? Please, go into this yourself. The controller is part of thought. When the controller tries to control thought that is a wastage of energy. But if you see the truth, that the controller is the controlled, then the conflict comes to an end. That means you have further energy, and this energy is necessary, this complete energy, which is not put together by friction. Friction has its own energy, but this energy that we are talking about is not put together by thought and, therefore, it is not the result of friction. This energy is necessary to come upon that which is sacred, which is the religious mind.

我们生活在迷茫之中，意识处于动荡之中，不断争斗，不断地选择、否定、断言、支配、执着。它处于持续的斗争之中，时刻沸腾；而这种沸腾是对能量的浪费。要平息这种动荡，冥想是其中的一部分，而非控制。当你试图控制时，谁才是控制者？请你亲自思考这个问题。控制者是思想的一部分。当控制者试图控制思想时，那是一种能量的浪费。但如果你看清真相，即控制者本身就是被控制者，那么冲突就会结束。这意味着你拥有了更多的能量，而这种能量是必要的，这种完整的能量并非由摩擦产生。摩擦本身也蕴含能量，但我们所说的这种能量并非由思想产生，因此，它并非摩擦的结果。这种能量对于抵达神圣之物——即宗教心灵——至关重要。

Meditation then is the emptying of the content of consciousness—which means the fears, the anxieties, the conflicts in relationship—the ending of sorrow and, therefore, compassion. The ending of the content of consciousness is complete silence. Then that silence is full of energy. It is not vacant silence. It is not a silence that wants something more.

因此，冥想就是清空意识的内容——这意味着消除恐惧、焦虑、人际关系中的冲突——止息悲伤，从而获得慈悲。意识内容的止息便是彻底的寂静。那时，寂静中蕴含着能量。它并非空洞的寂静，也并非渴望更多。

So meditation is not the repetition of mantras, not merely sitting down breathing carefully. Meditation must be totally uninvited, not contrived, not put together. Which means there is no measurement. If one has gone that far—no, it is not far or near—if one has done this, then there is that emptiness.

所以，冥想并非重复念诵咒语，也并非只是静坐呼吸。冥想必须完全自然而然，不加刻意，不事先安排。这意味着冥想无法衡量。如果一个人达到了那种境界——不，它既不遥远也不接近——如果一个人做到了这一点，那么他便能体验到那种空性。

Now wait a minute. Scientists say in this emptiness there is energy. We are saying that when there is this meditative process, movement, there is a totally different kind of consciousness of a dimension in which there is all this energy which has been gathered through meditation, order in life. You have total energy— there is total energy. And in that emptiness there is not a thing. There is nothing. Nothing means not a thing. Thing means thought. Thought is a material process. So in that emptiness thought does not exist at all. And, therefore, there is no experiencer who is experiencing this total nothingness.

稍等片刻。科学家说，在这片虚无之中蕴藏着能量。我们想说的是，当存在这种冥想过程和运动时，便会进入一种截然不同的意识状态，进入一个全新的维度，在这个维度中，所有的能量都通过冥想和生命秩序汇聚于此。你拥有全部的能量——那里存在着全部的能量。而在这种虚无之中，没有任何事物。什么都没有。“无”意味着不存在任何事物。“事物”指的是思想。思想是一种物质过程。因此，在这种虚无之中，思想根本不存在。所以，也没有任何体验者能够体验到这种彻底的虚无。

What is beauty? That is also part of our life. Is it the shadow? The line of an architectural building? The painting? The marvelous cultures that exist in the world? The mountains? The running waters? The beautiful face? What is beauty? Does not beauty exist when there is not a center of conflict? When you say, “How beautiful it is,” what is the feeling behind that? What is the nature, the quality of emotion, the surging of something? Is that beauty? Or is beauty the total absence of the observer? When there is only complete observation, in which there is no choice, no division, there must be this sense of beauty. That may be that which is sacred. Not the beauty of form of a woman or a man. There is the beauty of woman and man, the beauty of a tree, the beauty of a line, of a sheet of water, the running sea, but to find out, or come upon that sense of total absence of anything that is contradictory, something that is whole, complete, sane, rational. Such a mind is a beautiful mind, which is the religious mind. Because there you have total energy embodied.

美是什么？这也是我们生活的一部分。是影子吗？是建筑的线条吗？是绘画吗？是世界上存在的奇妙文化吗？是山峦吗？是流水吗？是美丽的容颜吗？美是什么？难道美不存在于没有冲突的中心吗？当你感叹“多么美丽啊”，这背后隐藏着怎样的感受？是情感的本质，是某种涌动的情绪吗？那是美吗？还是说，美就是观察者的完全缺席？当只有全然的观察，没有选择，没有分裂时，必然存在这种美感。那或许就是神圣之物。并非是男女形体的美。男女之美固然存在，树木之美，线条之美，水面之美，大海之美固然存在，但要找到或领悟到那种完全没有矛盾、完整、健全、理性的感受，才是真正的美。这样的心灵才是美的心灵，那就是宗教的心灵。因为那里蕴含着全部的能量。

So there is such a thing as something sacred that is not touched by thought, that is not touched or made corrupt by human beings, with their desires and frights and quarrels and mischief. And to come upon that is not only part of meditation, but the ending of sorrow, which is the beginning of wisdom. So wisdom is not learning from books or going to a school. When there is an ending of sorrow in yourself as a human being, then out of that comes wisdom.

所以，的确存在一种神圣之物，它不受思想的触及，不受人类的欲望、恐惧、争吵和邪恶所玷污或腐蚀。领悟这种神圣不仅是冥想的一部分，更是止息悲伤，而止息悲伤正是智慧的开端。因此，智慧并非来自书本学习或学校教育。当你作为一个人，内心的悲伤得以止息时，智慧便会由此而生。

And when a human being transforms himself, when you transform yourself radically, you are affecting the whole consciousness of mankind. You are mankind, you are the movement of mankind. This is a fact, this is actual. If you change, you affect the world. So it is your tremendous responsibility. We must be very skeptical of all psychological experiences, subjective experiences, because they are most destructive.

当一个人改变自己，彻底改变自己时，你就是在影响整个人类的意识。你就是人类，你就是人类运动的一部分。这是事实，这是现实。如果你改变，你就会影响世界。所以，这是你肩负的重大责任。我们必须对所有心理体验、主观体验保持高度怀疑，因为它们最具破坏性。

So meditation implies a life of great order and, therefore, great virtue, morality. And it implies the understanding and the depth of beauty. And it implies the emptying of that consciousness which is you, with all your attachments, fears, hopes, despairs, the emptying of all that by observing.

所以，冥想意味着一种高度有序的生活，因而也意味着高尚的德行和道德。它意味着对美的理解和领悟。它意味着清空你的意识——也就是你自身的所有执着、恐惧、希望和绝望——通过观察来清空这一切。

Then you have energy which alone can discover that which is eternal, which has no beginning and no ending.

然后你就会拥有那种能够发现永恒之物的能量，那永恒之物没有开始也没有结束。

Ojai, April 18, 1976

奥海，1976年4月18日

#↩

THE WHOLENESS OF LIFE

生命的完整性

One wonders, observing what is going on in the world, why there is so much disorder, why man is destroying man. Why is there such enormous expenditure on armaments? Why have people divided themselves into tribal romantic nationalities? Why have the organized religions, the accepted religions, throughout the world, divided themselves? Why is there such division in the world? We are inclined to think that an outside agency has created all this mess, that “God,” or some other supreme entity, having created man, has let him loose on the earth. What mankind has done is quite incredible and shocking, not only toward other human beings, but also in himself. Why in the world are there are so many neurotic people? Why is there this constant battle between man and woman? Why is there this inward disorder, which naturally must express itself in outward disorder?

观察世事变迁，人们不禁会问：为何世间如此混乱？为何人类自相残杀？为何军备开支如此巨大？为何人们会分裂成一个个充满浪漫色彩的部落民族？为何世界各地那些被广泛接受的宗教组织也分崩离析？为何世间如此纷争不断？我们倾向于认为，这一切混乱皆由外力所致，“上帝”或其他至高无上的存在创造了人类，并将他们放逐于世间。人类的所作所为令人难以置信，令人震惊，不仅针对其他人类，也针对自身。为何世间有如此多的神经质之人？为何男女之间永无休止的争斗？为何存在如此内在的混乱，而这种混乱又必然会以外在的混乱形式表现出来？

Our lives have produced the society in which we live. Society is not created by some extraordinary events but by the extraordinary lives we lead, not only we, but also past generations. Could we go together into it, think it out together, not only think it out but also go beyond the realm of thought? We have pointed out over and over again that thought is born of memory, memory is the result of knowledge and experience. And thought, therefore, is always limited, for knowledge is everlastingly limited because there can be no complete knowledge about anything. And thought born out of that must also be very, very limited. And the world in which we live, our daily life, our careers, our anxieties, fears, and sorrows, are the result of our thinking, are the product of our daily activity.

我们的生活塑造了我们所生活的社会。社会并非由某些非凡事件所创造，而是由我们所经历的非凡生活所塑造，不仅是我们，也包括过去的世代。我们能否携手共进，共同思考，不仅思考，更能超越思考的范畴？我们反复指出，思想源于记忆，记忆源于知识和经验。因此，思想总是有限的，因为知识永远有限，任何事物都不可能被完全了解。由此产生的思想也必然非常非常有限。我们所生活的世界，我们的日常生活，我们的事业，我们的焦虑、恐惧和悲伤，都是我们思考的结果，是我们日常活动的产物。

Could we together look at life as a whole, our education, our occupations, our hobbies, work, and all the travail that exists inwardly, the psychological conflicts, the anxieties, the fears, the pleasures, the sorrows? Could we take all that as a whole and not let thought occupy itself with one particular part, with one particular pattern, or cling to one particular experience, looking at life from only that point of view? Why do we live the way we are living? Why is there so much disorder in the world and in ourselves? Is the world disorder different from our disorder?

我们能否一起审视人生的整体，包括我们的教育、职业、爱好、工作，以及所有内在的挣扎，包括心理冲突、焦虑、恐惧、快乐和悲伤？我们能否将这一切视为一个整体，而不让思绪局限于某个特定的部分、某种特定的模式或某种特定的经历，仅仅从那个角度看待人生？我们为何如此生活？为何世界和我们自身都如此混乱？世界的混乱与我们自身的混乱有何不同？

Why is there disorder outwardly and disorder inwardly? Are they two separate disorders? Or are they one unitary process? The disorder out there is not different from the disorder in me, but rather this disorder is a movement which goes outward and comes inward. It is like a tide going back and forth endlessly. Can we begin to bring about order in our life? Because without order there is no freedom. Complete order, not occasionally or once a week, but in our daily life, not only brings freedom; there is then in that order love. A disordered, confused, mind that is in conflict cannot have or be aware of what love is.

为什么外在会有混乱，内在也会有混乱？它们是两种独立的混乱吗？还是一个统一的过程？外在的混乱与我内心的混乱并无二致，只不过这种混乱是一种向外涌动、向内收敛的运动，如同潮汐永不停息地来回流动。我们能否开始在生活中建立秩序？因为没有秩序就没有自由。完全的秩序，不是偶尔一次或一周一次，而是融入我们日常生活的方方面面，不仅能带来自由，而且秩序之中蕴藏着爱。一个混乱、迷茫、充满冲突的心灵，无法拥有或感知爱的真谛。

Can there be absolute order? We are using the word absolute in its right sense, complete, total, not an order that is intellectually brought about, an order that is based on values, not order that is the outcome of environmental pressures, or adaptation to a certain norm, a certain pattern. We are talking about absolute total order in which there is no division as disorder at all. We are asking whether there is an order in which there can never be disorder.

是否存在绝对秩序？我们这里所说的“绝对”是指完整、彻底的秩序，而非人为构建的秩序，并非基于价值观的秩序，也非环境压力或对某种规范、某种模式的适应所导致的秩序。我们谈论的是绝对的、彻底的秩序，其中不存在任何形式的混乱。我们探究的是，是否存在一种永远不会出现混乱的秩序。

Why does our mind, which includes the brain, our emotional responses, sensory responses, and so on, accept and live in disorder? If you observe your own mind, that is, your own life, which is based on your mind, your thoughts, your emotions, your experiences, your memories, regrets, apprehensions, why does that mind, which has all this in its consciousness, accept disorder? Not only the neurotic disorder, the acceptance of disorder and living with disorder, getting used to disorder, but why does the mind have this sense of division, this sense of order and disorder, this constant adjustment? Is this inevitable? Is this our natural state? If it is natural then one must live with this conflict, in this disorder, from the moment you are born until you die. And if it is unnatural, which obviously it is, what is the cause of it? What is the basis of it, what is the root of all this? Does the basis depend on our particular attitudes, on our particular desires?

为什么我们的心智，包括大脑、情绪反应、感官反应等等，会接受并生活在混乱之中？如果你观察自己的心智，也就是你的人生——它建立在你的心智、你的思想、你的情绪、你的经历、你的记忆、你的遗憾、你的担忧之上——为什么这个意识中包含着这一切的心智会接受混乱？不仅仅是神经症，接受混乱、与混乱共存、习惯混乱，而是为什么心智会有这种分裂感、这种秩序与混乱的感知、这种不断调整的感觉？这是不可避免的吗？这是我们的自然状态吗？如果这是自然的，那么从出生到死亡，我们就必须与这种冲突、这种混乱共存。如果这是不自然的（显然并非如此），那么它的根源是什么？它的根基是什么？这一切的根源是什么？它是否取决于我们特定的态度、特定的欲望？

One wants to find out what is the basis of this disorder, the root of it. To find out, how do we approach it? How do we approach the problem of disorder in order to resolve it totally? What is your approach? Are you approaching to find order out of disorder and, therefore, your approach is already directed? Suppose I am in disorder and I have the desire to bring about order. That very desire dictates what the order must be, whereas if I approach the problem of disorder as though I want to find the root of it, then my direction is not diverted, wasted in various intellectual, verbal, and emotional directions, but my whole attention is directed to the cause of it. So how do you, as a human being, living in this world, both outwardly and inwardly in disorder, approach this? We must be very clear what our approach is.

我们想要找出这种混乱的根源，它的本质是什么。为了找到答案，我们该如何着手？我们该如何解决混乱的问题才能彻底根除它？你的方法是什么？你是否抱着从混乱中寻求秩序的心态，因此你的方法就已经有了方向？假设我身处混乱之中，渴望建立秩序。这种渴望本身就决定了秩序应该是什么样子。然而，如果我抱着探寻混乱根源的心态去处理这个问题，那么我的方向就不会被分散，不会浪费在各种理智、语言和情感的方向上，而是会将全部注意力集中在混乱的根源上。那么，作为一个生活在这个世界上，无论外在还是内在都处于混乱之中的人，你该如何面对这个问题呢？我们必须非常清楚自己的方法是什么。

If it is clear then let us find out together what is the root of disorder. Is it self-contradiction? Is it desire that has created this division in us? Wherever there is division there must be conflict, and conflict means disorder. Conflict is disorder, whether it is minor, or conflict that brings about a great crisis. So is our conflict self-contradiction, saying one thing, doing another, having ideals and always trying to accommodate ourselves to those ideals? Is it our desire to become something? Or is this conflict created by thought? Because thought in itself, as we said, is limited and, therefore, it divides as the outer and the inner, the “you” and the “me.” Thought struggles to become something which it is not. Are these constant divisions, becoming, contradicting, conforming, comparing, imitating psychologically, the various expressions of a central cause?

如果这一点已经明确，那么让我们一起探究混乱的根源。是自相矛盾吗？是欲望在我们内心造成了这种分裂吗？哪里有分裂，哪里就必然有冲突，而冲突意味着混乱。冲突就是混乱，无论它是轻微的，还是会引发巨大危机的冲突。那么，我们的冲突是否源于自相矛盾——言行不一，拥有理想却总是试图让自己去适应这些理想？是否源于我们想要成为某种人的欲望？或者，这种冲突是由思想造成的？因为正如我们所说，思想本身是有限的，因此它会造成分裂，比如外在与内在，“你”与“我”。思想努力想要成为它本身并非的东西。这些持续不断的分裂——成为、矛盾、顺从、比较、心理上的模仿——是否是同一个核心原因的不同表现形式？

So what is the central cause, the root of all this? You are exercising your mind; therefore, you are aware of how you approach the problem, you are aware of your own contradictions, your own conflicts, your own divisions, your own apprehensions. Is one aware of all that? Or is one aware only of a fragment of it, a fragment that demands an immediate response? If I am concerned about my livelihood, I am not concerned about anything else because that is an immediate demand. I need money, food; I have children, responsibility; therefore, my approach to this whole problem will be directed by my desire to have a job. Or if I have been thinking along a certain pattern, along a certain direction, and I am unaware that I am caught in that pattern, then when I approach this question I am always approaching it according to the pattern that my mind has established. Or if I am emotional, romantic, then my approach will be sloppy, not precise, not exact.

那么，这一切的核心原因、根源是什么呢？你在运用你的思维；因此，你意识到自己是如何看待这个问题的，你意识到自身的矛盾、冲突、分裂和担忧。一个人是否意识到所有这些？或者，一个人是否只意识到其中的一部分，一部分需要立即回应？如果我只关心我的生计，我就不会关心其他任何事情，因为那是当务之急。我需要钱，需要食物；我有孩子，有责任；因此，我对整个问题的处理方式将受制于我想要一份工作的愿望。或者，如果我一直按照某种模式、某种方向思考，而我没有意识到自己被困在这种模式中，那么当我面对这个问题时，我总是按照我思维中已建立的模式来处理它。或者，如果我情绪化、浪漫，那么我的方法就会草率、不精确、不严谨。

So one must be very clear for oneself how one approaches this problem, because if we approach it with any pattern at all we shall not be able to solve it. Therefore, is our mind free from patterns? From ideals? From a direction? Are you aware of the confusion of the world, which is becoming worse every day? And of the confusion in us which we have inherited, to which we have added? Of the society in which we live, which is so utterly confused, where there is such great injustice: millions starving and the affluent society; tyranny and democratic freedom to think what you like, to express what you like?

所以，我们必须非常清楚自己该如何着手解决这个问题，因为如果我们带着任何既定的模式去处理它，就根本无法解决。那么，我们的思想是否摆脱了模式、理想和方向的束缚？你是否意识到这个世界的混乱，而且这种混乱还在日益加剧？你是否意识到我们自身继承的、并不断加剧的混乱？你是否意识到我们所处的社会如此混乱，存在着如此巨大的不公：数百万人忍饥挨饿，而上层社会却富足安康；暴政与民主的自由并存，人们可以自由地思考，自由地表达？

Our mind and our consciousness is the consciousness and the mind of the world. Wherever you go man is suffering, anxious, uncertain, lonely, desperate in his loneliness, burdened with sorrow, insecure. Psychologically, you are the humanity, you are not separate from the rest of mankind. The idea that you are an individual with a mind that is specially yours is an absurdity because this brain has evolved through time. It is the brain of mankind, and that brain is part of mankind, genetically, and so on, and so on. So you are the world and the world is you. It is not an idea or a concept, a utopian nonsense; it is a fact. And that mind is utterly confused. And we are trying to discover for ourselves the root of it.

我们的心智和意识就是世界的意识和心智。无论你走到哪里，人们都在受苦、焦虑、迷茫、孤独，在孤独中绝望，背负着悲伤，缺乏安全感。从心理学角度来说，你就是人类，你与其他人并非分离。认为你是一个拥有专属心智的个体是荒谬的，因为大脑是随着时间进化而来的。它是人类的大脑，而这个大脑在基因上是人类的一部分，等等等等。所以你就是世界，世界就是你。这不是一个想法或概念，也不是乌托邦式的无稽之谈；这是一个事实。而这颗心智完全混乱。我们正试图自己去发现它的根源。

What is the cause of these divisions between man and woman, between nation and nation, between one group and another group, these divisions of belief, ideals, concepts, historical conclusions, and materialistic attitudes? Division must inevitably create conflict. That is a fact. Through division we think that there can be security; where there is division as British, French, German, each group holding together as an idea, as a concept, under a flag, they think there is security. And this isolation must inevitably create division. So do we understand very deeply the truth that as long as there is division there must be conflict? Obviously there is no security in this isolation, this seclusion. You can build a wall around yourself as a nation but that wall is going to be broken down.

造成男女之间、国与国之间、群体之间，以及信仰、理想、观念、历史结论和物质态度等方面的分裂，其根源何在？分裂必然导致冲突，这是不争的事实。我们以为分裂就能带来安全；英国人、法国人、德国人，各自依附于某种理念、某种概念，在同一面旗帜下团结起来，他们以为这样就能获得安全。而这种孤立必然导致分裂。那么，我们是否真正理解，只要存在分裂，就必然存在冲突？显然，这种孤立、这种封闭并不能带来安全。你可以为国家筑起一道高墙，但这道墙终究会被推倒。

So what is the cause, the root, of this division? Each human being in the world thinks, lives according to the pattern, that he is separate from another, with his problems, his anxieties, his neurosis, his particular way of thinking. The center of this is the idea that I am separate from you. Now, is that a fact? Is it a fact that we are separate individuals, totally different from another? You may be tall, you may be short, have black hair, white hair, but inwardly are we different? Inwardly we all go through the same, or similar, things. So there is no division psychologically. And as long as we accept that idea that we are separate you must have conflict and, therefore, division and confusion.

那么，这种分裂的根源是什么？世界上每个人都按照某种模式思考和生活，认为自己与他人是分离的，拥有各自的问题、焦虑、神经质和独特的思维方式。这种模式的核心在于“我与你分离”的观念。然而，这真的是事实吗？我们真的是彼此分离、截然不同的个体吗？你可能个子高，也可能个子矮；你可能黑发，也可能白发，但我们的内心世界真的不同吗？在内心深处，我们都经历着相同或相似的事情。因此，从心理层面来说，并不存在真正的分离。只要我们接受“我们是分离的”这种观念，冲突就必然存在，分裂和混乱也就必然存在。

You hear a statement like this, that as long as you think you are separate from another human being psychologically, there must be conflict and disorder. That is a fact. When you hear that, do you make an abstraction of it as an idea and then see how that idea can be carried out? Or it is a fact? If it is a fact, then you can do something about it. But if you are merely making an abstraction of that fact into an idea then we are getting lost, because you have your idea and I have my idea. But it is a common fact upon which we stand as human beings, that as long as there is division inside me and you, there must be conflict and disorder and confusion. But our minds are so conditioned; for thousands of years we have been conditioned by what other people have said to think that we are separate. Religions have said that we are separate, that each individual must save himself; that whole pattern is repeated over and over and over again. Being so conditioned it is very difficult to accept something which perhaps is true. I am using the word perhaps because I am not being dogmatic; but it is a fact. Going into it analytically with you, if you are willing, with argument, intellectually, reasoning, at the end of it, we come to the same fact.

你听到这样的说法：只要你认为自己在心理上与他人分离，就必然存在冲突和混乱。这是事实。当你听到这句话时，你是把它抽象成一个概念，然后思考如何将这个概念付诸实践呢？还是把它当作事实来看待？如果这是事实，你就可以采取行动。但如果你只是把这个事实抽象成一个概念，那我们就迷失了方向，因为你有你的想法，我有我的想法。但作为人类，我们共同认同这样一个事实：只要你我内心存在隔阂，就必然存在冲突、混乱和困惑。然而，我们的思维方式早已被束缚；数千年来，我们一直被他人的言论所影响，认为我们是分离的。宗教也宣称我们是分离的，每个人都必须自救；这种模式一遍又一遍地重复。正因为如此，我们很难接受一些或许是真的事情。我用“或许”这个词，是因为我并非教条；但这的确是一个事实。如果你愿意，我们用分析的方法，用论证、用理性、用推理的方式去探讨这个问题，最终我们会得出相同的结论。

If we want to understand the nature of confusion and the ending of confusion—completely, not relatively—are we aware of this fact? If we are aware, then the question arises: What shall I do? I know I am divided, now how am I to put away this division?

如果我们想要彻底而非相对地理解混乱的本质以及如何终结混乱，我们是否意识到这一点？如果我们意识到了，那么问题就出现了：我该怎么办？我知道自己内心充满分裂，那么我该如何摆脱这种分裂呢？

Is the fact of this division different from the observer who is observing the fact? I will explain a little. I observe greed. I am greedy. Is that greed which I observe different from me, from the observer who says, “I am greedy”? Or greed is the observer? Right? So there is no division between the observer who says, “I am greedy” and who acts upon greed, saying, “I must not be greedy. I must control it. I must suppress it. I must go beyond it.” So there is a division, and that division is conflict and, therefore, disorder. But the fact is that the observer who says “I am greedy,’ that observer is greed himself. Have you gone that far? If you have gone that far, then I am asking: Is this confusion, this division, different from the observer who is me observing it? Or is this confusion, this division, me? My whole being is that, right? I wonder if you come to that point, otherwise you can’t go much further. Please come! This is really important if you can really understand this once and for all as a fact. If you understand it, it will make life totally different, because in that there is no conflict. I will point it out.

这种分裂的事实与观察这一事实的观察者有何不同？我稍作解释。我观察到贪婪。我本身也很贪婪。我观察到的这种贪婪与我，与那个说“我很贪婪”的观察者有何不同？或者说，贪婪就是观察者本身？对吗？因此，说“我很贪婪”的观察者和那些受贪婪驱使、说“我不能贪婪。我必须控制它。我必须抑制它。我必须超越它”的观察者之间并无区别。所以，分裂确实存在，而这种分裂就是冲突，因此也是混乱。但事实是，那个自称“我很贪婪”的观察者，他本身就是贪婪。你明白这一点了吗？如果你明白了，那么我想问：这种困惑，这种分裂，与作为观察者的我有什么不同？或者，这种困惑，这种分裂，就是我本身？我的整个存在就是如此，对吗？我想知道你是否能理解这一点，否则你无法继续深入。请理解！如果你能真正彻底地理解这一点，它就非常重要。如果你理解了，你的生活将会截然不同，因为其中不存在冲突。我会指出这一点。

Suppose I am attached to a person. In that attachment and in the consequences of that attachment are innumerable pains, jealousy, anxiety, dependency, the whole consequence of attachment. In that attachment to the person there is division immediately. Now is that attachment, the feeling of dependence, clinging, holding on to somebody, different from me? Or I am that? I am attachment . If one realizes that, conflict ends. It is so. Not that I must get rid of it, not that I must be independent, detached; detachment is attachment; if I try to become detached I am attached to that detachment.

假设我依恋一个人。这种依恋以及由此产生的后果会带来无数的痛苦、嫉妒、焦虑、依赖，以及依恋的全部后果。对这个人的依恋本身就包含着分离。那么，这种依恋，这种依赖、执着、紧抓不放的感觉，与我有什么不同呢？或者说，我就是它？我就是依恋。如果一个人意识到这一点，冲突就会结束。事实就是如此。这并不是说我必须摆脱它，也不是说我必须独立、超脱；超脱本身也是一种依恋；如果我试图变得超脱，我反而会依恋于这种超脱本身。

So now am I very clear that there is no division: When I say I am attached, I am attachment, I am the state of attachment. Therefore, I have removed completely all conflict, haven’t I? Do you realize that? I am that.

所以现在我很清楚了吧，这之间没有二元对立：当我说我执着于某事时，我就是执着本身，我就是执着的状态。因此，我已经彻底消除了所有冲突，不是吗？你明白了吗？我就是执着本身。

So I, me, is confusion. It is not that I realize I am confusion, or that I have been told that I am confusion, but the fact is that I, as a human being, am in a state of confusion. Any action I do will bring more confusion. So I am in a state of total confusion. And all the struggle to overcome it, suppress it, to be detached, all that is gone, all movement of escape has completely come to an end. If it has not, don’t move from there. Be free first of all escapes, of all verbal, symbolic escapes, and remain totally with the fact that you are, as a human being, in a state of confusion. Then what has taken place?

所以，我，我本身就是混乱。并非我意识到自己是混乱的，也并非有人告诉我我是混乱的，而是事实：作为一个人，我正处于混乱之中。我的任何行为只会带来更多的混乱。因此，我完全处于混乱之中。所有试图克服它、压制它、摆脱它的努力，都已消逝，所有逃避的尝试都已彻底结束。如果还没有结束，就不要再继续下去。首先要摆脱一切逃避，摆脱一切言语上的、象征性的逃避，全然地接受你作为一个人正处于混乱之中的事实。那么，究竟发生了什么？

We are two friends talking this over, this is not therapy or any of that nonsense, or psychological analysis. We are two people talking this over together, saying how we have come to that point, logically, rationally, unemotionally, and, therefore, sanely. Because to be sane is the most difficult thing. So we have come to that point: that is, I am that. What has taken place in the mind?

我们只是两个朋友在讨论这件事，这不是心理治疗，也不是什么无稽之谈，更不是什么心理分析。我们只是两个人一起讨论这件事，探讨我们是如何得出这个结论的，逻辑地、理性地、不带感情地，因此，也是理智地得出这个结论的。因为保持理智是最难的。所以我们得出了这个结论：那就是，我就是这样。那么，我的内心究竟发生了什么？

Before, I wasted energy in suppressing, trying to find how not to be confused, going to some guru or someone else. All that I have done is a wastage of energy. Now when there is the realization that I am confused, what has happened? Come with me! My mind then is completely attentive to confusion. My mind is in a state of complete attention with regard to confusion. Right? Therefore, what takes place? When there is complete attention, there is no confusion. It is only when there is no attention that confusion arises. Confusion arises when there is division, which is inattention.

以前，我浪费精力去压抑困惑，试图找到摆脱困惑的方法，去求助于什么大师或其他人。我所做的一切都是徒劳。现在，当我意识到自己感到困惑时，发生了什么？跟我来！那时，我的心完全专注于困惑本身。我的心处于一种完全专注于困惑的状态。对吗？那么，会发生什么呢？当心完全专注于困惑时，就不会有困惑。只有当缺乏专注时，困惑才会产生。困惑产生于分裂，也就是缺乏专注。

Where there is total attention there is no dissipation of energy. When I am saying, “How am I to get this total attention?” that is a wastage of energy. When you see that where there is confusion it is brought about by inattention, then that very inattention is attention.

当注意力完全集中时，能量就不会损耗。当我问自己“我该如何才能全神贯注？”时，这本身就是一种能量浪费。当你意识到混乱源于注意力不集中时，你会发现，这种注意力不集中本身就是一种专注。

Now with that attention we are going to examine fear, pleasure, suffering. It is important to be free of fear. The mind has never been free of fear. You may cover it, you may suppress it, you may be unaware of it, you may be so enchanted by the world outside that you are never aware of your own deep-rooted fears. Where there is fear there is no freedom, there is no love, there is discontent. To see this, you must have the capacity to run—not physically but inwardly run, jump—not go step by step like a snail.

现在，带着这份专注，我们将探讨恐惧、快乐和痛苦。摆脱恐惧至关重要。人的心灵从未真正摆脱过恐惧。你或许会掩盖它，或许会压抑它，或许会浑然不觉，或许会被外在世界深深吸引，以至于从未察觉到自己根深蒂固的恐惧。恐惧之中没有自由，没有爱，只有不满。要领悟这一点，你必须拥有奔跑的能力——不是身体上的奔跑，而是内心的奔跑、跳跃——而不是像蜗牛一样一步一步地前进。

One sees what fear does in our life. Fear brings darkness to the mind. We are not talking of a particular neurotic fear, but about fear itself. When we understand the root of fear, fear about something particular disappears. If I am afraid of the dark, that is my particular fear and I want that particular fear to be resolved; I am not concerned with the whole field of fear. But if I understand the whole field of fear, the other thing doesn’t exist. We are concerned with the whole field of fear. Can that fear be dissolved completely, so that the physical fear and the complex fears of the psyche, the inward fears, dissolve? The physical fears one can deal with fairly simply, but if you are attached to physical fears and are concerned only with resolving the physical fears then you are attached to that which will then create division and, therefore, conflict. If we understand first the psychological fears, then you can deal with the physical fears, not the other way round. First deal with the wider fear, the depth and the nature and the darkness of fear, then you will yourself resolve the particular physical fears. Don’t start the other way, with the physical fear, which is what we all want to do.

我们能看到恐惧在我们生活中造成的后果。恐惧会给心灵带来黑暗。我们说的不是某种特定的神经质恐惧，而是恐惧本身。当我们理解了恐惧的根源，对特定事物的恐惧就会消失。如果我害怕黑暗，那是我特定的恐惧，我想要解决的是这种特定的恐惧；我并不关心恐惧的全部。但如果我理解了恐惧的全部，那么其他的恐惧就不存在了。我们关心的是恐惧的全部。这种恐惧能否被彻底消除，以至于生理上的恐惧和复杂的心理恐惧，也就是内在的恐惧，都能消散？生理上的恐惧相对容易处理，但如果你执着于生理上的恐惧，只关注如何解决这些恐惧，那么你就会执着于那些会造成分裂，进而导致冲突的东西。如果我们首先理解了心理上的恐惧，那么你就能处理生理上的恐惧，而不是反过来。首先要处理更广泛的恐惧，恐惧的深度、本质和阴暗面，然后你才能自行解决具体的生理恐惧。不要本末倒置，先从生理恐惧入手，虽然我们都想这么做。

The psychological fears are far more important; they make us such ugly human beings. When there is fear, we become violent, we want to destroy in the name of God, in the name of religion, in the name of social revolution, and so on, and so on. Now, can we as human beings, who have lived with this fear for immeasurable time, be free of it? We have asked that question; now how do you approach the problem of fear? Do you approach it with the desire to resolve it? If you do, you are again separating yourself from the fact of fear. So are you approaching it as an observer who is afraid and wants to resolve it, or do you realize that you are fear?

心理上的恐惧远比物质上的恐惧重要得多；它们使我们变得如此丑陋。恐惧会让我们变得暴力，我们会以神的名义、以宗教的名义、以社会革命的名义等等，想要进行破坏。那么，我们这些在恐惧中生活了无数个世纪的人类，真的能够摆脱它吗？我们已经提出了这个问题；现在，你如何看待恐惧这个问题？你是否带着想要解决它的愿望去面对它？如果你这样做，你又一次把自己与恐惧的本质隔离开来。所以，你是以一个恐惧的旁观者的身份去面对它，想要解决它，还是你意识到自己就是恐惧本身？

Have you given your total attention to this fact? That you, as a human being, who is the rest of humanity, are frightened, live in fear, consciously or unconsciously, with superficial fears or deep hidden fears? The hidden fear becomes completely open when you are attentive.

你是否充分意识到这个事实？作为一个人，你和其余的人类一样，都感到恐惧，生活在恐惧之中，无论是有意识的还是无意识的，无论是表面上的恐惧还是深藏于心的恐惧？当你足够专注时，那些隐藏的恐惧就会完全显露出来。

You are investigating, you are looking at yourself, not agreeing with the speaker, the speaker is not important. And I mean it, he is not important. What is important is that you walk away without a single shadow of fear. So when you become aware of fear, do you escape from it? Do you try to find an answer for it? Do you try to overcome it? If you do, you are dissipating energy; therefore, you are dividing and, therefore, there is conflict about fear and how to be free of it. All that arises. But if you realize that fear is you, there is no movement to be made. There is no movement to be made, you are that and, therefore, all your attention is directed, is that; in that attention fear is held.

你在审视自己，你在反思自己，你不认同说话者的观点，说话者并不重要。我是认真的，他真的不重要。重要的是，你要毫无畏惧地离开。所以，当你意识到恐惧时，你会逃避它吗？你会试图找到答案吗？你会试图克服它吗？如果你这样做，你就是在消耗能量；因此，你造成了分裂，因此，关于恐惧以及如何摆脱恐惧的冲突就会产生。所有这些冲突都会出现。但如果你意识到恐惧就是你自身，那就无需采取任何行动。无需采取任何行动，你就是恐惧本身，因此，你所有的注意力都集中在恐惧上；恐惧就存在于你的注意力之中。

It is up to you. You see, as long as we try to overcome, the very overcoming has to be overcome. But if you say, “Yes, it is a fact and I won’t move from that,” then the thing dissolves—completely, not relatively, not gone one day and then the next day is full of fears. It is gone when you have given complete attention to it.

这取决于你。你看，只要我们试图克服困难，克服困难本身就必须被克服。但如果你说：“是的，这就是事实，我不会改变”，那么这件事就会彻底消失——不是相对的，也不是今天消失明天又充满恐惧。当你全神贯注于它时，它就会消失。

It is similar with regard to pleasure. Be careful now! We have to be very careful here.

快乐方面也是如此。现在要小心！我们必须非常小心。

I don’t know if you have noticed that right from the earliest time of man, one thing that has driven him everlastingly forward is pleasure, the pursuit of pleasure and the avoidance of sorrow. You can see it in the pictures, the paintings, the ancient writings, the symbols. Everything says, Pursue this, avoid that. Thought can divide life into fear, pleasure, sorrow, job; but they are all one, aren’t they? See what we have done: our mind has been conditioned, accepting, living in this norm of constant pursuit of pleasure. God, if you have that image, is the essence of pleasure. You name it differently but your urge is to attain that ultimate sublime pleasure so that you will never be disturbed, you will never be in conflict, and so on, and so on, and so on. And we must understand it, not suppress it, not run away from it.

我不知道你是否注意到，自人类诞生之初，驱使人类不断前进的动力之一就是享乐，追求享乐，逃避悲伤。你可以在图画、绘画、古代文献和各种符号中看到这一点。一切都在告诉我们：追求这个，避免那个。思想可以将生活划分为恐惧、享乐、悲伤和工作；但它们本质上是一体的，不是吗？看看我们做了什么：我们的思想已经被驯化，接受并生活在这种不断追求享乐的常态之中。如果你有这样的概念，上帝就是享乐的本质。你可能用不同的方式来称呼它，但你内心深处的渴望是获得那种至高无上的极致享乐，这样你就不会感到烦恼，不会陷入冲突，等等等等。我们必须理解它，而不是压制它，更不能逃避它。

Why has pleasure, like sorrow, like fear, become so all-important in life? Do you understand the word sorrow , the suffering of man, the suffering of centuries, war after war, destroying human beings, destroying nature, destroying animals, whales, everything? Man not only suffers but causes suffering. That is part of us, part of our consciousness. And we try to avoid that because we have not solved it. We think the pursuit of pleasure is the main thing, that in that at least we can have something accurate, something real that will go on. So that becomes dominant, and fear, sorrow, anxiety, are all in the background—not only sexual pleasures, but the remembrances, the pictures, and all the rest that goes on in the mind. If you watch it, you see what is happening, that your own minds become full of that. Not the actual act but the whole build-up, and that building-up is called love. So pleasure, love, suffering, fear are all entangled, all interrelated.

为什么快乐，就像悲伤和恐惧一样，在生活中变得如此重要？你理解“悲伤”这个词的含义吗？它代表着人类的苦难，几个世纪以来的苦难，一场又一场的战争，摧毁人类，摧毁自然，摧毁动物，鲸鱼，一切的一切。人类不仅承受苦难，也制造苦难。这是我们的一部分，是我们意识的一部分。我们试图逃避它，因为我们还没有解决这个问题。我们认为追求快乐才是最重要的，至少在快乐中，我们可以拥有一些准确、真实且持续的东西。于是快乐占据了主导地位，而恐惧、悲伤、焦虑则退居幕后——不仅仅是性快感，还有回忆、画面以及所有在脑海中浮现的其他东西。如果你观察一下，你会发现正在发生的事情，你的内心充满了这些。不是实际的行为，而是整个积累的过程，而这种积累就叫做爱。所以，快乐、爱、痛苦、恐惧，它们彼此交织，相互关联。

So will you take fear, pleasure, sorrow, separately, one by one? Or will you have the capacity to deal with the whole of it? Our minds are being broken up, so we take one by one, hoping to resolve one by one and come to the end of the breaking up, the fragments. Now how will you deal with the whole of it? Deal with your disorder, pleasure, fear, sorrow as a total movement of life? Not as something separate, but as a whole. Can you do it? That is, can you look at yourself as though it were in a mirror, psychologically, as a whole being? Or can you only look at a part?

所以，你会把恐惧、快乐、悲伤一个一个地单独处理吗？还是你有能力去应对它们的整体？我们的心智正在破碎，所以我们只能一个一个地处理，希望能够一个一个地解决，最终摆脱破碎的碎片。那么，你将如何应对它们的整体呢？将你的混乱、快乐、恐惧、悲伤视为生命整体的一部分来处理吗？不是将它们视为彼此分离的东西，而是视为一个整体。你能做到吗？也就是说，你能否像照镜子一样，从心理层面，将自己视为一个完整的个体？还是你只能看到其中的一部分？

How do you look at yourself? Can you take your job, your wife and children, your religion, your particular way of thinking, your experiences, your ideas, your intentions, your ambitions, as one unitary movement? That is the only way to solve the whole thing, not through fragments.

你如何看待自己？你能否将你的工作、妻子和孩子、你的宗教信仰、你独特的思维方式、你的经历、你的想法、你的意图、你的抱负视为一个整体？只有这样才能解决所有问题，而不是把所有事情割裂开来。

Now how will a mind, the brain, the emotions, that have been broken up for generations upon generations, approach or realize the totality? Will you approach the whole of life fragmentarily, business first, money first, house first, wife, children, sex, bit by bit? Or can your mind see the whole of existence? Is it capable of that?
