Or are you striving to see the whole of it? If you are striving to see the whole of it, it is finished, you will never have it, because then you create a division, conflict, confusion. To see that life is one movement, you need really to learn. Learn—not from me! Learn from yourself by observing. Learn to observe the division and see the futility of approaching that; see the obvious fact that you can’t through one fragment approach the whole universe. You must have a mind that is capable of receiving the whole universe, and that is possible only when the mind is clear of confusion, fear. Then there is no shadow of division, as the “me” and “you,” my country, your country, my dogma, and so on. That means, when there is complete freedom then there is the perception of the whole. And from that comprehension, from that intelligence, one can act in the world, to get a job, to get no job, to do anything. But now we approach it as parts and we are creating havoc in the world.

那么，一个世世代代被割裂的心灵、大脑和情感，又该如何接近或领悟整体呢？你会以碎片化的方式去理解人生，先是事业，先是金钱，先是房子，然后是妻子、孩子、性，一点一点地来吗？还是你的心灵能够洞察整个存在？它有能力做到吗？或者你只是在努力去理解它的全部？如果你试图去理解它的全部，那就失败了，你永远无法真正理解，因为那样你会制造分裂、冲突和混乱。要领悟到生命是一个整体，你需要真正地去学习。学习——不是向我学习！而是通过观察来学习你自己。学会观察这种分裂，并看清试图去理解它的徒劳；看清一个显而易见的事实：你不可能通过一个碎片来理解整个宇宙。你必须拥有一个能够接纳整个宇宙的心灵，而这只有在心灵摆脱了混乱和恐惧之后才有可能。那时，就不会有分裂的阴影，不会有“我”和“你”、我的国家和你的国家、我的教条等等。这意味着，当拥有完全的自由时，就能感知整体。凭借这种理解和智慧，人们可以在世间行动，找到工作，或者不找工作，去做任何事。但现在我们却将世界视为一个个局部，从而给世界带来了混乱。

Why does the mind live in time? It has evolved in time. The present mind that we have has evolved through thousands of years. And that is normal and healthy, obviously. But we are asking why time has become so important psychologically, inwardly. Please ask yourself. Is it because we are always avoiding what is in order to become something else, moving from this to that? Psychologically I am this, but I should not be this but that. Psychologically I am unhappy, but I must be happy. The “must” or “will” or “shall be” is the movement of time. So the mind is caught in time because it is always moving away from this, from what is . It will change in time: “I will be good, give me time.” That is like developing a muscle. Your muscle may not be sufficiently strong but if you keep on doing something to strengthen it, it will become strong. With the same mentality we say, “I am this, I will be that, so give me time.” But will what is be changed through time? When I have great anxiety, can that anxiety be changed through time? That is, will I become, or be in, a state where I have no anxiety? See what I have done? I have anxiety; I have projected a state of not being anxious; and to arrive at that state I must have time. But I never ask if this anxiety I have can be changed immediately without allowing time. See what happens: I am anxious; I hope to be not anxious; there is a time interval, a lag, and in that lag of time all other activities are going on, other pressures, negligence; so anxiety is never solved. I think I will come to a state when I have no anxiety, so I am struggling, struggling. It is like a man who is violent. He has invented nonviolence, but in that time interval he is violent, so he never reaches nonviolence.

为什么心灵会活在时间之中？因为它随着时间演化。我们现在的心灵经历了数千年的演化。这显然是正常且健康的。但我们想知道的是，为什么时间在心理层面、在内心深处变得如此重要？请扪心自问。是因为我们总是逃避现实，为了成为另一种状态，从一种状态走向另一种状态吗？心理上，我是这样，但我不应该这样，而应该那样。心理上，我不快乐，但我必须快乐。“必须”、“将会”或“应该”正是时间的流逝。所以，心灵被困在时间之中，因为它总是在逃离现实。它会随着时间改变：“我会变好的，给我点时间。”这就像锻炼肌肉。你的肌肉可能不够强壮，但如果你坚持锻炼，它就会变得强壮。我们抱着同样的心态说：“我现在是这样，我以后会变成那样，所以给我点时间。”但现实真的会随着时间改变吗？当我感到极度焦虑时，这种焦虑会随着时间改变吗？也就是说，我是否会达到，或者说是否会处于一种没有焦虑的状态？看看我做了什么？我有焦虑；我设想了一种没有焦虑的状态；而要达到那种状态，我需要时间。但我从未问过，我目前的焦虑是否可以在不等待时间的情况下立即改变。看看结果如何：我焦虑；我希望不再焦虑；这其中存在时间间隔，存在滞后，而在这段滞后的时间里，所有其他的活动、压力和疏忽都在进行；因此，焦虑永远无法消除。我认为我会达到一种没有焦虑的状态，所以我一直在挣扎，挣扎。这就像一个暴力的人。他发明了非暴力，但在那段时间间隔里，他仍然暴力，所以他永远无法达到非暴力。

So the question is then: Can what is be transformed immediately, which means never allowing time to interfere? Listen to this, you will find out, it is really simple. If we apply our mind we can solve anything. They have been to the moon, built marvelous submarines, done incredible things. Here, psychologically, we are so reluctant, so incapable, or have made ourselves incapable. If you do not allow time, or never think in terms of time, then the fact is not. Because we allow time the fact becomes important. If there is no time it is resolved. Suppose I died this second, there is no problem. When I allow time, I am afraid of death. If I live completely without psychological time, it is an extraordinary thing. Time means accumulation. Time means remembrance. Time means accumulating knowledge about oneself. But when there is no time at all, psychologically, there is nothing.

所以问题就变成了：事物能否立即改变，也就是说，能否完全不让时间干预？听我说，你会发现，其实很简单。如果我们运用智慧，就能解决任何问题。他们已经登上月球，建造了精妙的潜艇，创造了无数奇迹。然而，在心理层面，我们却如此犹豫不决，如此无能为力，或者说，是自己让自己变得无能为力。如果你不让时间介入，或者从不以时间的视角思考，那么事实就不存在。正因为我们让时间介入，事实才变得重要。如果没有时间，问题就迎刃而解。假设我此刻死去，那也没什么问题。当我让时间介入时，我反而会害怕死亡。如果我完全摆脱心理上的时间概念，那将是一件非同寻常的事情。时间意味着积累。时间意味着记忆。时间意味着积累关于自身的知识。但是，当心理层面完全没有时间时，一切就都不存在了。

Because we have allowed time as a factor to intervene between living and dying, fear arises. The nature of dying can be found in the living. That is, death is the ending, the ending of my possessions, my wife, my children, my house, my bank account. In that ending there is no argument. I don’t say to death, “Please hold on a minute.” So where there is ending, there is a beginning. I will go into it.

因为我们允许时间介入生与死之间，恐惧便由此而生。死亡的本质可以在生中找到。也就是说，死亡是终结，是我所有财产的终结，我的妻子、我的孩子、我的房子、我的银行存款。面对这样的终结，没有丝毫辩解。我不会对死亡说：“请稍等片刻。”所以，有终结的地方，就有新的开始。我会深入探讨这一点。

When there is an ending to attachment—completely, not just to persons and ideas but the whole process of attachment, with all the consequences of that—there is a totally different state of mind. Isn’t there? I have been attached to my furniture and that attachment has been a burden. With the ending of that burden there is freedom. So ending is more important than beginning. So can I, living, end? End my anxiety, end my fears. End, not the bank account, I am not talking of that, but ending psychologically. Ending my uncertainty. When I am confused, to end it, not say, “I must find out why I am confused, what is the cause of confusion, and I must be free from confusion.” All that is time. That is negligence, whereas diligence is to be aware of the whole movement of time and to end anxiety immediately. Therefore, there is no accumulation psychologically as knowledge.

当执着彻底终结——不仅仅是对人或观念的执着，而是对整个执着过程及其所有后果的执着——就会进入一种截然不同的心境。难道不是吗？我一直执着于我的家具，这种执着成了我的负担。摆脱了这种负担，我便获得了自由。所以，终结比开始更重要。那么，活着的我，能否终结？终结我的焦虑，终结我的恐惧。终结，不是指银行账户，我说的不是这个，而是指心理上的终结。终结我的不确定。当我感到困惑时，要终结它，而不是说：“我必须找出我困惑的原因，困惑的根源是什么，我必须摆脱困惑。”所有这些都只是时间问题。那是疏忽，而勤勉则是觉察时间的流逝，并立即终结焦虑。因此，心理上的知识积累是不存在的。

Now death is ending. Ending of everything. Death is an ending and I am living. We are living, active. Can we psychologically end everything? Can you end your attachment instantly, immediately—your anger, your violence, your greed, your this and that, end while living? Then living is dying. Not living and ultimately dying. Living means the dying, otherwise you are not alive. And most of us are frightened of dying because we have never been able to live properly, we have never lived. We have lived in conflict, in struggle, in pain, in anxiety, and we call that living. Living is not all that. If all that can be ended, then there is living. So you are then living and dying. They go together, like a flower with perfume; the perfume is not apart from the flower, it is there.

死亡即将终结。一切的终结。死亡是终结，而我活着。我们活着，积极地活着。我们能否在心理上终结一切？你能否在活着的同时，瞬间、立刻地断绝你的执念——你的愤怒、你的暴力、你的贪婪、你的种种执念？那样，活着就是死亡。不是活着，最终走向死亡。活着意味着死亡，否则你就不是活着。我们大多数人害怕死亡，因为我们从未真正地活过，我们从未真正地活过。我们生活在冲突、挣扎、痛苦和焦虑之中，而我们称之为活着。活着并非如此。如果这一切都能终结，那么活着才算真正。所以，你既活着，也死去。它们相辅相成，就像一朵花与一缕芬芳；芬芳并非独立于花朵之外，它就在那里。

This is the actual ending of senility, if you go into it very deeply, so the mind never gets old like a machine that is always wearing itself out because of friction. But it is not your mind, it is the human mind. The mind is the result of a million years, it is the mind of the Indian, of the Chinese, the Russians, all other human beings, because they go through similar pain, anxiety, sorrow, pleasures, occasional joys and occasional love. So our brain, our mind, is the mind of humanity. If you can understand that one real fact then we will live without any division, which is causing such disaster in the world.

如果你深入探究，就会发现这才是老年痴呆症的真正终结。人的思维不会像机器那样因摩擦而不断磨损。但这并非指你个人的思维，而是指全人类的思维。思维是亿万年来的产物，它是印度人、中国人、俄罗斯人以及所有人类的共同思维，因为他们都经历着相似的痛苦、焦虑、悲伤、快乐、偶尔的喜悦和偶尔的爱。所以，我们的大脑，我们的思维，就是全人类的思维。如果你能理解这个真理，我们就能生活在没有分裂的世界里，而分裂正是造成世界灾难的根源。

Because their minds are everlastingly chattering, everlastingly moving from one thing to another, driven by desire, driven by seeking reward and avoiding pain, human beings have always sought some kind of quietness, some kind of peace in which at least for ten minutes it can be quiet. Man has sought this. Go to the church, sit there quietly. Go to a marvelous cathedral, when there is no circus going on, and be quiet. And it is a strange fact that in all these churches there is never a moment of quietness, except when it is empty. Because if you are quiet, you might inquire. If you are quiet, you might begin to doubt. But if you are occupied all the time, you never have time to look around, to question, to doubt, to ask. That may be one of the great tricks of the human mind.

因为人类的思绪永不停歇地飞速运转，永不停歇地从一件事跳到另一件事，受欲望驱使，受追求回报和逃避痛苦的驱使，所以人类总是渴望某种宁静，某种平和，哪怕只有十分钟的片刻安宁。人类一直在追求这种宁静。去教堂，静静地坐下。去一座宏伟的大教堂，在没有喧闹表演的时候，静静地待在那里。然而，一个奇怪的事实是，在所有这些教堂里，除了空无一人的时候，从来没有片刻的宁静。因为如果你安静下来，你或许会去探究。如果你安静下来，你或许会开始怀疑。但如果你一直忙碌不停，你就永远没有时间环顾四周，去质疑，去怀疑，去询问。这或许是人类思维的一大奥秘。

What is meditation and why should one meditate? Is it natural? Like breathing, like seeing, like hearing, is it natural? And why have we made it so unnatural? Taking postures, following systems of Buddhist meditation, Tibetan meditation, Christian meditation, Tantric meditations, and the meditations set by your favorite guru. Aren’t all those really abnormal? Why should I take a certain position to meditate? Why should I practice, practice, practice? To arrive where? Can I follow a system—twenty minutes in the morning, twenty minutes in the evening—to have a quiet mind? Having achieved a little quiet mind I can go off and do other mischief all day long.

什么是冥想？为什么要冥想？它自然吗？就像呼吸、视觉、听觉一样，它自然吗？为什么我们把它变得如此不自然？摆出各种姿势，遵循佛教冥想、藏传佛教冥想、基督教冥想、密宗冥想，以及你最喜欢的上师制定的冥想方法。难道这些不都是不正常的吗？我为什么要采取特定的姿势来冥想？我为什么要练习、练习、再练习？最终又能达到什么目的？我能否遵循某种固定的模式——早上二十分钟，晚上二十分钟——来获得内心的平静？获得一点点平静之后，我就可以整天去做其他乱七八糟的事情了。

Is there a way of meditating that is none of these things? People say meditation is to quiet the mind, to have a mind that is capable of observation, to have a mind that is completely centered, completely concentrated, so that there is no thought except one thought, one picture, one image, one center upon which you are looking. Right? I don’t know if you have gone through all this? The speaker has played with them for half an hour for each of these meditations, for ten minutes, five minutes, and they meant nothing.

有没有一种冥想方法不包含以上任何一种？人们说冥想是为了让心灵平静下来，拥有一个能够观察的心灵，拥有一个完全集中、完全专注的心灵，以至于除了一个念头、一幅画面、一个意象、一个你注视的中心之外，别无他念。对吗？我不知道你是否经历过这一切？演讲者尝试了这些方法，每次冥想持续半小时、十分钟、五分钟，但都毫无意义。

You have to go into the question of who is the controller and who is the controlled. Our whole life, if you observe, is this: controlling and not controlling: I must control my emotions; I must control my thinking; I can only control my thinking by constant practice; and to practice I must have a system. A system implies a mechanical process, making the mind more and more mechanical. It is already mechanical now but we want to make it much more dull. Why do we go through all this? You want to have an experience, and you know drugs do you harm; therefore, you put them aside, but hope that by practicing something you will experience something else.

你必须探究谁是控制者，谁是被控制者。如果你仔细观察，就会发现我们的一生都在不断地控制与不控制之间摇摆不定：我必须控制自己的情绪；我必须控制自己的思想；我只能通过不断的练习来控制自己的思想；而要练习，我必须有一个系统。系统意味着一个机械的过程，这使得思维变得越来越机械。它现在已经很机械了，但我们却想让它变得更加迟钝。我们为什么要经历这一切？你想获得某种体验，你知道药物有害；因此，你把它们放在一边，但希望通过练习某种方法，你能获得另一种体验。

Why do human beings demand experience? Is the mind asleep, and experience means a challenge? Or is the mind awake and so does not need an experience? You have to find out if your mind is asleep, or bored with the experiences that you have had: sex, drugs, and all the rest. You want something far beyond all that; you are always craving for more delightful, more extravagant, experience. Why does the mind demand experience? Ask yourself, please.

人类为何如此渴望体验？是心灵沉睡，体验意味着挑战吗？还是心灵清醒，所以不需要体验？你必须弄清楚你的心灵是沉睡的，还是对过往的体验——性、毒品等等——感到厌倦。你想要的远不止这些；你总是渴望更愉悦、更奢华的体验。心灵为何如此渴望体验？请扪心自问。

There is only one thing. A mind that is very clear is free from all entanglements of attachment. Such a mind is a light to itself. Therefore, it does not want an experience, there is nothing to experience. You cannot experience enlightenment. The very idea of experiencing it is a stupid thing to say; to say, “I have achieved enlightenment,” is really dishonest. You cannot experience truth because there must be an experiencer to experience. If there is no experiencer, there is no experience at all. But we are attached to our experiencer and, therefore, we are always asking for more and more and more.

只有一件事。一颗清明的心摆脱了所有执着的纠缠。这样的心本身就是一盏明灯。因此，它不需要任何体验，因为没有什么可体验的。你无法体验开悟。说“我已经开悟了”本身就是愚蠢的；说“我已经开悟了”是虚伪的。你无法体验真理，因为必须有一个体验者才能体验。如果没有体验者，就根本无法体验。但我们执着于体验者，因此我们总是不断地索取更多、更多、更多。

Meditation generally as it is accepted now is the practice of a system, breathing properly, sitting in the right position, wanting or craving greater experience, or the ultimate experience. This is what we are doing. And all that is a constant struggle, a never-ending struggle. This is a never-ending struggle, which is hoping to end all struggles! See what we have done. I am struggling, struggling, struggling to end struggling sometime in the future. See what tricks I have played on myself. I am caught in time. I don’t say, “Why should I struggle at all?” If I can end this struggle that is enlightenment. To have no shadow of conflict. But we do not want to give up all those efforts; we are caught in time. And to be free of time is to be free to have pure observation, and then the mind becomes extraordinarily quiet. You don’t have to make the mind quiet. If you end all conflict, the mind naturally becomes quiet. And when the mind is absolutely silent, without any movement of thought, then perhaps you will see something, perhaps there is something sacred beyond all words. And this man has sought everlastingly, something that is beyond measure, beyond thought, which is incorruptible, unnameable, eternal. That can only take place when the mind is absolutely free and completely silent.

如今人们普遍接受的冥想，其实就是一套系统的练习：正确的呼吸、正确的坐姿，以及对更深层次体验或终极体验的渴望。这就是我们正在做的。而这一切都是一场持续不断的斗争，一场永无止境的斗争。这是一场永无止境的斗争，却妄图终结一切斗争！看看我们都做了些什么。我一直在挣扎，挣扎，挣扎，试图在未来的某个时刻终结这场斗争。看看我对自己耍了多少花招。我被困在了时间之中。我不会说：“我为什么要挣扎？”如果我能终结这场斗争，那就是开悟。那就是没有冲突的阴影。但我们不想放弃所有这些努力；我们被困在了时间之中。而摆脱时间，就是自由地拥有纯粹的观察力，那时，心灵就会变得异常平静。你无需刻意让心灵平静下来。如果你终结了所有冲突，心灵自然就会平静下来。当心灵绝对寂静，没有任何念头流动时，或许你会看到一些东西，或许存在着超越一切言语的神圣之物。这个人毕生都在追寻某种无法衡量、超越思维、不朽不灭、不可名状、永恒之物。唯有当心灵完全自由、彻底寂静时，才能抵达彼岸。

So one must begin very near, very near. And when you begin very near, there is no far. When you begin near, there is no distance and, therefore, there is no time. And it is only then that that which is most holy can be.

所以，必须从非常近的地方开始，非常近的地方。当你从非常近的地方开始，就没有遥远。当你从近的地方开始，就没有距离，因此也没有时间。只有这样，最神圣的事物才能存在。

Brockwood Park, September 6 and September 7, 1980

布罗克伍德公园，1980年9月6日和7日

#↩

THE ENDING OF SORROW

悲伤的终结

My friends, if you have listened to yourself, the speaker is only a mirror in which you see yourself as you are. If you see yourself as you are, then you can throw away the mirror, break it. The mirror is not important. It has no value. What has value is that you see clearly in that mirror yourself as you are, the pettiness, the narrowness, the brutality, the anxieties, the fears. When you begin to understand yourself then you go profoundly into something that is beyond all measure. But you must take the first step. And nobody is going to help you to take that first step.

朋友们，如果你认真倾听过自己的内心，就会发现说话者不过是一面镜子，让你从中看到真实的自己。如果你看清了自己，就可以扔掉这面镜子，把它打碎。镜子本身并不重要，它毫无价值。真正有价值的是，你在那面镜子里清晰地看到了真实的自己——你的狭隘、你的冷酷、你的焦虑、你的恐惧。当你开始真正了解自己时，你便会进入一个超越一切衡量的境界。但你必须迈出第一步。没有人会帮你迈出这第一步。

We are thinking together, walking down a lane full of quietness and a great sense of beauty. One wonders what beauty is. You may see some statue or picture or a lovely head of the Buddha in a museum, or in a house, and you say how marvelous it is; but behind the words, behind the structure of a painting, the shadows, the proportions, what is beauty? Is it in the way you look at it? Is it in the picture? Is it in the face of a person? When you see a marvelous mountain against a blue sky, with the great depth of a valley and snowcapped peaks, when you look at all that great beauty, for a moment you have forgotten yourself. The mountain is so vast, so extraordinarily lighted by the morning sun catching the highest peaks, and your whole brain is struck by the grandeur, by the greatness of that sight, and for a second you forget all about yourself, forget all about your worries; you forget your wife, your husband, your children, your country. And you look at that with all your being, and have no sense of contradiction, duality. Its splendor is there and the self, the “me” is for a second put aside by the greatness of that beauty.

我们一起思考，漫步在一条静谧而充满美感的林荫小道上。人们不禁会问，美究竟是什么？你或许会在博物馆或某户人家里看到一尊雕像、一幅画，或是一尊精美的佛像，你会赞叹它的美妙；但抛开文字，抛开画作的结构、光影和比例，美究竟是什么？它存在于你的观看方式中吗？它存在于画作本身吗？它存在于人的面容中吗？当你看到一座巍峨的山峰映衬着蔚蓝的天空，深邃的山谷和皑皑的雪峰环绕四周，当你凝视着这壮丽的景色，你会在那一刻忘却自我。山峦如此雄伟，晨曦洒在最高的山峰上，光芒四射，你的整个大脑都被这壮阔的景象所震撼，被这景象的伟大所震撼，那一刻，你忘却了所有，忘却了所有烦恼；你忘却了你的妻子、丈夫、孩子、国家。你全神贯注地凝视着这一切，心中没有丝毫矛盾和二元对立。它的壮丽就在那里，在那份伟大的美丽面前，自我，那个“我”，瞬间被抛在了脑后。

As one came in, one looked at the moon, very young, new, extraordinarily simple. And, therefore, one thought, what is the point of talking at all? What is the point of reading books, attending meetings, what is the point of all this existence when one cannot look at this simple thing clearly, with great love and affection, a simple thing, to approach life with all its complexity, simply, without all the accumulated knowledge of our past, our traditions? Just to look at this vast movement of life, simply, with a brain that is not burdened, a brain that is active, alive, full of energy, with clarity, simplicity.

走进房间，抬头望向月亮，它年轻、崭新、无比纯粹。于是，人们不禁思忖：说话的意义何在？读书、参加会议的意义何在？如果不能以无比的爱与关怀，清晰地看待这简单的事物，去直面生活的复杂性，抛开过往积累的知识和传统，那么这一切存在的意义又是什么？仅仅用一颗清澈、纯净的大脑，一颗活跃、鲜活、充满活力的大脑，去观察这浩瀚的生命运动。

Having said that, let us proceed together. We human beings have suffered a great deal. There have been incessant wars. For the last five thousand years there has been a war practically every year, human beings killing each other, destroying what they have built, great monuments being destroyed overnight. This has been the history of man, perpetual conflict, war. And through wars man has suffered enormously. How many people have shed tears—for their sons, their husbands left maimed for life, one arm, no legs, blind. Mankind has shed tears endlessly. And we too are shedding tears, because our life is rather empty, lonely. And we suffer too, all of us, not only watching the suffering of others but also the grief, the pain, the anxiety, of our own life, the poverty of people, not the poverty of the poor only but also the poverty of our own minds and hearts. And when we begin to discover this enormous poverty, in spite of our vast information and knowledge, that breeds also great sorrow.

话虽如此，让我们继续前行。我们人类饱受苦难。战争从未间断。过去五千年来，几乎每年都有战争，人类互相残杀，摧毁他们所建造的一切，伟大的纪念碑一夜之间化为乌有。这就是人类的历史，永无休止的冲突和战争。战争给人类带来了巨大的苦难。有多少人流泪——为了他们的儿子，为了他们终身残疾的丈夫，为了失去一只胳膊、一条腿、一只眼睛。人类的眼泪无尽流淌。我们也在流泪，因为我们的生活相当空虚、孤独。我们也在承受痛苦，我们所有人，不仅目睹他人的苦难，也承受着我们自身生活的悲伤、痛苦和焦虑，承受着人们的贫困，不仅是穷人的贫困，也包括我们自身心灵的贫瘠。当我们开始意识到这种巨大的贫瘠时，即便我们拥有丰富的信息和知识，也会带来巨大的悲伤。

There is the sorrow of loneliness, the sorrow brought about by man’s inhumanity to man, the sorrow of losing your friend, your son, your brother, your mother, and so on. We have carried this sorrow throughout our lives for centuries upon centuries. And we have never asked if that sorrow can ever end. We are asking now, together, looking at this sorrow of the world and the sorrow in which one lives, in your own heart, in your own mind, in your own brain. We are asking whether that sorrow can ever end, or must men and women always carry it throughout the future from the past. Can that sorrow ever end?

世间有孤独的悲伤，有人类残暴带来的悲伤，有失去朋友、儿子、兄弟、母亲等等的悲伤。几个世纪以来，我们一直背负着这份悲伤。我们从未问过，这份悲伤是否终将结束。如今，我们共同面对着这世间的悲伤，以及每个人内心深处、思想深处、思维深处的悲伤，我们不禁要问：这份悲伤是否终将结束？还是说，人们注定要永远背负着这份来自过去的悲伤，走向未来？这份悲伤，真的能够结束吗？

As there is an art in love and so on, there is also an art in questioning, doubting; doubting one’s own conclusions, one’s own opinions, to question why we tolerate this vast burden of sorrow. Sorrow is also self-pity, the feeling of utter loneliness, and the sorrow that is brought about through great failures, through comparison, through the whole movement of feeling a sense of lack of relationship to anybody. But we never go to the very end of it. We would rather escape from it, seek some form of comfort, some form of drug that gives us solace.

爱情等等，其中蕴含着艺术，质疑、怀疑也是一种艺术；质疑自己的结论、自己的观点，质疑我们为何要忍受这沉重的悲伤。悲伤也包含自怜，包含彻底的孤独感，包含因巨大的失败、因攀比、因感到与任何人缺乏联系而产生的悲伤。但我们从未真正面对过悲伤的尽头。我们宁愿逃避，寻求某种慰藉，某种能给我们带来慰藉的药物。

So, could we not try to find an answer, not ask whether sorrow can be conquered, but be aware to see the full meaning of that word sorrow ? Sorrow also means, etymologically, passion—not lust, passion. Without passion, life becomes rather dull, meaningless. And the ending of sorrow brings about passion. So together we are looking at this word, the content of that word, the significance of that thing called sorrow , which man has carried throughout his life—looking at it, not explaining it away, not finding the cause. There are many causes of sorrow—the death of a son, the failure of not being successful, not being able to fulfill, having no identification, and so on and so on—but if you are inquiring into the causes of sorrow then you are also preventing yourself from looking at the word, the beauty, the strength of that word.

所以，我们能否尝试寻找答案，而不是追问悲伤是否可以被战胜，而是去领悟“悲伤”一词的全部含义？从词源学上讲，“悲伤”也意味着激情——不是欲望，而是激情。没有激情，生活就会变得乏味、毫无意义。而悲伤的终结会带来激情。因此，我们共同审视这个词，审视它的内涵，审视人类一生都背负的“悲伤”的意义——审视它，而不是试图解释它，也不是寻找它的根源。悲伤的根源有很多——丧子之痛、事业失败、无法实现目标、缺乏认同感等等——但如果你只关注悲伤的根源，那么你也就无法真正欣赏这个词本身，欣赏它的美丽和力量。

Sorrow means grief, pain, anxiety, desperate loneliness, the meaninglessness of this existence. All that and more is contained in that word. Can you look at it wholly, as you would hold a precious jewel, a marvelous piece of sculpture? Hold it, remain with it, and not in any way allow thought to come and interfere with that actuality. If you can so remain with that, then that very word, the significance of that word, is totally ended. But we never stay with anything. We always want to find an end, and so we are always moving away from that very jewel that would give us great vitality, great strength, great passion.

悲伤意味着哀痛、痛苦、焦虑、绝望的孤独，以及人生的虚无。所有这些，甚至更多，都包含在这个词之中。你能否全然地看待它，如同捧着一颗珍贵的宝石，一件精美的雕塑？捧着它，与它同在，不让任何杂念干扰这份真实。如果你能如此与它同在，那么这个词本身，它的意义，就彻底消逝了。但我们永远无法与任何事物真正相伴。我们总是想要寻找终点，因此，我们总是远离那颗本可以赋予我们巨大活力、巨大力量、巨大激情的宝石。

Are we walking together, or are you merely listening to these words and getting emotional, romantic and, therefore, never looking at that thing, the pain of it, the grief, the emptiness of one’s own being? If one can really completely hold that jewel, it is a great jewel, but man has tried to do everything he can to escape from it; volumes have been written about it. But the books, the explanations, the words, are not the actual. Remain with the actual, then that very attention brings an end to that thing that we call sorrow.

我们是在携手同行，还是你只是在听着这些话语，沉浸在感伤和浪漫之中，因此从未正视过那件事——痛苦、悲伤、以及自身存在的空虚？如果一个人能够真正完全地把握住那颗宝石，它的确是一颗伟大的宝石，但人类却竭尽所能地想要逃避它；关于它的著作汗牛充栋。然而，书籍、解释、言语，都不是真实。唯有与真实相伴，那份专注本身，才能终结我们称之为悲伤的那件事。

Where there is sorrow there cannot be love. Love is not related to any activity of the human brain. Love is something that comes into being when there is no fear, when there is an end to sorrow. Then that very love becomes compassion, which is passion, with its immense intelligence.

悲伤之处，爱便无从谈起。爱与人脑的任何活动都无关。爱是在恐惧消散、悲伤终结之时产生的。那时，爱便化作慈悲，慈悲即激情，蕴含着无比的智慧。

We are all going to die, but we human beings put that as far away as possible from us; and so there is duality: living and dying. Have you ever considered what duality is and whether duality, the opposite, exists at all? We have been brought up by tradition, by education, by the books, to think that there is duality, contradiction, man and woman, anger and not being angry, violence and nonviolence, and so on. So we have divided the whole of life into duality. Is there such a thing as duality, is there an opposite, psychologically? Of course, there is an opposite between man and woman, between daylight and darkness, sunrise and sunset. You are taller than another, someone is fairer than another, one person is more learned than another; there is that physical duality, the opposites, dark hair, fair hair, the beautiful and the ugly.

我们终将一死，但人类却竭力将死亡与自己隔离开来；于是便有了二元性：生与死。你是否曾思考过二元性究竟是什么？二元性，或者说对立面，真的存在吗？我们从小就被传统、教育和书本灌输一种观念：世间万物皆有二元性，充满矛盾，比如男人与女人、愤怒与不愤怒、暴力与非暴力等等。我们把整个人生都分割成了二元对立。二元性真的存在吗？在心理学层面，真的存在对立面吗？当然，男人与女人、白昼与黑暗、日出与日落之间都存在对立面。你比别人高，有人比别人白皙，有人比别人博学；生理上的二元性，对立面，黑发与金发，美与丑，都存在。

Now, psychologically, inwardly, is there an opposite? Your tradition says there is. Books have been written about it saying that it is only the liberated who are free from duality—which is such utter nonsense. Sorry. You and I can look at this problem very simply—simply, not with all the complications of philosophers. There is duality outwardly, but inwardly, psychologically, inside the skin there is only one thing. There is anger, for example, and when you say, “I must not be angry,” it becomes duality, the ideal which thought has projected, has structured from the pain it has. So there is only that fact. Violence is a fact, nonviolence is nonfact. So why do we give such importance to the nonfact, which then becomes the opposite? We are caught in this ugly business of duality, which means choice, to choose.

那么，从心理层面，从内在层面来说，是否存在对立面呢？你们的传统认为存在。有人著书立说，只有获得解脱的人才能摆脱二元性——这简直是无稽之谈。抱歉。你我可以用非常简单的方式来看待这个问题——简单，而不是像哲学家那样陷入复杂的论证。外在存在二元性，但在内在，从心理层面，在皮肤之下，只有一件事。例如，存在愤怒，当你对自己说“我不能生气”时，它就变成了二元性，变成了思想投射的理想，是思想从痛苦中构建出来的。所以，只有这一个事实。暴力是事实，非暴力是非事实。那么，我们为什么如此重视非事实，而它最终却变成了对立面呢？我们被困在了这种丑陋的二元性之中，这意味着选择，意味着做出选择。

Is there an opposite, psychologically, in anything at all? There is violence, anger, hatred, dislike. Those are facts. But to invent a nonfact like nonviolence, that you must like people, and so on and so on, is just unreal. Therefore, there is only the fact. And a fact has no opposite. When we live with fact, then there is no conflict involved. Have you understood anything of this? But our whole condition is based on duality: I am this, I must not be that; I am a coward, I must be brave; I am ignorant about myself, so I must learn that. We are caught up in this. And we are saying there is no opposite psychologically at all actually. The opposite is structured, or put together, by thought to escape from the actual. I am violent, that’s actual; but there are a great many people telling me that I must be nonviolent. The nonviolence is totally unreal, because I am violent. But if I remain with the actuality then I can do something about it, or not do anything about it, not pretend. To pursue the ideal of nonviolence is just playing games with yourself. While you are pursuing nonviolence, you are actually violent. So we are saying there is no psychological opposite, there is only what is . And if you understand that, then does the conflict of duality exist at all?

从心理学角度来说，任何事物真的存在对立面吗？暴力、愤怒、仇恨、厌恶，这些都是事实。但凭空捏造出“非暴力”这种非事实，比如你必须喜欢别人等等，这完全是无稽之谈。因此，只有事实本身。而事实没有对立面。当我们接受事实时，就不会产生冲突。你明白这一点吗？但我们的整个处境都建立在二元对立之上：我是这样的，我不能是那样的；我是懦夫，我必须勇敢；我对自身一无所知，所以我必须学习。我们深陷其中。而我们却说，实际上，从心理学角度来看，根本不存在对立面。对立面是思想为了逃避现实而构建或拼凑出来的。我是暴力的，这是事实；但很多人告诉我，我必须非暴力。非暴力完全是无稽之谈，因为我本身就是暴力的。但如果我直面现实，我就可以有所作为，也可以选择不作为，而不是假装。追求非暴力的理想不过是自欺欺人。当你追求非暴力时，你实际上就是在施暴。所以我们说，不存在心理上的对立面，只有现实本身。如果你理解了这一点，那么二元对立的冲突还存在吗？

With that quality of brain that has understood this question of duality, let us look at what is called living and dying. We are trying to eliminate altogether this conflict between what is and “what should be.” Then the brain is free and full of energy to face things as they are. So there is the living and the dying as two opposites. To understand both, the living and the dying, one must approach this nondualistically. What is living, what do you call living? Going to the office from nine o’clock in the morning to six o’clock in the evening every day of your life for the next sixty years, being bossed, being bullied, and you bullying somebody else? Or you are a businessman always wanting more and more money, more power, better position, and then go home and quarrel with your wife, sleep with her, and beat her up verbally, or actually. And this constant struggle, constant conflict, the utter despair, hopelessness, goes on. This is what we call living. And in your heart of hearts there is fear, despair, anxiety, grief. This is actuality, isn’t it? And you are frightened to leave that, because death is coming. One is deeply identified with this so-called living, has taken roots in that, and is frightened to end all that.

凭借这种理解了二元性问题的思维能力，让我们来探讨一下所谓的生与死。我们试图彻底消除“存在”与“应然”之间的冲突。如此，大脑才能自由而充满活力地面对事物的本来面目。因此，生与死是两个对立面。要理解生与死，就必须以非二元论的视角来看待它们。什么是生活？你如何定义生活？是每天从早上九点到晚上六点去办公室，在接下来的六十年里，被人颐指气使、被人欺凌，甚至欺凌他人吗？还是你是一个商人，总是渴望更多的金钱、权力、地位，然后回家与妻子争吵、同床共枕，甚至对她进行言语或肢体上的虐待？这种持续不断的斗争、冲突、彻底的绝望和无助，就这样周而复始。这就是我们所说的生活。而你的内心深处，充满了恐惧、绝望、焦虑和悲伤。这就是现实，不是吗？你害怕离开这一切，因为死亡终将到来。人深深地认同了这种所谓的“生活”，已经在其中扎根，害怕结束这一切。

And so you say there will be a next life. Next life is the continuity of the same old pattern, only perhaps in a different environment. If you believe in the next life, then you must live rightly now—morally, ethically, have some sense of humility. But you really do not believe in the next life, you talk about it, you write volumes about it. If you actually believe, then you must live now rightly, because what you are now, your future will be the same. If you do not change now your future will be the same. This is logical. This is sane.

所以你说会有来世。来世不过是旧模式的延续，或许只是换了个环境。如果你相信来世，那么你现在就必须好好生活——在道德上、伦理上，并且保持谦逊。但你其实并不相信来世，你只是谈论它，写了很多关于它的文章。如果你真的相信，那么你现在就必须好好生活，因为你现在的样子，决定了你的未来。如果你现在不改变，你的未来也不会改变。这合乎逻辑，也合乎理智。

For us, death is total ending, the ending of your attachment, ending all that you have collected. You cannot take it with you. You may like to have it until the last minute, but you cannot possibly take it with you. We have divided life into dying and living, and this division has brought about great fear. Out of that fear we invent all kinds of theories that are very comforting; they may be illusory, but they are very comforting. Illusions are comfortably neurotic. But is it possible, as we live, to die to things that we are attached to? If I am attached to my reputation, and death is coming along, I am getting older and I am frightened, because I am going to lose everything. So can I be totally free of the image, of the reputation, that people have given me? So that I am dying as I am living. So the division between the living and dying is not miles apart, it is together. Do you understand the great beauty that each day, or each second, there is no accumulation, no psychological accumulation? You have to accumulate clothes, money, and so on, that’s a different matter, but psychologically there is no accumulation as knowledge, as attachment, saying, “It’s mine.”

对我们而言，死亡是彻底的终结，是所有执念的终结，是所有积累的终结。你无法带走它们。你或许想拥有它们直到最后一刻，但你终究无法带走它们。我们将生命划分为生与死，这种划分带来了巨大的恐惧。出于这种恐惧，我们发明了各种各样令人感到安慰的理论；它们或许是虚幻的，但却令人感到安慰。幻觉本身就是一种令人感到舒适的神经质。但是，当我们活着的时候，是否有可能放下我们所执着的事物呢？如果我执着于我的名誉，而死亡即将到来，我渐渐老去，我感到恐惧，因为我将失去一切。那么，我能否彻底摆脱人们赋予我的形象和名誉呢？这样，我便能在活着的同时走向死亡。因此，生与死的界限并非遥远，而是紧密相连。你是否理解，每一天，每一秒，都没有积累，没有心理上的积累，这其中蕴含着多么伟大的美？衣服、金钱等等都需要积累，这是另一回事，但在心理上，积累并不等同于知识的积累，也不等同于依恋，不会说“这是我的”。

Will you do it? Will you actually do this thing so that this conflict between death and living, with all its pain and fear and anxiety, comes totally to an end? So that you are—the brain is—incarnated. Then the brain is being reborn afresh, so that it has tremendous freedom. So, when living, be with death, so that you are a guest in this world, so that you have no roots anywhere, so that you have a brain that is amazingly alive. Because if you carry all the burdens of yesterday, your brain becomes mechanical, dull. If you leave all the psychological memories, hurts, pains, behind, every day, then it means dying and living are together. In that there is no fear.

你会做到吗？你真的会去做这件事吗？这样，生与死之间的冲突，以及随之而来的所有痛苦、恐惧和焦虑，就能彻底终结？这样，你——你的大脑——就能化身为人。然后，大脑就能获得新生，从而拥有巨大的自由。所以，活着的时候，要与死亡同在，这样你才能成为这个世界的过客，才能在任何地方都无根可依，才能拥有一个无比鲜活的大脑。因为如果你背负着昨日的所有重担，你的大脑就会变得机械、迟钝。如果你每天都放下所有的心理记忆、伤痛和痛苦，那就意味着生与死合二为一。在那种状态下，就没有恐惧。

What happens to the person who does not do any of this? Please, this is being said with great humility, with great compassion and affection. I hear from you of a totally different way of living. I see the logic of it, the sanity of it, the clarity of it. I see it intellectually, verbally I have accepted it. But I pursue my old ways, the ways of my life, to which I am accustomed. And I am going to die and I am frightened, as most people are frightened. So I ask what is going to happen? Will I be reborn?

那些不做这一切的人会怎么样呢？请相信，我怀着极大的谦卑、同情和爱意说出这些话。我听你们说起一种截然不同的生活方式。我理解它的逻辑、它的理智、它的清晰。我从理智上理解了它，也从言语上接受了它。但我仍然坚持我过去的方式，我习惯的生活方式。我终将死去，我感到恐惧，就像大多数人一样。所以我问，接下来会发生什么？我会转世重生吗？

My consciousness accepts this old way of life and hopes that perhaps next life it will have a better chance. But is that consciousness, which I have said is “mine,” my consciousness at all? That consciousness is the consciousness of humanity. Each one of us shares this consciousness, so it is not mine. Please, you must question whether your consciousness is your individual consciousness or is shared by all humanity. All humanity goes through what you are going through, in a different environment, in a different ambiance. So you are not actually an individual. You may have a different body from another, you may have a better bank account. One may be lame, one may be healthy, but inwardly your being is shared by all the rest of humanity. Therefore, you are humanity. So as long as you think you are an individual, you are living in illusion, because your consciousness, your life, is shared by everybody on this earth. So when you die, your consciousness, which is shared by all humanity, will continue. And that consciousness manifests itself, through someone, and then he says, “It is mine,” “I am an individual,” “ Atman ,” “soul,” and so on.

我的意识接受了这种旧有的生活方式，并希望来世或许会有更好的机会。但我所说的“我的”意识，真的是我的意识吗？那其实是全人类的意识。我们每个人都共享着这种意识，所以它并非属于我。请你扪心自问，你的意识究竟是你个人的意识，还是全人类共享的意识？全人类都在经历着你所经历的一切，只是身处不同的环境，不同的氛围。所以，你实际上并非一个独立的个体。你的身体或许与他人不同，你的银行存款或许更高。有人或许残疾，有人或许健康，但在你的内在，你的存在与全人类共享。因此，你就是全人类的一部分。所以，只要你认为自己是一个独立的个体，你就活在幻觉之中，因为你的意识，你的生命，与地球上的每个人都共享。所以，当你死去，你那与全人类共享的意识将继续存在。这种意识通过某人显现出来，然后他说：“这是我的”，“我是一个个体”，“阿特曼”，“灵魂”，等等。

So there is a way of living that is totally different. Then you are no longer concerned with dying, but with living—living which contains, which moves with, death. I leave it to you. If you don’t understand, please don’t deny it, find out, question, doubt your own individuality. It is possible to live a life psychologically in which there is never a continual recording, there is the ending of recording. Say you are flattered, or insulted, that is recorded. Now, not to record flattery or insult is to have a brain that is free, not burdened by a thousand records of a thousand yesterdays.

所以，有一种截然不同的生活方式。在这种生活方式中，你不再关注死亡，而是关注活着——一种包含死亡、与死亡共存的活着。这留给你自己去体会。如果你不理解，请不要否认，去探索、去质疑、去怀疑你自己的个性。在心理层面，我们可以过一种生活，在这种生活中，记录永远不会持续，记录终会结束。比如说，你受到奉承或侮辱，这些都会被记录下来。而不再记录奉承或侮辱，意味着你的大脑是自由的，不再被无数个昨天的记录所束缚。

The religions which exist throughout the world accept dogmas, some fantastic beliefs, some meaningless rituals. To find out what religion is, one must doubt the accepted thing, have the vitality, the strength, to wipe it out. One must question, doubt, wipe away all the structure put together by thought. When you question all this, to find out the nature of a religious brain, religious mind, there must be freedom to inquire. If you have a hypothesis, it must be proved under a microscope, or under the clarity of your own attention. If a human being, you, has the intention, the drive, the energy, the passion to find out if there is something sacred, holy, to do that there must be no fear, there must be no sense of anxiety, there must be complete freedom. And that is meditation.

世界上的各种宗教都接受教条，有些是荒诞的信仰，有些是毫无意义的仪式。要探寻宗教的本质，就必须质疑那些被奉为圭臬的事物，拥有将其彻底摧毁的活力和力量。必须质疑、怀疑，并抹去所有由思想构建的结构。当你质疑这一切，探寻宗教思维的本质时，必须拥有探究的自由。如果你有一个假设，就必须在显微镜下，或者在你清晰的注意力下去验证它。如果你，作为一个人，拥有探寻是否存在神圣之物的意愿、动力、能量和热情，那么在进行这项探索时，你必须毫无畏惧，毫无焦虑，必须拥有完全的自由。而这，就是冥想。

Meditation can only be actual, truthful, honest, when there is no fear, no hurt, no anxiety, no sorrow. Meditation can only take place when there is no conscious effort made to meditate. I am afraid it goes against everything you believe.

只有当心中没有恐惧、没有伤痛、没有焦虑、没有悲伤时，冥想才能是真实的、真诚的、坦率的。冥想只能在不刻意追求冥想的情况下发生。恐怕这与你的所有信念都背道而驰。

How do you come upon that which is sacred? Is there anything sacred? Man has sought throughout the ages something beyond. From the times of the ancient Sumerians, the Egyptians, Romans, people have sought. And they worshiped light, worshiped the sun, worshiped the tree, worshiped the mother, never finding anything. So can we together discover or rather, come upon, that thing which is most holy?

如何才能触及神圣之物？世间真的存在神圣之物吗？千百年来，人类一直在追寻超越尘世的事物。从古苏美尔人、埃及人、罗马人开始，人们便一直在寻觅。他们崇拜光明，崇拜太阳，崇拜树木，崇拜母亲，却始终一无所获。那么，我们能否共同发现，或者说，找到，那至圣之物呢？

That can only take place when there is absolute silence, when the brain is absolutely quiet. You can discover for yourself—if you are attentive, watchful, watchful of your words, the meaning of the words, never saying one thing and doing anther, if you are watchful all the time—that the brain has its own natural rhythm. But upon that natural rhythm thought has placed all kinds of things. For us, knowledge is tremendously important. To do anything physical requires knowledge, but psychological knowledge, the knowledge you have accumulated about your hurts, about your vanity, your arrogance, your ambition, all that knowledge is you. And with that knowledge we try to find out if there is anything most holy. You can never find out through knowledge, because knowledge is limited, and it will always be—physically, technologically, and psychologically.

只有在绝对的寂静中，当大脑完全安静下来时，这种情况才会发生。如果你足够专注、警觉，注意自己的言辞和言辞的含义，言行一致，时刻保持警觉，你就能亲身发现，大脑拥有其自身的自然节奏。然而，思想却将各种各样的东西强加于这种自然节奏之上。对我们而言，知识至关重要。任何体力活动都需要知识，而心理知识，你积累的关于自身伤痛、虚荣、傲慢、野心的知识，所有这些知识构成了你。我们试图通过这些知识去探寻是否存在至圣之物。你永远无法仅凭知识找到答案，因为知识是有限的，而且永远如此——无论从物质层面、技术层面还是心理层面来看都是如此。

So the brain must be absolutely quiet, not through control, not through following some method, system, not by cultivating silence. Silence implies space. Have you noticed how little space we have in our brain? It is cluttered up, full with so many thousands of things; it has very little space. And for silence there must be space because that which is immeasurable, that which is unnameable, cannot exist or be perceived or seen by a narrow little brain. If you take a journey into yourself, empty all the content that you have collected and go very, very deeply, then there is that vast space, that so-called emptiness, that is full of energy.

所以，大脑必须绝对安静，不是通过控制，不是通过遵循某种方法或系统，也不是通过刻意培养安静。安静意味着空间。你有没有注意到我们的大脑空间有多么有限？它杂乱不堪，塞满了成千上万的东西；它几乎没有空间。而安静需要空间，因为那不可衡量、不可名状的事物，无法被狭隘的大脑所感知或理解。如果你进行一次自我探索之旅，清空你积累的所有信息，深入内心，那么你就会发现那片广阔的空间，那所谓的空无，其中充满了能量。

And in that state alone there is that which is most sacred, most holy.

只有在那种状态下，才存在着最神圣、最纯洁的东西。

New Delhi, November 13, 1983

新德里，1983年11月13日

#↩

TRUTH MOST HOLY

至圣真理

1

We are going to talk together about the whole of our existence—from the moment we are born until we die. In that period of time, whether it be fifty years, ninety years, or a hundred years, we go through all kinds of problems and difficulties. We have economic, social, and religious problems, problems of personal relationship, problems of individual fulfillment, wanting to find roots in some place or other. We have innumerable psychological wounds, fears, pleasures, sensations. There is a great deal of fear in all human beings, a great deal of anxiety, uncertainty; and there is the pursuit of pleasure. All human beings on this beautiful earth suffer a great deal of pain, loneliness. We are going to talk about all that together, and about what place religion has in modern life. We are also going to talk over together the question of death, what is a religious mind, and what is meditation. Is there anything that is beyond thought and is there anything sacred in life, or is everything matter, so that we lead only a materialistic life?

我们将一起探讨我们存在的方方面面——从出生到死亡。在这段时间里，无论是五十年、九十年还是一百年，我们都会经历各种各样的问题和困难。我们有经济问题、社会问题、宗教问题，有人际关系问题，有个人实现自我价值的问题，渴望在某个地方找到归属感。我们有无数的心理创伤、恐惧、快乐和感受。所有人类都充满恐惧、焦虑和不确定感；同时，我们也追求快乐。这颗美丽地球上的所有人类都承受着巨大的痛苦和孤独。我们将一起探讨这一切，以及宗教在现代生活中的地位。我们还将一起探讨死亡的问题，什么是宗教心灵，什么是冥想。是否存在超越思想的事物？生命中是否存在神圣之物？或者一切都只是物质，以至于我们只能过着物质主义的生活？

This is a conversation between you and the speaker in which there is no implication of conversion, or propaganda, or of introducing new theories, ideas, and exotic nonsense. That would be too terrible. We are going to, if you will kindly, talk over together our problems as two friends. Though we don’t know each other, we are going to talk, discuss, have a conversation—which is much more important than being lectured at or being told what to do, what to believe, what to have faith in, and so on. On the contrary, we are going to observe dispassionately, impersonally, not anchored to any particular problem or theory, what mankind has done to the world and what we have done to each other. We are going to take a very long, complex journey together, and it is your responsibility, as well as that of the speaker, that we walk together, investigate together, look together at the world we have created.

这是你和演讲者之间的对话，其中不涉及任何皈依、宣传，或引入新的理论、思想和奇谈怪论。那样做太糟糕了。我们，请允许，像两个朋友一样，一起探讨我们的问题。虽然我们彼此并不认识，但我们会交谈、讨论、对话——这远比被说教或被告知该做什么、该相信什么、该信仰什么等等重要得多。相反，我们将以冷静客观、不带个人偏见的视角，不执着于任何特定的问题或理论，来观察人类对世界所做的一切，以及我们彼此之间所做的一切。我们将共同踏上一段漫长而复杂的旅程，而你和演讲者都有责任携手同行，共同探索，共同审视我们创造的世界。

The society in which we live is put together by man. Each one of us has contributed to it. Life is very complex. We like to look at complexity and get more and more complex. We never look at anything simply, with our brains, with our hearts, with our whole being. We have lived on this earth for many millennia, and during those long periods of time mankind has suffered loneliness, despair, uncertainty, confusion, multiple choices and, therefore, multiple complexities. There have been wars—not only physical bloody wars but also psychological wars. And mankind has asked if there can be peace on earth. But apparently this has not been possible. There are about forty wars going on at the present time, ideological, theoretical, economic, social. During historical times, perhaps about five thousand to six thousand years, there have been wars practically every year. We are preparing for wars now. Two ideologies, the communist and the so-called democratic, are at war over what kind of implements we should use, control of armaments. War seems to be the common lot of mankind. One observes all over the world the piling up of armaments, from the tiny little nation or tribe to the highly sophisticated affluent society like yours. How can we have peace on earth? Is it at all possible?

我们所生活的社会是由人类构建的。我们每个人都为此做出了贡献。生活极其复杂。我们喜欢探索复杂性，并让复杂性不断加剧。我们从未用简单的眼光去看待任何事物，用我们的大脑，用我们的心灵，用我们的整个身心去感受。我们在地球上生活了数千年，在这漫长的岁月中，人类饱受孤独、绝望、迷茫、困惑、多重选择之苦，因此也经历了多重复杂性。战争层出不穷——不仅是血腥的肉体战争，还有心理战。人类一直在问，地球上是否能够实现和平。但显然，这是不可能的。目前大约有四十场战争正在进行，涉及意识形态、理论、经济和社会等各个方面。在历史长河中，或许长达五六千年，几乎每年都有战争发生。我们现在正在为战争做准备。共产主义和所谓的民主两种意识形态正在就我们应该使用何种武器、如何控制军备展开争论。战争似乎已成为人类的共同命运。从偏远的小国或部落到像你们这样高度发达的富裕社会，世界各地都在堆积军备。我们如何才能实现世界和平？这真的可能吗？

It has been said that there is no peace on earth, only in heaven. This is repeated in different ways, both in the East and the West. Christians have killed more than anybody else on earth. We are observing these facts, these actualities, not taking sides. And then there are the different religions. In Buddhism there is no god; in Hinduism somebody calculated that there are about three hundred thousand gods—that’s rather fun, you can choose whichever god you like. In Christianity and Islam there is only one god, based on two books, the Bible and the Koran. So religions have divided man, just as nationalism, which is a glorified form of tribalism, has divided man, so has religious ardor. Fundamentalists in India, here, and in Europe, are reviving their religious traditions. I wonder if you have ever looked at the word reviving ? You can only revive something that is dead or dying. You can’t revive a living thing.

有人说，世间没有和平，只有天堂才有和平。这种说法在东方和西方都以不同的方式被反复提及。基督徒杀的人比地球上任何其他群体都多。我们只是在观察这些事实，这些现实，而不是偏袒任何一方。此外，还有不同的宗教。佛教没有神；印度教有人计算过大约有三十万个神——这很有趣，你可以选择任何你喜欢的神。基督教和伊斯兰教只有一个神，其依据是两部经典：《圣经》和《古兰经》。因此，宗教分裂了人类，正如民族主义（一种美化形式的部落主义）分裂了人类一样，宗教狂热也是如此。在印度、这里以及欧洲，原教旨主义者正在复兴他们的宗教传统。我不知道你是否仔细思考过“复兴”这个词？你只能复活已经死亡或濒临死亡的东西。你不可能复活一个活着的东西。

Man has always been in conflict. Everyone in this world goes through all kinds of misery, all kinds of sorrow, pain, desperate loneliness; and we long to escape from all that. We are observing together this extraordinary phenomenon: how man, after these thousands of years, still remains a barbarian—cruel, vulgar, full of anxiety and hatred. Violence is increasing in the world, so one asks if there can be peace on this earth, because without peace, inwardly, psychologically, the brain cannot flower; human beings cannot live completely, holistically.

人类自古以来就处于冲突之中。世间每个人都会经历各种各样的苦难、悲伤、痛苦和绝望的孤独；而我们渴望逃离这一切。我们共同见证着这一非凡的现象：历经数千年，人类依然野蛮——残忍、粗俗、充满焦虑和仇恨。世界上的暴力与日俱增，不禁让人质疑，这世间是否还能有和平？因为没有和平，内心深处，精神层面，大脑就无法蓬勃发展；人类也无法完整、全面地生活。

Why are we human beings, after this long evolution in which we have gathered immense experience, knowledge, a great deal of information, still perpetually in conflict? That’s the real question. Because when there is no conflict there is naturally peace. Without getting angry or irritated with what we are investigating together it is the responsibility of men and women to inquire, not merely intellectually, verbally, but with your hearts, with your brains, with all your being, and find out why we are what we are.

经历了漫长的进化，积累了丰富的经验、知识和信息之后，我们人类为何仍然深陷冲突之中？这才是真正的问题所在。因为没有冲突，自然就有和平。我们不应因共同探究而感到愤怒或烦躁，而应用心、用脑、用全部身心去探寻我们存在的意义。

We have tried various religions, various economic and social systems, and yet we live in conflict. Can this conflict in each one of us end—completely, not partially, not occasionally? It’s a very serious question. It demands a serious answer. Why do human beings, including you, and the speaker perhaps, live in perpetual conflict, with problems and divisions? Why have we divided the world into nationalities, religious groups, social behaviors? Can we seriously inquire into whether it is possible to end conflict? First psychologically, inwardly, because if there is a certain quality of freedom inwardly, then we shall produce a society in which there will be no conflict. It is our responsibility as human beings, as so-called individuals, seriously to put our brains, our energy, our passion, into discovering for ourselves—not according to any philosopher or psychiatrist, but find out for ourselves—whether this conflict between human beings can end.

我们尝试过各种宗教、各种经济和社会制度，却依然生活在冲突之中。我们每个人内心的这种冲突能否彻底结束——不是部分结束，也不是偶尔结束？这是一个非常严肃的问题，需要认真的回答。为什么人类，包括你我，或许也包括我，总是生活在永恒的冲突、问题和分裂之中？为什么我们将世界划分成不同的民族、宗教团体和社会行为？我们能否认真探究一下，冲突是否有可能终结？首先，从心理层面，从内心层面，因为如果内心拥有某种程度的自由，我们就能创造一个没有冲突的社会。作为人类，作为所谓的个体，我们有责任认真地运用我们的智慧、精力和热情，去探寻——不是照搬任何哲学家或精神病学家的理论，而是自己去发现——人类之间的这种冲突是否能够终结。

What is conflict? Why have we lived with conflict? Why have we problems? Please inquire with the speaker into these questions. What is a problem? The etymological meaning of that word is “something thrown at you,” a challenge, something you have to answer. When you are a child, you are sent to school, where you have the problems of writing, mathematics, history, science, chemistry, and so on. So from childhood you are trained to have problems. Look at it carefully. Your brain is conditioned, trained, educated to have problems. Observe it for yourself. We are together investigating, looking into the problems that we have. From childhood we are trained, educated, conditioned to have problems. And when new problems arise, as they inevitably do, it is our brains, full of problems, that try to solve them and thereby increase them, which is what is happening in the world. The politicians all over the world are increasing problem after problem. And they have found no answers.

什么是冲突？我们为何生活在冲突之中？我们为何会面临诸多问题？请与演讲者探讨这些问题。什么是问题？从词源学上看，问题指的是“抛向你的事物”，一种挑战，你必须面对的难题。当你还是个孩子时，你会被送去学校，在那里你会遇到写作、数学、历史、科学、化学等等各种问题。因此，从孩提时代起，你就被训练成去面对问题。仔细想想，你的大脑已经被训练、被教育成去面对问题。你自己观察一下就知道了。我们共同探索、审视着我们面临的问题。从孩提时代起，我们就被训练、被教育成去面对问题。而当新的问题出现时——它们不可避免地会出现——正是我们充满问题的大脑试图解决它们，结果却适得其反，使问题更加复杂，这正是当今世界正在发生的事情。世界各地的政客们不断地制造问题，却始终找不到答案。

Is it possible to have a brain that is free, so that you can solve problems, instead of a brain cluttered with problems? Is that possible? If you say it is or is not possible, you have stopped investigating. What is important in this inquiry is that one must have a great deal of doubt, skepticism, never accepting anything at its face value or according to pleasure or gratification. Life is much too serious.

是否有可能拥有一个自由的大脑，从而能够解决问题，而不是被问题所困扰？这有可能吗？如果你断言这有可能或不可能，那就意味着你已经停止了探索。这项探索的关键在于，我们必须保持高度的怀疑和批判精神，永远不要轻信表面现象，也不要为了满足自己的欲望或满足感而接受任何事物。人生太过严肃。

We should inquire not only into the nature of conflict and problems, but also perhaps into something which may be much more important: all over the world, go where you will, every human being on this earth goes through all kinds of sorrow. Millions have had tears, and occasional laughter. Like you, every human being on this earth has had great loneliness, despair, anxiety, has been confused, uncertain. Psychologically, this is a fact, an actuality. This is observable; you can see it on every face on this earth. And so psychologically you are the rest of mankind. You may be tall, short, black, or white, but psychologically you are mankind. Please understand this—not intellectually or ideologically or as a hypothesis, but as an actuality, a burning reality—that you psychologically are the rest of mankind. Therefore, psychologically you are not individuals. Although religions, except perhaps parts of Hinduism and Buddhism, have entertained, encouraged, the sense of individual growth, of saving individual souls and all that business, in actuality your consciousness is not yours. It is the rest of mankind’s, because we all go through the same mill, the same endless conflict. When you realize this, not emotionally, not as an intellectual concept but as something actual, real, true, then you will not kill another human being. You will never kill another, either verbally or intellectually, ideologically or physically, because then you are killing yourself.

我们不仅应该探究冲突和问题的本质，或许还应该探究一些更为重要的问题：无论你走到世界何处，地球上的每个人都会经历各种各样的悲伤。数以百万计的人流过泪，偶尔也会欢笑。就像你一样，地球上的每个人都经历过巨大的孤独、绝望、焦虑，都曾感到困惑和迷茫。从心理学角度来看，这是一个事实，一个客观存在的现象。这是可以观察到的；你可以在地球上每个人的脸上看到这些。因此，从心理学角度来看，你就是全人类。你或许高矮胖瘦，肤色各异，但从心理学角度来看，你就是全人类。请理解这一点——不是从理性的角度，也不是从意识形态的角度，更不是从假设的角度，而是作为一个现实，一个触目惊心的现实——从心理学角度来看，你就是全人类。因此，从心理学角度来看，你并非独立的个体。尽管宗教（或许除了印度教和佛教的部分内容）都提倡、鼓励个人成长、拯救灵魂等等，但实际上，你的意识并不属于你。这是全人类的共同命运，因为我们都经历着同样的磨难，同样的无休止的冲突。当你真正意识到这一点，不是出于情感，也不是出于理性的概念，而是将其视为一种真实的、切实的真理时，你就不会再杀害他人。你永远不会再以任何方式——无论是言语上的、理性上的、意识形态上的还是肉体上的——去杀害他人，因为那样你就是在杀死自己。

But individuality has been encouraged all over the world. Each one is struggling for himself, his success, his fulfillment, his achievement, pursuing his desires and creating havoc in the world. Please understand this very carefully. We are not saying that each individual is not important; on the contrary, if you are really concerned with peace—globally, not just in your own little backyard—as most serious people must be concerned, as you are the rest of humanity, that is a great responsibility.

但世界各地都鼓励个人主义。每个人都在为自己、为成功、为满足、为成就而奋斗，追求自己的欲望，却也因此在世界上制造混乱。请务必认真理解这一点。我们并非认为每个人都不重要；恰恰相反，如果你真的关心和平——全球和平，而不仅仅是你家门口的和平——就像大多数严肃的人应该关心的那样，就像你代表着全人类一样，那将是一项重大的责任。

So we must find out for ourselves why human beings have reduced the world to what it is now. What is the cause of all this? Why have we made such a mess of everything we touch? Why is there conflict in our personal relationships? Why is there conflict between your god and the other’s god? We must inquire together into whether it is possible to end conflict. Otherwise we will never have peace in this world. Peace on earth was talked about long before Christianity. Long before Christianity, people worshiped trees, stones, animals, lightning, the sun; there was no sense of “God” because they considered the earth as the mother to be worshiped, to be preserved, spared, not destroyed as we are doing now.

所以我们必须自己去探究，为什么人类会把世界变成如今这般模样。这一切的根源是什么？为什么我们把所触及的一切都搞得一团糟？为什么人际关系中充满冲突？为什么你的神和别人的神之间存在冲突？我们必须共同探究，是否有可能终结冲突。否则，这个世界将永远无法实现和平。早在基督教出现之前，人们就谈论过人间和平。在基督教出现之前，人们崇拜树木、石头、动物、闪电、太阳；那时没有“上帝”的概念，因为他们视大地为母亲，应当敬拜、保护、怜悯，而不是像我们现在这样肆意破坏。

Without agreeing or disagreeing, can all of us look at things as they are; not as you think they are, not from your idea or concept of what is , but just look? Look nonverbally, if that’s possible; that’s much more difficult.

抛开赞同或反对，我们能否都客观地看待事物？不是按照你认为的样子，不是从你对事物的固有观念或概念出发，而是仅仅去看？如果可能的话，尽量用非语言的方式去看；这要困难得多。

First of all, this is the actual world we live in. You cannot possibly escape from it through monasteries, through religious experiences. One must doubt all one’s experiences. Man has done everything on earth possible to run away from the actuality of daily living with all its complexities. Why do we have conflict in relationship between man and woman, sexual division? In this peculiar relationship, the man is pursuing his own ambition, his own greed, his own desires, his own fulfillment, and the woman is doing the same. So there are two ambitious, driving beings, driven by desire, two parallel lines never meeting, except perhaps sexually. How can there be a relationship between two people when each one is pursuing his own desires, ambitions, greeds? In this relationship, because there is this division, there is no love. That word love is spoiled, spat upon, degraded; it has become merely sensuous, pleasurable. Love is not pleasure. Love is not something put together by thought. It is not something dependent on sensation. So how can there be right, true relationship between two people when each one considers his own importance? Self-interest is the beginning of corruption, destruction, whether it be in the politician or the religious man. Self-interest dominates the world and, therefore, there is conflict.

首先，这就是我们所生活的真实世界。你不可能通过修道院或宗教体验逃离它。人必须质疑自己的一切经历。人类竭尽所能地逃避日常生活的现实及其复杂性。为什么男女之间会有冲突，会有性别的分裂？在这种特殊的关系中，男人追求自己的野心、贪婪、欲望和自我实现，女人也一样。于是，两个野心勃勃、充满欲望的人，两条平行线永不相交，或许只有在性方面才会交汇。当每个人都在追求自己的欲望、野心和贪婪时，两个人之间又怎能存在关系呢？在这种关系中，因为存在这种分裂，所以没有爱。“爱”这个词被玷污、被践踏、被贬低；它仅仅变成了感官上的愉悦。爱不是愉悦。爱不是由思想构建的。它不依赖于感觉。如果两个人都只顾自身利益，又怎能建立真正恰当的关系呢？无论是政客还是宗教人士，自私自利都是腐败和毁灭的根源。自私自利主宰着世界，因此冲突不断。

There is separation, as the Jew and the Arab, as the Christian who believes in some savior and the Hindu who doesn’t. There is national division, religious division, individual divisions. Where there is division there must be conflict. That is a law. So we live our daily life in a little circumscribed self, a limited self. Self is always limited and that is the cause of conflict. That is the central core of our struggle, pain, anxiety.

人与人之间存在隔阂，例如犹太人和阿拉伯人，信奉救世主的基督徒和不信奉救世主的印度教徒。存在民族分裂、宗教分裂、个人分裂。哪里有分裂，哪里就必然有冲突。这是一条规律。因此，我们每天都生活在一个狭小、局限的自我之中。自我总是有限的，而这正是冲突的根源。这正是我们挣扎、痛苦和焦虑的核心所在。

One becomes aware of it, as most people must naturally, not because you’re told to or because you read some book of philosophy or psychology, but because it’s an actual fact. Each one is concerned with himself. He lives in a separate world all to himself. And, therefore, there is division between you and another, between you and your religion, between you and your god, between you and your ideologies. So is it possible to understand, not intellectually but deeply, that you are the rest of mankind? Whatever you do, good or bad, affects the rest of mankind because you are mankind.

你会自然而然地意识到这一点，就像大多数人一样，这并非因为有人告诉你应该这样做，也不是因为你读过什么哲学或心理学书籍，而是因为这是一个客观存在的事实。每个人都只关注自身，生活在一个与世隔绝的独立世界里。因此，你与他人之间存在隔阂，你与你的宗教之间存在隔阂，你与你的神之间存在隔阂，你与你的意识形态之间存在隔阂。那么，我们是否有可能真正理解——不是仅仅停留在理性层面，而是深入地理解——你就是全人类的一部分？无论你做什么，无论是好事还是坏事，都会影响到全人类，因为你就是人类的一部分。

Your consciousness is not yours. Your consciousness is made up of its content. Without the content there is no consciousness. Your consciousness, like that of the rest of humanity, is made up of beliefs, fears, faith, gods, personal ambitions. Your whole consciousness is made up of all this, put together by thought.

你的意识并非属于你。你的意识是由其内容构成的。没有内容，就没有意识。你的意识，如同其他所有人的意识一样，由信念、恐惧、信仰、神祇和个人抱负构成。你的整个意识都由所有这些构成，并通过思想将它们组合在一起。

One hopes that we have taken the journey together, that together we are walking the same road, not that you are listening to a series of ideas. We are not pursuing ideas or ideologies, but facing actuality, because in actuality and going beyond that actuality is the truth. And when there is truth it is the most dangerous thing. Truth is very dangerous because it brings a revolution in oneself.

希望我们能携手同行，共同走在同一条路上，而不是仅仅聆听一系列观点。我们不追求理念或意识形态，而是直面现实，因为真理就蕴藏在现实之中，并超越现实。而真理一旦出现，便是最危险的。真理非常危险，因为它会引发一场内在的革命。

Have you ever gone into the question of why we ask questions? Not that you should not, but we are inquiring. Suppose you ask the speaker a question and he answers it; either you accept it or deny it. If it is satisfactory to you according to your conditioning or your background, then you say, “Yes, I agree with you entirely.” Or if you don’t agree, you say, “What nonsense.” But if you begin to inquire into the question itself, is the answer separate from the question? Or does the answer lie in the question itself? The perfume of a flower is the flower. The very flower is the essence of that perfume. But we depend on others so much to be helped, to be encouraged, to solve our problems; therefore, out of our confusion we create authority, the gurus, the priests.

你有没有想过我们为什么要提问？并非说你不应该提问，而是说我们是在探究。假设你问说话者一个问题，他回答了；你要么接受，要么拒绝。如果你的回答符合你的固有观念或背景，你会说：“是的，我完全同意你的观点。”如果你不同意，你会说：“胡说八道！”但如果你开始探究问题本身，答案是否独立于问题之外？或者答案就蕴藏在问题之中？花的香气就是花本身。花本身就是香气的精髓。但我们如此依赖他人来获得帮助、鼓励和解决问题；因此，在困惑之中，我们创造了权威、大师和祭司。

It is good to ask questions. You know, we have lost the art of investigation, discussion, not taking sides but looking at things. It is very complex.

提问是好事。你知道，我们已经失去了调查、讨论、不偏不倚地看待问题的能力。这非常复杂。

We should also ask why, from childhood, we are hurt psychologically. Most of us are wounded psychologically, and from that wound, whether one is conscious of it or not, many of our problems arise. A child is wounded by a scolding, by hearing something ugly, brutal, violent. When you say “I am wounded,” who is it that is wounded? Is it the image that you have built about yourself that is wounded, the psyche? The psyche is the “me” and the me is the image I have built about myself. There is nothing spiritual about it. That’s another ugly word, spiritual . So that image gets hurt and we carry that image right through our life. If one image is not pleasant, we put together another image which is pleasant, encouraging it as worthwhile, significant, giving intellectual meaning to our life.

我们也应该问问自己，为什么我们从童年起就会遭受心理创伤。我们大多数人都有心理创伤，而许多问题都源于这种创伤，无论我们是否意识到这一点。孩子会因为责骂、听到丑陋、残酷、暴力的话语而受伤。当你自称“我受伤了”时，究竟是谁受伤了？是你构建的自我形象，是你的心灵受伤了吗？心灵就是“我”，而“我”就是我构建的自我形象。它与精神层面无关。精神，又是一个令人不快的词。所以，这个自我形象受到了伤害，而我们却带着它走完了人生。如果一个自我形象不愉快，我们就会构建另一个愉快的自我形象，并鼓励它成为有价值的、重要的，赋予我们的人生以理性的意义。

Is it possible to live on this earth not having a single image about anybody—including god, if there is such an entity—no image about your wife and your children and your husband, or anyone? Not to have a single image? Then it is possible never to be hurt.

在这个世界上，是否有可能对任何人——包括上帝（如果真有上帝的话）——没有任何影像记忆？对你的妻子、孩子、丈夫，或者任何人，都没有影像记忆？完全没有影像记忆？如果是这样，就有可能永远不会受到伤害。

Just to observe without any distortion is entirely different from analysis, as you observe your neighbor’s dress, face, how he talks; just to observe, not to criticize, not to evaluate, judge, but to observe. Observe a tree, observe the moon and the swift-running waters. When you so observe then you ask yourself, what is beauty?

纯粹地观察，不带任何偏见，与分析截然不同。就像观察邻居的穿着、容貌、谈吐一样；只是观察，不去批评、不去评价、不去评判，只是观察。观察一棵树，观察月亮和奔流的溪水。当你这样观察时，你会问自己：什么是美？

They talk a great deal about beauty in the magazines: how you must be beautiful, your face, your hair, your complexion. What is beauty? Is beauty in the picture, in the painting, in the strange modern structure? Is beauty in a poem? Is beauty merely in the physical face and body? Have you ever asked this question? If you are an artist or a poet or a literary person, you may describe something very beautiful, paint something that is lovely, write a poem that really stirs your very being. So what is beauty? Have you ever noticed that when you give a nice toy, a complicated toy, to a child who is being naughty, he gets completely absorbed in it and all his naughtiness stops because he is absorbed? Is being absorbed in a poem, in a face, in a picture, beauty? When you look at a marvelous mountain with a cap of eternal snows, its line against the blue sky, for a second the immensity of that mountain drives away the self, the “me,” with all my problems, all my anxiety. In seeing the majesty of the great rocks and the lovely valleys and the rivers, at that moment, that second, the self is not. So the mountain has driven away the self, as the toy quiets the child. That mountain, that river, the depth of the blue valleys, dispel for a second all your problems, all your vanities and anxieties. Then you say, “How beautiful that is.” But is there beauty without being absorbed by something outside? That is, beauty is where the self is not.

杂志上大谈美：你必须美丽，你的脸庞，你的秀发，你的肤色。美究竟是什么？美存在于照片、绘画，还是奇特的现代建筑中？美存在于诗歌中吗？美仅仅存在于容貌和身材上吗？你是否曾思考过这个问题？如果你是一位艺术家、诗人或文学家，你或许能描绘出非常美好的事物，画出令人心醉的画作，写出一首真正触动你灵魂的诗。那么，美究竟是什么？你是否注意到，当你把一个漂亮的玩具，一个复杂的玩具，送给一个调皮的孩子时，他会完全沉浸其中，所有的调皮行为都会停止，因为他被玩具吸引住了？沉浸于诗歌、面容或画作中，就是美吗？当你凝视一座巍峨的雪山，山顶终年积雪覆盖，山峦轮廓映衬着蔚蓝的天空，那一刻，山峰的雄伟壮丽会驱散自我，驱散“我”，驱散我的所有烦恼和焦虑。当你看到巍峨的巨岩、秀丽的山谷和奔腾的河流时，在那一刻，在那一瞬间，自我便不复存在。正如玩具安抚孩童，山峦驱散了自我。那座山，那条河，那深邃的蓝色山谷，瞬间驱散了你所有的烦恼、虚荣和焦虑。然后你会说：“多么美丽啊！”但是，如果不被外在的事物所吸引，美又怎能存在呢？也就是说，美存在于自我不在其中的地方。

So beauty is when the self is not. That requires great meditation, great inquiry, a tremendous sense of discipline. The word discipline means the disciple who is learning from the master; learning , not disciplining as in conforming, imitating, adjusting. Learning brings its own tremendous discipline, and for an inward sense of austerity discipline is necessary.

所以，美在于放下自我。这需要深思熟虑、深入探究，以及极强的自律。这里的“自律”指的是弟子向师父学习的过程；是学习，而非顺从、模仿或调整。学习本身就蕴含着极强的自律，而内在的清净自律是必要的。

We must also inquire carefully into whether it is possible to be free of fear. This is really an important question to ask. I am not asking it for you, but you are asking this of yourself. Is it possible, living in modern society with all the brutality, with all the tremendous violence that is on the increase, to have freedom from fear? What is fear? Humanity has put up with fear, has never been able to solve fear. Never. There are various forms of fear. You may have your own particular fear: fear of death, fear of gods, fear of the devil, fear of your wife, fear of your husband, fear of the politicians. God knows how many fears humanity has. What is fear? Not the mere experience of fear in its multiple forms, but the reality, the actuality, of fear? How is it brought about? Why has humanity, which is each one of us, accepted fear as a way of life—violence on television, violence in our daily life, and the ultimate violence of organized killing, which is called war? Is not fear related to violence? We are inquiring into fear, the actual truth of fear, not the idea of fear. The idea of fear is different from the actuality of fear.

我们还必须认真探究是否有可能摆脱恐惧。这的确是一个至关重要的问题。我不是在替你问这个问题，而是你在问自己。生活在现代社会，面对种种残酷和日益猖獗的暴力，我们是否有可能摆脱恐惧？恐惧究竟是什么？人类一直忍受着恐惧，却从未真正战胜过它。恐惧有多种形式。你或许有自己独特的恐惧：害怕死亡，害怕神明，害怕魔鬼，害怕妻子，害怕丈夫，害怕政客。天知道人类究竟有多少恐惧。恐惧究竟是什么？不仅仅是体验各种形式的恐惧，而是恐惧本身，恐惧的本质？它是如何产生的？为什么人类，也就是我们每个人，会接受恐惧作为一种生活方式——电视上的暴力，日常生活中的暴力，以及被称为战争的终极暴力——有组织的杀戮？恐惧难道不与暴力息息相关吗？我们探究的是恐惧本身，是恐惧的真相，而不是恐惧的概念。恐惧的概念与恐惧的本质截然不同。

So what is fear? How has it come about? What is the relationship of fear to time, to thought? One may be frightened of tomorrow, or of many tomorrows, or have fear of what has happened before, in the past, or be in fear of what is actually going on now. And the fear of death is the ultimate fear. Is fear brought about by time? Someone has done something in the past to hurt you, and the past is time. The future is time. The present is time. So we are asking, is time a central factor of fear? Fear has many, many branches, many leaves, but it’s no good trimming the branches. We are asking what the root of fear is; not the multiple forms of fear, because fear is fear. Out of fear you have invented gods, saviors. If you have absolutely no fear psychologically, then there is tremendous relief, a great sense of freedom. You have dropped all the burdens of life.

那么，恐惧究竟是什么？它是如何产生的？恐惧与时间、与思想之间又存在怎样的关系？人们可能害怕明天，也可能害怕许多个明天；可能害怕过去发生的事情；也可能害怕当下正在发生的事情。而对死亡的恐惧则是终极的恐惧。恐惧是由时间造成的吗？过去有人伤害了你，而过去就是时间。未来也是时间。现在也是时间。所以我们要问的是，时间是恐惧的核心因素吗？恐惧有很多分支，很多分支，但修剪这些分支毫无意义。我们要探究的是恐惧的根源是什么；而不是恐惧的各种形式，因为恐惧就是恐惧。出于恐惧，人们创造了神灵，创造了救世主。如果你在心理上完全没有恐惧，那么你就会感到巨大的解脱，一种极大的自由感。你已经卸下了生活中所有的重担。

So we must inquire very seriously, closely, hesitantly, into this question: Is time a factor? Obviously. I have a good job now; I may lose it tomorrow, so I’m frightened. When there is fear, there is jealousy, anxiety, hatred, violence. So time is a factor of fear. Time is a factor and thought is a factor, thinking about what has happened, what might happen. Isn’t thinking a factor in fear? Has thinking brought about fear? One sees that time has brought fear. Time is not only time by the clock, but psychological time, the inward time: “I am going to be—”; “I am not good, but I will be”; “I will get rid of my violence,” which is again the future. All that implies time.

所以我们必须非常认真、仔细、谨慎地探究这个问题：时间是一个因素吗？显然是。我现在有一份好工作；我明天可能就会失去它，所以我很害怕。恐惧会滋生嫉妒、焦虑、仇恨和暴力。因此，时间是恐惧的一个因素。时间是一个因素，思想也是一个因素，思考已经发生的事情和可能发生的事情。思考难道不是恐惧的一个因素吗？思考是否带来了恐惧？我们看到，时间带来了恐惧。时间不仅仅是时钟上的时间，也是心理上的时间，是内在的时间：“我将会——”；“我现在不好，但我会变好”；“我会摆脱我的暴力”，这同样也是对未来的展望。所有这些都蕴含着时间。

Are you prepared for all this? Do you want to go into all this? If you do, I’m rather surprised, because you have all been instructed, informed, you have been told what to do by the psychologists, by the priests, by your leaders; you are always seeking help and finding new ways of being helped. So one has become a slave to others. One is never free to inquire, to stand psychologically completely by oneself.

你们准备好面对这一切了吗？你们想深入了解这一切吗？如果你们真的想，我会很惊讶，因为你们都被心理学家、牧师和你们的领袖们教导、告知，告诉你们该怎么做；你们总是寻求帮助，寻找新的求助方式。于是，你们成了别人的奴隶。你们永远无法自由地探究，无法在心理上完全独立地审视自己。

We are now going to inquire into time. What is time? Apart from the clock, apart from the sunrise and the sunset, apart from the light and the dark, what is time? Please, if you really understand the nature of time inwardly, you will find for yourself an extraordinary sense of having no time at all.

现在我们要探究时间。时间是什么？除了时钟，除了日出日落，除了光明与黑暗，时间究竟是什么？请相信，如果你真正从内心深处理解了时间的本质，你就会发现一种非凡的、仿佛时间不存在的感觉。

Time is the past, time is the future, and time is the present. The whole cycle is time. The past is your background, what you have thought, what you have lived through, your experiences, your conditioning as a Christian, a Hindu, a Buddhist. Without the past you wouldn’t be here. You have been programmed like a computer, repeating, repeating, repeating, for two thousand years, and the Hindus for three to five thousand years. So the past is the present; what you are now is the result of the past. And tomorrow, or a thousand tomorrows, is what you are now, so the future is now. In the now, all time is contained. This is a fact too, an actuality, not a theory. What you are is the result of the past and what you will be tomorrow is what you are now. If I am violent now, tomorrow I will be violent. So tomorrow is in the now, in the present, unless I radically, fundamentally, bring about a mutation. Otherwise I will be what I have been. We have had a long evolution, evolving to what we are now. And if we carry on that game, we will be violent, we will be barbarous the next day. So as all time is contained in the now—which is a fact, an actuality—can there be total mutation now in all our behavior and our way of living, thinking, feeling? Because if we don’t radically, psychologically bring about a mutation, then we will be exactly what we have been in the past. Is it possible to bring about this psychological mutation at all?

时间即过去，时间即未来，时间即现在。整个循环就是时间。过去是你的背景，你的思想，你的经历，你的体验，你作为基督徒、印度教徒或佛教徒的成长经历。没有过去，你就不会存在。你就像一台电脑，被设定程序，两千年来不断重复，印度教徒则被设定程序三到五千年。所以过去即现在；你现在的样子是过去的产物。而明天，或者一千个明天，就是你现在的样子，所以未来就是现在。所有时间都包含在当下。这也是一个事实，一个现实，而非理论。你现在的样子是过去的产物，你明天的样子就是你现在的样子。如果我现在暴力，明天我也会暴力。所以明天就在当下，就在现在，除非我彻底地、根本地带来改变。否则，我依然会是我过去的样子。我们经历了漫长的进化，才演变成现在的样子。如果我们继续这样下去，明天我们就会变得暴力，变得野蛮。既然所有时间都包含在当下——这是一个事实，一个现实——那么，我们所有的行为、生活方式、思维方式和感受方式，能否在当下发生彻底的改变呢？因为如果我们不从根本上、从心理层面进行变革，那么我们就会和过去一模一样。这种心理上的变革究竟是否有可能实现呢？

You know, when you have been going north all your life, following a particular direction, or no direction, just wobbling as most people do, if somebody comes along and tells you most seriously that going north leads nowhere, there is nothing at the end of it, you listen seriously, not only with the hearing of the ear but deeply. “Go east or south,” you are told, and you say, “I will do it.” At that moment you have taken a new turn and there is a mutation. The speaker is making it very simple, but it is a very complex problem: to realize deeply that we have been going on this way for centuries and we have not changed at all. We are still violent, brutal, and all the rest of it. If we actually perceive that, not intellectually or verbally but deeply, then we turn in another direction. At that second there is the mutation in the very brain cells themselves.

你知道，当你一生都在向北走，无论遵循哪个方向，或者漫无目的地游荡，就像大多数人一样，如果有人一本正经地告诉你，向北走是没有尽头的，尽头什么也没有，你会认真地听，不仅仅是用耳朵听，而是要深入地思考。“向东或向南走，”有人告诉你，你会说：“我愿意。”那一刻，你做出了新的选择，发生了改变。说话的人把事情说得很简单，但这却是一个非常复杂的问题：要深刻地意识到，我们几个世纪以来一直这样走着，却丝毫没有改变。我们依然暴力、残暴，等等等等。如果我们真正地、不是用理性或语言，而是用心灵去感知这一点，那么我们就会转向另一个方向。在那一刻，脑细胞本身就发生了改变。

We said time is important because we live by time, but we don’t live time as a whole, which is the present. In the present all time is contained, the future and the past. If I am violent today, I will be violent tomorrow. But can I end that violence today completely, not partially? I can. And is fear brought about by thought? Of course it is. Don’t accept the speaker’s word for it, look at it. I am secure today, but I am frightened of what might happen tomorrow: there might be war, there might be some other catastrophe. So time and thought are the root of fear.

我们说时间很重要，因为我们受时间支配，但我们并没有真正体验完整的时间，也就是当下。当下包含了所有的时间，过去和未来。如果我今天诉诸暴力，明天我依然会诉诸暴力。但我今天能彻底、彻底地停止暴力吗？我可以。恐惧是由思想引起的吗？当然是。不要轻信说话者的说法，要仔细审视。我今天感到安全，但我害怕明天可能发生的事情：可能会有战争，可能会有其他灾难。所以，时间和思想是恐惧的根源。

Now what is thinking? If time and thought are the root of fear—which they are in actuality—what is thinking? Why do we live, act, do everything, on the basis of thought? The marvelous cathedrals of Europe, their beauty, structure, architecture, have been put together by thought. All religions and their paraphernalia, their medieval robes, are put together by thought. All the rituals are contrived, arranged, by thought. And our relationship with each other, man and woman, is based on thought. When you drive a car, it is based on thought. Recognition is thought. So one has to inquire into what thinking is.

那么，思考究竟是什么？如果时间和思考是恐惧的根源——而事实上它们的确如此——那么，思考究竟是什么？为什么我们生活、行动、做一切事情都基于思考？欧洲那些宏伟的大教堂，它们的美丽、结构和建筑，都是由思考构建而成的。所有宗教及其相关物品，包括中世纪的服饰，都是由思考构建而成的。所有的仪式都是由思考设计、安排的。我们彼此之间的关系，男人和女人之间的关系，也是建立在思考之上的。当你开车时，也是基于思考。识别也是一种思考。因此，我们必须探究思考究竟是什么。

Probably very few people have asked this question. The speaker has been asking this question for sixty years. What is thought? If you can find out what is the origin, the beginning of thought, why thought has become so extraordinarily important in our life, there may be in that very inquiry a mutation taking place. So we are asking what is thought, what is thinking? Don’t wait for me to answer. Look at it, observe it.

或许很少有人问过这个问题。而我，六十年来一直在问自己这个问题：什么是思想？如果你能找到思想的起源，思想的开端，以及为什么思想在我们的生活中变得如此重要，那么或许在探究的过程中，某种转变正在发生。所以我们要问的是：什么是思想？什么是思考？别等我回答，自己去观察它，去思考它。

Thinking is the word. The word is important, the sound of the word, the quality of the word, the depth, the beauty of a word. Especially the sound. Thinking is part of memory, isn’t it? If we had no memory at all, would we be able to think? We wouldn’t. Our brain is the instrument of memory—memory of things that have happened, experience, and so on, the whole background of memory. Memory arises from knowledge, from experience. So experience, knowledge, memory, and the response of memory, is thought. This whole process of experiencing, recollecting, holding, becomes our knowledge. Experience is always limited, naturally. Is experience different from the experiencer? Give your brain to this, find out! If there is no experiencer, is there an experience? Of course not. So the experience and the experiencer are the same, like the observer and the observed. The thinker is not separate from his thoughts. The thinker is the thought.

思考即是词语。词语很重要，词语的声音、词语的品质、词语的深度、词语的美感都至关重要。尤其是声音。思考是记忆的一部分，不是吗？如果我们完全没有记忆，我们还能思考吗？当然不能。我们的大脑是记忆的工具——记忆过去发生的事情、经验等等，构成了记忆的整个背景。记忆源于知识，源于经验。因此，经验、知识、记忆以及对记忆的反应，就是思考。体验、回忆、保持的整个过程，最终形成了我们的知识。经验自然总是有限的。经验与体验者有区别吗？不妨思考一下，找出答案！如果没有体验者，经验是否存在？当然不存在。因此，经验与体验者是同一的，就像观察者与被观察者一样。思考者并非与其思想分离。思考者即是思想。

So experience is limited, as you can observe in the scientific world or any other field. They are adding more and more and more every day to their knowledge through experience, through experiments on animals and all that horror that is going on. And that knowledge is limited because it can be added to. So memory is limited. And from that memory thought is limited. So thought, being limited, must invariably bring about conflict. Just see the pattern of it; don’t accept what the speaker is saying. That’s absurd; he is not an authority, he is not a guru. We can observe this fact together, that thought and time are the root of fear. Time and thought are the same, they are not two separate movements. See this fact, this actuality, that time and thought, time-thought, are the root of fear. Just observe it in yourself. Don’t move away from the reality, from the truth that fear is caused by time and thought. Hold it, remain with it, don’t run away from it. It is so. Then it is like holding a precious jewel in your hand. You see all the beauty of that jewel. Then you will see for yourself that fear psychologically completely ends. And when there is no fear you are free. And when there is that total freedom you don’t have gods, rituals, you are a free man.

所以，经验是有限的，正如你在科学界或其他任何领域所观察到的那样。他们每天都在通过经验、动物实验以及所有那些骇人听闻的实验来不断积累知识。而这些知识本身也是有限的，因为它可以被不断补充。记忆也是有限的。而基于记忆的思考也是有限的。因此，思想既然有限，就必然会带来冲突。看看其中的模式；不要接受说话者的观点。那很荒谬；他不是权威，也不是大师。我们可以一起观察到这个事实：思想和时间是恐惧的根源。时间和思想是同一回事，它们不是两个独立的过程。看看这个事实，这个现实：时间和思想，时间-思想，是恐惧的根源。在你自身观察它。不要逃避现实，不要逃避恐惧是由时间和思想引起的这个真理。接受它，与它同在，不要逃避它。事实就是如此。然后，就像手中握着一颗珍贵的宝石。你会看到那颗宝石的所有美丽。然后你就会亲眼看到，恐惧会在心理上彻底消失。当没有恐惧时，你就自由了。当拥有那种完全的自由时，你不再需要神灵，不再需要仪式，你是一个自由的人。

When you yourself become both the teacher and the disciple—disciple being a man who is learning, learning, learning, not accumulating knowledge—then you are an extraordinary human being.

当你自己既是老师又是学生——学生是指不断学习、学习、再学习，而不是积累知识的人——那么你就是一个非凡的人。

Washington, D.C., April 20, 1985

华盛顿特区，1985年4月20日

2

We are going to face the truth of things, not live in delusions. With delusions it is very difficult to observe. If you are deluding yourself and not facing actualities, then it becomes impossible to look at oneself as one is. But we like delusions, illusions, every form of deception, because we are frightened to look at ourselves. To look at ourselves very clearly, accurately, precisely, is only possible in the mirror of relationship; that is the only mirror we have. In the mirror of relationship you see what you are, if you allow yourself to see what you are.

我们要直面真相，而不是活在幻想中。沉浸在幻想中，观察就变得异常困难。如果你自欺欺人，逃避现实，就无法看清真实的自己。但我们却喜欢幻想、错觉，喜欢一切形式的欺骗，因为我们害怕面对真实的自己。只有在关系这面镜子中，我们才能清晰、准确、精准地审视自己；这是我们唯一拥有的镜子。在关系这面镜子中，如果你允许自己去看清真实的自己，你就能看到真实的自己。

We want everlasting pleasure in different ways: sexual, sensory, intellectual, the pleasure of possession, the pleasure of acquiring a great skill, the pleasure one derives from having a great deal of information, knowledge, and the ultimate gratification of what we call “God.” Man has pursued pleasure endlessly, in the name of God, in the name of peace, in the name of ideology. And then there is the pleasure of power, having power over others, political power. Have you noticed that power is an ugly thing, when one dominates another in any form? Power is one of the evil things in life. And pleasure is the other side of the coin of fear. When one understands deeply, profoundly, seriously, the nature of fear, then pleasure is delight, seeing something beautiful, seeing the sunset or the morning light, the dawn, the marvelous colors, the reflection of the sun on the waters. That is delight; but we cultivate that memory as pleasure.

我们渴望以各种方式获得永恒的快乐：性欲的、感官的、智力的；拥有的快乐；掌握高超技能的快乐；拥有大量信息和知识带来的快乐；以及我们称之为“上帝”的终极满足。人类以上帝的名义、以和平的名义、以意识形态的名义，无休止地追求快乐。此外，还有权力的快乐，凌驾于他人之上的权力，政治权力。你是否注意到，权力是一种丑陋的东西，当一个人以任何形式支配他人时？权力是人生中的邪恶之一。而快乐则是恐惧的另一面。当一个人深刻、透彻、认真地理解恐惧的本质时，快乐就变成了喜悦，就像看到美好的事物，看到日落或晨光，看到黎明，看到奇妙的色彩，看到阳光在水面上的倒影。那才是喜悦；但我们却把这种记忆当作快乐来培养。

What is action? We are all so active from morning till night, not only physically but psychologically, the brain everlastingly chattering, going from one thing to another endlessly. During the day and during the night in dreams the brain is never at rest, it is perpetually in motion. What is action, the doing? The very word doing is in the present, it is not having done or “I will do.” Action means the doing now, accurately, completely, holistically, if I can use that word, action that is whole, complete, not partial. When action is based on some ideology, it is not action, is it? It is conformity to a certain pattern that you have established and, therefore, it is incomplete, action according to some memory, some conclusion. If you act according to a certain ideology, pattern, or conclusion, it is incomplete; there is a contradiction in it.

什么是行动？我们从早到晚都如此活跃，不仅在生理上，也在心理上，大脑永不停歇地运转，从一件事跳到另一件事。白天，夜晚在梦中，大脑从未停止过运转，它始终处于运动状态。什么是行动，什么是“做”？“做”这个词本身就意味着当下，它不是“已经做过”或“我将要做”。行动意味着现在就做，准确、完整、全面地做——如果我可以用这个词的话——完整的、彻底的行动，而不是片面的。当行动基于某种意识形态时，它就不是行动，对吗？它只是对你所建立的某种模式的顺从，因此是不完整的，是根据某种记忆或结论而采取的行动。如果你按照某种意识形态、模式或结论行事，那你的行动是不完整的；其中存在矛盾。

Is action related to disorder or to order? We live in disorder, our life is disorderly, confused, contradictory—saying one thing, doing another; thinking one thing and doing quite the opposite. What is order and what is disorder and what is the relationship of action to order and disorder?

行动与混乱还是秩序相关？我们生活在混乱之中，我们的生活杂乱无章、混乱不堪、自相矛盾——言行不一；所想所行截然相反。什么是秩序？什么是混乱？行动与秩序、混乱之间又存在怎样的关系？

What is disorder? Look at the world, if you will; the world is in disorder. Terrible things are happening.
