Very few of us know actually what is happening in the scientific world, in the world of the art of war, all the terrible things that are going on in other countries; the poverty in all countries, the rich and the terribly poor, always the threat of war, one political group against another political group. So there is this tremendous disorder. That is an actuality, not an invention or an illusion. We have created this disorder, because our very living is disorderly. And we are trying to bring about order through the social reforms. Without understanding and bringing about the end of disorder, we try to find order. It is like a confused mind trying to find clarity. A confused mind is a confused mind; it can never find clarity. So can there be an end to disorder in our life, our daily life ?  Not order in heaven or in another place, but in our daily life can there be order? Can there be the end of disorder? When there is the end of disorder there is naturally order. That order is living that is not according to a pattern or mold.

什么是混乱？看看这个世界吧；世界一片混乱。可怕的事情正在发生。我们当中很少有人真正了解科学界、战争艺术界正在发生的事情，以及其他国家正在发生的种种可怕事件；所有国家的贫困，富人和赤贫者，战争的威胁始终存在，各个政治团体之间相互冲突。因此，存在着巨大的混乱。这是现实，而非虚构或幻觉。我们制造了这种混乱，因为我们的生活本身就是混乱的。我们试图通过社会改革来建立秩序。然而，在没有理解并消除混乱的情况下，我们却试图寻找秩序。这就像一个迷茫的头脑试图找到清晰。迷茫的头脑永远无法找到清晰。那么，我们的生活，我们的日常生活，能否终结混乱？不是在天堂或某个地方的秩序，而是在我们日常生活中，能否有秩序？混乱能否终结？当混乱终结时，秩序自然而然就会到来。那是一种不按模式或模子行事的生活秩序。

We are investigating, looking at ourselves and learning about ourselves. Learning is different from acquiring knowledge. If you will please kindly give your attention to this a little bit, learning is an infinite process, a limitless process, whereas knowledge is always limited. And learning implies not only observing visually, optically, but also observing without any distortion, seeing things exactly as they are. That requires the discipline of one who is learning, not the terrible discipline of orthodoxy, tradition, or following certain rules, dictates. It is learning through clear observation, hearing exactly what the other fellow is saying without any distortion. And learning is not accumulative because you are moving. In learning what disorder is in ourselves, order comes about very naturally, easily, unexpectedly. And when there is order, order is virtue. There is no other virtue except complete order; that is complete morality, not some imposed or dictated morality.

我们正在探索、审视自身、了解自身。学习不同于获取知识。请您稍稍留意一下，学习是一个无限的过程，而知识始终是有限的。学习不仅意味着视觉观察，更意味着不带任何偏见地观察，如实地看待事物。这需要学习者自身的自律，而非正统观念、传统或墨守成规的束缚。学习是通过清晰的观察，不带任何偏见地聆听他人的话语。学习并非累积性的，因为你始终在不断进步。在了解自身混乱状态的过程中，秩序会自然而然地、轻松地、出乎意料地出现。而当秩序存在时，秩序本身就是一种美德。除了完全的秩序之外，别无其他美德；这才是完整的道德，而非某种强加的或被强加的道德。

Every human being, whether rich or poor, intellectual or just ordinary laymen like us, goes through every form of suffering. Have you ever looked at people who have cried through centuries? Through thousands of wars? There is immense sorrow in the world. Not that there is not also pleasure, joy, and so on, but in understanding and perhaps ending sorrow we will find something much greater. Can sorrow ever end or is mankind doomed forever to suffer, to suffer not only physically but psychologically? Inwardly we have suffered enormously without perhaps saying a word about it, or crying our hearts out. During all this long evolution of man from the beginning of time until now, every human being on this earth has suffered. Suffering is not merely the loss of someone you think you like or love, but also the suffering of the very poor, the illiterate. If you go to India or other parts of the world, you see people walking miles and miles to go to a school, little girls and little boys. They will never be rich, they will never ride in a car, probably never have a hot bath. They have one sari and that is all. And that is sorrow. And the man who goes by in a car, who looks at this, is in sorrow, if he is at all sensitive, aware. And there is the sorrow of ignorance; not ignorance of writing and literature, and so on, but the sorrow of a man who does not know himself. There are multiple ways of sorrow.

每个人，无论贫富，无论知识分子还是像我们一样的普通人，都会经历各种各样的苦难。你是否曾见过那些历经数百年、饱受数千战火洗礼的人们？世间充满了无尽的悲伤。当然，世间也有快乐、喜悦等等，但当我们理解并最终消除悲伤时，我们会发现更伟大的东西。悲伤是否终将消逝？人类是否注定要永远承受苦难，不仅是肉体上的，更是精神上的？我们内心深处承受着巨大的痛苦，却或许从未诉说，也从未痛哭流涕。从人类诞生之初到今天，在这漫长的进化历程中，地球上的每个人都经历过苦难。苦难不仅仅是失去你所爱之人，也包括那些极度贫困、目不识丁的人们所遭受的苦难。如果你去印度或世界其他地方，你会看到孩子们，尤其是小男孩和小女孩，为了上学要走上好几英里的路。他们永远不会富有，永远不会坐上汽车，或许永远也无法洗上热水澡。她们只有一件纱丽，仅此而已。这就是悲伤。开车路过的人，如果稍有感触，看到这一幕，也会感到悲伤。还有一种悲伤源于无知；并非对文字、文学等等的无知，而是一个不了解自己的人所感受到的悲伤。悲伤有很多种。

Can this sorrow end for each one? There is the sorrow in oneself and the sorrow of the world. There have been thousands of wars, people maimed, appalling cruelty. Every nation on earth has committed cruelties. It is appalling and we’re still perpetuating that cruelty. Cruelty brings enormous sorrow. As human beings, just observing, being aware sensitively of all this, we see sorrow is a terrible thing, and ask if that sorrow can end. Please ask yourself whether sorrow can ever end? Because, as with hatred, when there is sorrow there is no love. When you are suffering, concerned with your own suffering, how can there be love? So one must ask this question, however difficult it is, to find not the answer but the ending of sorrow.

这悲伤能否终结？每个人的悲伤既有自身的，也有世界的。历史上曾发生过无数战争，无数人伤残，无数暴行令人发指。地球上的每个国家都犯下过暴行。这令人震惊，而我们至今仍在延续这种暴行。暴行带来巨大的悲伤。作为人类，我们仅仅是观察，仅仅是敏锐地意识到这一切，我们就会明白悲伤是多么可怕，并会问：这悲伤能否终结？请扪心自问，悲伤真的能够终结吗？因为，如同仇恨一样，悲伤之中便无爱。当你身处痛苦之中，只关注自身的痛苦时，又怎能有爱呢？所以，无论多么艰难，我们都必须提出这个问题，去寻找的不是答案，而是悲伤的终结。

What is sorrow? Is sorrow self-pity? Please, investigate. We’re not saying it is or it is not, we are asking. Is sorrow brought about by self-pity? Is that one of the factors? Is sorrow brought about by loneliness, feeling desperately isolated, and in that isolation having no relationship with anything?

什么是悲伤？悲伤是自怜吗？请探究一番。我们并非断言它是或不是，我们只是在提问。悲伤是由自怜引起的吗？自怜是其中一个因素吗？悲伤是否源于孤独，源于那种极度孤立无援的感觉，以及在这种孤立中与任何事物都失去联系的感觉？

Is sorrow merely an intellectual affair to be rationalized, explained away? Or can one live with it without any desire for comfort? That is, to live with sorrow, not escape from it, not rationalize it, not find some exclusive comfort, some religious or illusory romantic escape, but to live with something that has tremendous significance. Sorrow is not only a physical shock; when one loses one’s son or husband, wife or girl, that is a tremendous biological shock; one is almost paralyzed with it. Can we look at sorrow as it actually is in us, and remain with it, hold it, and not move away from it? Sorrow is not different from the one who suffers. The person who suffers wants to run away, escape, do all kinds of things. But to look at it as you look at a beautiful child, to hold it, never escape from it, then you will see for yourself, if you really look deeply, that there is an end to sorrow. And when there is an end to sorrow, there is passion. Not lust, not sensory stimulation, but passion. Very few have this passion, because we are so consumed with our own griefs, with our own pains, with our own pity and vanity. We have tremendous energy, but we dissipate it by conflict, through fear, through endless chattering about nothing. And passion has tremendous energy. That passion is not stimulated. It doesn’t seek stimulation; it is there, like a burning fire. It only comes when there is the end of sorrow.

悲伤仅仅是需要理性分析、加以解释的理性问题吗？或者，我们能否在不寻求任何慰藉的情况下与悲伤共存？也就是说，与悲伤共存，不逃避，不试图用理性解释，不去寻求某种单一的慰藉，某种宗教的或虚幻的浪漫慰藉，而是与这意义非凡的事物共存。悲伤不仅仅是一种生理上的冲击；当一个人失去儿子、丈夫、妻子或爱人时，那是一种巨大的生理冲击；它几乎让人麻木。我们能否正视悲伤在我们心中的真实状态，与它同在，拥抱它，而不是逃离它？悲伤与受苦之人并无二致。受苦之人想要逃离，想要逃避，想要做各种各样的事情。但是，如果你像看待一个可爱的孩子那样看待悲伤，拥抱它，永远不要逃离它，那么如果你真的深入地观察，你就会明白，悲伤终有尽头。而当悲伤终结之时，激情便会到来。不是欲望，不是感官刺激，而是激情。很少有人拥有这种激情，因为我们都被自己的悲伤、痛苦、怜悯和虚荣所吞噬。我们拥有巨大的能量，却因冲突、恐惧和无休止的闲聊而耗尽。而激情本身就蕴含着巨大的能量。这种激情无需刺激，它不寻求刺激；它就在那里，如同熊熊燃烧的火焰。它只在悲伤消逝之时才会出现。

When you have the ending of this sorrow, it is not personal, because you are the rest of humanity. We all suffer; we all go through loneliness; every human being on this earth, rich or poor, learned or ignorant, goes through tremendous anxieties, conscious or unconscious. Your consciousness is not yours, it is human consciousness. In the content of that consciousness are all your beliefs, your sorrows, your pities, your vanities, your arrogance, your search for power, position. All that is your consciousness, which is shared by all human beings. Therefore, it is not your particular consciousness. And when you really realize that—not verbally or intellectually or theoretically or as a concept, but as an actuality—then you’ll not kill another, hurt another. You will have some other thing which is totally different, of a different dimension altogether.

当你最终走出这悲伤时，这并非针对你个人，因为你与全人类同在。我们都经历苦难；我们都感受孤独；地球上的每一个人，无论贫富，无论学识深浅，都承受着巨大的焦虑，或有意识，或无意识。你的意识并非你独有，而是全人类的意识。这意识的内容包含了你所有的信仰、悲伤、怜悯、虚荣、傲慢，以及对权力和地位的追求。所有这一切，都是全人类共享的意识。因此，它并非你个人的意识。当你真正领悟到这一点——不是用言语、用头脑、用理论或用概念来理解，而是将其视为一种现实——那么你便不会再杀人，不会再伤害他人。你将拥有某种截然不同、完全不同的境界。

What is love? We use the word love so loosely. It has become merely sensuous, sexual; love is identified with pleasure. And to find that perfume one must go into what is not love. Through negation you come to the positive, not the other way round. Through negation of what is not love you come to that which is immensely true, which is love.

什么是爱？我们如此随意地使用“爱”这个词。它已沦为感官的、性欲的象征；爱被等同于享乐。而要找到那份芬芳，就必须深入非爱的领域。否定才能带来肯定，而非反之。否定非爱，才能抵达那无比真谛——爱。

Love is not hate, that is obvious. Love is not vanity, arrogance. Love is not in the hand of power: wanting power, whether over a small child or over a group of people or a nation, surely is not love. Love is not pleasure. Love is not desire. Love is certainly not thought. When you are ambitious, aggressive—as you are all brought up to be successful, to be famous, to be known, which is all so utterly childish—how can there be love?

爱不是恨，这显而易见。爱不是虚荣，不是傲慢。爱不掌握权力：渴望权力，无论是对幼童、对一群人还是对一个国家，都绝非爱。爱不是享乐。爱不是欲望。爱当然也不是思想。当你野心勃勃、咄咄逼人——你们从小就被教育要成功、要出名、要受人瞩目，这一切都如此幼稚——又怎能有爱呢？

So love is something that cannot be invited or cultivated. It comes about naturally, easily, when the other things are not. And in learning about oneself, one comes upon this. Where there is love, there is compassion; and compassion has its own intelligence. That is the supreme form of intelligence, not the intelligence of thought, of cunning and deception. It is only when there is complete love and compassion that there is that excellence of intelligence that is not mechanical.

所以，爱是无法邀请或培养的。当其他事物无法自然而然地产生时，爱便会自然而然地出现。在认识自我的过程中，人们会领悟到这一点。哪里有爱，哪里就有慈悲；而慈悲本身就蕴含着智慧。这才是至高无上的智慧，而非思维、狡诈和欺骗的智慧。只有当爱与慈悲完全存在时，才能拥有那种非机械的卓越智慧。

Shall we talk about death? Are you interested in finding out what death is? What is the meaning of that word death , the dying, the ending? Not only the ending but what happens after death? Does one carry the memories of one’s own life? The whole Asiatic world believes in reincarnation; that is, I die, having led a miserable life, perhaps done a little good here and there, and next life I will be better, I will do more good. It is based on reward and punishment, like everything else in life. And in Christianity there is resurrection, and so on.

我们来谈谈死亡吧？你想了解死亡的本质吗？“死亡”、“垂死”、“终结”这些词究竟意味着什么？不仅是终结，死后又会发生什么？人会保留自己一生的记忆吗？整个亚洲世界都相信轮回转世；也就是说，我死后，或许过着悲惨的生活，也或许做过一些好事，但来世我会变得更好，我会做更多的好事。这和生活中的其他一切一样，都基于奖惩。基督教里也有复活之类的说法。

If we put all that aside for the moment, really put it aside, not cling to one thing or the other, then what is death? What does it mean to die? Not only biologically, physically, but also psychologically. You have acquired all the accumulation of memories, one’s tendencies, skills, idiosyncrasies, the things that one has gathered, whether it be money, knowledge, friendship; and death comes and says, “Sorry, you can’t take anything with you.” What does it mean to die? What is death? How do we inquire into it? I am living, I go along every day; it is routine, mechanical, miserable, happy, unhappy. And death comes, through accident, through disease, through old age, senility. We are frightened of death, we never see the greatness of this extraordinary thing. A child is born, a new human being comes into being. That is an extraordinary event. And that child grows and becomes whatever you have all become, and then dies. Death is also something most extraordinary; it must be; and you won’t see the depth and the greatness of it if you are frightened.

如果我们暂时把这一切都抛诸脑后，真正地抛诸脑后，不执着于任何事物，那么死亡究竟是什么？死亡的意义是什么？不仅是生物学意义上的、生理上的，也包括心理层面。你积累了所有的记忆、倾向、技能、个性，以及你所拥有的一切，无论是金钱、知识还是友谊；而死亡到来，却说：“抱歉，你什么也带不走。”死亡的意义是什么？死亡究竟是什么？我们该如何探究它？我活着，我日复一日地生活；生活单调乏味，机械机械，痛苦、快乐、悲伤交织。死亡会到来，通过意外、疾病、衰老、老年痴呆。我们害怕死亡，我们从未真正领悟到这件非凡之事的伟大。一个孩子出生，一个新的生命诞生。那是一件非凡的事件。这个孩子成长，成为你们所有人最终成为的样子，然后死去。死亡也是一件极其非凡的事情；它必然如此。如果你感到害怕，你就看不到它的深度和伟大之处。

Death means surely the ending of everything, the ending of my relationships, the ending of all the things I have put together in my life, all the knowledge, all the experience. I’ve led an idiotic life, a meaningless life, or I have tried to find intellectually a meaning to life; then death comes and says, “That’s the end.” But I am frightened, it can’t be the end. I’ve got so much, I’ve collected so much, not only furniture or pictures. I identify myself with the furniture or the pictures or the bank account so I am the bank account, the pictures, the furniture. When you identify with something so completely, you are that. I have established roots. I have established a great many things round me. And death comes and makes a clean sweep of all that. So I ask myself, is it possible to live with death all the time? Not at the end of ninety or a hundred years, not at the end of my life but with all my energy, vitality, and all the things that go on, can I live with death all the time? Not commit suicide, I don’t mean that, that’s too silly, but live with death, which means the ending every day of every thing I’ve collected. The ending .

死亡无疑意味着一切的终结，我所有关系的终结，我一生所积累的一切的终结，所有的知识，所有的经验。我曾过着愚蠢的、毫无意义的生活，或者我曾试图在理智上寻找生命的意义；然后死亡来临，说：“一切都结束了。”但我害怕，这不可能是终结。我拥有那么多，我收藏了那么多，不仅仅是家具或照片。我把自己与家具、照片或银行账户等同起来，所以我就是银行账户、照片和家具。当你如此彻底地认同某件事物时，你就是它本身。我扎根于此。我围绕着自己建立了许多东西。而死亡来临，将这一切彻底清除。所以我问自己，是否有可能一直与死亡共存？不是在九十年或一百年后，不是在我生命的尽头，而是在我精力充沛、活力四射、一切都在继续的时候，我能否一直与死亡共存？不是自杀，我不是那个意思，那太傻了，而是与死亡共存，这意味着我所收集的一切，每一天都将终结。终结。

Have you gone into the question of what continuity is and what ending is? That which continues can never renew itself, be reborn. So can I live with death, which means that everything that I have done and collected ends? Ending is more important than continuity. The ending means the beginning of something new. If you merely continue, it is the same pattern being repeated in a different mold. So can I live with death? That means freedom, complete, total, holistic freedom. And in that freedom there is great love and compassion, and that intelligence which has not an end, which is immense.

你是否思考过什么是延续，什么是终结？延续之物永远无法自我更新，无法重生。那么，我能否坦然接受死亡？死亡意味着我所做的一切、所积累的一切都将终结。终结比延续更重要。终结意味着新事物的开始。如果你只是简单地延续，那只是在不同的模具中重复同样的模式。那么，我能否坦然接受死亡？那意味着自由，完全的、彻底的、整体的自由。在那份自由之中，蕴藏着伟大的爱与慈悲，以及那永无止境、浩瀚无垠的智慧。

Man has always sought something beyond all this pain, anxiety, and sorrow. Is there something that is sacred, eternal, that is beyond all the reaches of thought? This has been a question from the most ancient of times. What is sacred? What is that which has no time, that which is incorruptible, that which is nameless, that which has no quality, no limitation, the timeless, the eternal? Is there such a thing? Man has asked this for thousands and thousands of years. So he has worshiped the sun, the earth, nature, the trees, the birds; everything that’s living on this earth man has worshiped since ancient times. The Vedas and the Upanishads never mention God. That which is supreme, they said, is not manifested.

人类始终在苦苦追寻超越痛苦、焦虑和悲伤之外的事物。是否存在某种神圣、永恒、超越一切思维范畴的存在？自古以来，这便是人们一直在追问的问题。何为神圣？何为超越时间、不朽、无名、无属性、无限制、永恒的存在？这样的存在真的存在吗？千百年来，人类一直在探寻这个问题。因此，他们崇拜太阳、大地、自然、树木、飞鸟；自古以来，世间万物都受到人类的崇拜。《吠陀经》和《奥义书》从未提及上帝。他们说，至高无上的存在，是不会显现的。

So are you asking that question too? Are you asking if there is something sacred? Is there something that is not put together by thought, as all organized religions are? What is religion? Not only what is religion, but what is the religious brain, religious mind? To inquire into that deeply, not superficially, there must be total freedom. Not freedom from one thing or the other, but freedom as a whole, per se. Is it possible, living in this ugly world, to be free from pain, sorrow, anxiety, loneliness?

所以你也在问这个问题吗？你在问是否存在神圣之物？是否存在某种并非由思想构建而成的东西，就像所有有组织的宗教一样？宗教是什么？不仅如此，宗教的思维、宗教的思想又是什么？要深入探究这个问题，而非流于表面，就必须拥有完全的自由。不是摆脱某一种或另一种束缚的自由，而是作为一个整体的自由。生活在这个丑陋的世界里，是否有可能摆脱痛苦、悲伤、焦虑和孤独？

If there is order in one’s life, real order, then what is meditation? Is it following certain systems, methods: the Zen method, the Buddhist meditation, the Hindu meditation, and the methods of the latest gurus? If meditation is determined, if it is following a system, a method, practiced day after day, what happens to the human brain? It becomes more and more dull. Is meditation something entirely different? It has nothing whatever to do with method, system, practices; therefore, it can never be mechanical. It can never be conscious meditation. It is like a man consciously wanting money and pursuing money: consciously you meditate, wanting to achieve peace, silence. The man who pursues money, success, power, and the man who pursues so-called spirituality are both the same.

如果生活中存在秩序，真正的秩序，那么冥想又是什么呢？是遵循某些体系或方法吗？比如禅宗、佛教冥想、印度教冥想，以及最新大师们的各种方法？如果冥想是刻板的，是遵循某种体系或方法，日复一日地练习，那么人脑会发生什么变化？它会变得越来越迟钝。冥想难道完全不同吗？它与方法、体系、练习毫无关系；因此，它绝不可能是机械的，也绝不可能是有意识的冥想。这就像一个人有意识地想要金钱并追求金钱一样：有意识地冥想，是为了获得平静和安宁。追求金钱、成功和权力的人，与追求所谓灵性的人，本质上是一样的。

Is there a meditation which is not determined, practiced? There is, but that requires enormous attention. That attention is a flame and that attention is not something that you come to; it is attention now to everything, every word, every gesture, every thought; it is to pay complete attention, not partial. If you are listening partially now, you are not giving complete attention. When you are completely attentive there is no self, there is no limitation.

是否存在一种无需刻意练习的冥想？的确存在，但这需要极大的专注力。这种专注力如同火焰，并非你刻意追求的，而是当下对一切事物、每个字句、每个动作、每个念头的全然关注；它意味着全身心的专注，而非片面的关注。如果你此刻只是片面地聆听，你便没有给予全然的专注。当你全然专注时，自我便不复存在，一切局限也随之消失。

The brain now is full of information, cluttered up, there is no space in it, and one must have space. Space means energy. When there is no space, your energy is very limited. The brain is now so heavily laden with knowledge, with theories, with power, position, so everlastingly in conflict and cluttered up, that it has no space. And freedom, complete freedom, is to have that limitless space. The brain is extraordinarily capable, has infinite capacity, but we have made it small and petty. When there is that space and emptiness and, therefore, immense energy—energy is passion, love and compassion and intelligence—then there is that truth which is most holy, most sacred, that which man has sought from time immemorial. That truth does not lie in any temple, in any mosque, in any church. And it has no path to it except through one’s own understanding of oneself, inquiring, studying, learning. Then there is that which is eternal.

如今，大脑充斥着信息，杂乱不堪，没有一丝空间，而人必须拥有空间。空间意味着能量。没有空间，你的能量就会非常有限。大脑如今承载着如此沉重的知识、理论、权力、地位，永远处于冲突和混乱之中，以至于没有空间。而真正的自由，完全的自由，就在于拥有那无限的空间。大脑拥有非凡的能力，拥有无限的容量，但我们却让它变得狭隘而琐碎。当拥有了那份空间和空灵，从而拥有了巨大的能量——能量是激情、爱、同情和智慧——那时，便能找到那至圣至洁的真理，那是人类自古以来所追寻的。那真理不在任何寺庙、清真寺或教堂里。它没有其他途径，只能通过对自身的理解、探究、学习和探索才能获得。那时，便能找到永恒。

Washington, D.C., April 21, 1985

华盛顿特区，1985年4月21日

#↩

资料来源及致谢

Part 1

第一部分

《我想做的事》：1935 年 10 月 20 日在墨西哥城举行的第一次公开演讲的报告，载于《克里希那穆提文集》第二卷第 221 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

你在寻求什么？：1934 年 6 月 16 日在加利福尼亚州奥海举行的第一次公开演讲的报告，《克里希那穆提文集》第二卷第 52 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

A Dynamic Society: The report of the third public talk at Ojai, California, June 18, 1934, page 62 in volume II of The Collected Works of J. Krishnamurti , © 1991 Krishnamurti Foundation of America.

Living in Ecstasy: The report of the tenth public talk at Ojai, California, June 29, 1934, page 94 in volume II of The Collected Works of J. Krishnamurti , © 1991 Krishnamurti Foundation of America.

生活在狂喜中：1934 年 6 月 29 日在加利福尼亚州奥海举行的第十次公开演讲的报告，《克里希那穆提文集》第二卷第 94 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

To Be a True Human Being: The report of the eleventh public talk at Ojai, California, June 30, 1934, page 99 in volume II of The Collected Works of J. Krishnamurti , © 1991 Krishnamurti Foundation of America.

成为真正的人：1934 年 6 月 30 日在加利福尼亚州奥海举行的第十一次公开演讲的报告，《克里希那穆提文集》第二卷第 99 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

Being Vulnerable to Truth: The report of the twelfth public talk at Ojai, California, July 1, 1934, page 104 in volume II of The Collected Works of J. Krishnamurti , © 1991 Krishnamurti Foundation of America.

易受真理伤害：1934 年 7 月 1 日在加利福尼亚州奥海举行的第十二次公开演讲的报告，《克里希那穆提文集》第二卷第 104 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

Part 3

第三部分

What Is It to Be Serious? From the report of the first public talk at Rajghat, Banaras, India, January 9, 1955, page 259 in volume VIII of The Collected Works of J. Krishnamurti , © 1991 Krishnamurti Foundation of America.

认真是什么？摘自 1955 年 1 月 9 日在印度瓦拉纳西拉杰加特举行的第一次公开演讲的报告，《克里希那穆提文集》第八卷第 259 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

Can We Create a New Culture? From the report of the first public talk in Bombay, February 16, 1955, page 207 in volume VIII of The Collected Works of J. Krishnamurti , © 1991 Krishnamurti Foundation of America.

我们能否创造一种新文化？摘自 1955 年 2 月 16 日在孟买举行的第一次公开演讲的报告，《克里希那穆提文集》第八卷第 207 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

Can You Understand the Fact of Emptiness? From the report of the fifth public talk in Paris, May 7, 1950, page 172 in volume VI of The Collected Works of J. Krishnamurti , © 1991 Krishnamurti Foundation of America.

你能理解空性的事实吗？摘自 1950 年 5 月 7 日在巴黎举行的第五次公开演讲的报告，《克里希那穆提文集》第六卷第 172 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

What Is Our Basic Problem? From the report of the second public talk in Bombay, February 10, 1957, page 239 in volume X of The Collected Works of J. Krishnamurti , © 1991 Krishnamurti Foundation of America.

我们的基本问题是什么？摘自 1957 年 2 月 10 日在孟买举行的第二次公开演讲的报告，《克里希那穆提文集》第十卷第 239 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

How Do You Approach the Problems of Living? From the report of the tenth public talk in Bombay, March 11, 1953, page 241 in volume VII of The Collected Works of J. Krishnamurti , © 1991 Krishnamurti Foundation of America.

你如何看待生活中的问题？摘自 1953 年 3 月 11 日在孟买举行的第十次公开演讲的报告，《克里希那穆提文集》第七卷第 241 页，© 1991 美国克里希那穆提基金会。

What Is the Central Core of Your Thinking? Meetings with students at Brockwood Park School, Hampshire, England; from Beginnings of Learning , © 1975 Krishnamurti Foundation Trust, Ltd.

你思考的核心是什么？与英国汉普郡布罗克伍德公园学校学生的会面；摘自《学习的开端》，© 1975 Krishnamurti Foundation Trust, Ltd.

What Is the Relation Between Krishnamurti’s Teaching and Truth? Meetings with the international trustees of the Krishnamurti Foundations at Ojai, California, in 1977; from The Wholeness of Life , © 1979 Krishnamurti Foundation Trust, Ltd.

克里希那穆提的教义与真理之间有何关系？1977 年在加利福尼亚州奥海与克里希那穆提基金会国际受托人会面；摘自《生命的完整性》，© 1979 克里希那穆提基金会信托有限公司。
